site_title: Starhill Global Reit to sell Tokyo property for 1.88b yen
summary: Starhill Global Reit agreed to sell its Tokyo property for 1.88 billion yen (S$18.9 million), a 39% premium to its latest valuation, and 2.9% premium to its acquisition price. The property, a three-storey retail and office building, has a net lettable area of 8,087 square feet and accounts for 0.5% of the Reit's asset value. The sale is expected to complete early next year, and the Reit's gearing is expected to drop from 36.5% to 36.1%.

images.alt_text: There are fewer people as usual outside Ngee Ann City and along Orchard road on 7 Apr 2020, as Singapore enter Day 1 of 'Circuit breaker' mode to deal with the current coronavirus situation.
CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust reported 21.3 per cent y-o-y growth in tenant sales and 21.9 per cent y-o-y growth in shopper traffic for 9M 2022.

site_title: China to curb shadow banking with draft rules for trust firms
summary: China's banking and insurance regulator has issued draft rules to step up oversight of the $3 trillion trust industry, aiming to reduce financial risks in the shadow banking sector. The new rules, effective in three years, will divide trust companies into three categories and ban "channelling" services and non-standard capital pools. The move is part of Beijing's crackdown on shadow banking, which has provided channels for high-yield but risky investments. The trust industry will be required to align with international standards and prioritize their original businesses of asset management and asset servicing.

images.alt_text: Surveillance cameras are seen outside the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) building in Beijing, China December 13, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer

site_title: The sweet, futile search for productivity
summary: Productivity has been a long-standing quest, with various apps, systems, and philosophies emerging to help individuals stay on track. The search for the "productivity sweet spot" continues, with many people struggling to find a method that works for them. Despite the numerous tools and techniques available, such as the Pomodoro Technique and Notion, individuals like Victoria Song and Terry Toh have found that using multiple apps can lead to frustration. Experts like Lakshmi Ramachandran emphasize the importance of understanding one's own life circumstances and prioritizing personal fulfillment to achieve productivity. A growing movement to combat productivity guilt, fueled by the rise of imposter syndrome, encourages embracing imperfection and trying to do the work, rather than fearing judgment or making mistakes.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Quantum computers and related technologies – such as quantum sensing and cryptography – could revolutionise everyday life.

site_title: Why we should all be reading more fiction
summary: Reading great works of fiction can transport readers to new worlds, times, and minds, fostering a nuanced worldview. Unlike history books, which impose a narrative on events, novels allow readers to experience the story itself, creating a sense of authenticity. Studies have found that reading literary fiction increases empathy, emotional intelligence, and complex worldviews by exposing readers to diverse experiences and cultures. By embracing fiction, readers can develop a more nuanced understanding of the world and its complexities, making it a valuable pursuit for personal growth and development.

images.alt_text: Which books make for great gifts this Christmas? Read our guide.
Waterford crystals are installed onto the Times Square New Year's Eve celebration ball on the roof of One Times Square on Dec 27, 2022 in New York City.
Great writing can transport us and delight us, yes, but it can also open our hearts.

site_title: Pele was the most important football player of all time
summary: Pele, widely regarded as the greatest football player of all time, has passed away at 82. His impact on the sport was immense, expanding the global market and making football a spectacle with billions of fans. Pele's charisma and success helped break the racial divide in the sport, inspiring a global audience and paving the way for modern football. His influence extended beyond the pitch, bringing football to new audiences and introducing it to the US market. As a symbol of hope and inspiration, Pele's legacy will continue to enrich the sport and inspire future generations.

images.alt_text: Pele had been undergoing chemotherapy since he had a tumour removed from his colon in September 2021.

site_title: China to extend FX market trading hours to further internationalise yuan
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced it will extend trading hours for its interbank foreign exchange market to 3 am from 11.30 pm, starting January 3, 2023. The new daily trading hours will be from 9.30 am to 1900 GMT, aiming to cover more trading sessions in Asian, European, and North American markets. This move is expected to facilitate global investors and enhance the attractiveness of yuan-denominated assets.

site_title: Thai Q3 household debt to GDP slows but remains a risk
summary: Thailand's household debt to GDP ratio decreased to 86.8% in Q3, a slowdown from 88.1% in the previous quarter, according to central bank data. The debt amount rose to 14.9 trillion baht, still among Asia's highest. The Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput warned that the high debt level poses a risk to economic recovery, urging the need to bring it down to sustainable levels.

images.alt_text: Exports, a key driver of growth, dropped 5.5 per cent year-on-year in November, and imports rose 8.2 per cent year on year, resulting in a trade surplus of US$0.5 billion in the month, the Bank of Thailand (BOT) said in a statement.

site_title: Oil ends year of wild price swings with second straight annual gain
summary: Oil prices ended 2022 with a second consecutive annual gain, closing the year at $85.91 a barrel for Brent crude and $80.26 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. The year saw significant price swings amid the war in Ukraine, economic concerns, and interest rate hikes. Despite tight supplies, declining fuel consumption due to a deteriorating economic environment is expected to offset the gains in 2023, with forecasters predicting lower oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for February delivery fell by a dollar to settle at US$82.26, down 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Rex International unit to acquire more shares of commercial drone company
summary: Rex International's unit will acquire US$1 million to buy 23,809 new shares in commercial drone company Xer Technologies, increasing its stake from 40% to about 53%. As part of the deal, Xer will become a subsidiary of Rex, with a shareholders' agreement requiring a capital injection of up to S$3 million if the company achieves certain milestones. The acquisition is aimed at further diversifying Rex's business into the drone industry, which has seen significant growth.

images.alt_text: Xer Technologies CEO Kristofer Skantze

site_title: Surging UK energy bills spark tensions among tenants
summary: Britain's cost-of-living crisis has worsened due to soaring energy bills, with the average domestic energy bill doubling over the past 12 months. This has led to inflation reaching its highest level in four decades and created a cost-of-living crisis. Households are forced to make energy-saving measures, such as turning off heating in bedrooms and using electric heaters, leading to tensions among flatmates. Campaigners warn that seven million households will be in fuel poverty this winter, unable to afford heating their homes to an acceptable standard.

images.alt_text: With supply tight, businesses and consumers have been asked to reduce usage.

site_title: China has no new Covid variants as sequencing efforts strengthen
summary: China has not seen the emergence of new Covid-19 variants, according to data from the global consortium Gisaid, which has received nearly 1,000 genetic sequences from infected patients in the past five days. The sequences are all of the Omicron subvariant, with no significant changes that raise concern. China's efforts to track mutations have increased, with a significant jump in sequencing data, and CEO Peter Bogner says the data provides "actionable insights" for adjusting diagnostic kits and vaccines, but does not provide information on the rear-view mirror of past cases and deaths.

site_title: Testing times ahead, so need to stay united: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the nation to stay united as more testing times are expected in 2023. Despite safely weathering the Covid-19 pandemic, the country faces challenges from the year-end travel season and a surge in China. If the situation remains stable, Singapore can lift all remaining restrictions. The government is committed to keeping public housing affordable, with efforts to build more HDB flats.

images.alt_text: Travellers in the transit area at Changi Airport. As air travel with China is progressively restored, MOH will take a cautious approach towards increasing seat capacity on planes, taking into account the overall public health assessment.

site_title: Tesla poised for another delivery record despite demand concerns
summary: Tesla is expected to announce record quarterly deliveries in January, with global fourth-quarter deliveries potentially reaching 420,760 vehicles, according to analyst estimates. Despite concerns over inflation, rising interest rates, and softening demand, the electric vehicle leader is offering a $7,500 discount and 10,000 miles of free Supercharging to clear inventory. The announcement comes as the Inflation Reduction Act restores federal tax credits for certain EVs starting January 1.

site_title: Bahamas regulator holds FTX assets pending delivery to customers, creditors
summary: Bahamas regulators appointed liquidators to wind down FTX's international trading business, holding $3.5 billion in assets pending delivery to customers and creditors. The assets were transferred to digital wallets under the commission's control after FTX filed for US bankruptcy in November. The FTX founders no longer have access to the transferred tokens or frozen assets. The regulators aim to deliver the assets to rightful owners while preventing potential asset misappropriation.

site_title: US: Stocks sink in worst yearly performance since 2008
summary: US stocks closed lower on Friday, December 30, 2022, in their worst annual performance since 2008, as surging inflation and interest rate hikes dented investor sentiment. The market slump follows global shocks such as Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Experts attributed the decline to a combination of factors, including inflation and interest rate hikes, which cooled demand. The year ended on a gloomy note, confirming a "horrible stock market," according to Peter Cardillo of Spartan Capital Securities.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 99.19 points, or 0.30 per cent, at the open to 33,121.61.

site_title: Biden signs US$1.7 trillion government spending bill
summary: US President Joe Biden signed a $1.7 trillion government spending bill, keeping the US government funded through the next fiscal year. The bill includes funding for medical research, veteran healthcare, disaster recovery, and programs combating violence against women. It also provides crucial assistance to Ukraine's war effort. Biden signed the bill while on vacation in the US Virgin Islands, stating that he looks forward to more in 2023.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden delivers a holiday message from the White House in Washington, Dec 22, 2022. Biden will decide if he plans to run for a second term.
To ensure that the government does not run out of funds and shut down at the end of Friday as the legislation is processed, the House has also approved a one-week stopgap bill.

site_title: China faces deluge of Covid deaths in first Lunar New Year without pandemic curbs
summary: China is bracing for a surge in COVID-19 deaths as the Lunar New Year approaches, with predictions of up to 25,000 fatalities per day. The country's sudden abandonment of its "Zero Covid" policy a month ago has led to a lack of accurate data, forcing estimates based on outside research. Daily infections are expected to peak at 3.7 million on January 13, with mortality rates expected to peak around January 23, coinciding with the start of the Lunar New Year festivities.

images.alt_text: Since the earliest days of the pandemic, China has been lambasted for its initial handling of the outbreak, including the transparency of reporting on its scale.

site_title: Covid travel curbs against Chinese visitors ‘discriminatory’: state media
summary: China's state media has criticized Covid-19 testing requirements imposed by countries like Italy, citing them as "discriminatory" against the country. The criticism comes as China has begun to lift its COVID-19 restrictions and is experiencing a surge in infections. The US, South Korea, India, Italy, Japan, and Taiwan have imposed COVID-19 tests for travelers from China, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: A chinese traveller leaves the arrival hall of Rome–Fiumicino International Airport, near Rome, on December 29, 2022 after being tested for the Covid-19 coronavirus. (Photo by Filippo MONTEFORTE / AFP)

site_title: Singapore appoints first government chief sustainability officer
summary: Singapore has appointed its first government chief sustainability officer (GCSO), Lim Tuang Liang, effective January 1, 2023, to drive the country's sustainability efforts under the Singapore Green Plan 2030. Lim will oversee the Public Sector Sustainability Office and Sustainability Partnerships Office, working with public sector agencies and private sector partners to advance the national sustainability agenda. As part of the Green Plan, Singapore aims to attain ambitious sustainability targets in carbon abatement and resource efficiency.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian Investment Authority is working with the Asian Development bank to fund the shutting of a coal power plant 10 to 15 years ahead of the end of its useful life.
Armed with the right tools, each business can have an impact in changing climate concern into climate action.
Harnessing green financing to push the boundaries of innovation

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

The Green SGS (Infra) will be issued under the Singapore Green Bond framework. It is  part of the pipeline of up to S$35 billion of sovereign and public sector green bonds that the government and its statutory boards will issue by 2030.

One major philosophy behind environmental, social and governance (ESG) investing is rooted in the broader role that investors have in society. The idea is that asset managers have an obligation to ensure that capital is directed in a responsible way to opportunities targeting an overall positive effect on society.

site_title: Thai businesses prep for return of Chinese tourists with caution
summary: Thai businesses are cautiously preparing for the return of Chinese tourists, with estimates ranging from 3-5 million visitors in 2023, down from 11.5 million in 2019. The pandemic has left a labor shortage in the tourism industry, with top-end hotels offering bonuses to former employees. Chinese tourists may not bring a significant influx of cash due to pre-paid tour packages, and the industry is still recovering from the crisis. The Thai government has rolled out measures to address labor shortages and develop skills, but a full recovery is expected to take another year.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy might accelerate next year and hit the 3.8 per cent growth if Chinese tourists return, helping offset weakening exports as global demand slows, Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith said earlier this week.

site_title: Hong Kong scraps quarantine rules for international air crews
summary: Hong Kong has scrapped closed-loop quarantine rules for international airline crews, effective immediately. The change allows foreign airline crews to leave quarantine hotels during stopovers and mingle with others outside their bubble, aligning with the rules for ordinary passengers. This move aims to rebuild Hong Kong's aviation hub reputation and comes as the city ends other Covid-related restrictions, including gathering limits and vaccination checks. Flag carrier Cathay Pacific Airways may take up to two years to return to pre-pandemic levels of activity.

site_title: Indonesia to export less palm oil to keep supplies at home
summary: Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil producer, plans to reduce palm oil exports to six times domestic sales, down from eight times, to ensure ample supply during Ramadan and Eid holidays in April. The move aims to maintain domestic production levels, which are expected to be weaker in Q1, and avoid price increases. The change is expected to boost shipments from Malaysia, the second-largest exporter, and drive up palm oil prices in Kuala Lumpur.

images.alt_text: epa09969055 A worker loads freshly harvested palm fruits on a truck at a palm oil plantation in Deli Serdang, North Sumatra, Indonesia, 23 May 2022. Indonesia has lifted the ban on palm oil exports after it had been imposed for weeks to control cooking oil prices in the domestic market.  EPA-EFE/DEDI SINUHAJI

site_title: China regulator asks Futu and UP Fintech to stop soliciting mainland clients
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has ordered online brokerages Futu Holding and UP Fintech Holding to stop soliciting mainland Chinese investors, citing unlawful securities businesses. The CSRC will also ask the brokerages to take corrective measures, such as stopping new business from mainland investors. The move comes after Futu and UP Fintech delayed their Hong Kong listing plans and US-listed shares plummeted. Existing Chinese clients will still be allowed to trade, but new money must not flow into these accounts unlawfully.

site_title: Time for new investors to take an old approach
summary: New investors, particularly young people, who have suffered losses due to big tech, meme stocks, and cryptocurrency market volatility are advised not to lose faith in investing. Instead, they should turn to steadier, proven investment strategies. Short-term speculation has more in common with gambling than investing, and low financial literacy and lack of investment education hinder finding alternative options. Experts suggest adopting a more long-term approach and focusing on steady, reliable investment methods to avoid getting caught up in the volatility of the market.

images.alt_text: clock, money, growth

site_title: Indonesia lifts remaining Covid restrictions
summary: Indonesia has lifted all COVID-19 restrictions, effective immediately, as most Indonesians have antibodies against the disease. President Joko Widodo announced the decision based on the latest infection figures, citing a decline in daily cases and hospitalizations. The country, with over 6.7 million cases and 160,583 fatalities, has a high vaccination rate, with nearly 75% of its population over 6 years old having received two vaccine shots and 68.5 million having had at least one booster injection.

images.alt_text: The policy would benefit Bali, as the resort island depends much on tourism to keep its economy going.

site_title: Bunkers, data and all the big stuff
summary: Vietnam, a key destination for foreign investors, faces "uber risks" in 2023, including the global economic slowdown, US-China decoupling, and potential conflicts in the Taiwan Strait and North Korea. Businesses in the region must navigate these challenges while managing compliance gaps. Executives and risk committees feel like they are on a "war footing," with the added complexity of managing global supply chains. The article emphasizes the need for companies to adapt to these changing circumstances and ensure they are prepared for the big stuff.

images.alt_text: epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

A worker adjusts the Asean flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur. The region's economies are expected to turn in an uneven score card in 2023, based on their levels of exposure to key sectors such as electronics production and commodities trading.

site_title: Remote workers descend on Mexico City and housing prices surge
summary: Remote workers from the US and Europe are increasingly using Airbnb to find long-term rentals in Mexico City, driving up housing costs and displacing residents. The influx of foreigners, particularly Americans, has pushed housing prices higher, with units appearing on Airbnb at rates four times the monthly rent. This has upended the fabric of neighborhoods, with long-time residents being told their leases won't be renewed, and new neighbors, mostly speaking English, moving in. The surge in remote workers has caused a housing crisis in the city, with many residents struggling to afford the rising costs.

images.alt_text: Visitors of Tepoztlan can also stay in holistic centers offering yoga and meditation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's power grid vendor SP Group attributes the recent price revisions to lower energy costs compared to the last quarter. Electricity tariffs are expected to fall by an average 0.79 Singapore cent per kilowatt-hour (kWh) or 2.7% between Jan 1 and Mar 31, resulting in lower household electricity bills.

site_title: Lower household electricity bills in Q1 next year as tariffs fall
summary: Singapore's power grid vendor SP Group announced that electricity tariffs will fall by an average 0.79 Singapore cents per kilowatt-hour (kWh), or 2.7%, from Jan 1 to Mar 31. This results in a decrease of 2.63 Singapore dollars per month for households living in HDB four-room flats before Goods and Services Tax (GST). The price revisions are attributed to lower energy costs compared to the last quarter. The Electricity industry regulator, Energy Market Authority, sets guidelines for quarterly tariff reviews.

site_title: Japfa unit AustAsia ends first day of trading just under offer price; S&P downgrades Indonesia unit
summary: Japfa's China-focused milk business unit AustAsia ended its first day of trading at HK$6.37, HK$0.03 below the offer price of HK$6.40. The company sold 30.6 million shares, with international offer shares receiving 1.16 times applications and Hong Kong offer shares 2.08 times subscribed. Following the listing, S&P Global Ratings downgraded Japfa Comfeed Indonesia due to the company's listing.

images.alt_text: 印尼佳发公司希望掌握新兴亚洲市场快速发展的牛奶行业。 （印尼佳发公司提供）

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by a positive US market session the previous day, where US jobless data showed signs of economic cooling. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 10.62 points to 3,259.86 points. 30.4 million shares worth S$29.7 million changed hands, with winners outnumbering losers 90 to 27.

images.alt_text: Trading of Japfa's diary unit AustAsia Group on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong starts on Friday.

site_title: Australians spend big as Christmas shopping hits record
summary: Australians spent a record-breaking A$74.5 billion in the run-up to Christmas, a 8.6% surge from last year, driven by rising prices and soaring interest rates. Trading on Boxing Day hit a record 15.3% growth from a year ago. Despite economic turbulence, consumers continued to spend, with inflation likely a key factor. The spending figures will influence Australia's monetary policy outlook as the central bank tries to slow demand to tame inflation.

site_title: Coal, gas lead 2022 commodities rally; recession fears greet New Year
summary: Commodity markets ended 2022 with strong gains, driven by a global energy crisis triggered by the Russia-Ukraine war. Coal and natural gas prices soared, with Newcastle coal futures rising 140% and US gas futures jumping 20%. Industrial metals, including iron ore and rubber, declined, while agricultural markets, including grains and palm oil, reached all-time highs. Despite recession fears and a potential European cap on gas prices, Goldman Sachs predicts commodities will remain the best-performing asset class in 2023.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - This aerial photo taken on July 21, 2022 shows a bucket wheel machine tranferring coal at a coal storage centre in Jiujiang, in China's central Jiangxi province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
Iron ore’s most-traded May contract on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange has ended daytime trade 0.2 per cent lower at 825 yuan (S$159) a tonne.

site_title: Hot stock: Japfa slides 33.6% to S$0.355, lowest since 2015
summary: Japfa's shares plummet 33.6% to S$0.355 after spinning off its dairy business in a Hong Kong Exchange listing. The company now has two distinct agri-food businesses: animal proteins and dairy, which may unlock value for shareholders. Japfa's CEO, Tan Yong Nang, stated that shareholders will participate in these businesses, each with a clear focus, strategy, and financial flexibility to grow in their respective Asian markets.

site_title: FTX Japan to return assets to clients from February
summary: FTX Japan plans to return customer assets from February. The company is developing a system to allow customers to withdraw assets through Liquid Japan's website, following the prolonged suspension of services. FTX Japan apologized for the trouble caused and cited the US bankruptcy filing and founder Sam Bankman-Fried's resignation as the reason. The move comes as the crypto industry faces calls for tighter regulation.

site_title: South Korea inflation stays elevated, paving way for more tightening
summary: South Korea's inflation remained elevated in December, staying at 5% from a year earlier, matching November's pace. The Bank of Korea (BOK) is expected to raise its benchmark rate to 3.5% in January, with some board members seeing this level as the terminal rate. The country's inflation has been driven by pent-up consumption and costlier imports, with rising borrowing costs worldwide posing risks to economic growth. The BOK aims to engineer a soft landing for the economy while keeping inflation in check.

images.alt_text: The retail sales index fell 1.8 per cent in November.

site_title: 2022 has been a year of brutal inflation
summary: The world experienced a year of brutal inflation in 2022, with consumer prices rising by 7% in the US and 10% in Germany, the highest in four decades and since the 1980s respectively. This unprecedented inflation rate is expected to improve in 2023, but at a severe cost to economic growth, as central banks may need to raise interest rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The biggest and most welcome surprise of the year has been the resilience of broadly liberal countries in the West.
The Fed and other major central banks are intent on fighting inflation
Will the US economy achieve a “soft landing” or will additional supply shocks and political pressures lead to stagflation and a painful and prolonged recession?

site_title: MicroStrategy hit lowest since 2020 after revealing sale
summary: MicroStrategy, a leading corporate buyer of Bitcoin, sold 704 tokens on December 22 for $11.8 million, citing tax purposes. This marks the company's first ever sale of Bitcoin. Despite this, MicroStrategy remains a net buyer of Bitcoin, holding approximately 132,500 coins worth over $4 billion. The company's stock fell 1.1% to $136.63 on December 29, and is down 75% this year. Analysts express concerns about MicroStrategy's high leverage and potential liquidity risk.

images.alt_text: Michael Saylor earlier this year relinquished MicroStrategy CEO role and now serves as executive chairman and still leading its Bitcoin strategy.

site_title: Toshiba bidder JIP still hasn’t secured firm commitments from lenders, sources say
summary: Toshiba's preferred bidder, Japan Industrial Partners (JIP), has failed to secure firm commitments from lenders for its planned 1.4 trillion yen (S$14 billion) acquisition financing as of December 30. Despite ongoing talks, financing is likely to continue into the new year, with discussions focusing on restructuring, governance, and potential dispatch of bank executives to Toshiba. The deal, expected to total at least 2.2 trillion yen, has been delayed, with investors closely watching the outcome.

site_title: Europe’s health officials oppose restrictions on China travel
summary: European health officials oppose restrictions on travel from China, citing high levels of protection against Covid-19 and equipped health systems. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control stated that the strains circulating in China are already present in Europe and the potential for imported infections is low. Despite this, officials remain vigilant and will be ready to use emergency measures if necessary. The European Commission has downplayed the risks, noting that Omicron is already present in Europe and has not significantly grown. Officials are closely monitoring the situation in China.

site_title: Global investors cool towards India’s bad debt reconstruction firms
summary: Global investors are losing interest in India's asset reconstruction companies (ARCs) due to improved bad loan situations and regulatory changes. According to the Reserve Bank of India, only 3.2% of gross non-performing loans were sold to ARCs in the fiscal year ended March 2022, down from 3.8% two years earlier. The decline in sales is attributed to rising costs of acquiring stressed loans and reduced opportunities for global investors like Blackstone and Apollo Global Management.

images.alt_text: The central bank retained its 6.7 per cent inflation forecast for the current fiscal year ending March.

site_title: Gold set for second straight yearly drop
summary: Gold prices are expected to decline for a second straight year due to aggressive interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve, which increased the opportunity cost of holding gold. As the dollar strengthens, gold becomes more expensive for foreign currency holders, leading to a 0.7% annual decline. Spot gold held steady at $1,815.20 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.2% to $1,821.90.

images.alt_text: Gold has risen nearly US$200 from a more than two-year low hit in September.

site_title: Local stocks end final trading session of the year largely flattish
summary: Singapore stocks ended the year largely unchanged, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.1% to 3,251.32. Liquidity was thin, and daily turnover was 711 million securities worth S$536.7 million. The Hang Seng Index and ASX 200 rose 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. Analysts warned of looming threats to capital markets, including inflation, recession, and global tensions, cautioning against premature optimism.

images.alt_text: A woman pushes a door of  Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation's branch in Tokyo April 9, 2009. Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG), Japan's third-largest bank, said it faced a net loss of $3.9 billion in the financial year just ended and would raise up to $8 billion through a share sale.   REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon (JAPAN BUSINESS)
With a drop of more than 20 per cent in 2022, the MSCI All-Country World Index is on track for its worst performance since the 2008 crisis.

site_title: Oil drops on China uncertainty; US demand limits decline
summary: Oil prices fell for a second straight session, with Brent crude futures dropping 1.2% to $82.26 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 0.7% to $78.40 per barrel. The decline comes amid uncertainty over Chinese demand, with countries considering restrictions on Chinese travelers due to rising Covid-19 cases. US crude oil inventories rose unexpectedly last week, but the market remains cautious, with interest rate hikes and geopolitical tensions, such as the Russia-Ukraine conflict, also affecting prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell US$1.07, or 1.3 per cent, to settle at US$83.26 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at US$78.96 per barrel, down 57 cents, or 0.7 per cent.

site_title: SGX, Shenzhen exchange cross-list ETF pair, garnering over S$270m in AUM
summary: SGX-listed ETFs have been cross-listed with the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, with the Southern CSOP CGS-CIMB FTSE Asia Pacific Low Carbon Index ETF being the first SGX-listed ETF directly available in China. The move has garnered over S$270 million in assets under management, boosting SGX's total ETF AUM to S$11.1 billion, with positive inflows of S$125 million in the year to date. This cross-listing allows investors to access Chinese markets through SGX, expanding the exchange's reach and offering exposure to innovative and high-growth companies in China.

images.alt_text: An electronic board shows Shanghai and Shenzhen stock indexes, at the Lujiazui financial district, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China October 25, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: China’s reopening to spur Asean growth, but may also draw equity investors north
summary: China's faster reopening is expected to boost Asia's growth, with Morgan Stanley predicting a 5.1% growth rate for the second half of 2023, up from a trough of 2.5% in Q1 2023. The faster reopening is expected to be a key driver of domestic demand support in Asia and have the largest positive spillover effects to the rest of the continent. Economies in Hong Kong, Thailand, Singapore, and Malaysia are likely to benefit the most, while past Asean winners may underperform due to high valuations relative to North Asia.

images.alt_text: Chinese tourists will no longer need to quarantine on return home starting Jan 8.
Many economists expect a reopening in China only after March next year, when the political reshuffle is finally completed.

Unfinished apartment buildings and construction scaffolding at a housing development in Shanghai, China, on Oct. 30, 2022.  After a year on the sidelines, Beijing has taken steps to get hundreds of billions of dollars into the hands of the countryÕs flailing real estate developers. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)
A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: China central bank promises more policy support for economy
summary: China's central bank has pledged to step up its "prudent" monetary policy to support the economy, aiming to stabilize growth, employment, and prices. The bank will keep liquidity reasonably ample and maintain credit growth, with a focus on domestic demand. To achieve this, it will lower companies' and consumers' financing costs, and guide financial institutions to increase loans to the manufacturing sector. The central bank also plans to enhance the yuan's flexibility while keeping it stable. This move aims to cushion the impact of a surge in Covid infections and a weakening global economy.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) said it would extend trading hours for its interbank foreign exchange market to 3 am (1900 GMT) from 11.30 pm (1530 GMT), according to an online statement.

site_title: Xi appoints China’s US envoy Qin Gang as foreign minister in sign of softer touch
summary: China appointed Qin Gang, its US envoy, as foreign minister, signaling a softer diplomatic approach. Qin, 56, has balanced defending Beijing's interests with a more moderate tone, as seen in his meetings with US leaders and public appearances. The move comes as Xi Jinping pushes to mend ties with the US and its allies, following a decline in public support for China due to its assertive foreign policy. Qin replaces Wang Yi, who is likely to take a top foreign policy position within the Communist Party.

site_title: Football star Pele, Brazilian legend of the beautiful game, dies at 82
summary: Brazilian football legend Pelé, a three-time World Cup winner, has died at 82 due to "multiple organ failures resulting from the progression of colon cancer associated with his previous medical condition." Tributes poured in from around the world, with the government declaring three days of mourning and the US, French, and Brazilian presidents paying their respects. A 24-hour wake and private ceremony will be held in his hometown of Santos, where he rose to fame as a teenager.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former Brazilian soccer star Pele acknowledges the fans during the opening ceremony of the Territorio Santos Modelo stadium in Torreon, Mexico November 11, 2009.  REUTERS/Tomas Bravo/File Photo

site_title: Singapore ready to step up border measures if needed; MOH monitoring situation as China reopens
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) is closely monitoring the global Covid-19 situation as China reopens its borders on January 8, 2023. If necessary, the country will step up border measures. MOH will take a cautious approach to increasing seat capacity on planes from China, considering the overall public health assessment. Despite concerns in other countries, Singapore's local situation remains stable, with no significant increase in infections after the XBB sub-variant wave.

images.alt_text: The State Administration for Market Regulation will stop testing chilled and frozen foods for Covid-19 from Jan 8, according to a notice seen by Reuters and confirmed by the agency.
Beijing’s decision to abruptly remove most pandemic restrictions with little preparation is driving an unprecedented number of cases, leaving hospitals and funeral homes overwhelmed.

A Chinese traveller leaving the arrival hall of Rome–Fiumicino International Airport on Dec 29, after being tested for Covid-19.  Italy is among the countries that have imposed Covid tests for travellers from China.

Vehicles travel along the Third Ring Road in Beijing. Morgan Stanley said China’s faster reopening will be an “additional pillar of domestic demand support in Asia, while also imparting the largest positive spillover effects to the rest of Asia”.

site_title: Global equity funds see outflows for an eighth straight week
summary: Global equity funds experienced their eighth consecutive week of outflows, with investors withdrawing a net $529 million from global equity funds. This marks a decrease from the previous week's outflows of $39.1 billion. The decline in outflows was attributed to a Commerce Department report showing US consumer spending barely rose in November and inflation cooled further.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one hundred dollar notes are seen in this picture illustration taken in Seoul February 7, 2011.   REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won/File Photo

site_title: UK mortgage rates stabilise ahead of pivotal year for housing market
summary: UK mortgage rates have stabilised at 5.79% for a two-year fixed-rate deal, near a 5.8% level, as the housing market braces for a pivotal year. Home prices fell for a fourth consecutive month, the longest downturn since the financial crisis, with economists predicting a 10% drop in property values next year. Mortgage costs are expected to remain elevated for a few years, and buy-to-let investors are likely to be significantly affected, with some potentially forced to sell and take capital profits.

images.alt_text: Eating out, takeaways and clothing were the things people said they’d cut first, pointing to weaker demand for retailers and hospitality firms in 2023.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track Wall Street higher
summary: Asia-Pacific stocks rose on Friday, December 30, as US Wall Street rebounded, boosting hopes for a easing of the Federal Reserve's rate hikes. Despite US jobless claims rising more than expected, investors were optimistic about the economy's trajectory. Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, and Taipei saw significant gains, with Hong Kong jumping nearly 1.5%. The rebound was seen as a positive sign for the region's markets heading into the new year.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Tokyo financial markets were both more than 1.0 per cent lower in early trade on Thursday.

site_title: Indonesia issues emergency regulation to replace controversial job creation law
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has signed an emergency regulation to replace a controversial job creation law, following a Constitutional Court ruling that deemed the law flawed due to inadequate public consultations. The new regulation aims to ensure legal certainty and achieve the government's investment target amid global geopolitical uncertainty. The move has been criticized by some legal experts, who see it as a government attempt to bypass proper debate in parliament, and has sparked concerns about the erosion of labor and environmental protections.

images.alt_text: Women buy vegetables at a street market in Jakarta August 1, 2011. Indonesia's annual inflation in July was seen easing to the lowest since May 2011 at 4.81 percent, though month-on-month inflation was expected to pick up to 0.87 percent as food prices went up ahead of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan in August.  REUTERS/Enny Nuraheni  (INDONESIA - Tags: BUSINESS FOOD)

site_title: India’s April-Nov fiscal deficit touches 9.78 trillion rupees
summary: India's fiscal deficit for April-November reached 9.78 trillion rupees, exceeding 58.9% of annual estimates. Net tax receipts were 12.25 trillion rupees, while total expenditure was 24.43 trillion rupees. The government's subsidy bill for food, fuel, and fertiliser was nearly exhausted, with a total of 3.01 trillion rupees spent, exceeding the budgeted 3.18 trillion rupees.

site_title: Six climate breakthroughs that made 2022 a step toward net zero
summary: In 2022, several climate breakthroughs marked progress toward a net-zero world. The US passed the Inflation Reduction Act, a $374 billion climate spending bill, and the EU set a 55% emissions reduction goal by 2030. The COP15 biodiversity conference pledged to protect 30% of the Earth's land and water by 2030, and a loss-and-damage fund was established to help developing countries impacted by climate change. Countries like China and the UK also made commitments to reduce emissions. Additionally, nations signed up to a global methane emissions pledge, and the US strengthened rules to reduce methane leaks.

site_title: Economically speaking, it was a surprisingly normal year
summary: In 2022, the global economy experienced a surprisingly normal year, with traditional economic approaches proving effective in explaining key events. Inflation, driven by growth in the money supply and energy price hikes, was the big story, aligning with standard macroeconomic theory. Supply constraints, particularly in Europe, led to downturns and recessions, highlighting the importance of traditional economic lessons. Meanwhile, the collapse of the FTX crypto exchange and the failures of Russia and China's economic policies underscored the limitations of exotic doctrines. Overall, the year reinforced the explanatory power of classical and traditional economic theories.

images.alt_text: With the crash of stock and bond prices in the second half of the year, the "bull market in everything" ended its run in 2022.
The biggest and most welcome surprise of the year has been the resilience of broadly liberal countries in the West.

site_title: Myanmar court jails Suu Kyi for 7 more years in final verdict
summary: Myanmar's former leader Aung San Suu Kyi has been sentenced to 7 more years in prison, bringing her total jail term to 33 years. She was found guilty of 5 corruption charges related to the rental and purchase of a helicopter between 2019 and 2021. The ruling extinguishes any chance of her staging a political comeback while the junta remains in power. Over 2,600 civilians have been killed and 16,500 arrested in a military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement since the 2021 coup.

site_title: Israel’s Netanyahu returns with hard-right Cabinet set to expand settlements
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has returned to office with a hard-right Cabinet, vowing to expand Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank. Netanyahu's bloc of nationalist and religious parties secured a Parliamentary majority, despite concerns about the fate of civil rights and diplomacy. The new government's conservative makeup has darkened the outlook for Palestinians, with violence surging and settlements set to expand. Netanyahu has pledged to promote tolerance and pursue peace, but his line-up has been criticized by world powers and Palestinians.

site_title: ‘Not meaningful’ for Pacific Star Development to resume trading, board says
summary: Pacific Star Development's board believes it's not meaningful to resume trading due to the uncertainty surrounding the bulk sale of unsold units at Puteri Cove Residences and Quayside, expected to take 11-12 months to complete. Trading has been suspended since March 2020. The board views resuming trading as not meaningful until the sale is complete and the company's future growth prospects are determined.

images.alt_text: Commercial real estate, which exhibits income growth potential, diversification benefits and relative stability, will see  strengthened interest.
Iskandar boleh

site_title: Europe: Shares fall, record worst year since 2018
summary: European shares closed at a record low for the year, down 12.9% from 2018, due to geopolitical tensions and fears of a recession. Tech stocks were among the worst performers, down 28.4% as major central banks raised interest rates. London's FTSE 100 outperformed peers due to its heavy commodity exposure, while energy stocks bucked the downtrend. The European Central Bank eased interest rate increases earlier this month, but warned of significant tightening ahead.

images.alt_text: Rate-sensitive European tech shares jumped 2.0 per cent, boosting the main index, as eurozone government bond yields fell.

site_title: China insists official Covid data is transparent
summary: China has insisted its official Covid-19 data is transparent, despite experts estimating up to 9,000 daily deaths, as the country releases limited information on new cases and fatalities. China counts only deaths from respiratory failure caused by the virus, excluding other deaths within 28 days of a positive test. The National Health Commission says this approach is in line with international criteria, but health risk analysis firm Airfinity estimates significantly higher numbers of daily deaths and infections.

images.alt_text: China suddenly ended its Covid Zero policy about a month ago, abandoning the strict testing and lockdown measures.

site_title: China’s factory activity likely cooled in December on Covid surge: poll
summary: China's factory activity likely cooled in December due to the surge in Covid cases after the relaxation of the country's "zero-Covid" policy. The official manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) is expected to stay at 48.0, a seven-month low, indicating contraction in activity. Rising Covid infections and labour shortages are expected to impact production lines, while external demand weakened due to global recession fears. The data suggests a challenging winter for manufacturers, despite the government's focus on economic growth.

images.alt_text: Traffic congestion levels across 15 major cities in China rebounded nearly 60 per cent by Wednesday from a week ago.

site_title: Covid-mutation risk drives rush to test travelers from China
summary: Countries including the US, UK, and France are testing passengers from China to monitor for new Covid-19 variants amid concerns about the country's lack of population immunity. The World Health Organization (WHO) is urging China to share more data on the outbreak, including genetic sequencing data, to inform effective responses. While most sequencing data shared publicly shows the variants are largely the same as those found elsewhere, experts warn that new variants could emerge and pose a risk to global populations. The WHO and other health organizations are closely monitoring the situation and preparing for potential outbreaks.

images.alt_text: Travellers in the transit area at Changi Airport. As air travel with China is progressively restored, MOH will take a cautious approach towards increasing seat capacity on planes, taking into account the overall public health assessment.

site_title: Modi’s popularity key to selling food aid cutbacks before Indian elections
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is cutting food aid to the poor by half, reducing the monthly allocation from 10 kg to 5 kg. The move, which will save the government around $20 billion annually, is seen as a fiscal sound decision but may be politically risky. Modi's popularity and trustworthiness among voters are expected to help him sell the idea to the public, despite criticism from some economists and opposition parties. The decision comes ahead of India's elections in 2023 and 2024.

images.alt_text: A labourer separates grains of wheat from the husk at a wholesale grain market in Ghaziabad on May 17, 2022. - The United States hopes that India will reverse its decision to ban exports of wheat, which will worsen global shortages of the commodity, Washington's top diplomat to the United Nations said on May 17. (Photo by Prakash SINGH / AFP)

site_title: China approves Merck’s covid therapy amid shortage of drugs
summary: China has granted conditional emergency approval for Merck's Covid-19 antiviral molnupiravir, known as Lagevrio, to treat mild and moderate infections among adults at risk of severe disease. The approval comes amid a massive wave of infections in Beijing following its pivot away from Covid Zero. The move aims to expand access to treatments in China, which faces domestic shortages due to the surge in infections. This is the second foreign Covid-19 treatment cleared for use in China, following Pfizer's Paxlovid in early 2022.

images.alt_text: The State Administration for Market Regulation will stop testing chilled and frozen foods for Covid-19 from Jan 8, according to a notice seen by Reuters and confirmed by the agency.
“The variants continue to circulate without any significant changes that raise any spectre of concern,” Gisaid's CEO Peter Bogner said.

site_title: With luxe in flux, Audi’s A8 sticks to its guns
summary: The Audi A8 has undergone a mild facelift, maintaining its classical approach to luxury. Despite its outdated design, the car excels in terms of space, comfort, and equipment, featuring a massage function and ventilation in the rear seats. The A8 L model offers ample legroom, and its 4.0-litre V8 engine provides thundering authority and a quiet ride. The car is priced at S$704,675, making it a significant investment for dedicated Audi fans.

images.alt_text: The Mirai even removes 99.5 per cent of PM2.5, the ultra-fine soot that is known to harm human health.

site_title: Recovery in ESG bond issuance seen in 2023 as rates stabilise, inflation subsides
summary: Global ESG bond issuance is expected to recover in 2023 as interest rates stabilize and inflation subsides. Despite a 26.4% decline in global ESG bond proceeds in 2022, South-east Asia bucked the trend, with ESG bond issuance growing 36.9% year-over-year. Analysts attribute the region's strength to large sovereign offerings and maturing of the market. As interest rates calm down, ESG issuance is expected to bounce back, with environmental bonds, including climate and biodiversity-related deals, remaining the main source of ESG issuance in 2023.

images.alt_text: At present, China’s green funds only operate within broad investment guidelines that came into effect in 2018 and do not have a mandatory labelling regime.
Harnessing green financing to push the boundaries of innovation
Bankers expect at least half of the loan deals for investment-grade firms in Europe, the Middle East and Africa to be tied to environmental, social and governance targets in 2023.
UK grocery chain Tesco was criticised last year for tying its SLB to goals that covered only 2 per cent of annual emissions.

site_title: India may review stance on Chinese investments to help firms relocate
summary: India may review its stance on Chinese investments to help global firms relocate due to supply chain disruptions. The move comes as companies like Apple explore a "China Plus One" strategy. Apple wants Chinese BYD to sign a joint venture with an Indian company to move iPad production. The government may allow joint ventures with Chinese companies in sectors where India lacks technical expertise, potentially easing tensions between the two countries. This could be a response to India's blocked Chinese companies from participating in government tenders and banned dozens of Chinese apps following a border clash in 2020.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of BYD is pictured at the 2022 Paris Auto Show in Paris, France October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: EC World Reit loans expected to be repaid or refinanced before due dates, manager assures
summary: The manager of EC World Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) assures that existing bank loans will be repaid or refinanced before due dates, with a repayment plan in the process of obtaining internal lender approval. The loans amount to S$561.3 million, representing 25% of total outstanding onshore and offshore loans. The Reit intends to fund the mandatory repayment using equity consideration from asset sales, and is in a net current liabilities position of S$216.1 million. The group expects to be in a net current assets position of S$141.8 million after proposed divestment and refinancing.

images.alt_text: The latest proposal is on the back of delays to divestment plans of two Chinese logistics assets, to the tune of some 2.03 billion yuan (S$392.7 million).
The last time there were no S-Reit IPOs was in 2008 and 2009, in the aftermath of the Global Financial Crisis.

site_title: US jobless claims rise slightly but remain near historic lows
summary: US initial unemployment claims rose by 9,000 to 225,000 in the week ended Dec 24, remaining near historic lows. Continuing claims reached 1.7 million, the most since early February. This data suggests the labor market remains resilient despite the Federal Reserve's efforts to cool demand.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on last trading day of torrid year
summary: US stocks opened lower on the final trading day of 2022, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 99.19 points, or 0.30%, to 33,121.61. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 20.22 points, or 0.53%, and the Nasdaq dropping 109.72 points, or 1.05%. The declines were attributed to aggressive interest-rate hikes and recession fears amid the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war.

site_title: China to cut weighting of US dollar, euro in CFETS yuan basket index in 2023
summary: China's central bank, CFETS, will adjust the weightings of a key yuan index basket in 2023. Starting Jan 1, the US dollar's weighting will decrease to 19.83% from 19.88%, while the euro's weighting will decrease to 18.21% from 18.45%. The adjustments aim to ensure the yuan's value aligns with trade situations and may impact the official daily midpoint fixing, but are unlikely to create volatility in yuan trades.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar and Chinese yuan notes are seen in this picture illustration June 2, 2017. REUTERS/Thomas White/File Photo

site_title: In 2023, big banks will show fintech who’s the boss
summary: Big banks are poised to regain their dominance in the fintech sector in 2023, as the industry experiences a "shakeout" due to overexpansion and increased risk. Fintech companies, particularly those in consumer lending, have expanded rapidly but now face a rough ride, with many struggling with job cuts and collapsing valuations. Meanwhile, banks with strong balance sheets, such as JPMorgan Chase, are well-positioned to take advantage of the situation through takeovers or winning back customers, solidifying their power in the industry.

images.alt_text: With a drop of more than 20 per cent in 2022, the MSCI All-Country World Index is on track for its worst performance since the 2008 crisis.
A
While the pace of hikes has slowed, chair Jerome Powell has also been clear that rates still have to go higher and will stay elevated for some time.
China will soon no longer subject inbound travellers to quarantine and has downgraded the management of Covid from its highest level.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen in front of a branch office in Bern, Switzerland November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
“The bank has taken, and continues to take, significant steps to enhance its resilience, including investments in controls, processes and technology,” says Credit Suisse.

site_title: China's Huawei sees 'business as usual' as US sanctions impact wanes
summary: Huawei's 2022 revenue remained flat at 636.9 billion yuan, despite sales decline due to US sanctions, with rotating chairman Eric Xu stating that US restrictions are now the company's new normal and business as usual. Revenue was a slight increase from 2021, when it fell 30% due to sanctions. The company continues to generate revenue from its networking equipment and cloud computing divisions, and has invested in electric vehicles and green technologies.

images.alt_text: Huawei 2021 profit leaps 76% on asset sales; CFO Meng returns to spotlight

site_title: China Covid wave sparks scramble for vital drugs across region
summary: A surge in COVID-19 cases in China has led to a shortage of key medications, including painkillers and antivirals, across the region. China's decision to lift pandemic restrictions has driven an unprecedented number of cases, overwhelming hospitals and funeral homes. Residents are resorting to buying medications from abroad, leading to shortages and price hikes. Some countries, including South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, have imposed purchase limits on certain medications, while couriers are charging exorbitant prices for deliveries. The shortage is expected to peak during January.

images.alt_text: Traffic congestion levels across 15 major cities in China rebounded nearly 60 per cent by Wednesday from a week ago.

This picture shows Covid-19 patients on beds at Tianjin Nankai Hospital in Tianjin on December 28, 2022. - Cities across China have struggled with surging infections, a resulting shortage of pharmaceuticals and overflowing hospital wards and crematoriums after Beijing suddenly dismantled its zero-Covid lockdown and testing regime. (Photo by Noel Celis / AFP)

site_title: JGB yields soften after Bank of Japan operations
summary: The Bank of Japan announced an extraordinary bond-buying operation for the third consecutive day, with super long-term bonds included, to soften long-term bond yields. The yield on 20-year notes dropped to 1.28%, its lowest level since October 2014. Yields have nearly tripled this year after the BOJ raised the cap on 10-year bond yields to 0.5% from 0.25%. The operations aimed to supply financial firms with easy cash, but market response was sluggish due to thinned year-end trading.

images.alt_text: Japan’s key inflation gauge is climbing at the fastest pace in four decades, putting further pressure on the central bank.

site_title: South Korea to raise electricity prices for Q1 2023 by nearly 10%
summary: South Korea plans to raise electricity prices by 13.1 won (9.5%) per kilowatt-hour for the first quarter of 2023, the highest quarterly increase in four decades. This is due to a surge in global energy prices and a projected deficit of over 30 trillion won for state-run electricity powerhouse Kepco this year. The increase is expected to impact energy supplies and management. The government will review trends in global energy prices and inflation conditions for subsequent quarters.

site_title: Russia’s Yandex co-founder Volozh pens farewell message to staff
summary: Russia's Yandex co-founder Arkady Volozh has penned a farewell message to staff ahead of corporate restructuring, which could see ownership of core services change hands. Volozh stepped down as CEO and left the board after being included on the EU's sanctions list. Yandex has sought to balance its Western investors and the Kremlin, selling its news feed to state-controlled rival VK. The company plans to divest ownership and control of most businesses, with international divisions developing independently from Russia.

site_title: US dollar slips, still set for biggest annual gain since 2015
summary: The US dollar index fell around 0.3% on its last trading day of the year, but is still on track for its biggest annual gain since 2015. The dollar has risen 8.4% against a basket of currencies this year, driven by the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Despite the dollar's gains, analysts expect the Fed's rate-hiking cycle to end next year, and the euro is expected to outperform the dollar in the near term. The dollar's performance is also influenced by China's reopening and the ongoing economic slowdown in the country.

site_title: GuocoLand promotes group general manager of asset management to managing director
summary: GuocoLand has promoted Valerie Wong, group general manager of asset management, to managing director, asset management, effective January 1, 2023. Wong, instrumental in developing GuocoLand's asset management capability, will oversee the group's strategy to expand its property asset management business across Singapore, China, and Malaysia. This move aims to leverage GuocoLand's expertise in Singapore to strengthen its asset management capabilities and business in China and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: ArtWalk Little India.

site_title: Putin expects China’s Xi to visit soon; Xi holds his line on Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expects Chinese President Xi Jinping to visit Moscow in the spring, marking a public show of solidarity between the two nations amid Russia's faltering invasion of Ukraine. The visit comes as Russia seeks to strengthen ties with China, which has declined to condemn the invasion. China has maintained its "objective and fair" stance, and Xi's introductory statement highlighted differences in approach to the issue. Despite this, the two leaders agreed to boost military cooperation and expand financial ties.

site_title: Rebates for 950,000 households to offset utility and conservancy bills from January
summary: The Singapore government will disburse rebates to 950,000 households in Housing Board flats from January to offset utility and conservancy bills. The largest rebate of S$190 will be given to one- and two-bedroom flat residents, while those in three-room flats will receive S$170. The rebates will be credited directly into utility accounts and are part of the government's Assurance Package, worth S$8 billion, to mitigate the rising cost of living.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s power grid vendor SP Group on Friday (Dec 30) attributed the price revisions to lower energy costs compared with the last quarter.

site_title: Some books to restore financial common sense in 2023
summary: Merryn Somerset Webb urges investors to relearn the basics of investing after every financial bubble, emphasizing that a share's value is determined by its future income, not its theoretical ownership. She recommends reading "A Shared Journey" by Robin Angus, "The Rocking-Horse Winner" by DH Lawrence, and "The Way We Live Now" by Anthony Trollope for their investing common sense. Webb also suggests books on understanding the causes of asset bubbles, including "The End of the Everything Bubble" by Alasdair Nairn and "The Price of Time" by Edward Chancellor, and warns against reading about cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: They key is to ignore short-term volatility and focus on the long term, and invest in a globally diversified portfolio.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as jobless claims data calm rate hike jitters
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, December 29, as data showing a cooling labor market eased concerns over future interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 145.72 points, or 0.44%, to 33,021.43, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, 0.59% and 1.06% respectively. The data provided a relief for investors, who had been worried about the impact of rising interest rates on the economy.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as China’s Covid surge quells risk appetite
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Dec 29, with technology stocks leading gains, boosted by Wall Street's positive reaction to eased US jobless data. The Stoxx 600 index has fallen nearly 12% this year due to investors' cautious mood ahead of 2023's expected rate hikes and recessions. Analyst Craig Erlam attributed the low bar for market expectations, stating that investors are prepared for more rate hikes and expecting global recessions.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 dipped 0.1 per cent, while the FTSE 100 advanced 0.3 per cent as miners and China-exposed stocks jumped.

site_title: India’s current account gap widens to 9-year high
summary: India's current account deficit widened to a 9-year high of $36.4 billion in the July-September quarter, driven by a surge in commodity prices and a weak rupee, which increased the country's trade gap. The deficit as a percentage of GDP reached 4.4%, its highest since 2013. The Reserve Bank of India attributed the widening deficit to increased merchandise trade deficit and net outgo under investment income, despite robust growth in services exports and remittances.

site_title: Geopolitical tensions, sustainability goals to continue to drive Asia-Pac M&A in 2023
summary: Asia-Pacific mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are expected to continue driven by sustainability goals and diversification amid geopolitical tensions in 2023. The region's M&A activity declined 34% in the first nine months of 2022 due to valuation expectations gaps between buyers and sellers. However, South-east Asia is seen as a resilient region, with venture capital and buyout funds seeking bigger returns in startups. Sustainability-driven deals are emerging, such as the shutdown of a coal power plant in Indonesia, while digital infrastructure is expected to be a key sector to watch.

images.alt_text: Sats share price sank after the ground handler and inflight caterer proposed acquisition of the world’s air cargo handler Worldwide Freight Services (WFS) for an enterprise value of about 2.3 billion euros (S$3.3 billion), including assuming WFS’  borrowings of 1 billion euros.

“M&A is the best house in a pretty tough neighborhood in investment banking right now,” said Mark Shafir, co-head of global M&A at Citigroup, which advised on three of the year’s largest transactions, including Broadcom’s US$61 billion takeover of VMWare.

In recent weeks, some banks have received mandates from Chinese companies looking at Australian assets, while other dealmakers say they are getting inbound inquiries from cashed-up potential buyers in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: India’s Eicher Motors to invest in Spanish EV firm Stark
summary: Eicher Motors, the parent of Royal Enfield, is investing 50 million euros (S$71.8 million) in Spanish electric motorcycle maker Stark Future, acquiring a nearly 10.35% stake. The investment will facilitate a long-term partnership in R&D, technology sharing, and manufacturing. This move follows rival Hero MotoCorp's investment in California-based Zero Motorcycles. Electric vehicles are expected to account for 33% of global sales by 2028, according to consultant AlixPartners.

site_title: FTX customers ask bankruptcy court to keep their names secret
summary: FTX customers from outside the US have asked a US bankruptcy judge to keep their names secret during the cryptocurrency exchange's bankruptcy case, citing concerns over identity theft and scams. The group claims that revealing their identities could undermine FTX's efforts to sell parts of its business. This request has been opposed by the US Department of Justice and media outlets, including the New York Times and Wall Street Journal. A hearing on customer privacy is scheduled for January 11.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried is charged with two counts of wire fraud and six counts of conspiracy.
The lawsuit is the latest legal effort to lay claim to the dwindling assets of FTX.

site_title: China’s Sinopec buys 49% of Thai oil retailer Susco Dealer
summary: Chinese state refiner Sinopec has acquired a 49% stake in Thai oil retailer Susco Dealer, expanding its fuel retail business in the country. The joint venture combines Sinopec's fuel supply base and brand with Susco Dealer's retail network, and will explore low-carbon and new energy businesses such as electric vehicles and biofuels. This investment aims to increase Sinopec's presence in the Thai market and diversify its business portfolio.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company logo of China’s Sinopec Corp is displayed at a news conference in Hong Kong, China March 26, 2018. REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo

site_title: The new inflation picture
summary: The US economy's inflation picture is shifting, with the Federal Reserve considering its next moves amid a potential "soft landing" or the risk of stagflation and recession. Following a significant increase in energy and commodity prices in 2022 due to the Ukraine war, inflation expectations have eased, and the latest PCE-chain inflation rate for November is 0.16%. The Fed should keep in mind its flexibility to move quickly and consider the long-term implications of maintaining a 2% inflation target, which may no longer be the best fit for new circumstances.

images.alt_text: In the US, all eyes are on prices and labour markets, and what they portend for Federal Reserve policy.
With the crash of stock and bond prices in the second half of the year, the "bull market in everything" ended its run in 2022.
The Fed and other major central banks are intent on fighting inflation
Many countries are now grappling with cost-of-living crises because wages are not keeping up with inflation, forcing households to make difficult choices in their spending.

site_title: Baidu, Pony.ai start driverless robotaxi tests in Beijing
summary: Baidu and Toyota-backed Pony.ai have been granted licenses to test fully autonomous vehicles without safety operators in Beijing, marking the first time such tests have been allowed in the city. The companies will begin testing 10 driverless vehicles each in a technology park, with Baidu aiming to expand its network of autonomous robotaxis across China. The move follows successful public journeys of over 1.4 million by Baidu's Apollo Go service, which operates without a safety driver in cities like Wuhan and Chongqing.

images.alt_text: Baidu is transitioning to artificial intelligence and self-driving cars after its core advertising revenue shrank in the mobile era.

site_title: Hong Kong exports drop most in almost 7 decades on global slump
summary: Hong Kong's exports plummeted 24.1% in November, the largest decline in nearly seven decades, due to a global slump and worsening economic conditions in China. This was worse than economists' median estimate of a 16.2% decline. Imports also fell 20.3% from a year earlier, leading to a trade deficit of HK$27.1 billion. The decline in shipments to China, the US, and other economies was significant, with exports to China dropping 29.7% and to the US plummeting 26.8%.

site_title: Sen Yue reports large discrepancies between audited, unaudited financials
summary: Sen Yue Holdings, a Catalist-listed waste management firm, reported material variances between its audited and unaudited financial statements for the 2021 full year. Audited financials showed significantly higher operating expenses ($6.4 million) and impairment losses ($1.2 million) compared to unaudited financials. As a result, the company recorded a loss of $5.5 million instead of a profit of $1.3 million, and a total comprehensive loss of $10 million. The discrepancies were attributed to accounting for financial guarantee claims and recognition of expenses admitted by judicial managers.

images.alt_text: The judicial managers were appointed after DBS, Sen Yue’s bank creditor, applied to the High Court for the waste management group and its subsidiary, SMC Industrial, to be placed under judicial management.

site_title: ‘Your legacy will be eternal’: sporting world pays tribute to Brazilian legend Pele
summary: Brazilian soccer legend Pele, a three-time World Cup winner, died on December 29 at 82 due to complications from cancer. The sporting world has paid tribute, with FIFA lowering flags at its headquarters, the Premier League and A-League observing minutes of silence and black armbands, and Liverpool's Mohamed Salah sharing a farewell post on Instagram. Tributes continued with a minute's applause before A-League games and a statement from Brazilian tennis player Thiago Monteiro, praising Pele as a national idol and inspiration for Brazilian athletes.

images.alt_text: Riding on Pele’s appeal, the market for soccer expanded rapidly, making the sport – and especially its quadrennial contest – the delight of advertisers as much as audiences.
Pele had been undergoing chemotherapy since he had a tumour removed from his colon in September 2021.

site_title: Japan's biggest banks to raise housing loan rates after BOJ's policy tweak
summary: Japan's three largest banks, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, Mizuho Bank, and Mitsubishi UFJ Bank, will raise interest rates for housing loans starting next month, following the Bank of Japan's policy tweak. The interest rate increases are as follows: Sumitomo Mitsui (10-year fixed-rate loans by 0.26 percentage point to 3.79%), Mizuho Bank (10-year fixed-rate loans by 0.3 percentage point to 3.50%), and Mitsubishi UFJ Bank (10-year fixed-rate loans by 0.18 percentage point to 3.7%). Each bank has special loan programs for selected customers with lower rates.

images.alt_text: A woman pushes a door of  Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation's branch in Tokyo April 9, 2009. Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG), Japan's third-largest bank, said it faced a net loss of $3.9 billion in the financial year just ended and would raise up to $8 billion through a share sale.   REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon (JAPAN BUSINESS)

site_title: A spectacular year for world sport
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The past year was marked by significant moments in world sports. Argentina won their first World Cup trophy since 1986, with Lionel Messi leading the team to victory. Pele, a global football icon, passed away on December 29 at 82. Novak Djokovic was banned from the Australian Open due to his unvaccinated status but will return in 2023. Roger Federer celebrated his farewell from tennis with a grand send-off at the Laver Cup. The F1 night race returned to Singapore after a two-year hiatus, and Loh Kean Yew rose to become the world's third-ranked badminton player.

images.alt_text:
FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Final - Argentina v France - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - December 18, 2022
Argentina's Lionel Messi celebrates with the trophy and teammates after winning the World Cup REUTERS/Carl Recine/File Photo

FILE — Pelé on the ball during his debut game with the New York Cosmos, at Randalls Island Stadium in New York on June 15, 1975. One of soccer’s greatest players and a transformative figure in 20th-century sports who achieved a level of global celebrity few athletes have known, Pelé died on Thursday, Dec. 29, 2022, in São Paulo. He was 82. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)
Serbia's Novak Djokovic practices ahead of the Adelaide International and Australian Open tournaments, at Memorial Drive Tennis Club in Adelaide, Australia, December 29, 2022.  REUTERS/Loren Elliott

site_title: China’s economic activity rebounds in cities where Covid peaked
summary: China's economic activity is rebounding in cities where COVID-19 cases peaked, with traffic congestion levels rising 60% in 15 major cities and subway usage increasing 40% in cities like Beijing, Chongqing, and Chengdu. However, mobility remains below pre-pandemic levels, and cases continue to spread in cities like Shanghai and Shenzhen. Analysts predict a faster-than-expected recovery once the infection wave passes, with December likely marking the bottom of the economy.

images.alt_text: Vehicles travel along the Third Ring Road in Beijing. Morgan Stanley said China’s faster reopening will be an “additional pillar of domestic demand support in Asia, while also imparting the largest positive spillover effects to the rest of Asia”.
China suddenly ended its Covid Zero policy about a month ago, abandoning the strict testing and lockdown measures.

site_title: Putin and Xi to speak by video link on Friday
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping will hold a video conference on Friday to discuss bilateral relations, regional issues, and economic ties. The talks come as Moscow seeks to deepen its economic, political, and security ties with Beijing. The two countries have signed a "no limits" strategic partnership since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February, with Beijing increasing oil and gas purchases from Russia. The conversation will also touch on regional issues, including Taiwan, amid differing views on the conflict.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DPM Lawrence Wong will deliver a round-up speech to address queries and feedback from Members of Parliament about the FY2023 Budget statement, set to be delivered on February 14, 2023.

site_title: Global stocks face more hurdles in 2023
summary: Global stocks are expected to face challenges in 2023, with the MSCI All-Country World Index on track for its worst performance since the 2008 crisis, a drop of over 20% in 2022. Central banks' rate-hiking efforts and tech troubles, including a 35% slump in the Nasdaq 100, may hinder market growth. Earnings recession and high inflation are also concerns, with some predicting a deeper drop in the second year of a bear market.
