The development is expected to obtain a temporary occupation permit in the second quarter of 2026 and will offer direct access to the Tanah Merah MRT station, along with a 50-metre lap pool and a garden.

images.alt_text: Developers in Singapore have sold 259 units in November, down nearly 20 per cent from October and 83.3 per cent from November 2021.
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.
Analysts say that higher land costs, along with the increased cost of construction and materials, are contributing to cost pressures.

site_title: China issues rules to assess risks in foreign banks’ Chinese branches
summary: China's China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) has issued rules to assess operational risks in foreign banks' Chinese branches. The rating system aims to allocate supervisory resources and promote healthy development in China. Foreign banks, including HSBC and Citi, will be evaluated on risk management, operational control, and asset quality. Those with poor ratings may face restrictions on capital expatriation, demands for fresh operating capital, and suspension of new branch approvals. The system will classify foreign banks into five categories, with the top rating indicating stable operations and strong support from headquarters.

site_title: PhillipCapital issues new asset-backed wine-based token
summary: PhillipCapital has issued the En Primeur Token (EP), a wine-based security linked to a 2020 Bordeaux EP vintage collection. The tokens represent secured notes that can be redeemed for payment from the sale of wines or physical collection by 2026. Investors can opt to redeem upon wine bottling in 2023 or maturity of the secured notes. The product aims to cater to investors' interest in alternative investment vehicles, offering a potentially lower price for highly demanded wines that may be impossible to find on the market.

images.alt_text: Champagne sales reached an all-time high last year at 5.7 billion euros ($8.2 billion), as the relaxation of pandemic-related curbs fuelled a surge in exports.

site_title: Thai Nov exports drop 6.0% y-o-y, slightly worse than forecast
summary: Thailand's exports declined 6.0% in November from a year earlier, worse than forecast, due to a global slowdown and China's lockdown measures. This marks the second straight month of decline. Exports of agricultural and agro-industrial products dropped 2% and industrial products 5.1%. Shipments to the US rose 1.2%, while those to South-east Asia and China declined 9.5% and 9.9%, respectively. The country's trade deficit in November was $1.34 billion, exceeding forecasts.

images.alt_text: Headline inflation stood at 5.55 per cent in November, far above the Bank of Thailand’s (BOT) target range.

site_title: Some progress on decarbonisation at IMO, but new rule makes global warming worse
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) made some progress on decarbonization, adopting amendments to designate the Mediterranean Sea as an Emission Control Area (ECA) for sulphur oxides and particulate matter. However, new research suggests that this move could make global warming worse by reflecting sunlight and reducing its warming effect. The IMO reaffirmed its commitment to adopting a revised GHG strategy, but progress on decarbonization remains complex, with disagreements over the level of ambition and the "basket of measures" needed to support it. Onboard carbon capture technology was also discussed briefly, but its implementation was deferred to MEPC 80.

images.alt_text: Container ship operator Samskip is installing carbon capture systems of two of its ships.

site_title: Don’t turn your hobby into a side hustle
summary: Don't turn your hobby into a side hustle, experts warn, as the rise of monetization can lead to a loss of enjoyment and a shift from personal enrichment to profit-driven pursuits. A hobby is meant to be a source of relaxation and creative expression, not a way to make a living. While some hobbies can be turned into profitable ventures, others should remain hobbies for their own sake, allowing individuals to recharge and pursue personal interests without the burden of financial expectations.

images.alt_text: The Closet Lover: from hobby to four retail stores in Singapore

site_title: Chip Eng Seng IFA says terms of Tangs offer fair ‘on balance’
summary: Chip Eng Seng's independent financial adviser, Xandar Capital, has concluded that the terms of the privatization offer by Gordon and Celine Tang at S$0.75 per share are fair "on balance". The offer represents a 43.9% discount to the revalued net asset value per share. Xandar cited eight factors supporting the fairness of the offer, including a higher implied price-to-earnings ratio and price-to-net-asset-value ratio compared to comparable companies. However, the IFA noted that only three factors were against the fairness of the consideration, and it should consider other matters, such as market liquidity.

images.alt_text: Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang  (pictured) and her husband Gordon Tang are required to attain more than 90 per cent of the company's shares to take it private.
Celine Tang, chairman of Chip Eng Seng, and her husband Gordon Tang earlier this year took SingHaiyi Group private at a 21.8 per cent discount to book value.

site_title: What would it take to turn more offices into housing?
summary: US office spaces totaling 998 million square feet are available, with 13% of the market sitting idle, offering potential for conversion into residential spaces, retail, or other uses. City governments and developers are discussing the possibility, driven by the estimated 39% decline in office value from pre-pandemic levels. However, converting office spaces to housing is complex due to differences in layout, cost, and zoning regulations. Some cities, like New York and Philadelphia, have successfully converted office spaces to housing in the past, but the process is slow and requires public incentives.

images.alt_text: Real estate firms report that more Manhattan landlords are now giving renters higher listing discounts.

site_title: Thailand to keep budget deficit within 3% of GDP for 2024 fiscal year
summary: Thailand's government plans to maintain a budget deficit of no more than 3% of GDP in the 2024 fiscal year, totaling 593 billion baht (S$23 billion). The inflation target of 1-3% aims to maintain price stability and keep medium-term inflation expectations anchored. The country's public debt is expected to reach 61.35% of GDP by the end of 2024. The central bank has also set a headline inflation target of 1-3% for 2023 and plans to continue raising interest rates to control inflation.

images.alt_text: A man wearing a face mask shops inside the Sampheng wholesale market as Thai government eases isolation measures, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Bangkok, Thailand, June 10, 2020. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Exports, a key driver of Thai growth, declined 6.0 per cent in November from a year earlier, compared with a forecast fall of 5.2 per cent year on year in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Designing new ways to give back
summary: The National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre's (NVPC) Community Matters program collaborated with the DesignSingapore Council's School of X to offer the nine-week Impact-A-Thon program, aimed at equipping non-profit organizations (NPOs) with design-thinking methods to reimagine their business models. The program, which included workshops and tailored coaching sessions, helped NPOs such as Image Mission, Acres, and Care Singapore develop practical solutions to tackle complex challenges. The program also secured seed funding from Ernst & Young Singapore to enable the teams to implement their designed solutions, resulting in increased sustainability and impact for the NPOs.

images.alt_text: Reach Community Services Society social worker Nina Catrina says the session allows participants to gather feedback from their peers.

site_title: Vietnam central bank buys US dollars to shore up reserves after sell-off
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam, is buying US dollars to strengthen its foreign exchange reserves after selling a large amount of dollars earlier this year to support the dong currency. The bank aims to keep inflation at 4.5% next year and has managed monetary policy in a flexible way to stabilize the markets. Strong foreign direct investment inflows and a large trade surplus have helped slow the weakening of the dong, which has lost about 3% against the US dollar this year.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam said it will aim to “stabilise the monetary and foreign exchange markets to ensure the safety of the banking system.”

site_title: Fosun app lets China users get BioNTech Covid vaccines in Hong Kong
summary: China's Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical Group allows users of its mobile health app to register for BioNTech Covid-19 booster shots in Hong Kong. The vaccine is recommended for those aged 18 and above who have completed their initial course of vaccination. This move comes as mainland China eases Covid-19 border controls, deeming the Omicron variant less pathogenic. The vaccine, adapted for the BA.4 and BA.5 subvariants, is the first variant-adapted vaccine approved as a booster dose in Hong Kong for individuals 12 years and older.

site_title: India and China – a 2023 tale of two markets
summary: India's stock market has outperformed China's, with its weight in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index rising to second place, despite China's larger economy. India's stocks have held up well due to pent-up urban demand after the pandemic, while China's equities have slumped due to isolationist policies, real estate sector turmoil, and antitrust campaigns. As China reopens, investors may rotate away from India, but domestic investors remain optimistic about earnings growth. India is seeking to become an alternative to China, but faces challenges such as investment risks, policy inwardness, and macroeconomic imbalances.

images.alt_text: National Stock Exchange of India Ltd. (NSE) building in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, Dec. 20, 2022. India is set to rank among this year’s best-performing major stock markets globally, overcoming concerns about higher interest rates and an economic slowdown that has mired peers. Photographer: Atul Loke/Bloomberg
UBS Group, Deutsche Bank, and Julius Baer Group are among firms hiring private bankers to serve clients from the world’s fifth-biggest economy, which has an estimated US$14.2 trillion in wealth.

site_title: China stocks jump on easing Covid curbs
summary: China's blue-chip CSI 300 Index rose 1.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index added 1% on Tuesday, marking the best day in three weeks, as the country relaxed Covid curbs further. China will stop requiring inbound travelers to quarantine starting January 8 and downgrade the seriousness of Covid-19. This led to gains in consumer staples, banks, and transportation, but losses in tourism-related companies and some drugmakers. Analysts expect a quicker economic recovery, with a shorter transitional pain in Q1 2023.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Tech Index has surged about 50 per cent since an October trough.

site_title: US dollar slips as investors take heart from looser China Covid rules
summary: The US dollar fell on Dec 27 after China announced it would scrap its Covid-19 quarantine rule for inbound travelers starting Jan 8, a move that boosted risk-related currencies like the New Zealand and Australian dollars. The offshore yuan rose 0.1% to 6.9686 per US dollar, while the New Zealand dollar rose 0.7% and the Australian currency rose 0.5%. This move is seen as a step towards China's border reopening, which is expected to have a positive impact on the Chinese yuan.

site_title: German businesses expect only mild recession as disruptions ease
summary: German businesses predict a mild recession next year, with a 1.4% economic growth this year and a 0.4% contraction the following year. Despite energy crisis, raw material shortages, and a global economic slowdown, companies expect only a slight slump, according to a survey by the Federation of German Industries. The prediction suggests that the German economy may stave off the worst of an economic downturn triggered by Russia's energy supply disruption.

site_title: Private enterprise matters to China’s reform drive
summary: China's Central Economic Work Conference (CEWC) emphasized the importance of supporting private enterprises to boost economic growth. The conference reiterated that China will encourage and guide the development of the non-public sector and bring tangible benefits to private enterprises. The private economy contributes significantly to China's tax revenue, GDP, technological innovation, urban employment, and total number of companies, making its support crucial for the national economy and family livelihoods. The government aims to ensure equal protection, maintain fairness, and implement institutional and legal measures to support private enterprises and entrepreneurs.

images.alt_text: China will speed up construction of major investment projects and equipment upgrading, state media quoted the Cabinet as saying after a regular meeting.

After three years of strict Covid Zero restrictions, a crackdown on financial risk in the property market and targeting excessive growth of Internet platform companies, President Xi Jinping now appears to be loosening the reins.

site_title: South Korea pardons jailed ex-president Lee
summary: Former South Korean President Lee Myung Bak was granted a presidential pardon, cutting short his 17-year sentence on corruption charges. The 81-year-old Lee, who was serving a life sentence, received a pardon along with over 1,300 others for "broad national unity through reconciliation, tolerance and consideration." The pardon was granted by President Yoon Suk Yeol, marking the second time he has exercised his clemency power since taking office in May.

site_title: Japan's Kishida loses fourth minister in three months
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's cabinet is experiencing a "domino effect" with the resignation of its fourth minister in three months. Reconstruction Minister Kenya Akiba and Parliamentary Vice-Minister Mio Sugita stepped down due to alleged financial improprieties and divisive rhetoric, respectively. Kishida's approval ratings are at an all-time low, with many speculating that he will reshuffle his cabinet before the next parliament session in January. The series of departures comes amid a wave of scandals involving ministers and their ties to the Unification Church sect.

images.alt_text: Kenya Akiba has battled accusations of being involved in violating election laws as well as having ties with the Unification Church.
The BOJ shocked markets last week with a surprise widening of the band around its 10-year yield target.
Japan is saddled with the industrial world’s heaviest public debt at more than twice the size of its US$5 trillion economy, the world’s third largest.

site_title: Japan to require China travellers to take Covid test on arrival
summary: Japan will require travellers from mainland China to take Covid-19 tests on arrival, starting Friday, due to concerns about the rapid spread of the virus in China. The measure was announced after Beijing ended inbound quarantine requirements, and Japan aims to cap flights from China. Travellers who test positive will be quarantined for seven days. This move comes after Japan eased its restrictions on tourists in recent months and only fully reopened to tourists in October, following two-and-a-half years of Covid restrictions.

images.alt_text: Travellers at Beijing Capital International Airport in Beijing, China, Dec 27, 2022. Online searches for flights abroad surged after Beijing said it would scrap mandatory quarantine for overseas arrivals, state media reported.
Beijing's announcement is its latest move to loosen its zero-Covid regime, after it abruptly dropped mandatory testing and lockdowns earlier this month.
After close to three years, SIA is reinstating its Singapore to Beijing passenger service every Friday on a fortnightly basis.
The government cut its view on factory output for the first time in six months as global demand for semiconductors is pausing.

site_title: New York artist turns tiny hip-hop street scenes into profitable business
summary: New York artist Danny Cortes has turned his hobby of creating miniature hip-hop street scenes into a profitable business. His tiny models, often made from recycled objects, capture the gritty atmosphere of neighborhoods like Bushwick, Brooklyn, where he grew up. Cortes' work has gained recognition, including a sale at Sotheby's for $10,000, and collaborations with rappers like Joell Ortiz and 2 Chainz. His art aims to document the changing face of his neighborhood, embracing gentrification as a symbol of growth and opportunity.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits one-week high as retailers soar
summary: The Nikkei share average in Tokyo reached a one-week high, closing at 26,543.47, after retailers surged due to Takashimaya's improved profit outlook and hopes for Chinese tourists' return. Financials outperformed following the Bank of Japan's yield policy shift. Travel shares also rallied, with Japan Airlines gaining 3.47% and H.I.S. rising 2.04%. The broader Topix index added 0.62% to 1,914.40, also reaching a one-week high.

site_title: Japan’s jobless rate falls to 2.5% in Nov
summary: Japan's jobless rate fell to 2.5% in November, matching economists' median forecast, according to government data. The jobs-to-applicants ratio remained at 1.35, its highest level since March 2020. The rate was down from 2.6% in October, indicating a stable labor market.

site_title: China to scrap quarantine for overseas arrivals: health authorities
summary: China will scrap quarantine measures for overseas arrivals starting January 8, allowing travelers to enter the country with a PCR test taken 48 hours prior. This move is part of Beijing's efforts to loosen its zero-Covid regime, following the recent drop of mandatory testing and lockdowns. The measures will take effect when Covid is downgraded from Class A to Class B, a second-tier infectious disease.

site_title: Myanmar court to deliver final verdicts this week in Suu Kyi trials
summary: A Myanmar court is set to deliver its final verdicts in cases against deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi on Friday. Suu Kyi, 77, was arrested in a coup that ended a decade of democracy in Myanmar, and has been convicted of multiple offenses including breaking Covid-19 restrictions and incitement. The verdicts, which carry up to 15 years in prison, come after marathon court proceedings that have been condemned as a sham by critics. Suu Kyi has called the cases "absurd" and is being held in an annex of a jail in Naypyitaw with limited access to lawyers.

site_title: China’s industrial profits slump on Covid fallout, next year seen improving
summary: China's industrial profits fell 3.6% in January-November to 7.7 trillion yuan, due to strict Covid-19 curbs disrupting factory activity and supply chains. However, analysts expect a robust recovery next year as the economy reopens. Industrial profits for private firms shrank 7.9% in the period, with 21 of 41 major industrial sectors experiencing a decline. Business confidence has fallen to its lowest level since 2013, and policymakers have pledged to step up policy adjustments to support the slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Catalist-listed Medtecs gains as much as 19.4 per cent, while Top Glove rises 5.9 per cent.
Beijing's announcement is its latest move to loosen its zero-Covid regime, after it abruptly dropped mandatory testing and lockdowns earlier this month.

Travellers at Beijing Capital International Airport in Beijing, China, Dec 27, 2022. Online searches for flights abroad surged after Beijing said it would scrap mandatory quarantine for overseas arrivals, state media reported.

site_title: Wall Street’s big banks score US$1 trillion of profit in a decade
summary: Wall Street's six major banks are on track to reach a decade of US$1 trillion in profit, with analyst estimates suggesting they will surpass the milestone by the end of 2022. The banks, including JPMorgan, Bank of America, and Wells Fargo, have thrived despite scandals, market volatility, and global protests over bailouts. The industry's ability to push through scandals and thrive anew has been attributed to factors such as tax cuts, investment in technology, and government intervention during the pandemic. However, critics argue that the banks' fortunes are tied to the health of their clients and that their epic profits will drop if the economy takes a downturn.

site_title: European shares rise on China optimism
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Tuesday, tracking a global rally after China relaxed its Covid-19 curbs, raising hopes for a recovery in the world's second-largest economy. The STOXX 600 index has lost nearly 12% so far this year, driven by concerns of economic recession due to central banks' monetary policy tightening. Miner and energy stocks gained 1.2% and 1.4%, respectively, while China-exposed luxury firms LVMH and Kering rose 1.9% and 1.3%.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, December 23, 2022.    REUTERS/Staff
China’s blue-chip CSI 300 Index has ended 1.2 per cent higher, while the Shanghai Composite Index has added 1 per cent.

site_title: Latin America’s democracies hold strong
summary: Latin America's democracies have proven resilient despite recent challenges, including authoritarian tendencies and court clashes. Peru's impeached president Pedro Castillo was peacefully removed, and Brazil's outgoing president Jair Bolsonaro's transfer of power is expected to proceed unimpeded. Argentina's democratic politics remain stable, with the opposition poised to win the next general election. Mexico's President Andrés Manuel López Obrador's judicial reform attempt was met with widespread opposition, and Chile's constitutional reform process is on track. The region's democracies are resilient, with institutions and the rule of law proving stronger than authoritarian impulses.

images.alt_text: The sales and especially the market value of Elon Musk's companies depend at least in part on the strength of his personal brand.

site_title: PLDT to cancel some projects to shave 48b peso overspend
summary: PLDT, the Philippines' largest phone company by revenue, will cancel some projects and seek discounts to cut a 48-billion peso (S$1.2 billion) overspend. The company is under probe by the Philippine Stock Exchange and Securities and Exchange Commission due to the overspend, but a forensic investigation found no evidence of fraud or anomalies. PLDT plans to book the overspend from this year and next, with some projects potentially being replaced with new ones to improve revenue growth and customer experience.

images.alt_text: The bourse has sent PLDT a letter asking for clarification on that matter and expects a response by Friday morning.

site_title: Chinese jubilant, plan trips abroad as inbound Covid quarantine set to end
summary: Chinese citizens reacted with joy after Beijing announced the end of mandatory Covid quarantine for overseas arrivals, effective January 8. The move follows the relaxation of hardline Covid-19 controls, which had kept the country largely isolated since March 2020. Online searches for flights abroad surged, with travel platforms reporting an 850% jump in searches. The decision comes as cases surge nationwide and hospitals face shortages of medicine and strain from undervaccinated elderly patients.

images.alt_text: Travellers stand by their luggage at Beijing Capital International Airport, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Beijing, China December 27, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Oil rises as China loosens travel rules, US battles winter freeze
summary: Oil prices rose as China relaxed its Covid-19 restrictions and the US faced a severe winter freeze, leading to refinery closures in Texas. West Texas Intermediate traded near $80 a barrel, despite a looming supply shortage. The US shutdown of two major refineries and over 1.8 million barrels of oil processing capacity due to freezing conditions weighed on oil prices. However, oil's forward curve indicates no major concern about supply, with Brent's prompt timespread in contango. Oil is set to end the year modestly higher after being volatile this year due to various global events.

site_title: Oil rises in thin trade on concerns over US storm impact
summary: Oil prices rose 0.9% to $84.65 a barrel due to concerns over US winter storms affecting logistics and production. Brent crude increased 73 cents, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 85 cents. The rally was attributed to fears of supply disruptions and a possible 5-7% production cut by Russia in response to price caps. However, analysts expect the rally to be short-lived as the US weather is forecast to improve this week.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Tuesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by a positive session on Wall Street last Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,275.11 points. Advancers outnumbered decliners 83 to 39. Key gainers included Biolidics, The Place Holdings, and Singtel, while banking stocks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose. The gains followed US stocks' higher close last Friday, driven by inflation data and energy shares.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine's EGM on its proposed merger with Keppel Offshore & marine is expected to take place in January 2023.

site_title: The gold rush to become the new Twitter
summary: Twitter's demise has sparked a gold rush to alternative social media platforms. Mastodon, a decentralized platform, is gaining popularity, but its onboarding process is complicated. Post, a new platform, is also emerging with features like headlines, text-formatting, and tipping. Koo, a Twitter clone, has gained traction in India, and T2.Social aims to replicate the original Twitter formula. Other alternatives include Discord, Reddit, Truth Social, Hive, Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube, which may attract users seeking a fresh start.

images.alt_text: Quakers at a prayer vigil in front of the armed forces recruitment booth in Times Square, New York City, in 1961.

site_title: Key trends shaping the supply chain and distribution outlook
summary: Global supply chains are stabilizing, but uncertainty and volatility remain, with the looming recession expected to drive business uncertainty. Key trends shaping the supply chain and distribution outlook in 2023 include: economic slowdowns, prioritizing agility and innovation over perfection, the impact of Russia's war on Ukraine, labor strikes and protests, China decoupling efforts, and the need for supply chain visibility to be redefined. To navigate these challenges, businesses must invest in technology stacks, prioritize adaptability and agility, and build capabilities to forecast and mitigate disruptions.

images.alt_text: In the US, all eyes are on prices and labour markets, and what they portend for Federal Reserve policy.

site_title: Crypto lender Vauld faces debt-plan deadline as takeover talks with Nexo in limbo
summary: Crypto lender Vauld faces a Jan 20 deadline to present a restructuring plan to creditors, after takeover talks with Nexo stalled. Despite initial discussions in July, the two firms failed to reach an agreement, citing challenges including "defamation" and misinformation. Nexo has announced it will phase out its US service, raising concerns about access to benefits for Vauld's US customers. The move has hindered negotiations, with Vauld stating Nexo hasn't responded to questions about the issue. Vauld's creditors await the restructuring plan, which could determine the fate of the struggling crypto lender.

site_title: Liverpool agree deal for Dutch star Gakpo
summary: Liverpool has agreed to a deal for Dutch international forward Cody Gakpo, who scored three goals at the World Cup for the Netherlands. The 23-year-old attacker will join the English giants after PSV Eindhoven announced an agreement with Liverpool FC. The transfer fee could rise to as much as 50 million euros, a club record for the Dutch club. Gakpo's arrival is a further rejuvenation for Liverpool's frontline, which has also seen signings of Luis Diaz and Darwin Nunez in the past year.

site_title: Surging Covid infections delay Chinese exporters’ deliveries
summary: A surge in COVID-19 cases across China is disrupting factory production and delaying exports, with workers falling ill and suppliers unable to meet deadlines. The disruptions, not caused by lockdowns or restrictions, have resulted in missed deliveries and production cuts, with some manufacturers operating at 20-50% capacity. The issue is attributed to China's recent end of the "zero-Covid" policy, which has led to a decrease in testing and a lack of enforcement of mask mandates, allowing the virus to spread.

images.alt_text: Subway trains in Beijing and Shanghai are packed as residents commute to work.
While global supply chains are stabilising somewhat, business and industry aren't yet out of the woods.
Beijing’s swift dismantling of Covid Zero restrictions has led to the unfettered spread of the highly contagious omicron variant in a population with low levels of natural immunity.

site_title: China banks rush traders back to office on Covid disruptions
summary: Chinese banks and financial institutions are rushing employees back to office due to the nation's massive Covid-19 outbreak, which has led to a significant disruption in operations. Companies like Sinolink Securities are asking staff who were off sick or in quarantine to return to work, even if they no longer show symptoms. Some firms are also allowing Covid-infected traders to work remotely, while others require surveillance cameras to monitor transactions. The government's dismantling of Covid Zero restrictions has led to the spread of the highly contagious omicron variant, prompting economic activity to slow.

images.alt_text: It’s likely that certain groups of Hong Kong residents would be given priority in the initial stages of reopening, the SCMP says, citing local government sources.
After close to three years, SIA is reinstating its Singapore to Beijing passenger service every Friday on a fortnightly basis.
A metaverse stand in Fintech Week 2022 in Hong Kong. Developing metaverse and web3 projects in mainland China is difficult, with the government taking a tough stance on cryptocurrency.
Beijing's announcement is its latest move to loosen its zero-Covid regime, after it abruptly dropped mandatory testing and lockdowns earlier this month.

site_title: Office leasing activity to take a hit, shadow space to rise next year
summary: Singapore's office market is expected to experience a decline in leasing activity in 2023 due to a weakening global economy and a slowdown in the tech sector. Despite this, office landlords may still see a modest rental increase in 2023, primarily driven by the tight supply of Grade A office space. The demand for smaller office units, driven by family offices and non-tech occupiers, is expected to continue, but at a slower pace. The market is also likely to see an increase in shadow space, with around 700,000 sq ft of excess space expected to enter the market by early 2023.

images.alt_text: The Business Times reported in May last year that Sea Ltd, parent company of e-commerce player Shopee, was expected to lease most of the office space at the CapitaLand Development-owned property in tandem with its business growth.
Islandwide occupancy rate ....
IOI Central Boulevard Towers, which is expected to be completed in October 2023, will have a podium and 2 towers.
IOI Central Boulevard Towers will have about 1.26 million sq ft of offices and 30,000 sq ft of retail space.

The white site in Jurong East (comprising three land plots) can be developed into about 150,000 sq m GFA of office space, 1,760 private homes and 75,000 sq m GFA of complementary uses such as for retail, hotel or community.

site_title: Hot stocks: Glove manufacturers rally on news of China’s reopening plans
summary: Shares of Medtecs International and Top Glove rose significantly on Dec 27, amid China's announcement to ease travel restrictions amid ongoing Covid-19 waves. Medtecs gained 19.4% and Top Glove rose 5.9% in heavy trading. The companies, which manufacture medical protective gear, including gloves and face masks, are expected to benefit from China's reopening plans. Despite posting a net loss for the first fiscal quarter, the shares reached their highest levels since Dec 1.

images.alt_text: Top Glove Corporation's dismal Q1FY23 showing follows two years after the glove maker's best year ever

site_title: ‘Blizzard of the century’ leaves nearly 50 dead across US
summary: A historic blizzard in the US has left nearly 50 dead and thousands stranded, with conditions described as the "blizzard of the century." The storm, which gripped the country for days, caused widespread power outages, travel delays, and extreme weather conditions, particularly in New York's Erie County. At least 25 deaths have been reported in the state, with the death toll expected to rise. The National Weather Service has forecast additional snow, and authorities have warned residents to remain indoors. The US government has offered support to the affected state, with President Joe Biden promising "the full force of the federal government" to aid in relief efforts.

images.alt_text: The extreme weather sent wind chill temperatures in all 48 contiguous US states below freezing over the weekend.
More than 1,500 US flights had been cancelled Thursday, and another 761 flights for Friday were scrapped because of the storm.
The 2017 movie Chasing Coral not only does justice to one of the world's greatest wonders, it also shows what climate change's consequences look like in visceral detail.

site_title: Vietnam central bank aims to keep inflation at 4.5% next year
summary: Vietnam's central bank aims to keep inflation at 4.5% next year, stabilizing the monetary and foreign exchange markets to ensure the safety of the banking system. This follows a 12.87% rise in lending by Vietnamese banks as of December 21. The State Bank of Vietnam has raised its 14% cap on credit growth by 1.5-2.0 percentage points to combat a credit crunch in property and financial markets. Vietnam's economy is expected to grow 8% this year, with inflation forecast to be below the 4% official target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A Vietnam Dong note is seen in this illustration photo May 31, 2017.     REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Mike Pence did not file to run for US president: adviser
summary: Former US Vice President Mike Pence did not file to run for president in 2024, according to his adviser Devin O'Malley. Filings appeared on the Federal Election Commission website, prompting some news outlets to report that Pence had filed. However, O'Malley confirmed that Pence did not file, and the FEC has not yet processed the filings. This news comes as Pence faces a challenging path to victory, with only 7% of primary voters planning to support him, according to recent polls.

site_title: EC World Reit proposes debt repayment plan, seeks deferment
summary: EC World Reit, a real estate investment trust, proposes a debt repayment plan to its lenders, seeking deferment of a 25% mandatory payment due by December 31, 2022. The plan, which may risk default if not agreed upon by December 31, is due to delays in divestment of two Chinese logistics assets worth 2.03 billion yuan. The sponsor will finance part of the repayment, with the remainder deferred to the first quarter of 2023. The proposal comes amid the ongoing COVID-19 situation in China.

images.alt_text: Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of the largest e-commerce developments in the Yangtze River Delta in Shanghai, China. This is one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio.

Stage 1 properties of Bei Gang Logistics. The Reit is proposing to divest its indirect interest in the asset, along with Chongxian Port Logistics, to pare down its loans while also making a special distribution to unitholders.

site_title: Embraer in talks to sell regional jets to Scoot
summary: Singapore Airlines' low-cost subsidiary Scoot is in talks with Embraer to supply regional jets, diversifying its fleet. The Brazilian planemaker is offering its E-jets, which seat 80 to 146 passengers, for services within South-east Asia. A potential order could swell to 50 aircraft, valued at around $1.61 billion. Talks are ongoing, and an agreement is not certain. This move would add a third aircraft manufacturer to Scoot's fleet, currently built around Boeing and Airbus aircraft.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Brazilian aircraft manufacturer Embraer unveils its new regional jet E-175, in Sao Jose dos Campos, north of Sao Paulo March 12, 2014.  REUTERS/Paulo Whitaker/File Photo
After close to three years, SIA is reinstating its Singapore to Beijing passenger service every Friday on a fortnightly basis.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EC World Reit, Sembmarine, Keppel Corp
summary: Sembmarine is set to hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) in January 2023 to vote on its proposed merger with Keppel Offshore & Marine. EC World Reit's manager is in discussions with creditors over a debt repayment plan after a planned divestment was delayed. The plan will see the Reit's sponsor finance part of a mandatory repayment due Dec 31, with the remainder deferred to Q1 2023. Sembmarine's shares closed 0.7% lower, while Keppel Corp's ended 0.5% down.

site_title: US retail sales grows 7.6% in holiday season: Mastercard
summary: US retail sales increased 7.6% from Nov 1 to Dec 24, driven by steep discounts during the holiday season to clear excess stock. This surpasses Mastercard's forecast of 7.1% growth. Despite the increase, holiday sales growth is lower than last year's 8.5% due to inflation, rising interest rates, and recession concerns. Key sales categories included a 10.6% jump in online sales and 4.4% and 15.1% increases in apparel and restaurants, respectively.

images.alt_text: The value of overall retail purchases dropped 0.6 per cent last month after rising 1.3 per cent in October, Commerce Department data showed on Thursday (Dec 15).

site_title: Gold ticks up in light trade after holiday weekend
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,802.63 per ounce in early Asian hours, driven by a softer dollar and thin trading after the holiday weekend. The dollar index slipped 0.1%, making bullion less expensive for overseas buyers. Inflation data showed US consumer spending rose 0.1% in November, while inflation cooled further. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank may raise interest rates further, according to ECB policymaker Isabel Schnabel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars are pictured on display at Korea Gold Exchange in Seoul, South Korea, August 6, 2020.    REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Novena Global Healthcare’s Nelson Loh arrested after 2 years on the run
summary: Nelson Loh, co-founder of Novena Global Healthcare Group, and his employee Michael Wong, a 43-year-old Singaporean, were arrested and charged with two counts of forgery offenses each after a two-year manhunt. The pair allegedly forged financial statements in 2019 to obtain bank loans totaling S$18 million. They were remanded at the Police Cantonment Complex and are facing up to 10 years in jail and fines if convicted. The arrest was facilitated by China's Ministry of Public Security, which helped bring Loh and Wong back to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Axington may have potential claims against its former directors Marjory Loh and Michael Wong, and the Loh cousins of scandal-hit Bellagraph Nova Group (pictured).
Axington ex-director Marjory Loh declared bankrupt
Novena Global Healthcare's Terence Loh declared bankrupt
Lynn Yeow applied for bankruptcy on the advice of her lawyers (file photo).

site_title: Russia could hike rates in 2023 if inflation risks have big impact: central bank
summary: The Bank of Russia may hike interest rates in 2023 due to growing inflation risks, including labor shortages and import restrictions, according to Deputy Governor Alexei Zabotkin. The central bank held its key interest rate at 7.5% in December but acknowledged these risks, stating that a rate hike may be needed to stabilize inflation at 4% by 2024. Zabotkin cited multiple factors contributing to inflationary pressures, including a structural shift in Russia's economy, and warned that a rate hike will be dictated by these factors in 2023.

images.alt_text: The powerful Security Council consists of 15 members tasked with tackling global crises by enacting sanctions, authorising military action, and approving changes to the UN charter.
Sberbank is one of several major Russian banks to have been blocked from the international Swift payments system and some senior executives have been personally hit by sanctions.

site_title: Why energy transition matters in South-east Asia’s golden decade
summary: South-east Asia, entering its "golden decade," faces significant challenges in accelerating its energy transition due to inadequate grids, regulations, and economic risks brought about by climate change. Despite progress in renewable energy adoption, many markets are heavily reliant on traditional energy systems, and a shift towards decentralisation is crucial to meet growing energy demands. Improving affordability and accessibility of renewable sources, fostering stakeholder collaborations, and changing mindsets are essential to unlock new opportunities and ease the transition towards a sustainable, low-carbon future.

images.alt_text: Vietnam, which has the highest solar power generation capacity in the region, is facing setbacks in its clean energy transition due to inadequate grids and regulations.

site_title: Consumers shop more ‘consciously’ this festive season amid inflation, GST fears: businesses
summary: Singapore consumers are becoming more price-conscious amid rising inflation and the impending 8% GST hike next year. Shoppers are seeking deals and promotions, opting for "bang for their buck" and valuing affordable, long-lasting products. About a third of respondents in a YouGov survey said they would spend less on Christmas this year due to rising costs. However, some customers are willing to pay more for timeless, high-quality items. Retailers expect this trend to continue, with a focus on value-for-money purchases and sustainable fashion.

images.alt_text: People wearing face masks queueing to enter Apple Marina Bay Sands from Basement 2 of The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands on Sept 27, 2020.
People cross a traffic light crossing with Christmas lights outside 313@somerset at Orchard Road, 12 November 2022.

site_title: Getting real about ESG
summary: Sustainable investing has faced challenges, with the climate crisis and volatile markets creating a stark contrast between financial value and values. The war in Ukraine, rising inflation, and higher fossil fuel prices have led investors to question the underlying values and performance of ESG investing. However, evidence of climate change and the energy crisis is driving minds towards long-term thinking and potential investment in renewables. Regulation targeting sustainability is already or soon to be implemented in many markets, indicating a shift towards integrating ESG for value.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks past a residential building damaged by Russian shelling in Kherson on Dec 20, 2022, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Investment

site_title: North Korea’s Kim kicks off key party meeting ahead of New Year
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has kicked off a key meeting of the ruling Workers' Party, state media reported. The Sixth Enlarged Plenary Meeting of the 8th Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK) will discuss major policy decisions ahead of the New Year. The meeting comes amid tensions, including the recent crossing of five North Korean drones into South Korea, and mounting economic challenges due to international sanctions and natural disasters. Kim presented a report highlighting the country's progress and goals for 2023, including increased power in politics, military, economy, and culture.

site_title: New Delhi should heed rising angst over GST system
summary: India's Goods and Services Tax (GST) system has been criticized for concentrating power in New Delhi and hindering state development. Despite being promoted as a "Good and Simple Tax," many traders struggle to manage the system's complexity and high tax rates. Foreign direct investment in manufacturing has shown no significant improvement, contradicting initial claims. The GST has become a "colonial taxation system" with one of the highest rates in the world, and its benefits primarily accrue to economically backward regions, not the economically better-off southern states. Reforms are needed to address these issues and ensure a more equitable distribution of power.

site_title: Russia ready to resume gas supplies to Europe via Yamal-Europe pipeline: Novak
summary: Russia is ready to resume gas supplies to Europe via the Yamal-Europe pipeline, according to Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak. The pipeline, which was stopped in December 2021, was reversed due to Poland's decision to draw on stored gas in Germany. Novak also mentioned discussions on additional gas supplies through Turkey and plans to increase gas supplies to Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan. Russia aims to ship 21 billion cubic meters of liquefied natural gas to Europe in 2022.

images.alt_text: The EU’s ban on Russian oil-product imports comes into force from Feb 5 and is on top of the crude imports restriction imposed in early December.

site_title: Avatar 2 gains US$56 million in storm-hit second weekend
summary: Avatar: The Way of Water earned an estimated US$56 million in its second weekend in the US, despite winter storms. Globally, the film has raked in US$855.4 million since its December 16 release. Domestic ticket sales fell 58% from its opening weekend, but international sales rose, with the film generating US$168.6 million internationally. Despite the challenges, the film's total haul is expected to reach US$82 million domestically over the four-day period.

images.alt_text: The second Avatar film adopts many of the latest visual technologies, including a high frame-rate 3D format that appears to have fallen prey to Japan’s laggard cinema industry.

site_title: For Alstom, a vision for green, smart and healthy regional transportation
summary: Alstom is exploring ways to introduce sustainable and fast mobility to the world, focusing on regional transportation. The company's Asia-Pacific president, Ling Fang, emphasizes the need to put people at the center of design and to address challenges such as weather conditions, stray animals, and pedestrians. Alstom has demonstrated an intelligent obstacle detection and recognition system, and plans to launch pilot programs for mainline autonomous trains in Germany and the Netherlands by 2023. The company aims to reduce carbon emissions from its solutions by 25% by 2025 and envisions a future with electric or low-emission trains, such as hydrogen or battery trains, replacing diesel trains by 2030.

images.alt_text: Alstom makes a sustained push for green solutions in the rail business
The Coradia iLint is the world’s first passenger train to be powered by hydrogen. On Thursday (Sep 15), it successfully travelled 1,175km without refueling its hydrogen tank.

site_title: Moving from sustainability ambition to impact
summary: Asia, home to half the global population and half of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, is a critical region for addressing climate change. Despite making strides forward, the world remains far from a net-zero emissions trajectory. Businesses in the Asia Pacific region face challenges in embedding sustainability within their processes, including a lack of clear strategy, ineffective goal-setting, and dearth of leadership. To drive impact, businesses must prioritize data visibility and leadership to make tangible sustainability investments. Tri-sector collaboration, including government, business, and academia, is crucial for accelerating action and meeting the green line.

images.alt_text: Investment

site_title: OxPay eyes new markets and merchants to grow its revenue
summary: OxPay Financial, a Catalist-listed payment company, is focusing on growing its payment business after a boardroom tussle. The company aims to expand into other countries in the region, with ambitions to double its payment touch points by end-2023. OxPay is also collaborating with Visa, Mastercard, and banks to enable Buy Now, Pay Later (BNPL) and lending platforms, with the expected launch in Q1 2023. The company's group managing director, Henry Tan, is confident about the growth prospects of the business.

images.alt_text: OxPay Financial files police report against certain ex-employees for 'potential wrongdoings' in AGM
OxPay Financial has been ordered by the Employment Claims Tribunal to pay its former chief executive and chief financial officer following their wrongful dismissal claims.

site_title: India’s real-time payments system on quest to leave global footprint
summary: India's real-time payments system, Unified Payments Interface (UPI), has made significant strides since its launch in 2016, with transactions now worth 55% of the country's gross domestic product (GDP). UPI transactions have seen a compounded annual growth rate of 160% over the last five years, with a recent report finding a 650% increase in value and volume in rural- and semi-urban retail counters. The system has expanded globally, with countries such as Nepal, Bhutan, France, and the UK adopting UPI, and plans are underway to link it with Singapore's PayNow for seamless cross-border payments.

images.alt_text: Next year’s optimism for India is driven by strong corporate earnings, a post-pandemic retail boom and an economy set to grow by 6 per cent in the next fiscal year.
India's central bank governor said the collapse of FTX was proof of the 'inherent risks' in cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Japan MOF to raise 10-year JGB coupon to 0.4-0.5% in Jan
summary: Japan's Ministry of Finance plans to raise the 10-year Japanese government bond (JGB) coupon rate to 0.4-0.5% in January, doubling the current 0.2% rate. This move comes after the Bank of Japan's tweak to its yield-curve control policy, which widened its cap on the 10-year bond yield. The new rate would be the highest since November 2015. BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated that the move is not a step towards exiting ultra-loose monetary policy.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - People walk past paper lanterns at a year-end fair in the Nihonbashi district of Tokyo on December 26, 2022. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Amid high interest rates, Reits may want to forgo acquisitions for organic growth instead
summary: Singapore-listed Reits are expected to navigate the challenges posed by high interest rates and slow acquisition growth by focusing on organic growth drivers. Despite falling prices, Reits can benefit from strong structural drivers in warehouses and data centers, as well as the relaxation of Covid restrictions in the hospitality sector. Additionally, Reits owning Singapore assets are well-positioned due to the country's stability and business hub status. With the potential for DPU and NAV growth, investors can consider Singapore Reits as a viable option, offering a spread of 240-310 basis points to the five-year government bond yield.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust reported 21.3 per cent y-o-y growth in tenant sales and 21.9 per cent y-o-y growth in shopper traffic for 9M 2022.
DBS expects Singapore’s economy to slow in 2023, resulting in more cautious business consumer sentiment.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida to replace embattled reconstruction minister Akiba: NHK
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida will replace embattled reconstruction minister Kenya Akiba, who has faced accusations of violating election laws and ties with the Unification Church. Akiba's office has denied the allegations. The move comes amid Kishida's low approval ratings, with the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's ties to the Unification Church cited as a reason. Kishida plans to replace Akiba with former financial services agency minister Tatsuya Ito, and also replace Parliamentary Vice-Minister for Internal Affairs Mio Sugita, who recently apologized for past comments.

images.alt_text: Support for Kishida’s cabinet has fallen to 33.1 per cent from 37.6 per cent a month ago in the Kyodo news poll, his lowest in the agency’s surveys since he took office in October 2021.

site_title: First flight from Singapore to Beijing on Dec 30; more such flights on SIA in coming months
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is reinstating its Singapore to Beijing passenger service every Friday on a fortnightly basis, starting December 30, after a nearly three-year hiatus due to the pandemic. The airline had previously suspended flights in March 2020. The move comes as China has relaxed its zero-Covid-19 policies and lifted travel curbs. SIA also operates flights to and from Shanghai and other Chinese cities, with plans to resume services to Guangzhou in the future.

images.alt_text: People wearing face masks walk on a street, as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreaks continue in Shanghai, China, December 13, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Beijing, Shanghai residents back to work as China limps towards living with Covid
summary: China has begun to transition towards living with Covid-19 after President Xi Jinping scrapped the country's zero-Covid policy. Despite the lifting of curbs, residents in Beijing and Shanghai are still coping with the spread of the virus, with packed subway trains and jammed roads reported. Hospitals are overwhelmed with patients, mostly elderly, and health experts are concerned about the country's statistics and ability to cope with the outbreak. China is expected to suffer further economic strain, but analysts predict a bounce-back next year.

images.alt_text: Commuters ride a subway train during the morning rush hour amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Beijing, China December 26, 2022. REUTERS/Josh Arslan
Even before the curbs were lifted, China’s economy was struggling, with a slump in consumer spending deepening and industrial output growing the slowest since the spring lockdowns.

site_title: Japan’s MUFG to invest US$200m in Indonesian fintech Akulaku
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) will invest $200 million in Indonesian fintech company Akulaku, backed by Alibaba Group. This move is part of MUFG's expansion in Asia, citing Indonesia's economic size and growth potential. The investment follows MUFG's recent purchase of Home Credit units in the Philippines and Indonesia. This is also seen as a precursor to MUFG's planned acquisition of a Japanese buy now pay later company, Kanmu Inc.

site_title: Ooway’s court injunction requests fail: Kitchen Culture
summary: The Singapore High Court dismissed an application from Ooway Group to order five directors of Kitchen Culture to step down or restrain them from exercising directorial powers. Ooway, a substantial shareholder, had sought to convene an EGM to remove the directors, but the court declined to order the firm to register five individuals in Ooway's camp as directors. The court also rejected Ooway's request for declarations that its appointees had been validly elected at the EGM. The outcome leaves minority shareholders with concerns about the board's legitimacy.

images.alt_text: Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company says it will “carry on its business and affairs normally” as it defends against legal proceedings launched by Ooway Group.
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company's sponsor has issued a statement in response to a Dec 7 article published in The Business Times.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Ooway Group became a substantial shareholder of Kitchen Culture in 2020, after it sold 30 per cent of its subsidiary Ooway Technology to Kitchen Culture in exchange for 90 million shares – around 21.2 per cent – of Kitchen Culture.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company says it has “taken swift action” to file corrective notices with Acra on Dec 2 after one of its directors attempted to change the company's records.
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. In its latest statement the company said it “sharply criticised” requisitioners for proceeding with an EGM held on Nov 25.
The meeting was requisitioned by a group of Kitchen Culture shareholders, including Ooway Group, who first requested to remove the incumbent directors in September this year.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture.  The group is urging its shareholders not to attend a Nov 1 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) proposed by requisitioners, as it deems notices for the EGM defective and invalid.

site_title: Sanctions forcing Russia's Sberbank to close UAE office, company says
summary: Russia's Sberbank will close its office in the UAE in the first quarter of 2023 due to sanctions pressure, the bank's first deputy chairman Alexander Vedyakhin said. Sberbank, one of several major Russian banks blocked from the international Swift payments system, will continue serving clients in the UAE market and is exploring options to open an office in China. The bank reported a 84.8% year-on-year slump in net profit in the first 11 months of 2022, but expects to be profitable in December.

images.alt_text: The logo of Russia's state-owned bank. Russia’s largest lender Sberbank has agreed to sell its Kazakh subsidiary to Kazakh state-owned financial holding Baiterek.

site_title: Ukraine to call for Russia's removal from UN Security Council
summary: Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba plans to call for Russia's removal from the UN Security Council on Monday, Dec 26. He questioned Russia's right to remain a permanent member, citing concerns about its actions in Ukraine. The move is part of ongoing efforts to reform the Security Council, which has been criticized for lack of representation and impotence due to veto power held by permanent members. The US has also expressed support for expanding the council to make it more inclusive.

images.alt_text: Vladimir Putin accused the West of trying to cleave Russia apart.

site_title: Sembmarine working towards EGM on proposed merger with Keppel O&M
summary: SembCorp Marine is working towards convening an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for its proposed merger with Keppel O&M, expected to take place in January 2023. The merger, first announced in April 2022, involves Sembmarine acquiring Keppel O&M from Keppel Corp at a revised equity-value exchange ratio of 46:54. Keppel shareholders voted in favor of the merger with 99.96% of votes cast, and regulatory approvals are being sought. The EGM will be held subject to these approvals and other consents being obtained.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Marine's NTA per share will be diluted following the merger

pixkeppel - Keppel provides solutions for sustainable urbanisation. The picture depicts staff at the Keppel Marina East Desalination Plant inspecting the filtration membranes used in the water treatment process.

site_title: Japan insurers in talks with reinsurers to resume coverage in Russian waters
summary: Japanese insurance companies Tokio Marine & Nichido Fire, Sompo Japan Insurance, and Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance are in talks with reinsurers to resume marine war insurance coverage in Russian waters, effective January 1. The decision, prompted by reinsurers' refusal to take on vessel risks related to the war, may impact Japan's imports of liquefied natural gas and other energy commodities. Insurers are negotiating with reinsurers to restore coverage, with some responding positively, to prevent shipowners from halting operations in Russian waters.

images.alt_text: Petronas CEO Tengku Taufik said Petronas would continue its efforts to offset any impact on Japanese customers.

site_title: Strict rules at home push Chinese metaverse entrepreneurs, investors overseas
summary: China's metaverse and web3 entrepreneurs face strict rules at home due to the government's tough stance on cryptocurrency. Despite this, they have turned to overseas markets, particularly South-east Asia, where regulations are more relaxed. Singapore has become a hotspot for Chinese tech talent, with many coders working on web3 projects remotely from China. Investors are seeking opportunities in metaverse and web3 projects, with Chinese private equity firms joining global venture capital investors to invest in local projects. However, the regulatory landscape is changing, with Singapore's financial regulator warning of risks in trading cryptocurrencies following the collapse of FTX.

images.alt_text: Visitors walk past a metaverse stand during Fintech Week 2022 in Hong Kong on November 1, 2022. - Hong Kong hosts a week of financial conferences aimed at resuscitating the Chinese hub's image. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)
A sign indicating digital yuan, also referred to as e-CNY, at a shopping mall in Shanghai, China; May 5, 2021.
The future may lie in a hybrid and connected experience that effectively bridges online and offline advantages.
Customers pulled more than US$3 billion from Binance in a single day last week as part of a three-day frenzy that saw more than US$6 billion withdrawn.

site_title: Investors would be better served if offer announcements had to reference book values
summary: A recent offer by the Tangs to privatize Chip Eng Seng at S$0.72 per share, a 27.3% discount to the company's net asset value (NAV), has raised concerns among investors. The offer price is significantly above the stock's lowest closing price over the last three years, but still below the NAV. This discount is similar to other recent privatizations of property companies in Singapore, which have also been offered at a discount to NAV. Investors are calling for offerors to include more relevant comparisons in their announcements, such as comparisons to NAV, to provide a more accurate picture of the offer price.

images.alt_text: Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers
The assets being disposed of are a strata hotel property and strata restaurant property, and the hotel business.
Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang  (pictured) and her husband Gordon Tang are required to attain more than 90 per cent of the company's shares to take it private.
Celine Tang, managing director of listed developer SingHaiyi Group
Celine Tang, managing director of listed developer SingHaiyi Group
Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang's voluntary conditional cash offer for the property player turns mandatory after she acquires 6.3 million shares in early trade.
The surge in trading volume comes a day after chairman Celine Tang and her husband made an offer to acquire all issued ordinary shares at S$0.72 apiece.
Celine Tang and Gordon Tang also recently privatised SingHaiyi Group at a significant discount to its net asset value.

site_title: OCBC said to hire ex-Goldman’s Jason Moo as its private bank CEO
summary: OCBC announced the hiring of Jason Moo, a former Goldman Sachs executive, as its new private bank CEO. Moo, who spent over 20 years at Goldman Sachs, will start at Bank of Singapore next year, succeeding Bahren Shaari. The move comes as the private banking industry faces competition from global wealth managers and volatile markets. Moo previously held roles at Julius Baer Group and will need to navigate the challenges of navigating the industry's highly competitive landscape.

site_title: South Korea’s SK Group may sell some South-east Asia assets
summary: SK Group, South Korea's second-largest conglomerate, is considering selling some of its assets in South-east Asia to reinvest in other businesses, particularly in Vietnam. The company holds significant stakes in Vietnamese firms Vingroup, Masan Group, and others, with a combined investment worth over $1 billion. SK Group plans to decide which assets to sell based on buyer offers, with the potential to reinvest proceeds in local firms. The move comes as South Korea and Vietnam upgraded their relations to a "comprehensive strategic partnership" earlier this month.

images.alt_text: Nguyen Hung expects TPBank’s total assets to rise at least 14 per cent next year.

site_title: Asia: Stocks start week positively
summary: Asian stocks started the week positively, driven by gains on Wall Street despite concerns over sluggish growth next year. A slowing US inflation rate and cautious gains in Shanghai, Tokyo, and Seoul were key factors. However, spiraling Covid-19 cases in China and the potential for Russia to cut oil production weighed on sentiment. Analysts predicted caution until more concrete signs of controlled inflation emerge, with the Federal Reserve closely monitoring the personal consumption expenditures price index.

images.alt_text: A glum warning from top chipmaker Micron and worries about China’s surging Covid cases added to the less-than-Christmassy mood on trading floors.

site_title: China to end quarantine for HK border as soon as Jan 3:  SCMP
summary: China is considering lifting quarantine requirements for cross-border travelers between Hong Kong and the mainland as early as January 3, according to a report by the South China Morning Post. Under the "0+3" policy, travelers would not need to quarantine for five days, but instead observe three days of medical surveillance. This plan comes after Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee announced plans to reopen borders with mainland China before mid-January, with top officials meeting to discuss details of a plan to fully reopen the border, which has been effectively shut for almost three years.

images.alt_text: Travellers from overseas will still be required to present a negative nucleic acid test certificate for entry, the Macau government said.

site_title: Pound’s tentative recovery masks worst year since Brexit vote
summary: The pound's recent recovery is seen as tentative, with many analysts doubting its sustainability due to ongoing economic concerns in the UK. The currency has surged from an all-time low in September but is still down 11% in 2022, its worst year since the Brexit vote in 2016. Central bank policy divergence and a weakening UK economy are expected to limit room for gains in 2023, with some predicting a decline in the pound against the US dollar to around $1.14 by the end of the first quarter.

site_title: Five financial trends that 2022 killed
summary: Financial markets experienced significant reversals in 2022, including the end of cheap money as interest rates rose. This trend reversed a decade-long expectation that rates would remain near zero. Other notable reversals included companies becoming less effective at layoffs and the "bull market in everything" coming to an end with a crash in stock and bond prices in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: At its lowest point in 2022, the S&P 500 index of leading American shares was down by almost a quarter, erasing more than US$10trn in market value.
In the US, all eyes are on prices and labour markets, and what they portend for Federal Reserve policy.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda dismisses near-term chance of exiting easy policy
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda dismissed the possibility of exiting ultra-loose monetary policy in the near term, citing the need for sustained wage growth to achieve the 2% inflation target. The BOJ widened its yield target band last week to ease the costs of prolonged stimulus, but Kuroda emphasized that this was not a step towards policy normalization. Labour shortages and structural changes in Japan's job market are expected to lead to higher pay for temporary workers and permanent workers, potentially increasing wage growth and helping the BOJ achieve its inflation target.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy unexpectedly shrank an annualised 0.8 per cent in the third quarter as global recession risks and higher import costs weighed on consumption and businesses.

site_title: King Charles invokes late Queen and faith in humanity in Christmas message
summary: King Charles III delivered his first Christmas message as monarch, invoking his late mother Queen Elizabeth and speaking of his faith in humanity during a time of "great anxiety and hardship." He praised charities providing support during the nation's cost-of-living crisis, citing footage of staff at food banks and hospital workers. Charles also highlighted community spirit, referencing his son William and wife Kate's recent visit to Wales. The message was delivered from St George's Chapel, where Elizabeth delivered a Christmas message in 1999.

images.alt_text: The new 50 pence piece features an effigy of Charles, who became king after the death of his mother Queen Elizabeth II in September.

site_title: Hong Kong plans to reopen border with China in weeks
summary: Hong Kong plans to reopen its border with China in weeks, aiming to return to pre-Covid cross-border travel arrangements. The border, effectively shut for almost three years, will "open fully in a gradual, orderly way," with daily traveler quotas and quarantine policies to be discussed. The move is expected to boost Hong Kong's GDP by 7.6% and follows China's plan to cut quarantine requirements for overseas travelers in January.

images.alt_text: Beijing fully supports Chief Executive John Lee and his administration’s efforts to respond to society’s concerns, kickstart the economy, and resolve the city’s deep-seated problems, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said.

site_title: This year was the beginning of a green transition
summary: This year marked a turning point in the world's transition to clean energy, driven by extreme weather events, economic pressures, and policy changes. The US passed the Inflation Reduction Act, investing $370 billion in clean industries, while Europe accelerated its shift towards renewable energy due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Elections in Australia and Brazil also set the stage for further climate policies. Despite challenges, the rapid growth in renewables has almost outweighed the shift towards coal, and clean energy is poised to win the day, with innovations in solar panels, electric vehicles, and heat pumps making them more affordable.

images.alt_text: Smokestacks belch noxious fumes into the air from a massive coal-fired power plant on the Indonesian coast, a stark illustration of Asia's addiction to the fossil fuel which is threatening climate targets.

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: Is a global recession really around the corner?
summary: A global recession is not inevitable and may not be as severe as predicted. Despite economists' concerns, the chances of a recession in 2023 are below 100%, with a 50% chance of a recession in 2023 and a 75% chance in the next two years. Europe is more likely to enter a recession due to soaring energy prices, while China's growth is expected to slow significantly but is unlikely to contract for two quarters. The US has made policy mistakes, including relinquishing leadership of the liberal international order and ignoring trade frameworks.

images.alt_text: China is now not set to overtake the US as the world’s largest economy until 2036 at the earliest — six years later than expected.
Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of GDP, is projected to barely grow in the middle half of the year.

Instead of the common definition of a recession as two straight quarters of negative growth, the United States' National Bureau of Economic Research decides whether the country has entered a recession based on a range of indicators.

site_title: Chinese cities see Covid peaking in January as official data gets obscured
summary: China is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases, with cities and provinces reporting hundreds of thousands of daily infections, surpassing the official national tally. The National Health Commission will stop publishing daily COVID surveillance data, which was seen as underestimating the illness's spread. Outbreaks are expected to peak in January, complicating the assessment of the toll on the economy, which is already unknown due to the lack of accurate data.

images.alt_text: On Sunday, China expanded the use of a homegrown Covid vaccine.
Even before the curbs were lifted, China’s economy was struggling, with a slump in consumer spending deepening and industrial output growing the slowest since the spring lockdowns.

site_title: Climate change is all around in the movies
summary: Climate change is a prominent theme in various films across different genres, serving as a warning and a commentary on its consequences. From documentaries like "Chasing Coral" and "David Attenborough: A Life on Our Planet" to dystopian thrillers like "Snowpiercer" and "The Day After Tomorrow", these movies showcase the devastating effects of climate change. Other notable films include "Waterworld", "Interstellar", "FernGully", "Soylent Green", "Princess Mononoke", and "Alcarràs", which all feature climate change as a central plot point. These films aim to raise awareness and inspire action to address the pressing issue of climate change.

images.alt_text: Scientists, engineers and administrators from the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories at the Department of Energy headquarters in Washington, DC, after the announcement of a breakthrough in fusion research on Dec 13, 2022 in Washington, DC.

site_title: ESG investors shift focus to transitioning high-emissions industries, impact in 2023
summary: ESG investors are shifting focus to transitioning high-emissions industries and prioritizing impact in 2023, driven by inflation and energy crises. This trend is expected to help steel producers tackle low-carbon steel production hurdles. Fund managers and analysts emphasize the need for a more sustainable world, despite a potentially messy and expensive transition. As a result, investors are finding bargains in industries such as Big Oil and exploring green technologies like carbon capture and storage.

images.alt_text: Australia's OneSteel Whyalla Steelworks plant.

People stop and have their picture taken at the COP15 logo during the United the Nations Biodiversity Conference (COP15) at the Palais des congrès de Montréal in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on December 16, 2022. - Montreal is expected to have at least 10cm (4 inches) of snow throughout the day. (Photo by ANDREJ IVANOV / AFP)
Hsieh is a banking and capital markets veteran who had notably served as UOB chairman, president of state-owned investor Temasek Holdings, and chairman of Tiger Airways.

CIX chief executive Mikkel Larsen said CIX and Carbonplace will now use outcomes from the pilot to explore how they can “most effectively” integrate their platforms and bring this new capability to the market.
Bursa Malaysia opened an exchange this month, joining more than a dozen that are underway or planned across the region.
At present, China’s green funds only operate within broad investment guidelines that came into effect in 2018 and do not have a mandatory labelling regime.

site_title: World economy is headed for a recession in 2023, researcher says
summary: The world economy is expected to face a recession in 2023 due to higher borrowing costs and inflation. The Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR) predicts this due to central bankers' efforts to control inflation, despite economic costs. China will not surpass the US as the world's largest economy until 2036, six years later than expected, and the East Asia and Pacific region will account for over a third of global output by 2037.

images.alt_text: resident Xi Jinping has sought to mend frayed ties with the US and its allies, holding his first in-person summit with President Joe Biden in Bali, Indonesia, last month.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to expand chip production at largest plant next year: media
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to expand its largest semiconductor plant in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, by adding 12-inch wafers capacity for Dram memory chips and 4-nanometre chip capacity under foundry contracts. The move, expected to be completed next year, will help the company maintain its market share in memory chips despite forecasts of an economic slowdown. This contrasts with rival chipmakers' scaling back of investments amid falling demand and a glut of chips. Analysts believe Samsung's persistence with investment plans will support its share price when demand recovers.

images.alt_text: Samsung plans to invest US$2 billion more into Vietnam, raising its total to US$20 billion.

site_title: China banks rush traders back to office amid Covid disruptions
summary: Chinese financial institutions are rushing traders back to office amid the surge of Omicron variant cases. Sinolink Securities has asked staff who were off sick or home quarantined to return to work if they no longer show Covid symptoms, citing disruptions to operations. The company prioritizes employee well-being, workplace safety, and business continuity. This move follows Beijing's swift dismantling of Covid Zero restrictions, leading to the spread of the highly contagious Omicron variant in a population with low natural immunity.

images.alt_text: Even before the curbs were lifted, China’s economy was struggling, with a slump in consumer spending deepening and industrial output growing the slowest since the spring lockdowns.

site_title: China stops releasing daily Covid data as accuracy questioned
summary: China's National Health Commission has stopped publishing daily Covid-19 case numbers due to accuracy concerns, with some cities reporting significantly higher infection rates than the official tally. Millions are believed to have contracted the virus nationwide, with 248 million people likely infected in the first 20 days of December. Hospitals and crematoriums are struggling to cope with the surge, and cities such as Zhejiang and Dongguan have reported over 1 million and 250,000 daily cases, respectively. The decision comes as China expands the use of its homegrown Covid vaccine for those three and above.

images.alt_text: Even before the curbs were lifted, China’s economy was struggling, with a slump in consumer spending deepening and industrial output growing the slowest since the spring lockdowns.

site_title: China aims to rebuild US ties in diplomatic push for 2023
