summary: China aims to rebuild US ties through diplomatic efforts for 2023, with President Xi Jinping seeking to mend frayed relations after a decade of assertive foreign policy. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that the country will increase communication with Europe and deepen mutual trust with Russia, while following through on a consensus reached with US President Joe Biden. China will also focus on implementing agreements and oppose any hegemony or bullying, without naming specific nations. This push aims to bring bilateral relations back on track after a collapse in public support.

images.alt_text: Shoppers at a Miniso store on Nanjing Road shopping street in Shanghai. Consumption will be a major indicator to watch to assess how well the economy will fare in 2023.

site_title: Nio CEO warns of sales challenges in first half on China demand
summary: Nio's CEO, William Li, warns of sales challenges in the first half of 2024 due to declining government subsidies and a broader economic slowdown in China, the world's largest new-energy vehicle market. The company plans to roll out its first mass-market model in 2024, which is expected to take time to recover from the pandemic. Li expects a full recovery by May or June, as customers may place orders before the end of the year when national subsidies for electric vehicles are phased out.

images.alt_text: At the weekend event in Hefei in central Anhui province, Shanghai-based Nio launched a revamped ES8, an iteration of the original electric sports utility vehicle it’s been selling since 2018.

site_title: After AIG, Greenbergs build US$6b fortune and push into China
summary: Maurice "Hank" Greenberg, co-founder of American International Group (AIG), has built a US$6 billion fortune alongside his son Evan, who is CEO of Chubb. The Greenbergs have a long history in China, dating back over a century, and are now expanding their business interests in the country. Following a message from Chinese leader Xi Jinping, Chubb acquired a majority stake in Chinese insurer Huatai Insurance Group, marking a significant step in the family's China expansion efforts. The Greenbergs' efforts to improve US-China relations have been recognized, with Evan Greenberg urging Americans to engage with China in non-sensitive areas.

images.alt_text: AIG, FP’s largest remaining creditor, had been accused of misleading investors about its exposure to subprime mortgages and credit default swaps during the financial crisis of 2008.

site_title: China must raise self-reliance in agricultural technology, Xi says
summary: China's President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for self-reliance in agricultural technology, urging the sector to "vigorously improve" its science and technology with more efficient innovation. Key areas to focus on include seed development and core equipment. Despite significant investment in basic research, China lacks large commercial companies that can bring innovative solutions to the market. Xi's comments come after the central leadership identified the seed industry as a weak link in the food chain in 2020, highlighting the need for improvement in innovation and commercialization.

site_title: Taiwan reports China’s largest incursion yet to air defence zone
summary: China has conducted its largest reported air incursion into Taiwan's air defense zone, with 71 aircraft, including fighter jets and drones, entering the zone over the past 24 hours. The incursion included 43 aircraft that crossed the Taiwan Strait's median line, an unofficial buffer between the two sides. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has increased military activities near the island in recent years. Taiwan's government says it wants peace but will defend itself if attacked.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese and Taiwanese printed flags are seen in this illustration taken, April 28, 2022. Picture taken April 28, 2022.  REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam’s TPBank sees 2023 profit jump, in foreign loan talks
summary: TPBank, Vietnam's pioneer in adopting automation technology, expects a 15% rise in pretax profit next year, driven by cost savings from robotic process automation and machine learning. The bank has reduced operational costs by 30% and plans to increase its customer base to 10 million from 8 million. TPBank also has 500 Live-Bank machines, allowing clients to deposit and transfer money digitally. The lender is in talks with foreign partners to fund an expansion, amid growing interest from overseas investors. Total assets are expected to rise at least 14% next year.

images.alt_text: The looming maturity wall risks triggering a wave of defaults that could turn the property woes into a wider crisis for the banking sector and the economy.

site_title: Savage US blizzard leaves 31 dead, power outages, travel snarls
summary: A severe winter storm brought extreme snow and frigid cold to the eastern US on Christmas Day, leaving at least 31 people dead and millions without power. The blizzard, which affected all 48 contiguous states, stranded travelers, canceled over 2,400 flights, and caused widespread power outages, with some residents not expected to regain power until Tuesday. The city of Buffalo, New York, was particularly hard hit, with 2.4-meter snow drifts and treacherous road conditions. Officials described the situation as "dangerous" and "life-threatening."

images.alt_text: resident Xi Jinping has sought to mend frayed ties with the US and its allies, holding his first in-person summit with President Joe Biden in Bali, Indonesia, last month.

site_title: Tesla’s ugly December and other omens for the auto industry
summary: Tesla's stock value plummeted $219 billion in December, rivaling Toyota's worth, amid concerns over CEO Elon Musk's focus on Twitter. The automaker's struggles come as a tough economy, high inflation, and rising interest rates challenge growth. Meanwhile, General Motors is poised to ramp up electric vehicle production in 2023, and autonomous vehicle companies like Cruise and Waymo will face tests in the coming year. The used-car industry is also facing challenges, with Carvana's debt restructuring uncertain, and auto-lending profits expected to fall 35% this year.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has previously made promises about not selling Tesla stock before subsequently selling it.
FILE PHOTO: A Tesla electric vehicle is seen through a charging point displayed during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 20, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Crypto is ‘effectively non-existent’ for big institutions, JPMorgan’s Gross says
summary: JPMorgan's Jared Gross says crypto is "effectively non-existent" for big institutions due to its high volatility and lack of intrinsic return. This sentiment comes as Bitcoin has shed 60% of its value in 2022 and Ether has tumbled 70%. Despite past hopes that crypto could be a digital gold or haven asset, it has failed to provide inflation protection. Most institutional investors are breathing a sigh of relief that they didn't invest in crypto and are unlikely to do so in the future.

images.alt_text: About US$2.3 trillion was wiped from the crypto market this past year, according to data from CoinGecko.
India's central bank governor said the collapse of FTX was proof of the 'inherent risks' in cryptocurrencies.

site_title: China’s economy is showing increasing strain from the Covid tsunami
summary: China's economy continues to show strain from the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak, with a contraction in activity in December according to Bloomberg's aggregate index of eight early indicators. Industrial output grew at its slowest pace since spring lockdowns, and consumer spending remains weak. The lifting of domestic restrictions has allowed the virus to circulate freely, impacting home and car sales, as well as industrial output. The spread of the virus also undermines confidence among small businesses and has led to a drop in global trade, potentially affecting China's exports.

images.alt_text: “The CBIRC will urge banking institutions to increase consumer loans appropriately,” the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) said in a statement.

site_title: Wednesday on a loop for markets?
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to remain volatile in 2023 due to lower consumer demand and elevated operating costs. Despite a sharp decline in the price-to-earnings (PE) ratio, investors should not avoid equities, as China's reopening is expected to boost demand. The Singapore market's Sentiment Index (STI) is currently trading at 10.7x 2023 earnings, which is -2 standard deviations below its 15-year historical average. Analysts predict a potential 8.9% decline or 11.5% upside from current levels depending on sentiment improvement in the second half of 2023.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
On the Singapore bourse, some 954.9 million shares worth a total of S$926.2 million were traded, with losers beating gainers 318 to 228.
Singapore-listed stocks could be negatively impacted by the triple threats of higher debt, tax and wage costs.

site_title: Equity funds record largest ever weekly outflows
summary: US investors recorded the largest ever weekly outflows from equity funds, with a net US$41.9 billion sold in the week to Wednesday, December 21. This was attributed to "tax loss harvesting" strategy, where assets are sold at a loss to offset capital gains taxes. US value funds and passive equities also saw record weekly net outflows of US$17.2 billion and US$27.8 billion, respectively.

site_title: US Congress clears US$1.7t spending package, averting shutdown
summary: US Congress has cleared a $1.7 trillion government funding package, averting a shutdown. The bill, sent to President Joe Biden's desk, includes significant increases to national security and domestic spending, with $858 billion for the military and $772 billion for education, health, and veterans programs. The measure caps off a year of bipartisan progress and ensures the government remains open through September 30. A one-week stopgap bill was also approved to prevent a shutdown while the legislation is processed.

images.alt_text:
epa09664290 (19/24) (FILE) - Pro-Trump protesters occupy the grounds of the West Front of the US Capitol, including the inaugural stage and viewing stands, in Washington, DC, USA, 06 January 2021 (reissued 03 January 2021). Following the November 2020 US presidential election, a tone set by supporters of defeated US President Donald Trump escalated further. Trump, who was refusing to concede the victory of Joe Biden, claiming voter fraud and rigged elections, told supporters and white nationalist extreme-right group Proud Boys to respectively 'Stop the Steal' and to 'stand back and stand by'. His social media accounts were suspended and the alt-right platform Parler gained in user numbers.

On 06 January 2021, incumbent US vice president Pence was due to certify the Electoral College votes before Congress, the last step in the process before President-elect Biden was to be sworn in. In the morning, pro-Trump protesters had gathered for the so-called Save America March. Soon after Trump finished his speech at the Ellipse, the crowd marched to the Capitol. The attack had begun.

Rioters broke into the Capitol building where the joint Congress session was being held. Lawmakers barricaded themselves inside the chambers and donned tear gas masks while rioters vandalized the building, some even occupying offices such as House Speaker Pelosi's. Eventually in the evening the building was cleared from insurrectionists, and the Congress chambers reconvened their session, confirming Joe Biden as the winner of the 2020 US presidential election.

In the aftermath, more than 600 people were charged with federal crimes in connection to the insurgency, and close Trump aides such as Steve Bannon, Mark Meadows and Roger Stone were subpoenaed by the House select committee investigating the attack. Trump himself was acquitted by the Senate in his second impeachment trial, this time for "inciting an insurrection".  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS  ATTENTION: This Image is part of a PHOTO SET

site_title: Divers hunting for Germany’s stolen ‘Green Vault’ artefacts
summary: Police divers in Berlin are searching the Landwehr Canal as part of the investigation into the 2019 looting of Germany's "Green Vault" treasures. A preliminary haul of 31 items, including a diamond-encrusted dagger and pearl necklace, was recovered, estimated to be worth over US$1 billion. The search operation is ongoing and no further information is available. This is one of several high-profile heists at German museums in recent years, with no insurance coverage on the stolen items due to high premiums.

images.alt_text: The site, about 35 km southwest of Bethlehem, has been known for generations as the Cave of Salome.

site_title: WealthBT: Investment guardrails for your portfolio (Ep 21)
summary: WealthBT podcast discusses investment guardrails for portfolios, citing a challenging 2022 environment where hope and reality often clashed. Experts highlight cash as a guardrail due to attractive fixed deposit rates and capital preservation, while dividends and bond coupons can cushion portfolio declines. Alternative assets, such as those with illiquidity, and personal resilience are also emphasized as guardrails. The podcast aims to provide general information, not investment advice, and encourages listeners to consult professional advisors.

images.alt_text: How can you be sure your ESG investments are doing good?
Find out how much planning goes into succession or wealth transfer from Angie Han, head of wealth planning at Pictet Wealth Management.
2022 has been particularly challenging for older investors who need to draw on their portfolios for living expenses.

site_title: US speeds up timeline in delisting threat for Chinese companies
summary: The US Congress passed legislation to speed up the timeline for delisting Chinese companies from the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq if regulators can't fully review their audit work papers. The provision, included in a $1.7 trillion government funding package, reduces the timeline from three years to two years. The move is aimed at increasing transparency and accountability for foreign companies listed on US exchanges, amid ongoing tensions with China over national security concerns. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board will review the situation, which could affect around 200 companies from Hong Kong and China.

images.alt_text: To ensure that the government does not run out of funds and shut down at the end of Friday as the legislation is processed, the House has also approved a one-week stopgap bill.
The Hang Seng Tech Index has surged about 50 per cent since an October trough.

site_title: Putin says Russia ready to negotiate over Ukraine, Kyiv voices doubts
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin stated that Russia is open to negotiations over the war in Ukraine, but only on Russia's terms, which include Ukraine accepting Moscow's annexation of four regions. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's adviser expressed doubt about Putin's willingness to negotiate, saying Russia is not interested in talks and is trying to avoid responsibility. The conflict has resulted in the deadliest European war since World War II, with no end in sight, as both sides maintain their positions, with Kyiv seeking the removal of Russian soldiers and the Kremlin vowing to fight until its aims are achieved.

images.alt_text: epa10298067 Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulates personnel and veterans of the Russia's Interior Ministry agencies on their professional holiday, in Moscow, Russia, 10 November 2022.  EPA-EFE/MIKHAIL METZEL / KREMLIN POOL / SPUTNIK MANDATORY CREDIT
Russian President Vladimir Putin hailed the launch of  Kovykta gas field as a “significant event” for Russia’s energy industry and the whole economy.

site_title: US orders Mastercard to stop blocking competing payment networks
summary: The US government has ordered Mastercard to stop blocking competing payment networks to process debit payments. Under a proposed order, Mastercard must provide customer account information to competing networks, benefiting consumers and merchants. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) enforced this move, which is seen as a victory for consumers and businesses relying on debit card payments.

images.alt_text: Mastercard Inc. credit and debit cards are arranged for a photograph in Arlington, Virginia, U.S. on Monday, April 29, 2019. Mastercard Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 30. Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

site_title: US new-home sales unexpectedly increase for a second month
summary: US new-home sales unexpectedly increased 5.8% to 640,000 annualized pace in November, following a 5.8% rise in October. The sales data may be influenced by a mid-month retreat in 30-year mortgage rates below 7% and increased builder incentives. However, the housing market faces headwinds due to elevated home prices and potential interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve, which may persist into 2023.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio launches new models, upgraded battery swaps
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio unveiled two new models, the revamped ES8 and the EC7, at its annual customer event in Hefei, China. The ES8, starting at 528,000 yuan, targets buyers seeking sporty performance, while the EC7, priced at 488,000 yuan, offers more space and sporty performance. Nio also showcased upgraded battery swapping stations, capable of 408 swaps per day, and a power swapping pilot for highways. The company aims to expand its product lineup to compete in the slowing Chinese EV market, with deliveries expected to kick off in May and June.

images.alt_text: The auto industry has been forced to spend billions of dollars to strengthen its data protection systems as it deals with a wave of cyberattacks.

site_title: Fontainebleau Las Vegas gets US$2.2b to finish construction
summary: Fontainebleau Las Vegas, a long-delayed resort on the Las Vegas Strip, has secured a US$2.2 billion loan to complete construction. The 67-story hotel, featuring a casino and convention space, is scheduled for completion in the fourth quarter of 2023. The total project cost is US$3.7 billion, with a two-level mall expected to have over 35 designer stores. Financing came from a group of investors including Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, Blackstone, and Goldman Sachs Group.

images.alt_text: The casino component of the UAE resort is shaping up to be somewhat larger than Wynn Las Vegas (pictured).

site_title: Amazon is trying to fill empty space on its air cargo flights as consumer demand cools
summary: Amazon is seeking to fill empty space on its air cargo flights as consumer demand cools, a move to adjust to a slowdown in online growth. The e-commerce retailer, which operates a fleet of 100 planes, has hired executives to market cargo space, including charter flights and using planes returning from Hawaii and Alaska. Despite a slowdown, Amazon remains committed to its long-term goal of boosting profits, with plans to add 10 Airbus A330-300 freighters and trim its fleet. The effort is part of Amazon's broader strategy to address slowing online sales and a fragile economy.

images.alt_text: Amazon has agreed not to use sellers’ data for its own competing retail business and its private label products.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic hopes for warm welcome on Australian Open return
summary: Novak Djokovic is set to return to the Australian Open next month, hoping for a warm welcome from the public after his deportation from the tournament in 2022. The nine-time champion was banned from entering Australia again due to his vaccination stance, but the decision has been reversed. Djokovic expressed his excitement to compete for a 10th title in Melbourne and a men's record-equalling 22nd major crown. He finished the 2022 season strong, winning titles in Tel Aviv, Astana, and the ATP Finals, and is now focused on playing into his 40s.

images.alt_text: This year’s Australian Open was in January overshadowed by nine-time champion Novak Djokovic being put on a plane on the eve of the contest after a high-stakes legal battle over his visa status.

site_title: France's Safran to pay US$17.2m to settle China bribery charges in US probe
summary: French jet engine maker Safran agreed to pay the US$17.2 million to settle charges of bribing Chinese officials for lucrative train contracts. The settlement involves Safran's US-based subsidiary, Monogram Systems, and its German unit, Evac. The company will turn over profits from corruptly obtained contracts and has taken internal measures, including firing an employee involved in the misconduct. Safran will continue to cooperate with the US Justice Department's ongoing investigation.

site_title: IRS delays US$600 income reporting rule for US gig workers
summary: The US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has delayed a rule requiring more extensive reporting by gig workers and others paid over $600 through third-party apps. The original rule, part of the American Rescue Plan, would have required reporting of income earned through these platforms in 2022. The delay applies to money earned in 2023, allowing the agency to address concerns about the timeline of implementation. The rule change will now be applied in 2023, rather than 2022 as initially planned.

site_title: Pictet says funds holding US$14b lose top ESG designation
summary: Pictet Asset Management, a major European investment manager, will remove the top ESG designation from approximately $14 billion of client savings, affecting four thematic equity funds. The funds will be reclassified as Article 8, a less stringent designation, due to stricter EU regulatory guidance. This move brings the total amount of client assets affected by downgrades to over $140 billion. The decision follows a wave of reclassifications in Europe's ESG market, sparking concerns about greenwashing risks and investor transparency.

images.alt_text: A plan by Europe’s markets watchdog, ESMA, to set quantifiable ESG and sustainable investing standards is forcing portfolio managers to rethink how they design and market an ESG fund class known as Article 8.

site_title: Europe: Shares end the week before Christmas higher
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed flat on Friday, poised for a 0.6% weekly gain, after a turbulent week marked by recession fears and hawkish central banks. Despite US data showing a tight labor market, investors weighed better-than-expected corporate earnings against macroeconomic concerns. European markets were subdued, with Germany's Dax rising 0.2%, while shares of miners and industrials rose. The index is expected to recoup some of last week's 3.3% loss, which was driven by concerns of a recession.

images.alt_text: The region-wide Stoxx 600 index closed 1.7 per cent higher.

site_title: Here’s where housing prices are cooling the most
summary: Global housing prices rose 8.8% in the third quarter, down from 10.9% at their peak, but adjusted for inflation, that's a 0.3% decline year-over-year. South Korea, Hong Kong, Peru, China, and New Zealand saw declines, while the US market cooled due to higher mortgage rates. Countries like Portugal, Singapore, and Ireland saw double-digit increases. 16 out of 150 cities tracked by Knight Frank saw price drops, with Wellington leading the way with a 17.3% decline. The slowdown in prices is taking longer than expected, with markets with large interest rate jumps starting to see a decline.

images.alt_text: Over 18,000 new private homes, excluding executive condominiums, are slated for completion in 2023, said OrangeTee in a report released on Friday.
A separate report found sales that of previously owned homes fell for a 10th-straight month in November .

site_title: South Korea's parliament passes 2023 budget bill
summary: South Korea's parliament approved the 2023 budget bill, valued at 638.7 trillion won, with a 6% reduction from the previous year's budget. The approved budget aims to cut the fiscal deficit to 0.6% of GDP from 3.3% this year, with a focus on strengthening government finances. The new government plans to contain debt growth by maintaining a fiscal deficit of 0.5-0.6% in the next few years, following President Yoon Suk-yeol's pledge to strengthen government finances.

images.alt_text: The South Korea government predicted Asia’s fourth-largest economy would see growth slowing to 1.6 per cent in 2023 from an estimated 2.5 per cent this year.
President Yoon, struggling against low approval ratings, says exports are the best choice for the manufacturing-heavy country to overcome its slump.

site_title: Olympics: IOC raises prospect of boxing being pulled from Paris Games
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has raised concerns about the International Boxing Association (IBA) and its involvement in the 2024 Paris Games, potentially leading to boxing's exclusion from the event. The IBA was stripped of involvement in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics and has not shown interest in the sport or its athletes. The IOC is organizing qualifying for the Paris 2024 boxing tournament, but may cancel the sport due to IBA's lack of commitment, citing a "no real interest" in the sport or its athletes.

images.alt_text: As part of the launch, Volocopter, a German developer of electric vertical take-off and landing craft or eVTOLs, as flying taxis are known, carried out a flight integrated into conventional air traffic.
“‘Phryges aim to show that sport can change everything, and that it deserves a prominent place in our society,” Paris 2024 brand director Julie Matikhine said Monday (Nov 14).

site_title: US core capital goods orders rise modestly in November
summary: US core capital goods orders rose 0.2% in November, a modest increase, after a 0.3% rise in October. Shipments of core capital goods fell 0.1% in November. The data suggests a slowdown in business spending on equipment, driven by higher borrowing costs and cooling demand. Economists attribute the moderation to slowing price increases, a strong US dollar, and a shift in spending from goods to services. This may hurt manufacturing, which accounts for 11.3% of the economy.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, edged up 0.1 per cent, the Commerce Department said on Friday (Dec 23).

site_title: Indonesia aims to export natural gas to Vietnam in 2026
summary: Indonesia plans to export natural gas to Vietnam starting in 2026 from the Tuna offshore block, with an estimated daily production of 100-150 million standard cubic feet per day. The Tuna oilfield, discovered in April 2014, will be operated by Harbour Energy. The gas pipeline will be built to deliver the gas to Vietnam.

site_title: Twitter probed by top EU privacy watchdog for pre-Musk era leak
summary: Ireland's Data Protection Commission launched a probe into Twitter over a suspected data breach affecting 5.4 million users, with reports of user personal data being made available online. The probe may result in fines of up to 4% of Twitter's annual sales under the EU's General Data Protection Regulation. The investigation comes as Elon Musk's takeover of Twitter raises concerns about the company's ability to protect user data, following a series of staff cuts and changes to its regulatory compliance.

site_title: What’s in store for China’s GDP, fiscal policy in 2023
summary: China's government has set policy priorities for 2023, focusing on stabilizing growth and expanding domestic demand. The main priorities include boosting consumption, supporting private businesses, and stabilizing the property sector. Fiscal policy will be more forceful, while monetary policy will be targeted and forceful but prudent. Economists expect China's GDP growth to range from 3% to 5.8% in 2023, with consumption being a key indicator of the economy's performance. The government is also expected to maintain a proactive fiscal policy, with a possible increase in the fiscal deficit ratio to support the economic recovery.

images.alt_text: The statement says that the government will take steps to expand domestic demand, prioritise consumption recovery, and achieve major economic targets in 2023.

After three years of strict Covid Zero restrictions, a crackdown on financial risk in the property market and targeting excessive growth of Internet platform companies, President Xi Jinping now appears to be loosening the reins.
The World Bank now sees China’s economy growing 2.7 per cent this year and 4.3 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Russia may raise crude oil exports if EU ban cuts refining
summary: Russia may increase crude oil exports if the EU ban on Russian oil-product imports leads to lower refinery throughput, according to Vice Prime Minister Alexander Novak. The EU ban on Russian oil-product imports comes into force on February 5, on top of a crude imports restriction imposed in early December. Novak stated that oil refining could be replaced by additional oil exports if there are problems with selling petroleum products, but also noted that the ban may not affect Russian oil refining.

site_title: UOB, OCBC make board changes
summary: UOB has appointed Ong Chong Tee as an independent director, effective January 1, 2023. Ong, a former deputy managing director of financial supervision at the Monetary Authority of Singapore, brings experience and skills to the role. Meanwhile, OCBC has appointed Andrew Lee Kok Keng as non-executive board chairman, replacing outgoing chairman Ooi Sang Kuang, who retires on January 31, 2023. Both appointments were made after thorough assessments by the banks' nominating committees.

images.alt_text: With effect from Jul 1, deputy chairman Ong Chong Tee will become Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (“ACRA”) Board’s new chairman, filling the shoes of the outgoing chairman Tan Ching Yee, said the Ministry of Finance on Wednesday (Jun 22).

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Headline inflation in Singapore remained steady at 6.7% in November, with most broad categories seeing prices hold steady. Factory output contracted 3.2% year-on-year, while Malaysia's inflation rate held steady at 4% in November. Singapore hotel average room rates slipped for the second straight month. Despite gloomy macroeconomic data, local shares ended the week in the red, down 0.4%.

site_title: Oil rises US$3 per barrel after Russia signals output cut due to price cap
summary: Oil prices rose $3 per barrel after Russia signaled it may cut crude output in response to the G7 price cap. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude both recorded their biggest weekly gains since October, with Brent crude settling at $83.92 and WTI crude at $79.56. Russia may cut oil output by 5-7% in early 2023, citing the price cap. A winter storm in the US is expected to lead to shut-ins in oil production, further supporting price gains. Analysts predict prices could move back above $100 per barrel next year.

images.alt_text: The rosy data increased concerns the Fed was more likely to intensify its rate hikes in a move that could slow the economy and hamper fuel consumption.

site_title: Alameda’s Ellison says she, Bankman-Fried agreed to mislead FTX lenders
summary: Former Alameda Research CEO Caroline Ellison and FTX co-founder Gary Wang have pleaded guilty to fraud charges, admitting they misled lenders about Alameda's borrowing from FTX. Ellison said she and Bankman-Fried agreed to conceal the arrangement, crafting false financial statements to hide billions in loans made to FTX executives. Wang stated he was "directed" to make changes to FTX's code to give Alameda special privileges. The guilty pleas undermine Bankman-Fried's defense that he was unaware of Alameda's activities, as he repeatedly claimed ignorance in interviews following FTX's bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo illustration taken on November 13, 2022, shows the logo of cryptocurrency FTX, reflected in its website on a laptop screen in Washington, DC. - Collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX suffered a "complete failure of corporate controls" under founder Sam Bankman-Fried, the company's new chief executive said on November 17, 2022, calling the situation "unprecedented." The scathing condemnation came in a filing in US bankruptcy court from John J. Ray -- an executive with 40 years of experience in corporate restructurings including the infamous implosion of Enron in 2001. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)
Sam Bankman-Fried, 30, was arrested last week in the Bahamas, where he lived and where FTX is based, cementing his fall from grace.
Sam Bankman-Fried, founder and former CEO of crypto currency exchange FTX, walking to a plane during his extradition to the US at Lynden Pindling international airport in Nassau, Bahamas.

site_title: US consumer spending, inflation cool in November
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in November, edging up from October's 0.9% increase, but annual inflation remained at its slowest pace in 13 months. Despite this, economists expect the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates to combat inflation, which is still above its 2% target. Consumer spending is expected to provide a boost to economic growth in the fourth quarter, driven by solid wage gains and savings accumulated during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Shipments of core capital goods dipped 0.1 per cent after increasing 1.4 per cent in October.

site_title: Malaysia’s urbanisation rate tripled over past five decades
summary: Malaysia's urbanisation rate has nearly tripled since 1970, with 75% of residents now living in cities. The urban population expanded to 24.4 million in 2020, while the rural population rose to 8.1 million. This transformation is driven by the growth of the electrical and electronics sector, making Malaysia a leading producer of semiconductors. The country's exports, primarily manufactured goods, now account for 85% of total exports, with agricultural goods making up 7%.

site_title: US: Wall Street gains as investors eye data for rate prospects, energy outperforms
summary: US stocks rose on Friday as investors assessed inflation data, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.59% to 3,845.11 points. Energy shares led the gains, driven by higher oil prices, while consumer spending data showed a slight rise in November. Despite this, the Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates high, with inflation cooling but not enough to ease concerns. Investors remain cautious, with the Fed's hawkish stance seen as a major cloud on the horizon.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 66.43 points, or 0.20 per cent, at the open to 32,961.06.

site_title: Hermes sees success and growth in watch business
summary: Hermes' watch division, led by CEO Laurent Dordet, has seen significant growth, with a 55% increase in watch sales in the latest quarterly results. The Arceau Le temps voyageur and H08 watches have been major contributors to this success, with the H08 selling three times more than projected and winning several awards, including the Best Men's and Best Women's complication at the Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Geneve. Dordet attributes the growth to the brand's existing customer base and affordable, simple yet creative watches, with plans to expand production in Switzerland to meet demand.

images.alt_text: Arceau Le temps voyageur blue dial close up
Revenue rose 24 per cent to 3.1 billion euros in the third quarter excluding currency swings, Hermes said on Thursday (Oct 20),

site_title: Meta to settle Cambridge Analytica case for US$725m
summary: Meta Platforms has agreed to pay $725 million to settle a class-action lawsuit accusing the social media giant of allowing third parties, including Cambridge Analytica, to access users' personal information. The proposed settlement resolves a long-running lawsuit prompted by revelations in 2018 that Facebook allowed Cambridge Analytica to access 87 million users' data. Meta did not admit wrongdoing and claims the settlement is in the best interest of its community and shareholders.

images.alt_text: Tech companies and investors are closely watching the suit amid concerns the case may make startup acquisitions more difficult.

European Commission said in a preliminary view that it would further investigate and that it could impose a fine of up to 10 per cent of Meta’s annual global turnover, if there is sufficient evidence of an infringement of EU rules.
The projection, given by CTO Andrew Bosworth, is little changed from the 18 per cent of spending Meta devoted to Reality Labs in the third quarter.

site_title: China tells banks to boost consumer loans ‘appropriately’
summary: China's banking regulator, the CBIRC, has urged banks to increase consumer loans "appropriately" and meet financing demands of high-quality property companies. The regulator also encourages banks to expand medium- and long-term loan issuance to the manufacturing sector and support private firms. This guidance aims to boost economic growth and stabilize the financial system.

site_title: UK businesses hit by Brexit blues two years on
summary: UK businesses continue to struggle two years after Brexit, with 56% facing difficulties adapting to new trading rules. The main issue is not customs duties, but a surge in regulatory paperwork, adding 25% to administration costs. The Office for Budget Responsibility estimates Brexit will reduce the country's long-term output by 4%. High-profile bosses who voted for Brexit are calling on the government to relax immigration rules, citing the loss of EU workers and the impact on exports.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in consumer services and manufacturing output drove the decline.
The survey of 1,168 businesses was published almost two years after the UK signed the Trade and Cooperation Agreement to allow post-Brexit tariff-free trade.
CER said departing the EU single market reduced goods trade by 7% in the second quarter of 2022.
Steel and other metal products are the biggest category of products awaiting completion.

site_title: AT&T, BlackRock to form commercial fibre-optic platform
summary: AT&T and BlackRock are forming a joint venture, Gigapower, to operate a fibre-optic platform in the US. The venture plans to deploy its network to 1.5 million customer locations outside of AT&T's traditional 21-state wireline service presence. The companies will jointly own and govern Gigapower, with AT&T expanding its high-speed home Internet service to attract new subscribers. The deal could be valued at $10 billion to $15 billion, and AT&T plans to report consumer subscribers served through Gigapower in its operational results.

site_title: Indonesia, BP sign 20 years contract extension for LNG operations in Papua
summary: Indonesia has extended a 20-year production sharing contract with BP for its LNG operations in Papua, allowing BP to operate until 2055. The extension will support the development of the Tangguh liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant, which is expected to increase production capacity to 11.4 million tonnes per annum. The move aims to maintain production and support Indonesia's increasing energy demand as it transitions to cleaner energy sources.

site_title: Fifa investigating how celebrity chef got onto World Cup final pitch
summary: FIFA is investigating how celebrity chef Nusret Gokce, known as 'Salt Bae,' gained access to the World Cup final pitch after he posted videos and photos of himself with Argentina's players and holding the World Cup trophy on social media. Gokce, who owns a chain of high-end restaurants, was not authorized to touch the trophy, which can only be touched by a "very select group of people." FIFA will take internal action after reviewing how individuals gained access to the pitch following the World Cup final on December 18.

site_title: War and ethics: What are the investment community’s responsibilities?
summary: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has significantly impacted the global investment community, forcing professionals to navigate complex ethical dilemmas. The war's consequences, including rising volatility and inflation, have raised questions about the investment community's responsibilities. Codes of professional conduct, such as the CFA Institute Code of Ethics, guide investment decisions, but may not be sufficient in the face of rapidly changing circumstances. The industry needs to develop common standards to apply during conflicts and work towards preventing them in the future, prioritizing moral norms and principles over profitability and reputation.

images.alt_text: Investigators at a house damaged during a Russian drone strike in the village of Stari Bezradychi, in Ukraine's Kyiv region, December 19, 2022.
A Christmas tree made of camouflage nets draws a small crowd in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, on Dec 19, 2022, amid the Russian invasion.

site_title: Japan gold buyers capitalise on dip in local prices, Covid dims China outlook
summary: Physical gold buyers in Japan capitalized on a 4% jump in the yen, resulting in a 12-week low in gold prices. The Bank of Japan's policy tweak led to strong buying interest, with dealers charging a premium of US$0.50 an ounce. In contrast, demand outlook in China was overshadowed by a flare-up in Covid-19 infections, with premiums in China dipping to US$8-16. Retail buying in India plummeted due to price rises, with gold discounts widening to nearly six months' highest level.

site_title: Three dead after shooting at Kurdish centre in Paris
summary: A gunman, identified as a 69-year-old white man, opened fire at a Kurdish cultural centre and a hairdressing salon in Paris on Friday, killing three people and injuring three others. The gunman, known for two previous attempted murders, initially targeted the cultural centre before entering the salon where he was arrested by police. The incident occurred in the trendy 10th district of Paris, a bustling area with a large Kurdish population.

site_title: TSMC in talks with suppliers over first European plant
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) is in talks with suppliers about setting up its first European plant in Dresden, Germany. A team of senior executives will visit Germany early next year to discuss government support and local supply chain capacity. TSMC has not ruled out the possibility of the plant but has no concrete plans. The German state of Saxony supports companies in the microelectronics industry, and the European Commission has earmarked €15 billion for public and private semiconductor projects by 2030.

images.alt_text: TSMC said in an emailed statement that it did not rule out any possibility for Japan but there were no concrete plans at the moment.

site_title: Toyota’s futuristic Mirai is still stuck in the future
summary: Toyota's Mirai, a fuel cell-powered electric vehicle, has made significant strides in reducing emissions and air pollution. The Mirai can remove 99.5% of ultra-fine soot and pollutants, making it a "mobile air purifier." Despite its benefits, the technology has struggled to gain traction, with only 19,000 units sold over two decades. Toyota is exploring other uses for hydrogen, including integrating it into existing engines, and is developing a "hydrogen toolkit" to scale up the technology. The company believes both fuel cells and combustion engines have their merits and is focusing on finding the right application for each.

images.alt_text:
jlbmw8



Credit: Big Fish Publishing Pte Ltd

site_title: Media mogul Michael Bloomberg looking to buy Dow Jones or Washington Post: Axios
summary: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg is reportedly considering acquiring either Dow Jones, parent of the Wall Street Journal, or the Washington Post. According to Axios, Bloomberg would prefer Dow Jones, but would also consider buying the Post if Jeff Bezos were interested in selling. Bloomberg already owns Bloomberg News, and a potential acquisition would expand his media empire.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Michael Bloomberg speaks at a rally during his presidential campaign in West Palm Beach, Florida, U.S., March 3, 2020. REUTERS/Maria Alejandra Cardona/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia slams EU deforestation-free law for blocking palm oil market access
summary: Malaysia has criticized the European Union's new deforestation-free law, which requires companies to produce a due diligence statement on their supply chains, potentially blocking market access for palm oil. The law, set to apply to soy, beef, and other commodities, has been deemed by Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister as a deliberate act to hurt small farmers and protect a domestic market. The EU Ambassador to Malaysia denied claims of a ban on palm oil, stating that deforestation-free and legally produced palm oil will continue to be sold in the EU market.

site_title: Japan lawmaker says TSMC is considering second plant in Japan
summary: Japan's secretary general of a ruling party lawmakers' group on chip industry strategy, Yoshihiro Seki, stated that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) is considering building a second plant in Japan, in addition to a US$8.6 billion facility currently under construction. TSMC did not rule out the possibility, but no concrete plans were mentioned. Seki urged Japan's government to create an environment that would make TSMC consider advanced projects, citing the need for technological innovation and cooperation between the public and private sectors.

site_title: Singapore shares end week in the red despite festive cheer, STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week in the red, losing 0.4% or 11.83 points to close at 3,257.70. Gloomy macroeconomic data, including steady inflation levels and a 3.2% contraction in factory output, contributed to investor worries. Despite festive cheer, US market volatility and potential recession fears also affected local shares, with top gainers including Medtecs International and top losers including Pegasus Asia and UOB.

images.alt_text: Bonds or financial management concepts. investment plan.money market forecasting
November’s lower figures came as tourist arrivals fell marginally to 816,254 for the month, breaking a nine-month growth streak.
A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on December 1, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Saudi Arabia-backed LIV Golf breathes new life into Asian Tour
summary: The Asian Tour has seen a significant boost in its finances and calendar after partnering with LIV Golf, backed by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund. The partnership has increased the tour's prize money and events, with a total of $200 million added to its coffers. The Asian Tour's 2023 calendar includes 11 events, including four International Series tournaments, with prize purses of at least $2 million. CEO Cho Minn Thant sees LIV Golf as a positive force in the golf industry, bringing competition and innovation, and is hopeful that the feuding parties can eventually strike a compromise.

images.alt_text: LIV Golf CEO and commissioner Greg Norman shakes hands with fans at the LIV Golf Invitational Miami tournament in October 2022.
South Korea's Park Ji Young won with a score of 11-under-par 133 to clinch the Hana Financial Group Singapore Women's Open on Dec 11, 2022.

site_title: Huawei patent royalties exceed payouts for second straight year
summary: Huawei generated $1.2 billion in patent licensing revenue globally over the past three years, exceeding payouts for patents for the second consecutive year. The company signed or renewed over 20 patent licensing deals in 2022, including deals with carmakers such as Mercedes-Benz and Audi. Huawei aims to offset losses due to US export curbs on its hardware business by generating returns on its research and development investments. The company's patent licensing revenue is not significant compared to its annual sales, but it is a growing area for the company.

images.alt_text: A person stands by a sign of Huawei during World Artificial Intelligence Conference, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, September 1, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

The Bill, introduced by Republican senator Tom Cotton and backed by lawmakers such as Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, seeks to “severely sanction” Huawei, and other “untrustworthy” Chinese 5G producers who they say engage in economic espionage against the US.
Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin says the US has “politicised and weaponised economic cooperation”.
Banning products made by Chinese firms such as Huawei, would remain on a case-by-case basis, said the German economy ministry spokesperson.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as investors assess inflation data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, December 23, due to investors assessing inflation data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 66.43 points, or 0.20%, to 32,961.06. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 falling 7.28 points, or 0.19%, to 3,815.11, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 38.37 points, or 0.37%, to 10,437.75. The decline was despite inflation data showing further cooling in November, which may not be enough to deter the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates next year.

site_title: China estimates covid surge is infecting 37 million people a day
summary: China's health authority estimates nearly 37 million people may have been infected with Covid-19 on a single day in mid-December, surpassing the world's largest outbreak. The estimate, based on internal meeting minutes, suggests 248 million people, or 18% of the population, contracted the virus in the first 20 days of December. China's swift dismantling of Covid Zero restrictions has led to the spread of the highly contagious Omicron variant, with hospitals in major cities overwhelmed and crematoriums struggling to handle the surge in deaths.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Commuters wear protective masks while they ride a subway train as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreaks continue in Shanghai, China, December 20, 2022. REUTERS/Casey Hall/File Photo
China is battling a wave of infections that has hit the elderly hard.

site_title: Court grants Zipmex’s rescue financing super-priority status
summary: The Singapore High Court granted Zipmex, a crypto exchange, super-priority status for a US$5.85 million rescue financing to restructure. The financing will keep the company afloat until January and aims to resume customer access to crypto assets in early April. The new investor's identity remains undisclosed, but a deal reportedly worth US$100 million is in the works. The company faces criticism over its settlement agreement with customers, with concerns raised about the fairness and transparency of the terms.

images.alt_text: An advertisement for the crypto-asset exchange Zipmex Pte in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, April 12, 2022. Indonesia will start taxing crypto transactions and assets next month, along with some financial-technology services. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
An advertisement for the crypto exchange Zipmex in Jakarta on April 12, 2022. The group was granted a moratorium as it seeks to restructure its debt.
Observers said proper education would involve educating consumers on the risks and challenges of cryptocurrency trading.

site_title: Air travellers warned of delays as UK passport control staff strike
summary: UK passport control staff, members of the Public and Commercial Services Union, went on strike on December 23, 2022, due to a 2% pay rise offer far below inflation. The strike, which will last until December 31, may cause delays at airports, with Gatwick warning of longer wait times at passport control. Despite this, Heathrow reported minimal queueing. The government is training armed forces and government officials to help staff passport controls during the strike.

images.alt_text: UK government said the “deeply regrettable” strike would result in fewer ambulances on the road, with only the most urgent life-threatening cases such as heart attacks prioritised.

site_title: Thailand saw 10.9 million tourist arrivals so far this year
summary: Thailand reported 10.9 million tourist arrivals between January and December 20, exceeding initial expectations. The country is forecast to reach 22 million arrivals in 2023, with a focus on high-spending tourists. The tourism sector is crucial for Thailand's economy, accounting for 12% of GDP before the pandemic. The government aims to diversify its tourism market, shifting focus from volume to high-spending tourists.

site_title: Thai PM declares candidacy in next year's general election
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha has declared his candidacy for the next year's general election, citing support from the newly-created United Thai Nation Party. Prayut, 68, came to power in a 2014 coup and cemented his position in a 2019 election, but his popularity has waned. The United Thai Nation Party has offered to support him in the election, which is scheduled to take place before May next year.

images.alt_text: Thaksin’s daughter, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, is emerging as one of Pheu Thai’s potential candidates for the premiership and has played a key role in rallying support for the party in recent months.

site_title: Iron ore futures slip as China Covid jitters flare up
summary: Iron ore futures slipped 0.2% on Friday as China's Covid-19 outbreaks dampened investor optimism, forcing businesses to shut down and production to stagnate. The Shanghai hospital expects half the city's 25 million people to get infected by the end of the year, while global iron ore shipments rebounded significantly, tempering price rebound hopes. Steel benchmarks were also subdued, with steel mills reining in output amid tepid demand.

images.alt_text: Copper cathodes are seen inside a warehouse near Yangshan Deep Water Port, south of Shanghai in this March 23, 2012 file photo. China's refined copper imports have surged over 70 percent so far this year to 1.1 million metric tons, while demand from Chinese manufacturers was forecast to rise by up to 7 percent. Meanwhile, iron ore shipments have risen 6 percent, with traders reckoning that local demand growth is much lower. Copper is used in housing and appliances and iron ore is the raw material for steel. For copper, Chinese traders appeared to have misjudged the fundamentals and embarked on a massive shopping spree in November, expecting demand to rebound after the Lunar New Year. But the buyers never materialized in bulk and China is now left with up to 1.4 million metric tons of copper, the most since 2009.  To match Analysis US-CHINA-COMMODITIES/ REUTERS/Carlos Barria/Files  (CHINA - Tags: BUSINESS COMMODITIES)
TOPSHOT - This aerial photo taken on July 21, 2022 shows a bucket wheel machine tranferring coal at a coal storage centre in Jiujiang, in China's central Jiangxi province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Temasek-linked bonds get upgrade and affirmation by S&P Global Ratings
summary: S&P Global Ratings has upgraded and affirmed its ratings for Astrea IV and Astrea VI, Temasek-linked private equity bonds, with Astrea IV's S$242 million Class A-1 notes now rated "AA- (sf)" and Astrea VI's S$382 million Class A-1 notes affirmed at "A+ (sf)". The upgrade reflects sufficient reserves to redeem the bonds on their scheduled call date and no impact from underlying private equity fund performance.

images.alt_text: Some may have opted for Class A bonds because they wanted a relatively safe way of storing their money at yields better than bank deposit rates. The exposure to the US dollar may have also made some investors less comfortable with the Class B offering.
The latest batch of Astrea private equity (PE) bonds, launched by Temasek-backed Azalea Asset Management, was overall 3 times subscribed.

site_title: Influx of new homes may ease rental pressures in 2023, but supply crunch looms
summary: Singapore is expected to see an influx of new private homes in 2023, with over 18,000 units slated for completion, potentially easing rental pressures. However, the supply crunch in the rental market is expected to continue, with a decrease in new HDB home supply and fewer flat owners renting out their units due to cooling measures. Rents are projected to rise further in 2023, albeit at a slower rate, while leasing activity is expected to remain robust despite potential downside risks.

images.alt_text: In the HDB rental market, prices are up 1.6 per cent from October 2022 and 27.8 per cent on a year-on-year basis.
Livethere notes that landlords have been pushing rents upwards to meet mortgage payments amid escalating interest rates and a looming recession.
The majority of HDB residents will pay between S$30 and $70 more in property tax after rebate in 2023, said the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore on Friday (Dec 2).

site_title: Thai power price hike to hurt business, competitiveness, warns business group
summary: Thailand's government plans to hike electricity prices by 20% in early 2023, which a business group warns will push up inflation and undermine the country's competitiveness as it recovers from the pandemic. The price hike will affect businesses, causing them to increase the price of goods, and could lead to higher inflation, with some predicting it could reach 3.5% next year. The move is expected to make Thailand's power costs 50-120% higher than those in countries like Vietnam and Indonesia, further impacting the country's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The pace, however, is still far above the central bank’s target range of 1 per cent to 3 per cent.

site_title: Tencent rant, Sea pay freeze hint at deepening gaming crisis
summary: Tencent and Sea, two major gaming companies, are signaling a tough year ahead for the US$200 billion gaming industry. Tencent co-founder Pony Ma attacked his staff for lacking urgency, while Sea founder Forrest Li warned of deeper economic challenges and cut bonuses and froze salaries. The industry faces geopolitical and economic ructions, including the war in Ukraine and soaring inflation, which could lead to a decline in consumer spending. Both companies have been hit by a slowdown in 2022 and have made significant cost-cutting measures, including job cuts and reduced investments.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation rate holds steady at 4% in November, slightly above economists’ forecasts
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate held steady at 4% in November, slightly above economists' forecasts of 3.9%. The main contributors to the increase were food and non-alcoholic beverages, as well as restaurants and hotels. Core inflation, excluding volatile items, was 4.2%, slightly higher than the previous month. Economists expect the inflation rate to moderate in 2023 due to declining commodity prices and a diminishing low-base effect, with projections ranging from 2-2.5% for next year.

images.alt_text: epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Nightmares before Christmas 2
summary: Post-pandemic disruptions are affecting Santa's toy factory, causing holiday joy to dwindle. The Business Times' comic strip, "Nightmares Before Christmas 2," explores the challenges Santa faces in meeting the growing demand for toys. The disruptions, partly due to staffing issues and supply chain problems, threaten to ruin Christmas. The comic strip serves as a commentary on the post-pandemic economic landscape and the struggles of companies in adapting to changing circumstances.

site_title: Japan unveils record budget in boost to military capacity
summary: Japan has unveiled a record 114.4 trillion yen budget for the next fiscal year, driven by increased military spending and higher social security costs due to an ageing population. The budget, endorsed by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's cabinet, features record military and welfare spending and includes a plan to double Japan's defence spending to 2% of GDP by 2027. To fund this, the government will issue construction bonds worth 434.3 billion yen, an unprecedented move. The budget also assumes a record tax revenue of 69.44 trillion yen.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An aerial view shows Japan's Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF)'s destroyer JS Asahi (DD-119) leading the fleet during the International Fleet Review to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the foundation of the JMSDF, at Sagami Bay, off Yokosuka, south of Tokyo, Japan November 6, 2022, in this photo taken by Kyodo.in this photo taken by Kyodo.
