site_title: Singapore hotel average room rates slip in November
summary: Singapore hotel average room rates slipped 2.3% in November to S$276.53, the second consecutive decline. Despite the drop, rates remain higher than pre-pandemic levels. November's tourist arrivals fell to 816,254, breaking a nine-month growth streak. Hotel room revenues dropped 5% to S$391.9 million, still surpassing pre-pandemic highs. Occupancy rates rose 8.7% to 86.6%, while revenue per available room increased 76.3%.

images.alt_text: In October, hotel performances were mixed across categories, as the economy and luxury segments saw gains while the mid-tier and upscale segments saw losses.
Indonesia, India, Malaysia and Australia continue to be the largest senders of tourists to Singapore in November.

site_title: Hospitals overflow in China’s Covid wave
summary: China is battling a wave of Covid-19 infections, particularly among the elderly, but has reported only a handful of deaths due to the government's revised definition of Covid deaths, which only counts those who die from respiratory failure, excluding pre-existing conditions exacerbated by the virus. Hospitals, such as No 5 People's Hospital in Chongqing, are overflowing with Covid patients, with the main entrance lobby converted into a makeshift ward. The revised definition has raised concerns about the accuracy of China's Covid death toll.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Commuters wear protective masks while they ride a subway train as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreaks continue in Shanghai, China, December 20, 2022. REUTERS/Casey Hall/File Photo

site_title: Apple's Australian workers go on Christmas strike for better wages, work terms
summary: Apple workers in Australia went on strike on December 23, 2022, demanding better wages and work terms. The strike, organized by the Retail and Fast Food Workers Union, is the first by Apple workers in Australia. The workers claim an 8-year-old agreement denies them essential rights, including weekends and consecutive days off. The strike may impact Apple's sales during the peak Christmas shopping period. This is the latest in a series of labor disputes by Apple workers in the US and Australia, following similar protests in China's iPhone plant.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A customer stands underneath an illuminated Apple logo as he looks out the window of the Apple store located in central Sydney, Australia, May 28, 2018. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo
Results released on Monday show 68 per cent of Apple workers rejected a workplace agreement proposed by management with 87 per cent of Apple’s almost 4,000 Australian workers participating.

site_title: Creating more impact with your donation
summary: Singapore's Giving.sg platform, integrated with Stripe's payment solutions, has seen significant donations since its digitalization in 2017. The platform, which allows donors to give to registered charities, has resulted in over S$2.8 million in additional donations for more than 400 charities. Donors can claim a 250% tax relief on their contributions by December 31. However, Stripe warns that digitalization can also increase the risk of fraud, emphasizing the need for organizations to leverage machine learning and two-factor authentication to prevent it.

images.alt_text: "Life happens, and there is a danger that some may feel like it is a chore. So the aim for us is to work with companies and education institutions to sensitise people to the needs of others," says Soh.

site_title: Thailand hosts Myanmar junta figures in talks, key Asean nations skip
summary: Thailand hosted regional talks on Myanmar's crisis, attended by Myanmar's junta figures and foreign ministers from Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam, but skipped by key Asean nations including Malaysia, the Philippines, Indonesia, and Singapore. The talks focused on humanitarian assistance and the implementation of the Five-Point Consensus peace plan, but no concrete results were reported. The UN Security Council adopted a resolution demanding an end to violence and the release of political detainees, amid strained ties between Myanmar and Asean.

images.alt_text: An empty chair set aside for Myanmar's delegation at the Asean Summit in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The Myanmar crisis dominated the first day of a summit.

site_title: Zara shopworkers call off strikes in company’s hometown after 25% pay rise
summary: Zara shop assistants in A Coruña, Spain, have ended planned strikes after agreeing to a 25% pay rise, bringing monthly salaries to 1,400 euros. The deal includes a one-off bonus of 1,000 euros and future pay increases of 20 and 40 euros in 2023 and 2024, respectively. The pay rise follows a previous offer of a 200 euros increase by 2024, which was rejected by the union. The agreement was reached after around 1,000 workers announced strikes on Dec 23 and Jan 7 to demand higher wage increases.

site_title: China’s soaring Covid cases push economic activity off a cliff
summary: China's soaring COVID-19 cases are causing a slump in economic activity, with subway passenger numbers plummeting in cities like Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Nanjing. Infections have surged, leading to crowded hospitals and funeral parlors, keeping people at home despite workers being told to return to work if sick. Economic activity, including factory production and travel, has fallen significantly, with congestion levels 56% below pre-pandemic levels. Experts predict the current wave of infections will peak in mid-December to late January, with a potential economic rebound relying on consumers spending their accumulated savings.

images.alt_text: China will speed up construction of major investment projects and equipment upgrading, state media quoted the Cabinet as saying after a regular meeting.

site_title: UK’s year of three prime ministers
summary: The UK experienced a historic year of governmental instability in 2022, with three prime ministers occupying Downing Street in the second half of the year. Boris Johnson left office in disgrace, followed by Liz Truss, who became the shortest-serving prime minister in UK history. Rishi Sunak, the current prime minister, may prove to be one of the weakest in living memory, with his government risking collapse in 2023. The Conservative Party's internal dynamics and potential calls for a general election could lead to another change of prime minister, with former leader Boris Johnson being a potential candidate for a comeback.

images.alt_text: Commuters wait for trains at Kings Cross Station in London. Some 40,000 rail workers have walked out on strike in an on-going dispute over pay and conditions, causing widespread travel chaos across the UK ahead of Christmas.
CER said departing the EU single market reduced goods trade by 7% in the second quarter of 2022.

site_title: Singapore shares echo negative sentiments on Wall Street; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.5% to 3,252.69 points, mirroring the negative sentiment on Wall Street, where stocks closed lower due to fears of continued aggressive monetary policy tightening following better-than-expected US economic data. The benchmark index saw 26 million securities worth S$32.1 million trade, with decliners outnumbering advancers 74 to 26.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries has commissioned a 285 MWh (megawatt hour) energy storage system (ESS) facility within six months.

site_title: China's stretched health system braces for peak in Covid infections
summary: China is bracing for a peak in Covid-19 infections, with over 1 million cases and 5,000 deaths per day, a stark contrast to official data. The country's health system is under strain due to a surge in cases, widespread protests, and a recent policy change that has lifted lockdowns and testing. Experts attribute the strain to a lack of preparation, including inadequate hospital capacity, insufficient vaccination, and excessive focus on eliminating the virus. China's vaccination rate for the elderly is low, and the country's domestically developed Covid shots are seen as less effective than Western-made vaccines.

images.alt_text: An emergency department at a Shanghai hospital was receiving 400 patients a day, all of them elderly people with underlying diseases, fever and respiratory infection, and in a very serious condition.

site_title: Capitol riot panel’s final report sets out case to try Trump
summary: The US Capitol riot panel's final report recommends charging former President Donald Trump with inciting the deadly January 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol. The 800-page report, based on 1,200 interviews and 60 court rulings, lists 17 findings and includes criminal referrals to the Justice Department of Trump and others. Trump has called the report "highly partisan" and a "witch hunt," but the report outlines evidence of Trump's efforts to overturn the 2020 election results and spark the attack. The Justice Department has not been compelled to act, but the report marks the first time in history that Congress has referred a former president for criminal prosecution.

images.alt_text: A summary of the committee's report also said the panel believed there were grounds to recommend criminal charges against some others close to Trump, including attorney John Eastman.

site_title: Singapore inflation holds steady in November, with core at 5.1% and headline at 6.7%
summary: Singapore's inflation remained steady in November, with headline inflation at 6.7% and core inflation at 5.1%, unchanged from the previous month. Energy prices offset rising retail and food prices, which saw increases of 3.6% and 7.3% year-over-year, respectively. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the core inflation to steeper increases in clothing and personal care products. The central bank has maintained its forecast for 2022 full-year inflation at 6% and 2023 forecasts at 5.5-6.5% for headline inflation and 3.5-4.5% for core inflation.

images.alt_text: Food prices bucks the trend with inflation inching up to 7.1 per cent, from 6.9 per cent in the previous month.

site_title: China tech stocks are winning back investors after awful year
summary: China's tech stocks have regained investor confidence after a tumultuous year, with the Hang Seng Tech Index surging 50% since an October low. Regulatory headwinds are easing, and earnings prospects are improving, with analysts at Morgan Stanley, UBS, and JPMorgan upgrading their forecasts. The sector's growth is expected to be driven by China's economic reopening and the resolution of a long-standing auditing dispute with the US. Shares of companies like Alibaba and Tencent have more than doubled, and investors are looking for further signs that the crackdown is over, such as the revival of Ant Group's IPO.

images.alt_text: The central bank will provide financial support for infrastructure and major projects, as well as help meet a reasonable need for bond issuance among private firms.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall St down as recession worries return
summary: Asia's markets fell on Friday, Dec 23, following a glum warning from top chipmaker Micron and concerns about China's surging Covid cases. The US stock market ended in the red after revised data showed the world's biggest economy grew more than initially thought, but jobless claims rose. The Bank of Japan's decision to move away from ultra-loose monetary policy increased bets on a more restrictive environment in 2023. Micron's poor outlook and better-than-expected US data supported the Federal Reserve's case for more interest rate increases, leading to losses in Asia markets.

images.alt_text: The global gains came after hefty selling since the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank last week signalled they would likely lift interest rates higher than expected to fight decades-high inflation.

site_title: South Korea’s Mirae Asset to invest 93b won in SpaceX in January 2023
summary: Mirae Asset Financial Group affiliates plan to invest 93 billion won (S$98 million) in SpaceX in January 2023, with Mirae Asset Securities investing 88.5 billion won and Mirae Asset Capital investing 4.5 billion won. This investment is separate from a July 2022 investment of 116 billion won through a fund. The move is part of Mirae Asset Financial Group's efforts to commit 300 billion won to finance Elon Musk's Twitter deal in October.

site_title: Top Indian banks vie for No 1 bond spot as credit demand surges
summary: Top Indian banks, Axis Bank and HDFC Bank, are competing fiercely for the No. 1 bond spot in the Indian market, as credit demand surges despite rising interest rates. Indian businesses are borrowing to cover higher operational costs and investments, driving a 3.7% increase in rupee corporate bond sales to 8.67 trillion rupees this year. The competition has heated up, with Axis Bank managing 18.8% of note sales, followed by HDFC Bank at 17.7%, narrowing the gap between them to the lowest since 2009.

images.alt_text: Next year’s optimism for India is driven by strong corporate earnings, a post-pandemic retail boom and an economy set to grow by 6 per cent in the next fiscal year.

site_title: Singapore’s factory output shrinks by worse-than-expected 3.2% in November
summary: Singapore's factory output contracted 3.2% in November, worse than expected, with the electronics cluster experiencing a 12.4% decline. This was driven by a slump in exports and softening demand for consumer goods. Excluding the biomedical cluster, factory output fell 4.8%, and the manufacturing sector is expected to underperform in the near term, with growth projected at 2.4% in 2022 and potentially contracting in 2023. Analysts attribute the decline to a global semiconductor downcycle and unwinding pandemic-related demand.

images.alt_text: Factory output has grown 1.9 per cent year on year in October, excluding the typically volatile biomedical cluster

site_title: Gold flat as focus shifts to inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,793.22 per ounce as traders awaited inflation data due later in the day to gauge the Federal Reserve's rate hike stance. Despite being considered an inflation hedge, rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion since it pays no interest. Investors are closely watching the personal consumption expenditure (PCE) data and economic data from the US and Europe for cues on inflation and interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: Rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion since it pays no interest.

site_title: HDB launches Tampines Avenue 11 and Plantation Close GLS sites for tender
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched two residential sites, Tampines Avenue 11 and Plantation Close, for tender under the government land sales (GLS) programme. The Tampines Avenue 11 site, with a 99-year lease, can potentially yield 1,685 residential units, while the Plantation Close site can yield 495 executive condominium units. The tenders will close on June 27, 2023, and analysts predict keen interest from developers, with top bids potentially exceeding $1,000 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: MND will supply land for development into 4,090 private homes (including 700 executive condo or EC units) on the confirmed list for the first half of 2023.
The residential site at Lentor Gardens is launched for sale under the confirmed list, while the residential site at Lentor Central is available for application under the reserve list.
118 of the 158 units at Frasers Property's Sky Eden@Bedok were sold at launch at an average price of S$2,100 per square foot.

site_title: What 2022 meant for the world
summary: The year 2022 posed numerous challenges to the world, from the invasion of Ukraine to Covid-19 in China, climate change, and Sino-American tensions. However, the resilience of liberal countries in the West, particularly the US, proved surprising and welcome. Western governments rallied behind Ukraine, while voters in many countries, including the US, France, and Italy, rejected populist candidates. In contrast, autocracies like Russia and Iran faced unrest and protests. The year also highlighted the strain on liberal values, with many countries adopting illiberal policies and economic nationalism gaining popularity. Despite these challenges, the West found its footing in 2022, and there is hope for a better future.

images.alt_text: The Fed and other major central banks are intent on fighting inflation

site_title: Dream big, start small: SMEs and mid-size firms can pivot nimbly to a greater cause
summary: Small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) and mid-size firms face significant challenges, including survival and expansion, talent issues, and maintaining a strong culture. However, only 7% of top executives cite sustainability as a major challenge, despite societal expectations for companies to pursue goals beyond traditional profit objectives. To overcome these challenges, SMEs can leverage digital transformation and sustainability strategies, such as artificial intelligence and computer simulations, to quantify environmental impact and derive greener operations. Effective leadership, talent fit, and clear strategies are also crucial for success.

images.alt_text: In the digital economy, the businesses that adapt to changes quickest will thrive. As disruption continues, CEOs who previously delegated their digital strategy want to take direct leadership today, says Sujith Abraham, senior vice president and GM, Asean, at Salesforce.
Eight in 10 of the SMEs surveyed in Singapore rate ESG as a high priority for their business.

site_title: China's overnight repo rate falls to new low after cash injection
summary: China's central bank lowered its overnight repo rate to a record low of 0.5527% after injecting a net $100.76 billion into the market to support liquidity ahead of the year-end cash rush. The move aims to ease cash demand and cushion potential economic shock from the easing of Covid-19 containment measures. Economists expect the central bank to maintain abundant cash conditions, which could lead to subdued growth in the next quarter but a strong rebound afterwards.

images.alt_text: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang
The central bank will provide financial support for infrastructure and major projects, as well as help meet a reasonable need for bond issuance among private firms.

site_title: US home sales posted record decline in November
summary: US home sales plummeted 35% year-over-year in November, marking the largest decline since 2012. High mortgage rates, fueled by the Federal Reserve's efforts to tame inflation, have crippled demand. The median US home-sale price rose just 2.6% from a year earlier, the smallest increase since May 2020. New listings also fell 28% year-over-year, the largest drop on record. However, mortgage rates recently fell for the sixth straight week, potentially easing the cooldown. Fewer home-purchase agreements were cancelled in November, suggesting a possible relief from the housing market's downturn.

site_title: Singapore’s Sea freezes salaries, cuts bonuses as tougher 2023 looms
summary: Sea Ltd, the Asian Internet giant, is freezing salaries for most staff and paying out lower bonuses for 2023, citing a worsening global economic environment. CEO Forrest Li warned of a challenging 2023, with a 77% loss in value this year due to rising interest rates and competition. The company has already cut 7,000 jobs and reduced expenses to achieve profitability, with a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss in November. Li assured staff that these measures are temporary and necessary to build towards a brighter future.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Lum Chang, Tiong Seng, Jumbo
summary: Sembcorp Industries has commissioned a 285 MWh energy storage system facility, the largest in South-east Asia, within six months. Lum Chang secured a $110 million tender to build a 19-storey hotel along Orchard Road. Tiong Seng sold nearly 90% of its units in the Sloane Residences project after obtaining a temporary occupation permit. Jumbo Group opened its first franchised outlet in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. GSS Energy requested a trading halt pending an announcement. These developments may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Elon Musk says he will not sell more Tesla stock for another 2 years
summary: Elon Musk has stated he won't sell any more Tesla stock for the next two years due to concerns over a potential recession in 2023 and decreased consumer demand for electric cars. This comes after a recent stock sell-off and Musk's previous sales of Tesla shares. Musk believes the economy will be in a "serious recession" and sees the need to maintain a cash reserve to account for a worst-case scenario.

images.alt_text: Tesla is giving a US$7,500 credit in the United States and a US$5,000 credit in Canada on Model 3 and Model Y vehicles delivered before the end of the year.

site_title: Bank of Korea says curbing inflation remains main rate policy target in 2023
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has reaffirmed its focus on curbing inflation as its main interest rate policy target for 2023. The bank expects inflation to fall to 3.6% next year, down from 5.1% in 2022, but notes that uncertainty remains. The Bank of Korea will decide on the final interest rate and its duration after considering inflation, economic growth, and market conditions. The bank has lifted interest rates by 275 basis points since last year, and is expected to finish its tightening cycle this year.

site_title: Why you shouldn’t strive for the perfect Christmas
summary: Tim Harford reflects on why striving for perfection in holiday preparations can lead to disappointment. He notes that as adults, we often prioritize telic goals (achieving a specific end state) over atelic activities (enjoying the journey). This can lead to an overemphasis on checking off tasks from a list, rather than appreciating the process itself. Harford suggests embracing the atelic nature of activities like gift-giving and Christmas preparations, focusing on the joy of the experience rather than the end result, and cultivating this mindset throughout the year.

images.alt_text: merry, christmas, merry christmas

The balancing act between keeping customers and remaining profitable makes that inevitable. Customers are making the same choices. Each purchase and every sale represents a vote for survival, a chance to make the world a better place and a hope that 2023 will see the world start to turn the corner towards stability and peace.
Get your home ready for Christmas.

site_title: Sembcorp commissions 285 MWh battery facility on Jurong Island
summary: Sembcorp Industries has commissioned its 285 MWh energy storage system facility on Jurong Island, making it South-east Asia's largest. The facility can meet the daily electrical needs of nearly 17,000 four-room flats. The system enhances grid resilience and addresses solar intermittency, and Sembcorp expects it to be accretive to earnings. The facility is part of a larger battery storage portfolio, now standing at 709 MWh in Singapore and the UK.

images.alt_text: Xingling New Energy is SPIC’s first renewable energy joint venture with a foreign strategic investor, says Sembcorp Industries’ CEO of China, Alex Tan.
Sembcorp says its gross renewable energy capacity will increase to 8.5 gigawatts after the acquisition.
Sembcorp's acquisition of the 3 solar projects in China through its joint venture with Beijing Energy will bring the mainboard-listed company's total solar capacity to 7.9 gigawatts.

site_title: Wall Street gets 2022 half right; the other half still hurts
summary: Wall Street forecasters accurately predicted 2022 earnings projections but fell short on stock prices. The S&P 500 Index earnings are on pace to match consensus forecasts, with a possible 1-2% deviation. However, stock prices are 22% below the projected average, largely due to monetary policy and higher interest rates. Analysts underestimated inflation and the Federal Reserve's response, leading to compressed earnings multiples. The 2023 outlook is uncertain, with only 5% of strategists' projections landing within 5% of the actual index value in the past 23 years.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Wall Street entrance to the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is seen in New York City, U.S., November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid//File Photo

site_title: Apple Watches violate AliveCor patents but import ban on hold: US ITC
summary: The US International Trade Commission (ITC) has ruled that Apple Watches with ECG technology infringe on AliveCor patents, but an import ban is on hold pending appeals at the US Patent and Trademark Office. The ITC had initially ordered a $2 bond for each infringing Apple device imported, but this was suspended. The Biden Administration will review the decision within 60 days and may veto the import ban. Apple has disputed the ITC's decision, while AliveCor CEO Priya Abani praised the ruling, citing the importance of intellectual property rights.

images.alt_text: Apple did begin iPhone production in India much faster this year than with prior generations.

site_title: Human this Christmas
summary: Academics are concerned about ChatGPT, an AI tool that can write human-like paragraphs, potentially undermining academic integrity. Professors fear that ChatGPT could be used to cheat on assignments, prompting a reevaluation of assessment methods and detection tools. While some argue for better tests, others suggest scaring students about cheating. Companies are struggling to lay people off, and the global economy is shifting towards climate investing. Meanwhile, China faces challenges in competing in the AI talent war, and a low-profile property trust is exploring a data center gambit.

images.alt_text: Chatbot technology is not new, although its deployment has met with mixed success.
AI-generated text desperately needs some kind of watermark, similar to how stock photo companies protect their images, says the author.

site_title: Banks open data-protection vault to other financial businesses
summary: A group of 160 financial institutions, including banks, insurance companies, and asset managers, have adopted a data-protection vault called Sheltered Harbor to store critical customer-account data. The vault, which is encrypted and separated from the institution's infrastructure, aims to maintain public confidence in the event of a devastating cyberattack. The program, started in 2015, is expanding to include more financial businesses and is intended for worst-case scenarios, including when regular backups fail. While the program has its drawbacks, industry analysts say it's a step in the right direction for preserving and protecting sensitive data.

images.alt_text: OCBC last month launched what it styled as an “integrated lifestyle and banking branch” at Wisma Atria, along the Orchard Road shopping belt.

site_title: Jumbo opens first franchised outlet in Cambodia
summary: Jumbo Group has opened its first franchised outlet in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, at Chip Mong 271 Mega Mall. The 6,200 sq ft outlet features four VIP rooms and a seating capacity of 146. This marks Jumbo's entry into the Cambodian market, showcasing the brand's resilience despite the Covid-19 pandemic. CEO Ang Kiam Meng stated that the brand will continue to expand its footprint, bringing the Singapore chilli crab experience to more cities.

images.alt_text: The outlet is Jumbo's first in Hanoi, and is located near monuments like the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and One Pillar Pagoda.

site_title: Microsoft tells judges its US$69b Activision deal would benefit gamers
summary: Microsoft has submitted a filing to a US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) judge arguing that its $69 billion bid to acquire Activision Blizzard would benefit gamers and the gaming industry. The FTC had previously expressed concerns that the merger would harm competition, but Microsoft has offered to sign a consent decree ensuring Call of Duty games would be available on non-Xbox devices. The company is also awaiting a decision from the European Union, which will review the deal by March 23, 2023.

images.alt_text: Microsoft has publicly stated that it offered Sony a 10-year deal to make Call of Duty available on the Japanese company’s PlayStation console.

site_title: Twitter’s top global policy official departs as layoffs continue
summary: Twitter's top global policy official, Sinead McSweeney, has left the company amid additional layoffs to the public policy unit. The departures come as regulators question Twitter's content moderation and user data protection following Elon Musk's significant staff cuts. McSweeney's departure has not been previously reported, and her role has been taken over by Nick Pickles. The public policy team is responsible for handling requests from governments and civil rights groups to remove problematic content and sets rules to protect vulnerable users.

images.alt_text: Since taking over Twitter on Oct 27, Musk has laid off 50 per cent of the company’s employees and demanded remaining staff commit to long hours and a “hardcore” culture, prompting more employee departures. T

site_title: FTX’s Bankman-Fried, charged with ‘epic’ fraud, released on US$250m bond
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the 30-year-old founder of FTX, was released on a $250 million bond package while awaiting trial for allegedly stealing billions of dollars in customer funds. The bond, set by US Magistrate Judge Gabriel Gorenstein, requires Bankman-Fried to surrender his passport, remain in home confinement, and undergo regular mental health treatment. The charges, considered a "fraud of epic proportions," were made by federal prosecutors in Manhattan, who also noted Bankman-Fried's reduced financial assets and lack of flight history. Bankman-Fried's trial is set for January 3, 2023.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried, founder and former CEO of crypto currency exchange FTX, walking to a plane during his extradition to the US at Lynden Pindling international airport in Nassau, Bahamas.
The US SEC said in a separate statement that it has also charged Ellison and Gary Wang for their roles in a multiyear scheme to defraud equity investors of FTX.

site_title: Arctic blast, blizzards disrupt US travel ahead of holidays
summary: A powerful Arctic blast and blizzard disrupted US travel ahead of the holiday weekend, canceling over 2,200 flights. The extreme winter weather, combined with snow, ice, and strong winds, caused at least four deaths, including a 50-vehicle traffic pileup on the Ohio Turnpike. The blizzard also disrupted energy supplies and shut down highways, with multiple lanes closed due to the accident. The storm's impact is expected to continue, with millions of Americans affected by the severe weather.

images.alt_text:
Travelers at LondonÕs Heathrow Airport on Thursday, July 14, 2022. After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.
(Isabella Kwai/The New York Times)

site_title: Japan’s November core consumer inflation hits fresh 40-year high
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation hit a 40-year high in November, rising 3.7% from a year earlier, driven by companies passing on rising costs to households. The BOJ, which has been under pressure to reduce massive stimulus, may face challenges in normalizing policy due to global recession risks and uncertainty over wage hikes. Analysts expect core inflation to slow near the BOJ's 2% target next year, but an elevated "core-core" index suggests inflationary pressure may persist. The BOJ will scrutinize CPI data when producing fresh quarterly inflation forecasts.

images.alt_text: Japan annual draft budget spending plan worth 114.38 trillion yen is expected to be approved by the Cabinet on Friday.

site_title: 3M blocked from shifting combat-earplug liability to unit in bankruptcy
summary: US District Court Judge M Casey Rodgers ruled that 3M cannot shift liability for US$300 million in damages awarded to veterans due to defective combat earplugs to its subsidiary Aearo Technologies, which filed for bankruptcy. The judge found 3M's attempt to change its litigation position in bad faith and a "brazen abuse of the litigation process." This ruling is part of more than US$7 billion in liabilities 3M faces over faulty earplugs, with over a dozen juries finding veterans' hearing loss tied to the defective earplugs.

images.alt_text: 3M’s exit from the category comes 20 years after management phased out an early, popular form of PFAS, known as PFOS, in 2002 under pressure from scientific studies about its potential harms.

site_title: JPMorgan announces new climate targets covering aviation, cement
summary: JPMorgan Chase has set new climate targets, aiming to reduce the carbon intensity of its financing portfolios for aviation, cement, iron ore, and steel companies by 36%, 31%, 29%, and 29% respectively by 2030. The targets follow the bank's previous emissions-reduction goals for oil and gas, electric power, and auto manufacturing. Despite criticism from environmental activists, JPMorgan's chairman and CEO Jamie Dimon emphasizes that the bank can balance energy security and reducing carbon footprint. The targets align with the International Energy Agency's net zero by 2050 scenario.

images.alt_text: A man exits the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters building in New York, U.S. in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 8, 2011. LivingSocial, the second-largest daily-coupon site, is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase & Co. as one of the banks to manage its initial public offering, a person with knowledge of the talks said. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: Chinese startup’s 1m yuan car can fly over traffic jams
summary: Chinese startup Xpeng Aeroht unveiled its 1 million yuan flying car, which can fly over traffic jams and also drive on the road for 90% of the time. The prototype, with four electric engines and eight propellers, is designed to be mass-produced in 2025. Xpeng, the billionaire founder's electric vehicle maker, has invested heavily in the startup and is betting on its success to capture a slice of the US$1 trillion urban air mobility market. Regulatory hurdles and commercial viability remain major concerns, but Aeroht's efforts to work with Chinese regulatory bodies and generate consumer interest offer hope for the industry's future.

images.alt_text: The eVTOL aircraft have been touted as air taxis that could be the future of urban air mobility.

site_title: Macau to drop Covid tests for arriving passengers
summary: Macau is dropping COVID-19 tests for arriving passengers from overseas, but still requires a negative nucleic acid test certificate for entry. This move is part of relaxing stringent COVID measures, effective from December 23. Travellers from Hong Kong and Taiwan will also be exempt from the test requirement.

site_title: US: Stocks close in the red on monetary tightening fears
summary: US stocks closed in the red on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.1%, the S&P 500 Index down 1.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 2.2%. Strong labor market and better-than-expected economic growth data supported the Federal Reserve's case for more rate increases, despite a moderation in pace this month. Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled the central bank's battle with inflation is not yet over, fueling market jitters. A resilient economy may lead to inflation remaining at higher levels, prompting the Fed to push on with steep rate hikes.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 14, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Volkswagen’s main plant faces production stoppages in January
summary: Volkswagen's main plant in Wolfsburg, Germany, will face production stoppages from January 9 to 27 due to the Covid-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine. The stoppage affects the late shift in Golf production for assembly line 3, car production, and other adjacent areas. The company will reduce the number of shifts, excluding holding areas and maintenance necessary to supply the plant. The reasons for the stoppage are attributed to the ongoing disruptions in supply chains caused by the pandemic and war.

site_title: China’s Li urges Hong Kong leader to boost financial hub status
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged Hong Kong leader John Lee to further integrate with mainland development plans and solidify the city's role as an international financial hub. Beijing supports Lee's efforts to respond to society's concerns, kickstart the economy, and resolve the city's deep-seated problems. Li's visit comes as China plans to cut quarantine requirements for overseas travelers in January, potentially paving the way for the border's reopening. Lee's meeting with President Xi Jinping on Friday will focus on Covid controls and the economic situation.

site_title: Oil falls by US$1 a barrel as rate hike fears outweigh tighter US stockpiles
summary: Oil prices fell by around $1 a barrel on Thursday, outweighing the impact of tighter US crude stocks due to a winter storm. Fears of Federal Reserve interest rate hikes and China's rising Covid-19 cases, which could slow the economy and reduce fuel consumption, contributed to the decline. Oil benchmarks Brent crude and WTI crude futures settled at $80.98 and $77.49 per barrel, respectively, after rising earlier in the session. The US dollar and falling equities also kept prices in check.

images.alt_text: Potentially curtailing oil demand, huge parts of the United States are forecast to face heavy snow that is likely to cause flight delays and impassable roads during one of the busiest travel periods of the year.

site_title: Lum Chang wins S$110 million contract to build hotel along Orchard Rd
summary: Lum Chang, a Singapore construction player, has secured a contract worth S$110 million to build a 19-storey hotel along Orchard Road. The hotel, expected to have 246 rooms, is scheduled for completion over 36 months starting from April next year. The contract is not expected to impact Lum Chang's financial results for the financial year ending June 30, 2023. This is the latest contract win for the company, adding to its outstanding value of construction works yet to be reported as revenue, totaling about S$1.6 billion.

site_title: Tiong Seng’s Sloane Residences obtains TOP; close to 90% units sold
summary: Tiong Seng's 12-storey freehold condominium, Sloane Residences, in Singapore's prime District 10, has obtained a temporary occupation permit (TOP) and sold nearly 90% of its units. Since achieving TOP on Nov 18, the property has seen a "sharp uptick" in buyer interest, selling 8 units in 4 weeks at an average selling price of S$2,907 psf. The project is located near Bukit Timah Road, Stevens Road, and Orchard Road, with Singaporeans making up 54% of buyers.

images.alt_text: Sales of Tiong Seng's 2 core central region projects hit hard by cooling measures

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as festive cheer fades on rate hike worries
summary: European shares fell 1.0% on Dec 22 as hopes of easing inflation gave way to fears of aggressive monetary policy tightening, particularly after better-than-expected US economic data. The Stoxx 600 index closed lower after rising earlier in the day. Rate-sensitive stocks slid, with the FTSE 100 down 0.4% and semiconductor companies like ASML Holding and Infineon Technologies down 3% each. The region's Stoxx 600 has fallen 12.4% this year, outperforming the US S&P 500, which has declined 20.8%.

images.alt_text: The region-wide Stoxx 600 index closed 1.7 per cent higher.

site_title: Xiaomi replaces president, chairman pledges investment in R&D
summary: Xiaomi replaces its president, Wang Xiang, who will step down on December 30, and is being replaced by Lu Weibing. Chairman Lei Jun announced the change in a letter to employees, pledging to increase investment in research and development and continue pushing the company's strategy for high-end products. This move comes amidst a global slowdown in smartphone demand and Xiaomi's own sales decline, which fell roughly 10% in the September quarter. Lei also mentioned the company's electric vehicle project, but did not confirm if the change will impact it.

site_title: Credit Suisse sells building in Geneva for US$217m
summary: Credit Suisse has sold a building in Geneva to an investment foundation for $217 million, marking the bank's latest asset sale as it works to return to profitability. The sale is unrelated to its restructuring plan announced in October. Credit Suisse will remain a long-term tenant of the building, which is located in the heart of Geneva's financial district. The sale is part of the bank's efforts to shed assets and focus on core businesses.

site_title: Tencent billionaire launches blistering tirade against staff as empire starts to crack
summary: Tencent billionaire Pony Ma delivered a rare and scathing internal address to his staff, criticizing employees for slacking, corruption, and poor decision-making. He targeted various units, including gaming, social media, and content, citing uncertain survival of some businesses and the need for aggressive cost-cutting. Ma also expressed concern over the company's aging social network, which is losing ground to mobile-native rivals, but acknowledged WeChat's short-video feed as a potential growth area. The company faces significant challenges, including a sweeping crackdown on private enterprise in China and an economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Beijing’s tech crackdown, which ensnared sectors from e-commerce to fintech and even education over a tumultuous year, spread to online gaming in August 2021.
FILE PHOTO: TikTok app logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Meituan, whose services also include restaurant reviews and bike-sharing, said total revenue rose to 62.62 billion yuan (S$12 billion) in the three months ended September.
Blizzard is now in talks with “potential release partners” over bringing World of Warcraft back to China.

site_title: S&P Global lowers Pakistan’s rating to ‘CCC+/C’
summary: S&P Global lowered Pakistan's long-term sovereign credit rating to "CCC+" from "B" due to continued weakening of external, fiscal, and economic metrics. The country's low foreign exchange reserves will remain under pressure unless oil prices slump or foreign assistance improves. Severe floods, surging inflation, and rising interest rates are expected to depress Pakistan's economic and fiscal outcomes, with refinancing challenges over the medium term. The agency maintained its outlook at "stable".

site_title: Hyflux sues Olivia Lum for more than S$690 million over alleged negligence, fiduciary duty breach
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment firm, has sued former CEO Olivia Lum for over S$690.6 million, alleging negligence and breach of fiduciary duty. The lawsuit claims Lum failed to recognize material impairments and provisions, resulting in overstated financial statements. Lum denies the allegations, stating that the statements were prepared by her staff and audited by KPMG, and that she acted in good faith. The lawsuit also claims Lum led the company to engage in wrongful trading and pay out dividends despite being in the red.

images.alt_text: Hyflux's liquidators say they have received total proof of debt amounting to around S$1.5 billion, but the realisations from the asset sales are unlikely to exceed S$100 million.
Besides the criminal charges, Olivia Lum, founder and former chief of water treatment firm Hyflux, is also being sued by the liquidators and the Hyflux group.
Hyflux announced the Tuaspring project in 2011, and issued S$400 million worth of preference shares that year
Olivia Lum Ooi Lin
KPMG faces litigation by embattled Hyflux, which is under liquidation.

site_title: BioNTech ships 11,500 doses of Covid vaccine to China for use by Germans
summary: BioNTech has delivered 11,500 doses of its Covid-19 vaccine to China for use by German expatriates, marking the first overseas-made shots allowed into the country. The doses, containing both original and updated vaccines targeting the BA.4/BA.5 Omicron subvariants, are enough for half of the 20,000 or so German nationals currently in China. This delivery comes as Beijing dismantles its "zero-Covid" regime, leading to a surge in cases.

images.alt_text: “We are working on the possibility that besides Germans also other foreigners can be vaccinated with BioNTech.” a German government spokesperson said.

site_title: Trust vacuum in Web3 after FTX failure; regulations loom
summary: The crypto market experienced a significant downturn in 2023, with a loss of approximately US$2.3 trillion, according to CoinGecko data. This has led to a loss of consumer and investor confidence in Web3 companies, resulting in scandals, contagion, and business collapses. Industry players are preparing for a leaner year and anticipating tougher regulations. With cheap capital and institutional interest waning, Web3 companies are struggling to rebuild trust and recover from the turmoil.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Japan’s Mitsubishi UFJ says ready to do more deals to expand in Asia
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Finance Group, Japan's largest banking group, is expanding in Asia with a focus on commercial banking and consumer finance. CEO Hironori Kamezawa announced the group's second phase of investment strategy, which includes leveraging commercial bank units for broader services. Mitsubishi UFJ has already made several acquisitions, including the purchase of Home Credit Group's units in the Philippines and Indonesia. The company is also investing in startups in India and has completed a US$8 billion sale of its US arm to focus on its wholesale business.

site_title: With Anwar as its new leader, Malaysia hopes for greater stability and progress in 2023
summary: Malaysia's new prime minister Anwar Ibrahim aims to bring stability and progress in 2023. Following the snap general election in November, the country's economy showed strong growth in the third quarter with a 14.2% increase. However, economists expect growth to moderate in 2023 due to global recession concerns. The central bank is expected to raise interest rates to combat inflation and slow down manufacturing activities. The ringgit is forecasted to weaken initially but gain strength by end-2023 as the unity government introduces pro-investment policies. The government's focus on tackling the high cost of living and implementing infrastructure improvements is also expected to boost the economy.

images.alt_text: Listed-companies which are perceived to be linked to the top Malaysia leaders have seen strong interest from short-term investors.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims up slightly; Q3 GDP revised higher
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 2,000 to 216,000 for the week ended Dec 17, below the 270,000 threshold. The labour market remains tight, with economists citing a structural labour shortage. The Federal Reserve projects at least 75 basis points of interest rate hikes by the end of 2023. The economy rebounded at a 3.2% annualized rate in Q3, revised up from 2.9%. Despite recession fears, growth estimates for the fourth quarter are as high as 2.7%, driven by consumer spending and savings.

images.alt_text: A measure of expectations – which reflects consumers’ six-month outlook – climbed to 82.4, the highest since January.

site_title: People’s Park Centre, Loyang Valley en bloc tenders close without bids
summary: The collective sale tenders for People's Park Centre and Loyang Valley in Singapore closed without bids, marking the latest en bloc sites to fail this year. People's Park Centre's second attempt at a collective sale at a reserve price of S$980 million was unsuccessful due to its large price tag, while Loyang Valley's first attempt at a collective sale at a reserve price of S$980 million also failed to gain enough support. Industry observers attribute the failure to high reserve prices exceeding S$1 billion, rising construction costs, and uncertainty in the macroeconomic conditions.

images.alt_text:

Commercial buildings and condominiums as viewed from OCBC Centre on Nov 10, 2022.

The reserve price for People’s Park Centre works out to a land rate of S$2,620 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr).

site_title: The year in food: Chefs dish up their thoughts on the F&B scene in 2022
summary: Chefs and restaurateurs in Singapore reflect on the food scene in 2022, citing a positive year despite challenges. Julien Royer of Odette notes the industry's pivot towards concise menus with more substance, prioritizing quality over quantity. Sebastien Lepinoy of Les Amis sees a decline in Japanese restaurants and a rise in "fusion" food, with young chefs adapting different culinary influences. Damian D'Silva of Rempapa faces rising food costs, which he plans to pass on to customers. Restaurateur Karen Cheng is cautiously optimistic about 2023, citing a busy industry and a desire for more authenticity in dining experiences. Key trends include a focus on quality over quantity, dry-aging, and Levantine cuisine.

images.alt_text: Kok Sen's new premises are far more comfortable and cleaner than the old space.

site_title: SGX best performers boosted by M&As as companies restructure, go private
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

In 2022, Singapore-listed companies saw a surge in merger and acquisition (M&A) activity, with many stocks rising due to such deals. Top performers included Golden Energy and Resources, Chip Eng Seng, Halcyon Agri, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which saw share price increases of 172.4%, 91.3%, 71.3%, and 110.5%, respectively. Conversely, Sats' share price sank after proposing the acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services, and companies like iFast Corporation and AEM Holdings experienced negative returns. Institutional investors played a significant role in swinging performances, with net inflows recorded for several counters.

images.alt_text: Rising costs and a challenging operating environment are oft-cited reasons for delisting.

site_title: China to cut quarantine for overseas travellers next month
summary: China plans to cut quarantine requirements for overseas travelers starting in January, replacing a "0+3" policy where arrivals would be monitored for three days after a hotel or isolation stay. The new policy would scrap hotel quarantine, instead requiring just three days of monitoring, which could take place at home. The move is part of China's dismantling of its Covid Zero policy, which has been relaxed since protests against the measures in late November.

images.alt_text: People wearing face masks walk on a street, as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreaks continue in Shanghai, China, December 13, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Yen firms, underpinned by BOJ policy tweak; US dollar steady
summary: The yen rose about 0.3% to 132.08 per US dollar, nearing a four-month peak, after the Bank of Japan's unexpected tweak to its bond yield controls. Analysts expect the yen to continue to appreciate as the BOJ becomes more hawkish and markets doubt the Fed's actions. The US dollar remained steady ahead of key data releases, while the euro rose 0.1% and sterling fell 0.3%. The yen also strengthened against the euro and pound, reaching its strongest levels since late September.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Applied Materials, a semiconductor equipment company, announced a S$600 million facility in Singapore set to double its manufacturing footprint. China's authorities emphasized prioritizing growth and helping the property sector recover. US prosecutors charged two top executives from FTX with defrauding investors. Meanwhile, global private banks are targeting India's rich as China's slowdown affects its appeal. Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, tracking regional gains.

site_title: Philippine bourse seeks clarity on PLDT’s claim it found no fraud
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) has asked PLDT to clarify its claim that it found no fraud in its 48 billion peso capital spending overrun. The exchange sent a letter to PLDT, requesting a response by Friday, after the company's chairman stated that the investigation was complete and there was no evidence of wrongdoing. The PSE's market surveillance unit initially found no evidence of insider trading on PLDT shares on December 16, but the investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Signage at the PLDT Inc. headquarters in Makati City, Metro Manila, the Philippines, on Monday, Dec. 19, 2022. PLDT, the largest Philippine phone company, sank as a 48 billion peso ($866 million) four-year capital spending overrun raised questions about its corporate governance and fiscal control. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Swiss National Bank surprises with forex purchases in Q3
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) unexpectedly purchased 12.8 billion Swiss francs of foreign currencies in the third quarter, reversing its previous trend of selling foreign currencies to maintain the franc's high nominal value. This move aims to battle resurgent inflation. Despite this, the SNB's net acquisition of foreign reserve assets declined to 2.4 billion francs due to sales of securities. The SNB's total reserve assets fell to 873 billion francs, and the country's current account surplus widened to 24.1 billion francs, driven by a strong goods trade and low services trade deficit.

site_title: Shortsellers gain nearly US$304b after tumble in US stocks
summary: Short sellers have achieved a significant gain this year, with US$303.7 billion in realised and unrealised profits, a fourfold increase compared to 2018. The majority of this gain comes from bets against Tesla, Amazon, and other megacap growth stocks, which have led to a 19% decline in the S&P 500 this year. Other top winners include Apple, Meta Platforms, and Carvana. Despite the gains, long-short hedge funds have posted a 9.7% loss through November, and experts expect tighter monetary policy to weigh on risk appetite next year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Tesla electric vehicle is seen through a charging point displayed during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 20, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

Both equities and fixed-income investors have struggled to make money this year as the US Federal Reserve and other major central banks raised rates swiftly to fight inflation, removing the tailwind of easy money.

site_title: Could fusion arrive in time to solve climate change?
summary: Scientists at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory have achieved the first controlled nuclear fusion reaction to produce more energy than it took to start, bringing humanity closer to harnessing the power of the sun. The breakthrough, announced in December 2022, could help wean the US off fossil fuels and reach net-zero emissions by 2050. However, significant technological and economic hurdles remain before fusion reaches true viability, with many experts questioning whether it can play a meaningful role in the global effort to halt climate change.

images.alt_text: In a brief moment lasting less than 100 trillionths of a second, 2.05 megajoules of energy – roughly the equivalent of a pound of TNT – bombarded a hydrogen pellet in a small cylinder about the size of a pencil eraser.

site_title: Japan government FY2023/24 budget to set debt-dependency ratio at 31.1%
summary: Japan's government is set to approve a fiscal 2023/24 budget with a debt-dependency ratio of 31.1%, down from 34.3% this fiscal year. The budget plan, worth 114.38 trillion yen, will reduce new debt issuance to 35.62 trillion yen, thanks to record tax revenue. Despite efforts to curb debt, the plan will face pressure from increased defence spending and welfare costs for an ageing population. The government aims to double defence spending to 2% of GDP by 2027.

site_title: Banker bonuses go from boom to bust in jarring reversal
summary: Banker bonuses are expected to decline by 40-45% for US managing directors at Goldman Sachs in 2022 due to leaner times. Recruiters estimate year-end bonuses will be 30-50% lower, with some receiving none, as dealmaking slows and economic gloom takes hold. This marks a reversal from last year's record-breaking awards, which were given as the economy recovered from the pandemic. The decline in bonuses is attributed to the industry's current challenges.

images.alt_text: “M&A is the best house in a pretty tough neighborhood in investment banking right now,” said Mark Shafir, co-head of global M&A at Citigroup, which advised on three of the year’s largest transactions, including Broadcom’s US$61 billion takeover of VMWare.

site_title: 🎓 Graduating into a recession
summary: Singapore's job market remains an "employee's market" despite a looming recession. To prepare, graduates should start job searching early, network with professionals, and upskill with resources like Coursera or Skillsfuture credits. Being flexible with job offers, budgeting 20% of income for savings, and cutting unnecessary expenses are also crucial. Additionally, finding a gig job, reviewing and refinancing loans, and prioritizing well-being during the challenging job search period are recommended.

site_title: TikTok steps up efforts to clinch US security deal
summary: TikTok has made significant efforts to address US security concerns, offering to operate more independently and subject to outside scrutiny. The company has proposed expanding Oracle's role in reviewing its technology infrastructure, forming a proxy board to oversee data protection and content moderation, and hiring independent auditors and monitors. Despite these measures, some government officials remain opposed to a security deal, citing concerns that TikTok's users would still be vulnerable due to its reliance on Chinese technology company ByteDance. The outcome of negotiations between the US government and TikTok will be determined by the White House.

images.alt_text: Some 19 of the 50 US states have now at least partially blocked access on government computers to TikTok.

site_title: Singapore shares track regional gains on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, tracking regional gains, with 309 gainers outnumbering 199 losers. The STI closed at 3,269.53, following a global rally. Key sectors, including technology and property companies, led the charge. Policymakers in China are providing support for major private property developers, while regulatory guidance is helping platform companies drive employment.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index has ended the midweek trading session up 0.1 per cent or 2.22 points, to close at 3,256.19.
Investors take heart from positive consumer data.

site_title: Indonesia central bank slows pace of rate hikes as growth seen easing
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised its benchmark 7-day reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 5.50% as inflation is seen easing. This marks a slower pace of rate hikes, with the bank reaffirming its aim to keep the rupiah stable. The central bank forecasts a slower pace of economic growth next year, with GDP growth expected to weaken to the middle of a 4.5% to 5.3% range, down from 3.7% this year.

site_title: Japan eyes record budget as BOJ shock pressures funding costs
summary: Japan plans to issue bonds worth over 35.6 trillion yen to finance a record 114.4 trillion yen budget for the year starting April, amid the Bank of Japan's surprise policy move that may pressure funding costs. The move could make it harder for the government to boost spending by issuing more debt cheaply, and higher borrowing costs may lead to increased debt-servicing costs. The government's budget includes a historic boost in defense spending, which will need to be funded either through unpopular tax increases or adding to Japan's massive debt pile.

images.alt_text: Japan is saddled with the industrial world’s heaviest public debt at more than twice the size of its US$5 trillion economy, the world’s third largest.

site_title: Philippines orders strengthened military presence after 'Chinese activities' near islands
summary: The Philippines has ordered a strengthened military presence in the South China Sea following "Chinese activities" near its strategic island of Pagasa (Thitu). China has built four uninhabited features in the disputed Spratly islands, prompting the Philippines to warn that any encroachment on its 200-mile exclusive economic zone poses a threat to its security. China denies the allegations, stating it adheres to a consensus among claimants not to develop uninhabited reefs and islands. The Philippines urges China to uphold the rules-based international order and refrain from exacerbating tensions.

images.alt_text: The encounter between the Chinese and Philippine officials in the South China Sea happened during US Vice-President Kamala Harris' visit in the country. Her trip included a stop on Palawan, an island on the edge of the South China Sea, to reaffirm the US' support for a 2016 tribunal ruling that invalidated China's claims on the disputed waterway.

site_title: China’s soaring Covid cases send people to black market for pills
summary: China is experiencing a surge in Covid-19 cases, leading to a shortage of antiviral medicines like Paxlovid. Despite the government's easing of Covid Zero measures, the healthcare system is strained, and people are turning to the black market for generic versions of the medication. The high price of Paxlovid is deterring many, with some paying up to 5,800 yuan for a single box. The shortage is expected to persist, with China struggling to meet the demand, and experts warn that the under-vaccinated elderly population is highly vulnerable.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Paxlovid, Pfizer's anti-viral medication to treat the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), is displayed in this picture illustration taken October 7, 2022. A morning and an evening does consists of one white 100-milligram tablet of Ritonavir and two pink 150-milligram tablets of PF-07321332. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: PropertyBT: Prospects for Orchard Road properties (Ep 14)
summary: Orchard Road properties are seeing improved prospects as tourists return, with luxury targeting a potential opportunity. Experts suggest focusing on the luxury market and redeveloping strata-held buildings. Some malls have struggled, but offices and homes in the area are showing interest. Redeveloping and repositioning properties could make Orchard Road more vibrant, but it's essential to consult professional advisors for independent advice.

images.alt_text: Some trends suggest that malls at Orchard Road, which is now lit up for Christmas, may see brighter prospects than suburban malls.
What to look out for when buying a freehold, a new 99-year leasehold or an older leasehold home.

site_title: Last-minute Christmas book gift ideas
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

This Christmas, consider gifting books that cater to various interests. "How to Take Over the World" by Ryan North is a humorous comic book and science fiction manual for aspiring supervillains. "Fright 1" is a Singapore horror anthology featuring 11 short stories by local writers. "Because Our Fathers Lied" by Craig McNamara is a memoir about a complicated father-son relationship. "An Immense World" by Ed Yong explores how different animals perceive the world. "Surrender" by Bono is a memoir by U2's frontman, detailing his music and philanthropy. These books offer unique and engaging reads for various tastes.

images.alt_text: JJ Lin feeling festive at the Little Social., a private Peranakan home dining space. He wears a knitted pullover and denim jeans by Louis Vuitton.
A hiker on the Trans-Bhutan Trail

site_title: Applied Materials announces S$600 million Singapore facility
summary: Applied Materials, a US chipmaker, has announced a S$600 million greenfield facility in Singapore, set to be completed in 2024. The 700,000 sq ft facility will double the company's manufacturing footprint in Singapore, with over 200,000 sq ft of equipment manufacturing clean room space. The facility aims to expand Applied Materials' global manufacturing and research capabilities, and strengthen technology ecosystem partnerships, with the goal of strengthening the local workforce over the next eight years.

images.alt_text: China’s push to further its own semiconductor industry, and to develop advanced military systems, has been complicated by the export controls.
Sources say the plan includes preferential tax policies for China's semiconductor industry.
Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin says the US has “politicised and weaponised economic cooperation”.
The Commerce Department on Thursday also targetted nine Chinese entities for allegedly seeking to support China’s military modernisation.

site_title: France fines Microsoft 60 million euros over advertising cookies
summary: France's National Commission for Technology and Freedoms (CNIL) has fined Microsoft 60 million euros for not allowing users to easily refuse advertising cookies on its search engine Bing. The regulator found that cookies were deposited on users' terminals without consent and used for advertising purposes. The fine is the largest imposed in 2022 and is part of a year-long investigation into websites using cookies. Microsoft has three months to rectify the issue and faces a potential further penalty of 60,000 euros per day.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo the logo of French headquarters of American multinational technology company Microsoft, is pictured outside on March 6, 2018 in Issy-Les-Moulineaux, a Paris' suburb. - Microsoft has said a state-sponsored hacking group operating out of China is exploiting previously unknown security flaws in its Exchange email services to steal data from business users. The company said the hacking group, which it has named "Hafnium", is a "highly skilled and sophisticated actor". In a blog post on March 2, 2021, Microsoft executive Tom Burt said the company had released updates to fix the security flaws, which apply to on-premises versions of the software rather than cloud-based versions, and urged customers to apply them. (Photo by GERARD JULIEN / AFP)

site_title: Get a head start on fitness
summary: Two Singaporean fitness studios, Project Send and Sphere, are promoting bouldering and recovery methods as alternatives to traditional gyms. Project Send, founded by Kenneth Ng and Sarah Chua, offers bouldering walls with varying difficulty levels and protective mattresses for safe falls. The studio also provides training programs and a cafe. Sphere, co-founded by Bowen You and Allan Ng, offers a performance space for personal training and recovery modalities such as infrared sauna, cold plunge pool, and flotation pool. Both studios cater to a diverse range of clients, from office workers to professional athletes, and offer customized programs for optimal performance and recovery.

images.alt_text:
schealth22 - Fitness - Performance



Credit: Sphere
Technogym's Cross Personal is designed to bring luxury into home gyms.

site_title: Why Toyota CEO’s unusual alter ego raced a strange new car in Thailand
summary: Toyota CEO Akio Toyoda, under his alter ego Morizo, participated in the Idemitsu 1500 race in Thailand. Despite being a strong advocate for hydrogen, Toyoda showcased his racing skills in a unique car. The 25-hour event drew a large crowd, with fans recognizing Toyoda's charismatic persona. This unusual side of Toyoda highlights his passion for racing, but also underscores his skepticism about hydrogen as a silver bullet for the automotive industry.

images.alt_text: The DBX707 transfers Aston’s signature styling elements to the bulk of an SUV body well.

site_title: Asian bonds receive biggest foreign money in 9 months in November
summary: Overseas investors injected US$6.6 billion into Asian bonds in November, the largest foreign investment in nine months, amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut. This followed a net withdrawal of US$3.2 billion in the previous month. The investments were made in bonds from India, Indonesia, Malaysia, South Korea, and Thailand. The increase in foreign investment is attributed to signs of cooling inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korean 10,000 won note is seen on U.S. 100 dollar notes in this picture illustration taken in Seoul, South Korea, December 15, 2015.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Electrifying public and private transport for city-wide improvement
summary: Singapore aims to electrify its public transportation by 2040, deploying 100% cleaner energy bus fleets, reducing carbon emissions by 1.5-2 million tonnes. Other Southeast Asian countries, such as Malaysia and Thailand, are also transitioning to electric vehicles (EVs) through government incentives, charging infrastructure development, and education campaigns. The adoption of EVs is crucial to meet the Paris Agreement goals and mitigate the impact of rapid urbanization on the region's transport infrastructure, with Asia accounting for 60% of the world's population.

images.alt_text: Indonesia targets 20 per cent of overall car sales in 2025 to be EVs, Indonesia’s Chief Economics Minister Airlangga Hartarto said.

site_title: Nippon Steel to start making low-carbon ingredients for green steel
summary: Nippon Steel, Japan's largest steelmaker, plans to start producing low-carbon raw materials, including "reduced iron" made using hydrogen, to meet growing demand for green steel. This move aims to reduce steel production's 7-9% contribution to global CO2 emissions. By making these raw materials in-house, Nippon Steel aims to advance decarbonization and reduce its reliance on iron ore and coking coal.

site_title: UK economy was G7 growth laggard in Q3 as dismal 2023 beckons
summary: The UK economy contracted 0.3% in Q3, more than initially thought, and fell below its 2019 level by 0.8%. This puts the UK at the bottom of the G7 in terms of quarterly growth. Business investment declined 2.5% and inflation-adjusted household disposable income contracted for a fourth quarter. Economists predict the economy will contract again in the current quarter, potentially defining a recession. The UK is expected to suffer the deepest recession among major advanced economies in 2023, according to a Pantheon Macroeconomics economist.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in consumer services and manufacturing output drove the decline.
The survey of 1,168 businesses was published almost two years after the UK signed the Trade and Cooperation Agreement to allow post-Brexit tariff-free trade.

site_title: Bankman-Fried now in the US to face fraud charges over FTX collapse
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, founder of FTX, arrived in the US in FBI custody, facing 11 charges including conspiracy, wire fraud, and money laundering over the collapse of FTX and Alameda Research. The crypto exchange, valued at $32 billion, went bankrupt last month, with prosecutors alleging Bankman-Fried cheated investors and misused customer funds. Bankman-Fried, 30, will be transported to the Southern District of New York, where he could face up to 20 years in prison for each of the five counts carrying that maximum sentence.

images.alt_text: Customers pulled more than US$3 billion from Binance in a single day last week as part of a three-day frenzy that saw more than US$6 billion withdrawn.

site_title: UBS, Deutsche Bank target India rich as China’s appeal cools
summary: Global private banks, including UBS, Deutsche Bank, and Julius Baer, are hiring private bankers to serve India's wealthy clients amid China's slowdown and a gloomier global outlook. India, with an estimated $14.2 trillion in wealth, is becoming a bright spot for wealth management. The country's relaxed regulatory environment and growing stock market value are attracting investors, with India's two richest people considering setting up family offices abroad. Private banks are seeking to diversify revenue streams and tap into India's vast wealth opportunities, which are forecast to be the fastest-growing major economy next year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at a branch office in Zurich, Switzerland, January 27, 2017. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: UK fell deeper into recession in fourth quarter: survey
summary: The UK economy likely fell deeper into recession in the fourth quarter, according to a survey by the Confederation of British Industry. Output in the private sector slowed sharply, driven by a slowdown in consumer services and manufacturing. This marks the fifth month of quarterly declines, attributed to concerns over inflation, supply chain chaos, Brexit, and interest rate hikes. The CBI expects the UK economy to shrink 0.4% in 2023 before returning to growth in 2024, with underlying momentum remaining poor.

site_title: Here are the 10 biggest Asian IPOs to watch out for in 2023
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Asia's largest IPOs to watch in 2023 include Ant Group, Syngenta Group, and Amer Sports, which could raise $1 billion or more. FWD Group Holdings, SCG Chemicals, and Cinema XXI are also planning listings. VinFast, an electric car maker, has filed for a US IPO, while Oyo Hotels and Rakuten Bank are targeting early 2023 offerings. Longi Green Energy Technology plans a global depository receipt sale worth up to $4 billion. These listings could be the largest in Asia and globally, following a resurgence in IPOs in China's onshore market in 2022.

images.alt_text: Chinese brokerages have muscled into the IPO market historically dominated by global banks, particularly in places like Hong Kong.

site_title: US prosecutors charge two top executives in connection with FTX collapse
summary: US federal prosecutors have charged Caroline Ellison, former CEO of Alameda Research, and Zixiao (Gary) Wang, former CTO of FTX Trading, with defrauding investors in the crypto trading platform FTX. Ellison and Wang have both pleaded guilty to the charges and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. The US Securities and Exchange Commission also charged Ellison and Wang for their roles in a multiyear scheme to defraud equity investors of FTX. Sam Bankman-Fried, FTX founder, is in FBI custody and en route to the US.

images.alt_text: Bankman-Fried signed his surrender documents on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong property giant buys land priced at 8-year low
summary: Hong Kong property developer CK Asset Holdings won a bid for land in Kai Tak, a former airport area, for HK$8.7 billion (S$1.5 billion), the lowest price in eight years. The site is valued at HK$6,138 per square foot, significantly lower than its previous estimated value of HK$14.9 billion. This sale reflects the weakening Hong Kong real estate market, which is experiencing a slump due to interest rate hikes and diminished demand, with home prices dropping over 14% this year.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong first-time home buyers can acquire more expensive properties with just 10 per cent down payment.

site_title: Slippery outlook for crude oil amid macro woes, but bulls can still hope
summary: Crude oil prices are expected to remain stable in 2023, despite a grim global economy outlook, due to tight supply from Russia's oil dislocation and potential output cuts by Opec+. China's reopening, which could boost oil demand, is a key factor. However, inflation is expected to soften, leading to fewer rate hikes and a better outlook for the global economy. Analysts forecast Brent prices to average around $80-$90 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate to stand around $60-$80 per barrel.

images.alt_text: The recent declines have come against what should be a supportive backdrop for prices.

Copper cathodes are seen inside a warehouse near Yangshan Deep Water Port, south of Shanghai in this March 23, 2012 file photo. China's refined copper imports have surged over 70 percent so far this year to 1.1 million metric tons, while demand from Chinese manufacturers was forecast to rise by up to 7 percent. Meanwhile, iron ore shipments have risen 6 percent, with traders reckoning that local demand growth is much lower. Copper is used in housing and appliances and iron ore is the raw material for steel. For copper, Chinese traders appeared to have misjudged the fundamentals and embarked on a massive shopping spree in November, expecting demand to rebound after the Lunar New Year. But the buyers never materialized in bulk and China is now left with up to 1.4 million metric tons of copper, the most since 2009.  To match Analysis US-CHINA-COMMODITIES/ REUTERS/Carlos Barria/Files  (CHINA - Tags: BUSINESS COMMODITIES)
Demand in China may recover as early as the second quarter.

site_title: Festive gifts with a local touch
summary: Local brands offer unique Christmas gift ideas, including Nodspark nail wraps ($15), Sigi Skin's anti-ageing night serum ($99), The Chroma Choker by Yung Raja ($33,000), I’VRE scent subscription ($19.95), and The Powder Shampoo's foam washes ($39.90). Other gift options include Urban Green Dot's tabletop hydroponics workshop ($70), Sunday Bedding's Downtime gift set ($100), A.muse Projects' "Build your own tea gift box" ($16.20), Scene Shang home fragrances ($39), and Supermama Social Wares tingkat ($48). These gifts cater to various interests and ages, making them suitable for friends and family.

images.alt_text: Get your home ready for Christmas.

site_title: China State Council, PBOC vow to boost growth, property
summary: China's State Council, central bank, and securities watchdog have vowed to boost economic growth and support the property sector, which has been struggling with its worst slump on record. The government has committed to implementing previously announced stimulus measures and has pledged to provide financial support for infrastructure and major projects. The central bank will also support the property sector through mergers and acquisitions and help meet a reasonable need for bond issuance among private firms. The moves aim to stabilize growth and set the economy on a track to stability in 2023.

images.alt_text: After nearly two years of trouble, 2023 is likely to see a shakeout in the Chinese property sector that will help identify winners and losers.

site_title: Gold steady as investors eye economic data
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,815.00 per ounce as investors awaited economic data, including US GDP and jobless claim numbers. Rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion, making it less attractive. Meanwhile, US consumer confidence rose to an eight-month high, while fears of a recession persisted.
