China aims to implement policy measures to support its economy in early 2023, and the US Federal Reserve is expected to deliver more rate hikes next year.

images.alt_text: Gold is seen as an inflation hedge, but higher interest rates raise the opportunity cost of holding the asset.

site_title: Crypto firm Binance endures wild weeks in wake of FTX collapse
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has endured a wild week after the collapse of FTX, with customers withdrawing over $6 billion in three days. The company's CEO, Changpeng Zhao, has faced criticism for his handling of the crisis, including a recent interview where he claimed Binance "forgot" about a $2.1 billion payment. Analysts warn that Binance's demise could be devastating for the crypto industry, but others argue that the company's size and structure provide a significant cushion against collapse. US authorities are reportedly weighing charges against Binance, further exacerbating the uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Logos for Binance Coin, top, Ether, left, and Bitcoin inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

site_title: Indian stocks top Asian markets, strong economic growth fuels hope
summary: India's stock market has topped Asian markets, driven by strong corporate earnings, a post-pandemic retail boom, and a forecasted 6% economic growth in the next fiscal year, making it the world's fastest-growing major economy in 2023. The Nifty 50 index reached a record high in December, up 5% this year, while Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan fell 19%. Foreign investors have been attracted to India, with total deal value jumping 33% to $164 billion, despite selling $18 billion worth of Indian assets this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People watch a large screen displaying India's benchmark share index on the facade of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai, India, January 20, 2016. REUTERS/Shailesh Andrade/File Photo

A labourer separates grains of wheat from the husk at a wholesale grain market in Ghaziabad on May 17, 2022. - The United States hopes that India will reverse its decision to ban exports of wheat, which will worsen global shortages of the commodity, Washington's top diplomat to the United Nations said on May 17. (Photo by Prakash SINGH / AFP)

site_title: US ban on ‘Made in Hong Kong’ label breaches trade rules: WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has ruled that the US ban on labeling imports from Hong Kong as "Made in Hong Kong" violates international trade rules. The US had removed Hong Kong's special trading privileges after Beijing imposed a security law in 2020, sparking the complaint. The WTO panel said the US requirement gives Hong Kong products "less favourable" treatment than others, and that issues of national security cannot be reviewed in WTO dispute settlement. Hong Kong's government praised the ruling and called on the US to reverse the move, while the US strongly rejected the WTO's conclusions.

images.alt_text: The FCC said in 2021 China Telecom (Americas) “is subject to exploitation, influence and control by the Chinese government.”

site_title: Chinese cities give out free fever drugs as Covid flares
summary: China is distributing free anti-fever drugs to the public as Covid-19 cases surge, largely unchecked for the first time since the country's policy U-turn in December. The move comes as hospitals scramble for beds and blood, and authorities build special clinics. Despite a relatively low official death toll of 5,241, experts predict over 1 million Covid deaths in China next year, and warn that the country's health system is fragile. China has also received mRNA vaccines from Germany to administer to its citizens.

images.alt_text: An elderly resident stands from a chair after receiving a dose of a vaccine against coronavirus disease (COVID-19), during a government-organized visit to a vaccination center in Langxia town on the outskirts of Shanghai, China December 21, 2022. REUTERS/Brenda Goh

site_title: Europe: Shares post best day in nearly 6 weeks as upbeat Nike results lift retailers
summary: European shares rose 1.7% on Wednesday, driven by upbeat results from Nike and gains in the retail sector, lifting the Stoxx 600 index. Adidas and Puma led gains after Nike beat revenue and profit expectations, while JD Sports jumped 6.1%. The positive sentiment also improved the eurozone's economic outlook, contributing to the region-wide Stoxx 600 index's best day in nearly six weeks.

images.alt_text: Germany’s DAX index was down 0.4 per cent as German 10-year bond yields jumped to their highest levels in more than a month.

site_title: Tesla offers discount on some car models in US, Canada
summary: Tesla is offering discounts on Model 3 and Model Y vehicles delivered in the US and Canada before the end of the year, with a $7,500 credit in the US and a $5,000 credit in Canada. The discounts also include free supercharging for 10,000 km. The move comes amid concerns about softening demand and comes just days after the US Treasury Department delayed releasing its proposed guidance on EV battery sourcing. The discounts are part of Tesla's efforts to push sales, following a disappointing revenue report.

images.alt_text: Under Tom Zhu, Tesla Shanghai rebounded strongly from lockdowns this year to bring Tesla close to its growth target for 2022 of 50 per cent production growth.

site_title: Japan homebuyers to get clue on higher mortgages after BOJ jolt
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has doubled its yield-curve cap on the 10-year Japanese government bond (JGB) to 0.5% from 0.25%, likely pushing up mortgage interest rates in Japan next year. The Japan Housing Finance Agency will announce the coupon on a residential mortgage-backed security (RMBS) on Thursday, providing insight into how much more homebuyers will have to pay for a popular fixed-rate mortgage. The cheapest rate on the agency's 35-year fixed-rate mortgage has already climbed to 1.65%, the highest since 2014.

images.alt_text: Japan’s real GDP is expected to expand 1.5 per cent in the fiscal year beginning in April 2023.

site_title: Elon Musk expects Twitter to be ‘cash flow break-even’ next year
summary: Elon Musk expects Twitter to reach "cash flow break-even" status by next year, despite previously tracking towards a $3 billion annual negative cash flow. Musk implemented deep cost-cutting measures, laying off 50% of Twitter's employees and demanding long hours, leading to more employee departures. With $12.5 billion in debt and $1 billion in cash, Musk aims to grow subscriber revenue to become a significant part of the business.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo illustration taken on August 05, 2022, shows a cellphone displaying a photo of Elon Musk placed on a computer monitor filled with Twitter logos in Washington, DC. - Twitter suspended December 15, 2022, the accounts of more than a half-dozen journalists who had been writing about the company and its new owner Elon Musk. Some of the journalists had been tweeting about Twitter shutting down an @ElonJet account that tracked flights of the billionaire's private jet and about versions of that account hosted at other social networks. (Photo by SAMUEL CORUM / AFP)

site_title: Asia: Markets enjoy some much-needed festive cheer
summary: Asian markets rose ahead of the Christmas break, driven by US earnings and consumer confidence data that tempered recession worries. Global gains followed a week of heavy selling due to interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Key indexes on Wall Street and European equities also surged. The Bank of Japan's surprise shift in monetary policy and China's economic reopening contributed to the mini "Santa rally." Investors are now looking for signs that the US economy may avoid a recession, with some analysts suggesting a more balanced Fed approach in 2023.

images.alt_text: Sentiment was also being weighed down by a spike in Covid infections in China as officials roll back many of the strict containment measures that have been in place for almost three years.

site_title: UK businesses hit a ‘brick wall’ as Brexit dents exports
summary: The UK is struggling to adapt to the new post-Brexit rules, with over half of businesses facing difficulties and more than three-quarters saying the Trade and Cooperation Agreement has not helped increase sales or expand businesses. The British Chambers of Commerce reports that 77% of firms have experienced shortages of goods and services, and the cost of importing has increased. The long-term competitiveness of the UK could be seriously damaged if no dialogue improves the trading relationship with the EU, according to the director-general of the BCC.

images.alt_text: CER said departing the EU single market reduced goods trade by 7% in the second quarter of 2022.

site_title: Intel splits graphic chips unit into two
summary: Intel is splitting its graphic chips unit into two, combining the consumer graphics unit with its client computing group and accelerating computing teams with its data center and AI business. The move aims to better compete with Nvidia and AMD as AI use surges. Raja Koduri, who led the graphic chips unit, will return to his role as chief architect and oversee Intel's long-term technology strategy. The realignment is part of Intel's focus on accelerated computing, a growing segment dominated by Nvidia.

site_title: Shanghai hospital warns of 'tragic battle' as Covid spreads
summary: A Shanghai hospital has warned its staff to prepare for a "tragic battle" against Covid-19 as the city expects half of its 25 million residents to get infected by the end of the year. With over 5.43 million cases in Shanghai and 12.5 million in China, the hospital is receiving 400 patients a day with severe symptoms, four times the usual number. Experts predict China could face over a million Covid deaths next year due to low vaccination rates among the elderly population.

images.alt_text: Medical staff moves a patient into a fever clinic at a hospital, as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreaks continue in Shanghai, China, December 19, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: MS Holdings to delist on Dec 28
summary: MS Holdings, a CATALIST-LISTED company, will delist on December 28, following the successful privatization by its executive chairman Ng Chui Hwa through her investment vehicle, Kingswin Investment. The company accepted a voluntary unconditional cash offer of S$0.07 per share in October, representing a 16.7% premium over its previous closing price. The offer was accepted by 96.72% of shareholders, allowing Kingswin to acquire the remaining shares.

site_title: China developers’ recovery after US$74b rout faces Covid turmoil
summary: China's property sector is expected to experience a shakeout in 2023, with winners and losers emerging from nearly two years of trouble. Despite a recent policy bazooka from Beijing, the sector remains uncertain due to weak homebuyer confidence and an uncertain economic recovery. The sector has rebounded 60% since November, but analysts expect a 25% decline in contracted sales next year. State-owned developers are poised to gain market share, while financially stronger developers may receive lending support. The sector's recovery is expected to take time, with some analysts cautioning that a patient who has been in the hospital for 18 months may still take time to recover.

images.alt_text: China to correct past ‘mistaken’ housing policies: top economist

site_title: South Korea November producer inflation falls to 19-month low
summary: South Korea's producer inflation in November fell to a 19-month low, slowing for a fifth consecutive month. The producer price index rose 6.3% compared to the same period last year, down from a revised 7.3% annual rise in October. This marks its slowest gain since April 2021. The annual growth has been slowing since reaching a near 14-year high of 10.0% in June.

site_title: Structural and policy cushions mean Asean can still outperform rest of the world
summary: Asean economies are expected to outperform the rest of the world in 2023, despite rising inflation and geopolitical risks. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) projects a 4.9% growth in constant terms for the Asean-5 economies. However, structural and policy cushions mean the region can still outperform the world. The pace of monetary policy tightening has lagged in emerging markets, putting them under the spotlight. Inflation is expected to remain lower in Asean than elsewhere, with forecasted levels ranging from 3% to 6%. The region's growth will be uneven, with some countries, such as the Philippines and Vietnam, expected to outperform others. China's reopening is seen as a potential wildcard, which could partially offset the US and Europe slowdown and strengthen Asean's economic outlook.

images.alt_text: The EU billed its first full summit with the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) in Brussels as a chance to push trade relations with the region’s fast-growing economies.
A tour boat makes its way out to the Marina Bay in Singapore on December 9, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Malaysia's industrial production index (IPI) growth for the month of October moderated to 4.6 per cent year on year due to slower growth in mining and manufacturing sectors.

epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Japan government revises up fiscal 2023 growth forecast on higher capex, wages
summary: Japan's government revised its fiscal 2023 growth forecast to 1.5% expansion, higher than the 1.1% estimated by economists, driven by robust domestic demand and higher business expenditure. The forecast also includes a 1.7% increase in the consumer price index, with the government aiming for wage hikes to offset rising living costs. The upgraded projections suggest Japan will buck the global growth slowdown, with real GDP expected to reach fresh records for two consecutive years.

images.alt_text: The government cut its view on factory output for the first time in six months as global demand for semiconductors is pausing.

site_title: Airbus pledges deeper industrial ties with India
summary: Airbus plans to deepen its industrial presence in India, with CEO Guillaume Faury stating the company will continue to support civil aviation growth and expand its footprint in the country. This comes as India is increasingly involved in the civil supply chain, with Boeing and other companies seeking to utilize its suppliers. Airbus hopes to secure a new home for six A350s originally earmarked for Russia's Aeroflot at Air India, which is in advanced stages of negotiating a major fleet renewal and expansion involving hundreds of Airbus jets.

images.alt_text: The C919, made by Commercial Aircraft of China, is one of five ordered by China Eastern to be delivered through 2023.

site_title: Yen’s share of global payments drops to lowest level since 2014
summary: The Japanese yen's share in global payments has dropped to its lowest level since 2014, falling to 2.54% in November, according to Swift data. This decline follows a drop in the yen's valuation this year, making it one of the worst performers in 2022. The US dollar remains the top currency in global payments at 41.38%, while the euro usage increased to 36.12%. The Chinese yuan's usage also rose, narrowing the gap with the yen.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Marcos-backed Philippines sovereign wealth fund faces pushback from business groups
summary: The Philippines is set to establish a sovereign wealth fund, the Maharlika Investment Fund (MIF), backed by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. The fund, which aims to boost foreign investment, has faced resistance from business groups, with critics questioning its governance and potential impact on private sector investments. The bill was passed in just 18 days, despite concerns over its provisions, including exemptions from taxes and potential misuse of funds. Economists argue that the fund is not needed, given the country's fiscal deficit and high inflation rate, and that the government's priorities should focus on addressing pressing national concerns.

images.alt_text: Commercial and residential buildings in Manila, the Philippines, on Friday, Dec. 16, 2022. The Philippine central bank isn’t likely to pause interest-rate increases at least in the next two meetings as inflation remains far above target, Governor Felipe Medalla said. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
At 8.0 per cent in November, consumer price inflation is well beyond the Philippine central bank’s target range of 2-4 per cent for this year and the medium term.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday’s open amid global rally; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% or 8.9 points to 3,265.09 on Thursday, tracking global rallies, as investors took heart from confident consumer data. Gainers outnumbered losers 95 to 23, with Sembcorp Marine, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust leading gains. Banking stocks were mixed, with OCBC advancing 0.4% and DBS and UOB dropping 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The Straits Times Index has ended the midweek trading session up 0.1 per cent or 2.22 points, to close at 3,256.19.
Singtel is partnering Telkom and Medco Power to build its first data centre project in Indonesia.

site_title: Hong Kong’s tiniest apartments take biggest hit in housing slump
summary: Hong Kong's tiny apartments, often no bigger than a parking space, are experiencing a significant downturn due to the city's property slump. Since October, only 7 out of 9 transactions for the 128 sq ft T Plus project resulted in losses. The decline is attributed to relaxed mortgage rules and lower prices, allowing buyers to opt for larger units. Developers are struggling to sell these nano flats, with only 48% of studio apartments sold in the first 11 months of the year.

images.alt_text: People walk past a screen displaying the Hang Seng stock index at Central district, in Hong Kong, China October 25, 2022. REUTERS/Lam Yik

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Keppel, Ho Bee Land, Vicom
summary: Singaporean telecommunications company Singtel partnered Telkom and Medco Power to build its first data centre project in Indonesia. Keppel Corporation's land unit acquired a site for its Chinese senior living market entry, while Ho Bee Land expects a significant decrease in net profit due to fair value losses and higher interest expenses. Vicom's subsidiary Setsco Services won a tender to lease an industrial site for S$7 million over 20 years. Shares of these companies closed flat to slightly higher on Wednesday.

site_title: Justin Bieber nears US$200m deal to sell music rights: WSJ
summary: Justin Bieber is nearing a $200 million deal to sell his music rights to Hipgnosis Songs Capital, a Blackstone-backed company. The potential deal includes both his publishing and recorded music catalogue. Hipgnosis earns revenue from artists' music being streamed online or used in movies or advertising. Bieber rose to fame at 13 with his song "Baby". The deal's terms and completion are yet to be confirmed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Singer Justin Bieber poses at the premiere for the documentary television series "Justin Bieber: Seasons" in Los Angeles, California, U.S., January 27, 2020. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo
The second Avatar film adopts many of the latest visual technologies, including a high frame-rate 3D format that appears to have fallen prey to Japan’s laggard cinema industry.

site_title: Champagne makers celebrate record sales ahead of Christmas
summary: Champagne sales reached an all-time high in 2022, with 5.7 billion euros ($8.2 billion) in sales, driven by the relaxation of pandemic-related curbs and a surge in exports. Producers expect sales to reach a new record this year, despite inflation, with a 45% increase in the wine harvest in Champagne. Export sales are also expected to reach record highs, with the first three markets (US, Britain, and Japan) performing well.

images.alt_text: What sets wine apart are the memories after consumption. Wine’s power to conjure up a moment, an emotion and a sense of time and place is uncanny.

site_title: Micron sets 10% job cuts in 2023 due to ‘supply-demand mismatch’
summary: Micron Technology announced a 10% job cut in 2023 due to a supply-demand mismatch in the semiconductor market, citing a challenging profitability outlook. The company forecast a second-quarter loss of 62 US cents per share and adjusted its investment plans to US$7 billion from US$7.5 billion. Revenue fell 47% year-over-year to US$4.09 billion in the first quarter, with a net loss of US$195 million. The job cuts and reduced investment plans reflect the ongoing impact of inflation, rising interest rates, and geopolitical tensions on the PC and smartphone market.

images.alt_text: The production of Micron’s most advanced chip, which can store a third more data than older chips, comes as Japan tries to revive and modernise its once-mighty chip industry.

site_title: Tesla sends Shanghai boss and aides to jumpstart US output
summary: Tesla has sent its China boss, Tom Zhu, and a team of his aides to the US to troubleshoot production issues, amid concerns over CEO Elon Musk's distraction from the company. Zhu, who led Tesla Shanghai's recovery from lockdowns, is being groomed for a bigger role at Tesla. He and his team have been working on the Cybertruck and Model Y in California and Texas. Analysts expect US production to fall short of the company's growth target of 50% in 2022, but Zhu's expertise may help turn things around.

images.alt_text: Tesla is also going to freeze hiring, according to the Electrek report.

site_title: China Covid curbs easing unlikely to help HPH Trust in near term
summary: China's easing of Covid curbs is unlikely to benefit Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) in the near term, according to a research note from DBS. Despite the easing of curbs, China's worsening Covid situation could cause lockdowns and negatively affect productivity and economic output. HPHT's dismal price performance, down 80% from its IPO price, was attributed to global challenges, including the pandemic, supply chain disruptions, and interest rate hikes, at its 2022 annual general meeting.

images.alt_text: The augmented fiscal deficit was 7.75 trillion yuan (S$1.5 trillion) in January to November, according to Bloomberg calculations based on data from China's Ministry of Finance.
Beijing has sought to mitigate low growth with a series of easing measures to provide support, slashing key interest rates and pumping cash into the banking system.
“I would say more than half of colleagues in Beijing are sick, compared with 5 per cent-10 per cent in Shanghai,” said a fund manager at PICC Asset Management.
SHARES of HPH Trust were trading in hefty volumes on Wednesday (Jul 27), as price slipped roughly 2.1 per cent or US$0.005 to US$0.235 as at 9.19am. Some 2.1 million shares changed hands at the time.

In a bourse filing on Tuesday (Jul 26), HPH Trust reported a 6.8 per cent dip in profit attributable to unitholders of the trust to HK$716.3 million (S$126.5 million) in H1 2022 ended Jun 30, from HK$768.3 million a year ago.

site_title: Oil prices rise over US$2 on drawdown in US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices rose by over $2 a barrel on Wednesday, driven by a larger-than-expected draw in US crude stockpiles and hopes that China would relax some Covid-19 curbs. US crude inventories fell by 5.89 million barrels, while distillate inventories also declined. The forecast of a heavy snowstorm in the US potentially curtailing oil demand, however, capped gains. Brent crude futures rose 2.76% to $82.20 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures gained 2.7% to $78.29 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were buoyed by a softer dollar and a US plan to restock petroleum reserves, but gains were capped by uncertainty over the impact of rising Covid-19 cases in China.

site_title: Bankers see US$1.2t blue-chip loan market reviving in 2023
summary: The US blue-chip corporate loan market is expected to revive in 2023, driven by refinancing, dealmaking, and liquidity raising. Investment-grade companies raised $1.2 trillion in revolving credit facilities, term loans, and other syndicated loans in 2022, down 14% from last year's record high. Banks are transitioning to the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) benchmark, with much of the refinancing expected in the first quarter of 2023. M&A financing is also expected to increase, with a focus on structuring deals differently due to capital requirements.

images.alt_text: A mix of rising inflation and interest rate hikes aimed at taming it have hurt stock market valuations and eroded investor appetite for the high-growth IPO candidates that have driven deals in recent years.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on consumer data, Nike results
summary: US stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.6% at 33,376.48, following a strong consumer confidence report and Nike's better-than-expected profits. The consumer confidence index jumped to 108.3, higher than November's figure, and Nike's 12.2% gain helped drive the market higher. Analysts say the market rebounded after four gloomy sessions due to recession worries and central bank efforts to counter inflation, with FedEx and other stocks also rising.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 178.35 points, or 0.54 per cent, at the open to 33,028.09.

site_title: US current account deficit shrinks in third quarter
summary: The US current account deficit narrowed 9.1% to $217.1 billion in the third quarter, the smallest gap since the second quarter of 2021. This was driven by a record-high export increase, which offset a decline in imports. The deficit represented 3.4% of GDP, the smallest share in two years.

site_title: Singapore businesses shouldn’t underestimate impact of new global minimum tax rules
summary: Singapore businesses should not underestimate the impact of new global minimum tax rules under the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) 2.0 framework, set to be introduced from 2024. The rules will affect all business groups with annual global revenue of $1.1 billion or more, regardless of industry, and will introduce a 15% global minimum tax. This may lead to higher cash tax costs and reduced earnings per share for affected companies, as well as increased compliance risks and the need for new governance processes.

images.alt_text: The global minimum tax is only one part, known as Pillar Two, of the OECD agreement.
According to the annual report, CIT revenues as a share of gross domestic product (GDP) and total tax revenues have fallen between 2019 and 2020 as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hsieh Fu Hua appointed WWF-Singapore chairman
summary: Former Singapore Exchange (SGX) chief executive Hsieh Fu Hua has been appointed chairman of the World Wide Fund for Nature Singapore (WWF-Singapore), replacing Achal Agarwal who stepped down in December 2020. Hsieh, a banking veteran, has supported WWF-Singapore's projects and expressed his commitment to enhancing the organization's work and standing under his leadership. With his involvement, WWF-Singapore aims to harness the power of the finance sector to create resilient and sustainable economies contributing to the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals.

images.alt_text: WWF-Singapore to teach public about responsible investing after strong uptake for industry courses
An estimated 63 per cent of Asia Pacific's GDP, US$19 trillion, is at risk from nature loss.
“The Taxonomy was supposed to help guide consumers and enable them to compare green investments,” Monique Goyens, director-general of the European Consumer Organisation (BEUC), said.

site_title: Sweden’s housing market seeks bottom as price drop continues
summary: Sweden's housing market continues to decline, with home prices dropping by nearly 15% since March, marking the eighth straight month of declines. This represents the worst slump in three decades. Most forecasters predict a 20% slump from peak levels, potentially erasing pandemic-era price gains, with a more adverse scenario involving rapidly rising unemployment and higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian in the Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai. Economists hope China's pivot out of its zero-Covid policy could help to shore up global growth.. But China's transition from zero-Covid is unlikely to be smooth.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on strong Nike earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by Nike's better-than-expected earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 178.35 points, or 0.54%, to 33,028.09. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 up 17.87 points, or 0.47%, and the Nasdaq Composite up 44.89 points, or 0.43%. Investors await economic data for interest rate hike hints, while awaiting more economic data for future interest rate hikes.

site_title: Germany sends first batch of BioNTech Covid vaccines to China
summary: Germany has sent its first batch of BioNTech Covid-19 vaccines to China, primarily for German expatriates, following a deal during Chancellor Olaf Scholz's visit to Beijing. The shipment comes as China agrees to allow German nationals to receive the vaccine, and in return, China will allow Chinese citizens in Europe to receive China's SinoVac vaccine. This gesture aims to strengthen ties between the two countries amid the pandemic, with China facing a surge of cases and potentially over a million Covid deaths next year.

site_title: The year’s best books on wine (and whisky)
summary:
The year's best books on wine and whisky have been compiled by wine writer Eric Asimov. Key recommendations include:

* "To Fall in Love, Drink This: A Wine Writer's Memoir" by Alice Feiring, a personal and insightful exploration of wine's role in community and culture.
* "Vino: The Essential Guide to Real Italian Wine" by Joe Campanale and Joshua David Stein, a comprehensive guide to Italian wines that offers a fresh perspective on quality and authenticity.
* "The Wine Bible 3rd Edition" by Karen MacNeil, a concise and authoritative reference guide that covers the basics of wine and its pairing with food.
* "The World of Natural Wine: What It Is, Who Makes It and Why It Matters" by Aaron Ayscough, a comprehensive overview of natural wine that highlights its complexities and importance.
* "Drinking With the Valkyries: Writings on Wine" by Andrew Jefford, a collection of essays that explore the poetry and mystique of wine.
* "A Sense of Place: A Journey Around Scotland's Whisky" by Dave Broom, a beautifully written exploration of Scotland's whisky culture and its connection to place and heritage.

images.alt_text: What sets wine apart are the memories after consumption. Wine’s power to conjure up a moment, an emotion and a sense of time and place is uncanny.

site_title: Brexit left the UK economy 5.5% smaller, report says
summary: The UK economy has shrunk by 5.5% since Brexit, according to a report by the Centre for European Reform. The departure from the EU single market reduced goods trade by 7% and investment by 11% in the second quarter of 2022, contributing to slower growth and higher tax revenues. This has led to a £46 billion tax hike and £105 billion budget shortfall. The report suggests that if the UK had remained in the EU, tax revenues would have been £40 billion higher annually, easing the need for austerity measures.

site_title: Keppel Land to acquire first senior living facility in Nanjing, China
summary: Keppel Land has acquired a 19,846 square meter senior living facility in Nanjing, China's Qixia District, marking its first foray into the Chinese senior living market. The facility, set to open in the second half of 2023, will be an assisted-living community with about 400 beds. The acquisition aims to capitalize on the region's aging population, with 20% of the population above 60 years old. Keppel Land plans to expand into other senior living markets in China and beyond, with signed Memoranda of Understanding for collaboration and high-quality senior care services.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The group is expected to gain about 135 million yuan following the sale, which is expected to be completed by the end of this year.
Upon completion of the transaction, Keppel Land will hold a 39.5 per cent effective interest in Samhwan Building (pictured), with the remainder in the hands of private funds of Keppel Capital.

site_title: Failed to protect soccer from interference: Blatter
summary: Former Fifa president Sepp Blatter stated that he was unable to protect soccer from interference due to over-commercialization. Blatter, who led Fifa for 17 years, believes that the organization was "squeezed" for more revenue, exemplified by the recent World Cup in Qatar. He also expressed concerns about Fifa's involvement in club football, stating that it has no business in the field. Blatter's comments come as he awaits the appeal of his 2015 conviction, which he was cleared of by a Swiss court in June.

site_title: BT’s World Cup CEO challenge nets S$26,000 for Budding Artists Fund
summary: A group of 16 business leaders in Singapore raised S$26,000 for charity through The Business Times-World Cup 2022 CEO Challenge. Participants "adopted" teams and made donations to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund if their team was eliminated. The final match saw Argentina defeat France, with Prudential Singapore's CEO Dennis Tan emerging as the overall winner and donating to the fund. OCBC Bank, runner-up in the challenge, also made a significant donation to the fund. The total raised will support arts training for financially disadvantaged children and youths.

images.alt_text: Fans flocked to buy Nike-brand Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) soccer club jerseys, with sales in particular for Messi and Mbappe jerseys on the official PSG online store surging by more than 200 per cent on Sunday.

Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Final - Argentina v France - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - December 18, 2022
Argentina's Lionel Messi and teammates celebrate winning the World Cup REUTERS/Peter Cziborra     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
Argentina fans celebrate winning the Fifa World Cup at the Obelisk in Buenos Aires with an image of team captain Lionel Messi.

site_title: Yen holds on to big gains after BOJ’s surprise policy tweak
summary: The Japanese yen surged 3.8% on Tuesday, its largest one-day rise since 1998, after the Bank of Japan unexpectedly tweaked its "yield curve control" policy, allowing government bond yields to move more freely. The yen slipped 0.13% on Wednesday, trading at 131.88 per US dollar, as traders digested the change. Analysts expect further tightening of monetary policy, which could lead to higher yields and a stronger yen.

site_title: No Signboard places six subsidiaries into creditors’ voluntary liquidation
summary: NO SIGNBOARD to place six subsidiaries into creditors' voluntary liquidation due to cash flow problems and inability to pay debts. The subsidiaries, including investment holding companies and restaurants, were incorporated in 2017 and 2018 and are now dormant. The move aims to address the company's financial difficulties and ensure it can continue operating.

images.alt_text: No Signboard unit to pursue creditors' voluntary liquidation
Fast food chain Mom's Touch shuts all outlets operated by No Signboard in Singapore
No Signboard places beer subsidiary into creditors' voluntary liquidation

site_title: Vicom wins tender for lease of Jalan Papan site for S$7 million
summary: Vicom's wholly-owned subsidiary Setsco Services has won a tender to lease an industrial site at Jalan Papan for S$7 million over 20 years. The 12,400.4 square meter site will be developed for testing, inspection, and certification activities.

site_title: US consumer confidence jumps to highest level in eight months
summary: US consumer confidence jumped to its highest level in eight months, reaching 108.3 in December, exceeding forecasts. The increase was driven by easing inflation and dropping petrol prices. A measure of expectations, which reflects consumers' six-month outlook, rose to 82.4, the highest since January. This marks a three-month high for the gauge of current conditions, which advanced to 147.2. The improvement is seen as a positive sign for the US economy.

site_title: WTO rules against US in Hong Kong labelling dispute
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) ruled that the US should not treat products imported from Hong Kong as coming from China, as the US had done since 2020. The US had argued that Hong Kong was not sufficiently autonomous to justify different treatment from China. The WTO decision comes after the US passed an order in 2020 requiring Hong Kong imports to be marked as Chinese, despite Hong Kong being a separate WTO member. The ruling is seen as a victory for Hong Kong, which had sought to maintain its separate identity in international trade.

images.alt_text: China’s push to further its own semiconductor industry, and to develop advanced military systems, has been complicated by the export controls.

site_title: Tata’s Bigbasket eyes IPO by 2025 after US$200m funding
summary: Bigbasket, India's largest online grocery firm, plans to list its shares within 24-36 months after raising $200 million in funding, valuing the company at $3.2 billion. The company, controlled by Tata Group, aims to expand its pan-India reach and boost its quick commerce arm, with plans to increase dark stores to 300 outlets by March. The IPO comes as the company seeks to strengthen its business model amid concerns over valuations and profitability in the Indian technology sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tata Motors logos are pictured outside their flagship showroom in Mumbai May 28, 2013. Picture taken May 28, 2013. REUTERS/Vivek Prakash/File Photo

site_title: China says it will implement policies to support 2023 growth
summary: China's Cabinet has announced plans to implement policies to support the economy in 2023, aiming for improved growth. The government will speed up construction of major investment projects and equipment upgrading, and balance Covid-prevention measures with economic development. China will also meet demand for Covid-prevention materials and drugs, and reasonably import urgently needed goods. The Cabinet aims to stabilize growth and achieve a good start for 2023, following a series of policy measures rolled out in recent months to support the slowing economy.

images.alt_text: China to correct past ‘mistaken’ housing policies: top economist

The Chinese government’s plan seems to be to weather the initial reopening wave quickly, and get the economy – hobbled by months of crippling lockdowns, mandatory quarantines and testing – back to consistent growth.
The index is based on a monthly survey conducted by Standard Chartered of more than 500 smaller companies across China.

site_title: US existing home sales fall for 10th straight month in November
summary: US existing home sales plummeted 7.7% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.09 million units in November, marking the lowest level since May 2020. Sales have declined for 10 straight months, with the housing market squeezed by higher mortgage rates. The median existing house price increased 3.5% to $370,700, while inventory levels remained tight, with 1.14 million homes on the market. The housing market's slowdown is attributed to the Federal Reserve's interest rate-hiking cycle, which aims to slow unacceptably high inflation.

images.alt_text: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 22: An 'open house' flag is displayed outside a single family home on September 22, 2022 in Los Angeles, California. The U.S. housing market is seeing a slow down in home sales due to the Federal Reserve raising mortgage interest rates to help fight inflation.   Allison Dinner/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Putin oversees launch of Siberian gas field feeding pipeline to China
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin oversaw the launch of the Kovykta gas field in Siberia, set to feed into the Power of Siberia pipeline carrying Russian gas to China. The field has 1.8 trillion cubic meters of recoverable reserves, marking a significant shift in Russia's energy strategy to supply gas to the east as the EU cuts reliance on Russian energy. Putin aims to boost annual gas sales to China to 48 bcm by 2025 and 88 bcm by 2030, with plans to construct additional pipelines.

site_title: UK retail sales pick up unexpectedly in December: CBI
summary: UK retail sales rebounded unexpectedly in December, with the CBI's distributive trades index rising to +11 from -19 in November, exceeding forecasts. However, retailers expect sales to decline again in 2023 due to high inflation and the rising cost of living. The CBI's survey also showed readings around average for the previous months. Despite a slight drop in consumer price inflation, the Bank of England expects it to remain high over the coming months.

images.alt_text: UK public borrowing for the first eight months of the financial year, from April to November, totalled £105.4 billion, up by £7.6 billion from the same period in 2021.
Falling house prices and higher borrowing costs will drain more money from household balance sheets, making many homeowners feel poorer and perhaps more cautious about spending.

site_title: Saudi’s Public Investment Fund buys 30% stake in cooling company Saudi Tabreed
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has acquired a 30% stake in cooling company Saudi Tabreed through a private placement of shares. National Central Cooling Company (Tabreed) has also increased its stake to 21.8% after acquiring additional shares. The deal is valued at approximately US$250 million. Saudi Tabreed provides district cooling services to major urban developments in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf region, including the Red Sea Project and Saudi Aramco.

site_title: Jamie Dimon is more crucial than ever to the bank he's run for 17 years
summary: Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase, is facing significant challenges as he nears the end of his 17-year tenure. Despite the bank's record $48 billion profit in 2021, investors have criticized his heavy spending on technology projects and compensation practices. The stock has dropped 17% this year, and Dimon has been jolted by markets with his predictions of an impending US recession. As he considers his successor, Dimon remains a dominant figure in finance, with a reputation for market prescience and a ability to "back up" his tough talk. The board has said it may keep him on as chairman after he steps down as CEO, ensuring his continued influence.

images.alt_text: Economic conditions are going to “tighten meaningfully from here,” Goldman Sachs Group chief executive officer David Solomon said at Saudi Arabia’s Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh.
In late 2021, JPMorgan was advising Clayton, Dubilier & Rice on its purchase of WM Morrison’s Supermarket in the biggest UK leveraged buyout deal in a decade.

site_title: Tesla to freeze hiring, lay off employees next quarter: Electrek
summary: Tesla plans to freeze hiring and lay off employees in the next quarter, according to a report by Electrek. This move comes as investors have raised concerns over CEO Elon Musk's distraction with Twitter and weakness in demand from China. Tesla analysts have also cut their price targets due to concerns about deliveries next year. Musk previously announced a 10% reduction in the salaried workforce over the next three months. The company's shares rose 1% in response to the news.

site_title: BMW broadens partnership with battery-maker Solid Power
summary: BMW has broadened its partnership with battery-maker Solid Power, paying US$20 million through June 2024 for proprietary technology, including solid-state electrode design and manufacturing expertise. The deal aims to lower the cost of BMW's electric vehicles. As part of the agreement, BMW will work closely with Solid Power to produce solid-state cells at its pilot facility, accelerating the commercialization of the promising cell technology. This partnership is part of BMW's efforts to develop fully new platforms for its electric vehicles, with a focus on increasing driving range and reducing costs.

images.alt_text: “Even if you consider yourself a premium manufacturer, it is wrong to leave the lower market segment – that will be the core of your business in the future,” Zipse said.

site_title: Dealmakers brace for slow 2023 recovery after global M&A sinks
summary: Global M&A activity fell 37% to $3.66 trillion in 2022, marking a decline from the previous year's record high of $5.9 trillion. Despite this, dealmakers predict a slow recovery in 2023, with many citing macroeconomic uncertainty and a tougher antitrust climate. Key deals, such as Broadcom's $61 billion acquisition of VMWare, were advised by top investment banks, and several megadeals worth tens of billions of dollars fell apart in 2022. However, private equity funds are expected to kick-start the recovery, and dealmakers remain optimistic about cross-border M&A activity in 2023.

site_title: India extends halt on futures trade in key farm commodities by a year
summary: India's market regulator, SEBI, extended the suspension of futures trading in key farm commodities by a year, until December 20, 2023. The suspension affects soybean and its derivatives, crude palm oil, wheat, paddy rice, chickpea, green gram, and rapeseed mustard, amid efforts to tame food inflation. The move is a setback for the industry, which had been expecting trading to resume after annual retail inflation eased.

images.alt_text: An oil pipeline is laid next to the Vopak-Dialog oil storage facility (R) and a Refinery and Petrochemical Integrated Development (RAPID) project construction site in Pangerang in Malaysia's southern state of Johor October 6, 2015. Liquefied Petroleum Gas, long a niche product used by the poor to cook and the rich to barbecue, has become a rare bright spot amid a broad commodities rout, riding on the wave of strong economic growth in India and parts of Southeast Asia.   REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: HSBC wins court case over convicted billionaire’s ponzi scheme
summary: HSBC has won a UK court case against the administrators of SIB, a bank controlled by convicted billionaire Allen Stanford, who perpetrated a $140 million Ponzi scheme. The court dismissed an appeal, effectively ending a long-running dispute, with HSBC arguing it had no duty to block suspicious payments. HSBC, acting as the correspondent bank to SIB, had previously won a lower court case on the same grounds. Stanford is serving a 110-year prison sentence for the scheme, which affected over 17,000 investors worldwide.

site_title: G20 to Asean: Translating vision into action
summary: The G20 summit in Bali emphasized the need for a more inclusive, sustainable, and balanced global economic transformation. Amidst the war in Ukraine, Indonesia's G20 leadership stressed the importance of reforming collective commitments. The year 2022 showed the significance of multilateralism in addressing global crises. Asean is seen as a potential epicenter of global economic transformation in the years ahead, requiring a collaborative effort from nations.

images.alt_text: Sri Mulyani Indrawati, Finance Minister, Indonesia Ministry of Finance. speaking at the inaugural Asean+3 Economic Cooperation and Financial Stability Forum, organised by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO).
The flags of G20 member nations are flown in Bali, the venue for this year's summit.

site_title: Europe's new Vega-C rocket lost shortly after lift-off
summary: Europe's Vega-C rocket lost shortly after lift-off from French Guiana on December 20, 2022, with two Airbus satellites on board. The failure threatens to ground the Vega-C, leaving Europe without a short-term way to launch satellites into orbit. The setback comes after delays to the Ariane 6 rocket and cancelled Russian cooperation due to the Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: US Navy divers depart the U.S.S. Portland in small vessels as part of recovery operations before Nasa's Orion Capsule splashed down after a successful uncrewed mission.

site_title: Local shares book minor gains on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the midweek trading session up 0.1% or 2.22 points, closing at 3,256.19. The local market saw minor gains despite concerns over inflationary pressures and interest rate hikes. Regional markets were mixed, with some indices down and others up. The gains were attributed to traders hunting for bargains in the local market.

images.alt_text: China’s blue-chip CSI 300 Index was flat, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.17 per cent.
The fair value loss was a result of changes in the fair value of Golden Agri's investments in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Ho Bee Land flags ‘significant decrease’ in six-month, full-year net profit
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singapore-based real estate developer, expects a "significant decrease" in its net profit for the six months and full year ending Dec 31, despite year-on-year revenue and operating profit increases. The company's revenue and operating profit rose due to higher sales of development properties in Singapore and Australia, as well as rental income from investment properties. However, fair-value losses in London's investment properties, primarily caused by higher cap rates, offset these gains.

images.alt_text: Nicholas Chua, chief executive officer of Ho Bee Land said the enlarged portfolio of investment properties after the acquisition of The Scalpel continues to underpin the group’s profit and sales from the Sentosa Cove projects have also been encouraging.

site_title: Global coffee production to rebound in 2022/23
summary: Global coffee production is forecast to rebound in 2022/23, rising by 6.6 million bags to 172.8 million, driven by a larger crop in Brazil. Consumption is expected to increase by 800,000 bags to 167.9 million. Coffee prices have fallen by 25% since February due to the improving supply situation. Arabica production in Brazil is forecast to rise by 3.4 million bags, while Vietnam's production is expected to decline by 1.4 million bags due to reduced yields. Global stocks are forecast to rise by 1.5 million bags to 34.1 million.

images.alt_text: “Farmers have harvested most of their crop and the outcome is not very promising. Output is going to be 20 per cent lower than previously forecast,” said a trader based in the coffee belt.

site_title: China takes Covid vaccination drive to villages as cases surge
summary: China ramps up Covid vaccination efforts in villages as cases surge, with over-60s being targeted due to the dismantling of its zero-Covid regime. The government has deployed specialist vehicles and set up temporary clinics in villages to boost coverage rates, which have lagged among the elderly. Vaccination efforts are also being accompanied by public information campaigns to alleviate concerns about vaccine safety and effectiveness. The goal is to ensure the vulnerable population receives necessary protection against Covid-19, particularly ahead of the Chinese New Year when elderly residents are expected to travel.

images.alt_text: The Chinese government’s plan seems to be to weather the initial reopening wave quickly, and get the economy – hobbled by months of crippling lockdowns, mandatory quarantines and testing – back to consistent growth.
China’s blue-chip CSI 300 Index was flat, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.17 per cent.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's T-bill rates rose to 4.28% in the last auction for 2022, with experts predicting they will be buoyant in the coming months. Singapore and China's Jiangsu province agreed to work closer on green development and innovation, with 16 memoranda of understanding signed. South Korean and Chinese telcos are seen as top contenders in the Asian telecoms space due to rapid 5G adoption and low competition. Doctor Anywhere raised US$38.8m in a Series C1 funding round, while businesses warned the upcoming GST hike is part of broader inflation woes.

site_title: BOJ credibility in question as traders test Kuroda’s new red line
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is facing criticism over its latest policy decision, which has raised concerns about its credibility. The central bank's decision to widen its yield curve control band has blindsided economists and investors, causing the yen to surge against the US dollar and bond yields to rise. Prominent economists are calling for the BOJ to scrap its yield curve control to avoid repeated market ructions, while traders are betting that the BOJ will abandon its 0.8% yield cap on 10-year bonds. The move has implications for global markets, as Japanese firms and individuals are major buyers of overseas assets.

images.alt_text: Japanese 10,000 yen banknotes counted by a cash counting machine at the Birdy Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 16, 2022. Amateur investors have been coming to swap their bills for yen at Birdy Exchange,  seeing a buying opportunity in the currency's fall to its weakest levels against the Hong Kong dollar since 2002. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: People pass by an electronic screen showing Japan's Nikkei share price index inside a conference hall  in Tokyo, Japan June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
The government cut its view on factory output for the first time in six months as global demand for semiconductors is pausing.

site_title: Crypto could cause next financial crisis: India central bank chief
summary: India's central bank governor Shaktikanta Das warned that cryptocurrency markets risk causing the next global financial crisis due to their "inherent risks." The collapse of FTX is cited as proof of these risks. Unlike traditional products, cryptocurrencies lack underlying value, making them vulnerable to market fluctuations. This comes as India's crypto owners face a challenging year, including a global market collapse and steep domestic taxes.

images.alt_text: Bankman-Fried signed his surrender documents on Tuesday.
Crashes, contagion, collapses came in such quick succession that crypto investors were, towards the end of the year, asking serious existential questions.

site_title: Thousands of UK ambulance staff strike as public urged to avoid risks
summary: Thousands of UK ambulance staff in England and Wales went on strike over pay, increasing pressure on the state-funded health service. The strike resulted in fewer ambulances on the road, with only life-threatening cases prioritized. The government advised the public to use their "common sense" and warned of reduced ambulance services. Unions claimed the government's refusal to negotiate a pay rise above inflation led to the strike, which risked patient safety. The strike follows a nurses' walkout the day before.

images.alt_text: NHS staff members attach a Unison sign outside NHS London Ambulance Service, on the day of a planned strike, amid a dispute with the government over pay, in London, Britain December 21, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: China stocks flat, Hong Kong inch higher on border reopening hopes
summary: China's blue-chip CSI 300 Index and Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.34% ahead of the festive season. China's healthcare system was tested as Covid cases spiked, with hospitals reporting increased patient numbers. Despite this, analysts believe economic growth will recover quarter by quarter and surpass 5% in 2023, with risk assets likely to post good performance. Hong Kong's tech giants and HSBC led gains, while the US offered support to China's surging Covid-19 outbreak.

images.alt_text: The index is based on a monthly survey conducted by Standard Chartered of more than 500 smaller companies across China.

site_title: Chinese cities, factories tell people with mild Covid to go back to work
summary: The Chinese government is allowing workers with mild COVID-19 symptoms to return to work in some cities, including Chongqing, Zhejiang, and Anhui, as the country reopens after abandoning its "Covid Zero" regime. This move aims to minimize the economic impact of a surge in cases, which have hit major urban centers, particularly Beijing. Experts predict a "tsunami" of COVID-19 cases across the nation. The shift marks a significant change in the government's approach to COVID-19, from stringent measures to a more relaxed stance.

images.alt_text: Workers in protective suits move a casket outside a crematorium at a funeral home, amid the coronavirus disease outbreak in Beijing.
China’s blue-chip CSI 300 Index was flat, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.17 per cent.

site_title: China to correct past ‘mistaken’ housing policies: top economist
summary: China's top economist, Yao Yang, says the government will roll out supportive measures to correct past "mistaken" housing policies that curbed the sector's growth. The measures aim to stop the decline of the housing market, which has fallen 23% since 2022. Yao, dean of the National School of Development, believes the government will promote the housing sector again, citing President Xi Jinping's pledge to support housing demand in 2023. Yao criticizes the "three red lines" rule, which he says was a mistake that hurt healthy companies, and expects fiscal and monetary policy to boost growth next year.

images.alt_text: Unfinished apartment buildings and construction scaffolding at a housing development in Shanghai, China, on Oct. 30, 2022.  After a year on the sidelines, Beijing has taken steps to get hundreds of billions of dollars into the hands of the countryÕs flailing real estate developers. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)

site_title: Musk says cost-cutting averted US$3b Twitter shortfall
summary: Elon Musk stated that cost-cutting measures have averted a US$3 billion Twitter shortfall, citing that the company was on track to post revenue of around US$3 billion and had around US$1 billion in cash on its balance sheet. Musk confirmed that advertisers have been asking tough questions about their return on investment, but he expects Twitter to "roughly" hit cash flow break-even next year. Musk attributed the turnaround to his efforts to cut costs, including laying off more than half of Twitter's staff, and stepped down as CEO once a replacement is found.

site_title: South Korean, Chinese telcos strongest contenders in Asian telecoms space: analysts
summary: South Korean and Chinese telecommunications companies are seen as the strongest contenders in the Asian telecoms space due to their early adoption of 5G technology and benign competitive environments. South Korea's KT Corp and SK Telecom have outperformed the benchmark Kospi index, with dividend yields expected to rise. China's telcos, including China Telecom, China Mobile, and China Unicom, are also favored for their strong dividend performance and growing earnings. Analysts suggest that Singapore's telcos, such as Singtel, remain good defensive picks due to their relatively well-developed market and lower capital expenditure requirements.

images.alt_text: While Singtel and StarHub both have very substantial and profitable consumer operations, margins on consumer services have been hit as a result of stiff competition.
A groundbreaking ceremony at Singtel's new hyperscale data centre in Kabil Industrial Estate in Batam, Indonesia. The ceremony was jointly held by Singtel and partners Telkom and Medco Power.

site_title: Avatar sequel crashes movie theatre equipment in Japan
summary: Disney's Avatar: The Way of Water experienced technical difficulties during its opening weekend in Japan, with some theaters crashing screening equipment due to the film's high frame-rate 3D format. Audiences reported abrupt cancellations and staff apologized, issuing refunds. To screen the film, at least one theater reduced the frame rate by half. The issue appears to be related to Japan's slow cinema industry upgrade to the latest equipment.

site_title: Doctor Anywhere raises US$38.8m from investors including IHH Healthcare, EDBI
summary: Doctor Anywhere, a healthcare company, has raised US$38.8 million in its Series C1 round led by Novo Holdings, with participation from IHH Healthcare and Singapore's EDBI. The funding will be used to acquire Asian Healthcare Specialists and accelerate growth. Founder Lim Wai Mun said the acquisition will enable the delivery of "more integrated, holistic care and greater value" to users. This brings the total capital raised to nearly US$140 million, with the company continuing to look for opportunities and targeted acquisitions. The acquisition is expected to strengthen the company's capabilities.

images.alt_text: Apart from garnering no less than 90 per cent of the total shares to make this offer a deal, Labrador Park also requires that all clearances, waivers and approvals must be secured from the landlords of the premises leased by the Asian Healthcare Specialists group.

Lim Wai Mun of Doctor Anywhere, picked as the EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2022 Singapore, will go on to compete with other global contenders at the EY World Entrepreneur of the Year in June next year.

site_title: Musk will resign as Twitter CEO and focus on engineering
summary: Elon Musk will step down as Twitter CEO after finding a successor, with over 10 million votes supporting his resignation in a straw poll. Musk plans to retain control over the company's engineering teams and has already found a few trusted individuals to take on the role. The billionaire executive has overseen significant staff layoffs, sparking concerns about the platform's future, and has warned of the risk of bankruptcy. Musk's departure marks a significant shift in his priorities, with engineering taking center stage, and he will focus on engineering full-time.

images.alt_text: With about four hours left and 14 million votes cast, 57 per cent of participants have said yes.

site_title: Malaysia floods force tens of thousands to evacuate
summary: Malaysia is experiencing severe floods, forcing over 72,000 people to evacuate as torrential rains inundate towns and cities. At least two deaths have been reported, with emergency responders wading in waist-deep water to rescue victims. Authorities have set up hundreds of relief shelters and warned of more floods in the coming days due to the monsoon season. Experts attribute the vulnerability to rapid urbanization and deforestation, exacerbated by climate change.

site_title: India on lookout for new Covid variants as cases in other countries climb
summary: India's government has asked states to monitor for new Covid-19 variants amid a surge in cases in China and other countries, including Japan, the US, and South Korea. Health Minister Mansukh Mandaviya has directed states to send positive case samples to 54 genome sequencing laboratories to detect any new variants. This comes as China lifts Covid restrictions, leading to a spike in infections. With 44 million Covid cases reported, India has the most cases globally, but its number of confirmed infections has fallen sharply in recent months.

images.alt_text: People walk at a crowded market amidst the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), in the old quarters of Delhi, India, April 6, 2021. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Chinese banks edge out Wall Street rivals in global IPO rankings
summary: Chinese banks have taken the top spots in global IPO rankings, with Citic Securities pushing ahead of Goldman Sachs as the top underwriter of IPOs this year. Chinese brokerages have muscled into the historically dominated market, with six of the world's top 10 IPO banks being Chinese, commanding a 28% market share. This trend is attributed to mainland authorities encouraging more listings on domestic exchanges and rising tensions with the US causing Chinese companies to list domestically or in Hong Kong instead. Despite a record year for Chinese IPOs, with $93.8 billion raised, the US market contributed only $24 billion.

images.alt_text: “I would say more than half of colleagues in Beijing are sick, compared with 5 per cent-10 per cent in Shanghai,” said a fund manager at PICC Asset Management.

The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) logo is displayed atop a gong at the HKEX Connect Hall in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Most Hong Kong people were caught off-guard by Beijing's proposal of the national security bill. Executive Council Member and the Chairman of HKEX Laura Cha said she was also surprised but was convinced the bill would ensure clarity and stability of the city. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg

site_title: Hearses queue at Beijing crematorium, even as China reports no new Covid deaths
summary: China's "zero-Covid" policy has been dismantled, leading to a surge in cases and a strain on its health system. A Beijing crematorium has a queue of 40 hearses, with 20 coffins awaiting cremation, despite the government reporting no new Covid-19 deaths. Experts predict over a million Covid deaths in China next year. The health system is scrambling for beds, blood, and pharmacies, with hospitals racing to build special clinics. The government downplays concerns about virus mutations, but a respiratory expert predicts a spike in severe cases in Beijing by late January.

images.alt_text: The government cut its view on factory output for the first time in six months as global demand for semiconductors is pausing.

site_title: Looking back at dining in 2022
summary: Chefs and restaurateurs reflect on 2022, acknowledging the industry's recovery from COVID-19 restrictions while facing rising prices and manpower shortages. They express gratitude for the ability to dine out freely and look forward to the holiday season. Meanwhile, local businesses offer gift ideas, festive reading recommendations, and unique gyms for New Year's resolutions. The article highlights the reopening of Elan, a French-inspired restaurant, and features various other articles on local businesses and initiatives.

site_title: Hong Kong records highest quarterly net outflows in a year
summary: Hong Kong's portfolio investment saw a record net outflow of HK$239.17 billion in the July to September quarter, driven mainly by equities and plummeting initial public offerings. This represents a 34.4% increase from the previous quarter and the highest quarterly outflow in a year. The decline in initial public offerings was 74% for the first nine months of the year.

images.alt_text: People walk past a screen displaying the Hang Seng stock index at Central district, in Hong Kong, China October 25, 2022. REUTERS/Lam Yik
A total of 8,600 withdrawal claims from the Mandatory Provident Fund were made in the July-September quarter this year, compared with 9,300 claims during the same period in 2021.

site_title: Higher mortgage rates depress US single-family housing starts, building permits
summary: US single-family housing starts plummeted to a two-and-a-half-year low in November, dropping 4.1% to 828,000 units, while building permits for single-family homes also fell 7.1% to 781,000 units. The decline was attributed to higher mortgage rates, which have surged to above 7% and forced many potential homebuyers to remain renters. The housing market has contracted for six straight quarters, with residential investment expected to cut off 0.7 percentage point from gross domestic product this quarter.

images.alt_text: Higher costs for materials and labour have made it more expensive to build.

site_title: German employment outlook for Q1 2023 is positive: Ifo
summary: Germany's employment outlook for Q1 2023 is positive, driven by service providers, according to the Ifo economic institute. Despite a rise in unemployment in November, the labor market remains stable, influenced by high energy prices and record inflation. A separate Ifo survey showed improved business morale in December, with personnel service providers optimistic about the coming months. The positive outlook is attributed to the resilience of the service sector.

site_title: UK house prices set to drop 10% or more in 2023, economists say
summary: UK house prices are expected to drop 10% or more in 2023 due to soaring interest rates and a deepening recession, according to a survey of economists and property-market forecasters. The decline is driven by a surge in mortgage interest rates, higher borrowing costs, and a tightening cost-of-living squeeze. Experts predict a recession that may last into 2024, with a near 20% gap between house prices and justified fundamentals. Some forecasters expect a 10% decline in 2023, while others predict smaller declines or reversals in house price losses by 2026.

images.alt_text: epa10353654 Properties for sale in London, Britain, 07 December 2022. According to the the Halifax House Price Index released on 07 December 2022, UK house prices have seen their biggest fall since the financial crisis, dropping by some 2.3 percent in November.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
Extending the programme comes as Britain’s housing market is headed for its worst slump since the global financial crisis more than a decade ago.

site_title: UK public borrowing hits record £22b in November
summary: UK public borrowing reached a record £22.017 billion in November, exceeding forecasts. For the first eight months of the financial year, borrowing totalled £105.4 billion, a 7.6 billion increase from 2021. Higher energy subsidies and debt-interest costs contributed to the increase. Economists predict full-year borrowing may hit the government's forecast of £177 billion, but risk overshooting in future years.

site_title: SportSG chief Lim Teck Yin to step down in April 2023, replacement named
summary: Lim Teck Yin, CEO of Sport Singapore, will step down in April 2023 after 12 years in the role. His replacement is Alan Goh, deputy secretary of development and regulation at the Ministry of Communications and Information, who will take over as CEO designate on February 15, 2023. Goh has experience in developing Singapore's digital technology infrastructure and leading the Singapore Digital Office. Lim will leave after spearheading the ActiveSG national movement and forming partnerships with industry players. The change is seen as a continuation of the government's efforts to enhance sporting culture in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore Sports Hub CEO Lionel Yeo will leave the organisation when the government takes over the project on Dec 9, 2022.
Quek who is currently the CEO of New Business in Surbana Jurong and will be the fifth person to helm the eight-year-old Sports Hub on a permanent basis.
The S$1.3 billion facility was completed in 2014.

site_title: China’s Xi vows to build sustainable ties with Australia
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has vowed to build sustainable ties with Australia, stating that a stable diplomatic relationship is in the interest of both nations. The announcement comes ahead of Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong's first state visit to China since 2018, following a diplomatic reset after the election of a centre-left Labor Party government in May. Ties had grown strained under the previous prime minister, Scott Morrison, who called for an international investigation into the origins of Covid-19, leading to trade sanctions on Australian exports.

images.alt_text: With the Covid Zero policy being rapidly dismantled, the threat of economic disruption remains high.
TOPSHOT - This aerial photo taken on July 21, 2022 shows a bucket wheel machine tranferring coal at a coal storage centre in Jiujiang, in China's central Jiangxi province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Philips says tests on recalled products show limited health risks
summary: Dutch health technology company Philips announced that independent tests on its recalled respiratory devices showed limited health risks. The tests, conducted by five independent labs, found that exposure to particulate matter emissions from degraded foam was unlikely to result in appreciable harm to patients, provided machines had not been treated with ozone-based cleaning products. The company expects to finish the recall and replacement of all affected products in the first half of 2023. Philips shares rose 3.5% on the news, wiping 70% off the company's market value since the recall last year.

images.alt_text: The US FDA said on Tuesday (Aug 16) it had received 48,000 reports associated with breakdown or suspected breakdown in the foam used in Philips respirators over the 3 months ending Jul 31, 2022.

site_title: Number of tourists visiting Japan jumps for second straight month
summary: Japan's number of foreign visitors rebounded in November, with 934,500 overseas travelers visiting, a 87% increase from the prior month. The recovery suggests retailers and restaurants will see relief next year, but the tourism industry struggles with staffing issues, with over 60% of inns and hotels understaffed. A weaker yen and lower inflation have driven travel to Japan, with analysts predicting a full recovery in 2025 or later due to rising input costs and labor shortages.

images.alt_text: People walk through a shopping street in Omotesando area of Tokyo on December 15, 2022. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)
Japan is saddled with the industrial world’s heaviest public debt at more than twice the size of its US$5 trillion economy, the world’s third largest.

site_title: COE prices down except for big cars at last tender exercise for 2022
summary: COE prices for cars with engines up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, as well as electric vehicles, fell 0.6% to S$88,007, while motorcycle COE prices dropped 3.4% to S$11,690. However, larger cars and more powerful EVs saw a 2.4% increase to S$108,006. Commercial vehicle COE premiums fell 4.1% to S$78,200, the largest drop among categories. The final tender exercise for 2022 closed on December 21, with only the large car category bucking the trend of declining COE prices.

site_title: No sign of smartphone recovery until late 2023, TDK CEO warns
summary: TDK, a battery supplier to the mobile industry, has warned that global smartphone sales won't recover until the year-end holiday season of 2023, citing a lacklustre market hit by inflationary and geopolitical pressures. TDK President Noboru Saito expects the situation to last until mid-2023, followed by a gradual recovery. This outlook is the most pessimistic among industry peers, with other suppliers like Taiyo Yuden and Murata Manufacturing expecting a rebound earlier. TDK sees no imminent exit from China, where it makes 60% of its products and 50% of its sales.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi had 35,314 staff as of Sep 30, the paper reported, with over 32,000 in mainland China.

site_title: German consumer morale picks up as new year beckons
summary: German consumer morale has improved slightly as the new year approaches, with a key survey showing a 2.3-point increase to minus 37.8 points in January. The improvement is attributed to easing energy costs and the government's energy support package. However, consumer expert Rolf Buerkl cautioned that the rebound is on "shaky ground" and could be reversed if energy prices rise again. The survey's results are part of a series of indicators showing an improved outlook for the German economy, with business confidence rising for a third consecutive month and some economists predicting a recession may be avoided.

images.alt_text: Producer prices of industrial products rose 28.2 per cent on the same month last year compared with a 34.5 per cent year-on-year rise in October, the Federal Statistical Office reported.

site_title: Global economy faces challenging 2023
summary: The global economy is expected to face a challenging 2023, with low global growth, high average inflation, and unemployment. The US Federal Reserve's policy is uncertain, with some analysts projecting a rate cut and others expecting higher rates to combat inflation. China's growth is expected to pick up, but the country's reopening may be tempered by rising Covid cases and a stretched healthcare system. The euro area is forecast to face a recession, while Japan's economy is expected to muddle along with inflation concerns. Market volatility and uncertainty are likely to prevail in 2023 due to the many open questions in the global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of GDP, is projected to barely grow in the middle half of the year.
US companies are forecast to have the slowest full-year profit growth since 2020 and the start of the coronavirus pandemic.
Firms based in London were among the least confident of those surveyed.

site_title: Funders and non-profits work together to address community needs
summary: The National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre's (NVPC) Level Up series brings together non-profit professionals, corporate partners, and funders to address community needs through intentional collaboration and peer learning. The series aims to bridge skills gaps and introduce new approaches to problem-solving, enabling non-profits to strengthen programme rigour and enhance deliverables. Recent workshops have focused on grant-proposal writing and youth sports programme development, providing a platform for collaboration, feedback, and knowledge-sharing among stakeholders.

images.alt_text: "Life happens, and there is a danger that some may feel like it is a chore. So the aim for us is to work with companies and education institutions to sensitise people to the needs of others," says Soh.

site_title: Kirin seeks more North American craft beer factories after strong growth
summary: Kirin, Japan's second-largest brewer, is seeking to acquire North American craft beer factory facilities to maintain strong growth in the US craft beer market. The company has seen sales volumes in the region increase by double-digit percentage figures since acquiring New Belgium Brewing in 2019 and Bell's Brewery in 2021. CEO Yoshinori Isozaki stated that Kirin's craft beer business in North America is "on a roll," indicating the company's confidence in its expansion plans. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for craft beer in the US market.

images.alt_text: According to figures published by Kirin in 2018, Myanmar Brewery – whose beverages include the ubiquitous Myanmar Beer brand – boasted a market share of nearly 80 per cent.
