site_title: Upcoming GST hike is just part of wider inflation woes: businesses
summary: Singapore's upcoming 1% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) from 7% to 8% on January 1, 2023, will have a limited impact due to broader inflationary pressures. Businesses are unlikely to absorb the increase, instead passing it on to customers or adjusting prices. Some companies may see increased demand as consumers switch to more affordable alternatives. However, unregistered businesses may face significant costs and consider registering for GST to claim input tax credits.

images.alt_text: Similar to the fourth quarter, five out of six indicators remains expansionary.
About 40 per cent of the 100,000 or so GST-registered businesses will be dealing with a rate change for the first time.

site_title: Crypto miner Core Scientific files for bankruptcy as industry contagion bites
summary: Crypto miner Core Scientific files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Texas, citing a restructuring support agreement with creditors representing over 50% of its convertible notes. The company, one of the largest US-based cryptocurrency mining companies, will not liquidate and will continue to operate normally. This comes as the industry faces a downturn, with bitcoin prices plummeting over 60% in 2022. Core Scientific's bankruptcy filing is the latest in a string of failures to hit the sector, highlighting the challenges faced by cryptocurrency mining companies.

images.alt_text: Bankman-Fried signed his surrender documents on Tuesday.

Logos for Binance Coin, top, Ether, left, and Bitcoin inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

site_title: VinFast gets regulatory approval to sell first electric SUVs in US
summary: VinFast, a unit of Vietnam's conglomerate Vingroup, has received regulatory approval to sell its first electric SUVs in the US, with deliveries set to begin this month. The company, backed by Vietnam's richest man, has qualified its cars for sale in the US market and will work with US Bank for consumer auto loans and leasing. VinFast is also exploring other US lenders for customer loans. The move comes ahead of the company's planned initial public offering.

site_title: Asia jet fuel set for bumpy ride in 2023 despite some China recovery
summary: Asia's jet fuel demand is expected to recover in 2023, driven by China's easing of Covid-19 restrictions and resumption of flights. China's jet fuel demand is forecast to rise 43% in 2023, with the International Energy Agency expecting 701,000 barrels per day. A full recovery in jet fuel consumption will boost Asian refiners' margins and crude demand, lifting global prices. However, forecasts for Covid-19 infections and uncertainty over international flights may hinder a full recovery in the short term.

images.alt_text: HKIA’s bus, a BYD J6 model, seats 14 passengers, features 10 cameras placed outside the vehicle from Uisee Technology (Beijing) Co. and uses GPS locators to track its position.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB initiates Cromwell E-Reit with ‘buy’ on recovery prospects
summary: RHB Research initiated a "buy" call on Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) due to its "record-high" occupancy rate of 95.7% and potential recovery in Western European property markets. Analyst Vijay Natarajan expects a 40% upside from current levels, driven by the Reit's attractive 10% dividend yield and strong occupancy rates. The Reit has a portfolio of 115 assets valued at 2.6 billion euros, with a focus on office and industrial/logistics assets. Despite near-term weaknesses, Natarajan believes Cromwell E-Reit will emerge stronger from current market challenges.

images.alt_text: The Reit’s gross revenue gains 10.4 per cent to 55.9 million euros from 50.7 million euros, while net property income grows 4.1 per cent to 34.5 million euros from 33.1 million euros.
Cromwell E-Reit’s manager does not expect the transaction to have a material effect on the Reit’s net tangible assets.
Simon Garing, CEO of Cromwell E-Reit's manager. The Reit is selling 3 of its non-core, light/industrial logistics assets at a total consideration of 22 million euros

site_title: Food inflation fears send Thai rice exports to 4-year high
summary: Thailand is set to ship its highest volume of rice in four years, with estimated exports reaching 8 million tons in 2022, driven by a weak currency and countries such as China and Indonesia boosting purchases to replenish stockpiles and control food inflation. The move follows India's decision to limit rice shipments, creating an opportunity for Thailand to capitalize on its lower prices and strong competitiveness. This increase in rice exports is expected to continue into next year, supported by favorable weather conditions and robust off-season production.

images.alt_text: At 8.0 per cent in November, consumer price inflation is well beyond the Philippine central bank’s target range of 2-4 per cent for this year and the medium term.

site_title: Philippine bourse sees no fraudulent trading in PLDT shares
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) has found no evidence of fraudulent trading in PLDT shares before the company's disclosure of budget overruns. An internal investigation by the PSE did not reveal any suspicious trades, with most deals being carried out by institutional traders. The PSE has started its own probe into the selloff, which led to a 19% drop in PLDT's share price. PLDT has cooperated fully with regulators and its share price has since recovered by over 5%.

images.alt_text: Signage at the PLDT Inc. headquarters in Makati City, Metro Manila, the Philippines, on Monday, Dec. 19, 2022. PLDT, the largest Philippine phone company, sank as a 48 billion peso ($866 million) four-year capital spending overrun raised questions about its corporate governance and fiscal control. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
The spending probe casts a stain on the finances and governance of PLDT, which is among the nation’s most widely held stocks by foreign investors.

site_title: Singapore, Jiangsu to work more closely in green development, innovation
summary: Singapore and Jiangsu province in China agreed to deepen their collaboration in green development and innovation, with 16 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) signed at the 16th Singapore-Jiangsu Cooperation Council (SJCC) meeting. The renewed SJCC MOU aims to enhance bilateral trade, which has grown 12.5% year on year to $12.8 billion in the first three quarters of 2022. The agreements also focus on intellectual property, civil service training, and startup incubation, offering opportunities for Singapore companies to venture into the Chinese market and Jiangsu companies to expand regionally and internationally.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said that while Singapore may not be able to do much to influence the course of US-China relations, the city state will do all that it can to keep the region open and inclusive.
Singapore launches welcome pack to help Jiangsu firms set up business hub

site_title: South Korea vows support, deregulation as growth slows
summary: South Korea's government has predicted its economy, the fourth-largest in Asia, will grow at 1.6% in 2023, down from an estimated 2.5% this year. The slower growth forecast reflects a worsening global economic outlook. To boost growth, the government has promised policy support and deregulation. Finance Minister Choo Kyung-ho attributed the lower forecast to external factors, not internal weaknesses.

images.alt_text: People wearing masks to prevent contracting the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) walk on a street in downtown Seoul, South Korea, January 5, 2022.  REUTERS/Heo Ran

site_title: Global economy bets on China learning to live with Covid
summary: The World Bank has cut its China growth forecast to 2.7% for this year and 4.3% for 2023, citing the impact of China's loosening of Covid-19 restrictions and its fragile health structures. However, experts believe that if China can manage its Covid-19 stance, it will boost both its domestic economy and the global one, potentially alleviating inflation and recession concerns in G7 countries. The situation remains uncertain, with potential disruptions to global supply chains and inflationary pressures, but a stronger recovery is expected from mid-2023.

images.alt_text: Beijing has sought to mitigate low growth with a series of easing measures to provide support, slashing key interest rates and pumping cash into the banking system.

site_title: Australia’s competition watchdog rejects Telstra-TPG network sharing deal
summary: Australia's competition watchdog rejected a network sharing deal between Telstra and TPG Telecom, citing concerns that it would weaken competition in the country. The deal, signed in February, would have given Telstra access to TPG's 4G and 5G spectrums, but the ACCC said it would lead to less competition and higher prices for Australian mobile users. TPG is preparing an application for a review of the decision, which was welcomed by Optus, Australia's second-largest mobile operator. The deal was expected to generate A$1.6-1.8 billion in revenue for Telstra over 10 years.

images.alt_text: The telecom firm is now required to deregister sites it registered in January that would have prevented Optus from gaining early access to the spectrum.

site_title: A plethora of risks hangs over major economies, threatening consumption
summary: Economists are concerned about a potential global recession in 2023 due to rising interest rates, inflation, and falling asset values. The US Federal Reserve has raised rates by 425 basis points, and economists expect it to reach 5% in 2023. Global growth expectations have been significantly reduced, with the World Bank forecasting 2.9% growth for 2022 and 3.2% for 2023. China's pivot out of its zero-Covid policy may help shore up global growth, but its transition is unlikely to be smooth, potentially exacerbating inflation. Austerity may become a dominant theme among consumers in 2023, threatening global growth.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian in the Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Dec. 20, 2022. China appears to be seeing an increase in Covid deaths across a swath of the country that aren’t being reported in government figures, according to social media posts, adding to speculation that officials are masking the full impact of their abrupt shift away from Covid Zero. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The World Bank now sees China’s economy growing 2.7 per cent this year and 4.3 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Japan warns of China’s Covid situation, cuts view on factory output
summary: Japan's government has cut its view on factory output for the first time in six months due to a global slowdown in semiconductor demand. The country will closely monitor China's COVID-19 situation, which could impact supply chains and trade. Despite this, the overall economy is expected to improve moderately, with business sentiment showing signs of recovery. Private consumption and capital spending are also recovering, and the government expects the Bank of Japan to achieve its 2% inflation target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People pass by an electronic screen showing Japan's Nikkei share price index inside a conference hall  in Tokyo, Japan June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Ferrari heir sets up succession with trust for supercar firm stake
summary: Piero Ferrari, son of Ferrari's founder Enzo, has set up a family trust to manage his 10% stake in the luxury sports carmaker. The trust, valued at around 4 billion euros, will benefit his daughter and grandsons, while Piero Ferrari retains voting rights exceeding 15%. The move outlines succession plans and preserves the unity of his current stake, without affecting his consultation pact with Exor, Ferrari's largest investor.

images.alt_text: Ferrari says they have started the search for Binotto's replacement, likely to be finalised in the new year.

site_title: UK business confidence makes strongest rebound since April 2021
summary: UK business confidence made its strongest rebound since April 2021, rising to 17% in December, according to Lloyds Bank's survey. The improvement was driven by easing labour market pressures and a better-than-expected festive trading period. However, firms remained pessimistic about the economy, with inflation and the risk of a downturn still tempering their optimism. Wage expectations rose, and more firms expected to increase prices next year, which may worsen the Bank of England's challenge to tame double-digit consumer price inflation.

site_title: China will not replace the US in the Middle East anytime soon
summary: Chinese leader Xi Jinping's recent visit to Saudi Arabia and meetings with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman did not lead to a shift in Riyadh's allegiance to Beijing, contrary to speculation in Washington. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' decision to cut oil production was seen as a slap in the face of the US administration, rather than a sign of Saudi Arabia pivoting to China. Xi's visit was met with a warm reception, and there is no evidence to suggest that Saudi Arabia is abandoning its traditional relationship with the US.

images.alt_text: In this photo released by Xinhua News Agency, Chinese President Xi Jinping meets with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at the royal palace in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Thursday Dec. 8, 2022. Gulf Arab leaders and others in the Mideast met Friday in Saudi Arabia as part of a state visit by Chinese leader Xi Jinping, seeking to firm up their relations with Beijing as decades of U.S. attention on the region wanes. (Yue Yuewei/Xinhua via AP)
US ties with Middle East allies have frayed; China benefits
US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping held talks on the sidelines of the G20 leaders' summit in Bali, Indonesia, Nov 14, 2022.

site_title: Latest Treasury bill yields 4.28% in Singapore’s last auction for 2022
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill auction ended with a cut-off yield of 4.28%, slightly above the 4% mark, as investors showed interest in the risk-free fixed income security. The auction received a 2.7 times bid-to-cover ratio, with non-competitive bidders fully allotted and competitive bidders securing 80% of their applications. DBS senior rates strategist Eugene Leow expects T-bill rates to remain buoyant in the coming months due to the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes, but short-term Singapore dollar rates are moderating.

images.alt_text: The last time yields were at the 4 per cent level was in 1989.
T-bills can be purchased by anyone above the age of 18, even non-Singapore residents. They can also be purchased by institutions.
Singapore Treasury bills (T-bills) receives explosive investor interest lately.

site_title: Chinese electric automaker Nio hit by data breach
summary: Chinese electric carmaker Nio reported a data breach after hackers accessed user data and vehicle sales. The hackers demanded $2.25 million in bitcoin and claimed to have internal data. Nio is working with government authorities to investigate. This incident highlights the growing concern of cyberattacks in the auto industry, which has led to significant spending on data protection systems.

images.alt_text: Nio’s battery swap stations promise to send drivers out with a new, fully-charged battery in just a few minutes, faster than current charging alternatives.

site_title: Bank of America clients pour the most cash into ETFs since 2017
summary: Bank of America clients poured $2.8 billion into US stocks last week, marking a sixth consecutive week of equity inflows, with ETFs seeing the biggest gains since 2017. Energy ETFs led the way, while technology and health care stocks saw significant outflows. Institutional clients were the largest buyers, with retail clients selling equities for the first time in six weeks. The trend is attributed to tax-loss selling by individual investors and rebounding institutional clients in the months following October.

images.alt_text: Sectors such as renewable energy and retail are set to benefit as India pulls ahead of emerging market rivals in attracting overseas investors.

site_title: China small business confidence still falling despite reopening
summary: China's small businesses continue to face a weakening outlook, with a gauge of business conditions at small and medium enterprises falling into contractionary territory for a third consecutive month in December. The 'performance' sub-index rose 0.1 point to 48, while the 'expectations' sub-index declined 0.4 point to 49.3 due to weak consumer sentiment and rising COVID cases. The manufacturing sector saw some improvement, but services SMEs continued to face headwinds, with only accommodation and catering firms showing a sharp rebound in performance.

site_title: Gold steadies near one-week high on weaker dollar
summary: Gold prices steadied near a one-week high at US$1,816.94 per ounce due to a weaker US dollar after the Bank of Japan's surprise policy tweak. The dollar's decline makes gold more appealing to overseas investors. Despite being seen as an inflation hedge, higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the asset. Gold futures rose 0.1% to US$1,827.10, while silver fell 0.2% to US$24.12.

images.alt_text: Although gold is seen as an inflation hedge, higher interest rates raise the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: Oil prices settle higher on weak dollar, worries US winter storm could cut travel
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures up 19 US cents to $79.99 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 90 US cents to $76.09 per barrel. A weaker dollar and US plans to restock petroleum reserves supported prices, but uncertainty over China's rising Covid-19 cases capped gains. A major US winter storm may curb travel plans, affecting oil demand, and a US plan to buy up to 3 million barrels of oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was announced.

images.alt_text: Oil surged towards its record high of US$147 a barrel earlier in the year after Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

site_title: Indonesia considers 5 trillion rupiah in incentives to boost EV sales in 2023
summary: Indonesia plans to allocate 5 trillion rupiah (S$434 million) from its 2023 budget to incentivize electric vehicle (EV) sales, aiming for 20% of overall car sales in 2025. The government will offer discounts and subsidies to buyers and sellers, with details of the scheme still being finalized. Industry Minister Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita previously mentioned a discount of 80 million rupiah for domestic EV manufacturers, while Chief Economics Minister Airlangga Hartarto said authorities will determine the amount per sale based on the budget allocation.

site_title: Fall in New Zealand confidence raises spectre of deeper recession
summary: New Zealand's consumer confidence has plummeted to its lowest since 2004, raising concerns of a deeper recession than forecast. The December ANZ Consumer Confidence survey and Westpac quarterly confidence survey both recorded record lows, while the ANZ Business Confidence survey also reached a record low. Experts attribute the decline to a sharp increase in interest rates aimed at dampening inflation, which is near three-decade highs. Forecasts now suggest a deeper recession in the second quarter of 2023, with a protracted period of weak demand and higher unemployment expected.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank last month raised the Official Cash Rate by a record 75 basis points to 4.25 per cent.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried to fly to US Wednesday, escorted by FBI agents
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, FTX co-founder, signed surrender documents on Tuesday and will be escorted by FBI agents on a non-commercial aircraft to the US on Wednesday to face criminal charges related to the FTX collapse. He'll sign papers finalizing his waiver of extradition rights at the Magistrate's Court in Nassau. Bankman-Fried has been held in a correctional facility since being denied bail at an initial court hearing. His return to the US caps a tumultuous week of speculation about his return and potential bail. The exact US airport he'll land at is not immediately clear.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried, founder and former CEO of crypto currency exchange FTX, leaves the Magistrate Court building in Nassau, Bahamas December 19, 2022.  REUTERS/Marco Bello
Bankman-Fried has acknowledged risk management failures at FTX but said he does not believe he has criminal liability.

site_title: China to unveil new rules to rein in fund ‘greenwashing’: sources
summary: China plans to introduce new rules for green funds in the first half of 2023, aiming to curb "greenwashing" and regulate the sector. The regulations will require mutual funds or exchange-traded funds to have at least 60% of their assets in defined green investments to be eligible for the green label. The move aims to tighten oversight in China's rapidly growing green fund market, which has raised tens of billions of dollars in recent years. The rules will be subject to final approval by the China Securities Regulatory Commission.

site_title: South Korea’s early trade shows further export drop as global woes mount
summary: South Korea's early trade data showed a 8.8% decline in exports in the first 20 days of December compared to the same period last year, amid global economic headwinds. Shipments excluding working-day differences also fell 8.8%, with chip sales declining 24.3% and exports to China tumbling 26.6%. The country is expected to post a trade deficit of $6.43 billion and a total export value of $662 billion in 2023, with memory chips likely to regain momentum from the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The central bank’s latest inflation projections released last month forecast it will slow to 4.2 per cent in the first half of 2023.

site_title: Indonesia says bauxite export ban to proceed as scheduled in June 2023
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo announced a ban on bauxite exports starting from June 2023 to encourage domestic processing of the material. The ban is in line with the country's mining law and aims to replicate the success of nickel processing development. China, Indonesia's key buyer, imported 17.8 million tonnes of bauxite from Indonesia in 2021. The move is expected to face lawsuits, but Widodo is determined to proceed. The ban is part of a broader effort to encourage domestic processing of minerals and reduce reliance on exports.

images.alt_text: The Suralaya coal-fired power plant in Cilegon, Indonesia; Sept 22, 2021.
Indonesia's former trade minister Thomas Lembong says the economy will need a short-term counter-cyclical boost to employment and wages as soon as possible.

site_title: GM’s Cruise expands robotaxi service to Phoenix and Austin even with safety probe
summary: GM's Cruise unit has expanded its robotaxi service to Phoenix and Austin, despite a safety probe into its autonomous driving system following three non-fatal accidents. The company plans to rapidly expand to serve the general public in larger geographic areas, with a goal of $1 billion in revenue by 2025. Cruise's CEO, Kyle Vogt, believes the technology can reach a "massive amount of revenue" once it can operate at scale. The company faces scrutiny from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which is investigating software and incidents involving Cruise vehicles.

images.alt_text: Uber is partnering with Motional to allow customers to hail self-driving rides in Las Vegas.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Golden Agri-Resources, HPL, Nio
summary: Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) is selling all seven of its shop units in Ming Arcade to Singapore-based Royal Hiranandani for S$61 million. Despite the sale, HPL's shares closed flat at S$3.60. Golden Agri-Resources reported it expects to be profitable in Q4 and for the full year, despite a US$230 million fair value loss for the quarter.

site_title: Thousands reported without power after strong quake rattles northern California
summary: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of northern California, causing widespread damage and leaving thousands without power. The quake hit 25 miles southwest of Eureka, Humboldt county, at 2:34 am local time, with reports of gas leaks, downed powerlines, and a structure fire in Ferndale. The earthquake was relatively shallow, 10 miles deep, and caused significant disruptions to the area. Authorities reported numerous incidents, but no fatalities have been confirmed.

site_title: These are the fees you pay when buying funds
summary: Singapore investors may be paying higher fees than they realize, with the country receiving a "below average" grade in Morningstar's Global Investor Experience report. Fees for investors include annual fees, sales charges, platform fees, fund management fees, and trailer fees, which can be confusing due to new fee models. Self-serve platforms like FundSupermart and DollarDex charge lower fees, but require investors to do their own research and portfolio rebalancing. Robo-advisers may not be the best option for investors, especially those with higher investment amounts, and individual circumstances should be considered when choosing an investment platform.

site_title: Tesla falls on growing angst over Musk’s focus on Twitter
summary: Tesla shares fell 0.2% on Monday as Twitter users voted for Elon Musk to step down as CEO, citing a distraction from the electric-vehicle maker. Analysts cut price targets, citing risk from Musk's Twitter focus and potential damage to the Tesla brand. Shares hit a two-year low of $140.86, losing nearly 60% of their value this year. Analysts also downgraded Tesla's shares ahead of the company's quarterly deliveries report, citing weakening demand in China and a lower delivery estimate for 2023.

images.alt_text: The Mexican Gigafactory, planned on the outskirts of the city Monterrey, would start by building components for current Tesla models.

site_title: Investor in Musk’s Twitter buyout expects to make up to five times its money
summary: Aliya Capital Partners, a Miami-based investor that joined Elon Musk's $44-billion Twitter acquisition, expects to make up to five times its $360 million investment. Despite Twitter hemorrhaging advertisers and alienating users with its moderation policies, Aliya believes Musk will capitalize on the platform's 229 million daily active users, which have historically been under-monetized. Musk has stated that Twitter is "in the fast lane to bankruptcy," but Aliya is confident in its investment.

images.alt_text: With about four hours left and 14 million votes cast, 57 per cent of participants have said yes.

site_title: Singapore shares show optimism at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.97 points or 0.2% to 3,258.94 points on Wednesday, driven by a positive Wall Street session. Advancers outweighed decliners 54 to 38. Golden Agri-Resources, Genting Singapore, and Shen Yao were among top traded securities, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC opened in positive territory. This follows a four-day slump in US stocks, which reversed on Tuesday with gains in the Dow Jones, Nasdaq Composite, and S&P 500.

images.alt_text: Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers
Hotel Properties is selling all seven of its shop units in Ming Arcade to Singapore-based Royal Hiranandani for S$61 million.

site_title: Nike reports robust sales amid sustained inventory pileup
summary: Nike reported robust sales, with global sales rising 17% to $13.3 billion in the quarter ending Nov 30, exceeding Wall Street's estimates. Despite a 43% inventory buildup, the company's gross margin exceeded expectations, driven by increased marketing spending. Sales fell 3% in China, but executives noted growth in demand for their products. Nike maintained its revenue growth projection for the full fiscal year and expects a 200-250 basis point decline in gross margin. The company's shares rose 13% in after-market trading.

images.alt_text: Lockdowns in China in October and November are also expected to be a drag on its sales in the region for the second quarter.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as BOJ’s policy shift dents risk appetite
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, December 20, as the Bank of Japan's policy shift allowed long-term interest rates to rise further, denting risk appetite. The BOJ's move to widen its 10-year bond yield band by 50 basis points sparked concerns about the potential end of Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy and a possible increase in yields. This shift was seen as a precursor to monetary policy tightening, which dampened hopes for a year-end rally. Rate-sensitive tech and industrial stocks declined, while banks added 2.5% to limit losses.

images.alt_text: Recent signs of easing inflationary pressures had offered hopes of central banks signalling an end to their monetary policy tightening, lifting equities off their October lows.

site_title: Germany should help China-EU ties develop ‘not subject to third party’: Xi
summary: China's President Xi Jinping urged Germany to help develop China-EU relations without third-party interference. In a phone call, Xi said China hopes Germany can provide a fair operating environment for Chinese enterprises in Germany, the EU's largest market. China supports EU strategic autonomy and hopes for a partnership based on mutual respect. This comes after a recent agreement on providing German vaccines to German nationals in China.

site_title: Coming legislation for virtual general meetings presents opportunity to rethink investor engagement
summary: Singapore-listed companies should be required to continue offering investors the option of participating in general meetings virtually, following the proposed legislative amendments by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The amendments aim to build on the hybrid format introduced during the pandemic, allowing for a more effective means of engaging investors. Companies may need to rethink their investor engagement strategies, taking into account the growing emphasis on environmental, social, and governance issues, and the increasing willingness of investors to use their votes to signal their displeasure.

images.alt_text: ACRA and MAS would be proposing legislative amendments to provide groups with the option to conduct general meetings electronically after the orders are revoked.

site_title: Musk is looking for a new Twitter CEO after losing poll
summary: Elon Musk is searching for a new Twitter CEO after losing a straw poll where 57.5% of users voted for him to step down. The poll, which garnered over 10 million votes, was initially committed to abide by the results, but Musk delayed addressing the outcome. Several Twitter accounts raised concerns about vote manipulation by bots, prompting Musk's response. The search for a new CEO may be drawn out and not yield results quickly, according to a person familiar with the matter.

images.alt_text: With about four hours left and 14 million votes cast, 57 per cent of participants have said yes.

site_title: Economists place 70% chance for US recession in 2023
summary: Economists predict a 70% chance of a US recession in 2023 due to surging interest rates, high inflation, and weak export markets. GDP growth is forecasted at 0.3% for the year, with a 0.7% decline in the second quarter and flat readings in the first and third quarters. Consumer spending is expected to barely grow in the middle half of the year, and inflation is seen softening but still above the Federal Reserve's 2% goal. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates high, potentially delaying construction and hiring plans.

site_title: Hyundai, now the No 3 carmaker, takes aim at Toyota and Volkswagen
summary: South Korea's Hyundai Motor has surpassed General Motors, Nissan, and Stellantis to become the world's third-largest carmaker, selling 6.6 million vehicles in 2021. Hyundai's global presence is rooted in its strong manufacturing base in South Korea, with 19.4 trillion won in investments planned for electrification by 2030. The company aims to introduce at least 17 battery-powered EVs, including the Ioniq 6, which has already sold out in Europe. Hyundai faces challenges, including the suspension of a Russian factory, allegations of underage labor in Alabama, and US legislation that could hurt EV subsidies.

images.alt_text: Around 2,600 people built Hyundai and Kia cars at the plant, which has a capacity of some 200,000 vehicles per year.

site_title: Singapore’s consumer sector cautiously optimistic about 2023
summary: Singapore's consumer sector is cautiously optimistic about 2023, with both tourist and domestic spending recovering. Retail sales have grown year-on-year for eight months, driven by a low base in 2021 and increased spending as borders reopen. However, labour shortages and rising costs remain major concerns, with some retailers seeing a levelling-off of demand as consumers shift to travel and restaurants. The hospitality sector expects a sustained recovery, supported by a healthy pipeline of events and elevated tourism offerings. Despite these challenges, the sector is cautiously optimistic about 2023, with some retailers investing in digitalization and technology to cope with cost increases.

images.alt_text: Tripartism was important in saving jobs, supporting workers and businesses, and protecting livelihoods during the pandemic, Manpower Minister Tan See Leng says.

Peppermint’s festive buffet on
Christmas Eve and Christmas Day.
Industry players and market watchers said rising inflation, rental costs and the ongoing manpower crunch are pushing some F&B players to exit the market or seek out strategic partners for support.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher after four-day slump
summary: US stocks closed higher on Tuesday, recovering from a four-day slump, as investors sought to look past market uncertainty and fears of a slowdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index remained nearly flat. The S&P 500 ticked up 0.1%. The Bank of Japan's shift away from ultra-loose monetary policy had a negative impact on the dollar, attracting some buying and bargain hunting. Investors will focus on company earnings before the Christmas holiday and existing home sales data due on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 22.30 points, or 0.07 per cent, at the open to 32,735.24.

site_title: Bell & Ross goes green with limited-edition piece
summary: Bell & Ross has released a limited-edition watch, the BR 05 Sincere Green Steel, to celebrate the opening of its new boutique at Marina Bay Sands. The watch, nicknamed the Greenback, features a green dial with an embossed monogram and is powered by the BR-CAL.321 movement. Only 111 pieces are available, and the watch retails for S$7,900. The collaboration with Sincere Fine Watches reflects the shared values of both brands, emphasizing the passion for haute horlogerie, innovation, and style.

images.alt_text: The new BR-X5 combines the aviation-inspired origins of the BR-01 and the urbane elegance of the BR-05; and elevates both with modern, industrial-inspired design and technical dynamism.

site_title: Indonesia must refocus on short-term wage gains to combat recession: former trade minister
summary: Indonesia's former trade minister Thomas Lembong warns that the country's economy needs a short-term counter-cyclical boost to employment and wages due to expected global recession. Lembong cites policy contradictions, such as favoring capital-intensive sectors over labor-intensive industries, as major obstacles. He recommends increasing short-term wages and employment to combat recession and developing human capital to address the country's skills gap. Indonesia's economy is expected to grow 5.4% in 2022, but Lembong predicts tougher times ahead, with the central bank likely to raise interest rates to defend the rupiah.

images.alt_text: Resource-rich Indonesia has seen an export boom this year, riding on high global commodity prices.
With a slower pace of rate hikes predicted from the Fed, the pressure on the rupiah providing room for BI to scale down its pace of tightening.

site_title: China’s budget deficit hits record 7.75 trillion yuan on Covid zero slump
summary: China's budget deficit reached a record 7.75 trillion yuan (S$1.5 trillion) from January to November, more than double the same period last year and larger than in 2020. The COVID Zero policy and housing slump have been damaging to the economy and government finances. The economy contracted in the second quarter, and with COVID infections spreading, healthcare spending is expected to jump, further straining finances. Total income from the general public and government funds was down 3% from a year earlier, while total fiscal spending is expected to total 26.3 trillion yuan this year.

site_title: European airports see cautious passenger recovery with 2023 uncertain
summary: European airports have revised their passenger traffic recovery timeline to 2025, citing a cautious outlook due to a looming recession, double-digit inflation, and the war in Ukraine. The recovery, initially expected in 2024, will be slow and uncertain, with many airport markets taking longer to recover. Airlines, such as Lufthansa and Ryanair, remain optimistic about steady bookings and growth, but some executives warn of trouble in 2023. Passenger volumes are expected to only match 2017 levels by next year, with Christmas flight bookings showing a 14% decline compared to 2019.

images.alt_text: Most European airlines posted soaring profits this northern hemisphere summer as people took advantage of the first travel season without Covid-19 restrictions for three years.

site_title: Amazon reaches settlement with EU over use of data, avoids fine
summary: Amazon has reached a settlement with the European Union, avoiding a fine of up to 10% of its global turnover. The US online retailer agreed not to use sellers' data for its own competing retail business and private label products, addressing concerns over its use of data to gain an unfair advantage over rival merchants. This move resolves two antitrust probes and resolves the EU's concerns about Amazon's data practices.

images.alt_text: The logo of Amazon is seen at the company's logistics center in Bretigny-sur-Orge, near Paris, France, November 25, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier

Games Workshop said Amazon will develop its intellectual property into film and television productions, adding that it will also grant merchandising rights to the US company, beginning with the Warhammer 40,000 universe.

site_title: Company delistings to remain elevated given tough market: analysts
summary: 34 Singapore Exchange (SGX) counters were delisted in 2022, with analysts expecting a high number of exits in 2023 due to rising costs and challenging operating environments. Many delistings occurred following acquisitions or mergers, such as Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) after being acquired by Cuscaden Peak. The delisting trend is attributed to tough market conditions, with analysts warning of further exits before the year ends.

images.alt_text: The acquisition of SP allows Tuan Sing to reduce the duplication of compliance and associated costs in maintaining the listing status of both companies.
MS Holdings, better known as Moh Seng Cranes in the industry, is in the business of leasing mobile and lorry cranes, and trading cranes and related equipment.
As at 9 pm on Nov 21, the offer secures valid acceptances from shareholders representing 79.56 per cent of total shares issued.
Gear has rationalised its break-up and privatisation with an ESG narrative
The series of proposals come as Gear seeks to reduce its exposure to energy coal by shifting away from its existing energy coal business currently conducted by Gems through the proposed distribution.
MS Holdings, better known as Moh Seng Cranes in the industry, is in the business of leasing mobile and lorry cranes, trading cranes and related equipment.

MS Holdings, better known as Moh Seng Cranes in the industry, business of leasing
of mobile and lorry cranes and trading of cranes and related equipment.
The Singapore Exchange has taken steps in response to the trend of delistings in recent years, including allowing dual-class capital structures and SPACs in the market.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within Frasers Hospitality Trust.

site_title: FedEx profit tops estimates as higher prices offset decline in shipments
summary: FedEx reported fiscal second-quarter earnings beating analysts' estimates, driven by price increases and cost cuts. The company cited weakness in demand at its express business, but reported an additional $1 billion of projected savings in 2023. FedEx's shares rose 3.6% after the announcement, and the company now expects adjusted earnings of $13-$14 per share for the year. Despite a decline in shipments, FedEx's cost reduction efforts and higher pricing helped offset the decline, with sales for the quarter falling below estimates.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) on Monday said that it is in discussions with the Malaysian authorities on possible options to enable its unit, Great Eastern Life Assurance (Malaysia) Berhad (GELM), to satisfy prevailing foreign ownership requirements applicable to insurance companies in Malaysia.
FedEx said the affected routes account for less than 0.5 per cent of Ground’s 60,000 routes and that contingency plans are in place.

site_title: US housing starts fall for a third month, building permits drop
summary: US home construction declined for a third month, with residential starts falling 0.5% to an annualised 1.43 million units in November. Single-family homebuilding dropped to its lowest rate since May 2020, at 828,000 units. Building permits also plummeted, decreasing 11.2% to 1.34 million units, the lowest since May 2020. High borrowing costs and inflation eroded housing affordability and demand, leading to the decline in construction and permits.

site_title: Deutsche Bank weighs 4% base pay hike, dealmaker bonus cuts
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering a 4% base pay hike for non-unionized staff and investment bankers with weaker performance, while cutting bonuses for those in investment banking. The move aims to offset surging inflation, which CEO Christian Sewing says affects profitability. The bank's fixed income and currencies trading revenue is up 26% due to investors reorganizing their portfolios, but debt origination revenue slumped 72% and equity origination plummeted 82% in the first nine months of the year.

images.alt_text: Deutsche’s bottom line has benefited from a surge in securities trading and dealmaking but higher interest rates are fattening profits from regular banking, while there has been a decline in mergers and acquisitions deals.

site_title: Hotel Properties Limited to sell Ming Arcade commercial units for S$61m
summary: Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) announced the sale of its seven commercial units in Ming Arcade to Royal Hiranandani for S$61 million, unlocking the underlying value of its investments. The units, totaling 1,774 square meters, account for 54.63% of the strata area and 54.6% of the total share value. The sale is seen as beneficial for the group and shareholders, allowing HPL to realize its investments and redevelop the site. The transaction follows the sale of Ming Arcade to Royal Group of Companies for S$172 million in a public tender exercise.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies at crossroads after annus horribilis
summary: Cryptocurrency investors are reevaluating their stance after a tumultuous 2022 marked by crashes, contagion, and collapses. Bitcoin, the largest cryptocurrency, has plummeted about three-quarters from its November peak of $69,000, struggling to stay above water for more than a week. This year's events have left investors questioning the long-term viability of the cryptocurrency market.

images.alt_text: Logos for Binance Coin, top, Ether, left, and Bitcoin inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
Coinbase has been among the hardest hit crypto firms as investors yank coins off exchanges or exit the asset class as a whole.
Bankman-Fried has acknowledged risk management failures at FTX but said he does not believe he has criminal liability.

site_title: Anwar pledges more funds as Malaysia’s monsoon floods worsen
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has pledged extra funds for disaster management and rescue efforts following severe monsoonal floods that have displaced over 56,000 people across five states. The government has allocated RM400 million and will provide more funds as needed. The floods, triggered by the north-east monsoon, have caused estimated losses of RM6.1 billion, similar to last year's devastating floods that left dozens dead. The situation is expected to worsen until early next year due to an active La Nina and negative Indian Ocean Dipole concurrences.

site_title: Yen soars to 4-month high after surprise BOJ policy tweak
summary: The yen surged to a four-month peak against the dollar after the Bank of Japan's surprise decision to review its yield curve control policy and widen the trading band for the 10-year government bond yield. The dollar traded 3.17% weaker at 132.56 yen, with the euro tumbling 3.5% to its lowest since late September at 140.17 yen, and sterling sliding 3.7% to its lowest since October 12 at 160.34 yen.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Recession, rate hikes seen jamming brakes on global 2023 earnings growth
summary: Global corporate earnings growth is expected to slow in 2023 due to higher inflation and rising interest rates, with US companies forecast to have the slowest full-year profit growth since 2020. Analysts predict a decline in earnings for the S&P 500, with the consumer discretionary sector expected to see the highest year-over-year earnings growth, while the energy sector is expected to have the biggest decline. European company earnings are also forecast for a sharp slowdown, with some strategists predicting a 12% decline in earnings per share.

site_title: Indonesia’s renewable energy bill: An ambitious attempt at energy transition
summary: Indonesia is set to pass a new renewable energy bill, known as RUU EBT, which aims to transition the country to green energy and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The bill provides incentives for renewable energy projects, creates an ecosystem for green energy research and education, and supports state-owned power companies in purchasing green energy. However, the bill has some shortcomings, including unclear implementation of public involvement and red tape reduction. The bill also includes provisions that allow for the transition to "new energy" sources, including coal-derived products, which may undermine the goal of phasing out polluting technologies.

images.alt_text: The latest figure remains below the 1.5 million visitors recorded in September 2019 before the pandemic.
Indonesia, home to the world’s third-largest rainforest, pledges to be carbon-neutral by 2050, 10 years earlier than previously planned, and to almost double its renewable energy generation by 2030.

site_title: HSBC offers lower paid UK staff £2,150 pay rise
summary: HSBC has offered a £2,150 pay rise to around 18,000 of its UK staff on the two lowest pay grades, following negotiations with union Unite. The offer is similar to those made by rivals NatWest and Lloyds, aiming to curb inflation's impact on employees' finances. The pay bump applies to over 20% of staff, with another 60% receiving an 8-10% increase, but Unite has not recommended the offer to its members, who will be balloted in January.

site_title: Signs of Salome, said to be nurse to baby Jesus, unearthed in Israel
summary: Archaeologists have uncovered more signs that a 2,000-year-old cave in Israel, known as the Cave of Salome, was a Jewish tomb and Christian pilgrimage site. The cave, believed to be the burial place of Salome, a nurse to the newborn Jesus, features a 350 square meter forecourt with stone slabs and mosaic floors consistent with a family tomb for prominent Jews. The findings, announced by the Israel Antiquities Authority, support the cave's status as an important historical site, providing insight into early Christian and Jewish traditions.

site_title: Demand for Messi, Mbappe football gear spikes after World Cup
summary: Demand for Lionel Messi and Kylian Mbappe football gear has surged after Argentina's World Cup win, with sales of PSG jerseys tripling and global sales of football gear increasing by 700% compared to the 2018 World Cup. Messi scored twice and Mbappe netted three times in the 3-3 draw that Argentina won 4-2 on penalties. The victory marked Argentina's first World Cup win since 1986, ending a 36-year drought.

images.alt_text: The players arrived in Buenos Aires to thousands of supporters waiting to greet them, and will begin a tour of the Buenos Aires city centre from Tuesday (Dec 20).

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower on Tuesday amid inflation, rate hike jitters
summary: Singapore stocks ended lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 0.1% due to concerns over inflation and potential interest rate hikes. The market saw a significant decline, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 2.5% and the ASX 200 dropping 1.5%. The Singapore bourse traded 954.9 million shares worth S$926.2 million, with losers beating gainers 318 to 228. The decline was part of a regional downturn, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and South Korea's Kospi also experiencing losses.

images.alt_text: Sentiment was also being weighed down by a spike in Covid infections in China as officials roll back many of the strict containment measures that have been in place for almost three years.
Bursa Malaysia opened an exchange this month, joining more than a dozen that are underway or planned across the region.

site_title: Appeals court rejects China Telecom bid to reverse US ban
summary: A US appeals court rejected China Telecom's bid to reverse a 2021 FCC order withdrawing its authority to provide services in the US. The FCC stated China Telecom (Americas) is "subject to exploitation, influence, and control by the Chinese government." This decision upholds the 2021 FCC decision that denied China Mobile and other Chinese telecom firms the right to provide US services. The FCC had previously withdrawn US authorisations for several Chinese telecom carriers in 2019.

site_title: China Evergrande resumes work on pre-sold projects
summary: China Evergrande Group has resumed work on 631 pre-sold and undelivered projects, aiming to deliver 300,000 units this year, following a delivery target of 256,000 units between January and November. The debt-laden real estate developer is scrambling to raise funds to pay lenders and suppliers, while also engaging with offshore creditors to reach a consensus on a restructuring plan. The company reported contracted sales of 29.12 billion yuan in the first eleven months of the year, despite its electric vehicle unit suspending mass production due to a lack of new orders.

site_title: US: Wall St subdued at open after BOJ’s policy surprise
summary: US stock markets opened subdued on Dec 20, 2022, after the Bank of Japan's surprise policy shift to allow long-term interest rates to rise more. The Dow Jones fell 22.30 points, or 0.07%, to 32,735.24. The S&P 500 opened lower by 7.19 points, or 0.19%, to 3,810.47, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 3.87 points, or 0.04%, to 10,709.29.

site_title: China completes construction of second biggest hydro plant
summary: China has completed the construction of the Baihetan hydropower plant, the second-largest hydropower generator in the world. The plant, located on the Yangtze river, features 16 1-gigawatt turbines and is estimated to generate 62.44 billion kilowatt-hour annually, saving about 90.45 million tons of coal and reducing annual carbon dioxide emissions by 248.4 million tonnes.

site_title: China confirms change to Covid death definition as doubts on data grow
summary: China has revised its definition of a COVID-19 death, only counting individuals who tested positive and died from respiratory failure as official virus deaths. The change, announced by a top infectious disease doctor, reflects the country's low official death toll and comes as cases surge amid Beijing's decision to let the virus run free. The revised definition may mask the true number of fatalities, with the country reporting fewer than 10 deaths since the start of the month, despite a growing number of cases and concerns about the virus's impact on the economy and trade.

images.alt_text: Some health experts estimate 60 per cent of people in China could be infected over the coming months, and that more than 2 million could die.

site_title: The Fed needs to take the digital yuan seriously
summary: The Federal Reserve should take China's digital yuan, or e-CNY, seriously as a potential challenge to the dollar's hegemony. A recent trial in Hong Kong saw 500 accounts tied to the e-CNY snapped up in two days, and the digital currency is set to integrate with the Faster Payment System. This could allow for faster and cheaper international transactions, potentially reducing the dollar's role in regional commerce. China's e-CNY aims to fill a domestic hole in cash usage and has a geopolitical motivation to reshape the US-centric global monetary order.

images.alt_text: Even the most decentralised currencies cannot avoid law enforcement. Exchanges are under pressure to monitor links to regular currencies, as are other service providers.
Binance backed out of plans to acquire FTX, the company said on Wednesday (Nov 9).
China is well advanced with real-life trials of an e-yuan.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund to buy stake in UAE Tabreed’s local venture
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is in talks to buy a $250 million stake in Saudi Tabreed, a local venture of UAE-listed National Central Cooling. The deal, expected to be finalized in the next two to three years, would give the PIF a significant holding in the district cooling company ahead of a planned initial public offering. The PIF aims to diversify Saudi Arabia's economy away from oil reliance, following a rapid expansion of its assets to over $600 billion globally.

images.alt_text: Ceer, a joint venture with Taiwan’s Foxconn Technology Group, secured a 1 million square-metre plot within the King Abdullah Economic Center in a deal worth about US$96 million.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Keppel Corporation's Offshore and Marine unit agreed to pay 343.6 million reais (S$88.1 million) in fines and damages for corrupt payments in Brazil. Real estate investment volumes in the Asia-Pacific are forecasted to drop 5-10% in 2023 due to economic and financing conditions. Many residential collective sale sites are expected to remain unsold in 2023 due to mismatched price expectations and uncertain market conditions. SP Corporation will delist on Dec 23 following its privatization. Singapore shares fell marginally on Dec 20 amid inflation and rate hike concerns.

site_title: Pioneers of buildings of the future
summary: Lendlease Reit, the first Singapore real estate investment trust, has achieved net-zero carbon status ahead of its 2025 target. The trust's properties, including Jem mall, feature energy-efficient systems such as a chilled water plant and energy recovery lifts, reducing energy consumption by 13 gigawatt-hours per year. Lendlease Reit aims to achieve absolute zero carbon emissions by 2040, with plans to install electric vehicle chargers, improve waste management, and use technology to enhance energy efficiency. The trust has also established green leases with 100% of its tenants, including H&M, to promote sustainability.

images.alt_text: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit acquired Jem in April 2022

In the near-term, the manager has plans to optimise the remaining untapped gross floor area of 10,200 sqft from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) Master Plan 2019 to maximise the full potential of 313@somerset and create new value for LREIT’s unitholders.

site_title: Pakistan plans work from home, shut shops in austerity drive
summary: Pakistan has implemented austerity measures to combat its economic crisis, including shutting shopping centers at 8 pm and asking 20% of government employees to work from home to reduce power consumption. The measures aim to cut power demand by 9,000 megawatts per day, amid a national growth cut by half due to the devastating floods, estimated to have caused $32 billion in damage. The move follows rolling blackouts and increased power costs earlier this year, and is part of a broader effort to address the nation's struggling economy and dwindling foreign exchange reserves.

images.alt_text: The concessionary ADB loan was signed at the rate of 1 per cent for a period of 40 years, Pakistan Economic Affairs Minister Ayaz Sadiq said.

site_title: US CFPB orders Wells Fargo to pay US$3.7b for mismanagement
summary: Wells Fargo has agreed to pay $3.7 billion to settle charges from the US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) over widespread mismanagement of automobile loans, mortgages, and deposit accounts. The CFPB ordered the bank to pay a $1.7 billion civil penalty and $2 billion to redress over 16 million consumer accounts affected by the numerous violations, including unauthorized fees and interest charges. The bank had also improperly repossessed cars and charged surprise overdraft fees. The settlement marks a significant fine for Wells Fargo, with the CFPB's more aggressive posture under President Joe Biden's administration highlighted.

site_title: Golden Agri expects to be profitable despite Q4 fair value loss
summary: Golden Agri-Resources expects to be profitable despite a Q4 fair value loss of US$230 million due to changes in investments. The company recorded a net profit of US$675 million for the first nine months of the year, indicating its business model remains intact. Golden Agri attributed its resilience to its integrated business model and successful value extraction throughout the value chain. The profit guidance is based on preliminary financial information, with full financial results to be released on March 1, 2023.

site_title: Turning more negative on the US dollar
summary: The US dollar's record-breaking run in 2022 is expected to correct in 2023 due to narrowing policy rate differentials and a reversal of safe-haven flows. The dollar's real effective exchange rate is overvalued, with a 30% overvaluation against the yen, and its purchasing power parity suggests the same. Narrowing rate differentials and a decline in safe-haven flows could drive a weaker dollar, with major constituents of the DXY Index, such as the euro and yen, potentially performing better. Investors should monitor their currency exposures and consider hedging their USD exposure to mitigate potential losses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

The ECB has been raising rates at an unprecedented pace to rein in prices that have soared since economies reopened after the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by supply bottlenecks and then surging energy costs following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: 6 dead, one rescued as Thailand races to find missing marines from sunken warship
summary: Thailand's navy is searching for 23 marines still unaccounted for after a warship, HTMS Sukhothai, sank off the country's southeastern coast. One marine was rescued alive 41 hours after the ship sank, and six were found dead. The vessel suffered an engine malfunction and took on water, forcing dozens to abandon ship in life jackets. Weather conditions improved, allowing helicopters, warships, and drones to be deployed to find the missing sailors. The navy's chief of staff believes some survivors may still be alive and is continuing the search.

images.alt_text: The HTMS Sukhothai warship on its side before sinking in the Gulf of Thailand. At least 31 Royal Thai navy personnel are missing.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange headed for its worst IPO finish in a decade
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is on track for its weakest year since 2012 for new listings, with 69 new listings raising HK$87.8 billion in 2022, a 74% drop from the previous year. The decline is attributed to the pandemic, rising interest rates, and China's economic uncertainty. Despite this, bankers and analysts expect a recovery in listings with China's reopening, with several delayed Chinese IPOs and follow-on transactions anticipated in the near term.

images.alt_text: A poster advertising Bitcoins and cryptocurrencies in Hong Kong. The city aims to become a top Asian crypto hub offering legalised retail trading and digital-asset ETFs.

site_title: Taiwan Nov export orders plunge, China’s Covid surge clouds outlook
summary: Taiwan's export orders in November fell 23.4% to US$50.14 billion, the steepest decline in over a decade, due to weaker global consumer spending and a plunge in China demand. Orders for telecoms products plummeted 30.5% and electronic products fell 15.2%. Despite semiconductor demand and stockpiling ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday, uncertainties including the rapid spread of Covid-19 in China remain. The ministry expects export orders this month to be lower than in December 2021 by between 27.8% and 30.8%.

site_title: Malaysia's 2022 GDP growth very likely to beat forecasts, says PM
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stated that the country's 2022 GDP growth is likely to exceed earlier projections of 6.5-7% due to the rapid recovery of its economy after pandemic restrictions were eased in April. Despite concerns about a global slowdown affecting export growth, the economy expanded at its fastest pace in over a year in the third quarter. Anwar also emphasized the need to improve the ease of doing business and create high-value jobs for Malaysians, while cautioning about the uncertain global economic outlook in 2023.

images.alt_text: The exports of manufacturing and mining goods in Malaysia continued to rise in November but agriculture goods were declining due to lower exports of palm oil and palm oil-based products.

site_title: Greek woodcutters give energy crisis the chop
summary: Greek lumberjacks are meeting increased demand for firewood due to rising energy prices, with many households relying on affordable wood heating. However, the profession's future is uncertain, with dwindling numbers of younger workers and concerns about over-exploitation of the forest. Despite efforts to maintain sustainable forestry practices, the industry faces challenges, including outdated infrastructure and a lack of young successors.

images.alt_text: The new cap will only take effect if the price difference with global liquefied natural gas prices is greater than 35 euros.
Oil surged towards its record high of US$147 a barrel earlier in the year after Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

site_title: Hong Kong scraps rapid tests for bars in further Covid easing
summary: Hong Kong has ended the testing rule for entry to bars and nightclubs, allowing patrons to enter without a negative rapid test, effective from December 22. The city has also scrapped limits on venues, including banquets with a cap of 240 participants. The mask mandate remains in place, and a 12-person limit for outdoor gatherings will continue. The changes come as Chief Executive John Lee heads to Beijing to meet with President Xi Jinping, amid growing expectations for the city's border with mainland China to reopen.

site_title: Anwar addresses sodomy trials after opposition attack
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim addressed sodomy trials during his first parliamentary speech, stating the trials were "unjust" and the king at the time had recognized this in 2018. Anwar was granted a royal pardon for his convictions, which he did not apply for due to being punished. He cited discrepancies in the case, including a building that did not exist at the time, and expressed opposition to a judiciary that goes against justice principles.

images.alt_text: Malaysian prime minister Anwar Ibrahim's vote of confidence was passed in a simple voice vote at the first parliamentary session on Dec 19, 2022.

site_title: US Congress to advance US$1.66t government funding Bill
summary: US Congress is moving forward with a $1.66 trillion government funding bill, including record military spending, before temporary funding expires at the end of the week. The bill is an increase from the previous year's $1.5 trillion appropriation and includes measures such as banning TikTok on government devices and clarifying Congress's role in election certification. Negotiators from both parties have agreed on these measures, aiming to pass the bill before the deadline.

site_title: Look forward, not back
summary: We're entering payback time, where years of easy money will lead to tighter money supply and potentially recession. This could be a good opportunity to reset investments. The main reason for this is the reversion to mean, where we pay back years of low interest rates. Austerity is expected to bite, making it essential to prioritize what's truly important. As a result, investors may need to be more cautious about where they put their money.

images.alt_text: Gold prices have fallen 11.8 per cent from their peak of more than US$2,000 per ounce in early March.

site_title: German producer prices rise less than expected in November
summary: German producer prices rose 28.2% in November compared to the same month last year, down from a 34.5% year-on-year rise in October. This marks the second consecutive month of easing inflation, as the cost of natural gas and electricity fell. Analysts had forecast a 30.6% reading. Prices fell 3.9% compared to October 2022, below the 2.5% consensus drop.

site_title: Multibillion-dollar effort is timely to wean more nations off coal
summary: The European Union and several G20 governments have pledged $20 billion in financing to help Indonesia phase out its main energy source, coal. This move is part of the Just Transition Energy Partnership, which aims to guide Indonesia towards renewable sources. The G7 has also pledged $15.5 billion to help Vietnam transition away from coal. These significant commitments come as countries worldwide commit to a greener future, with over 75% of coal power capacity expected to be shut down by 2030.

images.alt_text: The Suralaya coal-fired power plant in Cilegon, Indonesia; Sept 22, 2021.
Australia has been slow in developing its offshore wind sector to replace a fleet of ageing coal plants that still provide most of its energy.

site_title: World Cup winners Argentina return ahead of welcome home party
summary: Argentina's World Cup-winning team, led by captain Lionel Messi, returned home to Buenos Aires on December 20, ahead of a welcome home party. The players arrived at Ezeiza International Airport to thousands of supporters, and began a tour of the city centre from midday. This comes after they defeated France in the thrilling final on Sunday. The return marks a public holiday, with millions expected to be in the streets to celebrate the team's historic victory.

images.alt_text: Argentina fans celebrate winning the Fifa World Cup at the Obelisk in Buenos Aires with an image of team captain Lionel Messi.

Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Final - Argentina v France - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - December 18, 2022
Argentina's Lionel Messi and teammates celebrate winning the World Cup REUTERS/Peter Cziborra     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
Qatar is ploughing ahead with its sporting ambitions despite criticism of its rights record – particularly its treatment of foreign workers.

site_title: 3M will stop producing ‘forever chemical’ PFAS by end of 2025
summary: 3M will stop producing per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), also known as "forever chemicals," by the end of 2025 due to regulatory pressure and lawsuits that threaten billions of US dollars in damages. The company expects to book pretax charges of US$1.3 billion to US$2.3 billion and will discontinue the use of PFAS in products. 3M's decision comes 20 years after phasing out an early form of PFAS, known as PFOS, and marks a historic break with an entire class of chemicals that were first created during World War II.

site_title: Mind the triple whammy of higher debt, tax and wage costs hitting Singapore stocks
summary: Singapore-listed stocks face a triple whammy of higher debt, tax, and wage costs, which could negatively impact profitability. Rising borrowing costs, increased property and income taxes, and higher wage bills are expected to squeeze profit margins. However, if wages lift the middle class's spending power, consumption may rise, benefiting businesses that cater to this demographic, such as suburban malls, budget airlines, and consumer banking franchises.

images.alt_text: Banks saw their profits rise on strong net interest margin expansion.

site_title: Indonesia’s budget deficit narrows sharply amid strong revenues
summary: Indonesia's budget deficit narrowed to 1.22% of GDP as of mid-December, exceeding initial expectations, according to Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati. The country recorded a fiscal deficit of 237.7 trillion rupiah, driven by strong revenue collection and good budget discipline. This is a significant improvement from last year's deficit of 4.6% and 2020's deficit of 6.1%. Total revenue was 37% higher than last year, boosted by high commodity prices and economic recovery from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Resource-rich Indonesia has seen an export boom this year, riding on high global commodity prices.
With a slower pace of rate hikes predicted from the Fed, the pressure on the rupiah providing room for BI to scale down its pace of tightening.

site_title: Gold ticks lower on rate hike fears, firm dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,784.98 per ounce as a firmer dollar and expectations of further interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve reduced its appeal. The dollar index gained 0.1%, making gold more expensive for overseas buyers. Despite being seen as an inflation hedge, higher interest rates raise the opportunity cost of holding gold, according to Fed Chair Jerome Powell. The European Central Bank also plans to keep raising interest rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Gold prices have fallen 11.8 per cent from their peak of more than US$2,000 per ounce in early March.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down on worries over rate hikes, inflation
summary: Asia markets fell on Tuesday, December 20, as traders worried about central bank efforts to control inflation and potential recession. The sell-off was also fueled by a spike in Covid infections in China as officials roll back strict containment measures. The mood was dampened by warnings from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank about higher interest rates next year. Tokyo edged up slightly ahead of a Bank of Japan policy decision, while Hong Kong and other markets declined, including tech firms tracking US giants like Amazon and Apple.

images.alt_text: asia stock

site_title: Low-priced Russian oil boosts profits of China’s independent refiners
summary: China's independent refiners are boosting profits from processing low-priced Russian oil, despite the Group of Seven's US$60 per-barrel price cap and European Union's ban on Russian seaborne imports. Independent refiners in eastern China's Shandong province are attracted to the oil's short shipping distance and low-sulphur quality, and are willing to pay above the price cap. Spot discounts for ESPO crude have widened to around US$6.50 per barrel, as most Chinese refiners wrap up purchases ahead of the Chinese New Year.

site_title: British Airways flights held on ground amid pilot software issue
summary: British Airways faced hours-long flight delays due to a software issue affecting its flight-planning system. The problem stemmed from a failure of software that BA pilots access via Apple iPads, resulting in around 50% of flights being grounded. The airline confirmed the issue was resolved and apologized for the disruption to customers' travel plans. There was no safety issue, and short-haul flights were not affected. The glitch is the latest in a series of software failures to hit airlines, adding to BA's challenges including staff shortages and a looming strike by Border Force officials.

site_title: Coking coal slumps as talks on Australia-China trade rift loom
summary: China's restrictions on Australian commodities, including coal, led to a 3% drop in coking coal futures. The move may increase supply if Beijing lifts trade sanctions against Australia. Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong will push China to lift sanctions during her trip to Beijing to mend diplomatic ties, which have been strained since Australia introduced laws to deal with Chinese interference in politics and called for an independent Covid-19 investigation. The sanctions have affected Australian steel production and the country's export earnings.

images.alt_text: Few would question the urgency of climate action. The harder nut to crack is how to make the transition an inclusive one.

site_title: SP Corp to delist on Dec 23
summary: SP Corporation, a mainboard-listed commodities trading group, will delist on December 23 due to its privatization by Tuan Sing Holdings. The acquisition scheme took effect on December 9, with each shareholder receiving S$1.59 in cash, equivalent to SP's book value per share as of June 30, 2022. This move aims to reduce duplication of compliance and associated costs in maintaining the listing status of both companies.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: Kitchen Culture ‘intends vehemently to resist’ Ooway’s legal proceedings
summary: Kitchen Culture has announced it will "intensely resist" Ooway Group's legal proceedings, which seek to declare the validity of an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) held on November 25. Ooway claims that five of Kitchen Culture's current directors were removed and replaced with five new directors appointed by Ooway, while Kitchen Culture maintains its current board remains unchanged. The hearing for Ooway's summons for an injunction is set for December 23, and Kitchen Culture's lawyers will advise and act in relation to the matter, emphasizing the company's intention to resist the proceedings.

images.alt_text: Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company's sponsor has issued a statement in response to a Dec 7 article published in The Business Times.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Ooway Group became a substantial shareholder of Kitchen Culture in 2020, after it sold 30 per cent of its subsidiary Ooway Technology to Kitchen Culture in exchange for 90 million shares – around 21.2 per cent – of Kitchen Culture.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company says it has “taken swift action” to file corrective notices with Acra on Dec 2 after one of its directors attempted to change the company's records.
The meeting was requisitioned by a group of Kitchen Culture shareholders, including Ooway Group, who first requested to remove the incumbent directors in September this year.
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Its largest shareholder Ooway Group together with seven individuals are requisitioning to remove five of the company's six directors.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The embattled kitchen systems provider reminds shareholders that an extraordinary general meeting intended to be held by requisitioners seeking to remove five of its six directors will not be proceeding.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture.  The group is urging its shareholders not to attend a Nov 1 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) proposed by requisitioners, as it deems notices for the EGM defective and invalid.
Kitchen Culture shareholders fail to confirm whether EGM notices have been sent out

site_title: New Zealand business confidence plummets to record low, ANZ says
summary: New Zealand business confidence plummeted to a record low of minus 70.2 in December, according to ANZ Bank New Zealand. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's 75 basis point interest rate hike in November is expected to lead to a recession next year. Economists attribute the decline in confidence to rising costs, falling house prices, and inflation pressures. The New Zealand dollar fell after the release of the data, and most economists agree that a recession is imminent, with the benchmark interest rate expected to reach 5.5% next year.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk near the main entrance to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand located in central Wellington, New Zealand, July 3, 2017. REUTERS/David Gray

site_title: Why petulant oligarchs rule our world
summary: Paul Krugman argues that the "cult of the genius entrepreneur" has led to the rise of "petulant oligarchs" like Elon Musk, who use their immense wealth and privilege to act erratically and further their own interests. Krugman attributes this phenomenon to the concentration of wealth at the top, with the top 0.00001% holding nearly 10 times more wealth than they did four decades ago. This has enabled them to wield significant power and act childishly, tarnishing what was once a useful resource like Twitter and degrading the public discourse.

images.alt_text: The Asian Games due to take place in Hangzhou in September have been postponed indefinitely, organisers said on Friday, as China battles a resurgence of Covid cases.
Sam Bankman-Fried in Hong Kong in May 2021. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
With about four hours left and 14 million votes cast, 57 per cent of participants have said yes.

site_title: Thailand approves tax break to boost public consumption
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved tax measures to boost public consumption and support the economy as it recovers. The measures include a 40,000 baht deduction for shoppers, a 15% cut in land and property tax, and a reduction in jet fuel tax. The tax breaks are estimated to cost the government 18.7 billion baht but are expected to increase gross domestic product by 0.76% and boost spending by 279 billion baht. The central bank forecasts the economy will expand 3.2% this year and 3.9% in 2024.
