site_title: Grab to implement cost cuts, cites uncertain macroeconomic situation: CEO in memo
summary: Grab, South-east Asia's largest ride-hailing and food delivery firm, is implementing cost-cutting measures to cope with an uncertain macroeconomic situation. CEO Anthony Tan has instructed a freeze on most hirings, salary freezes for senior managers, and cuts in travel and expense budgets. These measures aim to help Grab become "leaner and fitter" as it accelerates towards sustainable, profitable growth. The company is preparing for 2023 in an environment where rising prices and interest rates are expected to impact growth.

images.alt_text: Singapore has made clear its stand that platform workers aren't employees, but also hasn't said that they would be classified as independent contractors.
Singapore has set out that platform workers should enjoy the same levels of coverage that employees do.

site_title: Embraer in talks to sell regional jets to Scoot
summary: Embraer is in talks with Singapore Airlines' low-cost subsidiary Scoot to supply regional jets, specifically the E-jet, to serve destinations in South-east Asia. The potential order could be as large as 50 aircraft, valued at around $1.61 billion, and would add a third aircraft manufacturer to Singapore Airlines' fleet. This deal would diversify Scoot's fleet, currently built around Boeing and Airbus SE aircraft, and cater to growing travel demand in the region.

images.alt_text: SIA had announced the issuance of S$850 million worth of the five-year convertible bonds back in 2020.
Group capacity was up 109.7 per cent year on year, reaching 71 per cent of pre-Covid-19 levels during October.

site_title: UK airports to relax aircraft liquid rules from 2024
summary: The UK government plans to relax liquid restrictions in carry-on luggage at airports from June 2024, allowing containers up to 2 liters. Currently, only 100ml containers are allowed, and larger items must be checked in the hold. New security technology, including CT X-ray machines, will be deployed at major airports, reducing queue times and improving the passenger experience. The rules, introduced in the early 2000s, will be relaxed to address the inconvenience caused to travelers, with the aim of detecting potential threats more effectively.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Passengers queue inside the departures terminal of Terminal 2 at Heathrow Airport in London, Britain, June 27, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: New private home sales sink further in November amid holiday lull
summary: New private home sales in Singapore plummeted to 259 units in November, a 17.3% drop from October and 83.3% lower than the same period last year. This is the lowest sales figure in November since 2020. The lack of major launches and extremely low unsold stock are attributed to the market's slow pace. Analysts predict that the supply-demand imbalance will persist, with limited options for buyers, and expect muted market activity for the rest of the year. New projects are expected to resume in January 2023, with increased supply anticipated in 2023.

images.alt_text: Leonard Tay, head of research at Knight Frank, points to the popularity of Copen Grand as evidence that “homebuyers are hungry for new products”.
Developers in Singapore sold a total of 987 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), with more than 913 units launched in September.
Developers sold a total of 437 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), 47.6 per cent lower than the 834 units sold in July 2022.

site_title: Japanese banks agree to back Toshiba’s preferred bidder, sources say
summary: Four major Japanese banks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Mizuho Financial Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, and Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings, have agreed to provide a 1.2 trillion yen (S$12 billion) loan to the Japan Industrial Partners-led consortium for its buyout offer of Toshiba. The banks are finalizing the details and could issue commitment letters by the end of this month. The loan is crucial for the consortium's bid to take Toshiba private at approximately 2.2 trillion yen, with the potential takeover facing headwinds due to rising financing costs.

site_title: China’s factory, retail sectors skid as Covid-19 hits growth
summary: China's factory and retail sectors experienced significant declines in November, with retail sales falling 5.9% and industrial output growing 2.2% year-over-year, missing forecasts. The country's economy, impacted by surging Covid-19 cases and lockdowns, is expected to face a bumpy road ahead. Analysts predict further economic deterioration, with some forecasting a 2.8% GDP growth rate in the fourth quarter. China's central bank has ramped up cash injections into the banking system, and policymakers are expected to map out more stimulus steps to ease disruptions caused by the sudden end of Covid-19 curbs.

site_title: Fashion retailer H&M’s Sep-Nov sales beat forecast
summary: H&M reported a 10% year-on-year increase in September-November net sales, exceeding market expectations. The company's fiscal fourth quarter net sales reached 62.5 billion krona, driven by a 9.5% rise in sales. H&M's efforts to save 2 billion Swedish krona a year due to the cost-of-living crisis included laying off staff, becoming the first big European retailer to do so. This move came after H&M struggled to keep up with rival Zara, which reported a 19% jump in net profit but slower sales growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The H&M clothing store is seen in Times Square in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 15, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Markets sink with Wall Street on hawkish Federal Reserve outlook
summary: Asia's markets sank on Thursday, following a hawkish Federal Reserve statement that signaled US interest rates would rise higher than expected, and warned of slower-than-expected US growth next year. The Fed lifted rates by 50 basis points, citing elevated inflation, and signaled rates could top 5.1% next year, sparking fears of a recession. Asia's major markets fell, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, and Sydney, as traders took cues from Wall Street. The Fed's tougher stance dashed hopes of a soft landing and fueled worries about a recession.

site_title: EU and Asean leaders keen on more cooperation in digital and green economies: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the European Union and ASEAN are keen on more cooperation in digital and green economies, following the conclusion of the one-day Asean-EU Commemorative Summit in Brussels. The two blocs have committed to promoting sustainable and inclusive trade and investment, including in areas such as climate change, renewable energy, and digital transitions. They also agreed to work together in the digital economy, green technologies, and green services, with Singapore and the EU having already established a digital partnership and a comprehensive air transport agreement.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong greets President of the European Council Charles Michel (left) and President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen. ST PHOTO: MARK CHEONG
PM Lee Hsien Loong and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced the EU-Singapore Digital Partnership on Dec 14, 2022.

site_title: Analysts favour US equities, dollar as Fed remains hawkish
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised terminal rate projections at its September meeting, despite a slowdown in rate hikes. This decision led to a decline in US stock markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite indexes falling 0.6% and 0.8% respectively. Asian markets also suffered losses, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi declining 0.4% and 1.6% respectively. The Fed's continued hawkish stance has investors shifting their focus to the dollar and US equities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An eagle tops the U.S. Federal Reserve building's facade in Washington, July 31, 2013. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo

site_title: HSBC’s disgruntled shareholders launch new campaign for spinoff
summary: A small group of HSBC's Hong Kong-based retail investors, led by activist Ken Lui, is launching a campaign to put a resolution to the bank's 2023 annual meeting calling for a return to its pre-pandemic dividend rate and a plan to spin off assets. The resolution seeks to restore quarterly payouts of US$0.51 per share, which were scrapped in 2020. The campaign comes weeks after top HSBC shareholder Ping An Insurance Group urged the lender to aggressively reduce costs and dispose of non-Asian businesses, sparking a renewed push for a spinoff.

images.alt_text: Forestry, agriculture and other environmental assets are among the investments in one of two natural capital funds, managed by Climate Asset Management.
HSBC said it seeks to align its financed emissions to net zero by 2050 or sooner in line with the goals of the Paris Agreement on climate change.

site_title: Singapore shares muted at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% or 2.42 points to 3,280.99 on Thursday, with 31.6 million shares worth S$64 million changing hands. The gains were largely muted, following overnight declines on Wall Street as the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by half a percentage point. Gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 39, with H2G Green Limited and Thai Beverage being among the top performers.

images.alt_text: A man walks in front of the Singapore Exchange building (SGX) on July 21, 2022.

site_title: Weeding out inequality in Singapore’s digital skills education
summary: Singapore's digital skills education faces inequality, with vocational education graduates and university students having disparate access to training opportunities. The country's tech industry is highly competitive, leaving little room for skilled workers to mentor younger employees. However, emerging talent from polytechnics and technical education can contribute significantly to the digital economy. To address this, businesses should invest in education and mentorship, and consider alternative pathways such as online learning, to promote equal access to opportunity and propel Singapore's digital talent pool.

images.alt_text: The demand for workers with skills in software engineering, cloud and analytics is likely to increase with the rise of tech trends in 5G, cloud computing and AI, according to the Jobs Transformation Map for tech workers.

site_title: Housing prices in Asia-Pacific ‘misaligned’ and at a turning point: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that housing prices in the Asia-Pacific region are "misaligned" and at a turning point, with many countries facing a decline of 5-20% due to a surge in prices during the pandemic. Advanced economies, such as New Zealand and Australia, have already seen housing prices decline, while China's property sector is in crisis. The IMF recommends a multifaceted approach to address affordability, including macroprudential policies, monetary and fiscal policies, and considering high levels of household debt.

site_title: Ex-UK PM Johnson earns over £1m for speeches since quitting
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has earned over £1 million for speeches since leaving office in September, according to an official UK parliament register. Johnson, 58, received payments ranging from £215,000 to £277,000 each time, delivering talks to bankers, insurers, and at a CNN summit in Portugal and India. Despite leaving office, Johnson remains an MP and has not ruled out another bid for the top job, citing his party's chances in 2024.

site_title: Should an SGX stock quote be clearly marked as either a Catalist or mainboard listing?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) considers providing clearer indications to investors about Catalist-listed companies, which have unique features such as no quantitative entry criteria and a light-touch regulatory regime. This could help investors better understand the differences between Catalist and mainboard listings, which carry different risk profiles. The SGX website already provides options for investors to filter companies by board, but marking Catalist companies with a color-coded symbol or small icon could further enhance transparency and encourage critical thinking among investors.

images.alt_text: As at Sep 16, LMS Compliance offers more than 1,100 accredited tests and 10,200 non-accredited tests to customers from industries like food, medical devices and pharmaceuticals.
Post-IPO, NoonTalk chief executive officer Dasmond Koh will hold a 62.6 per cent stake in the company.

site_title: Oil prices climb by US$2 amid forecasts for 2023 demand uptick
summary: Oil prices rose by $2 amid forecasts of a 2023 demand uptick and easing US interest rate hikes. Brent crude futures settled at $82.70 per barrel, up 2.4%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $77.28, up 2.5%. The increase was driven by a surge in diesel futures ahead of cold weather and a leak in the Keystone Pipeline, which ships Canadian crude to the US.

site_title: Gold eases as Federal Reserve hints at more rate hikes next year
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1% to US$1,806.11 per ounce, as the US Federal Reserve hinted at more interest rate hikes next year, despite the US economy potentially entering a recession. The Fed Chair, Jerome Powell, argued that higher interest rates are needed to control inflation. The European Central Bank is set to raise interest rates for a fourth consecutive time. China's economy struggles with Covid-19 and weakening external demand, but plans to expand domestic consumption and investment.

site_title: Twitter suspends account tracking Elon Musk’s plane
summary: Twitter has suspended an account tracking Elon Musk's private jet, @ElonJet, after Musk criticized the platform's workers for content moderation decisions. The account, run by Jack Sweeney, was briefly reinstated but ultimately suspended due to Twitter's updated policy on sharing real-time location information. Musk defended the suspension, stating it was a physical safety violation. The move comes a day after Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey defended the platform's workers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla CEO Elon Musk gestures as he visits the construction site of Tesla's Gigafactory in Gruenheide near Berlin, Germany, August 13, 2021. Patrick Pleul/Pool via Reuters - RC2B4P9PCFBM/File Photo

site_title: New Singapore-EU pact to boost cooperation and establish common framework in digital realm
summary: Singapore and the European Union have signed a new pact to boost cooperation and establish a common framework in the digital realm. The EU-Singapore Digital Partnership aims to enhance cooperation on digital issues such as trade facilitation, trusted data flows, and digital skills for workers. The partnership also seeks to make supply chains more resilient and advance new areas like 5G and artificial intelligence. Both parties agreed on a set of digital trade principles, reflecting a commitment to an open digital economy and facilitating joint efforts to boost digital trade.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) and the President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen, pose for pictures in front of the press at the Europa Building in Brussels, during the Asean-EU Summit on December 14, 2022.

site_title: World Cup: France end Morocco’s dream to set up Argentina final
summary: France defeated Morocco 2-0 in the World Cup semi-finals, ending Morocco's dream run to the final. Theo Hernandez scored the first goal in the 5th minute, and Randal Kolo Muani sealed the victory with a late second goal. The win sets up a final showdown with Argentina on Sunday. Morocco, the first African and Arab team to reach the last four at a World Cup, fought despite losing key players to injury.

images.alt_text: Argentina supporters gather outside the Lusail Stadium in Lusail, north of Doha on November 22, 2022, ahead of the Qatar 2022 World Cup Group C football match between Argentina and Saudi Arabia. (Photo by Glyn KIRK / AFP)

Argentina's Julian Alvarez celebrates scoring their second goal with Lionel Messi, Rodrigo De Paul and Nahuel Molina as Croatia's Dominik Livakovic and teammates look dejected, Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar, Dec 13, 2022
The 2026 format has the 48 teams reduced to 32 after the group phase and then the tournament becomes a knockout affair.

site_title: Developing nations demand more money at crunch UN biodiversity talks
summary: Developing nations at the UN COP15 biodiversity conference in Montreal are demanding more financial support from wealthy countries to protect the world's biodiversity. The group, including Brazil, is seeking $100 billion annually, or 1% of global GDP, until 2030, to establish protected areas and implement biodiversity action plans. However, wealthy nations prefer to reform existing financial mechanisms and leverage private sector funding, leading to a walkout by developing nations. The negotiations are critical as world leaders arrive for the high-level phase of the summit.

images.alt_text: Forestry, agriculture and other environmental assets are among the investments in one of two natural capital funds, managed by Climate Asset Management.
Harnessing green financing to push the boundaries of innovation

site_title: EY names future heads of its audit and consulting businesses
summary: EY has named Carmine Di Sibio as the future head of its advisory business and Julie Boland as the head of its assurance business, ahead of a planned split of the firm's audit and consulting units. The appointments will be effective from the date of the separation, which is expected to occur after EY's 13,000 partners vote in favor of the plan next year. Di Sibio, current global chair and CEO, has led EY to its highest revenue growth in nearly two decades, while Boland, US chair and managing partner, has previously served as CFO of US companies.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 27, 2018 a picture shows the logo of EY (Ernst & Young), a multinational professional services firm, in Madrid. - US authorities fined Ernst & Young a record $100 million over cheating on accounting ethics exams that the firm initially covered up from regulators, officials announced June 28, 2022. (Photo by GABRIEL BOUYS / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia mobile tech firm Macrokiosk to grow regional footprint in Laos, Cambodia
summary: Malaysia-based mobile tech firm Macrokiosk plans to expand its regional presence to Cambodia and Laos, as part of a three-year strategy to drive the digital economy. Founded 22 years ago by three brothers, Macrokiosk currently operates in seven South-east Asian countries. CEO Kenny Goh aims to enhance the company's market position through the expansion, which is part of a broader effort to grow its regional footprint.

images.alt_text: Macrokiosk is a 100 per cent owned asset by Trigoh, an investment holding company, which was founded by three brothers - CS Goh (from left), Kenny Goh and Henry Goh.

site_title: Federal Reserve pledges more rate hikes despite fears of US economy stalling
summary: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by half a percentage point, projecting a target federal funds rate of 5.1% by the end of 2023, with at least 75 basis points of additional increases. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated the speed of rate rises is less critical now, and he's not ready to confirm the peak in price pressures despite recent inflation news. The Fed's decision aims to combat inflation, which has reached 40-year highs, but may slow economic growth.

images.alt_text: epa10366266 Chair of the Federal Reserve Jerome Powell speaks at a news conference at the William McChesney Martin Jr. Building in Washington, DC, USA, 14 December 2022. The US Federal Reserve announced plans to raise its benchmark interest rate half a percentage point, bringing the rate to highest level in 15 years as policy makers continue to try address inflation.  EPA-EFE/ERIC LEE

site_title: China plans to expand domestic demand to spur economy
summary: China plans to boost domestic consumption and investment to spur economic growth, aiming to achieve a new level of scale by 2035. The move aims to reduce income gaps, promote "common prosperity," and enhance economic resilience. Beijing will support housing, encourage electric vehicle adoption, and boost quality consumer goods. The strategy, part of the "dual circulation" plan, seeks to increase reliance on domestic production, distribution, and consumption.

images.alt_text: Visitors walk down the Nanjing Road in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, Oct. 2, 2022. The Chinese yuan advanced on last week in both onshore and offshore trading after a report that state-owned banks are preparing for intervention. Mainland markets are closed this week for a holiday. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan extends trade deficits as surging imports outrun exports
summary: Japan's trade deficit widened for the 16th consecutive month in November, driven by a 30.3% surge in imports, surpassing economists' expectations. Exports grew 20% year-on-year, but at a slower pace than October, resulting in a trade deficit of 2 trillion yen. The slowdown in exports to China, fueled by declining demand for chip-making machinery, and the yen's depreciation further raised concerns about global recession and Japan's central bank's continued easy money policy.

site_title: Russian billionaire’s luxury Riviera villa continues to feel the freeze
summary: Russian billionaire Alexander Ponomarenko lost his lawsuit to lift an asset freeze on a luxury villa in Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, France. The villa, valued at $119.8 million, was purchased over a decade ago and was sanctioned following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Ponomarenko's bid comes nearly 10 months after he became one of the first Russian tycoons to own luxury real estate in the South of France to be sanctioned. The villa's asset freeze remains in place.

images.alt_text: Villa Cuccia Noya 3, centre right, in Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, France.
The US Treasury also imposed sanctions on Alina Kabaeva (right), a former Olympic gymnast widely described as Vladimir Putin’s girlfriend.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as Federal Reserve signals more rate hikes ahead
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve signaled more interest rate hikes ahead, despite moderation in inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.6% and 0.8%, respectively. The Fed announced a half-point interest rate hike, citing still-high wage inflation. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that the central bank's policy was "not restrictive enough" in light of inflation, indicating a hawkish stance.

site_title: Suspect in Paul Pelosi assault: ‘pretty amicable’ before hammer attack
summary: David Wayne DePape, 42, accused of attacking Paul Pelosi, husband of US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, told investigators the incident was "pretty amicable" before he hit the 82-year-old with a hammer. DePape, a Canadian citizen, had denied attempted murder and other charges in connection with a break-in in October, where he intended to kidnap Nancy Pelosi. He said he had threatened Paul Pelosi but the encounter was mostly calm before the violent attack, which prosecutors say was premeditated.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: European shares were flat on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, following a near one-week high the previous day. The Stoxx 600 index remained unchanged after softer-than-expected US inflation data raised hopes of smaller rate hikes. The European Central Bank will also announce its interest rate decision on Thursday, with inflation expected to remain above 2% for the next three years. Defensive stocks such as Nestle and Unilever added 1% each, while rate-sensitive technology stocks declined 0.9%.

site_title: Heal Partners launches second PE health and education fund, aims to raise up to US$500m
summary: Heal Partners, a private equity firm, has launched its second health and education fund, Heal Fund II, aiming to raise US$350-500 million. The firm's managing partner, Martin Robinson, believes valuations of target companies are "compelling" and investments in education and healthcare benefit from strong demographic and economic tailwinds. Heal Fund I, closed at A$200 million in 2022, and the new fund is expected to be a good vintage for funds in the health and education sectors.

images.alt_text: China’s massive health sector, comprising pharmaceuticals and fast-growing tech and biotech firms, has also been underpinned by rising public and private spending.

site_title: Sotheby’s gets new Hong Kong auction house after record sales
summary: Sotheby's is set to open a new Hong Kong auction house in 2024, located at Landmark Chater in the Central district. The 2,230 sqm space will feature an exhibition space, collectibles for instant purchase, live auctions, and a cafe. The company will also move its local headquarters to a nearby office, marking a move to cater to growth in Greater China following record sales. This expansion comes as the global art market experiences record highs, with Sotheby's Asia auctions reaching $1.1 billion in sales in 2022.

images.alt_text: People shop for Christmas items at a market in Hong Kong. Analysts told BT they are expecting Hong Kong’s economy to shrink this year, and notch growth of between 1.4 to 3 per cent in 2023.
Despite the buoyant stock market, life is hardly back to pre-pandemic normalcy.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank raises interest rate after Federal Reserve hike
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority raised its base rate by 50 basis points to 4.75% on Thursday, following a similar 50 basis point hike by the US Federal Reserve. This move is in line with Hong Kong's currency peg to the US dollar, and aims to control inflation. The rate hike is the latest development in a global trend of central banks tightening monetary policy to combat rising inflation.

site_title: Branch wars: Banks woo customers with elaborately decked physical spaces
summary: Singapore banks are revamping their branches to offer unique, customer-centric experiences. OCBC has launched an "integrated lifestyle and banking branch" at Wisma Atria with 20,000 sq ft of retail space, including an omakase restaurant, bookshop, and art gallery. UOB has introduced wellness zones with yoga, perfume-making, and bento-making classes. Citi has built wealth advisory hubs to facilitate wealth conversations and reviews. DBS is incorporating digital with physical offerings, offering 24/7 digital services and face-to-face consultations. These branches aim to deepen relationships with customers, drive transactions, and differentiate themselves from competitors.

images.alt_text: MAS said in December 2020 that there were 14 "eligible applications" for the new digital bank licences
DBS, OCBC and UOB ATMs at Tang Plaza near Orchard MRT on July 30, 2020.
UOB's brand refresh event concluded with a fashion show, featuring staff walking down the runway with the bank’s new branch ambassador uniforms.

site_title: KOP unit receives S$30.6m final payment from arbitration over China ski resort
summary: KOP Northern Lights, a unit of KOP Ltd, has received S$30.6 million from an arbitration case over the development of the world's largest indoor ski resort in China, Wintastar Shanghai. The company had withdrawn from the project after disagreements arose with partners in 2020. The arbitration centre ruled that agreements were terminated in 2020, and the other parties acquired KOPNL's 30% stake in the JV company at a fair-market value. The payment brings an end to the case, generating a healthy cash inflow for KOP.

images.alt_text: The damages awarded comprised largely US$6.1 million in loss of profits from Razer’s e-commerce platform.

site_title: PwC global chairman Bob Moritz says no pressure to split the firm
summary: PwC global chairman Bob Moritz stated that his firm does not feel pressure to split its assurance and consultancy operations, unlike rival EY. Moritz believes a multidisciplinary model is essential for providing employees with opportunities to grow and attract talent. He noted that companies are under significant pressure to build trust and deliver sustained outcomes, driven by growing ESG scrutiny and technological change. PwC aims to offer the right technological capabilities and a combination of them to help clients stay on top of big-picture issues.

images.alt_text: The salary increases came as firms struggle to retain staff.
V
(Photo by GABRIEL BOUYS / AFP)

site_title: Japfa unit AustAsia to list on Hong Kong Exchange by end-December
summary: Japfa's China-focused dairy unit, AustAsia Group, is set to list on the Hong Kong Exchange by December 30, barring unforeseen circumstances. The group believes the listing will unlock value for shareholders by creating two separate businesses, providing operational flexibility, and allowing each entity to concentrate on its core business. AustAsia will register its prospectus on December 15, with a public offering starting on December 16 and closing on December 21. Japfa has previously announced its intention to list AustAsia in March, proposing a distribution-in-specie of its entire shareholding in the unit.

images.alt_text: Tan Yong Nang, chief executive officer of Japfa. The group posted a 59 per cent drop in net profit for 9M FY2022, despite recording higher revenue.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng offer turns unconditional; closing date extended to Jan 19
summary: Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang and her husband Gordon Tang's mandatory cash offer to acquire the property player has turned unconditional, with over 405.7 million shares accepted, representing 51.73% of the company. The offer price is S$0.75 per share. The closing date has been extended to Jan 19, 2023, from Jan 5, after the offeror received valid acceptances of 52.34% of the company's maximum potential issued share capital. The Tangs must attain more than 90% of Chip Eng Seng's shares to take the company private.

images.alt_text: Celine Tang, managing director of listed developer SingHaiyi Group
Chip Eng Seng plans to develop a lagoon in the Maldives into a five-star resort.

site_title: US authorities charge 8 social media influencers in securities fraud scheme
summary: US authorities have charged eight social media influencers with securities fraud, alleging they reaped $114 million by manipulating stocks on Twitter and Discord. The defendants, who claimed to be successful traders, used a "pump and dump" scheme to hype stocks and sell them at inflated prices. The US Securities and Exchange Commission has filed civil charges against seven of the defendants, while the eighth was charged with aiding and abetting the scheme through his podcast. The scheme was uncovered in the Southern District of Texas, with the Justice Department's Assistant Attorney General Kenneth Polite stating that securities fraud undermines public markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Top Glove, Japfa, CDLHT, Samudera, KOP, Stamford Tyres
summary: BlackRock sold S$8.9 million worth of Keppel shares, lowering its stake from 5.03% to 4.96%. Keppel shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday. Top Glove may take up to a year to return to profitability after posting a net loss of RM168.2 million (S$51.6 million) for the first quarter. Japfa's subsidiary AustAsia Group is set to list on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong on December 30. CDL Hospitality Trusts signed a new 10-year lease agreement with Banyan Tree for the Angsana Velavaru resort in the Maldives.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Vibrant Group posts a 20.4 per cent rise in net profit to S$3.5 million for the first half of its financial year.

site_title: Harnessing green financing to push the boundaries of innovation
summary: Singapore aims to support the growing global demand for green solutions through various initiatives, including the Singapore Green Plan 2030 and the Enterprise Sustainability Programme. The government has also established the Green Finance Industry Taskforce to develop a taxonomy for green financing. To increase access to green financing, the Monetary Authority of Singapore offers grant schemes and the Enterprise Financing Scheme – Green, which provides a 70% risk-share for small and medium-sized enterprises. This has catalyzed over S$100 million in green loans for more than 30 SMEs. The growing demand for green financing is expected to reach over US$3 trillion by 2030, enabling enterprises to capture emerging opportunities in the green economy and drive innovation.

images.alt_text: A plan by Europe’s markets watchdog, ESMA, to set quantifiable ESG and sustainable investing standards is forcing portfolio managers to rethink how they design and market an ESG fund class known as Article 8.

Most Singapore companies that have sought independent assurance on their ESG disclosures have opted to go with limited assurance, but market pressures will eventually drive them to seek a higher level of assurance. (PHOTO: AFP)
Bursa Malaysia CEO Muhamad Umar Swift at the launch of the first Shariah-compliant carbon exchange in the world on Dec 9, 2022 in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: World Cup: Fifa to re-think 2026 format as they face spoiling winning recipe
summary: FIFA is re-examining the 2026 World Cup format, which currently features 48 teams reduced to 32 after the group phase, to prevent "dead" matches and potential controversy. The current format has been criticized for the possibility of contrived results. Alternative formats, such as 12 groups of four teams or two separate halves of 24 teams, are being considered. These changes could lead to more games, potentially diluting the tournament's excitement, but also increase television rights money for FIFA.

site_title: WhatsApp Pay India chief quits within months of taking charge
summary: WhatsApp's India head of payment business Vinay Choletti has quit within four months of taking charge, following a series of senior-level departures at parent Meta. Choletti expressed confidence in WhatsApp's potential to transform digital payments and financial inclusion in India. This departure marks the latest in a series of executive changes at Meta, which has seen layoffs and struggles in the competitive Indian payments market, where it faces rivals such as Google Pay and Paytm.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a hoarding of the WhatsApp application installed at a skywalk in Mumbai, India, August 26, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s take on the changing nature of employment
summary: Singapore has implemented new protections for gig economy workers, including workplace injury compensation, housing and retirement benefits, and increased representation. The government accepted 12 recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers, which aim to provide a greater level of protection for gig workers without classifying them as employees or independent contractors. The changes include mandatory Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions for gig workers, which will increase their take-home pay by 20%. The move aims to address concerns over work benefit inequalities and the sustainability of the gig economy arrangement in the long term.

images.alt_text: An association representing Deliveroo, Grab and foodpanda disagrees with the exclusion of street-hail taxis and certain logistics companies from the new rules.
While some platforms do provide some form of insurance to their gig workers, coverage is incomplete.
The Advisory Committee on Platform Workers has made 12 recommendations to strengthen protections for gig workers.

site_title: FTX bankruptcy standoff heats up as Bahamas challenges US case
summary: Bahamas court officials are challenging a US case in the FTX bankruptcy, seeking to remove millions of dollars of company-owned real estate from oversight by a US judge. Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, is in jail in the Bahamas awaiting extradition to the US on fraud charges. The dispute highlights a key tension in the downfall of the crypto empire, with US-based lawyers accusing Bahamian officials of working closely with Bankman-Fried.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried told a court in Nassau after his arrest on a US request that he would not waive his right to a hearing on extradition, local media reported from the court.

site_title: EU vows investment in push to boost South-east Asia ties
summary: The European Union (EU) has pledged billions of dollars in investment to South-east Asia, aiming to strengthen ties and counterbalance China's growing influence in the region. The EU's 10 billion euro investment package is part of its Global Gateway strategy, designed to diversify supply chains away from China. The move comes as the EU seeks to boost trade relations with Asean nations, which have been divided in their response to Russia's war in Ukraine. EU leaders also pushed for stronger language to condemn Russia, while navigating delicate relationships with China and Asean's diverse member states.

site_title: UK households less sensitive to rate hikes
summary: UK households are less sensitive to interest rate hikes, according to a Bank of England survey. 27% of respondents believe higher rates would be "best for them personally," while 30% want rates to fall. The shift to fixed mortgages and increased savings among households may contribute to this reduced sensitivity. The Bank of England is expected to hike rates to 3.5% to tackle inflation, but its monetary policy may be less effective in reining in inflation due to this changing consumer behavior.

images.alt_text: BOE said the average payment for those who remortgage will reach 1,000 pounds a month next year – £250 a month higher than the current level.

site_title: China central bank sets out draft controls over financial infrastructure
summary: China's central bank has issued draft rules to supervise and manage financial infrastructure, aiming to push finance groups to better serve the real economy. The rules would cover institutions involved in clearing and settlement, trading facilities, and payment systems, with all data collected within Chinese territory to be stored domestically. The regulations emphasize the Communist Party's dominant role and maintain "absolute control" over infrastructure affecting national financial security.

site_title: TPG Telecom joins list of hacked Australian companies; shares slide
summary: TPG Telecom, an Australian internet services provider, announced that up to 15,000 corporate customer e-mail addresses were accessed in a cyberattack. The company's shares fell 2.8% following the news. This incident is part of at least eight other Australian companies that have publicly disclosed hacks since October, prompting the government to develop a new cybersecurity strategy and consider banning ransom payments to cybercriminals.

images.alt_text: The Australian Federal Court has ordered Telstra to pay A$15 million, a unit of TPG Telecom to cough up A$5 million, and imposed a fine of A$13.5 million on Optus, a unit of Singtel.

The sale of the assets, which include more than 1,200 sites and represent about 21 per cent of TPG’s mobile network footprint, will deliver net cash proceeds of A$890 million, which will be used to repay existing bank debt
TPG stays light to drive growth

site_title: Data-driven: Trust, transparency and exceptional experiences in hospitality
summary: F&B outlets in Singapore can tap into customer data to provide personalized experiences, but public trust has plummeted due to data breaches and lack of transparency. As data collection increases, there is uncertainty over who owns the data, with third-party tech companies and hospitality operators claiming ownership. To regain trust, companies must prioritize transparency and data protection, allowing consumers to feel compelled to share approved data with their favorite restaurants and cafes. This shift towards data-driven experiences can lead to meaningful and personalized interactions for guests.

images.alt_text: More advanced and connected medical devices are coming to the market and being adopted by consumers and healthcare providers.

site_title: Indonesia to offer US$5,000 subsidy on electric car sales
summary: Indonesia's government plans to offer a US$5,000 subsidy on the sale of electric cars, as well as incentives for hybrid cars and electric motorbikes. The incentives aim to reduce carbon emissions in the country, with targets of at least 1.2 million electric bikes and 35,000 electric vehicles by 2024. The subsidy and incentives will be offered to buyers of electric vehicles produced in Indonesia, with conversion costs for motorbikes also covered. A timeline for implementation and total budget are not provided.

site_title: PM Lee holds bilateral meetings with EU leaders, with focus on growing cooperation
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with EU leaders, including Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, and Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda, during the Asean-EU Commemorative Summit in Brussels. The meetings reaffirmed mutual interest in strengthening cooperation between Singapore and the EU, as well as between Asean and the EU. Lee emphasized the importance of free and open trade and a rules-based international order, particularly as maritime nations.

images.alt_text: Joint Press Conference between German Federal Chancellor Olaf Scholz, and PM Lee Hsien Loong on 14 November 2022.  PM Lee will meet Chancellor Scholz during an official visit to Germany in December.

site_title: Malaysia to cut power subsidies for large businesses: Anwar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced plans to cut power subsidies for large businesses and multinational corporations, estimated to cost the government RM30 billion. However, small- and medium-sized enterprises, as well as those involved in agriculture and food production, will not be affected. The move aims to channel spending towards those in need, with the goal of reducing the burden of rising prices on low-income groups.

images.alt_text: Listed-companies which are perceived to be linked to the top Malaysia leaders have seen strong interest from short-term investors.
The International Court of Justice in 2008 awarded sovereignty over Pedra Branca to Singapore.
The investigation comes after Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim this week announced a review of government projects worth billions of dollars approved by his predecessor Muhyiddin Yassin.

site_title: US-backed high-tech nuclear plant in Wyoming delayed
summary: A US-backed high-tech nuclear plant in Wyoming, backed by Bill Gates, is delayed by at least two years due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The $4 billion Natrium plant, which aims to cut carbon emissions, relies on Russian fuel, and the US Department of Energy is looking to downblend its stockpile of weapons-grade uranium to provide an alternative. Senator John Barrasso has introduced a bill to boost domestic production of advanced nuclear fuel, citing the need for the US to reduce reliance on Russia for this fuel.

site_title: US dollar wallows at six-month low ahead of last Fed meeting of 2022
summary: The US dollar index fell to a six-month low of 103.57 against six major currencies due to cooling US inflation, giving the Federal Reserve room to slow future rate hikes. The dollar traded at 103.91, down from its previous low. Investors expect the Fed to raise interest rates by 50 basis points, similar to expected rate hikes by the Bank of England and European Central Bank.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Private-sector economists have lowered their 2023 forecast for Singapore's economic growth to 1.8%, down from 2.8%, but raised their inflation forecasts. Corporate governance practices among Singapore companies improved in 2021, and industry maps are being refreshed to support the country's hub status in food manufacturing. Residential leasing volumes fell in November, while condominium and HDB rentals rose. The STI rose 0.2% on hopes of softer US Fed rate hikes.

site_title: US consumer loan delinquencies seen surging to 13-year high in 2023
summary: US consumer loan delinquencies are expected to surge to a 13-year high in 2023, according to TransUnion's forecast. Americans took out record 87.5 million new credit cards and 22.1 million personal loans in 2022. Rising interest rates and inflation, combined with recession fears, are contributing to the expected delinquencies. This marks the highest delinquency rate since 2010, with consumers facing significant financial challenges.

images.alt_text: Demand for any kind of credit is strongest from consumers with high credit scores.

site_title: AIG subsidiary files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy
summary: AIG subsidiary AIG Financial Products (FP) filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, marking the culmination of a process that began during the 2008 financial crisis. FP has no material operations or businesses, and its bankruptcy is expected to have a minimal impact on AIG's balance sheet. The filing comes after AIG was accused of misleading investors about its exposure to subprime mortgages and credit default swaps during the crisis, resulting in a $182.3 billion federal bailout.

site_title: Sri Lanka expects up to US$8b more in loans, asset restructuring
summary: Sri Lanka is expecting to receive up to $8 billion in loans, including $5 billion from multilateral agencies and $3 billion from asset restructuring. Foreign Minister Ali Sabry stated that the country is looking to secure additional funding beyond its deal with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The government aims to strengthen its treasury and reserves through asset restructuring, with a potential gain of $2-$3 billion.

site_title: Avatar sequel helps Imax bulls make the case that cinema’s not dead
summary: Imax shares have gained momentum due to the release of Avatar: The Way of Water, a science-fiction epic developed with Imax equipment. The film's success is expected to boost Imax's box office and exposure, with analysts citing its valuation and long-term growth potential as attractive. Despite a 13% decline in 2022, Imax's shares have outperformed rivals Cinemark and AMC, with over 80% of analysts recommending a buy. The film's big-budget release and immersive experience align with Imax's strengths, solidifying its position in the industry.

site_title: India regulator planning ‘micro’ Reits to boost nascent market: source
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) is planning to introduce "micro" Reits to boost the country's nascent real estate investment trust market. Sebi is considering allowing Reits to hold single assets or diversified portfolios, potentially lowering the minimum asset value of 5 billion rupees (S$81.6 million). This move aims to increase supply and flexibility for investors, helping India's real estate market recover from a pandemic-induced lull.

images.alt_text: Average house prices in India were expected to rise 5.0 per cent over each of the next three years, lagging the current consumer price inflation rate, after increasing by 7 per cent in 2022, according to the Nov 9-Dec 1 poll.
CapitaLand India Trust will acquire ownership of the properties it develops with L&T Realty in a phased manner

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank ‘negative’ on Thai tourism sector as uncertain recovery, high valuations weigh
summary: Maybank Securities has downgraded Thailand's tourism sector to "negative" due to uncertain recovery and high valuations, despite expecting 22 million international tourist arrivals in 2023 and 40 million in 2024. Analyst Yuwanee Prommaporn cites high costs and depressed Ebitda margins as reasons for the downgrade. However, she notes that China's relaxation of Covid-19 curbs could boost tourist arrivals in the first half of 2023, and Thai tourism operators are expected to turn profitable in the fiscal year ahead.

images.alt_text: Foreign tourists walk along the popular Khaosan Road in Bangkok on May 17, 2022. - Thailand's economy grew 2.2 percent in the first quarter following an export and tourism boost after the relaxation of pandemic entry restrictions, the kingdom's main economic agency said May 17. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Thailand is seeking to lure more foreign visitors in the post-Covid period by promoting itself as a world-class destination for medical treatment.

site_title: Hong Kong police wrong to ban Tiananmen vigil, court rules
summary: A Hong Kong court ruled that police were wrong to ban a Tiananmen vigil in 2021, overturning the conviction of democracy activist Chow Hang-tung. The ban, citing security and coronavirus concerns, was deemed unlawful as police failed to facilitate public gatherings. Chow remains in custody, facing further national security charges. The ruling is a rare rebuke of Hong Kong authorities, where commemoration of the 1989 Beijing crackdown has been largely suppressed.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong deployed heavy security near a major park on Saturday (Jun 4) as it warned people not to gather to commemorate China’s bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square 33 years ago, as Taiwan decried efforts to erase the memories.

site_title: London rents lag rest of UK after shift to remote work
summary: London rents have slowed down, with private rental prices increasing by 3.5% in November, lower than the 4% average growth in the rest of the UK. This is attributed to the shift to remote work, where consumers are choosing where to live rather than being tied to office locations. Median rent in London remains the highest, at £1,475, while Northern Ireland saw the fastest growth, with prices rising 9.5%. The data adds to evidence of rising costs for tenants, with rental stock still in limited supply and mortgage rates increasing.

images.alt_text: House prices in the south west of England fell the most in December, registering a drop of 3.4 per cent.
Rent now costs 35 per cent of average earnings, the highest level since at least 2009.

site_title: China asks banks to buy bonds after market slump
summary: China's central bank asked major banks to buy bonds to stabilize the domestic market amid a credit selloff fueled by retail investor withdrawals. The goal is to absorb selling pressure from wealth management products. Regulators also provided window guidance on bond purchases, including notes from local government financing vehicles. This move aims to prevent financial instability, as bond prices have slumped rapidly since early November.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks are now moving by 5 per cent a day more frequently than at any time since the global market meltdown of 2008.

site_title: BlackRock ceases to be substantial shareholder of Keppel
summary: BlackRock, a major asset manager, has ceased to be a substantial shareholder of Keppel Corp after selling approximately 1.2 million shares worth S$8.9 million on December 12, reducing its stake from 5.03% to 4.96%. The sale lowered BlackRock's stake in the Singapore-based company, bringing its average selling price per share to S$7.44. Keppel shares closed at S$7.48 on the same day, up 0.5% or S$0.04.

site_title: CDLHT unit enters new 10-year lease agreement for Maldives resort
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) has signed a 10-year lease agreement with Banyan Tree Holdings for the Angsana Velavaru resort in the Maldives. The existing lease expires on January 31, 2023, and the new agreement maintains the same rental formula and management fee terms as the existing one. The lessee will pay rent equivalent to the resort's gross operating profit minus management fees, with a minimum rent guarantee. The agreement is set to commence on February 1, 2023.

images.alt_text: maldives, tropics, tropical

site_title: Stamford Tyres more than doubles H1 net profit to S$2.1 million
summary: Stamford Tyres more than doubled its net profit to S$2.1 million in the first half of the year, driven by higher sales across South-east Asia. The company's revenue rose 10.2% to S$97 million, but operating expenses increased by 3.6% due to higher staff, marketing, and distribution costs. The company has implemented strategies to diversify its product offerings to adapt to the challenging global economic outlook. Stamford Tyres has S$28.3 million in cash and plans to focus on growing sales of car tyres, SSW Wheels, and truck tyres.

images.alt_text: Vibrant remains cautious about its logistics and freight segment.

site_title: PM Anwar told A-G to review Pedra Branca issue for ‘meaningful’ talks with Singapore
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has instructed the Attorney-General to review the Pedra Branca issue to facilitate meaningful talks with Singapore. The International Court of Justice awarded sovereignty over Pedra Branca to Singapore in 2008, and Malaysia calls the island Batu Puteh. Anwar aims for fruitful negotiations and a positive outcome to avoid issues in relations with its neighboring country.

site_title: Hong Kong wants to prove it can still be ‘Asia’s World City’
summary: Hong Kong aims to reestablish itself as "Asia's World City" despite lingering effects of the pandemic. The city's economy has recovered, with the Hang Seng Index rising, but life is not yet back to pre-pandemic normalcy. Many professionals, including bankers and lawyers, have left, and over 60 international companies have moved their regional headquarters out of Hong Kong. The government has relaxed visa rules and reduced stamp duty, but concerns over civil liberties and Beijing's influence persist, potentially deterring international business.

images.alt_text: Travellers arrive at the Hong Kong International Airport on the first day Covid-19 hotel quarantine was scrapped, Hong Kong, China, Sept 26, 2022.
People shop for Christmas items at a market in Hong Kong. Analysts told BT they are expecting Hong Kong’s economy to shrink this year, and notch growth of between 1.4 to 3 per cent in 2023.
The resumption of tourism from the mainland would be a boon for Hong Kong’s economy, which has been hobbled by more than two years of Covid-related border restrictions.

site_title: Samudera to buy JV partner’s 25% stake in LNG transporter for US$14.8 million
summary: Samudera Shipping Line has agreed to purchase a 25% stake in LNG East-West Shipping Company (LNG EW) for US$14.8 million, increasing its interest to 50%. The deal aims to better realize value from LNG EW's liquefied natural gas transportation business. The acquisition is expected to be completed by mid-December and is not expected to impact Samudera's earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Thai economy in recovery, bolstered by tourists, minister says
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to recover this year, growing 3.4% and 3.8% in 2022 and 2023, respectively, driven by a rebound in its tourism sector. Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith attributed this growth to global uncertainties and average inflation of 6% this year. The country has seen a significant increase in foreign tourist arrivals, breaking the government's target of 10 million for the year, with 11.5 million expected by the end of 2022. This growth is a positive sign for the Thai economy, which experienced slow growth of 1.5% last year.

site_title: G7, Vietnam reach US$15.5b climate deal to cut coal use
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) has agreed to fund Vietnam's transition away from coal with $15.5 billion, a deal to be announced at a Brussels summit. The funding will come from both public and private sectors, with half from each, and will focus on projects like offshore wind farms and power grid upgrades. This is the third such agreement reached by G7 nations, following similar deals with South Africa and Indonesia.

site_title: US existing home sales to slide to 11-year low in 2023
summary: US existing home sales are projected to fall to an 11-year low in 2023, with a 6.8% decline to 4.78 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. Despite this, prices are expected to remain flat due to supply constraints, with the median transaction price estimated at $385,800. Mortgage rates are predicted to ease from 7% to 5.7% as the Federal Reserve dials back on rate hikes, and rental inflation is expected to decrease next year to 5% from 7% this year.

images.alt_text: In the HDB rental market, prices are up 1.6 per cent from October 2022 and 27.8 per cent on a year-on-year basis.

site_title: Strikes and snow turn London’s office districts into ghost towns
summary: Thousands of financial professionals in London's office districts have chosen to work from home due to rail strikes and freezing weather, resulting in office occupancy plummeting to 19% on Monday. The strikes, which began Tuesday morning, have led to thousands of commuters avoiding the city, causing empty streets and deserted business districts. This marks a significant decline from the 33% occupancy rate recorded a week earlier, highlighting the impact of the strikes on the city's commercial activity.

images.alt_text: Some of the world’s biggest banks are under pressure to move more traders into EU cities such as Paris, Frankfurt and Amsterdam.

Starting from Dec 13, thousands of members of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers and Transport Salaried Staffs’ Association will walk out on train companies across the country.

site_title: Are Qatar’s World Cup stadiums the future of sports in a warming world?
summary: Qatar's World Cup stadiums have been hailed as a pioneering example of air-conditioned outdoor venues that can keep athletes and spectators comfortable in extreme heat. Designed by Professor Saud Ghani and his team, the eight stadiums use a combination of cool air, shading, and ventilation to maintain a neutral temperature. The system, which uses cold water to cool the air, is designed to be efficient and unobtrusive, with subtle airflow and sensors to adjust the temperature during games. While some critics have raised concerns about the environmental impact and cost of the stadiums, Ghani believes that his design has the potential to revolutionize stadium design in a warming world, and plans to establish a regional centre for building physics to further develop his research.

images.alt_text: Cinema Still : Escape to Victory

site_title: India’s Mahindra to invest 100 billion rupees in new EV plant
summary: Indian automaker Mahindra and Mahindra will invest 100 billion rupees (S$1.6 billion) to set up an electric vehicle manufacturing plant near Pune. The investment will be spread over 7-8 years and will produce the EV variant of its popular SUV, XUV 700. The new plant aims to grow India's electric car market from 1% to 30% by 2030, challenging domestic rival Tata Motors, which dominates the market. Mahindra's new EV unit is valued at US$9 billion and is expected to be available for sale in January.

site_title: Crypto firm Binance says deposits returning after heavy withdrawals
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, reported deposits are returning after heavy withdrawals. On Tuesday, the exchange saw US$1.9 billion in withdrawals, the largest outflow since June, and halted some stablecoin withdrawals. CEO Changpeng Zhao stated that "things seem to have stabilised" in a tweet. The halt was initially attributed to a "token swap", but its cause remains unclear. Deposits are now resuming, indicating a return to normal operations for the exchange.

images.alt_text: The withdrawals mark Binance's largest daily outflow since at least June, and account for a majority of the US$2.2 billion in Ethereum-based withdrawals in the last seven days.

site_title: US lawmakers introduce Bill to restrict Huawei’s access to banks
summary: US lawmakers have introduced a bipartisan Bill to sanction Chinese tech company Huawei Technologies and other Chinese 5G producers, restricting their access to US banks. The Bill, backed by Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, seeks to "severely sanction" Huawei and other entities accused of economic espionage. If passed, it would add them to the Treasury Department's Specially Designated Nationals List, freezing their access to the US financial system. China's Foreign Ministry has opposed the move, saying it unfairly generalizes national security concerns.

site_title: UK inflation falls from 41-year high
summary: UK inflation fell to a 41-year low in November, with consumer prices rising 10.7% from last year, down from October's 11.1%. The decline was largely due to decreases in petrol and used car prices. Food and non-alcoholic beverage prices rose 16.4%, the highest level since 1977. This decrease suggests the worst of the UK's cost-of-living crisis may be over, but economists still expect inflation to remain high.

images.alt_text: Waterloo Station in London is near empty on Tuesday (Dec 13) as rail workers strike over pay and term, leading thousands of financial professionals to choose to work from home to avoid disrupted commutes.

Starting from Dec 13, thousands of members of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers and Transport Salaried Staffs’ Association will walk out on train companies across the country.
Steel and other metal products are the biggest category of products awaiting completion.

site_title: Indonesia’s GoTo sells 1.5 trillion rupiah stake in retailer Alfamart
summary: GoTo, a merger between Gojek and Tokopedia, has sold its 1.5 trillion rupiah stake in Indonesian retailer Alfamart, worth around $123 million. The move comes after the tech firm's shares plummeted nearly 55% in two weeks, wiping out nearly $8.8 billion in market value. The sale is part of GoTo's strategy to focus on accelerating profitability, as the company faces a market value loss of over $23 billion.

site_title: STI rises 0.2% on hopes of softer US Fed rate hikes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,278.57 on Wednesday, driven by hopes of softer US Federal Reserve rate hikes following mild inflation data. Key regional bourses also posted advances, with gains outnumbering losses 310 to 196. Despite a November CPI reading of 7.1%, economists see a potential slowdown in interest-rate hikes, with Bank of Singapore's chief economist citing cooling inflation as a positive factor.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on November 25, 2022, people shop at Macy's department store during Black Friday in New York City. - US retailers cheered a buoyant start to the holiday shopping season on November 29, 2022, but warned that a potential freight rail strike could still cripple the critically busy period. In spite of grinding inflation, customer counts on "Black Friday" and throughout the Thanksgiving holiday shopping weekend jumped from last year, exceeding expectations, according to data from the National Retail Federation. (Photo by Yuki IWAMURA / AFP)
Asian markets tracked Wall Street higher on Wednesday, though the gains were limited ahead of the Fed meeting.
This marked the second quarterly loss for the group since its listing in Malaysia in 2001, and the red ink more than tripled from last quarter’s net loss of RM52.6 million.

site_title: China fuel demand outlook brightens as road, air traffic jump after Covid curbs ease
summary: China's road and air traffic have rebounded sharply after easing Covid-19 restrictions, boosting fuel demand and crude prices. Road and air transport increased for the first time in almost two months, with road traffic picking up and domestic air passenger volumes jumping 68% last week. Analysts expect mobility to normalize by end-March 2023, supporting a rise in global oil prices. However, concerns remain about the impact of rising Covid cases on the recent momentum in mobility, with China's leaders delaying a key economic policy meeting amid surging infections.

site_title: US to blacklist over 30 Chinese companies
summary: The US has planned to add over 30 Chinese companies to a trade blacklist, including Yangtze Memory Technologies, a leading maker of memory chips. The move is expected to prevent these companies from buying American components and deepens tensions between the US and China. The US Department of Commerce will block the companies from buying technology from US suppliers unless they obtain a special export license. This move comes after Huawei Technologies and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation were already on the list, causing significant disruptions to their businesses.

site_title: Court approves Hong Kong Airlines’ HK$49b debt restructuring
summary: Hong Kong Airlines' HK$49 billion debt restructuring plan has been approved by the High Court, boosting the carrier's survival chances after years of financial turmoil. The plan involves jettisoning 33 aircraft, issuing new shares, and raising about HK$3 billion. The carrier has struggled to repay debt since before the Covid crisis, when anti-government protests kept visitors away. The court approval is timely, as the process of renewing Hong Kong Airlines' transport licence is set to begin this month.

site_title: Public good precedes corporate interests in insuring platform workers
summary: Singapore has set a proposal requiring platform workers to enjoy the same levels of coverage as employees under the Work Injury Compensation Act (Wica). This includes compensation thresholds of S$76,000 to S$225,000 for a worker's death. The proposal aims to protect platform workers from work-related injuries, despite disagreement from the General Insurance Association of Singapore, which advocated for tweaks to existing products instead. The government has decided to implement the Wica-based solution, with coverage based on earnings from all platforms, to ensure fair premiums and dispute resolution.

images.alt_text: The Advisory Committee for Platform Workers took a nuanced, rather than broad-based approach.
The Advisory Committee on Platform Workers has made 12 recommendations to strengthen protections for gig workers.

site_title: Germany’s recession to be milder than expected in 2023: Ifo
summary: Germany's recession is expected to be milder than predicted, according to a report by Ifo. Economic output growth is forecast to shrink by 0.1% in 2023, down from a previous 0.3% contraction. Inflation is expected to slide from 7.8% in 2022 to 6.4% in 2023, as energy prices are capped. Demand for goods in the manufacturing sector remains strong, and growth is predicted to pick up in 2024, with 1.6% growth expected.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend US rally after inflation boost, eyes on Federal Reserve
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, following a US inflation report that showed a 7.1% increase in consumer prices, less than forecast. The reading fueled hopes that inflation has peaked, and investors welcomed the news ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting. The dollar struggled to recover, with the yen, euro, and pound gaining. Despite the positive start, concerns remain about the US economy potentially tipping into recession next year due to elevated interest rates.

site_title: Festive F&B demand dampened by Singaporeans flying out
summary: Singapore's food and beverage industry sees a rise in corporate and tourist demand for year-end celebrations, with bookings for groups of 200-300 people coming in on a weekly basis. Despite a doubling of business in December compared to last year, F&B players expect a potential slowdown due to locals traveling abroad. The industry's manpower crunch is gradually improving, but businesses still struggle to cater to increased demand. Long-running challenges, including a lack of trained staff, remain. F&B players prepare for the festive season, with some offering special packages and promotions to attract customers.

images.alt_text: Industry players and market watchers said rising inflation, rental costs and the ongoing manpower crunch are pushing some F&B players to exit the market or seek out strategic partners for support.
Compared to last year, retail brands have expanded their range of products and stocked up on inventory in preparation for the holiday shopping season.

site_title: UAE funds to buy US$855m stake in Israeli financial firm
summary: ABU Dhabi Developmental Holding Company (ADQ) and its partners are in talks to buy a 25-30% stake in Phoenix Group, an Israeli financial services firm, for $855 million. The deal is part of the UAE's efforts to improve economic relations with Israel, following the two countries' 2020 diplomatic agreement. This move comes as other UAE-based companies, such as Mubadala Investment and G42, have invested in Israeli ventures, including natural gas fields and AI development. The deal is expected to further strengthen economic ties between the two countries.

images.alt_text: From a regional hub in Singapore, the bank covers countries such as Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines where de Sanctis sees “very, very attractive” business opportunities.
Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund and Dubai businessman Mohamed Alabbar sold 2.5 billion shares in Americana Restaurants International.
COP28 – the 28th session of the United Nations Climate Change Conference – will take place in the UAE in 2023, one of the top producers of oil in the world.

site_title: Acra, Ipos seek views on new framework for disclosing non-physical company assets
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) and Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (Ipos) are seeking public views on a new framework to disclose non-physical company assets, including technologies, brand recognition, and intellectual property. The framework aims to enhance transparency and facilitate the commercialization of intangible assets, potentially boosting access to financing. The public consultation will run from December 14, 2022, to February 28, 2023.

site_title: Condo, HDB leasing volumes fall as November rentals climb: SRX, 99.co
summary: Residential leasing volumes in Singapore declined in November, with condo rentals rising 2% month-over-month and 34% year-over-year, driven by the Outside Central Region. HDB rentals also increased, 1.6% from October 2022 and 27.8% on a year-on-year basis. The decline in leasing transactions may be attributed to holiday periods and a diminishing rental stock. Experts predict a potential slowdown in rental demand due to high rates, but some expect landlords to pass increased property taxes to tenants, leading to continued rental growth, albeit at a slower clip.

images.alt_text: Resale prices continue to trend upwards in November, show flash figures from SRX and 99.co.
The majority of HDB residents will pay between S$30 and $70 more in property tax after rebate in 2023, said the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore on Friday (Dec 2).
Photo by Yen Meng Jiin. Generic pictures of properties in Singapore
The Lentor Modern condominium is one of many new launches this year that commanded psf prices of above S$2,100.
HDB rents for October increased by 1.8 per cent from the previous month, with mature and non-mature estate rents rising by 1.6 per cent and 2.1 per cent respectively.
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.

site_title: Capital A’s logistics arm announces US$50m capital raise
summary: Teleport, the logistics arm of Capital A, has raised US$50 million in new growth capital from large institutional investors. The funds will be used to induct additional freighters, build critical hubs in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Malaysia, and further invest in technology. Teleport aims to extend its network of coverage by air over the next three years and connect manufacturers, exporters, and e-commerce directly to any South-east Asian market. The company has quadrupled its intra-South-east Asian market share to 9% and grown its e-commerce business by six times year on year.

images.alt_text: Capital A posted an operating loss of 491.3 million ringgit (S$153.3 million) for the 3 months ended June 30, compared to a loss of 792.2 million ringgit in the year-ago period.
A321 freighters are converted from passenger aircraft into dedicated cargo carriers.
AirAsia unit Teleport backs Indonesian trucking startup Kargo
AirAsia changes name to Capital A as it grows beyond an airline

site_title: How sexism influenced corporate governance
summary: A Stanford Law Review article by Sarah Haan argues that sexism has had a lasting impact on corporate governance, dating back to the early 20th century when many women owned shares in companies like AT&T and General Electric. Despite being outnumbered, women were often viewed as passive shareholders who couldn't discipline company management. This led to a shift from shareholder-led governance to market-based discipline, where executives prioritize stock prices over shareholder concerns. Haan contends that this legacy of sexism has persisted, with women still underrepresented on corporate boards and ordinary shareholders often overlooked in decision-making.

images.alt_text: More women and fewer long-serving IDs on Singapore listed companies' boards: report
That's a message that more companies will need to accept, with new Hong Kong stock exchange rules creating more than 1,300 director positions exclusively for women by the end of 2024.
Suntory recently ran a week-long pop-up store featuring its non-alcoholic drinks in the salaryman hub of Shimbashi in Tokyo.

site_title: Japan’s ruling party agrees to raise taxes to boost defence, says official
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party has agreed to raise corporate, tobacco, and special income taxes to boost the country's defense budget. The plan aims to double defense spending to 2% of GDP within five years to address China, North Korea, and Russia. However, the party's decision on using tax hikes was split, with some lawmakers opposing the move. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aims to secure 1 trillion yen by March 2028 through tax hikes, while the government plans to use other non-tax revenue and foreign reserves to fund the defense budget.

images.alt_text: “Fundamentally strengthening our defence capabilities is the most urgent challenge in this severe security environment,” Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said at the weekend.
Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has pledged 43 trillion yen in defence outlays over the period to fiscal 2027.
Shunichi Suzuki, Japan's finance minister, speaks during a budget committee session at the upper house of parliament in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Dec 1, 2022.

site_title: JGB yields fall on hopes for slower Fed rate hike
summary: Japanese government bond yields fell on Wednesday, tracking US Treasury yields lower, as inflation data raised optimism for a slower pace of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The 20-year JGB yield fell 2 basis points to 1.065%, and the 30-year JGB yield fell 2 basis points to 1.380%. Investors are betting that the Bank of Japan will tweak its ultra-rate policy, contributing to the decline in yields. This marks the second consecutive day of falls in yields on Japanese super-long notes, which have been declining since their peak in October.

images.alt_text: The BOJ ramped up bond purchases so far this year to the most since 2017, in a bid to fend off speculative attacks on its curve control policy.

site_title: MAS bans ex-Great Eastern agent for cheating clients of S$58,000
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued an 8-year prohibition order against Selvarajulu Subramaniam, a former insurance agent with Great Eastern Life Assurance, for cheating clients of S$58,000. Subramaniam was convicted of four cheating charges and sentenced to 1 year and 5 months in jail. The ban prohibits him from providing financial advisory services, managing firms, or taking part in insurance intermediary management. He is also barred from continuing business as an insurance intermediary and managing insurance intermediaries.

images.alt_text: MAS said that Han will not be allowed to provide any financial advisory service and is barred from taking part in the management, whether as a director, or as a substantial shareholder of any financial advisory firm.

site_title: The art teacher who showed the world China's protests
summary: A Chinese art teacher, known as "Teacher Li," became a key source of information on social media about the country's protests against Beijing's zero-Covid policy. Despite facing threats and censorship, he shared real-time videos and information from citizen journalists on the ground, garnering over 830,000 followers on Twitter. His actions helped amplify the voices of protesters, who demanded answers and concessions from the government. China's government eventually rolled back the harshest zero-Covid restrictions, a rare concession to public frustration. Li's actions have been praised for giving a platform to the Chinese people and bringing attention to their struggles.

images.alt_text: While China has not announced that the health codes will be scrapped, several cities have said that residents are no longer required to show these codes when entering shops and restaurants.

site_title: Refreshed industry map to support Singapore’s hub status in food manufacturing
summary: Singapore's food manufacturing sector has unveiled its refreshed Industry Transformation Map (ITM) 2025, aiming to establish the country as a trusted food and nutrition leader and regional hub. The map outlines four key strategies: internationalisation and innovation, increasing attractiveness as a regional food hub, building resilient and sustainable companies, and pursuing job redesign, upskilling, and reskilling. The sector also plans to automate 80% of its processes by 2023, with the goal of increasing production efficiency. The move is expected to create 2,500 new jobs and enhance employees' competitiveness and capabilities.

images.alt_text: (From left) Janice Lee, event director for hospitality, food and beverage at Informa Markets, Singapore; Angeline Chan, director of food services at Enterprise Singapore; Ian Roberts, vice-president of Informa Markets, Asia; Alvin Tan, MOS for Ministry of Trade and Industry and Culture, Community and Youth; Yap Chin Siang, deputy chief executive of STB; Kwee Wei-Lin, president of SHA; and David Tan, president of Singapore Food Manufacturers' Association are at the opening ceremony of Food & Hotel Asia (FHA) - Hotel, Restaurant and Café 2022.

At ITAP 2022, DPM Heng announced an investment into a new semiconductor materials centre, green commitments, the launch of a handbook for talent attraction and retention and five refreshed industry transformation maps (ITMs).

site_title: IMF declines to testify to UK MPs over mini-budget intervention
summary: The UK Parliament has asked International Monetary Fund (IMF) officials to testify about a statement they made urging former Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng to re-evaluate his tax-cutting "Growth Plan" shortly before it imploded. The IMF declined, citing its engagement with governments and parliamentarians during the annual UK check-up. The statement, made on September 27, also criticized the plan's potential to increase inequality and advised against large, un-targeted fiscal packages.
