pixgeneric / generic pictures of SGX [Singapore Exchange] at 2 Shenton Way, Singapore 068804.
Picture taken on 15 Feb 2019 at 2 Shenton Way, Singapore 068804.

On a year-to-date total return basis, S-Reits have seen a 10.9 per cent decline, against the Straits Times Index’s 9.6 per cent gain, while the FTSE EPRA Nareit Developed Index has seen a decline of 21.1 per cent.
Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) received net inflows of S$9 million and S$39 million from institutional and retail investors respectively.
Retail investors have been a key driver in the locally-listed Reit ETFs for the past year, accounting for 44 per cent of Reit ETF holdings.

site_title: Investors see returns in depressed Asian dollar bonds, but risks too
summary: Investors are cautiously returning to Asian dollar bond markets, driven by China's property measures and easing pandemic controls, which have sparked some risk-taking. Despite the rebound, investors remain wary of risks, including defaults and a global recession, and are opting for higher-yielding high-yield bonds. Investment-grade bonds are also gaining traction, with Morgan Stanley predicting a 9.8% return in Asia next year. Investors are focusing on sectors like infrastructure, renewables, and asset management companies in China and India, and are adopting conservative strategies with shorter maturities.

images.alt_text: Rupiah sovereign notes reeled in US$467 million on Monday, the largest one-day inflow since August 2021.

site_title: Indonesia to produce Merck’s HPV vaccines to combat cervical cancer
summary: Indonesia's state-owned pharmaceutical company Bio Farma has signed a deal with Merck to produce the company's HPV vaccines, aiming to combat cervical cancer in the country. Cervical cancer is the fourth-most common cancer among women globally, with 90% of new cases and deaths occurring in low- and middle-income countries. Indonesia reported over 36,000 cervical cancer deaths in 2021, with the Bio Farma-Merck deal expected to stem the number of cases.

site_title: BlackRock’s top bet is shunning sovereign bonds in all scenarios
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, has shifted its stance on long-term sovereign bonds, advising against them due to expected inflation to outpace central bank targets. The firm's top conviction is to avoid nominal long-term government bonds, citing policymakers' deliberate actions to cause recessions and engineer inflation to policy targets. BlackRock prefers inflation-linked bonds to protect its portfolio, amid a record annual rout in Treasuries and a divided market outlook.

images.alt_text: Following the share purchase, BlackRock currently holds a deemed interest of about 87.7 million Keppel shares.

site_title: Companies can get extra S Pass, work permit quota if they meet criteria on ‘economic priorities’, local workers
summary: Singapore has launched the Manpower for Strategic Economic Priorities (M-SEP) scheme, providing higher foreign worker quotas for companies that contribute to the country's economic priorities through ambitious investment, innovation, or internationalization activities. The scheme allows eligible companies to temporarily hire S Pass and work permit holders above the prevailing dependency ratio ceiling, with a cap of 50 workers per firm. Companies must commit to employing more locals, training them, or meet specific economic criteria to access the additional quotas, which can be renewed for two years.

images.alt_text: In addition to easing manpower shortages by filling lower-wage roles, foreign talent are also sought after to take up top positions and transfer knowledge and resources to Singaporeans.

site_title: UK jobless rate rises again but pay growth will keep Bank of England on edge
summary: The UK's jobless rate rose to 3.7% in October, up from 3.6% in September, as the economy stumbles. However, pay growth remained strong, with basic pay increasing by 6.1% and total pay including bonuses rising by the same amount. Despite this, the Bank of England is likely to raise interest rates for the ninth consecutive meeting, citing ongoing inflationary pressures. Economists predict the rate hike will slow to 50 basis points, but the central bank remains cautious about the economy's prospects.

site_title: IBM partners with Japan’s Rapidus in bid to manufacture advanced chips
summary: IBM and Japan's Rapidus announced a partnership to manufacture the world's most advanced chips in Japan by the second half of the decade. The agreement comes as US-China relations remain tense over chips. Japan aims to catch up on chip manufacturing to support its carmakers and IT companies. IBM will work with Rapidus to produce 2-nanometre-node chips, and the companies will collaborate on research and development. Japan's industry and trade ministry has invested 70 billion yen in Rapidus, with more investments expected.

images.alt_text: The three-country alliance would represent a near-total blockade of China’s ability to buy the equipment necessary to make leading-edge chips.

site_title: Video game hub Japan confronts problem of addiction
summary: Japan is grappling with a growing problem of video game addiction among children, with a recent education ministry survey revealing that 17% of children aged 6-12 spend over four hours daily gaming, up from 9% in 2017. The issue is exacerbated by pandemic restrictions and the industry's lack of action. A support group for parents has been established to share strategies for tackling the issue, while experts recommend addressing underlying problems such as stress and bullying. Japan has not implemented drastic restrictions like China and South Korea, leaving parents to deal with the issue on their own.

site_title: Corporate celebrities : Don’t fall for hype or glib tongues
summary: Successful business founders, such as Bill Gates, Steve Jobs, and Jeff Bezos, have had a greater impact on the world than many Hollywood stars. However, the rise of "celebrity businesspeople" who prioritize marketing and brand creation over genuine innovation and wealth creation has led to the downfall of entrepreneurs like Elizabeth Holmes and Sam Bankman-Fried. These individuals gained fame through media attention and befriending politicians, but ultimately abused the public's trust and violated the law, highlighting the need for investors to be cautious of media narratives that turn potential fraudsters into "genius billionaires".

images.alt_text: Like in the US, legions of people in East Asia were drawn to Sam Bankman-Fried’s righteous nerd-of-the-people veneer.

FILE — Sam Bankman-Fried speaks at the Crypto Bahamas conference in Nassau on April 27, 2022. According to federal campaign records, in the lead-up to the 2022 elections, Bankman-Fried became the Democratic Party’s second largest single donor after George Soros. (Erika P. Rodriguez/The New York Times)
Lawyers for Holmes, 38, filed a single-page notice of appeal late Friday (Dec 2) in federal court in San Jose, California.

site_title: ESR Group proposes listing of logistics assets on Shanghai Stock Exchange
summary: ESR Group proposes listing its three logistics projects, Jiangsu Friend I, II, and III, on the Shanghai Stock Exchange through a publicly offered infrastructure securities fund. The projects have a combined gross floor area of 327,173 square meters and lease expiries in 2054 and 2056. The proposed spin-off aligns with a pilot programme launched by China's National Development and Reform Commission and the China Securities Regulatory Commission. This move is part of ESR Group's expansion into the Chinese market and diversification of its business portfolio.

site_title: Crypto is the cure for, not the cause of, financial shocks
summary: Crypto can help create a sounder financial system by adopting decentralization, immutability, and verifiability principles. The FTX collapse highlights the need for these principles in centralized institutions, which are prone to excesses like fractional reserve banking. Effective regulation and monetary policy are unlikely to work in crypto, as it offers a pathway to transparency and accountability. To take the industry forward, crypto advocates should impose these principles on centralized financial institutions, such as on-chain proof of reserves and automated audits. Despite recent setbacks, crypto has shown resilience, and its adoption rate remains high, with Bitcoin continuing to process transactions and smart contracts.

images.alt_text: Blackrock's CEO Larry Fink has publicly criticised crypto and questioned its utility, but the firm has partnered with Coinbase to let its clients trade bitcoin.
The Bahamas police have arrested former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried, the country’s attorney general said in a statement on Monday.

site_title: How investors can navigate a year of two halves in 2023
summary: Investors can navigate 2023's "year of two halves" by focusing on core asset classes, particularly equities and fixed income, where quality and resilience matter. A volatile bottoming process in the first half will give way to a broad recovery in the second half as inflation decelerates and recessionary pressures kick in. Asset allocation, active management, and security selection are key, with opportunities in high-quality assets, distressed valuations in Hong Kong and China equities, and select consumer firms. Fixed income assets, including US Treasuries and developed-market bonds, are also favored, while equities remain volatile and uncertain.

images.alt_text: Market participants are more neutral on equities in 2023, with expectations for a bumpy ride in markets.

site_title: Shell to divest stake in Malaysia’s Baram Delta for US$475m
summary: Shell to sell its stake in Malaysia's Baram Delta for US$475 million to Petroleum Sarawak Exploration & Production, as part of its strategy to focus and increase resilience in its upstream business. The sale is contingent on commodity prices and will be completed by early 2023. Shell holds a 40% and 50% stake in the Baram Delta EOR and SK 307 production sharing contracts, which will be transferred to Petronas Carigali, the exploration and production arm of Malaysia's state energy company Petronas.

site_title: Singapore marine fuel sales hit 22-month high in Nov
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales reached a 22-month high in November, with 4.37 million tonnes sold, up 3% month-on-month and 4% year-on-year. Despite lower vessel arrivals, the higher sales were driven by lower prices, incentivizing shippers to buy more fuel. Low-sulphur marine fuel oil sales increased 6% to 2.75 million tonnes, while high-sulphur marine fuel oil sales dipped 5% to 1.25 million tonnes. The trend is expected to continue as prices remain competitive with other regional ports.

images.alt_text: Interested parties may visit either EMA or MPA’s websites to view the EOI document and submit their proposals by 11.59pm on Apr 30, 2023.

site_title: Biggest merger to shake up India debt market as top seller exits
summary: India's largest merger, between Housing Development Finance (HDFC) and HDFC Bank, is expected to create a $200 billion financial services behemoth. The merger will allow HDFC to tap into the bank's deposits instead of accumulating more debt, potentially reducing its issuance of bonds in the rupee market. The exit of HDFC, India's largest bond seller in 2022, may initially hurt debt sales and arrangement fees for banks, but could lead to new borrowers tapping the market and helping to deepen India's debt market.

images.alt_text: Sectors such as renewable energy and retail are set to benefit as India pulls ahead of emerging market rivals in attracting overseas investors.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals dip from post-Covid record to 816,254 in November
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals declined to 816,254 in November, down from October's record 816,758. This marks a slight break in a nine-month growth streak. Analysts attribute the drop to historical trends and global economic headwinds, with flight capacity being a major challenge. Despite this, they expect growth in December and anticipate a recovery driven by China's relaxation of Covid restrictions.

images.alt_text: The resumption of tourism from the mainland would be a boon for Hong Kong’s economy, which has been hobbled by more than two years of Covid-related border restrictions.
Most economists predict the RBA will hike another one or two times from the current 3.1 per cent cash rate, with the peak seen at 3.6 per cent.
Singapore saw 816,758 international visitor arrivals in October, setting yet another monthly record since the start of the pandemic.

site_title: ChildAid returns triumphant as a full-scale concert
summary: ChildAid 2022, a full-scale concert after two years of staging restrictions, was a resounding success, raising over S$2 million for its two charities. The event, featuring a diverse range of music genres, was attended by 1,400-strong audience at the University Cultural Centre in Kent Ridge. The concert, now in its 18th year, has raised over S$27 million for underprivileged children, providing arts courses and school pocket money assistance.

images.alt_text: Dancers from Jitterbugs Swingapore.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,253.14 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 35, with Sembcorp Marine and Singtel gaining 1.4% and 0.4% respectively. US stocks surged on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 1.6%. The gains followed cautious optimism ahead of key inflation data and a Federal Reserve meeting.

images.alt_text: Recession woes ahead of US Fed meeting and release of inflation data out of the world's largest economy weighed on trading sentiments

site_title: Asia: Markets extend US rally ahead of inflation, Fed decision
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, driven by a US rally ahead of key inflation data and a Federal Reserve policy decision, despite ongoing uncertainty. China's shift away from its zero-Covid policy offered support, while oil prices surged due to expected demand boosts. The Fed is expected to lift interest rates 50 basis points on Wednesday, with analysts debating the pace of future rate hikes. Markets await the Fed's post-meeting statement and comments from Jerome Powell, which could impact policy expectations for 2023.

site_title: China-HK to start quarantine-free travel in January: report
summary: China and Hong Kong are set to resume quarantine-free travel starting January, with travel possible as early as January 9, according to a report from HK01. China will require visitors from Hong Kong to undergo three days of home monitoring. The resumption of tourism is expected to boost Hong Kong's economy by an estimated 7.6% due to increased exports and tourism income, according to Goldman Sachs economists.

images.alt_text: Xi’s goal of raising the nation’s per-capita GDP to the level of a medium-developed country by 2035 would require annual growth rates at 5 per cent or higher through 2030.

site_title: Thai Airways in talks to add some 20 twin-aisle jets to fleet
summary: Thai Airways is in talks with Boeing and Airbus to add 20 twin-aisle passenger jets to its fleet, as part of a US$5.3 billion debt rehabilitation plan. The airline, which has already reduced its workforce and 40% of its fleet, aims to revive flights quickly amid a travel rebound in South-east Asia. Thai Airways plans to issue new shares next year to raise 25 billion baht, and has obtained regulatory approval to increase its registered capital. The airline is also considering temporarily bringing back six Airbus A380s from 2024.

images.alt_text: Thai Airways is looking at codesharing SIA’s flight services in South Africa, US and Canada.

site_title: Gas producers warn Australian supply at risk under price cap plan
summary: Australia's largest natural gas producers have warned that the government's plan to cap gas prices at A$12 per gigajoule could deter investment in new supply, rather than meeting energy security goals. Global major Shell has paused accepting bids for gas under a plan to boost supply for Australia's east coast in 2023 and 2024 while assessing the government's proposal. The government's proposed "reasonable pricing" regime would set gas prices at production costs plus an agreed profit margin after a one-year price cap expires, raising concerns among producers.

site_title: Hong Kong scraps virus tracing app, curbs on arrivals
summary: Hong Kong has lifted its COVID-19 tracing app requirement for residents to enter venues and relaxed curbs on overseas arrivals, allowing them to visit bars and restaurants immediately upon arrival. The move, announced by Chief Executive John Lee, comes after mainland China retired its own tracking app and follows Hong Kong's lighter version of China's zero-COVID strategy. The city still maintains some restrictions, including widespread face mask use and a ban on gatherings of more than 12 people, with travel between Hong Kong and the mainland largely closed.

site_title: Nomura to hire bankers in Dubai for Middle East wealth push
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to expand its wealth management services in Dubai, hiring 5-10 relationship managers to tap into the growing pool of rich clients in the Middle East. Led by Adil Khan, the business will focus on serving families doing business in the Indian subcontinent and other areas. The move aims to capitalize on Dubai's growing importance as a financial hub, similar to Singapore and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Nomura’s launch of its digital-assets arm in September.

site_title: Gold steady on caution ahead of US CPI, Fed meet
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,781.66 per ounce ahead of US inflation data and the Federal Reserve's policy decision. Investors maintained caution, shifting focus to the US consumer price index report for November. The US central bank is expected to hike interest rates by 50 basis points, which tends to benefit gold prices. Goldman Sachs predicts gold will outperform bitcoin in the long term due to its real demand drivers. Spot silver, platinum, and palladium also remained unchanged or flat.

images.alt_text: Gold premiums in China rose last week as demand picked up after the top consumer eased Covid-19 restrictions, while high prices muted activity in India.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust acquiring Chennai site to develop 19.4b rupee data centre
summary: CapitaLand India Trust is acquiring a 4.01-acre site in Chennai, India for approximately 832.8 million rupees to develop its third data centre, with a planned completion by 2025. The project, valued at 19.4 billion rupees, will be funded through debt and internal resources. The facility is expected to have a 55 megawatt power capacity and host approximately 4,900 racks, catering to global technology giants and large enterprise clients. The acquisition is part of the trust's strategy to diversify into India's growing data centre market.

images.alt_text: In addition to the data centre in Chennai, CapitaLand India Trust will be developing a data centre in Navi, Mumbai (pictured).

site_title: Australia sues former Star Entertainment CEO, chairman for money laundering risk lapses
summary: Australia's corporate regulator is suing 11 current and former directors and officers of Star Entertainment Group, including former CEO Matthias Bekier and chairman John O'Neill, for failing to manage money-laundering risks. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission alleges the board members approved relationships with individuals with criminal links and knowingly permitted misleading statements to be made to a bank. The lawsuit carries maximum penalties of A$1,050,000 each and follows recent penalties and fines imposed on Star Entertainment, including A$100 million in Queensland and A$100 million in New South Wales.

site_title: Real estate platform Ohmyhome expects to raise over US$14.6m in IPO
summary: Singapore-based real estate platform Ohmyhome has filed for a US initial public offering (IPO) aiming to raise over US$14.6 million. The company, co-founded by sisters Rhonda and Race Wong, plans to use the funds for market expansion, research and development, repaying loans, and working capital. There are no plans to pay out dividends on ordinary shares, and earnings will be channeled into business operation and growth. The IPO filing was made under Ohmyhome Ltd's Cayman-Island-incorporated entity, with shares to be issued at between US$4 and US$5.

images.alt_text: The Finra said in its statement last week that it, the NYSE and Nasdaq have observed potential “pump-and-dump-like schemes” in certain small IPOs on US exchanges

site_title: Sony PlayStation 5 sales surge in US as supply woes ease
summary: Sony's PlayStation 5 sales surged in the US, with a 45% increase in November to $1.3 billion, driven by easing supply chain issues. The company is now assembling consoles at a faster rate, and retailers are processing orders without requiring a store-issued credit card. This marks a significant improvement in the console's availability, which has lagged demand since its launch two years ago. Sony's improved supply has contributed to the PS5 being the best-selling hardware platform in November, according to NPD Group.

images.alt_text: Sony said in early November that shortages of PlayStation 5 consoles are easing as Covid-related chip and logistics snarls end. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH initiates coverage on Sea with ‘hold’
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on Sea Ltd with a "hold" call and a target price of US$58.77, citing concerns over slower growth in Sea's digital entertainment and e-commerce segments. The brokerage remains doubtful that the company's cost rationalising exercises will improve profitability, citing potential headwinds for Garena and cautions on Shopee's profitability. The move follows Sea's 50% share price recovery after a narrower-than-expected net loss in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: The app of Indonesian e-commerce company Bukalapak, which is among the unicorns that have suffered share price drops. The shares of Bukalapak and Singapore-based Grab Holdings have fallen more than 65 per cent since their IPOs.
Sea’s gaming segment remains the sole weak spot in the group’s latest set of financial results, notes CGS-CIMB.

site_title: Japan is set to boost limit on tax-free investment accounts
summary: Japan plans to increase the annual limit on tax-free investment accounts to 1.2 million yen (S$11,769) and the lifetime limit to 18 million yen (S$176,976), effective January 2024. The revamped Nisa system will also abolish existing time limits on tax exemptions and permit the use of both types of accounts simultaneously. The move aims to boost people's incomes from financial assets and buoy the stock market, potentially benefiting financial firms.

site_title: Bank of America expects US$10b in India green deals in 2023
summary: Bank of America predicts India will attract nearly $10 billion in renewable energy investments in 2023, driven by the country's clear targets to achieve net zero carbon and geopolitical stability. The lender expects sectors like renewable energy, retail, and electric vehicles to benefit, as well as consumer brands and so-called "friend-shoring" by companies rethinking their supply chains. However, initial public offerings (IPOs) in India are expected to remain sluggish, with large listings not expected until the end of 2023 or into 2024.

images.alt_text: The second-largest US lender will incur a US$354 million expense for the settlement when it reports third-quarter earnings on Oct 17.

site_title: US: Stocks soar ahead of inflation data and Federal Reserve meeting
summary: US stocks surged ahead of inflation data and a Federal Reserve meeting, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 1.6% to 34,005.04 and the S&P 500 rising 1.4% to 3,990.56 on Monday. Investors are optimistic about slowing inflation and a potential smaller interest rate hike by the US central bank. Positive news included a survey showing decreasing inflation expectations and a major biopharmaceutical deal. Markets are cautiously optimistic, with the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index also rising 1.3%.

site_title: UK manufacturers are sitting on a £24b pile of unfinished goods
summary: UK manufacturers have £24 billion worth of unfinished goods due to persistent supply shortages. 72% of 631 companies surveyed cited lack of components, materials, or ingredients as the main reason. Steel, food, plastics, and electronics are the most affected categories. The issues are attributed to the pandemic, Brexit, China's lockdowns, Russia's war in Ukraine, and the pound's weakness. Despite supply chain challenges, nearly 60% of respondents expect little change in the next six months. Labour shortages remain, with over 250,000 job openings.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to stop making unsecured consumer loans: source
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to stop originating unsecured consumer loans, a move following the scaling back of its consumer business and job cuts. The decision comes after the bank reorganized its main business units and moved Marcus, its loss-making consumer unit, into the wealth management arm. The bank also plans to cut at least 500 jobs, with some reports suggesting up to 1,000 positions may be eliminated. This move is seen as another sign the bank is stepping back from its consumer business amid worsening economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Goldman is doing due diligence on a number of different crypto firms and sees some really interesting opportunities, priced much more sensibly.

site_title: Singapore’s F&B space could see uptick in M&A activity; more businesses up for sale or seeking growth capital
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) space is expected to see an uptick in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity due to rising inflation, rental, and labor costs. Industry players are selling their businesses or seeking growth capital to reduce debt. Several acquisitions have been made in recent months, including the sale of Rive Gauche Patisserie to Muginoho Global and Sun Venture taking full ownership of PSGourmet. Strategic equity partners are being sought to reduce debt and invest in technology solutions to increase efficiency.

images.alt_text: A PS.Cafe outlet at Raffles City. The PSGourmet group's brands include nine PS.Cafe outlets and neighbourhood gourmet PS.Cafe Petit.

site_title: Queues at fever clinics as China wrestles with Covid surge
summary: China is grappling with a Covid-19 surge, with fever clinics seeing a 16-fold increase in visitors, and authorities struggling to contain the spread. The government has relaxed testing requirements and ended a state-mandated mobile app tracking residents, but experts warn of an imminent surge in contagion. With the Omicron strain not causing long-term damage, some analysts remain optimistic, but others fear the fragile health system and businesses may be severely impacted, leading to a slow economic recovery.

images.alt_text: A Covid-19 testing booth in Shanghai, China. The country's watchdog is banning activities including price inflation, collusion, price discrimination, misleading propaganda and hoarding.

site_title: World Cup: Messi ‘fool’ taunt spawns mugs, T-shirts in Argentina
summary: Argentina fans are celebrating Lionel Messi's World Cup quarter-final taunt of Dutch player Wout Weghorst, with the phrase "What are you looking at, fool? Get lost!" appearing on various products, including mugs, T-shirts, and caps. The phrase has drawn comparisons to Diego Maradona, a legendary Argentine soccer player known for his fiery moments. Despite Fifa opening disciplinary proceedings against both teams, the phrase has become a source of national pride in Argentina, with many fans finding it "innocent and tender" compared to the usual language in Argentine sports.

images.alt_text: Croatia's Bruno Petkovic during training, Doha, Qatar, Dec 11, 2022.
The websites were shut down after a Fifa representative identified sites being used to distribute copyright-infringing content without the authorisation of the soccer world governing body.

site_title: Microsoft’s offer to Sony for Call of Duty includes subscription service
summary: Microsoft has offered Sony a 10-year deal to make Call of Duty available on the Japanese company's PlayStation console as part of its gaming subscription service, Xbox Game Pass. The proposal includes rights to sell the title on PlayStation Plus. The move aims to win regulatory approval for Microsoft's US$69 billion purchase of Activision Blizzard, which the FTC is seeking to block due to concerns over Microsoft's dominance in the gaming market.

images.alt_text: Microsoft president Brad Smith tweeted: “our acquisition will bring Call of Duty to more gamers and more platforms than ever before ... Any day @Sony wants to sit down and talk, we’ll be happy to hammer out a 10-year deal for PlayStation as well”

site_title: Citi to cut as many as 50 bankers in EMEA: sources
summary: Citi is cutting up to 50 bankers in the Europe, Middle East, and Africa region, according to sources. The move is attributed to a decline in dealmaking, caused by the Ukraine war, higher interest rates, and soaring inflation. Citi employs around 6,000 people globally and the majority of the cuts will affect director roles, with some managing directors also set to exit. This move follows a 64% year-on-year decline in investment banking revenues in the third quarter.

site_title: Gold is better portfolio diversifier than Bitcoin: Goldman Sachs
summary: Gold is expected to outperform Bitcoin as a portfolio diversifier due to its real demand drivers and lesser influence from financial conditions. Goldman Sachs notes that gold has non-speculative use cases, while Bitcoin's value proposition relies on speculative growth. The bank forecasts tighter financial conditions, which may negatively impact Bitcoin's volatility, but gold's exposure to real demand drivers such as Asian consumer buying and safe-haven investments may benefit it. As a result, gold is marginally up year on year against Bitcoin's 75% decline.

images.alt_text: Gold premiums in China rose last week as demand picked up after the top consumer eased Covid-19 restrictions, while high prices muted activity in India.

site_title: White House says Musk’s condemnation of Fauci is ‘dangerous,’ ’disgusting’
summary: White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre condemned Elon Musk's public criticism of top US health official Anthony Fauci, calling it "dangerous" and "disgusting." Fauci has faced criticism for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, but Jean-Pierre praised his handling of public health crises. Fauci plans to retire in December, but has faced death threats and criticism from Republicans. Musk's tweet "My pronouns are Prosecute/Fauci" sparked a response from his own post, adding "Truth resonates."

site_title: Resilience among the storm clouds
summary: A global downturn in 2023 is becoming increasingly likely, with indicators such as the yield curve and the Conference Board Leading Economic Index flashing red. The US Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes are increasing the risk of a hard landing, while Europe faces an economic contraction due to the Ukraine conflict. China, however, is seen as a bright spot, with its reopening and plans to rescue its crisis-ridden property sector expected to mitigate the impact of a global slowdown.

images.alt_text: In 2023, Singapore's growth is likely to be dragged by the trade-related cluster amid weaker external demand., according to Monetary Authority of Singapore's half-yearly macroeconomic review.
A tight labour market may be the biggest inflationary factor. In the US there are roughly 1.7 vacancies for every person registered as unemployed.

epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Australia’s consumer sentiment improves from ‘disastrous’ drop
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment has rebounded from a 2-1/2-year low, rising 3% to 80.3 in December, according to Westpac Banking. This marks a significant improvement from the "disastrous" 6.9% drop in November. Economists predict the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will hike interest rates one or two more times, with the peak at 3.6%, but hopes of a pause in tightening have boosted optimism for house prices and family finances. The RBA's recent rate hikes have hammered consumer confidence, but a return of tourists and international students is bolstering industries like tourism and education.

images.alt_text: The Australian government's decision to cap coal and gas prices for a year is drawing mixed reactions from power producers.

site_title: IMF says global debt well above pre-pandemic levels despite steep 2021 drop
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reported that global debt levels remained above pre-pandemic levels, decreasing by 10 percentage points to 247% of global GDP in 2021. Private debt, driven by a 6 percentage point decrease, was the main contributor to this reduction. However, public debt continued to rise, reaching 96% of GDP, and low-income countries saw their debt ratios increase. The IMF warns that debt dynamics will worsen in 2023 due to forecasted economic declines and rising debt servicing costs, posing repayment concerns for low- and middle-income countries.

images.alt_text: One source close to the matter says that the conditions for an external debt restructuring are the final hurdle, and that an agreement is expected to be reached on Friday.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on fears over rising China Covid-19 cases, await rate decisions
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.5% lower on Monday due to concerns over rising China Covid-19 cases and anticipation of US and European central bank interest rate decisions. The index has fallen 10.4% this year amid tightening monetary policy. Economists expect the European Central Bank to deliver a 50 basis point rate hike on December 15, while US economic data has cooled expectations. Rising Covid-19 cases in China also weighed on industrials and luxury firms, while miners were hit by economic worries in top consumer China.

site_title: US to announce scientific breakthrough on fusion energy
summary: US scientists at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory have achieved a net energy gain in a fusion experiment, marking a significant breakthrough in fusion energy. The process, which powers the sun and stars, has the potential to provide a cheap source of electricity without producing radioactive nuclear waste. If commercialized, fusion energy could offer a game-changer in the energy sector. Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm is set to hold a media briefing on the breakthrough on Tuesday.

site_title: Taylor Swift’s ticketing fiasco shows vulnerability of investing in a monopoly
summary: Taylor Swift's Eras Tour ticketing debacle has sparked outrage towards Live Nation Entertainment, a New York-listed parent company, as an example of an unchecked monopoly. The issue has ignited discussions about investing in a dominant ticketing company, with some speculating it could return enough capital for concert ticket purchases. The controversy highlights the vulnerability of investing in a single, powerful market player.

site_title: Former FTX CEO Bankman-Fried arrested in Bahamas, US to unveil charges
summary: Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried was arrested in the Bahamas on Monday (Dec 12) after being criminally charged by US prosecutors. He is expected to be extradited to the US, where he faces charges related to various financial offenses. Bankman-Fried, 30, founded and led FTX until the cryptocurrency exchange filed for bankruptcy in November after struggling to raise funds. The arrest comes ahead of his scheduled appearance before US lawmakers on Tuesday, where he was set to give testimony via a video link.

images.alt_text: Blackrock's CEO Larry Fink has publicly criticised crypto and questioned its utility, but the firm has partnered with Coinbase to let its clients trade bitcoin.

FILE — Sam Bankman-Fried speaks at the Crypto Bahamas conference in Nassau on April 27, 2022. According to federal campaign records, in the lead-up to the 2022 elections, Bankman-Fried became the Democratic Party’s second largest single donor after George Soros. (Erika P. Rodriguez/The New York Times)
Gold is less likely to be influenced by tighter financial conditions.

site_title: Twitter Blue service is back, including ‘verified’ check marks
summary: Twitter has resumed selling its Twitter Blue premium service, offering a blue verification badge and various colored check marks for different types of accounts. The service, which costs $8/month, will also allow users to edit tweets. Twitter has implemented measures to prevent impersonation, including requiring a valid phone number and temporarily removing verification badges for users who change their name or photo. Users who don't pay for Twitter Blue will lose their verification badges in a few months.

images.alt_text: Twitter is facing a growing number of lawsuits over the terms of employees' terminations.

site_title: Japan to join US effort to tighten chip exports to China
summary: Japan and the Netherlands are set to join the US in tightening controls over the export of advanced chipmaking machinery to China, a move that would represent a near-total blockade of Beijing's ability to buy equipment necessary to make leading-edge chips. The three-country alliance aims to prevent China's military from obtaining advanced semiconductors. The US restrictions, announced in October, restricted the supply from American gear suppliers, and Japan and the Netherlands will adopt similar measures, potentially crippling China's technology ambitions.

images.alt_text:
If fusion is commercialised, it will produce 
energy without radioactive nuclear waste that today’s fission reactors produce.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand India Trust, SIA, Soilbuild
summary: SIA adjusts convertible bond prices to S$5.6309 and S$4.7453, effective Dec 13. CapitaLand India Trust acquires a freehold site in Ambattur, Chennai, for 832.8 million rupees to develop its third data centre in India, estimated to cost 19.4 billion rupees over four to five years. Soilbuild Construction Group clinches S$140.4 million in new contracts, bringing its total order book to S$492.7 million.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Singapore Airlines planes sit on the tarmac at Changi Airport in Singapore December 8, 2020.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Microsoft to buy minor stake in London Stock Exchange
summary: Microsoft is acquiring a 4% stake in the London Stock Exchange Group worth £1.5 billion, while LSEG will commit to spending at least US$2.8 billion on cloud-related services. The partnership focuses on next-generation data and analytics and cloud infrastructure solutions, including artificial intelligence. The tie-up aims to boost revenue growth and further integrate Refinitiv, a US financial data provider. LSEG shares rose 2.7% following the announcement, giving the company a stock market capitalization of approximately £37.3 billion.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit by Washington follows an intervention by the European Union, which opened an in-depth probe into the transaction over its concerns that the deal would see Activision Blizzard’s popular games become exclusive to Microsoft, the maker of the Xbox console.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz Vans plans first electric-only plant in Poland
summary: Mercedes-Benz Vans plans to build its first electric-only van plant in Jawor, Poland, pending government approval. The plant will be the fourth in the company's European van production network and will produce vans on the VAN.EA platform. A joint venture with US electric van maker Rivian to produce electric vans in Poland is no longer planned due to Rivian's shift in focus. The investment is part of Mercedes-Benz's reorganization towards producing only fully-electric vans.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as investors await CPI data, Fed decision
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as investors awaited inflation data and the Federal Reserve's policy decision later this week to gauge the US economic outlook amid recession concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 43.04 points, or 0.13%, to 33,519.50. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 4.91 and 10.86 points, respectively. The market awaits the inflation data and Fed decision to assess the US economic outlook.

site_title: Tata Motors looks to sell part stake in Tata Technologies via IPO
summary: Tata Motors plans to sell a portion of its stake in Tata Technologies through an initial public offering (IPO). The proposed IPO could be the automaker's first in years. Tata Technologies, a product engineering and digital services company, was previously owned by Tata Motors with a 74.43% stake. The company's sales have driven a 46% jump in Tata Motors' revenue from other operations. This move comes after Tata Motors previously called off a deal to sell a 43% stake in Tata Technologies to Warburg Pincus in 2018.

site_title: Bored-Ape NFT investors are suing Bieber, Madonna and other celebrity promoters
summary: Celebrities such as Justin Bieber, Madonna, and Paris Hilton are being sued by Bored-Ape NFT investors who claim they were misled into buying the collectibles by celebrities who were paid to promote them. The investors allege that the celebrities' endorsements artificially increased the interest and price of the NFTs, causing them to purchase the collectibles at inflated prices. The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles federal court, accuses Yuga Labs, Guy Oseary, and MoonPay USA of engaging in a promotional campaign that generated billions of dollars in sales.

images.alt_text: Brian Gothong Tan's series of NFTs includes this work titled Cosmic Embryo.

site_title: China to set economic plans amid shift from Covid Zero to growth
summary: China's abrupt end to its Covid Zero policy is expected to inject uncertainty into the economy, raising the prospect of looser fiscal and monetary policy to bolster growth. The Communist Party's new Politburo is set to discuss policy objectives, including a potential target for next year's growth, at the Central Economic Work Conference. Economists predict an annual growth rate of 5% or higher through 2030 to achieve President Xi Jinping's goal of raising per-capita GDP to a medium-developed country by 2035. The conference may also discuss easing in the property market and monetary and fiscal policy to stimulate growth.

images.alt_text: Xi JinpingPhotographer: Justin Chin/Bloomberg

site_title: Bali governor says new Indonesian sex laws pose no risk to tourists
summary: Bali Governor Wayan Koster has reassured tourists that Indonesia's newly ratified criminal code poses no risk to them, stating that the laws can only be prosecuted with a complaint from a parent, spouse, or child. The revised laws, which include provisions against sex outside marriage and cohabitation between unmarried couples, will not impact tourists, and the governor has vowed to ensure there will be no checks on marital status at tourism accommodations.

images.alt_text: Activists holding a protest against the new criminal code outside Parliament building in Jakarta. The UN is concerned that several articles in the revised Criminal Code contravene Indonesia’s international legal obligations with respect to human rights.
People enjoy the beach during sunset in Jimbaran, Bali, Indonesia, September 2, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower at start of week as rate hike bets weigh; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,239.66, tracking losses on Wall Street and ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting. Recession woes and expected 50-basis-point interest rate hikes by the Fed weigh on the market. Analysts predict significant downward market risk through December and possibly 2023 due to a slowing US and global economy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led the way lower, having surged last week, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Jakarta and Wellington were also in the red.
Chinese stocks are now moving by 5 per cent a day more frequently than at any time since the global market meltdown of 2008.

site_title: Slowing growth, elevated inflation: Investment themes to watch for next year
summary: Market participants expect a bumpy ride for equities in 2023, with inflation remaining elevated. However, investors' focus may shift from interest rates to the state of the global economy. Credit Suisse's Asia-Pacific chief investment officer, John Woods, predicts that inflation will become less of a concern in two quarters' time, as the focus will be on decelerating growth. This shift in attention could impact investment themes, with a focus on the global economy and its implications for markets.

site_title: US seizes 55 websites for illegally live-streaming World Cup
summary: The US Justice Department has seized 55 websites for illegally live-streaming World Cup matches without FIFA's authorization, a move aimed at protecting the soccer world governing body's intellectual property rights. A Fifa representative identified the sites, which were shut down to prevent copyright infringement and potential conduit to other forms of criminal activity. The seized websites will redirect visitors to another site for additional information.

site_title: Oracle sales top estimates on growth at Cerner health-records unit
summary: Oracle reported quarterly sales that exceeded estimates, with sales increasing 18% to $12.3 billion, driven by strong growth from its Cerner digital health records unit. Cloud revenue rose 43% to $3.8 billion, with the segment producing 45% year-over-year growth in the prior quarter. The company's acquisition of Cerner contributed to the growth, with $1.5 billion in revenue generated in the quarter. Oracle's stock gained 2% in extended trading, marking its 33% rise since September, outperforming the S&P 500 Information Technology Index.

images.alt_text: Oracle Corp. headquarters stands in Redwood City, California, U.S., on Saturday, June 15, 2013. Oracle Corp. is expected to release earnings data on June 20. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Jin from BTS begins military service, marking end of an era
summary: BTS star Jin began his mandatory 5-week South Korean military training on Tuesday, marking the start of an era for the K-pop group. As the first member to enlist since their hiatus announcement in June, Jin will be deployed to a "frontline" unit near the North Korean border. The group's hiatus, citing exhaustion and pressure, was strategically timed to coincide with the compulsory military duty. Fans are expressing their support and farewell, with some speculating that the group will reunite around 2025 after all members complete their service, which will last until then.

site_title: Oil up US$2/bbl on supply risks amid ongoing Keystone outage
summary: Oil prices rose by about $2 a barrel on Monday, driven by supply concerns amid the ongoing Keystone pipeline outage in the US. Brent crude futures settled at $77.99 a barrel, up 2.5%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 3% to $73.17 a barrel. The pipeline's shutdown is expected to shrink US crude inventories, adding to supply risks. Meanwhile, China's loosening COVID-19 restrictions are expected to boost fuel demand, while Russia threatened to cut production if a price cap is imposed on its exports.

site_title: ‘Avatar’ and ‘Top Gun’ sequels, ‘Elvis’ land Golden Globe nominations
summary: The Golden Globe nominations have been announced for the 2023 ceremony, taking place on January 10. "Avatar: The Way of Water," "Top Gun: Maverick," and "Elvis" are among the contenders for best drama film, competing against "The Fabelmans," "Tar," and "The Banshees of Inisherin." Other nominees include "Everything Everywhere All at Once," "Babylon," and "Triangle of Sadness." The ceremony returns to television after a year off following a diversity and ethics scandal, and will also stream on Peacock.

images.alt_text: The HFPA, which hands out the annual Golden Globe awards for television and film, has formed a special committee to determine “potential outside strategic interest”, it said.

site_title: US dollar eases, but inflation outlook stays high on investors' radar
summary: The US dollar eased on Monday, but its gains were limited by data showing US wholesale inflation rose more than expected last month, potentially keeping interest rates higher for longer. The dollar briefly rose 0.5% against the pound, but its gains were short-lived. Investors remain cautious ahead of key economic data, including US consumer inflation, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions and the dollar's outlook.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was broadly steady against a range of major currencies.

site_title: Customers of payment platform Get complain unable to use cards or withdraw money
summary: Get, a payment platform popular among teenagers, is facing complaints from customers who claim their debit cards are not working and they cannot withdraw money from their accounts. Since October, users have reported issues with transferring funds, receiving "insufficient funds" messages, and account balances being deducted without transfers. Get's founder, Daniel Liang, attributes the issues to Nium, the service provider, and claims the cards will be working soon. However, the company has not posted new content on social media since June, and its licensing status is unclear.

images.alt_text: Spenmo is laying off employees in an effort to push its cash runway past five years.

site_title: China’s credit remains subdued despite PBOC’s lending push
summary: China's credit expanded at a slower pace than expected in November, reaching 2 trillion yuan, despite the People's Bank of China's efforts to boost lending and ease restrictions on property financing. New loans rose to 1.2 trillion yuan, and money supply growth accelerated to 12.4%, but demand for loans remains subdued. The central bank is likely to maintain a loose monetary policy and provide credit support to the economy, with potential for further reductions in benchmark loan prime rates to boost the property sector.

images.alt_text: PBOC Governor Yi Gang says the central bank has a pretty accommodative monetary policy in place to help with economic recovery and to maximise employment.

site_title: Yellen expects US inflation to be much lower by end 2023
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expects US inflation to be much lower by the end of 2023, unless there are unanticipated economic shocks. She cited positive signs, including lower shipping costs and shortened delivery times, and hopes the elevated prices will be "short lived." Yellen expressed confidence in the labor market remaining healthy, allowing people to feel good about their finances. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points in December, with further hikes likely next year, as it aims to bring inflation under control.

images.alt_text: Regulators can both encourage competition and protect consumers largely with existing authorities, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said.

site_title: Dealmakers in last-minute US$70b M&A rush before holidays
summary: A flurry of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) worth nearly $70 billion is being finalized in the US before the holidays, with several major deals announced this week. Amgen is leading the rush, buying Horizon Therapeutics for $28 billion, while Thoma Bravo acquired Coupa Software for $8 billion, and Novozymes acquired Chr Hansen Holding for $12 billion. This late-year activity is a bright spot in a difficult 2022 for M&A, with global deals down by almost a third and Wall Street firms cutting bonuses and headcount.

images.alt_text: Amgen will pay US$116.50 in cash for each Horizon share held, a premium of nearly 20 per cent to the stock’s last close.

site_title: Aramco in talks with investors on US$110b gas project
summary: Saudi Aramco is in talks with investors to secure funding for its $110 billion Jafurah gas development project, one of the world's largest unconventional gas fields. The state-controlled oil producer is seeking equity investors to fund midstream and downstream projects, potentially offering stakes in carbon capture, pipelines, and hydrogen plants. The project, which aims to produce 2 billion standard cubic feet of gas per day by 2030, is part of Saudi Arabia's strategy to diversify its energy exports beyond oil.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco owns 70 per cent of the refinery business while the rest is held by Jadwa nvestment. The offering consists of Jadwa’s sale of its shares in Luberef.

site_title:
SIA to adjust conversion prices of 1.625% 
convertible bonds, MCBs in view of dividend
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has adjusted the conversion prices of its 1.625% convertible bonds due 2025 and zero-coupon mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) due 2030. The adjustments, effective Dec 13, account for the interim dividend of S$0.10 per share announced last month. The conversion prices have been lowered from S$5.743 and S$4.84 to S$5.6309 and S$4.7453, respectively. This move aims to reflect the company's liquidity position and investor interest in its debt offerings.

site_title: China's weekly new home sales rise on easing Covid curbs
summary: China's new home sales rose 4.9% in 16 cities for the week of December 4-10, a 3.8% increase from the previous week, according to the China Index Academy. The growth is attributed to government support policies and easing of Covid-19 restrictions, which have improved consumer sentiment. Analysts believe that more policies are needed to lift confidence, but the sector is slowly recovering. New home sales in Tier-3 cities increased by 45.4% last week, with areas like Beijing, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen experiencing week-on-week growth.

images.alt_text: China’s shadow banking industry is scrambling for new business, including direct investment in companies, family offices and asset management.

site_title: Britain's GDP grew 0.5% in October: statistics office
summary: Britain's GDP grew 0.5% in October, rebounding from a 0.6% decline in September due to the royal funeral. The economy shrank by 0.2% in the third quarter. Car sales and the health sector contributed to the growth, with car sales rebounding after a poor September. The data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) provides a positive note for the British economy, despite previous declines.

images.alt_text: British trade minister Kemi Badenoch, who was appointed to her role in September, will meet Indian Trade Minister Piyush Goyal and address the negotiating teams before the round of talks begins.

The reforms which British finance minister Jeremy Hunt said will “turbocharge” growth in the face of recession and a cost of living crisis, take advantage of Britain’s European Union exit to tailor its own rules.

Britain has been hit hard by a surge in natural gas prices following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, as well as an incomplete labour market recovery after the Covid-19 pandemic and persistently weak investment and productivity.

site_title: Geely's electric car brand Zeekr seeks over US$1b in IPO: sources
summary: Zeekr, Geely's premium electric vehicle brand, has confidentially filed for a US initial public offering (IPO) to raise over $1 billion, seeking a valuation of more than $10 billion. This would be the first major Chinese float in the US in over a year and a half. The IPO comes after the brand's maiden external fundraising last year valued it at around $9 billion.

images.alt_text: The new capital raise, which involves other investors such as Chinese logistics and chemical group Transfar and an investment firm backed by major Chinese investment bank CITIC Securities, came as Geely stepped up its new energy vehicle development.
Zeekr is exploring listing venues including the US and Hong Kong and hasn’t decided on the IPO size.
Geely said its vehicle sales, which fell 9 per cent in the first half, were below management expectations, citing the Covid-19 curbs and shortages of semiconductors.

site_title: Top 10 highlights of ChildAid 2022
summary: The 2022 ChildAid concert, organized by BT and ST, took place on December 12 at the University Cultural Centre, featuring music from BTS, OneRepublic, and ABBA, among others. The event raised money for underprivileged children, with performances by talented young artists, including six-year-old pianist Shalom Shyann-E Ng and 13-year-old whistler Lim Jing Rui. The concert also featured a medley of iconic 80s songs and a musical theatre tribute to Paul and Pasek. The event was streamed live on YouTube channels and aimed to bring the community together in celebration of music and giving back.

site_title: EU chiefs shocked by European Parliament corruption probe
summary: EU foreign ministers expressed shock and dismay over a Belgian investigation into allegations of corruption in the European Parliament, with four people charged and one vice president, Eva Kaili, suspended from duties. Prosecutors seized 600,000 euros in cash and searched 16 houses in Brussels, suspecting a Gulf state of trying to buy influence. The European Parliament is set to look into a proposal to extend visa-free travel to Qatar, amid calls for more oversight of policymaking. The investigation has triggered concerns over the credibility of Europe and the impact on EU-Qatar relations.

site_title: Politically-linked Malaysian stocks rise and fall with new leadership at the helm
summary: Malaysia's stock market saw a surge following the conclusion of the country's 15th general election, with the benchmark Kuala Lumpur Composite Index (KLCI) closing at 1,477.19 points, a 2% increase from the previous day. Stocks with perceived political connections, such as Advance Synergy, Malayan United Industries, and Pan Malaysia Holdings, saw significant gains. Companies linked to newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, including Advance Synergy, surged in share prices, while those associated with former Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin declined. The new government's cabinet appointments also led to significant changes in share prices of companies related to deputy prime ministers Ahmad Zahid Hamidi and Fadillah Yusof.

images.alt_text: We expect Anwar Ibrahim's (centre) new government to be more people-oriented, pushing for more targeted subsidies to help low-income groups, while maintaining or revising some of the key initiatives proposed in the previous Budget 2023.

Malaysia saw its first-ever hung parliament in Saturdays election after none of the three major coalitions won enough seats to form a majority, extending the political crisis in an economy on a fragile rebound.

site_title: Indicators lining up for a strong first-half rally in 2023
summary: A bearish outlook for 2023 is gaining traction, with forecasters predicting a decline in the stock market. However, indicators are pointing to a strong first half of 2023, including a weakening US dollar, a potential short squeeze in US Treasury bonds, and copper's 20% gain since its July bottom. Contrary to recession fears, the International Monetary Fund's research report suggests that higher wages rarely spiral out of control, and the US economy has never entered a recession in the first half of a pre-election year. A strong rally into 2023's first half is possible, with the tech sector potentially underperforming the broader market.

images.alt_text: A Covid-19 testing booth in Shanghai. Government officials signaled a transition away from the harshest Covid containment measures. Recalibration of China's pandemic and property responses signals that economic growth remains an imperative.

site_title: Malaysia’s factory output growth slips to 4.6% in October, below economists’ expectation
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index (IPI) growth for October slowed to 4.6% year-on-year, below economists' expectations of 8.1%. The October IPI fell 3.7% from September's 10.8% growth, reversing the previous month's expansion. The decline was attributed to slower growth in the mining and manufacturing sectors, ending four consecutive months of double-digit growth.

images.alt_text: The electrical and electronics products output has contributed to the growth of Malaysia’s manufacturing sector.

site_title: Malaysia’s Public Bank founder Teh Hong Piow dead at 92
summary: Malaysia's Public Bank founder Teh Hong Piow, 92, died on December 12, 2022, after a peaceful passing. He co-founded the bank in 1965 and served as its non-executive chairman from 2018 to 2019. A banking legend in Malaysia, Teh was the second-largest shareholder and fourth richest person in the country, with an estimated US$5.9 billion in wealth. His passing has been met with condolences from the bank's management and staff, who describe him as a great loss.

site_title: Roche promotes diagnostics head Schinecker to CEO
summary: Roche, a Swiss drugmaker, has appointed Thomas Schinecker as its new group CEO, replacing Severin Schwan, who will become the company's next chairman. Schinecker, who previously led Roche's diagnostics division, will take over effective after the annual general meeting on March 14, 2023. This change comes as Bill Anderson, CEO of the pharmaceuticals division, will leave the company on December 31. The moves aim to maintain strategic weight in both diagnostics and pharmaceuticals businesses, according to Schwan.

site_title: Can Europe’s energy bridge to Russia ever be rebuilt?
summary: The European Union has not banned oil imports from Russia, but has done so with Russian liquefied natural gas. A recent industry gathering showed a split straw poll of 40% to 40% on whether the EU would again make Russia its key gas supplier, with the rest undecided. This highlights the complexity of the EU's energy policy towards Russia, with oil and gas treated differently.

site_title: Sunlit Greece seeks to lure Europeans amid winter energy crisis
summary: Greece is launching a campaign to attract European tourists during the winter months, capitalizing on the country's mild winters and low energy costs. The Greek government has allocated €20 million for a poster campaign targeting mainly European pensioners, aiming to boost the economy, which relies heavily on the tourism sector. With northern European countries facing colder and more expensive winters, Greece is positioning itself as a sun-seeker's destination, with tourism minister Vassilis Kikilias calling it the "Florida of Europe".

site_title: The four forces driving transformation of private capital markets
summary:
Private capital markets are undergoing significant transformation driven by four key factors: 

1. Banks and finance companies are reducing their involvement in riskier business segments, allowing private companies to access more capital.

2. The supply and demand for private capital have increased dramatically since the 2008 Global Financial Crisis.

3. The pandemic and inflationary shocks have not significantly dampened the momentum for private capital markets.

4. Institutional investors are seeking alternative investments, driving growth in private markets.

These factors are reshaping the ground beneath investors' feet, enabling private companies to access billions of dollars in financing.

site_title: Star South-east Asian unicorns see US$51b gone since their listings
summary: South-east Asian unicorns, including Indonesian e-commerce companies Bukalapak and Grab Holdings, have collectively lost US$51 billion in market value since their initial public offerings (IPOs). Their shares have plummeted over 65% since debuts, underperforming local benchmarks and experiencing a 30% drop in the Nasdaq 100. The decline is attributed to a global slump in technology stocks and growing doubts on their path to profitability.

site_title: Keppel to debut on main Dow Jones Sustainability Index; CDL dropped
summary: Keppel Corporation will debut on the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index, effective December 19, while City Developments Limited (CDL) will be dropped. Keppel's CEO Loh Chin Hua attributed the inclusion to the company's focus on sustainability as part of its 2030 vision. CDL's exclusion is seen as marginally negative, potentially impacting its stock performance, as it had not met the index's ESG standards due to the impact of the pandemic on its hospitality sector.

site_title: Stoehr most senior departure from Credit Suisse Greater China
summary: Credit Suisse's CEO of Greater China, Carsten Stoehr, is leaving the bank after more than two years of awaiting final approvals to expand its operations in China. Stoehr, who also served as chairman of the board of Credit Suisse (Hong Kong) and Credit Suisse Securities (Hong Kong), will depart on December 15. His departure follows deep cuts to the bank's workforce in China, including letting go of at least one-third of its investment-banking staff and 40% of research staff. Eugene Fung will take over as chairman of the two entities.

site_title: Bank runs just aren’t what they used to be
summary: Financial institutions, such as Credit Suisse and Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust (Breit), have experienced outflows of assets, but these are not traditional bank runs. Unlike past events, such as the Panic of 1857, today's outflows do not lead to a loss of confidence in the financial system, and no contagion occurred. Regulated banks, like Credit Suisse, are equipped to handle the outflows due to their liquidity requirements, and investor redemptions are limited by fund structures, preventing a self-fulfilling run.

site_title: Soilbuild bags S$140.4 million in new construction contracts
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has secured S$140.4 million in new construction contracts, bringing its total order book to S$492.7 million as of end-October. The company's order book comprises S$384.6 million in construction projects and S$108.1 million in precast supply and delivery projects. The new projects include a S$384.6 million residential block project at Toa Payoh Neighbourhood 1 and a S$108.1 million piling works project at Pasir Ris, both scheduled to start in Q4 this year.

site_title: Even Emirati royals can’t always buy ultra-hot Rolexes in Dubai
summary: Dubai's luxury market for Swiss watches is thriving, with the UAE becoming the world's ninth-largest market, driven by a surge in demand over the past two years. Despite being a popular destination for luxury goods, even Emirati royals may face challenges in acquiring ultra-hot Rolexes, with the company maintaining a selective approach for gifts. To educate customers and manage demand, Seddiqi Holding is considering a watchmaking learning space in its Dubai Mall store, and has even flown clients to Switzerland to witness watchmakers in action.

images.alt_text: The UAE city’s relative affordability and welcome of Russian wealth is underpinning its surge.
The move to authenticate its own pre-owned watches marks a significant shift for Rolex, whose timepieces dominate secondhand sales at dealers and online.

site_title: Did a robot write this? The need for watermarks to spot AI
summary: A growing concern is that AI-generated text lacks a clear identifier, making it difficult to distinguish between human and machine-made content online. To address this, OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT, is exploring methods to watermark its text, similar to how stock photos are protected. A proposed approach involves converting text into a string of tokens, which can be detected using a cryptographic key known only to OpenAI. However, the company faces a dilemma: releasing the watermark keys to the public could lead to misuse, while keeping them private could create a lucrative business model for OpenAI.

site_title: Toyota to outline 3-year EV plan changes to suppliers: sources
summary: Toyota is set to outline changes to its 3-year electric vehicle (EV) plan to key suppliers in early 2026, aiming to narrow the gap with industry leaders Tesla and BYD. The changes, which may include delays to some development programs, focus on improving EV competitiveness through performance-boosting technologies. The plan, led by former chief competitive officer Shigeki Terashi, aims to close the cost and performance gap with Tesla and deliver a dedicated EV platform, potentially replacing the e-TNGA architecture. The revamp is part of Toyota's effort to achieve carbon neutrality and respond to industry-wide EV sales growth.

images.alt_text: Toyota unveiled the new Prius last month amid criticism from ESG investors and environmental groups for its slow rollout of fully electric vehicles.

site_title: SGX securities turnover down 3.2% to S$27.2b in November
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 3.2% decline in total securities turnover to S$27.2 billion in November 2022, with a daily average value of S$1.2 billion. This marks a 13.2% drop in market turnover volume to 33.9 billion securities. Despite the decline, the total market turnover value rose 18% month-over-month, and derivatives volumes increased due to record foreign exchange trading activity amid optimism over Asian economies and easing interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: SGX attributed the rise in securities market turnover value in September to the strong performance of Straits Times Index (STI) constituent stocks and real estate investment trusts (Reits).
Securities daily average value stood at S$1.1 billion in August, 12 per cent lower year on year but 22.6 per cent higher on the month.
Comparing month on month, total market turnover value fell 30 per cent while total market turnover volume dipped 36.8 per cent, according to SGX data released on Thursday (Aug 11).

site_title: Amgen to buy Horizon Therapeutics for US$26.4b
summary: Amgen agreed to acquire Horizon Therapeutics for $26.4 billion, paying $116.50 in cash for each Horizon share. The deal gives Amgen access to the blockbuster thyroid eye disease treatment Tepezza, adding several approved drugs to its portfolio. The acquisition aims to counter declining sales of Amgen's top-selling arthritis drug Enbrel, which have fallen 14% in the latest quarter. The offer values Horizon at $26.40 billion, a premium of nearly 20% to the stock's last close, and is Amgen's biggest deal ever.

AstraZeneca agreed to acquire biotechnology firm TeneoTwo in a deal worth up to US$1.27 billion on Tuesday, in a move to bolster its roster of therapies to treat blood cancers.

site_title: Abu Dhabi Investment Authority to invest in India’s Lenskart: report
summary: Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (Adia) is in talks to invest $350-400 million in Indian eyewear retailer Lenskart, with a potential stake of almost 10%. The investment, valued at $4.5 billion, could be made through a secondary sale of shares or a small primary round. Lenskart, which operates in India, the US, Singapore, and the UAE, had recently acquired a majority stake in Japanese eyewear brand Owndays. An official announcement is expected in a couple of weeks.

site_title: China’s markets primed for extreme volatility in 2023
summary: China's markets are poised for extreme volatility in 2023, with stocks moving by 5% daily more frequently than since the 2008 global market meltdown. Volatility in the offshore yuan is near a record level, and the cost of insuring Chinese government debt against default is at multi-year highs. Despite expectations of a Chinese asset rise, catalysts for extreme shifts in sentiment remain, including the risk of overwhelming infections, the lingering property crisis, and China's relations with the US. Market analysts are cautiously optimistic on the reopening in China, but warn of a "bumpy" recovery and potential volatility.

site_title: China stocks slide as traders take profit after sharp recent run
summary: China stocks slid 3.1% on Monday, with technology stocks like Meituan and Alibaba Group Holding being the biggest drags, as investors took profits after a sharp recent run amid general caution ahead of global central bank meetings. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped 3.1% and the CSI 300 Index fell 0.9%. Profit-taking and risk-cutting ahead of key US inflation data and interest-rate decisions from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank contributed to the decline.

site_title: Target financial literacy education at the young to address crypto gambling
summary: A recent survey by OCBC Bank found that 40% of Singaporeans in their 20s and 30s are still interested in cryptocurrency investments, despite warnings from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Many are influenced by social media "gurus" and seek to retire early, with 42% of those in their 20s and 35% of those in their 30s losing money on their investments. Experts emphasize the need for financial education to start early, covering topics like money management, saving, and investing according to risk profiles.

summary: Europe's industrial sector is under threat due to high energy costs, with the EU's industrial base potentially becoming structurally uncompetitive if the issue is not addressed. The US's Inflation Protection Act has created "distortions" by providing massive green energy subsidies to US industry, prompting the European Commission to call for changes to EU state aid rules. The EU may consider a European sovereignty fund to support businesses and meet ambitious green standards, and Brussels is expected to propose new legislation to build up reserves of critical raw materials.

site_title: Air India nears historic order for up to 500 jets: sources
summary: Air India is nears historic order for up to 500 jets, worth tens of billions of dollars, from Airbus and Boeing. The deal includes 400 narrow-body jets and 100 wide-body jets, potentially ranking among the largest by a single airline. The order could top $100 billion at list prices and cap a volatile year for plane giants. The move aims to revive Air India's reputation as a world-class airline and strengthen its presence in the world's fastest-growing air travel market.

site_title: Oil rises after last week’s plunge, as key pipeline stays shut
summary: Oil prices rose after a key pipeline in North America remained shut, despite crude remaining on track for its first back-to-back quarterly decline since 2019. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rose to around $72 a barrel, following a 11% fall last week. The Keystone pipeline, which connects Canadian fields to US Gulf Coast refiners, has been shut since November and TC Energy has yet to set a restart date. site_title: Japanese composer, fighting cancer, livestreams what may be final concert
summary: Japanese composer Ryuichi Sakamoto, 70, livestreamed a potentially final concert due to stage 4 cancer, which he had announced earlier this year. The online performance featured 13 solo piano songs, including themes from "The Last Emperor" and "Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence," and was streamed to over two dozen nations. Sakamoto, a two-time Academy Award winner, had previously been diagnosed with throat cancer in 2014, but the cancer had spread to his rectum and was now in stage 4.

site_title: Oil rebounds as key pipeline remains shut and China eases curbs
summary: Oil prices rebounded after a key North American pipeline remained shut, with West Texas Intermediate rising toward $72 a barrel. China's easing of COVID curbs is expected to boost demand, offsetting concerns of a US recession. Crude prices remain on track for a first back-to-back quarterly decline since 2019 due to thin liquidity and a US$60-a-barrel price cap on Russian crude.
