site_title: Businesses in China’s Wuhan face fresh worries after easing of zero-Covid curbs
summary: Businesses in Wuhan, China, are facing financial struggles after the easing of zero-Covid curbs, with many shopkeepers and small-business owners reporting "no business" due to the sick and fearful staying home. Despite the lifting of strict regulations, the government shows few signs of stepping in to help. Owners of restaurants, eateries, and other businesses are losing money daily, with some estimating losses of 1,000 yuan (S$194) per day. Experts warn that the economic downturn is likely to continue, with factory activity shrinking and exports and imports falling, as the country grapples with an economic downturn this year.

images.alt_text: Although the Chinese government has loosened key parts of its zero-Covid policy, many appear wary of shaking off the shackles too quickly.
With the Covid Zero policy being rapidly dismantled, the threat of economic disruption remains high.
The strict approach has battered the world’s second-largest economy, put mental strain on hundreds of millions, and last month prompted the biggest show of public discontent.

site_title: Taiwan central bank likely to announce another mild rate hike: poll
summary: Taiwan's central bank is expected to announce another mild rate hike of 12.5 basis points to 1.75% at its quarterly meeting on Thursday, according to economists polled by Reuters. The rate increase is seen as a response to slowing exports and inflation, which has been slowing since August. The median forecast suggests the central bank will keep the rate steady in 2023 to support the economy. The decision comes as Taiwan's economy faces challenges, including a slowdown in exports and global inflation woes.

site_title: Securing anchor tenants can be a double-edged sword for commercial property landlords
summary: IOI Properties' landmark development, IOI Central Boulevard Towers in Singapore's CBD, is nearing completion after six years of construction. Securing Amazon as an anchor tenant has boosted the project, with the e-commerce giant taking up 369,000 sq ft of office space. This deal has helped alleviate financing costs and reduced the risk of the project being a "white elephant." However, it also means IOI may have to offer Amazon favorable terms, potentially limiting revenue. The development's retail space is also expected to benefit from the presence of office tenants.

images.alt_text: Islandwide occupancy rate ....
IOI Central Boulevard Towers, which is expected to be completed in October 2023, will have a podium and 2 towers.

site_title: US drugmaker Clovis files for bankruptcy
summary: US drugmaker Clovis Oncology has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in Delaware, citing liabilities of $500-1 billion and estimated assets worth $100-500 million. The company reported a lack of sufficient liquidity to maintain operations beyond January 2023, following a decline in cancer drug sales and challenges in raising additional capital. Clovis attributed its financial struggles to a combination of factors, including a decline in sales and increased competition in the oncology market.

images.alt_text: The FDA’s decision is in line with an advisory panel’s recommendation to not approve the drug.
FILE PHOTO: Signage for GlaxoSmithKline is seen on it's offices in London, Britain, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo
This is a second setback for GSK’s oncology portfolio this week, after the company on Monday revealed its blood cancer drug Blenrep failed to outperform an older therapy in a key study.

site_title: Waning trust: China shadow banks pivot away from property to survive
summary: China's shadow banking industry, worth about $3 trillion, is pivoting away from property to survive after a government clampdown on real estate firms' debt binge collapses the industry's single biggest revenue stream. The industry is now seeking new business through direct investment in companies, family offices, and asset management. Revenue has plummeted, with Shanghai Trust firm reporting a 50% decline in revenue this year compared to the previous year. The industry's plight contrasts with China's main street financial firms, which remain unaffected by the crisis.

images.alt_text: The sentiment index had been trending downward this year as the country grappled with Covid outbreaks and a property market slump.

site_title: Global private equity deal value continues monthly slide in November: S&P
summary: Global private equity deal value declined 53.5% in November, reaching $63.5 billion, with the Asia-Pacific region leading global dealmaking at $25.7 billion across 407 transactions. This marks a 40.5% decrease from the same period last year. The year-to-date total deal value was $677.2 billion, down 37.3% from 2021.

images.alt_text: Investor surveys by alternative assets data company Preqin show most investors are expecting the value of their portfolios to fall.
VC investments in South-east Asia in 2021 grew twice as quickly as the rest of Asia, according to Preqin.
A total value of US$52.97 billion across 1,652 entries were recorded by PE and VC firms for the month of May.

site_title: India’s Tata Group to open 100 exclusive Apple stores: report
summary: Tata Group's Infiniti Retail plans to open 100 exclusive Apple stores across India, with stores set at shopping malls, high-street, and neighbourhood locations. The move is an Apple-authorised reseller and comes after talks with premium malls and high streets. The lease terms include restrictions on other brands being opened near these outlets. This development follows previous reports of Tata Group's talks with Wistron to set up a joint venture to assemble iPhones in India.

images.alt_text: New products are exhibited at an Apple event at their headquarters in Cupertino, California, U.S. September 7, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

site_title: China consumer sentiment fell near 2020 lows before lifted curbs
summary: China's consumer sentiment index fell to near 2020 lows in November, according to a survey from Morning Consult. The index, which measures consumer attitudes towards financial conditions, ticked upward slightly in October before declining as coronavirus cases surged and lockdowns were implemented. Consumer sentiment was nearly as negative as it was in early 2020, with 70% of people describing Covid-19 as a major threat to their country. The data suggests the economy faces significant stress as policymakers roll back Covid Zero measures, presenting risks to the Chinese and global economies.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UBS issues double upgrade for GoTo from ‘sell’ to ‘buy’
summary: UBS has upgraded GoTo Group from a "sell" to a "buy" rating, citing improved competition in the Indonesian internet sector and the company's on-track path to profitability in 2023. Despite a 70% decline in GoTo's share price in the past month, UBS sees an opportunity to invest in the ride-hailing and e-commerce company. The bank notes that GoTo has lowered incentives and cut expenses, making it more competitive in the market.

images.alt_text: The stock fell as much as 6.8% in Jakarta trading and headed for its eighth straight daily drop, leaving it down 55% since its initial public offering in late March. Indonesia’s largest tech company now has a market value of about $11 billion.
GoTo raised US$1.1 billion from its IPO but its shares have plunged by 70 per cent since and sank 6.5 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars drop as focus turns to US inflation data, Fed meeting
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars dropped 0.5% and 0.4% respectively, breaking winning streaks, amid caution ahead of US inflation data and global rate decisions. The Aussie has surged 10% since mid-October but faces resistance at 68 cents, while the kiwi faces resistance at 64 cents. US producer prices rose faster than expected, fueling concerns about sticky inflation and potential longer interest rate hikes. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise rates by 50 basis points on Wednesday, with other central banks also announcing decisions this week.

site_title: Volkswagen’s Skoda considers withdrawing from China: report
summary: Skoda Auto, a part of Volkswagen, is considering withdrawing from China due to intense competition. CEO Klaus Zellmer stated that the company could sell cars in China without producing them, or focus on India instead. A final decision is expected next year. Volkswagen confirmed that it's normal business procedure for Skoda to assess its position in international markets and adapt to local developments, with no decisions made on possible strategy changes.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street down on inflation fears
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, following a drop on Wall Street, due to concerns over inflation and interest rates. The producer price index reading for November beat expectations, suggesting the Federal Reserve may need to continue hiking rates. Investors await the release of consumer price index figures, which could impact policy decisions in the US and other economies. The dollar edged up, and markets remain cautious ahead of key events, including the Fed's policy meeting and developments in China's shift away from zero-Covid policies.

images.alt_text: People wait to cross a street past an electronic sign showing numbers of the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong on November 11, 2022. - Hong Kong stocks surged six percent at the open on November 11, following a bumper session on Wall Street as lower US inflation dimmed expectations of more aggressive Fed interest-rate hikes. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: The great delusion behind Twitter
summary: The article "The great delusion behind Twitter" argues that Twitter's role as a "global town square" is a misconception. The author, Ezra Klein, claims that this metaphor is wrong on three levels: Twitter cannot be a single, universal town square, its governance is not public, and its purpose is not to facilitate meaningful discussions. Instead, Klein suggests that the true cost of social media is the deterioration of our capacity for attention and reflection. He cites the example of Quakers, who use silence to deliberate and make decisions, as a model for how to foster more thoughtful and democratic online discourse. The article concludes by highlighting the potential for a more democratic and community-driven approach to social media, citing examples such as Taiwan's Reddit-like platform, which is owned and governed by the academic network.

images.alt_text: Yoel Roth's departure from Twitter rattled advertisers, many of whom backed away from Twitter after Musk laid off half of the staff, including many involved with content moderation.
when the global soccer tournament started Nov 20, Twitter’s US ad revenue was running at 80 per cent below internal expectations for that week.
ESG scores can be problematic for investors because they’re largely based on self-reported and unaudited data from companies.
Indian government officials have called on tech companies such as Google, Meta, and Twitter to take stronger action against the spread of fake news.
Twitter is facing a growing number of lawsuits over the terms of employees' terminations.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday’s open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,239.85 on Monday, tracking Wall Street declines. The decline was attributed to US stocks falling last Friday due to economic data and interest rate hike concerns. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also fell in early morning trade. The top traded counter was Marco Polo Marine, while Eneco Energy gained 9.1% after a significant increase in shares.

images.alt_text: Across the broader Singapore market, gainers outnumbered decliners 308 to 207 after 1.3 billion securities worth S$1 billion were traded on Friday

site_title: China shipyards feast on record LNG tanker orders as South Korea builders are full up
summary: China's shipyards won a record 45 LNG tanker orders worth $9.8 billion, surpassing South Korea's dominance in the market. Chinese shipyards, particularly Hudong-Zhonghua, won nearly 30% of this year's 163 new LNG carrier orders, tripling their order books from 2021. The surge in demand is driven by China's need to transport US LNG and its goal to meet its 2060 carbon-neutral target. Chinese yards' lower financing costs and growing relationship with foreign engineering companies like Gaztransport & Technigaz (GTT) are also attracting foreign bookings.

images.alt_text: The deal between Sinopec and Qatar Energy will last for 27 years, making it China’s longest LNG supply agreement to date.

site_title: Chinese property tycoon to sell stake as share sales ramp up
summary: Chinese property tycoon Yang Huiyan is selling a stake in Country Garden Holdings to raise about $650 million amid a flurry of share sales by cash-strapped Chinese developers. Yang, co-chairman of Country Garden, is selling 237 million shares at a 10.9% discount to the latest closing price. This sale follows a series of share sales by other Chinese developers, with some seeing a 88% surge in shares since October. The move is seen as a way to shore up finances hurt by an unprecedented housing slump.

site_title: Musk targets US Covid response lead Fauci in viral tweet
summary: Elon Musk targeted US Covid-19 response lead Anthony Fauci in a viral tweet, using a meme that appeared to criticize Fauci's past comments on lockdowns. Musk's tweet sparked widespread criticism, with some praising Fauci and others defending Musk's right to free speech. Fauci, set to step down this month, previously slammed the proliferation of bad health advice online. The incident highlights ongoing polarization over pandemic policies and Fauci's legacy.

site_title: Confidential records show a Saudi golf Tour built on far-fetched assumptions
summary: Saudi Arabia's golf tour, LIV Golf, was built on unrealistic assumptions, including signing top 12 golfers, attracting sponsors, and landing TV deals despite declining viewership. Confidential records show that Saudi officials were told they faced significant challenges, with a golf investment of at least $2 billion expected to yield only relatively thin profits. Despite these doubts, LIV Golf has failed to meet its goals, with no major broadcasting or sponsorship deals, and its hopes for a surrender by the PGA Tour have collapsed into an acrimonious court battle.

images.alt_text: South Korea's Park Ji Young won with a score of 11-under-par 133 to clinch the Hana Financial Group Singapore Women's Open on Dec 11, 2022.
Rory McIlroy said that “nothing will happen” as long as the lawsuits were ongoing.

Education Minister Chan Chun Sing (centre), together with (to his right) Citi senior executives Stacey N. Lacy, Amol Gupte and Hector Garcia, present the cheque of S$550,000 to representatives of ChildAid (to Minister’s left) Lee Su Shyan and Helmi Yusof at the Citi & Partners Charity Golf event. Together with them on stage are child beneficiaries of The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation near steady at 9.3% as commodity prices ease
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation remained steady at 9.3% in November, its 21st consecutive month of annual increase, as global commodity prices eased. The yen's weakness boosted import costs, but moderating demand from China and easing commodity prices led to a slowdown in price gains for certain goods. The Bank of Japan noted that companies were passing on rising raw material costs, but some goods saw the impact of recent easing of global commodity prices. This data offers some relief for Japan's economy, which relies heavily on imports.

site_title: Why Indonesia’s financial revamp has the market on edge
summary: Indonesia is set to enact sweeping changes to its financial sector regulation, expanding the central bank's mandate and cementing its authority to buy government bonds during crisis times. The proposed law also aims to bring regulations in step with financial technology and cryptocurrency. The central bank plans to buy 1,144 trillion rupiah (S$99 billion) in debt papers by the end of 2022, and the changes are seen as a response to market pushback and two years of thwarted attempts.

images.alt_text: Activists holding a protest against the new criminal code outside Parliament building in Jakarta. The UN is concerned that several articles in the revised Criminal Code contravene Indonesia’s international legal obligations with respect to human rights.
The latest draft of the financial sector omnibus law retained a provision that calls on Bank Indonesia (BI) to undertake debt monetisation in times of crisis.

site_title: UK home asking prices are falling at sharpest pace in four years
summary: UK home prices fell at the sharpest pace in four years, with the average asking price dropping 2.1% in December to £359,137. The decline is attributed to soaring interest rates making buyers more hesitant, with Rightmove citing a 3.4% drop in the south west of England. Despite this, the website notes that interest remains strong among potential buyers, with a 11% rise in views. The slowdown in price growth is attributed to rising mortgage costs and economic uncertainty, with the Bank of England raising rates eight times in the past year.

images.alt_text: Recent UK official data showed that manufacturing output in September was 5.8 per cent lower than a year earlier.

site_title: Frasers Property appoints ThaiBev CEO to board of directors
summary: Frasers Property has appointed ThaiBev CEO Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi as a non-executive, non-independent director, effective January 1, 2023. He joins the executive committee and remuneration committee. Six current directors will step down, including Charles Mak and Philip Eng, who will be replaced by Chin Yoke Choong as chairman of the remuneration committee and Pramoad Phornprapha as chairman of the nominating committee and sustainability and risk management committee. The appointments align with the company's plans for board refreshment and renewal.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
In this newly created role, Bevilacqua will deepen Frasers Property’s environmental, social and governance (ESG) agenda by working with the leadership team and with its business units.

Higher contributions from residential projects in Singapore helped to boost Frasers Property's earnings in FY2022. The company sold 75 per cent of Sky Eden@Bedok on the first day of launch in September.
Sky Eden@Bedok by Frasers Property. The group announced changes to its board composition with effect from Tuesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Alset, Yeo Hiap Seng
summary: Key developments in the stock market include Alset International agreeing to sell its US subsidiary American Home Reit for $26.3 million. Yeo Hiap Seng CEO Samuel Koh is resigning, with Ong Yuh Hwang taking over as CEO and Koh becoming a consultant from January 1 to June 3. Trading was halted for H2G Green pending an announcement. Additionally, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Takeaways from a challenging 2022
summary: 2022 was a challenging year for investors, particularly those in their golden years, as stocks and bonds fell in tandem, resulting in double-digit losses. However, a silver lining is that bond yields have become more attractive, especially for those willing to take on credit risk. To mitigate losses, investors can consider fixed-maturity bond funds with static portfolios, which aim to maximize income while minimizing mark-to-market risks. Avoiding permanent loss is crucial, and investors should be cautious of unregulated entities, such as cryptocurrency platforms, which can pose significant risks.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Bear market

site_title: Tokyo’s broken bond market needs more than BOJ tweaks to heal
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) efforts to address the liquidity drought in Japan's debt market through massive bond purchases have been deemed insufficient, with investors calling for a fundamental overhaul of its policy framework. The BOJ's unprecedented asset purchases have distorted the yield curve, limited market functioning, and increased the risk of a surge in yields. Experts warn that the central bank's large-scale bond buying is harming market functioning, and a policy change is necessary to address the issues, with some speculating that a review of the BOJ's easing framework may be on the horizon.

images.alt_text: The BOJ remains an outlier among a global wave of central banks tightening monetary policy to combat soaring inflation.

site_title: British trade minister heads to India to kick off new round of trade talks
summary: British trade minister Kemi Badenoch is visiting India to kick off a new round of trade talks, aiming to secure a free trade agreement (FTA) between the countries. The talks, the first formal round since July, follow a missed deadline set by former Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Badenoch will discuss cutting tariffs and opening opportunities for the UK's services sector, with a focus on reducing tariffs on goods such as whisky. The UK and India have a £29 billion trading relationship, with expanding it a key part of the UK's Indo-Pacific foreign policy.

site_title: Crypto fugitive Do Kwon placed in Serbia by South Korean reports
summary: Crypto fugitive Do Kwon has been reported to be in Serbia, according to South Korean authorities. Do Kwon, the progenitor of the TerraUSD and Luna ecosystem, has been on the run since a warrant for his arrest was issued in mid-September due to breaches of capital-markets law. Serbia is believed to be cooperating with South Korea, with an anonymous source citing a request for cooperation from the Balkan nation. Do Kwon denies wrongdoing and has argued that capital-markets legislation doesn't apply to crypto tokens.

images.alt_text: Do Kwon, co-founder and chief executive officer of Terraform Labs, in the company's office in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, April 14, 2022. Kwon is counting on the oldest cryptocurrency as a backstop for his stablecoin, which some critics liken to a ginormous Ponzi scheme. Photographer: Woohae Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Gold eases; US inflation data, Fed verdict in focus
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $1,793.44 per ounce, weighed down by a firmer dollar, ahead of US inflation data and the Federal Reserve's rate-hike verdict this week. Investors expect a 93% chance of a 50-basis-point rate hike, which tends to increase gold's opportunity cost. China's gold premiums rose after easing Covid-19 restrictions, while India's high prices muted demand. Spot silver fell 0.7% to $23.29, and platinum and palladium also declined.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates tend to increase the opportunity cost of holding gold as it yields no interest.

site_title: Alset International to sell American Home Reit to its controlling shareholder for US$26.3m
summary: Alset International agreed to sell its US-based real estate investment trust, American Home Reit, to its controlling shareholder, Alset Inc, for approximately US$26.3 million. The transaction is subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting. The sale is part of Alset International's capital recycling plan to unlock the value of its real estate holdings and fund future property development projects.

images.alt_text: Alset diversifies into crypto mining business through new subsidiary

site_title: Market looks to clearer disclosure standards and tech boost for external assurance of ESG reports
summary: Singapore's market is seeking clearer disclosure standards and technology to boost external assurance of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) reports. Demand for assurance is growing, driven by laws and standards on sustainability and climate-related reporting, as well as increasing awareness of climate change. However, challenges include data quality and availability, as well as a lack of global standards. The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) and International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) are expected to deliver standards in 2023, which will help address these challenges. Companies are expected to gradually aim for higher levels of assurance, with reasonable assurance likely to become the norm by 2030.

images.alt_text: Investors are familiar with audits of financial statements, but many may not be aware that a similar form of assurance is increasingly being obtained for non-financial disclosures relating to companies' sustainability and climate-related conduct.

Widely accepted global standards may boost the utility of independent assurance but, as long as companies can pick and choose what to subject to such assurance, the risk of greenwashing remains, says Professor Mak Yuen Teen. (PHOTO: MAK YUEN TEEN)
Getting the ISSB's expected global standards on sustainability and climate disclosures to reflect local realities will be a complex undertaking.

Leading Singapore organisations have raised concerns about aspects of draft sustainability- and climate-related disclosure standards by the global accounting body International Sustainability Standards Board.

site_title: China retires major Covid tracking app as virus rules ease
summary: China has retired its major Covid-19 tracking app, "Communications Itinerary Card", as the country eases its zero-tolerance coronavirus strategy. The app, which tracked contacts based on phone signal, will be offline on Tuesday after over two years in operation. The decision comes days after China announced an end to large-scale lockdowns and testing measures. Official reported cases have dropped sharply, but top health expert Zhong Nanshan warned of the Omicron variant's rapid spread. The retirement of the app marks a significant shift in China's pandemic strategy, with millions of people previously required to key in their phone numbers to travel.

images.alt_text: Beijing has announced an end to large-scale lockdowns, mandatory quarantine in central gacilities, and a broad relaxation of testing measures © Noel CELIS / AFP
The sentiment index had been trending downward this year as the country grappled with Covid outbreaks and a property market slump.

site_title: Saudi Arabia remains on track to be fastest-growing G20 economy
summary: Saudi Arabia's economy is expected to expand by 3.1% in 2023, making it the fastest-growing G20 economy this year. The country's GDP expanded 8.8% in the third quarter, driven by a 14.2% growth in oil-related GDP and a 6% growth in the non-oil economy. The non-oil economy has been on a recent tear, with business activity expanding at the fastest pace in over seven years. The kingdom's forecast for a budget surplus in 2023 has also been revised upward, signaling confidence in its revenue despite global economic concerns.

images.alt_text: China is seeking to strengthen coordination with Saudi Arabia and its neighbours on energy policy and exploration.

site_title: Tech layoffs turn talent hiring into employer’s market
summary: Tech companies are laying off employees, with at least 1,270 Singapore resident jobs cut between July and November this year, surpassing the sector's annual average of 790 resident workers retrenched in the past five years. However, talent is being quickly absorbed by startups, which are now actively seeking high-level hires. Salaries are also staying relatively flat or seeing single-digit growth, with demand expected to be high for senior-level jobseekers in certain sectors over the next six to eight months.

site_title: BT Mark to Market : Can SIA fly higher in 2023? (Ep 26)
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is enjoying a strong FY2023 due to increased travel demand, but investors should be cautious as losses in India and competition may weigh on the company's performance in 2024. SIA has resumed dividend payouts and redeemed its first tranche of Mandatory Convertible Bonds (MCBs), but the need to redeem the remaining MCBs could impact investor sentiment. The airline's poor long-term investment fundamentals may also be a concern.

images.alt_text: SIA said its quarterly revenue per available seat-kilometre hit a record high for the three months to Sep 30
Why are Match Group stocks worth looking into? Ben Paul finds out.

site_title: Nasdaq 100 to benefit from Fed’s less hawkish stance
summary: US stocks rebounded after the US Federal Reserve confirmed a pivot away from its hawkish stance on interest rates and policies. The Nasdaq 100 is expected to benefit, potentially breaking the 12,000 level in the final month of 2022, driven by a weaker labor market and the end-of-year holiday period. However, a bearish scenario suggests the index may decline back to the 11,000-11,200 region if it fails to break above 12,000.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - OCTOBER 12: People walk past the Nasdaq MarketSite on October 12, 2022 in New York City. The Nasdaq Composite Index yesterday hit its lowest level since July, slipping into a bear market for the second time this year.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: World Cup: Croatia’s mental strength has deep roots, says hero Petkovic
summary: Croatia's World Cup team credits their mental strength to their country's struggle for independence, with striker Bruno Petkovic saying the nation's fight for freedom has instilled a strong work ethic and determination. The team's experience in the 1990s conflict has also played a role, with veteran players like Luka Modric and Dejan Lovren having personal connections to the conflict. Croatia's mental toughness has led to two penalty shoot-out wins in the World Cup, with Petkovic's late equalizer against Brazil being a key factor.

site_title: Fed’s message that rates will stay on hold for ‘some time’ clashes with 2023 rate-cut bets
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to increase its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points, lifting it to a 4.25-4.5% target range, in a move to curb inflation. However, financial markets anticipate a rapid retreat from peak rates later next year, reflecting differing views on inflation's persistence. Fed officials, led by Jerome Powell, expect to hold rates high to defeat inflation, while investors expect price pressures to ease faster. The Fed's communication policy is seen as the key factor in the discrepancy, with some warning of a sticky quality to inflation and others predicting a quick deceleration.

images.alt_text: Stock markets will likely benefit from the confirmation of the US Federal Reserve pivoting away from its hawkish stance on interest rates and policies. PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Spenmo lays off staff to extend cash runway
summary: Financial software startup Spenmo is laying off 30-70% of its workforce, approximately 60-140 employees, as part of a push to extend its cash runway past five years. The layoffs, which occurred on November 18, were attributed to the macroeconomic environment and the need for a longer cash runway. The company had recently raised a $75.5 million Series B round in January 2022. Spenmo offers spending management software-as-a-service solutions, ranging from corporate cards to employee reimbursement.

images.alt_text: This is at least the third round of job cuts Shopee has made this year.
Carousell co-founder Quek Siu Rui admitted that he was too optimistic about the investment Carousell was making in hiring versus the platform's impact.
Kraken had recently expanded quickly, and the cuts will return its workforce to where it was a year ago.

site_title: Fund managers brace for ESG correction with US$4t at stake
summary: European regulators are proposing stricter standards for ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) funds, requiring at least 80% of holdings in Article 8 funds to meet the strategy description and 40% in Article 8 sustainable funds. This could lead to a reclassification of up to $4 trillion in assets, forcing fund managers to rethink their ESG designations and potentially downgrading funds from the EU's top ESG class to Article 6. The goal is to protect investors against unsubstantiated sustainability claims, but some institutional investors welcome the stricter standards.

images.alt_text: Most Singapore companies that have sought independent assurance on their ESG disclosures have opted to go with limited assurance, but market pressures will eventually drive them to seek a higher level of assurance. (PHOTO: AFP)

site_title: UK manufacturers expect output to fall 3.2% in 2023
summary: UK manufacturers expect a 3.2% decline in output for 2023 due to rising raw material prices and borrowing costs, as well as a decrease in consumer demand. This follows a 4.4% decline in 2022. Trade body Make UK warns that more government support may be needed to avoid a prolonged period of low growth, with forecasts suggesting the broader economy will shrink 0.9% next year. Make UK calls for temporary relaxation of immigration controls, lower property taxes, and greater tax incentives for training and investment to support the industry.

site_title: Volkwagen’s Skoda considers withdrawing from China
summary: Skoda Auto, a Czech carmaker part of Volkswagen, is considering withdrawing from China due to intense competition. CEO Klaus Zellmer stated that the company could sell cars in China rather than producing them there. Skoda aims to focus on India at the moment, and a final decision will be made next year.

images.alt_text: Klaus Zellmer, CEO of Skoda Auto, speaks during the German-Czech Economic Forum in Prague, Czech Republic, October 17, 2022. REUTERS/David W Cerny

site_title: World Cup: Ronaldo won’t make ‘heat of moment’ decision after Portugal exit
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo has spoken out after Portugal's World Cup elimination, saying "there's no point in reacting in the heat of the moment" and that he will allow time to pass before drawing conclusions. Ronaldo, 37, stayed in Qatar after the team's 1-0 loss to Morocco and has been without a club since a bitter divorce with Manchester United. He denied speculation about his future and vowed to continue supporting his teammates and country, despite being eliminated from the World Cup.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says US$50b investments agreed at China summit
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced $50 billion in investment agreements at a China summit, according to Investment Minister Khalid Al Falih. The deals, including private and public sector partnerships, were signed during President Xi Jinping's visit to Saudi Arabia. Most agreements were memorandums of understanding with no firm timelines or commitments. The summit showcased the Gulf's deepening ties with Beijing, with Saudi Arabia seeking to strengthen its economic ties with China.

site_title: Businesses keen to work with governments to leverage opportunities in Asean
summary: Business leaders in Asean remain optimistic about the region's growth potential, with 9 in 10 expecting positive revenue growth from their Asean businesses. The four key growth sectors - construction and infrastructure, consumer products, pharmaceuticals and healthcare, and digital and e-commerce - are expected to drive growth, with compound annual growth rates projected to outpace the overall industry average. To navigate challenges, businesses are focusing on collaboration, talent, and infrastructure development, with value chains, talent, and infrastructure being top areas for improvement.

images.alt_text: epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES
Transformational and structural trends present an attractive set of opportunities especially in Asia, says Benjamin Hung, CEO, Asia, Standard Chartered.

site_title: Nasa capsule Orion splashes down after record-setting lunar voyage
summary: NASA's Orion space capsule successfully splashed down in the Pacific Ocean after a record-breaking 25-day journey around the Moon, marking a significant milestone in the Artemis program. The uncrewed mission logged over 1.6 million km and broke the distance record for a habitable spacecraft. Orion's heat shield was tested, and the capsule showed no evidence of damage after reentering the Earth's atmosphere. The spacecraft will be recovered by a US Navy ship off Mexico's Baja California, paving the way for future human missions to the Moon and beyond.

site_title: A generational shift: How Singapore’s Millennials and Zoomers are reshaping the workplace
summary: Singapore's Gen Z workforce, born between the mid-1990s and early 2010s, is driving the country's economy with their demands for flexibility, work-life balance, and positive workplace culture. Unlike Millennials, Gen Zers are tech-savvy, preferring open communication and collaboration tools, such as no-code workflow management software. They value freedom, flexibility, and independence, and are less patient with inefficiency and hierarchy. To attract and retain talent, organizations must adapt to Gen Z's needs, providing tools for collaboration and open communication, and supportive leadership. Failure to do so may lead to voluntary turnover and struggle to retain top talent.

images.alt_text: “We value paper qualifications a lot”: Assoc Prof Irene Ng of the NUS.

Companies that tested a four-day work week registered gains in revenue and employee productivity, as well as drops in absenteeism and turnover. Workers on a four-day schedule also were more inclined to work from the office than home.

Shasparay Irvin, at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, felt she wasn't reaching the students she had just begun teaching remotely, so she is now completing a master's degree and considering other career options.

Staff can feel comfortable having candid conversations about their current state of wellbeing and workplace struggles, or arrange for one-on-one meetings with managers for professional guidance. When done right, coaching provides greater intrinsic motivation.

site_title: China cracks down on drug price gouging amid fears of Covid spike
summary: China cracks down on price gouging of medical supplies and drugs amid fears of a Covid-19 outbreak. The country's watchdog banned activities including price inflation, collusion, and hoarding, and urged local governments to ensure smooth transport and logistics. China's State Administration for Market Regulation warned against price gouging, citing the need to protect human lives and health. The measures aim to maintain normal living and working order as the nation eases its zero-Covid policy.

images.alt_text: A Covid-19 testing booth in Shanghai, China, on Monday, Dec. 5, 2022. Government officials over the past week signaled a transition away from the harshest Covid containment measures, which have weighed on the economy and prompted thousands of demonstrators to take to the streets to voice their anger. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Thailand hits tourism goal as foreign arrivals top 10 million
summary: Thailand has reached its target of 10 million foreign visitors for the year, exceeding expectations after the COVID-19 pandemic nearly decimated its tourism sector. The milestone was celebrated with cultural events and gifts at airports and border checkpoints. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha stated that the success will create confidence that Thailand remains a global destination, with plans to welcome more travelers in the future. This marks a significant growth driver for Thailand's economy, accounting for 12% of its GDP.

images.alt_text: In pre-pandemic 2019, there were nearly 40 million foreign tourists who spent 1.91 trillion baht.

site_title: SIA faces short-term pain of MCB redemptions, losses in India amid post-pandemic recovery
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is facing short-term challenges due to mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) redemption and losses in India, despite a record high quarterly revenue per available seat-kilometre. The airline's profitability is likely to be eroded by competition as demand and supply in the aviation sector normalizes. SIA is redeeming its MCBs, which will reduce its capital base, but the cost of redemption will rise over time. The merger of Vistara and Air India, in which SIA will own 25.1%, is expected to provide long-term benefits but may weigh down SIA's recurring earnings in the short term.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines has noticed business travel demand has increased in its second quarter , after lagging leisure travel in an earlier quarter.
SIA resumes dividend payments, with an interim dividend of S$0.10 to be pain in December.
Other parts of SIA’s network across the Americas and Europe will also be adjusted in line with the airline’s review of travel demand and capacity needs.
Thai Airways is looking at codesharing SIA’s flight services in South Africa, US and Canada.

SIA expects the merger of Air India and Vistara will boost its presence in India, strengthen its multi-hub strategy, and allow it to continue participating directing in a large and fast-growing aviation market.

site_title: Surging heating costs squeeze landlords and threaten higher rents
summary: US household bills for natural gas and heating oil are expected to rise nearly 30% this winter, with electricity prices also on track to increase. This will add to the burden of landlords, who are already dealing with high inflation and supply chain issues. Rent hikes are likely, with the north-east region expected to be hit hardest due to cold climate and older housing stock. Energy-efficient systems, such as electric heat pumps, may become more attractive to landlords as a long-term solution, but smaller owners may struggle to afford the upfront costs.

images.alt_text: The biggest contribution Japan could make to resolve the energy trilemma is to focus on lowering demand.

site_title: In post-pandemic era, South-east Asia primed for rapid healthcare change
summary: South-east Asia is poised for rapid healthcare change in the post-pandemic era, driven by shifting demographics, rising consumer expectations, and an underdeveloped healthcare ecosystem. The region's emerging markets comprise 60% of the world's population but contribute only 20% of global healthcare spending. Despite significant supply side constraints, including a shortage of trained medical professionals and slow innovation, healthcare expenditure is expected to grow rapidly in the coming decade. Governments and private players are partnering to improve outcomes for patients, with digital adoption and innovative healthcare solutions playing a key role in enabling more quality and affordable healthcare.

images.alt_text: Arich Tan, group chief executive officer of A Wellness Holdings, ventured into the beauty industry so that the group would not be too reliant on its original NATRAHEA brand.
Students protesting against China's zero-Covid policy at Tsinghua University in Beijing, Nov 27, 2022.

site_title: How a theme park property default started South Korea’s credit crunch
summary: South Korea's credit crunch was triggered by a theme park property default in Gangwon province, which missed a 205 billion won repayment of project finance asset-backed commercial paper (PF-ABCP) in late September. This rare default, linked to the property market, has led to a surge in short-term yields, the worst run-up since the global financial crisis. The crisis highlights the risks of pushing too far, too fast in taming inflation, and the key role of markets in maintaining financial system stability. Central bankers are racing to address the issue.

images.alt_text: The nation’s housing market has continued dropping in recent weeks after the worst monthly decline since the global financial crisis in August.

site_title: Saudi refiner Luberef prices US$1.3b IPO at top end
summary: Saudi Aramco Base Oil, a refining unit of Saudi Aramco, priced its initial public offering at 99 riyals per share, raising 4.95 billion riyals (S$1.8 billion) for the private equity firm. The IPO, taking place at the top end of its marketed range, suggests demand for share sales in the region remains strong despite recent muted trading debuts. This marks the last large Gulf listing of the year, indicating investors' appetite for listings remains despite typical year-end caution.

images.alt_text: China is seeking to strengthen coordination with Saudi Arabia and its neighbours on energy policy and exploration.

site_title: The ‘Spac King’ is over it
summary: Chamath Palihapitiya, known as the "Spac King," is blaming the Federal Reserve for the collapse of the special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) market. He had promoted SPACs to everyday investors, raising over $2.2 billion, but many of his stocks have dropped nearly 90% since listing. Palihapitiya, who had sold most of his shares early, doubled his initial investment, but many small investors who followed his advice may not fare well. He blames the Fed's sharp interest-rate increases for making SPACs less enticing for big investors.

images.alt_text: Demand for lithium, a material that’s key to the renewable-energy transition, is forecast to almost triple by mid-decade from last year’s level.
laboratory, analysis, chemistry
Proceeds from the merger will be used to expand headcount, Super Apps said. The combined company will be listed on Nasdaq and named TETE Technologies.
The platform has more than 3 million active users, with over 25,000 vehicles registered by their owners.
To extend equity research services to more retail investors, the community can also explore innovative methods of partnership.

Intuitive Machines is 1 of NASA’s contractors and its lunar payload delivery services were selected by the space agency for 3 lunar missions to send the first American spacecraft to the surface of the Moon since the Apollo Program.
KKR & Co on Friday (Aug 26) confirmed a Bloomberg News scoop that it’s abandoning a US$14 billion bid for Australian hospital chain Ramsay Health Care.

site_title: Top China expert says Covid 'spreading rapidly' after rules easing
summary: China's top health expert, Zhong Nanshan, warns of a surge in Covid-19 cases due to the easing of the country's "zero-Covid" policy, citing the highly transmissible Omicron strain. Shops and restaurants in Beijing are deserted as the government allows some positive cases to quarantine at home and ends large-scale lockdowns. With millions of elderly unvaccinated and underfunded hospitals lacking capacity, China faces a significant challenge in handling the surge, with official caseloads having dropped sharply following the government's decision to scrap routine mass testing.

images.alt_text: A ministry spokeswoman says China and Germany have reached agreement on providing German vaccines for German nationals in China.

site_title: Japanese startup launches historic moon mission
summary: A Japanese startup, ispace, has launched a historic moon mission, becoming the first private company to reach the lunar surface. The Hakuto-R mission, named after the Japanese phrase for "white rabbit," was launched by SpaceX in Cape Canaveral, Florida, on December 11, 2022. The spacecraft is expected to touch down on the moon in April 2023, carrying a 10kg rover built by the United Arab Emirates, and will be the first Arab world mission to the moon.

images.alt_text: SpaceX postpones the launch of the world's first private lander to the Moon.

site_title: Payments company Adyen retains hiring pace despite tech slowdown
summary: Dutch fintech Adyen plans to continue its hiring pace until at least 2024, driven by its strong financial position and ambitions to grow its business. The company added 395 new employees in the first half of 2022, a 50% increase from the previous two years. Despite a global tech slowdown, Adyen remains optimistic, with a focus on organic growth and expanding into specialized offerings like unified commerce and embedded finance. The company's cash and equivalents rose 21% to €5.6 billion, with no debt, and free cash flow increased 25% to €308.9 million.

site_title: Credit market investors are watching for a Federal Reserve pivot
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to announce a 50 basis-point interest rate hike at its FOMC meeting this week, diverging from 75 basis-point hikes this year to tame inflation. This move would come despite mixed data and investor expectations of a Fed pivot to lower rate hikes. The decision may impact US corporate credit and leveraged finance markets, with some analysts predicting a pause in rate hikes for next year. The latest consumer price index data will also be released, adding to the Fed's consideration.

site_title: A Son SoftBank buyout would look more like Musk than Dell
summary: Japanese billionaire Masayoshi Son's stake in SoftBank Group has increased to over a third, fueling rumors of a potential US$78 billion management buyout. Son has stepped away from being the public face of the firm, indicating a desire to maintain control. This move has been seen as a departure from the company's public listing, which Son has previously criticized for being less effective in capturing SoftBank's value. A private buyout would be the largest of its kind, marking a significant shift in the company's structure and operations.

images.alt_text: Masayoshi Son is closer to the point where he could mount an effort to take SoftBank private, an idea he has repeatedly discussed internally.

site_title: Taiwan mulls WTO case after latest Chinese import bans
summary: Taiwan is considering filing a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against China's import bans on Taiwanese food and drink products, citing a "pressure campaign." The latest bans cover fishery products, beers, and liquors, and China claims the Taiwanese companies did not complete necessary paperwork. Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang said China's actions are "interfering" in normal trade and not in line with WTO norms, and Taiwan may take the issue to the WTO if necessary.

images.alt_text: China imported US$56 million worth of fish and crustaceans in the six months from May to October, compared with US$138 million during the same period a year earlier.

While the list of issues that Brussels and Beijing remain at odds over remains long, both sides are also keen to emphasise areas of common interest and cooperation.

site_title: China’s carbon market falls far short of making a climate impact
summary: China's national carbon market has failed to force power companies to slash emissions, with trading volumes underwhelming due to narrow participation and generous allowances. The cost of releasing a tonne of carbon dioxide in China averages less than $9, compared to $85 in the European Union. The government has deliberately kept prices low to avoid straining the finances of key companies, and the market is unlikely to become a prominent tool for fighting climate change until China cuts coal consumption and adds other polluting industries.

site_title: British PM Sunak faces new demands from his fractious party
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is facing new demands from his fractious Conservative Party, just six weeks into his tenure. The party has launched two campaigns to address concerns about its direction, with one group calling for £7 billion in "waste" to be cut to allow for tax cuts or increased spending on frontline services. The campaigns come as Sunak tries to unite a party that has already ousted two prime ministers in 2022 and trails the opposition Labour party in the polls by double digits.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak arrives ahead of an emergency meeting of leaders at the G20 summit following the overnight missile strike by a Russian-made rocket on Poland, on November 16, 2022, in Bali, Indonesia.  Leon Neal/Pool via Reuters

site_title: Rain scraps play as Park Ji-young is declared Singapore Women’s Open champion
summary: Park Ji-young, a South Korean golfer, won the inaugural Hana Financial Group Singapore Women's Open with a score of 11-under-par 133. The tournament was cancelled due to inclement weather, with only seven groups completing their rounds before play was halted. Park's strong opening 36-hole performance secured her fifth KLPGA Tour title, making her the champion of the event.

images.alt_text: (From left) Golfers Kim Su Ji, Park Min Ji, Atthaya Thitikul, Shin Ji Yai, Choi Hye Jin and Yealimi Noh pose with the trophy for the Hana Financial Group Singapore Women's Open at Tanah Merah Country Club on Dec 7, 2022.

site_title: Thaksin-linked party tipped to form next Thai government
summary: Thailand's main opposition party, Pheu Thai, is seen to have the highest chance of forming the next government with 73% of respondents' confidence in a recent poll. The party, linked to former premier Thaksin Shinawatra, has pledged to lift minimum wages by 70% and boost economic growth to 5% annually. Thaksin's daughter, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, is emerging as a potential candidate for the premiership and has rallied support for the party in recent months. The party aims for a "landslide" win with over half the seats in the House of Representatives in elections expected early next year.

images.alt_text: Ousted Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra's daughter Paetongtarn is tipped to be one of Pheu Thai party’s three candidates for the premier job.

site_title: Healthcare S-Reits capture Japan opportunities with expanding footprint
summary: Two actively traded healthcare S-Reits, ParkwayLife Reit and First Reit, have significantly expanded their portfolios in Japan's growing healthcare market. ParkwayLife Reit acquired 57 nursing homes worth S$872.9 million, while First Reit acquired 14 nursing homes, increasing its rental income by 39.2% year-on-year. Japan's aging population and high demand for healthcare services make it an attractive market for these S-Reits. Their expansion is expected to position them for long-term growth with stability, with First Reit aiming to reach 50% of assets under management in developed markets by 2027.

images.alt_text: On a year-to-date total return basis, S-Reits have seen a 10.9 per cent decline, against the Straits Times Index’s 9.6 per cent gain, while the FTSE EPRA Nareit Developed Index has seen a decline of 21.1 per cent.

site_title: World’s top money managers see global stocks recovering in 2023
summary: World's top money managers predict global stocks will recover in 2023, with 71% expecting equities to rise and 19% forecasting declines. They expect modest gains of 10% for 2023, with sectors like dividend payers, healthcare, and low-volatility stocks favored. However, stubbornly high inflation and a deep recession remain major concerns, and investors remain cautious for the start of the year, with the path to a rebound expected to be skewed to the second half of 2023.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is expected to announce a 50 basis-point hike this week, marking a divergence from a series of 75 basis-point hikes this year to help tame inflation.

site_title: Filtering out of the fast lane
summary: A runner reflects on the benefits of "slow runs" and how varying their pace can improve their overall performance and reduce the risk of injury. They discovered that running at a comfortable pace allows the body to improve its aerobic energy system, making them less fatigued. The author also applies this principle to life, recognizing the importance of taking rest days and slowing down to avoid burnout. They hope to prioritize self-care and balance in 2023, taking a more relaxed approach to their schedule and life in general.

images.alt_text: Each device defines “stress” differently, although many use heart rate variability as an indicator. However, this capability could be a double-edged sword.

site_title: Goldman’s Waldron sees ‘bumpy’ China reopening curbing growth
summary: Goldman Sachs president John Waldron warns that China's reopening could be "bumpy," potentially leading to a tougher economic climate. This comes as the country pivots from a Covid Zero policy, amid geopolitical tensions and a slump in dealmaking. Despite this, Goldman's business in China is doing well, particularly in capital markets, and the bank aims to expand its role in China's asset management industry.

site_title: UK power surges to record as sub-zero chill sends demand surging
summary: The UK has seen record power prices as a cold snap sends demand surging, with prices reaching £674.78 (S$1,121.71) per MWh on Monday. Temperatures are expected to drop to -3 degrees Celsius, boosting heating demand, while wind generation will be almost zero on Sunday and very low on Monday. This has led to a supply crunch, with power consumption expected to peak at 46,695 MW on Monday. The cold snap is expected to last for seven days across north-west Europe, with the UK's National Grid testing a demand flexibility service to reduce consumption.

site_title: The US$115b thematic ETF boom lives on even as losses mount
summary: US thematic ETFs, which target investments based on trends such as robotics or electric cars, continue to attract investors despite an average 30% drawdown in 2022. Outflows account for less than 1% of the $115 billion in assets under management, according to data compiled by Bloomberg Intelligence. Thematic funds that focus on innovation and emerging markets technology saw inflows of $2.2 billion and $1.8 billion respectively, while tech and communications saw the most outflows. Despite concerns about the impact of Fed policy on growth and corporate earnings, issuers remain optimistic about the space, citing the potential for investor conviction and diversification.

site_title: Cash crops: Dutch use Bitcoin mining to grow tulips
summary: Dutch flower farmers are using Bitcoin mining to heat their greenhouses, reducing reliance on expensive gas. The process involves complex calculations performed by Bitcoin miners, which generate heat that warms the hothouses where tulips grow. This innovative approach allows farmers to cut costs and earn some Bitcoin in the process, creating a "win-win situation." The method has been successfully implemented by several farmers, including Bert De Groot, who now has 17 clients, including restaurants and warehouses.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of December 9, 2022, highlights the following key trends and events:

- The Capesize market rose by over $1,200 to close at $13,957, driven by pre-Christmas loading and prompt-dated vessels.
- The Atlantic basin remained largely uneventful, with modest rate gains for owners and steady rates agreed for laden legs and US Gulf fronthaul runs.
- The Asian market saw a mixed picture, with an up-tick in demand on Indonesia to China supply trips and slightly firmer numbers on NoPac round trips.
- Ultramax/Supramax rates were patchy, with the US Gulf being the only area to gain traction.
- Handysize rates were balanced in Asia, with mixed results in the Atlantic basin.
- LR2s and MRs saw improvements in the Middle East Gulf and UK-Continent regions, respectively.
- VLCC rates eased downwards, with the 270,000mt Middle East Gulf to China rate falling four points lower than a week ago.
- Suezmax rates recovered 24.5 points to just shy of WS300, while Aframax rates picked up a little in the European market.
- LNG spot voyage prices continued their fall, with all three routes seeing similar falls of around 16-24%.
- LPG rates were relatively flat, with the BLPG1 route falling just over $1.5 over the week.

site_title: China stocks are a buy on reopening, top money managers say
summary: China stocks are expected to rally in 2023 due to a rebound in the country's economy as strict coronavirus measures are relaxed, according to a Bloomberg News survey of 134 fund managers. About 60% recommended buying China's stocks, citing cheap valuations and optimism about the country's reopening. Despite risks from government policy and regulations, investors see upside potential for earnings in China and downside potential in the US and Europe, with the MSCI China Index trading at 11 times forward earnings, below the average level for the past five years.

images.alt_text: The next week will be crucial, with rate decisions due from the Fed, Bank of England and European Central Bank.

site_title: Unsold private housing stock hits 15-year low, likely to help support prices in 2023
summary: Unsold private housing stock has reached a 15-year low, with 5,320 units under construction and not expected to increase in 2023. Strong demand and high land and building costs will keep prices elevated. This follows a 9-quarter decline in unsold units, with the last peak in Q2 2020 at 20,919 units. Developers are unlikely to lower prices due to diminishing inventory and strong demand, with a projected 7,500-8,000 private housing units sold in 2023, keeping inventory below 10,000 units.

site_title: To rein in Big Tech, Europe looked beyond lawsuits. Will the US follow?
summary: The US is taking a cautious approach to regulating big tech companies, unlike the European Union and Britain, which have passed legislation to limit their power. The Biden administration has nominated progressive antitrust enforcers, Jonathan Kanter and Lina Khan, to challenge large tech acquisitions and accuse companies of being monopolists. The Justice Department is investigating Google's dominance in online ads, but a final decision may take years. Experts suggest that new rules, such as mandated data sharing and interoperability, could bring more competition and new offerings for consumers, but tech companies warn that overly broad regulation can slow innovation and reduce investment.

site_title: Morocco’s foreign-born contingent deliver in Qatar
summary: Morocco's World Cup semi-final appearance can be attributed to their policy of seeking out talent in the diaspora. The team's 26-man squad features 14 players born outside the country, the most of any team at the tournament. This eclectic mix of players from growing migrant communities in Europe has helped Morocco break new ground, becoming the first African and Arab country to reach the World Cup's last four. Their 1-0 quarter-final win over Portugal marked a historic achievement for the team.

images.alt_text: Portugal’s Cristiano Ronaldo looks dejected after being eliminated from the World Cup, as Morocco’s Jawad El Yamiq looks on.

site_title: Bad news piles up for candidate Trump
summary: Donald Trump's presidential campaign has faced significant setbacks, with the former president struggling to gain momentum despite a year of investigations into his handling of the 2020 election and the January 6 Capitol attack. Trump's campaign has been marred by scandals, including his dinner with Kanye West and a white supremacist, and his calls to abandon the US Constitution. A recent Senate loss by his protege, Herschel Walker, and public statements from high-profile donors have further eroded his support. With the 2024 presidential election nearly two years away, Trump's ability to stage a comeback remains uncertain.

site_title: PM Lee on official visit to Germany before attending Asean-EU summit in Brussels
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is visiting Germany from Dec 12-13 before attending the Asean-EU Commemorative Summit in Brussels on Dec 14. During the visit, he will meet German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, officiate at the launch of two new Republic of Singapore Navy submarines, and be accompanied by his wife and key ministers. This visit comes after Scholz's trip to Singapore last month. The summit marks 45 years of Asean-EU dialogue relations and aims to deepen cooperation between the two regions.

images.alt_text: Singapore and Germany on Monday (Nov 14) endorsed a joint declaration, titled "Partners for a Resilient and Sustainable Future", outlining further bilateral co-operation between the two countries.

site_title: A black market for dollars emerges in crisis-stricken Pakistan
summary: A black market for US dollars has emerged in Pakistan due to the central bank's restriction on foreign currency access to preserve dwindling reserves. The shortage has led to a 10% premium on the black market, making it difficult for international travelers and importers to access dollars. The phenomenon adds to Pakistan's economic woes, which include devastating floods, an economic crisis, and political turbulence. The black market's emergence could signal weakness in the country's currency and negatively impact foreign investment and the business environment.

site_title: FTX founder Bankman-Fried 'willing to testify' before US House panel
summary: FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried has stated he is willing to testify before the US House Committee on December 13, despite having limited access to his data. This comes after Chairwoman Maxine Waters warned of a possible subpoena if he didn't appear. Bankman-Fried expressed his willingness to testify, but the nature of his appearance is unclear, whether in person or via video feed. The hearing is part of the ongoing investigation into the collapse of FTX, which filed for bankruptcy last month amidst a liquidity crisis.

site_title: Spirit Airlines offers big raises to pilots in new contract: union memo
summary: Spirit Airlines has offered a 43% cumulative weighted average pay raise to its pilots over two years, amounting to a $463 million economic gain, according to the Air Line Pilots Association. The deal, which includes a 34% cumulative weighted average pay increase, will become effective on January 1 if ratified by pilots. This move comes after Delta Air Lines offered a similar pay increase to its pilots last week, highlighting the bargaining power of pilots as airlines staff up to meet booming travel demand.

images.alt_text: Lawyers for JetBlue and American argued the alliance, which was announced in 2020, has not raised air fares or resulted in flight cuts. They say it has expanded flights and made them more competitive with Delta Air Lines and United Airlines on northeast routes.

site_title: China central bank official calls for orderly carbon reduction
summary: China's central bank official, Xuan Changneng, has called for an orderly transition to green economic activities, warning against "campaign-style" carbon reductions that could increase financial risks. Financial institutions must enhance their ability to identify green and low-carbon economic activities and cope with climate-related risks. The central bank plans to boost financial regulation and conduct stress tests tied to climate risks to prevent moral hazards. China aims to peak carbon emissions by 2030 and be carbon neutral by 2060, relying heavily on its banking system to support low-carbon projects and businesses.

site_title: Albertsons’ US$4b payout cleared by Washington state judge
summary: A Washington state judge cleared Albertsons to proceed with a $4 billion special dividend while its pending merger with Kroger is under regulatory review. The judge rejected a state attorney general's request to block the dividend, citing that Albertsons had already planned to disburse the funds before merger talks began. The decision extends a temporary hold on the dividend until Dec 19, and Kroger has expressed support for the deal. The US Federal Trade Commission is conducting an in-depth antitrust review of the merger, which is expected to be completed in 2024.

site_title: Standard Chartered Ventures is bucking the conventions of innovation
summary: Standard Chartered Ventures, a business unit of Standard Chartered Bank, is merging corporate innovation, investment, and venture-building to create a unique approach to innovation. Led by Alex Manson, SCV invests in startups and builds new ventures, taking calculated risks to achieve returns. The unit combines a corporate innovation unit with a venture fund, and also runs intrapreneur programs for employees and partners, aiming to drive commercially viable innovation. This approach is the result of learnings from previous experiences and seeks to marry innovation and investment to drive growth for the bank.

images.alt_text: Accelerator programmes at the three local banks have morphed beyond the usual dabbling with startups

site_title: No Signboard to sell IP rights to controlling shareholder GuGong
summary: No Signboard Seafood restaurant operator has entered into an agreement to sell its intellectual property rights to controlling shareholder GuGong for up to S$10,000. The sale includes trademarks and brand insignia, allowing GuGong to rebrand No Signboard's casual and quick-serve restaurant outlets. The rebranding exercise aims to refresh the company and adapt to the post-Covid-19 competitive landscape. Proceeds from the sale will go towards the rebranding exercise, which is conditional on GuGong voting in favor of proposals at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Wilmar, Wee Hur and TCA chairmen add to their stakes
summary: Institutional investors were net sellers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ended Dec 8, with a net outflow of S$359 million. The Straits Times Index declined 1.7% and the Hang Seng Index gained 3.7%, while the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI slipped 1.6%. DBS, OCBC, and Jardine Cycle & Carriage led the net institutional outflow. Share buybacks were conducted by 24 primary-listed companies, with Sembcorp Industries and Digital Core Reit Management being the most active. Director and substantial shareholder transactions were also reported, with Wilmar International, Chip Eng Seng Corporation, and Wee Hur Holdings seeing increased stakes.

site_title: Panama ex-president Martinelli to stand trial on money laundering charge
summary: Panamanian judge summons former president Ricardo Martinelli to stand trial for a money laundering charge related to the alleged purchase of a news outlet with public funds during his 2009-2014 term. Nearly 20 others are charged in connection with the "New Business" case. Martinelli, who maintains his innocence, claims he's being politically targeted and plans to run for president in 2024. This is the second trial against Martinelli announced this year, with both trials expected to take place in 2023.

site_title: Australian energy caps are necessary intervention, minister says
summary: Australian Energy Minister Chris Bowen supports price caps on domestic energy prices, citing the need to protect consumers from rising "war" prices. The caps, announced by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, aim to ease cost-of-living pressures. Bowen rejects the argument that the caps could reduce investment confidence and future supply, citing that gas was trading at the same level as the proposed cap price last year. The measures apply to domestic energy prices, excluding new installations and exports.

site_title: Morocco stun Portugal, becoming first African team ever to reach semi-finals
summary: Morocco stunned Portugal 1-0 in the World Cup quarter-finals, becoming the first African team to reach the semi-finals. The Atlas Lions, led by coach Walid Regragui, overcame a strong Portuguese side despite being down a man after Hakim Ziyech's yellow card. Morocco's sole goal was scored by Youssef En-Nesyri in the 42nd minute, and they held on for a crucial win after a tense second half. The victory sends Morocco to face either England or France in the semi-finals, capping off a fairy-tale run in Qatar.

site_title: France's Mediawan buys majority stake in Brad Pitt's Plan B
summary: French media company Mediawan has acquired a majority stake in Brad Pitt's production house Plan B Entertainment for over $300 million. The deal marks Mediawan's entry into the US market and values Plan B at more than $300 million. Plan B, co-founded by Pitt in the early 2000s, has produced three Best Picture Oscar winners, including "The Departed," "Twelve Years a Slave," and "Moonlight." Pitt expressed confidence in the partnership, stating that the company will continue to produce films and series globally.

images.alt_text: Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie  once one of Hollywood’s highest profile pairings, have been embroiled in a lengthy dispute over their marriage, custody of their six children and shared assets, including a French winery.

site_title: US presses UN on Israeli settlement business blacklist
summary: The US is pressuring the UN not to update a blacklist of companies doing business in Israeli settlements, despite calls for the list to be updated to stop expansion in the occupied Palestinian territory. The US Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, warned the incoming Israeli government that the US would oppose settlement expansion. The list, which was first published in 2020, poses a threat to companies in the region, according to the US, and reinforces an anti-Israel bias at the UN. The US has raised concerns with the UN human rights office, opposing any work to update the list.

site_title: World Cup: Argentines celebrate victory over Netherlands
summary: Argentine soccer team advances to the World Cup semifinals after a 4-3 penalty shootout victory over the Netherlands. The match, held on December 9, was watched by thousands of fans in Buenos Aires and marked the team's first win in the tournament. Led by star Lionel Messi, Argentina will face Croatia in the semifinals, with the opportunity to win the country's third World Cup title.

site_title: Xi offers use of Shanghai exchange for yuan energy deals with Gulf nations
summary: China's President Xi Jinping proposed using the Shanghai Petroleum and National Gas Exchange as a platform for yuan settlement of oil and gas trade with Gulf nations. He also announced plans for cooperation in finance, investment, innovation, aerospace, and language and cultures. Xi stated that China will continue to import large quantities of crude oil and liquefied natural gas from GCC countries, and will establish bilateral investment and economic cooperation working mechanisms. The proposal comes as China seeks to strengthen ties with the region amid strained relations with the US.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Arab leaders pose for a group photo during the China-Arab summit in Riyadh.

site_title: Fitch affirms United Kingdom rating at 'AA-'
summary: Fitch has reaffirmed the United Kingdom's sovereign debt rating at 'AA-', citing Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's macroeconomic policy framework and the sterling's international reserve currency status. Despite concerns about a potential recession, investors are optimistic about the new government's ability to restore confidence in the country's fiscal health. The agency also maintained its outlook for the country at 'negative' due to high debt and rising energy prices, and affirmed the Bank of England's rating at 'AA-' with a negative outlook.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng CEO Samuel Koh resigns to ‘pursue other interests’
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's CEO Samuel Koh has resigned, effective Jan 1, 2023, to pursue other interests. He will take on a consultant role until June 3, 2023, ensuring an orderly transition. Ong Yuh Hwang, current chief operating officer, will replace Koh as CEO. Deputy CFO Daphne Heng Hee Choo has been promoted to CFO, following Koh's departure.

images.alt_text: Ong will assist the group chief executive officer in managing the group’s operations and executing its strategic plans.
Yeo Hiap Seng saw stronger demand in Malaysia, Indonesia and Cambodia.

site_title: Why US power stations are vulnerable targets for attacks
summary: The US electric grid is vulnerable to attacks due to ageing infrastructure, extreme weather events, and a lack of security measures. Recent incidents, including a December attack on two North Carolina substations, have highlighted the risk. Substations, where power is stepped up and down, are particularly vulnerable, with over 79,000 in the US. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) has ordered utilities to develop security plans, but progress remains a work in progress. The US grid is under strain, with over 756,000 kilometers of circuits, and a shift to renewables has put additional pressure on the system.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on China optimism, but snap seven-week winning streak
summary: European shares rose 0.8% on Friday, snapping a five-day losing streak, driven by China-led optimism and industrial and financial stocks gains. The Stoxx 600 index closed the week down 1.1% despite recession worries ahead of central bank decisions, including the ECB's potential 50 basis point rate hike. Data on US jobless claims and China's easing of Covid curbs also boosted sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 slipped 0.2 per cent on Thursday, with investors jittery ahead of a slew of interest rate decisions from major central banks.

site_title: Rivian, Warner Bros Discovery to be added to Nasdaq 100
summary: Rivian Automotive and Warner Bros Discovery will join the Nasdaq 100 Index, replacing VeriSign, Skyworks Solutions, Splunk, Baidu, Match Group, DocuSign, and NetEase, as part of its annual rebalancing. The changes are effective December 19 and aim to clean out underperforming companies. The Nasdaq 100, dominated by mega tech, has declined 29% this year, with the S&P 500 Index down 17% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 8%. The additions are expected to provide increased equity trading liquidity and heightened visibility for the companies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6 per cent to close at 33,745.69, while the broad-based S&P 500 edged up 0.5 per cent to 3,965.34 on Friday.

site_title: Britain fines Santander bank over money laundering failures
summary: Britain fined Santander UK nearly £108 million for failing to properly oversee and manage its anti-money laundering systems between 2012 and 2017, affecting over 560,000 business customers. The Financial Conduct Authority found "serious and persistent gaps" in the bank's controls, leading to a prolonged risk of money laundering and financial crime. Santander accepted the conclusions and apologized, with the bank qualifying for a 30% discount on the fine.

images.alt_text: All employees earning under £35,000 (S$58,567) will be eligible for the rise, which covers 60 per cent of the bank's UK workforce, Santander said.
