site_title: Oil drops in volatile trade, records biggest weekly slump in months
summary: Oil prices dropped in volatile trading, recording their biggest weekly declines in months, amid growing recession fears and weakened demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude settled 44 US cents lower at $71.02 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 5 US cents to $76.10 per barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns about the economy, with the US Federal Reserve expected to raise interest rates, furthering recession fears.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled at US$76.15 a barrel on Thursday, losing US$1.02, or 1.3 per cent.
The recent declines have come against what should be a supportive backdrop for prices.

site_title: Bootleg album of jailed R&B star R Kelly surfaces on Spotify and Apple Music: media
summary: A previously unreleased R&B album by R. Kelly, "I Admit It," surfaced on Spotify and Apple Music, despite the artist being jailed for sex offenses. The 13-track album, featuring a 19-minute title song, was reportedly a bootleg copy and briefly made public before being removed. Kelly's lawyer claims intellectual property was stolen, and the singer denies involvement in the release. The album's release coincides with Kelly facing a sentence of 10-90 years in prison for federal prosecutors in Illinois.

site_title: IMF and Ghana expected to reach staff-level agreement by Tuesday: sources
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Ghana are expected to reach a staff-level agreement on a loan deal by Tuesday, December 13, according to sources. The agreement is expected to be an extended credit facility, providing financial assistance to Ghana due to its drawn-out balance of payments issues. Conditions for an external debt restructuring are the final hurdle, with an agreement expected to be reached on Friday, December 16.

site_title: Indian banks raise US$2b via infrastructure bonds in 2 weeks
summary: Indian banks have raised US$2 billion through infrastructure bonds over the last two weeks, anticipating a revival in private capital expenditure and government spending. Two private lenders and one state-run bank have tapped the market, with State Bank of India raising 100 billion rupees (S$1.6 billion) in the largest issue. Analysts attribute the surge in demand to a pick-up in economic activity, with several banks planning to issue similar funds in the coming weeks.

site_title: US producer prices increase in November
summary: US producer prices rose 0.3% in November, excluding volatile food, energy, and trade services components. This is slightly higher than expected and follows a 0.2% increase in October. The core producer price index rose 4.9% in the 12 months through November, after increasing 5.4% in October. The moderation in inflation could allow the Federal Reserve to slow interest rate hikes next week, as Fed Chair Jerome Powell hinted in December.

site_title: US stocks open lower as producer prices rise more than expected
summary: US stocks declined on Friday, December 9, as producer prices rose 0.3% in November, exceeding economists' expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.3%. The higher-than-expected inflation data fueled concerns about the pace of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, despite some analysts suggesting that producer costs may have peaked, supporting a slower pace of rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 finished 0.8 per cent higher at 3,963.51, its first positive session since Nov 30.

site_title: One Championship heads to Colorado for its big US debut
summary: One Championship, a Singapore-based combat sports organization, will debut in the US with its first live MMA event in Colorado on May 5, 2023. The event will be held at the 6,500-seat 1stBank Center arena in Broomfield. The main event will feature a world championship trilogy bout between flyweight world champion Demetrious Johnson and Adriano Moraes. One Championship Group President Teh Hua Fung stated that the company has grown to become one of the two largest combat sports organizations in the world, alongside UFC.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise as Asian markets close higher on Friday; STI up 0.3 per cent
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Friday, tracking a broader Asian market rally, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,245.97. The market saw 308 gainers and 207 decliners after 1.3 billion securities worth S$1 billion were traded. Key indices in Japan, Shanghai, Hong Kong, and South Korea also rose, driven by investors awaiting key inflation data and the US Federal Reserve's meeting next week.

site_title: A surge in tourists in restive Kashmir, but ‘no mental peace’ for residents
summary: Tourists have flocked to Jammu and Kashmir, India, in recent years, with over 2 million visitors this year, a threefold increase from the previous year. However, residents, including Kashmiris, report a lack of mental peace due to a heavy military presence and constant surveillance, which has reduced terror attacks but also led to a wave of assassinations of minority Hindus and militant recruitment. The region's semi-autonomous status was revoked in 2019, and the government has divided it into two separate union territories, each directly ruled by New Delhi. Despite a slight drop in terror incidents, residents remain fearful of the new normal, which they describe as "suppression" and "depression."

site_title: China's Xi meets Arab leaders in 'new era' of ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with Arab leaders in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, marking the first of two "milestone" summits, signaling a new era in China-Arab relations. Xi signed a strategic partnership pact with Saudi Arabia, which is seeking to balance its relations with the US and China amid strained ties with Washington. The summit emphasized cooperation on energy, non-interference, and a peaceful solution to the Ukraine conflict, with Beijing and Riyadh reaffirming their commitment to stability in global oil markets and non-oil trade.

images.alt_text: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Salman with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Riyadh. “The People’s Republic of China welcomed the Kingdom’s role as a supporter of the balance and stability in the world oil markets, and as a reliable major exporter of crude oil to China,” the joint statement carried on Saudi state media said.

site_title: China auto sales to hit 27.6m in 2023, up 3%
summary: China's auto sales are expected to rise 3% to 27.6 million in 2023, driven by economic recovery, despite rising Covid-19 infections. New-energy vehicle sales are projected to grow 35% to 9 million. Automakers and investors are bracing for a downturn, but CAAM expects increased government support to sustain the economy. The industry is also seeking an extension of government incentives, which are set to expire at the end of 2022.

images.alt_text: Sales of Chinese branded passenger cars, including Haval, Chery and Geely have surged, rising to 16,138 units in November, data from Russian analytical agency Autostat showed.

site_title: US sanctions Nasdaq-listed Chinese company over illegal fishing
summary: The US Treasury Department sanctioned Chinese company Pingtan Marine Enterprise (PME), listed on the Nasdaq exchange, for its involvement in illegal fishing in the Pacific. PME's owner, Xinrong Zhuo, was also sanctioned. The move aims to combat illegal and unregulated fishing globally, with the US citing violations of laws and regulations, human rights abuses, and environmental harm. The sanctions are part of a broader push to demonstrate the US's commitment to the region and follow previous sanctions against Russia and other countries.

images.alt_text: man, fishing net, lake

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower as investors digest economic data
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday as investors digested economic data and awaited a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Producer prices rose slightly more than expected in November, but the trend is moderating, with annual inflation at its smallest increase in 1-1/2 years. The S&P 500 declined 0.7% to 3,934.38 points, while the Nasdaq fell 0.7% to 11,004.62 points. Futures suggest a 77% chance of a 50-basis point interest rate hike next week, despite improved consumer sentiment and eased inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Monday, Dec. 13, 2021. site_title: Beijing approves mRNA vaccines for German nationals in China
summary: China has approved mRNA vaccines produced by Germany for German nationals living in the country, according to a foreign ministry spokeswoman. The agreement was reached after German Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced last month that China would make BioNTech SE's Covid-19 vaccine available to foreigners. The move aims to provide German expats in China with access to a vaccine, although specific arrangements will be discussed through diplomatic channels.

site_title: Strata Titles Board stops Chuan Park’s S$890m en bloc sale
summary: The Strata Titles Board has issued a stop order on the collective sale of Chuan Park, a 99-year leasehold condo in Singapore, after a group of six minority owners objected to the transaction. The owners alleged that the collective sale committee and marketing agent ERA Realty failed to disclose material facts, including a higher development baseline, which would have resulted in a "deep discount" for buyers. The majority owners must now apply to the High Court within 14 days to seek approval for the sale.

site_title: Seeking a natural fit: Tapping the new TNFD framework
summary: Singapore aims to develop 130 hectares of new parks by 2026 and 1,000 hectares of green spaces by 2035, as part of its efforts to protect nature and integrate its value into financial decisions. The city-state is addressing the challenges of nature-related financial disclosures through the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) framework. Project Greenprint, run by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), aims to build digital utilities for trusted sustainability data, including an ESG disclosure portal and a data orchestrator. Singapore also plans to play a leading role in reducing atmospheric carbon levels, with the goal of becoming a carbon services and trading hub.

images.alt_text: One of the key targets in the draft biodiversity pact is a commitment to protecting at least 30 per cent of land and water around the globe by 2030.

site_title: Agritrade’s Singaporean CFO duped major banks worldwide, causing ‘unprecedented’ S$631m in losses
summary: A former chief financial officer of Agritrade International, Lulu Lim Beng Kim, pleaded guilty to 12 charges, including cheating and falsification of accounts, for duping 16 financial institutions worldwide, causing losses of S$631 million. Lim instructed subordinates to submit unaudited and false financial statements, resulting in the disbursement of over US$586.5 million to suppliers and their subsidiaries. The case has tarnished Singapore's reputation, with Deputy Public Prosecutor seeking a 19½-year sentence. Lim claimed she was manipulated, but prosecutors noted her role as the No 2 or No 3 person in the company.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: French semiconductor manufacturer Soitec's CEO Pierre Barnbae expects the sector to return to growth due to high demand for components in emerging areas like electric vehicles.

site_title: China will issue 750b yuan in special treasury bonds
summary: China will issue 750 billion yuan (S$145.9 billion) three-year special treasury bonds on Dec 12, as the economy faces challenges from Covid-19 and a property downturn. This is the third such issuance, following 2020's one trillion yuan special treasury bonds. The move aims to fund stimulus and shore up the economy.

site_title: UK's Hunt says public-sector pay restraint needed to tame inflation
summary: UK finance minister Jeremy Hunt stated that the government may need to impose pay restraint on public-sector workers to combat high inflation. He warned that agreeing to pay rises that would not reduce inflation could have the opposite effect. Hunt cited forecasts that inflation will fall to 3.7% by early 2024. The government's approach is in line with the Bank of England's assessment that widespread pay rises will not bring a lasting recovery in living standards due to surging energy prices.

images.alt_text: Industrial action is becoming more widespread across Britain’s transport network.

site_title: China, Saudi Arabia affirm importance of stable global oil markets
summary: China and Saudi Arabia reaffirmed the importance of stable global oil markets during a visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping to the kingdom. The two nations pledged greater trade and economic cooperation, including exploring investment opportunities in petrochemicals and renewable energy. Saudi Arabia, the world's top oil exporter, welcomed China's recognition of its role in maintaining oil market stability. The two countries also signed a potential crude supply agreement and chemicals products offtake deal, with plans to collaborate on integrated refining and petrochemicals in China.

images.alt_text: Xi’s trip includes direct talks with Saudi Arabia, a wider meeting with the six-nation Gulf Arab alliance, and a summit with Arab leaders.

site_title: Sunshine Insurance Group ends flat in its trading debut
summary: Sunshine Insurance Group, a Beijing-based firm, ended flat in its trading debut after listing at HK$5.83 (S$1.01) on Friday, following a HK$6.7 billion (S$1.16 billion) IPO. The company's shares traded below the listing price, and the IPO raised a lower amount than expected due to high trading volatility. Despite this, analysts believe the valuation may match that of peers, citing a net income of US$244 million for the six months ended in June.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) logo is displayed atop a gong at the HKEX Connect Hall in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Most Hong Kong people were caught off-guard by Beijing's proposal of the national security bill. Executive Council Member and the Chairman of HKEX Laura Cha said she was also surprised but was convinced the bill would ensure clarity and stability of the city. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg

site_title: FTSE 100 up as financials gain on UK's move to reform sector
summary: The UK's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% on Friday as financial stocks gained on a government move to overhaul the sector and maintain the City of London's competitiveness. The move includes repealing EU rules and implementing 30 measures to boost investments. Energy stocks fell 1.2% due to subdued crude prices. The FTSE 100 is on track to end the week lower, with investors awaiting the Bank of England's interest rate decision next week.

images.alt_text: Median pay for the heads of FTSE 100 companies rose by more than a third last year to £3.41 million (S$5.6 million), according to research published on Monday.

site_title: 'It's dead out here': China's slow exit from zero-Covid
summary: China has loosened key parts of its zero-Covid policy, but many are wary of a speedy return to normalcy due to enduring anxieties about the coronavirus. Protests against Covid curbs in cities marked the biggest public discontent since President Xi Jinping's power, and some businesses are reluctant to drop their Covid curbs. The relaxed policy has yet to alleviate concerns, potentially hampering China's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: China announced a nationwide loosening of Covid-19 restrictions, which had been widely anticipated and was to have given markets a boost, but investors reacted instead by selling on the news.
With the Covid Zero policy being rapidly dismantled, the threat of economic disruption remains high.
Some cities and regions in China began relaxing Covid controls, in moves that heralded a nationwide loosening of the rules unveiled by the National Health Commission (NHC) on Wednesday.
Pedestrians pass an electronic board showing the numbers for the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong on December 5, 2022. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)

site_title: The Philippines expects wider balance-of-payments gap, lower reserves
summary: The Philippines' central bank forecasts a wider balance-of-payments gap, with a predicted deficit of $11.2 billion in 2022, down from an earlier estimate of $8.4 billion. Foreign exchange reserves are expected to end 2022 at $93 billion, down from $99 billion. The peso has gained 6% against the US dollar this quarter, easing trade pressures. The BSP attributes the forecast to persistent external risks, subdued global growth prospects, and a widening current account deficit.

images.alt_text: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas governor Felipe Medalla last week raised concerns about the wealth fund plan.
Felipe Medalla Photographer: Geric Cruz/Bloomberg

The bill, overseen by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, proposes that the fund may invest in various types of instruments including, cash, foreign currencies, metals, tradeable commodities, bonds, Islamic investments and listed or unlisted equities.
The peso has rebounded 3 per cent to 57.21 from the record-low 59 per dollar it touched in late September.

A security guard stands beside a logo of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) posted at the main gate in Manila, Philippines April 28, 2016.    REUTERS/Romeo Ranoco/File Photo

site_title: Philippine economic officials push for sovereign wealth fund
summary: Philippine economic officials are urging the passage of a sovereign wealth fund plan, which would source contributions from the central bank's dividends instead of pension funds. Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno stated that the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) would contribute its annual dividends into the fund for the first two years, with the option to contribute half in subsequent years. The plan aims to boost investment, funding of infrastructure, and reduce fiscal pressure, and would be run professionally with accountability measures in place.

images.alt_text: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas governor Felipe Medalla last week raised concerns about the wealth fund plan.
Felipe Medalla Photographer: Geric Cruz/Bloomberg

Philippine lawmakers believe that a sovereign wealth fund, to be chaired by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, will boost growth in the country, but critics warn that it will be prone to graft and risk Filipino pensions.

site_title: TSMC Nov revenue rises 50% despite Covid challenges
summary: TSMC reported a 50% increase in November revenue to NT$222.7 billion, driven by strong demand despite Covid challenges and slumping consumer electronics sales. The company has been investing heavily to expand production capacity and meet growing orders. TSMC's sales growth is attributed to a spike in demand during the pandemic and its exclusive supply of Apple's silicon chips for iPhones and Macs.

site_title: China regulators, state banks split staff on fears of new Covid outbreaks: sources
summary: Chinese regulators and state-owned banks are taking measures to split staff in Beijing due to lingering anxieties about new Covid-19 outbreaks. The arrangements include closed-loop systems, split-shift working, and rotating shifts to minimize exposure. This reflects the lingering fears created by Beijing's three-year 'zero-Covid' policy, which is likely to hinder a quick return to health for China's economy. The measures are also driven by concerns about the virus spreading quickly in the city, with companies and businesses taking precautions to stay open.

images.alt_text: China announced a nationwide loosening of Covid-19 restrictions, which had been widely anticipated and was to have given markets a boost, but investors reacted instead by selling on the news.
The producer price index (PPI) was down 1.3 per cent on a year earlier, unchanged from an annual contraction seen in October.

site_title: Eurozone banks to repay another 447b euros of central bank loans early
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced that eurozone banks will repay an additional 447.5 billion euros in multi-year loans early, reducing the ECB's oversized balance sheet. This follows a rate hike in hopes that banks would repay loans earlier, with 296 billion euros repaid last month. The ECB aims to tighten financing conditions, ease inflation, and temper demand, with the balance sheet expected to be reduced further. Analysts predict a 175 billion euro reduction in bond holdings next year, with the ECB planning to let some debt expire in a gradual process.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Bursa Malaysia launches first syariah-compliant carbon exchange platform
summary: Bursa Malaysia has launched the world's first Shariah-compliant carbon exchange platform, Bursa Carbon Exchange (BCX). The first trade of carbon credits via auction is set to take place in March 2023. The platform aims to promote local capabilities for the voluntary carbon market (VCM) ecosystem, encouraging participation from project developers, investors, and buyers. The online auction is currently at the testing stage, with carbon projects in the final stage of screening. This move is expected to support Malaysia's transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: Integrity problem of carbon credits overhyped, say market players
Bursa Malaysia to launch carbon exchange on Dec 9

site_title: Zurich Insurance front-runner to buy MetLife’s Malaysia insurer
summary: Zurich Insurance Group has emerged as the front-runner to buy a majority stake in AmMetLife Insurance, a Malaysian insurance business owned by US insurer MetLife and Kuala Lumpur-listed AMMB Holdings. A deal could value AmMetLife at about US$400 million and would require approval from the Malaysian central bank. If the transaction materializes, MetLife will exit its investment in AmMetLife while AMMB will retain a 30% stake. Deliberations are ongoing, and the companies could still decide not to proceed with the transaction.

images.alt_text: AMMB has been approached by other industry players and private equity firms which have expressed interest in AmInvest, the people said.

site_title: Korea EV supercharging maker opens US office, expands in Japan
summary: South Korean EV supercharging station maker Chaevi is expanding its presence in the US and Japan, opening a Silicon Valley office and considering a US manufacturing base. The company, which has installed 26,000 EV chargers since 2016, aims to build an ultra-fast network in the US. The move is driven by the Inflation Reduction Act and the growing demand for cleaner transportation. Chaevi will partner with automakers in Japan, going up against established players like Tesla and EVgo.

images.alt_text: Toyota unveiled the new Prius last month amid criticism from ESG investors and environmental groups for its slow rollout of fully electric vehicles.
Apple had previously discussed launching a car that looks similar to Canoo’s Lifestyle Vehicle.
More advanced and connected medical devices are coming to the market and being adopted by consumers and healthcare providers.

site_title: China, HK stocks extend rally as Beijing eases Covid rules
summary: China's benchmark CSI300 Index gained 1% to a 12-week high, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.3%, as investors grew optimistic about the country's recovery following eased Covid-19 measures. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index climbed 2.3%, with a surge in property shares driven by support from state banks and a developer's restructuring proposal. The government's plans to boost vaccination and reopen the economy also boosted investor sentiment, with Morgan Stanley upgrading Chinese equities earlier this week.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass an electronic board showing the numbers for the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong on December 5, 2022. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia’s unemployment down to lowest level since start of Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Malaysia's unemployment rate remained steady at 3.6% in October, the lowest since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, according to the Department of Statistics Malaysia. The number of employed persons increased by 0.2% to nearly 16.1 million, while the labour force grew by 0.2% to almost 16.7 million. The services sector saw significant growth, particularly in food and beverages services, wholesale and retail trade, and finance and insurance activities. The country's steady economic fundamentals and growing economic and social activities are expected to maintain its growth momentum despite global uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's economy recorded double digits growth in Q3 2022, driven by strong domestic consumption and robust exports.

site_title: Indonesia's new laws a threat to privacy, press and human rights, says UN
summary: The United Nations has expressed concern over Indonesia's new criminal code, which it says threatens civil liberties, including press freedom, privacy, and human rights. The revised laws include provisions that criminalize insulting the president, spreading fake news, and promoting contraception to minors. The code also includes "morality clauses" that could affect reproductive and privacy rights and exacerbate gender-based violence. The UN warns that these laws could contravene Indonesia's international human rights obligations and disproportionately impact LGBT individuals and women.

images.alt_text: People enjoy the beach during sunset in Jimbaran, Bali, Indonesia, September 2, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: China embargo on Taiwan fish deepens in wake of Pelosi trip
summary: China has significantly reduced imports of Taiwanese fish and crustaceans, importing $56 million worth in the six months from May to October, compared to $138 million in the same period last year. This move is part of China's punishment for Taiwan's expanding ties with the US and its allies, with the majority of recent purchases being non-human consumption products. The reduction affects a small fraction of Taiwan's $328 billion two-way trade with China, but has raised concerns among Taiwanese businesses.

images.alt_text: The sand export ban cuts off the island's main source of the construction material.

site_title: China's producer prices fall, consumer inflation slows on soft demand
summary: China's producer prices fell 1.3% in November, marking a second consecutive month of decline, while consumer inflation slowed to 1.6%, its slowest pace in eight months. The data suggests weak economic activity and soft demand, prompting analysts to expect the government to keep interest rates low and take measures to boost confidence. The government's focus on stabilizing growth, promoting domestic demand, and opening up to the outside world was reaffirmed in a high-level meeting, with economists predicting further measures to spur the economy.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on November 17, 2022 shows a worker manufacturing transformers at a factory in Haian in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: AI-generated anime selfies propel beauty app to top in Japan
summary: Meitu, a Hong Kong-based AI-driven technology company, has seen its shares jump 50% after its app's ability to turn selfies into anime characters propelled it to the top of Japan's download rankings. The app, available on Apple's App Store in multiple countries, including the US, Brazil, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, has seen global downloads surge 79% since November 28. Meitu's CEO, Wu Xinhong, attributes the success to the app's AI technology, which has become a viral sensation among users.

images.alt_text: The service will offer personalised birthday and holiday video greetings from animated children’s characters.
Ele.me would be 1 of the biggest players to date that Douyin, the Chinese equivalent of TikTok, has brought into its mini-programme platform that it launched some 2 years ago.

site_title: Razer wins lawsuit against IT vendor over data leak, awarded S$8.7m in damages
summary: Razer wins a lawsuit against IT vendor Capgemini, awarded S$8.7 million in damages, largely US$6.1 million in loss of profits from its e-commerce platform due to a data leak in September 2020. The leak affected thousands of customers worldwide, compromising shipping information and order details. The High Court verdict is a significant win for Razer, which sued Capgemini in 2020 over the breach, seeking compensation for the financial losses incurred.

images.alt_text: Home-grown gaming hardware company Razer has sued an IT vendor for allegedly causing a widely reported cybersecurity breach in 2020 that resulted in a leak of its customer and sales data.

site_title: Australia to cap prices of coal, gas to drive down energy bills
summary: The Australian government has capped coal and gas prices for a year to help households and businesses affected by the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Coal prices will be capped at A$125 per tonne, while gas prices will be capped at A$12 per gigajoule. The government will also provide up to A$1.5 billion in assistance to homes and small businesses. However, power producers have expressed concerns that the price cap may deter future investment in supply, potentially driving up prices in the long run.

images.alt_text: Projects that could be affected by Clough's collapse span Australia, Mongolia and Papua New Guinea.

An oil pipeline is laid next to the Vopak-Dialog oil storage facility (R) and a Refinery and Petrochemical Integrated Development (RAPID) project construction site in Pangerang in Malaysia's southern state of Johor October 6, 2015. Liquefied Petroleum Gas, long a niche product used by the poor to cook and the rich to barbecue, has become a rare bright spot amid a broad commodities rout, riding on the wave of strong economic growth in India and parts of Southeast Asia.   REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: Australian court dismisses suit against Google over personal data use
summary: Australia's competition regulator had its lawsuit against Google dismissed by a court, with the Federal Court ruling that Google's 2016 policy change combining personal data was not misleading. The court found that users were given the option to accept policy changes and that Google did not reduce account holders' rights under the privacy policy. The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission had alleged that Google misled consumers about the expanded use of personal data for targeted advertising. The decision was made on December 9, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia narrows scope of probe into alleged misuse of Covid-era funds
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency, the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC), has narrowed its investigation into alleged misuse of Covid-era funds to RM92.5 billion (S$28.3 billion) out of a total of RM600 billion. The investigation focuses on funds spent by the government between 2020 and 2021 on stimulus packages, with the finance ministry set to submit details on public fund usage next week. The agency's decision comes after the government reported spending RM530 billion on stimulus packages in 2020 and 2021, with RM437.5 billion coming from external funds.

site_title: Soitec CEO remains positive on semiconductor growth
summary: Soitec CEO Pierre Barnabe remains optimistic about the semiconductor industry's growth, citing emerging areas like electric vehicles as drivers of demand. He expects the sector to become a trillion-dollar industry by 2030. The French company has broken ground on a 400 million euro extension to its Wafer Fab Park in Singapore, which will double its annual production capacity and add 45,000 square meters of clean room and office space. Soitec sees Singapore playing a key role in the sector, with plans to double its workforce to over 600 by 2026.

images.alt_text: Paul Boudre, CEO, Soitec.

In recent years, several global chip firms have announced substantial investments to expand their operations in Singapore as part of plans to ramp up production capacity amid the global chip shortage.

site_title: Catering to new, young investors
summary: Singapore's growing online brokerages and increasing financial literacy among young investors signal a surge in retail investing, driven by the city-state's rising income levels. The rise of online brokerages has led to a decrease in fees, attracting tech-savvy first-time investors who seek information on investing in US markets. Retail investors are increasingly seeking access to professional-level trading tools and data, such as order book depth, to make informed decisions. As financial literacy improves, the demand for sophisticated information and data analytics is expected to grow, setting the stage for continued growth in trading and brokerage accounts in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Sign-up page for the Thrive newsletter, which will provide weekly advice on career, money and life. Find out more at bt.sg/thrive.

site_title: FTX debacle: End of the bromance between institutional investors and crypto?
summary: The FTX debacle has raised concerns about the utility and legitimacy of cryptocurrencies, potentially ending the "bromance" between institutional investors and crypto. Despite the allure of high returns, institutional investors have been warming up to cryptocurrencies, with firms like BlackRock, Fidelity, and BNY Mellon partnering with crypto companies. However, the FTX collapse has highlighted the risks of regulatory capture, offshore finance havens, and the dangers of high-risk assets, leading to a decline in institutional interest and a decrease in the appetite for high-risk assets in a rising interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Crypto is but a get-rich-quick lie, wrapped in hype, bobbing on an ocean of libertarian technobabble -- that's the grim reality.

Northern Rock customers queue from the banks entrance,left, onto the pavement outside the branch in Golders Green, London, U.K., on Monday, Sept. 17, 2007.Northern Rock Plc, the U.K. mortgage lender bailed out by the Bank of England last week, tumbled to a seven-year low in London trading after customers lined up at branches across the country to withdraw their savings. Photographer: Will Wintercross/Bloomberg News

This photo illustration shows the logo of cryptocurrency FTX, reflected in its website on a laptop screen in Washington, DC, on November 13, 2022. - The new chief executive of troubled cryptocurrency platform FTX said on November 12, 2022, the company was making "every effort to secure all assets" following unauthorized transactions potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Additionally, the platform's chief executive, 30-year-old Sam Bankman-Fried, once considered a star in the freewheeling cryptocurrency world, resigned. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: Truckers’ union in South Korea vote to end strike
summary: South Korean truckers' union voted 62% in favor of ending a nationwide strike, which had disrupted supply chains. The strike, involving 25,000 unionized truckers and non-union drivers, aimed to pressure the government into making a minimum wage programme permanent and wider in scope. The decision to end the strike came after the government increased pressure, prompting some drivers to return to work, risking lost income and jobs.

site_title: US plans sanctions on Russia, China: officials
summary: The US plans to impose new sanctions on Russia and China, targeting Russian defense industry entities for using Iranian drones in Ukraine and 170 Chinese entities for alleged illegal fishing in the Pacific. The sanctions will be imposed under the Global Magnitsky Act, freezing assets and banning officials from entering the US. The move comes amid concerns over China's maritime influence and the US has condemned Iran's export of military drones to Russia. The sanctions are expected to be announced on Friday.

site_title: Delegates at regional meeting on labour issues reaffirm support for tripartism
summary: Delegates at the 17th Asia and the Pacific Regional Meeting (APRM) in Singapore reaffirmed their commitment to tripartism, a collaborative approach to promote shared economic and social goals among unions, employers, and the government. The meeting adopted the Singapore Statement, outlining priorities in labour policies and actions for participating countries, and a to-do list for the United Nations' International Labour Organization (ILO). The countries agreed to address persistent work deficits, including the lack of social protections and gender gaps, and to work towards a human-centred recovery from the Covid-19 crisis.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Tripartism was important in saving jobs, supporting workers and businesses, and protecting livelihoods during the pandemic, Manpower Minister Tan See Leng says.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Markets struggle for inspiration (Ep 24)
summary: Singapore markets struggled to find inspiration this week, with a lack of clear market drivers contributing to the uncertainty. According to SGX's wrap, the market was influenced by various factors, including the US Federal Reserve's comments. Claressa Monteiro, the host of the podcast, analyzed the situation and provided insights from The Business Times' newsdesk. The episode also covered notable market-driving news and company-focused news. The episode aims to provide general information only and is not intended to be a source of investment advice.

images.alt_text: How did the Fed affect markets this week?
Why did enthusiasm drive sentiment this week?

site_title: AirAsia turns to Cambodia with new airline after woes elsewhere
summary: AirAsia is launching a new low-cost airline in Cambodia, following a reorganization of its network after the collapse of a joint venture in Japan and the sale of an Indian affiliate. The airline aims to begin operations late next year, starting with two aircraft, and expand to 15 planes. Cambodia's population of 13 million and tourism potential make it an attractive market, and AirAsia expects the new airline to be profitable "from the get-go".

images.alt_text: Capital A posted an operating loss of 491.3 million ringgit (S$153.3 million) for the 3 months ended June 30, compared to a loss of 792.2 million ringgit in the year-ago period.

site_title: Google Ad Manager outage costs big websites ad sales
summary: Google's Ad Manager service, used by major news publishers to sell and display ads, was down for approximately three hours on Dec 8, resulting in significant revenue loss for affected websites. The outage occurred during a key revenue period and was deemed a "P0" incident, Google's highest-priority designation. News outlets such as the New York Times and Los Angeles Times were impacted, with one source estimating lost revenue of thousands of dollars per hour. The outage highlights concerns over Google's market power and lack of competition, with lawmakers pursuing legislation to curb its influence.

images.alt_text: “Since 2014, we’ve worked hard to implement the right to be forgotten in Europe, and to strike a sensible balance between people’s rights of access to information and privacy,” a Google spokesperson said.

site_title: Harry & Meghan review — a Netflix appeal for both admiration and pity
summary: The Netflix documentary series "Harry & Meghan" has sparked controversy and mixed reactions. The couple, who stepped down from royal duties in 2020, share their story, but the tone is often perceived as seeking admiration and pity. The documentary lacks explosive revelations, instead focusing on the couple's personal struggles and experiences. Critics argue that the show relies on the Netflix formula of stretching out content over several episodes, making it feel slow-paced and uneventful. The series has dominated UK media coverage, but its impact is uncertain, leaving viewers divided on its value and significance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Britain's Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, Duke and Duchess of Sussex, arrive for the annual Salute to Freedom Gala at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in Manhattan in New York City, U.S., November 10, 2021. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz/File Photo
A recent British poll suggested that Prince Harry and his wife Meghan are now the least popular senior royals apart from the disgraced Prince Andrew.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz commits to making electric vehicles in Thailand
summary: Mercedes-Benz has committed to manufacturing electric vehicles in Thailand, signing an agreement to import and assemble battery-powered cars in the country. The luxury carmaker will receive incentives, including lower import duties and excise taxes, and is likely to produce electric car models at its Samut Prakan plant. This move follows other global brands entering Thailand's electric passenger car market, including Tesla and BYD. Thailand aims to have 30% of car sales be electric by 2030, with the government allocating 43 billion baht for achieving this goal.

images.alt_text: epa10338458 A woman walks past a large Mercedes Benz logo during the media day of the 39th Thailand International Motor Expo 2022 in Bangkok, Thailand, 30 November 2022. More than 30 car brands as well as electric vehicles and motorcycles are showcased at the 12 day expo, running from 01 to 12 December 2022.  EPA-EFE/DIEGO AZUBEL

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by Wall Street gains, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,246.01 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 32, led by Sembcorp Marine's 2.8% gain. Local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC also opened on positive notes. The S&P 500 finished up 0.8% after tech shares rallied, snapping a five-day losing streak.

images.alt_text: Across the broader Singapore market, gainers outnumbered losers 304 to 222 after 1.4 billion securities worth S$928.7 million changed hands on Thursday.

site_title: Lessons from one woman’s ascent to a CEO job in Japan
summary: Makiko Ono, 62, has become the first female chief executive of Suntory's listed beverage and food unit, marking a significant milestone for women in Japan's corporate world. Despite a government-led push for female empowerment, only 8.2% of Japanese companies have female presidents. Ono's rise shows that more is needed to address gender imbalance, including mentoring programs and a shift towards merit-based evaluation. Her appointment is seen as a step towards increasing diversity on Japanese company boards and promoting women's economic independence.

images.alt_text: “The conversation around women and leadership was really dominated by bias and discrimination,” gender researcher Leah Sheppard says. “We thought that there was a place to talk about women’s agency: Are women actually intending to pursue these positions as much as men?”

site_title: Will they or won’t they? The risk of betting on the Fed
summary: The article discusses recent market volatility and speculation about the Federal Reserve's next move. In March 2020, the Fed responded to the COVID-19 pandemic by extending liquidity to prevent a financial crisis, similar to its actions during the 2008 global financial crisis. The article notes that market participants were on edge, with the Dow Jones plummeting nearly 3,000 points. The Fed's actions helped calm the markets, but the article also mentions ongoing speculation about the Fed's future moves, which continues to drive market volatility.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - SEPTEMBER 19: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve Board Building is seen on September 19, 2022 in Washington, DC. The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) is set to hold its two-day meeting on interest rates starting on September 20.   Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Disney+ streaming service launches with major advertisers
summary: Disney+ launched an ad-supported version on December 8, attracting major advertisers and introducing a second revenue source for the streaming service. Over 100 brands, including Mattel and Marriott Hotels & Resorts, are participating in the launch. The ad-free version of Disney+ now costs $10.99 per month, while the ad-supported version costs $7.99. Researcher Kantar predicts that one out of four Disney+ subscribers may switch to the less expensive ad-supported version. The move aims to supplement subscription fees and push Disney's streaming business into profitability.

images.alt_text: Disney is grappling with massive changes in how consumers watch movies and TV shows.

site_title: Temasek's PSA explores multi-billion dollar exit from Hutchison Ports: sources
summary: Temasek Holdings, the owner of PSA International, is exploring a potential multi-billion dollar exit from its 20% stake in CK Hutchison Holdings' ports business. The move comes as PSA reviews its portfolio amid muted global shipping activity. Potential bidders include Chinese port operators, shipping lines, and global infrastructure funds. A successful deal would depend on regulatory approvals and valuation, with Temasek executives previously indicating a slowdown in investments due to the deteriorating global economy.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s port, which served as a “catch-up” port for ships that faced delays elsewhere, handled a record high container throughput of 37.5 million TEUs last year, said Senior Minister of State for Transport Chee Hong Tat.

site_title: Toshiba’s preferred bidder moving closer to securing financing for buyout: sources
summary: Toshiba's preferred bidder, Japan Industrial Partners (JIP), has moved closer to securing financing for its planned buyout. JIP's proposed restructuring steps have made lenders, including Sumitomo Mitsui Banking and Mizuho Bank, more confident in its post-acquisition plans. JIP aims to secure commitments from banks this month for a buyout valued at around 2.2 trillion yen ($21.8 billion), including debt. Key lenders have not yet finalized how much they will take on in financing, but JIP's bid includes a proposal to retain Toshiba management, which has made some banks cautious.

images.alt_text: The lenders are reviewing the JIP-led group’s plans for Toshiba’s business, and to assess whether the loans will be redeemed on schedule.

site_title: Funds bet Asia ESG stocks will bounce back on policy tailwinds
summary: Investors are becoming more optimistic about Asia's clean-energy stocks, betting on a comeback next year due to attractive valuations and policy support. Funds such as Nikko Asset Management and M&G Investments are investing in environmental, social and governance (ESG) themes, driven by trends like China's reopening and the transition of "dirty" businesses in the region. This shift is expected to boost stock performance, following a tough year for responsible investment funds that had faced greenwashing concerns and commodity price volatility.

images.alt_text: ESG scores can be problematic for investors because they’re largely based on self-reported and unaudited data from companies.
Hecker says the development will probably impact some of the biggest climate coalitions, pressuring them to “level up their standards”.

site_title: Gold flat as traders await US inflation data, Fed meet next week
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,788.56 per ounce, awaiting US inflation data and the Federal Reserve's rate hike decision next week. Market participants expect a 93% chance of a 50-basis point rate hike, which may increase the opportunity cost of holding gold. The US Consumer Price Index report for November will also be closely watched. The US labor market remains strong, despite recession fears, and China's economic recovery is expected to be delayed due to COVID-19 surges.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China raised holdings to 63.67 million troy ounces as of end-November, from 62.64 million in the prior month, according to data on its website on Wednesday (Dec 7).
High interest rates have weighed on gold’s traditional status as a hedge against inflation and other uncertainties this year.

site_title: Median rents for three-bedroom condos in Orchard hit S$15,000 in November: report
summary: Median rents for three-bedroom condos in Orchard, Singapore reached S$15,000 in November, a 13.1% increase over the last quarter. Landlords are pushing rents up to meet mortgage payments amid rising interest rates and a looming recession. The top submarkets for condominium rents were Orchard, Raffles Place, and Tanglin, with median rents of S$15,000, S$12,400, and S$9,750, respectively.

images.alt_text: URA does not prescribe sizes for different unit types within a development, provided they follow the broader set of measures that are already in place.
Photo by Yen Meng Jiin. Generic pictures of properties in Singapore
HDB rents for October increased by 1.8 per cent from the previous month, with mature and non-mature estate rents rising by 1.6 per cent and 2.1 per cent respectively.

Despite the rising rental prices, volumes for both the HDB and condo markets remain strong as “it is still a landlord’s market now”, said Christine Sun, Orange Tee & Tie’s senior vice president of research and analytics.

site_title: India’s Paytm considers share buyback
summary: Paytm, India's largest digital payments company, is considering a share buyback due to its current low stock price. The announcement comes after SoftBank Group sold a 4.5% stake in November. Paytm's parent company, One97 Communications, plans to meet on December 13 to discuss the proposal, which the management believes could be beneficial for shareholders given the company's liquidity and financial position. The buyback would come at a time when Paytm's shares are trading 75% lower than their stock market debut last year.

site_title: Amazon is launching TikTok-style feed in bet on social commerce
summary: Amazon has launched Inspire, a TikTok-style feed allowing customers to discover products through curated photos and videos. The feature, set to roll out to select US customers in early December and nationwide in the next few months, will use over 20 interests to tailor feeds and enable purchases from customers, brands, and influencers. This move aims to improve shopper engagement and discovery on the platform, following the success of social commerce in China.

images.alt_text: AWS has long been a profit engine, sometimes accounting for all of the parent company’s operating income.

site_title: US mortgage rates fall for a fourth week, sending 30-year to 6.33%
summary: US mortgage rates fell for a fourth week, dropping to 6.33% for a 30-year, fixed loan. This marks the largest drop since 2008, with rates tumbling three quarters of a point over the past four weeks. The decline may provide hope for the flagging housing market, but buyer sentiment remains low due to economic uncertainty. Experts say borrowing costs must fall further to have a positive impact on sales, and investors await November data on consumer prices and the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates.

images.alt_text: Workers produce some of the specialized valves at Emerson Electric Co.’s factory in Marshalltown, Iowa, U.S., July 26, 2018. Picture taken on July 26, 2018.   REUTERS/Timothy Aeppel/File Photo

site_title: Rebooting sustainable finance and ESG
summary: The global push for sustainable finance and Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investment is facing criticism and backlash, particularly in the US. Despite the need for massive financing to combat climate change, commitments are insufficient, and financing gaps remain, especially for developing countries. The US has seen increasing pushback against ESG investment, with states like Texas and Florida banning ESG factors from investment decisions. In contrast, companies like Shell and BlackRock are being called out for their "hypocrisy" on ESG. To address these concerns, there is a need for universal ESG standards and convergence among companies, governments, and investors.

images.alt_text: Solar panels on the rooftop of an HDB block in Ang Mo Kio. Singapore is looking to quadruple its solar energy deployment by 2025 by covering the rooftops of its public housing blocks with solar panels.

More than ever, we need the companies making progress on sustainability to inspire their peers - this is impossible if progress is happening in silence, says Renat Heuberger, CEO of South Pole. (PHOTO SOUTH POLE)

“We need to have much clearer guidance from the authorities to make sure we aren’t misled and we aren’t being sold greenwashed investment products,” Guillaume Prache, managing director of Better Finance, said in an interview.

site_title: DBS picks FCT, LReit, CLCT as proxies to a rebound in China tourist spending
summary: DBS predicts China's tourist spending will rebound in 2023 as Covid-19 restrictions ease. Analysts expect consumers to prioritize spending on necessities, reducing discretionary spending. The bank cites rising costs of living and mortgages as contributing factors. DBS names FCT, LReit, and CLCT as proxy stocks for a potential rebound in China's tourist spending, citing their exposure to the country's retail sector.

images.alt_text: 联实全球商业REIT初始投资组合包括坐落在乌节路一带的零售项目313@somerset购物中心。（档案照片）
Compared to last year, retail brands have expanded their range of products and stocked up on inventory in preparation for the holiday shopping season.
Some trends suggest that malls at Orchard Road, which is now lit up for Christmas, may see brighter prospects than suburban malls.

site_title: Cash use slips to just 15% of British purchases in 2021
summary: The British Retail Consortium reported that cash usage in retail transactions decreased to 15% in 2021, down from nearly 40% before the pandemic. Debit cards accounted for 67% of transactions, while credit cards made up 15%. Adjusting for transaction size, cash was used for just 8% of retail spending. This shift is attributed to government advice to go contactless during the pandemic and a surge in online shopping. The BRC urged the government to intervene to ensure cash remains viable for shoppers, citing the high cost of handling cash and the need to limit payment provider fees.

site_title: UK rents rose twice as fast as wages in the past year
summary: UK rents rose 12.1% in the past year, outpacing wages growth of 6%, with rent now accounting for 35% of average earnings, the highest level since 2009. London rents are particularly burdensome, with 48.4% of average wages going towards rent. The shortage of new rental properties and rising mortgage rates are exacerbating the issue, with renters facing gentler price hikes if they stay in the same property but more pain if they move. Experts warn of a "tipping point" where rents become unaffordable, potentially leading to landlord-tenant disputes.

images.alt_text: Spending remained flat when compared to a year ago, reflecting a sharp real-terms decline given the high rate of inflation.

site_title: Poorest nations need US$436b to tackle Covid aftermath: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that the world's 69 poorest countries need an additional $436 billion over five years to address the COVID-19 aftermath and rebuild external buffers. The funds will be split into $170 billion to tackle pandemic effects and $266 billion to help low-income nations catch up with emerging markets' spending ratios by 2026. The lost output through 2026 is projected to be $4 trillion, with about one-third of the world economy experiencing at least two consecutive quarters of contraction this year and next.

images.alt_text: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said that during the Beijing meetings she intends to discuss ways to accelerate China’s participation in debt relief for poor and developing countries as the world’s largest official bilateral creditor.

site_title: Credit Suisse raises US$4.3b capital after wild ride
summary: Credit Suisse has completed a 4 billion-franc (S$5.8 billion) capital increase to shore up its finances after billions in losses and recent client defections. The bank raised 2.24 billion francs through a rights offer, with investors agreeing to buy 98.2% of the stock. This is the second leg of the bank's capital raising, following a 1.76 billion franc private placement last month. The move aims to put to rest concerns about the bank's financial strength and allows CEO Ulrich Koerner to embark on a comprehensive restructuring.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse and SoftBank have engaged in a series of shadow legal skirmishes in the US and UK ahead of the filing of the claim.

site_title: United Airlines, Boeing set to announce major 787 order: sources
summary: United Airlines is set to announce a major order for Boeing 787 Dreamliners, with the airline's CEO, Scott Kirby, and Boeing's CEO, Stan Deal, scheduled to attend the announcement at a Boeing factory. The order is expected to be over 100 wide-body airplanes, following a report that United was evaluating offers from Boeing and Airbus SE's A350. The announcement comes after Boeing faced a setback when Congress failed to extend a deadline for introducing a new safety standard for the 737 MAX.

images.alt_text: The proposal hasn’t been finalised and is opposed by some lawmakers and family members of passengers who died in the crashes of two 737 Max planes in 2018 and 2019.
The aviation industry has been beset by parts shortages on everything from small components to engines.

site_title: Be greedy when others are fearful, Warren Buffett said. Here’s why this is very hard to do
summary: Warren Buffett advises investors to be greedy when others are fearful, as this can help avoid behavioral biases and market timing mistakes. Despite this, many investors tend to jump in late, holding onto expectations of falling markets. A notable example is the 2020 S&P 500 collapse, where Google searches for the term "S&P 500" spiked, and anecdotal evidence suggests many investors made their first trades during this time. This highlights the difficulty in resisting irrational tendencies and timing the market.

images.alt_text: Bear market
CPF could be on the brink of adjusting Special Account interest rates, as 10-year Singapore government bond yields have climbed to more than 3.1 per cent

site_title: Mystery of Terra collapse deepens with possible FTX role raised
summary: US prosecutors are investigating Sam Bankman-Fried, founder of collapsed crypto exchange FTX, for his possible involvement in the collapse of the Terra algorithmic stablecoin ecosystem, which wiped out around $40 billion in market value in May. The investigation raises questions about the role of FTX and its sister trading platform Alameda Research in the Terra ecosystem's downfall. The collapse was attributed to a "death spiral" caused by traders swapping UST for Luna, which led to a loss of confidence in one token causing the other to plummet in value.

images.alt_text: Like in the US, legions of people in East Asia were drawn to Sam Bankman-Fried’s righteous nerd-of-the-people veneer.
the Seoul Southern District Court rejected a request for an arrest warrant as they do not believe Shin poses a flight risk or would destroy evidence.

site_title: China delivers first jet aimed at rivalling Boeing and Airbus
summary: China has delivered its first C919 passenger jet, a narrowbody aircraft aimed at rivaling Boeing and Airbus. The C919, made by Commercial Aircraft of China, is one of five ordered by China Eastern Airlines and is set to start flying commercially next spring. The plane features 164 seats and is priced at $99 million, although costs for comparable Airbus and Boeing models are not disclosed. The delivery marks a significant milestone in China's aviation ambitions, but faces an uphill battle to challenge the European and American manufacturing duopoly.

images.alt_text: A COMAC C919 passenger jet taxis on the runway after after making its maiden flight from the Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, China, on Saturday 05 May, 2017. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The C919 had received a type certificate in September declaring the model safe to fly but each individual jet manufactured had needed a separate sign-off from the regulator upon production.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed with focus on US inflation data, Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday, with Hong Kong and Tokyo rising, while Shanghai and Jakarta edged down. Optimism about China's economic reopening contrasts with concerns about rising interest rates and a possible recession. The US Federal Reserve is expected to announce a 50 basis point interest rate hike, despite uncertainty about the strength of the US economy and potential for a moderate recession. Analysts warn of further pain for US markets, while some see China's reopening as a positive factor for Asian markets.

site_title: Japan vows to stick to budget balancing goal despite defence boost
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki reaffirmed the country's commitment to achieving a primary budget surplus by the 2025 fiscal year, despite plans to boost defense spending. The 43 trillion yen defense spending over five years poses a challenge to Japan's fiscal target. Suzuki emphasized the need for fiscal discipline and ruled out issuing additional debt. Instead, the government plans to reform spending, tap unused budget and non-tax revenue, and increase taxes in stages to fund the increased defense spending.

site_title: US SEC presses firms to disclose exposure to crypto bankruptcies
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has released guidance for publicly traded companies to disclose their exposure to the crypto market, particularly in light of the collapse of FTX. The guidance requires companies to address the general impact of crypto-market developments, assess counterparty risk, and explain how they safeguard customers' crypto assets. The SEC is seeking to address crypto-market uncertainty and ensure transparency among investors. The guidance applies to companies with material exposure to the crypto market, regardless of whether they incorporate digital assets into their businesses.

images.alt_text: Crypto investors suffered a series of blows this year from the collapse of the FTX exchange, to the crash of stablecoin TerraUSD and the decline of Bitcoin.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip for fifth day on weakness in banks, consumer staples
summary: European shares slipped 0.2% on Thursday for the fifth consecutive day due to concerns over bank and consumer staple weakness, ahead of key interest rate decisions from major central banks, including the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank. Investors are jittery about the potential for an impending recession and the pace of interest rate tightening. Market strategist Hugh Gimber at JPMorgan Asset Management said investors are in a wait-and-see mode, with inflation still too high to justify rapid rate hikes.

site_title: Far East Orchard buys new student accommodation in UK for £13.9m
summary: Far East Orchard has acquired a freehold student accommodation property in Southampton, UK, for £13.9m, marking the developer's first UK student accommodation property. The 180-bed property, located near three Solent University campuses, is expected to be earnings accretive, with Far East estimating an increase in earnings per share. The acquisition is part of the group's efforts to expand and diversify its student accommodation portfolio in the UK.

images.alt_text: Revenue rose 15.9 per cent to S$63.7 million in H1, from S$54.9 million a year ago.

site_title: Japan to ramp up scrutiny of ESG data providers with new guidelines
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency is finalizing its draft code of conduct for environmental, social and governance (ESG) data and ratings providers, aiming to improve transparency and fairness in the industry. The guidelines, set to be released this month, follow industry feedback and align with International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) recommendations. The move aims to address concerns over ESG data providers' influence and potential risks such as greenwashing and misallocation of assets. Other countries, including Singapore and the UK, are exploring similar guidelines, while the EU is considering a proposal to bring more transparency to the market.

images.alt_text: Hecker says the development will probably impact some of the biggest climate coalitions, pressuring them to “level up their standards”.

Some Reits produce an ESG sustainability report that is more voluminous than their annual report. Reit stakeholders and investors are overwhelmed by universal data that fill up space in the report, resulting in Information asymmetries. There is a risk that some truly pertinent data will get submerged or distorted.

site_title: Tech layoffs offer hiring boon for startups that survive
summary: Tech layoffs have led to a hiring boon for startups that survive, as venture capitalists pull back on funding. Total funding dropped 34% in the third quarter, with 55% less than a year ago, and 42% less than the previous quarter. Startups need to have existing funding to capitalize on this trend, and even those with cash on hand remain cautious due to uncertainty about future fundraising. The shift in investor focus may result in a reduction of average deal sizes for late-stage startups.

images.alt_text: The management team of UnaBiz after its acquisition of Sigfox. From left to right: UnaBiz chief commercial officer Loic Barancourt, chief technology officer Alexis Susset, co-founders and co-CEOs Philippe Chiu and Henri Bong, and chief operating officer Rémi François.

site_title: US sues to block Microsoft’s blockbuster buyout of gaming giant Activision
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) sued to block Microsoft's $69 billion buyout of Activision Blizzard, citing concerns that the deal would stifle competition in the gaming industry. The lawsuit follows an intervention by the European Union, which also raised concerns about the deal's impact on competition. The FTC claims that Microsoft's acquisition would harm competition in multiple gaming markets, and raises significant doubts on the future of the transaction. The move marks one of the biggest interventions by the US government to stop consolidation in the tech industry.

site_title: World Cup:  Brazil, Argentina target blockbuster World Cup semi-final
summary: Brazil aims to become the first team to reach the World Cup semi-finals, facing Croatia in the quarter-finals. Meanwhile, Argentina seeks to set up a blockbuster all-South American clash with the Netherlands, who have never beaten Argentina in 90 minutes. Seven-time Ballon d'Or winner Lionel Messi hopes to finally end his wait for a World Cup title with Argentina, while Croatia's Luka Modric remains the key player for the team. The two teams will face off in the quarter-finals on Friday, with Brazil looking to overcome their Croatian opponents and Argentina seeking to overcome the Netherlands.

site_title: Musk faces legal onslaught from angry ex-Twitter workers
summary: Elon Musk is facing a growing number of lawsuits from former Twitter employees who were terminated during his takeover, with allegations of violating California law and ignoring promised severance packages. The lawsuits claim Musk's "hardcore" work ethic ultimatum was a disguised layoff plan, and that he disregarded employees' medical conditions. Twitter is facing hundreds of arbitration claims, which could cost the company and Musk dearly, and may force a settlement. The lawsuits also accuse Musk of converting office space into bedrooms without proper compensation.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on February 10, 2022, Elon Musk speaks during a press conference at SpaceX's Starbase facility near Boca Chica Village in South Texas. - Elon Musk has sold nearly $7 billion worth of Tesla shares, according to legal filings, amid a high-stakes court battle with Twitter over a $44 billion buyout deal. (Photo by JIM WATSON / AFP)
The move was likely a pushback against Apple’s 30 per cent cut on any payments made by users via apps on the iOS operating system.
The company is estimated to face annual interest costs of about US$1.2 billion if the current debt structure remains in place.
Heavy job losses in technology are being offset by an uptick in other sectors, including leisure, hospitality, healthcare and construction, November data from the Bureau of Labour Statistics show.

site_title: Tesla’s troubles are piling up while Elon Musk is distracted with Twitter
summary: Tesla faces increasing challenges, despite expected record sales, as Elon Musk is distracted with Twitter. The company is slowing production in China due to weakening demand, delaying hiring at its Shanghai factory, and its top executive is overseeing operations in Texas. Tesla's stock has lost over $500 billion in market value this year and is under pressure as Musk's advisers consider using his shares as collateral for new loans. Some investors are calling for a stock buyback and a new board member to represent retail shareholders.

images.alt_text: After enjoying a dream start in China, Tesla is now facing tougher competition from local electric car makers in the word’s biggest auto market.
The company is estimated to face annual interest costs of about US$1.2 billion if the current debt structure remains in place.

site_title: Hard term limits for independent directors: about time?
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation has proposed eliminating the two-tier voting system, which has been criticized for allowing independent directors to accumulate a significant portion of shares, potentially undermining their independence. The proposed change aims to ensure that independent directors are truly independent and not influenced by their own shareholdings. The Singapore Code of Corporate Governance currently limits independent directors to a 9-year term, but the proposed change could further address concerns about director independence. The consultation paper, launched in October 2022, seeks feedback from stakeholders on the proposed changes.

images.alt_text: A director who has been called upon to assist with investigations should familiarise himself with the investigation process and seek legal advice and representation for himself, if necessary.

site_title: WTO rules against US tariffs on steel, aluminium imposed by Trump
summary: The World Trade Organisation (WTO) has ruled that the US violated trade rules when imposing steel and aluminium tariffs imposed by former President Donald Trump, citing national security concerns. The decision could increase pressure on President Joe Biden to reconsider the tariffs, which have had a muted impact on US steel and aluminium producers. The ruling, which has yet to be confirmed by the WTO, can be appealed within 60 days and is unlikely to have an immediate impact on the industry.

images.alt_text: US ambassador Katharine Tai’s office said it had looked at arguments from both supporters and opponents of extending the WTO decision and that “in both cases, the views concern both the system as a whole

site_title: World Cup: Morocco chasing history against free-scoring Portugal
summary: Morocco is set to face Portugal in the World Cup quarterfinals, aiming to make history as Africa's first semi-finalists. After a surprise run, Morocco, led by coach Walid Regragui, has reached the quarterfinals for the first time, becoming the fourth African side to do so. The Atlas Lions have enjoyed significant crowd support throughout the tournament and are expected to receive similar backing against Portugal, who have scored six goals in their last match against Switzerland.

images.alt_text: The influx of visitors represents a 25 per cent boost to the country’s resident population of 3 million.
Portugal striker Goncalo Ramos celebrates after scoring his team's fifth goal to complete his hat-trick in the 6-1 win over Switzerland on Dec 6, 2022.
Royal Spanish Football Federation said they wanted to thank Luis Enrique and his staff for their work, but had decided to start a “new project”.

site_title: US FDA authorises Moderna, Pfizer updated Covid boosters for 6 months old
summary: The US FDA has authorized updated Covid-19 booster shots from Moderna and Pfizer/BioNTech for children as young as 6 months of age. Moderna's bivalent shot is now available for children 6 months to 5 years, while the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine can be given to those 6 months to 4 years. The Pfizer shot can also be administered as the third shot for eligible children who have not completed their primary vaccination series.

site_title: World Bank chief urges China to take ‘active leadership’ on debt
summary: World Bank President David Malpass urged China to take "active leadership" on debt issues, citing rapidly rising debt service payments draining resources from developing economies. Malpass asked Chinese officials to publish more data on debt instruments to speed up restructurings for poor countries. The World Bank reported that developing countries now owe $62 billion in annual bilateral debt service, equivalent to 10% of their export income. Malpass also discussed debt transparency and reporting with Chinese officials, including Finance Minister Liu Kun.

site_title: Oil falls on prospect of Keystone resumption, weakening demand
summary: Oil prices fell for a fifth consecutive session on Thursday, with Brent crude settling at US$76.15 a barrel, down 1.3% from the previous day. The decline was attributed to the prospect of Keystone pipeline resuming service, which would increase crude supply at a time of slowing global economic growth and fuel demand fears. Despite US crude inventories falling last week, petrol and distillate inventories surged, adding to concerns about easing demand.

site_title: Ethereum developers are targeting March for next software upgrade
summary: Ethereum developers aim to roll out the Shanghai software upgrade in March, allowing withdrawals of Ether from staking wallets. The upgrade is crucial for enabling staked Ether withdrawals, which is expected to drive more users into staking and improve network security. The Shanghai upgrade is a priority for developers, who have delayed previous upgrades to ensure a smooth rollout. The upgrade will replace validators with miners, similar to the Merge upgrade in September.

site_title: Airbus CEO says European suppliers shifting to US to escape high energy costs
summary: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury warned that European suppliers are shifting to the US to escape high energy costs, citing President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act as a major draw. German companies have already relocated, while France is considering departures early next year. Faury urged governments to provide tax breaks to halt the flow, stating that the US law is "very favourable" to aviation suppliers. The EU is weighing a complaint against the US law, which it claims violates World Trade Organization subsidy rules.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury takes part in a panel discussion at the International Air Transport Association's (IATA) Annual General Meeting in Boston, Massachusetts, U.S., October 4, 2021.   REUTERS/Brian Snyder/File Photo

site_title: Citi sees family offices swarming bond market and fuelling rally
summary: Citi's chief investment officer, David Bailin, notes that family offices and ultra-wealthy clients are investing heavily in bonds, driven by expectations of a weak 2023 for global growth. This investment surge is despite a recent equity market rally, and Citi does not foresee the bear market for stocks being over. The firm manages about $700 billion of customer assets, with high-end clients actively seeking bonds.

images.alt_text: Citigroup, which was Revlon’s loan agent, had accidentally used its own money in August 2020 to pay off the company’s US$894 million loan three years early instead of paying US$7.8 million in interest.

site_title: Bentley paints bleak picture for rest of Britain’s car industry
summary: Bentley CEO Adrian Hallmark has painted a bleak picture for the rest of Britain's car industry, citing Brexit and labor shortages as major challenges. Despite record sales and profit in 2022, Hallmark warns that other UK manufacturers will struggle due to high electricity costs, labor shortages, and the need for domestic battery production. He notes that Bentley's focus on luxury sales and ability to import expensive batteries have helped it navigate these challenges, but the broader industry faces significant hurdles in the transition to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Adrian Hallmark, the brand’s chief executive, said in July that the company’s customisation division has been more than pulling its weight

site_title: Broadcom forecast signals strong corporate tech spending
summary: Broadcom forecasts strong corporate tech spending for the current period, with revenue expected to reach $8.9 billion in the fiscal first quarter, surpassing analyst estimates. The company's diversification into enterprise software, security, and mainframe capabilities has helped it outperform the broader chip industry. CEO Hock Tan's focus on key end markets, such as Apple's iPhone and Amazon's data centers, has insulated the company from a slowdown. This continues Broadcom's run of outperforming the industry, with the company continuing to capitalize on strong demand from corporate customers and the cloud infrastructure sector.

images.alt_text: Raghuram believes VMware’s revenues will improve in predictability as the company transitions its business model.

site_title: China’s lifting of Covid curbs yields little cheer as recession fears weigh on markets
summary: China has lifted its Covid-19 restrictions nationwide, allowing for reduced testing and lockdowns, and permitting self-isolation at home for non-severe cases. However, investors reacted negatively, with Asian markets opening lower and US indices finishing flat. Analysts say the loosening is unlikely to boost growth significantly due to recession fears in the West, and the measures do not provide a clear roadmap for exiting lockdowns. The US Federal Reserve's rate hikes and potential surging infections in China are also weighing on markets.

images.alt_text: China’s planned changes come after major cities from Beijing to Shanghai and Shenzhen in the past two weeks rapidly wound back policies such as mass testing and broad.
Outbound shipments have lost steam since August as surging inflation, sweeping interest rate increases across many countries.
Across the broader Singapore market, gainers outnumbered losers 304 to 222 after 1.4 billion securities worth S$928.7 million changed hands on Thursday.

site_title: Cameo launches Cameo Kids personalised videos with Candle Media
summary: Cameo, a celebrity video messaging service, has partnered with Candle Media to launch Cameo Kids, offering personalised birthday and holiday video greetings from animated children's characters like Blippi and CoComelon. The service aims to expand Cameo's market, targeting parents who want to create similar experiences for their kids. The partnership taps into Candle Media's Moonbug Entertainment franchises and features individualised messages from characters, starting at $25.
