The design of a CBDC will be crucial in addressing these concerns, and Australia will carefully weigh the complex issues before deciding on issuing a CBDC.

images.alt_text: Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed real gross domestic product (GDP) rose 0.6 per cent in the third quarter, compared with 0.9 per cent the previous quarter and just under forecasts of 0.7 per cent.

site_title: FTX hires forensic team to probe money trail: WSJ
summary: FTX hires a forensic team from AlixPartners to investigate the missing billions of dollars from the failed cryptocurrency exchange. The team, led by former SEC chief accountant Matt Jacques, aims to track the money trail. Regulators globally are investigating the role of FTX's top executives in the firm's collapse.

site_title: Ensnared by celebrity endorsers, ease of use and an alluring nerd, FTX clients across Asia now pay the price
summary: Thousands of FTX clients in East Asia, including Japan, China, and South Korea, have lost significant amounts of money after the company's spectacular collapse. Despite the ease of use and attractive features, FTX lacked official approvals to operate in these countries, allowing users to open accounts without scrutiny. Many users were drawn to the platform's "righteous nerd-of-the-people" image and perceived safety, with some even investing family savings. The company's bankruptcy is expected to be prolonged, with payouts far from guaranteed, even for those who choose to sue.

images.alt_text: Regulators around the globe are investigating the role of FTX’s top executives in the firm’s stunning collapse.

site_title: Wage growth in 2023 to stay robust even as slowing economy cuts labour demand
summary: Singapore's labor market is expected to remain tight in 2023 despite slowing economic growth, driven by upward wage pressures from inflation and labor market tightness. Employers face challenges in paying wages, with some sectors, such as tech, maintaining robust demand for talent. New policies, including progressive wage models and the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, aim to attract top talent and support low-income residents. However, some experts warn that wage increases may plateau in 2023 and that the government should avoid tipping the economy into recession to ease labor market tightness.

images.alt_text: A global city should welcome foreign talent not just for a short duration until they are no longer ‘needed’, but also if they choose to stay.
Some sectors are already seeing the early effects of slowing demand. Hiring activity has started to cool in the red-hot sectors of tech and manufacturing, for instance.
Retrenchment numbers from July to mid-December 2022 represent an uptick, said the Manpower Minister.
Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee has seen three rounds of layoffs this year.

ST20221101-202253546871-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/

Generic photograph of office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

Progressive wages should promote productivity, career progression: MOM, SNEF

site_title: Bentley China orders slowed by shutdowns, has no IPO plans
summary: Bentley China's slowdown in orders due to shutdowns in major cities like Beijing and Shanghai is expected to result in a slight drop in production in 2023. Despite this, the company remains optimistic, with more than half of its 2023 sales already sold out. Bentley plans to make around 15,000 cars this year and has been running at maximum capacity at its Crewe factory. The company has no plans for an initial public offering (IPO) and is focusing on customisation and electric vehicle development, with its first fully-electric vehicle set to launch in 2026.

images.alt_text: Adrian Hallmark, the brand’s chief executive, said in July that the company’s customisation division has been more than pulling its weight

site_title: US military bill features up to US$10b to boost Taiwan
summary: The US Congress is expected to vote on a massive military policy bill, the National Defence Authorisation Act (NDAA), which includes up to $10 billion in security assistance and fast-tracked weapons procurement for Taiwan. The bill authorizes $2 billion in annual military grant assistance for Taiwan, if the US secretary of state certifies that Taiwan increases its defense spending. The move is seen as a response to China's increasing pressure on the democratically governed island, with China considering Taiwan its territory and vowing to use force to bring it under control.

images.alt_text: Flags of Taiwan and U.S. are placed for a meeting in Taipei, Taiwan March 27, 2018. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% or 13.3 points to 3,238.75, with 70 gainers outnumbering 39 losers in morning trading. Sembcorp Marine led the gainers, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB traded mixed. The Straits Times Index follows Wall Street's overnight decline, with US stocks closing mostly lower due to recession worries ahead of consumer price data and a Federal Reserve decision.

images.alt_text: Del Monte Pacific posts a 38 per cent rise in year-on-year net profit on its US subsidiary's higher gross margin.

site_title: GameStop posts 9.4% fall in third-quarter revenue
summary: GameStop's third-quarter revenue fell 9.4% to $1.19 billion, marking a decline from $1.30 billion in the same period last year. The company reported a net loss of $94.7 million, or 31 cents per share. This slowdown in revenue is attributed to consumers cutting back on discretionary spending amid high inflation. The decline also highlights the challenges faced by gaming companies, which are struggling with a slowdown in demand for video games. GameStop's digital wallet ambitions are also facing a bleak future due to the plummeting value of cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Oil gives up the year’s gains, closing at 2022 low
summary: Oil prices fell to a 2022 low, closing at nearly $100 a barrel, after US fuel stocks rose more than expected. The decline comes despite a supportive energy market backdrop due to high energy costs. The price surge in March was driven by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and economists now expect weakened worldwide growth due to high energy costs. The losses mark the end of the year's gains, which began after the Ukraine invasion.

site_title: A growing portfolio of health and wellness alternatives
summary: A Wellness Holdings, a Singapore-based health and wellness company, has grown through mergers and acquisitions, expanding its portfolio to include businesses in slimming, facial and spa services, pain management, and cosmetic procedures. Founded in 2012, Natrahea, a chain of clinics offering alternative healthcare, has captured market share with its holistic approach and digital marketing efforts. The company has also ventured into the beauty industry, acquiring local heritage brands, and plans to expand in South-east Asia, digitalize its processes, and go green with sustainable initiatives.

images.alt_text: From left: Frank Chen, founder and managing director of BR Metals; Victor Yeap, managing director of Yeap Medical Supplies; and Li Xiaowen, deputy managing director of Apro Asian Protection at the Enterprise 50 Awards on Wednesday.
Eastern Harvest Foods founder and managing director Derek Cheng (sixth from left) with staff members at an exhibition booth.

site_title: Challenges ahead for Manulife US Reit as it mulls divestment, diversification
summary: Manulife US Reit is considering divestment and diversification amid US office sector headwinds. The Reit, trading 56.6% below its IPO price, has generated a negative 4.7% annualized return since its inception. Analysts recommend selling underperforming assets and exploring new asset classes and geographies. Divestments could help lower gearing and limit capital expenditure, while diversification could broaden the Reit's asset class and strengthen its balance sheet. However, divestments may not be feasible due to market uncertainty, and the Reit may need to build scale and expertise in new asset classes.

images.alt_text: This comes after the reit said it would be exploring options to enhance shareholder value through the formation of a new strategic working group comprising the senior members of the manager and the board of the manager.

CGS-CIMB says that the Reit’s occupancy could come under pressure in the medium term, with major tenant TCW Group deciding to vacate its space in the Figueroa property (above) when its lease expires in December 2023.
The manager attributes the decline in occupancy largely to Quinn Emanuel’s downsizing of about 71,000 sq ft at its Figueroa property (above).

site_title: Singapore’s other pure-play Reits trading below book could do with strategic reviews too
summary: The manager of Manulife US Reit has announced a strategic review, just six years after listing on the Singapore Exchange. This move is seen as a bold step, acknowledging the need for a makeover. Other Singapore-listed Reits (S-Reits) with narrow focuses could benefit from similar reviews, particularly those trading at significant discounts to net asset values. Only two S-Reits, OUE Commercial Reit and Cromwell European Reit, have diversified portfolios with multiple asset classes and geographies, suggesting the market favors diversification.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
DBS has cut the target price of Manulife US Reit, which is currently undergoing a strategic review, by 31 per cent.
"We're taking a look at all of our options at this point," says Tripp Gantt, CEO of Manulife US Reit .

site_title: Sasseur Reit manager’s CFO under probe for personal trading of securities
summary: The chief financial officer (CFO) of Sasseur Reit, Xie Jianfeng, is under investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for personal trading of securities. Xie was interviewed by the authorities on December 5 and stated he was aware of the circumstances of the case. The investigation relates to trading that occurred before he became an employee of the Reit manager.

images.alt_text: The manager of Suntec Reit says its stronger operational performance was weighed down by interest rate and exchange rate pressures.
The manager of Sasseur Reit says the increase in distributable income is due mainly to an income tax refund relating to its Chongqing Liangjiang outlets.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall for fourth day on growth worries
summary: European shares fell for a fourth consecutive session on December 7, 2022, as investors grew worried about global recession fears. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6% lower, despite gains in healthcare stocks. Investors await interest rate decisions from the Fed and European Central Bank next week for further clues on monetary policy. Energy stocks declined 2.0% as crude prices slid, while banks fell for their third straight session. Euro zone government bond yields hit fresh multi-week lows amid conflicting inflation signals.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6 per cent lower, extending losses for a third day.

site_title: Banks face 6% capital hike from remaining Basel rules, says Bank of England
summary: The Bank of England announced that banks in the UK will face a 6% capital hike under the remaining Basel rules, known as Basel 3.1, which will increase capital requirements by the end of the decade. The new rules will be implemented from January 2025 and will affect major lenders such as HSBC, Barclays, and Lloyds. Director Phil Evans stated that the impact will be limited until the mid-to-late 2020s, with a small increase in capital requirements by 2030. The move aims to align with international standards while considering Britain's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Central bank data shows that the policy tightening wave is shifting towards Asia and away from Latin America and emerging Europe, where the cycle is nearing its end.

site_title: UK’s ex-health minister Hancock to quit at next national election
summary: Former UK Health Minister Matt Hancock announces his decision not to stand for re-election at the next general election, citing a desire to explore new ways to communicate with people outside of Parliament. Hancock, who was suspended by the Conservative Party in November, will remain an elected lawmaker but feels it is unnecessary due to the party's promise to re-admit him in due course. He expressed a desire to reach a wider audience and explore new possibilities for public engagement.

site_title: Warnock’s narrow victory solidifies Georgia as a battleground state for 2024
summary: Senator Raphael Warnock won a narrow reelection in Georgia's runoff, securing a 51-49 majority and giving Democrats a crucial cushion in close votes. This victory solidifies Georgia as a battleground state for the 2024 presidential election, potentially forcing Republicans to spend millions in a traditionally Republican state. The win also offers Democrats a blueprint for other states like North Carolina, where President Donald Trump edged Biden by a small margin in 2020.

images.alt_text: US Senator Mark Kelly (D-AZ) celebrates his election victory at a press conference outside Barrio Cafe in Phoenix, Arizona.

site_title: BT Podcast: Upsides left to capture in real estate?
summary: Claressa Monteiro discusses real estate's potential as an inflation hedge with Richard Kimble from Nuveen. Real estate can mitigate market volatility, but its income may struggle to keep pace with inflation. The sector is worth exploring, particularly in sectors like sustainability and global cities. Kimble notes that interest rates and real estate are interconnected, and the sector's outlook for 2023 is uncertain. Overall, real estate may still offer upside opportunities, but investors should carefully consider its performance throughout the cycle. Nuveen's managing director emphasizes the need for nuanced understanding of the sector's dynamics.

images.alt_text: Global cities are a conduit and showcase for megatrends.
What to look out for when buying a freehold, a new 99-year leasehold or an older leasehold home.

site_title: These are not the most expensive cities…unless you are an expat
summary: The Economist Intelligence Unit's Worldwide Cost of Living Survey ranked Singapore as the most expensive city in 2022, tied with New York, while Japanese cities like Tokyo and Osaka were not included in the top 10. However, the survey's methodology may not accurately reflect the cost of living for locals, as it primarily focuses on expenses relevant to expats and business travelers. The survey's items, such as car ownership and tuition fees, may not capture the true cost of living in cities like Singapore, where public transportation and affordable housing are readily available.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Passersby walk on the crossing during the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), at Shinjuku district in Tokyo, Japan June 24, 2020. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: US dollar slips with economy in focus, yuan firms as China eases curbs
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.15% against a basket of currencies, reaching 105.39, amid uncertainty over the economy. Meanwhile, China's yuan strengthened as authorities eased zero-Covid rules, reducing pressure on the currency. The dollar's decline was partly offset by upbeat US employment data, which raised questions about the Federal Reserve's potential interest-rate hikes.

site_title: ECB seeks urgent regulation after multiple crypto bubbles burst
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is urging urgent regulation of the crypto market due to multiple bubbles bursting this year, including the collapse of FTX, TerraUSD, and Bitcoin's decline. ECB board member Fabio Panetta stated that unbacked crypto assets are a form of financial gambling with no socially or economically useful function, posing risks to investors and the global financial system. Panetta emphasized that regulation is necessary to prevent crypto assets from being used to circumvent financial regulations and to shield the mainstream financial system from crypto risks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Temasek logo is seen at the annual Temasek Review in Singapore July 7, 2016. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
Nomura’s launch of its digital-assets arm in September.

This photo illustration shows the logo of cryptocurrency FTX, reflected in its website on a laptop screen in Washington, DC, on November 13, 2022. - The new chief executive of troubled cryptocurrency platform FTX said on November 12, 2022, the company was making "every effort to secure all assets" following unauthorized transactions potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Additionally, the platform's chief executive, 30-year-old Sam Bankman-Fried, once considered a star in the freewheeling cryptocurrency world, resigned. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as recession worries mount
summary: US stocks opened lower on Dec 7, with the Dow Jones falling 39.9 points, or 0.12%, to 33,556.4. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, as recession worries outweighed optimism over China's relaxation of zero-Covid rules. This follows recent warnings from major Wall Street bankers about a potential recession.

site_title: Crypto lender Genesis tells clients it is working to preserve their assets
summary: Crypto lender Genesis, owned by venture capital firm Digital Currency Group, is working to preserve client assets and strengthen liquidity after freezing customer withdrawals in November due to the collapse of FTX. The company stated it will take "weeks rather than days" to form a plan. Genesis aims to avoid a bankruptcy filing, seeking to address concerns among clients. The move comes as the company navigates a challenging market environment.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, Genesis Global Capital suspended customer redemptions in its lending business.

site_title: Mobileye beats revenue estimates in first quarterly report since IPO
summary: Mobileye, Intel's self-driving technology unit, reported its first quarterly earnings after going public, beating revenue estimates with a 38% growth to $450 million. The company's shares rose 2% and forecast a revenue range for the current quarter above expectations. Despite a widening net loss to $45 million, Mobileye's adjusted earnings exceeded analyst estimates. The company's stock has risen 45% from its IPO price, valuing the company at $24.45 billion.

site_title: Elon Musk loses title of world's richest man to LVMH's Arnault: Forbes
summary: Elon Musk lost his title as the world's richest person to Bernard Arnault, CEO of LVMH, due to Musk's expensive bets and stock sales. Musk's net worth dropped to $185.3 billion, while Arnault's wealth rose to $185.4 billion. This marks the first time Arnault has taken the top spot since 2021. Musk's loss in the title comes after his $44 billion deal for Twitter.

site_title: As Vietnam struggles with fuel disruptions, a renewed call to relook price structures
summary: Vietnam's fuel market has experienced repeated disruptions, with hundreds of petrol stations in major city centers temporarily closed due to fuel reserve shortages and sourcing difficulties. Industry observers suggest speculation by fuel importers may be the primary cause, rather than actual supply shortages. The country has 18.6 million tonnes of oil and gas available, sufficient to meet 90% of the country's demand for a year. To address the crisis, Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh requested the Ministry of Industry and Trade to ensure oil and gas supplies, while economists propose a transition to a market-driven price mechanism to eliminate delays and bring domestic fuel prices in line with international market prices.

images.alt_text: VinFast has said it has almost 65,000 orders globally in total and expects to sell 750,000 EVs annually by 2026.
It is unclear if the cuts in Vietnam reflect Samsung’s general drop in production or a shift to other manufacturing countries.
Many global tech giants, such as Apple, Luxshare, Pegatron and Wistron, have decided to expand their production capacities in Vietnam in recent years.

site_title: EU agrees to make airlines pay for pollution
summary: The European Union has agreed to a law requiring airlines to pay for their carbon dioxide emissions, starting in 2026. Currently, most CO2 permits are given for free, but under the new law, airlines will have to pay for their permits, providing a financial incentive to reduce emissions. The law will phase out free permits by 2026, with 20 million free permits still available for airlines using sustainable aviation fuels until 2030.

images.alt_text: Deforestation is a major source of greenhouse gas emissions that drive climate change and will be in focus at a UN COP15 conference this week, where countries will seek a global deal to protect nature.
The SAF will be supplied by Neste, produced from used cooking oil and waste animal fats, then blended with refined jet fuel at Exxon Mobil’s facilities in the city-state.
Singapore receives 15 recommendations on creation of a sustainable air hub
Continuous progress on fuel efficiency has been made through business-as-usual transformations in flight infrastructure and operations.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly down after choppy session
summary: US stocks ended mostly down on Wednesday after a choppy session, weighed by recession worries and awaiting key economic data. The Dow Jones finished flat, the S&P 500 dipped 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.5%. Individual companies saw mixed results, with Carvana plummeting 42.9% and Campbell Soup jumping 6.0%. Analysts are hopeful for a similar pivot at next week's Fed meeting, where key economic data and monetary policy decisions will be announced.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 39.9 points, or 0.12 per cent, at the open to 33556.4.

site_title: US Q3 productivity raised; labour costs still running high
summary: US productivity rebounded at a 0.8% annualised rate in the third quarter, revised up from 0.3% in the previous month. However, unit labour costs continued to rise at a 2.4% rate, driven by a tight labour market. This has kept inflation high and the Federal Reserve expected to continue raising interest rates. Productivity has declined for three straight quarters on an annual basis, and economists say the recent weakness may be overstated, with growth averaging 1.6% over the last five years.

images.alt_text: Although the dollar has erased much of its advance in recent months, the strong currency is still keeping US goods more expensive for overseas customers.

site_title: Sunak vows action to deal with ‘unreasonable’ UK strike leaders
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has warned union leaders that he will take action to protect the British public if they continue to be "unreasonable" in their demands. He vowed to pass "tough laws" to mitigate disruption caused by strikes in emergency services, including ambulance workers, ahead of Christmas. The strikes, which include nursing staff and teachers, are protesting over pay and conditions amid soaring inflation. Sunak claims the government has been "reasonable" in its dealings, but if union leaders remain unreasonable, he will take action to protect the public.

images.alt_text: epa10334170 NHS Ambulance staff outside a hospital in London, Britain, 28 November 2022.  The army may be brought in to help answer emergency calls over the festive period if NHS ambulance staff vote to strike over a pay dispute. NHS ambulance staff are voting this week whether or not to take industrial action.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Revez Corp receives mandatory offer at 3.06 cents per share
summary: Revez Corp has received a mandatory offer at 3.06 cents per share from investors Lim Quee Lan and Tan Swee Kim Bernard. The duo acquired a 58.6% stake, acquiring from Revez's CEO Victor Neo and others. The offer price is 66% below the last-transacted price and 65.6% below the volume-weighted average price. The joint offerors plan to review strategic options to release value of existing businesses, including potential acquisitions and business model transformation opportunities.

images.alt_text: History suggests US stocks climb once elevated inflation peaks, with the S&P 500 delivering double-digit gains one year later.

site_title: Life in pictures
summary: A new exhibition, "Living Pictures," at National Gallery Singapore showcases over 5,000 images by top local and regional photographers, tracing the history of photography in Singapore and South-east Asia from the colonial era to social media. The exhibition features works by notable photographers, including 82-year-old Tan Lip Seng, who won over 1,000 awards in international salons. The five-year curated exhibition highlights the evolution of photography in the region.

images.alt_text:
hypictures9 - By the turn of the century, wealthy locals were able to take their own photos, such as this 1910 photo of unidentified subjects taken at the famous Lee Brothers Studio.

site_title: Time magazine names Ukraine's Zelensky 'Person of the Year'
summary: Time magazine has named Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky as its 2022 "Person of the Year", along with "the spirit of Ukraine", for his leadership and resistance against Russia's invasion. Editor-in-chief Edward Felsenthal praised Zelensky's decision to stay in Kyiv and rally the country, calling it "fateful" and "the most clear-cut in memory". Zelensky's actions have galvanized the world, shifting geopolitical weather and inspiring global action.

images.alt_text: The award is dedicated to those Ukrainians fighting on the ground, for those who have been forced to flee, for those who have lost relatives and friends, for all those who stand up and fight for who and what they believe in.
Zelensky will make his speech Thursday (Oct 20) via video link at the five-day annual fair, which attracts tens of thousands of visitors from around the world and hundreds of exhibitors.

A Ukrainian flag waves on a street of the recently liberated village of Vysokopillya in the Kherson region of Ukraine. Ukraine’s tenacity shows how powerful liberal nationalism can be in the face of an authoritarian threat.

site_title: Britain’s electric car dream threatened by shortage of mechanics
summary: The UK's electric vehicle (EV) industry is facing a shortage of 25,000 qualified technicians by 2030, threatening the country's goal to phase out petrol and diesel cars by the same year. The shortage, driven by the need for high-voltage electricity maintenance, could drive up servicing costs and leave some EV owners unable to properly maintain their vehicles. The Social Market Foundation has called for mandatory licensing and increased training to address the shortage, warning that the UK's EV dream could be imperiled.

site_title: US mortgage rates fall a fourth week, longest stretch since 2019
summary: US mortgage rates fell for a fourth consecutive week, the longest stretch since May 2019, with the 30-year fixed mortgage rate easing 8 basis points to 6.41%. The Federal Reserve's signal to slow interest-rate hikes likely contributed to the decline. However, the mortgage purchase index fell 3% for the first time in five weeks, and refinancing activity remains near a two-decade low, indicating fickle demand and a decline in overall mortgage applications.

site_title: China's Xi in Saudi Arabia to deepen economic and strategic ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Saudi Arabia on December 7 for a three-day visit aimed at deepening economic and strategic ties. The trip includes direct talks with Saudi Arabia, a meeting with the six-nation Gulf Arab alliance, and a summit with Arab leaders. Beijing hopes to strengthen "unity and cooperation" with Saudi Arabia, which is seeking to expand its global alliances beyond the US. China and Saudi Arabia are expected to sign deals worth $30 billion, marking a significant boost to economic ties between the two countries.

images.alt_text: The overseas trip is only Xi’s third since the coronavirus pandemic began in 2020, and his first to Saudi Arabia, the world’s biggest crude oil exporter, since 2016.
Saudi Aramco owns 70 per cent of the refinery business while the rest is held by Jadwa nvestment. The offering consists of Jadwa’s sale of its shares in Luberef.
Diplomats say invitations have gone out to leaders in the Middle East and North Africa for the Chinese-Arab gathering during Xi's visit Saudi Arabia.

site_title: SL Green pursues tallest tower, 3D ads at Times Square casino
summary: SL Green Realty is pursuing a redevelopment of a Times Square office building into the tallest tower in the area, partnering with Caesars Entertainment and Roc Nation. The project, which includes a theatre, boutique gaming venue, and 5-star hotel, will feature the world's largest 3D advertising signs. The company also plans to explore office-to-residential conversions in New York City, citing high demand for housing.

images.alt_text: For New York, Times Square is an important financial engine; the city relies heavily on tourists to spend money at the neighbourhood’s hotels, restaurants, stores and entertainment venues.

site_title: End of easy-money era sparks questions over landlords’ true debt loads
summary: The European Public Real Estate Association's recommendation to include hybrid bonds as debt in loan-to-value ratios has sparked concerns over landlords' true debt loads. Hybrid bonds, valued at over $21 billion, have been treated as equity, not debt, under international accounting rules. The change in guidance has led to a sell-off in real estate hybrid bonds and raised questions about how landlords account for their debt. This move could lead to a sudden increase in relative indebtedness for landlords, prompting criticism and short-selling.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates have roiled real estate markets across Europe, making buying a home unaffordable for many consumers.
Hungarian housing prices have climbed by 151 per cent since 2015.

site_title: India urges global companies to help build fertiliser storage
summary: India's Fertiliser Minister Mansukh Mandaviya is urging global companies to invest in building fertiliser storage facilities in the country. India, a major importer of fertilisers, faces challenges due to disrupted supplies from Russia and Ukraine. The government has signed long-term deals for fertiliser imports to ensure stable supplies. Mandaviya encouraged global companies to invest in India for long-term strategies, citing the country's experience in providing medicines to over 100 countries without compromising quality. The government aims to provide financial support to farmers through fertiliser subsidies.

site_title: Rex International’s diversification bet on drones looks set for take-off
summary: Rex International's investment in Swedish drone company Xer Technologies is gaining momentum. Xer has unveiled its first product, the X8, a heavy-duty hybrid electric drone capable of flying 2.5 hours with a 4 kg payload. The company plans to launch the X12 in late 2023 and is in talks to secure new clients for railroad inspection in the US and Europe. Xer aims to ramp up sales to 20 drones next year and become operationally cashflow positive by end-2023, with potential for an initial public offering (IPO) in two to three years.

images.alt_text: Stocks of firms that diversified into hot sectors, crude oil plays among best performers for 2021
Rex International cranks up the production volume
Most pundits expect oil prices to remain high as a result of tight conditions but there are serious headwinds

site_title: Volkswagen tries to fix electric shift with new SUV, factory revamp
summary: Volkswagen is revamping its main factory in Germany to produce two new electric vehicles, including a revamped ID.3 hatchback and a new electric SUV, starting next year and late 2025, respectively. The decision follows software issues and internal discord that delayed key models. CEO Oliver Blume is under pressure to turn around VW's electric push, which has been plagued by setbacks. The company is also retooling its existing plant in Wolfsburg, spending 460 million euros, and will present a status update on its software rollout to the supervisory board on December 15.

site_title: Top Xiaomi India executive resigns just as challenges mount
summary: Xiaomi India's top executive, Ragu Reddy, has resigned amid intensifying regulatory scrutiny and competitive pressure in the country. Reddy, who helped Xiaomi become a leading smartphone and smart-television brand in India, cited "different growth opportunities externally" for his departure. Xiaomi faces regulatory issues, including accusations of tax evasion and illegal remittances, amid tensions between India and China. The company is also under pressure to build local supply chains and export more from India. Reddy's resignation comes as Indian authorities have frozen Xiaomi assets in the country.

images.alt_text: The blockage of Vivo’s shipments at the airport is likely to unnerve other Chinese smartphone players in India.
Many Chinese companies have struggled to do business in India due to political tensions following a border clash in 2020.
Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp posted a steep drop in second quarter revenue on Friday as the world’s biggest smartphone market shrank, hit by strict Covid restrictions.
Exclusion from India's entry-level market would hurt Xiaomi and its peers, which in recent years have increasingly relied on India.
India is seeking 43.89 billion rupees (S$774.1 million) from smartphone maker Oppo for allegedly evading customs duties, the latest in a flurry of accusations by Delhi against Chinese tech giants.
India has seized US$725 million from the local bank accounts of Xiaomi after a probe found the Chinese smartphone giant unlawfully sent money abroad in the guise of royalty payments.

site_title: Barclays promotes head of consumer business to chief operating officer
summary: Barclays has appointed Alistair Currie as its new chief operating officer (COO), replacing Mark Ashton-Rigby. Currie previously led the consumer banking and payments business, while Vim Maru takes over in that role. The appointment comes as Barclays shifts focus to its consumer business, amid a debate over resource allocation between the consumer and investment bank. CEO CS Venkatakrishnan, who is undergoing cancer treatment, has stated that the investment bank may shrink relative to the rest of Barclays.

images.alt_text: Barclays says 2023 looks set to be one of the weakest in four decades with advanced economies likely heading into a recession.
London’s Metropolitan Police Service said on Thursday (Nov 24) it had shut down fraud website iSpoof and made more than 100 UK arrests in connection with the case.

site_title: Credit Suisse edges towards US$440m clash with SoftBank
summary: Credit Suisse is close to filing a US$440 million lawsuit against SoftBank over the collapse of Greensill Capital in 2021. A London judge ruled that Credit Suisse's supply chain fund could be considered a "victim" of disputed transactions, paving the way for the claim. The Swiss bank alleges SoftBank orchestrated the restructuring to pull its own money out, knowing Greensill would default on its debt. A formal lawsuit can still be issued after SoftBank defends itself. The case stems from the collapse of financier Lex Greensill's empire, which also hit Credit Suisse last year.

site_title: Tourists 'think twice' about Indonesia following criminal code revisions
summary: Indonesia's new criminal code revisions, which ban cohabitation and sex outside of marriage, have raised concerns among tourists and businesses, potentially deterring foreigners from visiting or investing in the country. The changes, set to come into force in three years, have been criticized as a step backwards for the country's democracy. Travelers have expressed hesitation about staying in Indonesia due to the new laws, while hotel operators have downplayed concerns, stating that the regulation will not impact their business. Foreign arrivals in Bali, a popular tourist destination, are expected to reach pre-pandemic levels by 2025.

images.alt_text: Yasonna Laoly, Indonesian Minister of Law and Human Rights (L), receives the new criminal code report from Bambang Wuryanto, head of the parliamentary commission in Jakarta on Dec 6, 2022.

site_title: World Bank-backed global carbon credit registry to go live by Q1 2023
summary: A World Bank-backed global carbon credit registry, Climate Action Data Trust (Cad Trust), is set to launch by Q1 2023. Headquartered in Singapore, the registry aims to unify data from leading registries, including Verra and Gold Standard. The platform will integrate data from four major registries and two smaller ones, with the first public data layer expected to go live in Q1 2023. The initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to harmonize the carbon credit market and support its goal of becoming a carbon-neutral nation by 2050.

images.alt_text: The Climate Action Data Trust will be an independent entity domiciled in Singapore.
Controversies to do with unclear rules in the carbon market still occasionally make headlines.
The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) said carbon credits supplied from Wednesday will be treated as “neither a supply of goods nor a supply of services, i.e. an excluded transaction”.

site_title: Del Monte Q2 net income up 38% to US$49.5 million
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a 38% increase in Q2 net income to US$49.5 million, driven by a 28% rise in gross margin at its US subsidiary, Del Monte Foods Inc. The group's overall gross margin improved to 29.4%, fueling a 15% growth in gross profit. Sales for the second quarter rose 7% to US$698.9 million, with growth in key markets, including the US, Philippines, and international markets. The company will raise prices again, with hikes in January for the Philippines and February for the US, to pass on inflation and maintain revenue and income growth.

images.alt_text: Del Monte's US subsidiary Del Monte Foods Inc (DMFI) in early September executed its third price increase since May 2021.
Del Monte said Q1 revenue dipped 1.2 per cent to US$456.6 million due to lower revenue in the Philippines despite better performance in the US and international markets.

site_title: Global Switch expects binding bids soon in US$8b deal, according to sources
summary: Global Switch, a British-based data centre provider controlled by Chinese steelmaker Jiangsu Shagang Group, is expected to receive binding bids in a US$8 billion deal. Private equity firms PAG, KKR & Co, and EQT are in the final round of bidding. The deal is expected to value the company at around US$8 billion, short of Global Switch's initial valuation of US$10 billion. An agreement is likely to be reached in 2023, making it one of Asia's largest ongoing transactions this year.

images.alt_text: A deal would mark a rare investment in the European financial services industry for KKR.

site_title: Philippine officials defend wealth fund amid business concerns
summary: Philippine officials have defended the proposed Maharlika Investments Fund, a sovereign wealth fund aimed at providing funding for infrastructure and pensions. Despite concerns from business groups over governance and fiscal prudence, officials argue that the fund has safeguards to ensure its integrity. The fund will be subject to internal, external, and government audits, and will be funded by remittances from overseas Filipinos and outsourcing companies. Officials say the fund will benefit the economy and provide a stable source of funding for infrastructure projects.

images.alt_text: Philippine lawmakers believe that a sovereign wealth fund, to be chaired by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, will boost growth in the country, but critics warn that it will be prone to graft and risk Filipino pensions.

site_title: A night celebrating Singapore’s E50 winners, Enterprise 50 - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: BR Metals has won the top spot at this year's E50 Awards, recognizing the company's outstanding achievements in the metals industry. The E50 Awards honor companies that demonstrate exceptional growth, innovation, and leadership. BR Metals was selected for its commitment to sustainability, technological advancements, and business expansion. The company's recognition is a testament to its dedication to excellence and its impact on the global metals market. The E50 Awards ceremony was held to celebrate the accomplishments of the top-performing companies in the industry, solidifying BR Metals' position as a leader in the sector.

site_title: Voluntary carbon markets need to be regulated to build liquidity: Ieta panel
summary: Industry observers agree that voluntary carbon markets (VCMs) need regulation to increase financing and ensure integrity. However, they differ on the extent of regulations, with some advocating for limited oversight to avoid hindering market development and liquidity. The panel suggests a balanced approach to regulate carbon credits as tradable commodities, similar to oil, to build liquidity and enhance carbon project quality and financing.

images.alt_text: Carbon pricing can affect leverage, profitability of Asia’s heavy emitters

site_title: Uber rolls out robotaxis even as self-driving car hype wanes
summary: Uber is launching its first robotaxi service in Las Vegas, partnering with Motional to offer self-driving rides. The 10-year deal pairs Motional's all-electric IONIQ 5 robotaxis with Uber's ride-hailing platform, marking a commitment to a self-driving taxi fleet despite fading autonomous vehicle hype. This marks the second phase of testing, following initial driverless food deliveries on Uber Eats in Santa Monica, California.

site_title: Five digital banks join Credit Bureau Singapore
summary: Five Singapore-licensed digital banks, including Grab's GXS bank and Sea's MariBank Singapore, have joined Credit Bureau Singapore. The two full digital banks will submit consumer data related to credit reporting, while the two digital wholesale banks will need customer consent before accessing reports. This expansion enriches CBS' data repository and is expected to positively impact revenue and profitability for the financial year ending 2023. The move brings CBS' total members to 36, with the digital banks expected to contribute significantly to the company's growth.

images.alt_text: Credit Bureau Asia's executive director William Lim said the inclusion of digital banks in CBA's member network will create a multiplier effect.

site_title: Indonesia targets IPOs at 2 Pertamina units next   year, says deputy minister
summary: Indonesia plans to launch initial public offerings (IPOs) for the upstream and geothermal units of state energy firm Pertamina next year to fund expansion plans. The upstream unit, Pertamina Hulu Energi, is expected to sell a 10-15% stake in an IPO, potentially raising $1-3 billion. The geothermal unit's IPO, initially targeted for this year, will now take place in the first quarter of next year. The government aims to diversify financing and enhance energy security through these IPOs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker of a petrol station of the state-owned company Pertamina fills a motorcycle with subsidised fuel after the announcement of a fuel price hike, in Bekasi, on the outskirts of Jakarta, Indonesia, September 3, 2022. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana/File Photo

site_title: China reports jump in gold reserves after more than 3 years
summary: China reported a jump in its gold reserves, with holdings increasing to 63.67 million troy ounces as of end-November, a first in over three years. This rise is seen as a potential support for gold prices. The increase, equivalent to about 32 tons, follows a cumulative 106 tons added over the 10 months through September 2019.

images.alt_text: Multiple weighted gold bars sit in a stack in this arranged photograph at Gold Investments Ltd. bullion dealers in London, U.K., on Thursday, Nov. 1, 2012. Gold may rise for a third straight day, as China's manufacturing expanded for the first time in three months, increasing demand prospects for commodities. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: China forex reserves rise to US$3.117 trillion in November
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose to $3.117 trillion in November, a $65.1 billion increase, driven by a weakening US dollar. The yuan strengthened 3% against the US dollar, while China's gold reserves rose to $111.65 billion. The growth in reserves was in line with expectations, despite China's GDP growth expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Eurozone economy grew more than estimated in third quarter
summary: The eurozone economy grew more than initially estimated in the third quarter, with a 0.3% increase in gross domestic product, slightly above the 0.2% preliminary estimate. Fixed capital investment and household consumption drove growth, despite negative net exports. However, the European Central Bank expects a mild recession in the current quarter and at the start of 2023, citing rising interest rates. The economy is expected to endure a downturn, but the bank believes it will be less severe than previously thought.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Wednesday, tracking Asia decline; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% on Wednesday, mirroring a decline in Asian markets, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,225.45. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong tumbled 3.2% due to disappointing trade data in China. Investors are concerned about the outlook for external demand, especially as the US and EU economies are expected to head into recession next year. Local banks and real estate investment trusts also ended the day in the red, with only a few constituents closing in positive territory.

images.alt_text: Outbound shipments have lost steam since August as surging inflation, sweeping interest rate increases across many countries.
Singapore-listed stocks could be negatively impacted by the triple threats of higher debt, tax and wage costs.

site_title: Does ChatGPT mean robots are coming for the skilled jobs?
summary: ChatGPT, a recent AI program, has raised concerns about the potential impact of technology on skilled jobs. While machines have not eliminated the need for workers, they can replace certain types of jobs, such as those involving manual labor. However, the jobs that disappear are often replaced by new ones, and technology can also create new opportunities for knowledge workers. The author argues that a significant portion of knowledge work may be replaceable by AI, potentially reducing the demand for certain knowledge workers, but also creating new job opportunities in AI development and implementation.

images.alt_text: Sony launched a robot dog called Aibo more than two decades ago. It sold about 150,000 units of Aibo from 1999 until 2006 and launched an advanced version in 2018, selling about 20,000 units in the first six months.
A survey by McKinsey Global Institute found that 50 per cent of firms across the world tried to use AI in some way in 2022, up from 20 per cent in 2017.

site_title: Jurong-Clementi and Pasir Ris-Punggol town councils flagged for administrative errors: MND
summary: Two Singapore town councils, Jurong-Clementi and Pasir Ris-Punggol, were flagged for administrative errors, including a computational error and incorrect allocation of funds. These incidents were rectified, and the town councils received green ratings for corporate governance. The Ministry of National Development (MND) completed its review of town councils' audited financial statements and noted significant cost pressures due to higher energy prices and manpower costs.

site_title: CMA CGM nears deal for New York, New Jersey container terminals
summary: CMA CGM has agreed to acquire two major US shipping terminals in New York and New Jersey, bolstering its presence on the US east coast. The deal, valued at around $3 billion, gives CMA CGM a gateway to the northeastern US supply chain areas and strengthens its position as a global port terminal operator. The acquisition is seen as a strategic investment, reinforcing CMA CGM's services to US customers and supply chain efficiency. The terminals have an existing combined capacity of 2 million TEUs per year and potential for further expansion.

images.alt_text: There are no reported injuries and no immediate impact to port operations, MPA said.

site_title: Limited impact on airlines forced to ration jet fuel in New Zealand
summary: Airlines in New Zealand, including Air New Zealand and Singapore Airlines, will continue scheduled flights despite jet fuel rationing. The fuel was found to have conductivity levels above regulatory thresholds in a recent shipment. Regional airlines will mitigate the impact by loading extra fuel at destinations like Australia, while longer-haul airlines may need to consider refueling stops or trade off cargo for more fuel. No immediate schedule changes have been announced by national carriers.

images.alt_text: The risk of fuel shortages comes as New Zealand approaches its annual summer vacation period.
Air New Zealand continues to see domestic leisure travel running ahead of pre-Covid levels and also a recovery in business travel.
Over 40 countries including Germany, the UK and New Zealand have asked the United Nations body that sets aviation standards to help make single-pilot flights a safe reality.

site_title: Recruitment platform Glints lays off 18% of staff
summary: Glints, a Singapore-based recruitment platform, has laid off 18% of its staff, approximately 180 employees, due to a slowdown in business growth caused by market uncertainty and reduced consumer spending. The company cited a shift in focus towards long-term growth and has taken pay cuts and reduced perks for its remaining staff. Despite this, Glints reported a 101% year-over-year increase in demand-side revenue and a 160% year-over-year increase in supply-side job applications in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Flash Coffee opens over 250 outlets across seven countries in two years after raising millions of dollars from investors.
(from left) Agung Bezharie, co-founder of Warung Pintar and Brian Marshal, founder of Sirclo. Both startups merged their teams to form a workforce of nearly 2,000 at the start of the year.

site_title: Chinese M&A interest in Australia picks up as political ties thaw
summary: Chinese companies are showing renewed interest in Australian acquisition targets, particularly in natural resources and agricultural assets, as diplomatic ties between the two countries thaw. This follows a meeting between Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Chinese President Xi Jinping, which raised expectations of closer bilateral ties. Chinese firms are exploring investment opportunities in Australia's battery minerals sector, and some banks have received mandates from Chinese companies looking at Australian assets. However, investment in sensitive sectors such as telecoms, defence, and critical minerals is likely to be restricted due to Australia's foreign investment framework.

site_title: Singapore unemployment rates hold steady at pre-Covid levels in October
summary: Singapore's unemployment rates remained steady at pre-Covid levels in October, according to the Ministry of Manpower's report. The overall unemployment rate fell to 2%, while resident unemployment and citizen unemployment rates stood at 2.8% and 3%, respectively. A total of 67,700 residents were unemployed, with 60,800 being citizens. This marks a 0.1 percentage point decrease from September, with improvements seen across occupational groups.

site_title: New nutrition labelling scheme in line with shifting taste buds of the health-conscious
summary: Beverage manufacturers in Singapore are reformulating their drinks to meet the new Nutri-Grade labelling scheme, which requires lower sugar content and clearer nutrition labels. The scheme, set to kick in by year-end, grades drinks from A (healthiest) to D (unhealthiest), with D-grade drinks prohibited from advertising. Companies such as JJ Drinks and MWD Beverages have reduced sugar in their products and introduced new low-sugar and no-sugar variants, while Pokka Singapore has rolled out nutrition labels ahead of the deadline. The scheme aims to reduce Singaporeans' high sugar intake, linked to obesity and diabetes.

images.alt_text: The buzz in booze-free beverages

site_title: Microsoft to bring Call of Duty to Nintendo, Sony on the spot
summary: Microsoft has entered a 10-year agreement to bring Call of Duty to Nintendo platforms, marking the first time the popular first-person shooter series will be available on Nintendo consoles. The deal comes after Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard raised concerns among regulators, with Sony criticizing the deal. Microsoft president Brad Smith tweeted that the company is open to negotiating a 10-year deal with Sony for PlayStation as well, following Sony's gaming chief Jim Ryan's criticism of the initial offer.

images.alt_text: Microsoft mulled building the app to loosen the hold of Alphabet’s Google and Apple on the mobile search space

site_title: Taiwan November exports plunge, outlook poor
summary: Taiwan's exports of electronics components in November fell 4.9% to $15.15 billion, with semiconductor exports down 3.4% from the previous year. This marks the third straight month of declines, with exports dropping 13.1% from a year earlier to $36.13 billion, the lowest figure in 19 months. The decline is attributed to worsening global economic conditions, inflation, and interest rate rises. Taiwan's exports to China, the island's largest trading partner, also plummeted 20.9% to $13.56 billion in November.

site_title: India central bank says digital currency transactions to stay largely anonymous
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has stated that transactions via its central bank digital currency (CBDC), the e-rupee, will remain "to a certain degree" anonymous. The RBI has begun experiments on both wholesale and retail versions of the e-rupee using blockchain technology, with plans to expand its use to consumers and retailers. Deputy governor T Rabi Sankar emphasized the need for anonymity in currency transactions, stating that it is a basic feature of currency and will be ensured through technology and legal provisions.

images.alt_text: The pilot would cover select locations in a closed user group comprising participating customers and merchants, the India central bank said.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate remained steady at pre-Covid levels in October, with 60,800 out of 67,700 unemployed residents being citizens. The Ministry of Manpower's report showed no significant change. Meanwhile, the Housing and Development Board clarified that public housing flat prices are separate from development costs, and a former UOB and OCBC bank staff was banned by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for cheating seven people of almost S$2m. The World Bank-backed carbon credit registry is set to launch by Q1 2023, while Glints, a recruitment platform, laid off 18% of its staff.

site_title: New Zealand Navy idles ships as labour crisis hits
summary: New Zealand's Defence Force has idled three naval ships due to a severe labour crisis, with personnel lured out of the military by higher civilian salaries. The HMNZS Wellington, an offshore patrol vessel, was taken out of operation in November after a crew shortage. This is the third ship to be put into "care and custody" since last year, with the Pacific region facing rising tensions between China and the US and its allies. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has stated that the Pacific region can manage security issues on its own.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on November 4, 2021 shows New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern speaking to a reporter during an interview about climate change at the parliament in Wellington. - Ardern has warned the Glasgow climate summit is "make or break" in the fight to curb global warming, saying the world is now paying the price for decades of procrastination. (Photo by Marty MELVILLE / AFP) / TO GO WITH UN-climate-COP26-NZealand-Ardern,INTERVIEW by Neil SANDS

site_title: Tesla offers additional discount to Chinese buyers on some models
summary: Tesla is offering a limited-time discount of 6,000 yuan (S$1,168) to Chinese buyers on some models from December 7 to the end of 2022. This is in addition to a previously announced 4,000 yuan insurance subsidy, applicable only to customers buying current models and completing delivery by December 31. The move aims to boost sales amid slowing demand in China's auto market and elevated inventory levels at Tesla's Shanghai plant.

site_title: Artificial intelligence is permeating business at last
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly being adopted in various industries, with 50% of firms worldwide trying to use AI in some way in 2022, up from 20% in 2017. Companies like John Deere, Amazon, and Google are leveraging AI to improve efficiency, productivity, and customer experience. The "coming wave" of foundation models, which can generate new content and perform multiple tasks, is expected to further accelerate AI adoption. While there are concerns about bias, explainability, and legal liabilities, many experts believe that AI will become an essential tool for businesses, driving significant benefits.

images.alt_text:
AI is a powerful tool, and C-suite executives need to understand how to both leverage it for growth and innovation, and do so responsibly and ethically.



EXEL
Cerebras said Andromeda can perform 1 exaflop worth of AI computing – or at least one quintillion (10 to the power of 18) operations per second – based on a precision of 16 bit floating point format.
Chatbot technology is not new, although its deployment has met with mixed success.

site_title: LA approves tax increase on real estate deals over US$5m
summary: Los Angeles voters approved a tax increase on real estate deals over $5 million, boosting the one-time transfer tax to 4% for deals between $5 million and $10 million, and 5.5% for deals above $10 million. The measure, Proposition ULA, aims to raise $600-1.1 billion annually to fund affordable housing projects and homelessness prevention. The new tax will take effect on April 1, 2023, and is expected to dedicate 70% of funding to affordable housing.

images.alt_text: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 22: An 'open house' flag is displayed outside a single family home on September 22, 2022 in Los Angeles, California. The U.S. housing market is seeing a slow down in home sales due to the Federal Reserve raising mortgage interest rates to help fight inflation.   Allison Dinner/Getty Images/AFP
Initial unemployment claims increased by 17,000 to 240,000 in the week ended Nov 19, Labor Department data showed on Wednesday (Nov 23).
A soccer stadium deal in Queens last week that is expected to create 2,500 units of affordable housing. But that housing is not expected to be completed until 2030.
The most vulnerable New York City counties include Kings and Richmond counties, which cover Brooklyn and Staten Island, and 7 counties in the suburbs.

site_title: Is Fomo the new greed when it comes to investing?
summary: The article explores whether the current phenomenon of "fear of missing out" (Fomo) in investing is a legitimate concern or simply a form of greed. Historically, Fomo has led to irrational exuberance, as seen in the FTX collapse and other recent market debacles. However, some investors argue that Fomo can be a legitimate concern, particularly in the context of China's economic rise and potential decoupling from the US. As China's economy continues to grow, investors may be forced to reevaluate their presence in the country, leading to a potential Fomo event.

images.alt_text: FILE — Balenciaga sneakers in New York, July 18, 2018. “When prices are shooting up and you feel the fear of missing out, you can talk yourself into imagining intrinsic value in anything,” writes New York Times columnist Farhad Manjoo. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

site_title: China considers GDP target of about 5% in pro-growth shift
summary: China is considering a GDP growth target of around 5% for next year, a significant shift towards a more pro-growth stance after months of economic turmoil. The move aims to boost the economy and market confidence, following record Covid outbreaks and a property market crisis. The target is expected to be discussed at the Central Economic Work Conference, with some officials arguing it's too ambitious, while others see it as a necessary signal to local officials and the public. The goal is to bring next year's growth rate back to its potential of above 5%, but the outlook remains highly uncertain due to a likely surge in Coronavirus infections and global economic risks.

images.alt_text: The prospect of further relaxation of rules has sparked optimism among investors that the world’s second-biggest economy would regain strength and help boost global growth.
Outbound shipments have lost steam since August as surging inflation, sweeping interest rate increases across many countries.

site_title: DWS plans divestments and special dividend
summary: DWS, a Deutsche Bank-owned fund manager, plans to create 100 million euros in savings by 2025 through divestments and cost reductions. The company aims for earnings per share (EPS) of 4.50 euros by 2025 and a cost-to-income ratio of below 59%. A proposed dividend of up to one billion euros in 2024 is also planned, with the savings to be reallocated to growth areas. The announcements come as the company tries to move on from allegations of misleading investors over its green credentials.

images.alt_text: With Asia grappling with its reliance on coal, and the US beset by ESG politicisation, Europe has emerged as the leader on sustainable finance.
Demonstrators take part in a protest against the greenwashing of nuclear energy and gas through the taxonomy of the EU in front of the Euro sign in Frankfurt, Germany, January 11, 2022.

The headquarters of Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt, Germany. Deutsche Bank and its asset management unit had their Frankfurt offices raided by police, adding to legal headaches facing Germany's largest lender.

site_title: G7 makes new US$15b offer to Vietnam to cut coal use: sources
summary: The G7 has made a new US$15 billion offer to Vietnam to transition away from coal, following a summit next week. The offer includes US$7.5 billion in public sector loans and US$7.5 billion in private sector pledges. This is an expansion from an initial pledge of US$2 billion in public funds. Vietnam's energy security remains at risk due to the focus on renewable energy, potentially leading to power shortages. The offer's fate remains uncertain, with a 50/50 chance of a deal, according to sources.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam said in a statement banks with good liquidity and offering low interest rates will be eligible for an increase in their credit growth,

site_title: After hat-trick heroics, Portugal’s Goncalo Ramos steals World Cup spotlight
summary: Portugal's 21-year-old striker Goncalo Ramos stole the World Cup spotlight with a hat-trick in a 6-1 victory over Switzerland, propelling his team into the quarter-finals. Coach Fernando Santos dropped Cristiano Ronaldo from the starting lineup, and despite Ronaldo's efforts to make an impact, Ramos's impressive performance earned him a starting spot for the rest of the tournament. The win sets up Portugal's date with Morocco in the quarter-finals, with Ronaldo now expected to be on the bench.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Portugal's forward #26 Goncalo Ramos celebrates after scoring his team's fifth goal, his hat-trick, during the Qatar 2022 World Cup round of 16 football match between Portugal and Switzerland at Lusail Stadium in Lusail, north of Doha on December 6, 2022. (Photo by Jewel SAMAD / AFP)

site_title: China's property sector support fails to lure bond investors
summary: China's property sector support fails to attract long-term bond investors, with analysts at Citi predicting further defaults, particularly among lower-rated developers. Despite a 16-step plan by the Chinese central bank and banking regulator to support the industry, long-term investors remain cautious, waiting for signs of a deeper recovery. The measures have so far only led to a tentative rebound in high-yield US dollar-denominated bonds of companies such as Powerlong Real Estate and Country Garden.

images.alt_text: The market’s historic turmoil will make a comeback difficult, even with the slew of measures announced in recent months to address a developer cash crunch and boost housing demand.
Among 100 cities surveyed by the research firm, 57 saw November new-home prices lower than in October, when prices had been lower in 54 cities.
The 100 biggest real estate developers saw new-home sales drop 25.5 per cent from a year earlier to 559 billion yuan in November.

site_title: Suicide bombing kills Indonesian police officer, wounds 10
summary: A suicide bombing at a police station in Bandung, Indonesia, killed one officer and wounded 10 others on December 7, 2022. The attacker, identified as 34-year-old Agus Sujatno, linked to the pro-Islamic State group Jamaah Ansharut Daulah, was linked to a previous bombing in 2017. The blast occurred at the Astana Anyar police office during a morning roll call, and a second device was later found and safely detonated. The attack was condemned in messages attached to the attacker's motorbike, which also rejected a newly passed amendment to Indonesia's criminal code.

site_title: India asks Google to stop displaying online betting ads: report
summary: India has asked Google to stop displaying online betting ads, including surrogate ads, from overseas betting companies on search results and YouTube. This comes after the government overruled a proposal to only regulate games of skill and leave out games of chance. The request follows a government panel's recommendation to create a regulatory body to classify online games, introduce rules to block prohibited formats, and take a stricter stance on gambling websites.

site_title: In FTX soul-searching, don’t snuff Temasek’s ventures
summary: Temasek, a Singapore government-owned investment firm, is conducting an internal review after revealing a US$275 million investment in collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX will be written down. The firm had spent eight months doing due diligence before investing, but the circumstances of the collapse, including corporate malfeasance and lack of oversight, raise questions about Temasek's due diligence processes and risk assessment. The review aims to avoid over-reaction and preserve Temasek's ability to make risky bets, while also improving its processes to prevent similar mistakes in the future.

images.alt_text: Advisers are working to rebuild balance sheets for FTX entities from the bottom up, John J Ray III, FTX’s new CEO said.
Temasek is now preparing to write off the entire amount, one of the people said, asking not to be identified as the matter is private.
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong said that the intrisic value of cryptocurrency is zero and investors must be prepared to lose all their money,

site_title: MAS bans former UOB, OCBC bank staff who cheated seven people of almost S$2m
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a 15-year prohibition order against Han Delong, a former representative of UOB and OCBC, for his role in cheating seven customers out of nearly S$2 million through fraudulent activities. Han was convicted in May last year for criminal breach of trust, cheating, forgery, and transferring benefits of his criminal conduct. He is barred from providing financial advisory services and participating in the management of financial advisory firms. The MAS aims to safeguard the integrity of and trust in Singapore's financial sector.

images.alt_text: MAS said it placed Binance on its alert list after the exchange was found to be in potential breach of the Payment Services Act.

site_title: UK house prices fall at the fastest pace in 14 years, says mortgage lender
summary: UK house prices fell 2.3% in November, marking the sharpest decline in 14 years, as interest rates surged, reducing affordability. The typical property now costs £285,579, down from £292,406 in October. Mortgage rates have soared above 6%, prompting a potential half-point increase in the key rate next week. The housing market may be headed into a protracted downturn, with 85% of mortgage holders on fixed rates protected from high borrowing costs, but those who refinance in 2023 will see monthly payments double.

images.alt_text: Estate agents advertising signs ‘For Sale’ and ‘To Let’ outside properties at a housing development in London, UK, on Thursday, Nov. 17, 2022. Finding a rental property in London can feel like an impossible quest, with prices surging as demand vastly outpaces the number of available units.Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
Excluding the Covid-19 pandemic, UK house prices have not fallen this sharply since the global financial crisis more than a decade ago.
In annual terms, house price inflation slowed to 7.8 per cent, with quarterly growth at 0.7 per cent, the lowest rate since February 2020.

site_title: Thai headline CPI below forecast in November, seen slowing further
summary: Thailand's headline consumer price index (CPI) rose 5.55% in November, the slowest pace in seven months, due to lower food prices. This is below forecast and follows October's 5.98% increase. The pace remains above the central bank's target range of 1-3%, leading to expectations of further interest rate hikes to control inflation.

site_title: India sticks to fighting inflation with slower rate hike
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), maintained its 6.7% inflation forecast for the current fiscal year, while slowing the pace of borrowing cost hikes. The RBI raised its benchmark repurchase rate by 35 basis points to 6.25%, as predicted by 32 economists. Governor Shaktikanta Das stated that the battle against inflation is not over, despite economic growth remaining resilient. The decision aims to balance inflation control with growth, with the central bank focusing on withdrawing accommodation.

images.alt_text: The World Bank is confident that the global slowdown will have a much lower impact on India than other emerging economies.

site_title: Blackstone’s private credit fund hits its cap on withdrawals
summary: Blackstone's private credit fund, Bcred, has reached its redemption limit for the first time in its two-year history, with $2.5 billion in redemptions in the latest quarter. This marks the highest withdrawals since the fund's establishment in January 2021. The withdrawals echo a trend seen in another Blackstone investment vehicle, Breit, which was forced to halt redemptions due to high withdrawal requests. The move highlights market uncertainty and potential investor risk aversion.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust has been facing withdrawal requests exceeding its quarterly limit, a major test for the one of the private equity firm’s most ambitious efforts to reach individual investors.

site_title: Toyota offers cheaper Prius if customers take software updates
summary: Toyota is offering a cheaper Prius lease option in Japan, requiring customers to opt-in for over-the-air software updates that can bring monthly lease payments down by 10%. The service, similar to Tesla's approach, aims to preserve used-car values and cut costs. Toyota plans to expand the service to other vehicles within a year or two, with potential global offering. The move is seen as a cost-saving strategy for Toyota, targeting a different customer segment that prioritizes reliability and affordability over new technology.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Toyota cars are seen at a briefing on the company's strategies on battery EVs in Tokyo, Japan, December 14, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: TSMC triples Arizona chip plant investment, Biden hails project
summary: US President Joe Biden hailed a major investment by Taiwanese chipmaker TSMC, which is tripling its Arizona plant investment to $40 billion, the largest foreign investment in US history. The move is seen as a boost to semiconductor production following pandemic-induced supply chain issues. Biden called it a "big win" for American manufacturing, stating "American manufacturing is back." The project is expected to support the US economy and address shortages of chips for vehicles and other items.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden delivers his remarks during a visit to TSMC AZ's first Fab (Semiconductor Fabrication Plant) in P1A (Phase 1A), in Phoenix, Arizona, U.S. December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst
Apple and other major tech companies rely on TSMC for their chipmaking needs, and the change means they’ll be able to get more of their processors from the US.

site_title: Judge dismisses Khashoggi lawsuit against Saudi prince, citing Biden’s grant of immunity
summary: A US federal judge dismissed a lawsuit against Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, citing President Biden's grant of immunity. The lawsuit was filed by Jamal Khashoggi's fiance, Hatice Cengiz, over Khashoggi's killing in 2018. The judge cited head of state immunity, as determined by the Biden administration, despite concerns over the prince's involvement in the murder. The prince has denied ordering the killing but acknowledged it occurred "under my watch."

images.alt_text: This handout picture released by the Saudi Press Agency SPA shows Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Salman during his meeting with officials at the defence ministry headquarters in the Red Sea coastal city of Jeddah on September 27, 2022. - Saudi Arabia's power crown prince, whose prior formal role was defence minister, strengthened his position when his father, King Salman, issued a decree late on September 27 naming him as prime minister, a title traditionally held by the king. The 37-year-old de facto ruler has overseen the most fundamental transformation in the modern history of the Gulf nation and sidelined all rivals after he became crown prince in June 2017. (Photo by SPA / AFP) / === RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO / HO / SPA" - NO MARKETING NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS ===

site_title: 5 Questions with journalist turned crypto investor, Jon Russell
summary: Journalist turned crypto investor Jon Russell, a partner at Crypto.com Capital, believes the future of crypto in South-east Asia is bright due to high retail adoption of Web3 projects and ownership of tokens. Governments in the region are embracing technology, and large corporations are exploring Web3 components. Despite recent market challenges, Russell sees strong entrepreneurs and promising new companies emerging, and believes that business standards will be raised, leading to broader adoption from investors and institutions.

images.alt_text: Kelvin Teo started Funding Societies in 2015 after meeting his co-founder at Harvard Business School.
Rachel Lau, managing partner at RHL Ventures
Li Jianggan, founder and CEO of Momentum Works.

site_title: Asian bonds are back in vogue as funds scoop up Indonesian debt
summary: Global funds have invested US$467 million in Indonesian debt, the largest one-day inflow since August 2021, according to government data. This follows a US$1.5 billion purchase in November, marking the most in three years. The demand reflects an improving macro outlook and a relaxation of Covid curbs in China. As the Federal Reserve signals a slower pace of rate hikes, emerging Asian debt is expected to outperform, with Indonesian bonds seen as a barometer of risk appetite.

site_title: COE premiums fall across the board, large car category sees biggest dip of 7.4%
summary: COE premiums fell across all five categories, with the largest drop of 7.4% in the large car and electric vehicle category, down from S$113,881 to S$105,501. The open category COE price fell 3.1% to S$110,524, while the motorcycle category saw a 3.9% decrease to S$12,100. The commercial vehicle COE price decreased by 0.37% to S$81,501. These price drops indicate a decrease in demand for vehicles in Singapore.

site_title: HDB gives BTO cost breakdown; says pricing not linked to development cost
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) stated that the pricing of new public housing flats is separate from development costs and does not include a profit margin. BTO flats are priced to ensure affordability in relation to residents' household incomes and mortgage servicing ability. The HDB aims to maintain affordability and is guided by median resident employed household income, which has kept pace with the increase in average selling prices of BTO flats in both mature and non-mature estates. This pricing strategy is designed to support the needs of residents.

site_title: Preparing for next stage of Asean’s digital consumers
summary: Southeast Asia's digital consumers are evolving, with a hybrid and connected experience becoming the future. E-commerce penetration growth remains positive, with 11% of total retail valued at $129 billion. Consumers demand seamless movement between online and offline channels, driving brand-switching and the rise of non-traditional e-commerce platforms. Emerging technologies like the metaverse, Web3, and fintech are converging, creating opportunities for disruption. Businesses must adapt with strategies such as investing in the future, focusing on talent, and building a hybrid strategy to succeed in the region's digital landscape.

images.alt_text: E-commerce is expected to drive the digital economy growth in Singapore as GMV is forecasted to hit US$30 billion in 2025.

site_title: Apple CEO Cook confirms made-in-US chips push at Arizona plant
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook confirmed the company's plan to build chips in the US for the first time in nearly a decade. The Arizona plant, set to open in 2024, will initially produce chips in small quantities for Apple and may use inferior technology. The plant will build chips for most Apple devices, with the goal of producing "Made in America" chips. This move aims to reduce Apple's reliance on Asia-based manufacturing and expand its relationship with chip company TSMC.

site_title: US sees record 2023 oil output in reversal after cutting outlook
summary: The US Energy Information Administration has raised its forecast for oil production next year, reversing a five-month decline and projecting 12.34 million barrels per day, surpassing the 2019 record of 12.315 million barrels per day. This reversal follows a 30% increase in oil rigs this year, and aims to quell fears of a slowdown in US shale production amid rising crude prices and economic concerns. The revised forecast could help mitigate the risk of tight supplies following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
