site_title: Japan business mood up, global slowdown weighs on outlook: poll
summary: Japan's business sentiment has improved, with large manufacturers showing a steady outlook and the service sector experiencing a three-year high. The Reuters monthly poll found manufacturers' sentiment rose to +8, up from +2 in November, while the service sector index rose to +25, the best reading since October 2019. However, respondents expressed caution due to high energy costs, a weak yen, and global economic slowdown concerns. Despite this, the mixed readings suggest a gradual recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with the Bank of Japan's tankan quarterly survey to be released on December 14.

images.alt_text: The solid spending data suggests the release of pent-up demand is supporting the country’s recovery path for now even as inflation eats into households’ purchasing power.
Fumio Kishida’s increase could mean Japan leapfrogs countries like Saudi Arabia and France to become the world’s fifth-largest defence spender.

site_title: China’s exports, imports dive in November on feeble demand, domestic Covid woes
summary: China's exports and imports contracted 8.7% and 10.6% year-over-year in November, respectively, as feeble global and domestic demand, Covid-impacted production disruptions, and a property slump pressured the world's second-largest economy. Outbound shipments have lost steam since August due to surging inflation, interest rate increases, and the Ukraine crisis. The data marked the worst performance since February 2020 and underlined the impact of fresh Covid restrictions on manufacturing hubs.

site_title: Xi travels to Saudi for three days of Mideast outreach
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has arrived in Saudi Arabia for a three-day trip, marking his first visit to the country since 2016. The trip is Xi's third overseas trip since the 2020 coronavirus pandemic and is expected to focus on energy discussions with Saudi leaders, including King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Xi will also attend a summit with the six-member Gulf Cooperation Council and a broader China-Arab summit.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on June 29, 2017 shows China's President Xi Jinping speaking upon his arrival at Hong Kong's international airport. - Chinese President Xi Jinping will visit Hong Kong to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the city's handover to China, state media Xinhua News Agency reported on June 25, 2022. (Photo by Anthony WALLACE / AFP)

site_title: ‘Avatar’ sequel finally premieres 13 years after original
summary: James Cameron finally premiered the long-awaited sequel "Avatar: The Way of Water" 13 years after the original, taking audiences back to Pandora. The film follows Jake Sully and Neytiri, now parents of five, as they flee to a far-flung territory and seek refuge with the oceanic Metkayina clan. The sequel expands the world and family unit, with a heart-wrenching story that connects with audiences. Four Avatar movies are planned through 2028, with Cameron promising to continue exploring new locations and meeting new clans.

images.alt_text: Avatar: The Way of Water will be released in China on the same day as its global release, 20th Century Studios said on its official Weibo account.

site_title: World Cup: Ramos bags hat-trick as Portugal crush Swiss 6-1
summary: Portugal crushed Switzerland 6-1 in a World Cup quarter-final match, with Goncalo Ramos scoring a hat-trick on his full debut, becoming the youngest player to achieve this feat since Pele in 1958. The 21-year-old Ramos justified coach Fernando Santos' decision to drop Cristiano Ronaldo, who had been struggling in the tournament. Portugal will face Morocco on Saturday for a place in the last four in Qatar.

images.alt_text: People purchase beer from a Budweiser tent at a fan zone during the World Cup in Doha. A bottle of beer there is nearly 10 times the price of what it costs at a convenience store in South Korea.
Japan roared back to stun former champions Spain and Germany and top Group E, before suffering a heartbreaking defeat to 2018 finalists Croatia on penalties.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand India Trust
summary: CapitaLand India Trust is developing a data centre in Hyderabad with a planned investment of about 1,200 crore rupees (S$210 million) over 3-5 years. The project is its second data centre development in India. This news led to a 1.7% decline in the trust's units, ending at S$1.15.

site_title: New York jury finds Trump Organization guilty of fraud
summary: A New York jury found the Trump Organization guilty of tax fraud on all nine counts, marking the first time the organization has been convicted of crimes. The Trump Organization faces a fine of around $1.5 million for a 13-year scheme to defraud and evade taxes by falsifying business records. Longtime CFO Allen Weisselberg had previously pleaded guilty to 15 counts of tax fraud and testified against his former company as part of a plea bargain. The verdict holds the Trump companies accountable for their long-running criminal scheme.

images.alt_text: The jury conviction on Tuesday of two militia leaders on charges of seditious conspiracy raised the stakes for Donald Trump, who is under investigation over his role in fomenting the Capitol assault, which was aimed at keeping him in power after his election loss.

Former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at a rally to support Republican candidates ahead of midterm elections, in Dayton, Ohio, US, Nov 7, 2022. Trump’s suggestion that the United States disregard rules and regulations including “those found in the Constitution” drew scathing rebukes this weekend from politicians of both parties.

site_title: Australia’s economy slows in Q3 as higher rates, prices sap spending power
summary: Australia's economy slowed to a 0.6% growth in the third quarter, lower than forecasts, due to higher interest rates and prices sapping consumer spending power. Annual growth remains strong at 5.9%, driven by a one-off boom in travel and spending. Household consumption rose 1.1% but was down from the previous quarter, and the saving ratio dropped to 6.9%. The Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary policy campaign appears to be working, with signs of consumers tightening their belts and inflation pressure evident in the GDP report.

site_title: Apple loosens tight grip on App Store pricing
summary: Apple has announced the largest upgrade to the App Store pricing system since its launch, allowing developers to charge from 29 cents to $10,000 for their offerings. The change, set to roll out by spring 2023, offers nearly 10 times the previous number of pricing options, giving developers more flexibility to price their products. The move comes as Apple faces accusations of monopolistic control over the App Store and pressure from politicians and developers to relax its grip.

site_title: Meta expected to face new fines after EU privacy ruling
summary: Meta is expected to face another large fine after Europe's data watchdog imposed binding decisions concerning the treatment of personal data by the owner of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp. The European Data Protection Supervisor found Meta's three apps fail to meet Europe's strict rules on data protection, specifically regarding targeted advertising. Authorities in Ireland have a month to impose the ruling, which could have a dramatic impact on Meta's revenue in Europe.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again on recession worries
summary: US stocks fell 1.0-1.4% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.0% at 33,596.34, the S&P 500 down 1.4% at 3,941.26, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 2.0% at 11,014.89. Recession worries fueled the decline, with leading bank executives expressing concerns about a possible recession in 2023. Large technology companies were particularly weak, with Apple, Amazon, and Alphabet losing over 2.0%. The decline added to investor unease amid ongoing concerns about the Federal Reserve's policies.

site_title: New Zealand faces jet fuel shortage after shipment fails test
summary: New Zealand is facing a potential jet fuel shortage due to a shipment that failed quality control testing. The Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment was informed of the issue, and fuel companies have started rationing fuel until new supply is available from December 18. Airlines are working to minimize the impact on customers, with some expected to advise of any impacts once better understood.

images.alt_text: Rising building costs have been a big component of New Zealand’s soaring inflation rate.

site_title: China announces nationwide loosening of Covid restrictions
summary: China announced nationwide loosening of Covid restrictions on December 7, 2022, following protests against the zero-Covid policy. The new guidelines reduce PCR testing frequency and scope, scale down lockdowns, and allow people with mild cases to isolate at home. Non-severe cases no longer require forced quarantines, and people can enter public buildings without a green health code, except for certain institutions. The move comes as the country accelerates vaccination of the elderly and faces economic impacts from the zero-Covid policy, including a 10.6% year-on-year drop in imports and 8.7% drop in exports in November.

images.alt_text: The prospect of further relaxation of rules has sparked optimism among investors that the world’s second-biggest economy would regain strength and help boost global growth.

site_title: Vietnam’s EV maker Vinfast files for US IPO to fuel global expansion
summary: Vietnam's electric vehicle maker VinFast has filed for a US IPO to fund its global expansion, aiming to raise $2 billion with a valuation of $60 billion. The company, which has 65,000 global orders and expects to sell 750,000 EVs annually by 2026, plans to build a production plant in North Carolina. VinFast will convert to a Singapore public limited company and list on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "VFS," following a confidential submission to the US Securities and Exchange Commission in April.

images.alt_text: VinFast is in the process of building an electric-vehicle plant in North Carolina that is awaiting final regulatory approval from local officials.

site_title: Australia fines Uber A$21m for misleading advertisements about fares and cancellation fees
summary: An Australian court fined Uber Technologies Inc A$21 million (S$19.1 million) for misleading customers with threatening cancellation fees it never charged and overstating fare estimates on some rides from 2017 to 2021. The ruling also found that Uber used an inaccurate software algorithm to estimate fares for a taxi service until August 2020. The fine is lower than a regulator wanted but a setback for the company.

site_title: Gold struggles for momentum as investors await further Fed cues
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged at US$1,770.46 per ounce as investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting on December 13-14 for further rate hike cues. The Fed is expected to increase interest rates by 50 basis points, with 91% probability, according to Fed fund futures. High interest rates have weighed on gold's traditional status as a hedge against inflation, as they translate into a higher opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding metal. The US trade deficit widened in October, and the European Central Bank may need to raise interest rates to tame price pressures.

images.alt_text: US gold futures were little changed at US$1,780.90.

site_title: Singapore shares decline on Wednesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.2% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling to 3,246.43 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 71 to 41, with Sembcorp Marine losing 0.7% and Singtel slipping 0.4%. The decline follows Wall Street's losses on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1% and the S&P 500 shedding 1.4%.

images.alt_text: The data centre will be situated at the trust’s 20-acre International Tech Park in Madhapur.

site_title: Adobe cuts 100 jobs concentrated in sales as tech tightens belt
summary: Adobe has cut about 100 jobs, mostly in sales, as part of its efforts to reduce expenses. The move is part of a trend among tech companies to streamline staff and cut costs. Despite this, Adobe's workforce remains significant, with over 28,700 employees as of September. The company shifted some employees to critical positions and reduced a small number of other jobs, according to a statement. This move is smaller compared to other tech companies that have announced thousands of job cuts.

site_title: US to increase rotational military presence in Australia, invite Japan
summary: The US will increase the rotational military presence in Australia, including air, land, and sea forces, including bomber aircraft and fighter jets, amid shared concerns about China. The US also invited Japan to integrate into force posture initiatives in Australia. The move aims to push back against China's aggressive actions in the Indo-Pacific region, including around Taiwan and the Pacific Island countries. The agreements were made during the 32nd annual Australia-US Ministerial Consultations and include increased force-posture cooperation, enhanced military capability, and the creation of a seamless defense industrial base.

site_title: Apple scales back self-driving car and delays debut until 2026
summary: Apple has scaled back its self-driving car plans, shifting from a fully autonomous vehicle to a design with a steering wheel and pedals, and limited to highways. The project, dubbed Titan, had been delayed to 2026 from a 2025 debut. The company is now aiming to offer the vehicle for less than $100,000, with a focus on practical goals rather than ambitious technological advancements. Apple's technology, including a custom onboard computer system and sensors, will be used to support autonomous capabilities on highways, but not in urban areas.

images.alt_text: Initially, the plant will only build chips in small quantities for Apple and may use technology that is inferior to what the company will need for its flagship devices in 2024.

site_title: Sailing in the ‘dark’
summary: A growing number of commercial vessels are switching off their Automatic Identification System (AIS) signals, making them harder to track, in an effort to evade sanctions and restrictions related to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. This trend is linked to geopolitics and illegal activities such as fishing in Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZs). Companies like Unseenlabs are detecting these vessels, which can become invisible for hours or days, and are being used to transport Russian oil and other cargoes. The development is a concern, as it threatens transparency and regulation in global shipping.

images.alt_text: BIMCO

site_title: Chinese hackers stole millions of US Covid relief money, Secret Service says
summary: Chinese hackers, part of the APT41 group, have stolen tens of millions of dollars in US Covid relief benefits since 2020, according to the Secret Service. The group, known for government-backed cyber intrusions and financially motivated data breaches, was indicted in 2019 and 2020 for spying on over 100 companies. China's Embassy in Washington denies making the country safe for cybercriminals, calling the accusations "groundless." The Secret Service declined to provide further details on the incident.

site_title: Chinese carmaker BYD eyes Chilean lithium deals in search for EV fuel
summary: BYD, a Chinese electric carmaker, is seeking lithium deals in Chile and Africa amid record-high prices, which have more than doubled in China this year. The company's executive vice-president, Stella Li, said BYD is scouting for opportunities globally, including a mining project in Chile and investments in African lithium projects. BYD aims to process raw lithium into cathode for batteries and secure a reserve of the key battery component. The move follows BYD's expansion into the EV market and its need for reliable lithium supplies.

images.alt_text: China’s BYD, in which Berkshire Hathaway owns a stake, said it will roll out an electric sports utility vehicle, ATTO 3, in Japan starting Jan 31.

site_title: Credit Suisse dangles sweetened rates to rebuild depleted assets
summary: Credit Suisse is offering sweetened rates to its wealthy clients to rebuild depleted assets, amid a recent pullout of $90 billion. The bank's head of wealth unit, Francesco de Ferrari, is mobilizing 1,800 relationship managers to offer higher-yield notes and bonus deposit rates. This includes a 5% to 6% interest rate threshold and fixed-rate notes paying 7% to compensate investors for lending their cash for months. The move aims to regain stability in the bank's core business of managing wealth for the rich.

images.alt_text: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is considering an investment of around US$500 million to back the new unit CS First Boston (CSFB) and its CEO-designate Michael Klein, the report said, adding that bank has not yet received a formal proposal from any Saudi entity.

site_title: Markets look to big political year in 2023
summary: Markets are focusing on 2023's key elections, including India's hosting of the G20, which may boost Prime Minister Narendra Modi's re-election prospects in 2024. Other notable elections include the US midterm congressional ballots, Myanmar's first election since the 2021 coup, and the polls in Turkey, Nigeria, Spain, and Poland. These elections will shape domestic politics, international relations, and the global economic and financial landscape, potentially having long-term effects beyond the 2020s.

site_title: Dearth of China tourists hindering Asia’s economic recovery
summary: Mainland Chinese tourists significantly contributed to Asia's economic recovery, but a decline in their numbers is hindering the region's growth. According to the United Nations, international arrivals to Asia and the Pacific plummeted by 95.3% in 2021 due to travel restrictions, resulting in 30 million job losses. The tourism sector, which previously accounted for 185 million jobs, is struggling, with less developed economies feeling the impact most. The lack of foreign currency income is exacerbating the economic challenges in these regions.

images.alt_text: Residents wait in line at a Covid-19 testing facility at night in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. China's top leaders will likely signal a more pragmatic approach toward Covid controls at a key upcoming meeting while putting more focus on boosting economic growth, economists say. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The Bank of Thailand predicts about 10.5 million foreign tourist arrivals this year, and 22 million in 2023.
Fear of Covid-19 infection was the top concern of people saying they would postpone travel in a survey of 4,000 consumers in China by consultancy Oliver Wyman.

site_title: Biden celebrates US manufacturing comeback at giant semiconductor project
summary: US President Joe Biden celebrated the comeback of US manufacturing at a Taiwanese-owned semiconductor plant in Phoenix, Arizona, as the company plans to invest $40 billion in expanding and upgrading its US production hub. The project, which will produce 600,000 microchips per year, is expected to create 10,000 high-tech jobs and meet the US goal of ending reliance on foreign-located factories, particularly in Taiwan. The expansion is seen as a major milestone in revitalizing US-based manufacturing, with Biden citing his signature CHIPS Act as a key factor in attracting the investment.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall for third day on renewed global recession fears
summary: European shares fell for a third day on Tuesday, with the Stoxx 600 index closing 0.6% lower, amid concerns about a global economic slowdown and interest rate hikes. Investors are worried about a recession in the run-up to major central bank decisions. The European Central Bank, US Federal Reserve, and Bank of England will meet next week to discuss monetary policy. Rate-sensitive tech stocks slid 1.6%, while the healthcare sector lost 1.2%, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Morgan Stanley will cut about 2,000 jobs ahead of potential US recession
summary: Morgan Stanley plans to cut about 2,000 jobs, roughly 2% of its global workforce, to reduce costs ahead of a potential US recession. The cuts, estimated to be around 1,600 employees, come as the bank seeks to operate more efficiently. Morgan Stanley had over 80,000 employees at the end of the third quarter, compared to about 60,000 before the pandemic. The move is part of the bank's efforts to tame costs and prepare for a potential economic downturn.

site_title: Oil prices slump to pre-Ukraine crisis levels on economic jitters
summary: Oil prices plummeted to pre-Ukraine crisis levels, with Brent crude futures falling 4% to $79.35 a barrel and WTI crude futures dropping 3.5% to $74.25 a barrel. The decline was driven by economic jitters, including a string of bearish news, a rout in equity markets, and uncertainty around Federal Reserve rate hikes. Service-sector activity in China has slowed, and European economies are struggling due to high energy costs and rising interest rates. Analysts predict prices could drop further, with some predicting $60-a-barrel WTI.

images.alt_text: Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak expects a slight output decline in the country's oil and gas condensate following the latest sanctions.

site_title: India holds up export of 27,000 Vivo phones in clash with China
summary: India has blocked the export of 27,000 Vivo smartphones worth nearly $15 million due to an alleged misdeclaration of device models and value. The shipment has been held up at New Delhi airport for over a week, potentially affecting other Chinese smartphone players in India. The move is seen as a setback to Vivo's plans to ship devices to neighboring markets and could threaten India's target of exporting $120 billion worth of electronics by 2026. The action has also been criticized by industry lobby groups, citing "unilateral and preposterous" actions by the government agency.

images.alt_text: A man cleans a screen displaying a phone model of Chinese smartphone maker Vivo inside a shop in Ahmedabad, India, December 14, 2018 REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Foxconn is pictured on top of a company's building in Taipei, Taiwan October 31, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins/File Photo

site_title: The mess at Kitchen Culture leaves  minority shareholders with a bad taste
summary: A dispute at Singapore-listed Kitchen Culture has left minority shareholders feeling disenfranchised. Ooway Group and seven other shareholders attempted to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to oust five directors from the company's board, citing concerns over unauthorised transactions and payroll irregularities. However, the EGM's validity was disputed, and the issue now lies with the courts. The situation highlights the need for an independent party to ensure that shareholders receive adequate information, potentially involving the sponsor or regulator in facilitating a resolution.

images.alt_text: Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. In its latest statement the company said it “sharply criticised” requisitioners for proceeding with an EGM held on Nov 25.

In the bourse filing, Kitchen Culture said the redesignation is due to “the need for the chairman of the board to lead the company forward in the challenging business climate and shareholders’ issues faced by the company”

site_title: World Cup: Morocco dump Spain out on penalties to reach historic quarter-finals
summary: Morocco defeated Spain 3-0 in a penalty shootout after a 0-0 draw, advancing to the World Cup quarter-finals for the first time. ACHRAF Hakimi scored the decisive penalty, dinking it past the Spanish goalkeeper. Morocco will face Portugal in the quarter-finals, marking a historic milestone for the North African team. The win comes after Spain coach Luis Enrique claimed his team prepared for penalties by taking 1,000.

site_title: Making the case for Singapore law
summary: Singapore law is gaining recognition as a preferred governing law in cross-border transactions, ranking second only to English law in a 2019 survey. The country's neutrality, progressive legislation, and supportive judiciary contribute to its success as a dispute resolution venue. To further promote the adoption and use of Singapore law, policymakers should consider liberalizing the legal profession, enabling more foreign lawyers to advise on Singapore law, and allowing for joint law ventures and qualifying foreign law practices. This will not only benefit the legal profession but also enhance Singapore's stature as a leading financial and legal hub.

images.alt_text: Han Kun plans to have less than 10 staff in Singapore though it could expand further based on demand, one of the people added.
The S$12.6 million civil penalty imposed on Noble seems minuscule compared to the billions of dollars in market value that evaporated
The law exodus: Where is the Promised Land?

site_title: Goldman warns on job cuts as BofA slows hiring on potential recession
summary: Goldman Sachs is embarking on its largest job cuts since the pandemic, planning to eliminate several hundred roles, amid mounting economic uncertainty and a potential US recession. Morgan Stanley is also reducing its global workforce by 1,600, or 2%, as rival banks slow hiring. Goldman's CEO David Solomon warned of "bumpy times ahead" and exercising caution with financial resources, citing slowing growth and a possible recession in 2023. This move is part of a broader trend of job cuts and hiring freezes in the US, with Bank of America also slowing hiring.

images.alt_text: Goldman is doing due diligence on a number of different crypto firms and sees some really interesting opportunities, priced much more sensibly.
The company is trying to protect its profitability after a costlier-than-expected foray into consumer banking.

site_title: US: Wall St inches lower at open after selloff on Fed worries
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Tuesday, December 6, after a selloff on concerns the Federal Reserve may continue with interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones fell 10.23 points, or 0.03%, to 33,936.87, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The focus shifted to the Georgia runoff election that could decide the Senate's fate.

site_title: Ensuring safety as tech controls our health
summary: Singapore's Cyber Security Agency has launched a new labelling scheme for medical devices to address growing cybersecurity risks from connected medical devices. The scheme aims to ensure patient safety and protect sensitive medical data. However, experts warn that medical devices pose multiple attack vectors, including legacy devices lacking cybersecurity capabilities, and the risk of firmware-level corruption. The labelling scheme rates devices based on testing and assessment, but it's just the first step in a long journey for the healthcare industry to develop robust cybersecurity defences and protect patient data.

images.alt_text: laboratory, test tubes, healthcare worker
Switching to an online trust management platform can bring huge cost savings to the healthcare sector.
Realising smarter, more secure healthcare

site_title: US backs delaying WTO decision on Covid therapies, tests
summary: The US has urged a delay in a World Trade Organization (WTO) decision on COVID-19 treatments and tests, citing a need for additional information. The six-month deadline for agreeing to extend a partial intellectual property waiver was previously set. US Ambassador Katharine Tai's office stated that real questions remain on the issue, and more time will help the world make an informed decision. The US International Trade Commission (USITC) study will examine production processes, intellectual property protections, and global market data, among other areas.

site_title: Developing economies’ debt more than doubled over decade: World Bank
summary: The external debt of developing economies has more than doubled from $4 trillion in 2011 to $9 trillion in 2021, according to the World Bank. This intensifies the debt crisis facing these countries, with many already facing or at risk of debt distress due to global inflation and rising interest rates. The World Bank warns of a fifth wave of debt crisis, urging a comprehensive approach to reduce debt, increase transparency, and facilitate swifter restructuring to support growth and reduce poverty. Global growth is slowing sharply, with a risk of world recession in 2023.

images.alt_text: The World Bank is confident that the global slowdown will have a much lower impact on India than other emerging economies.

site_title: An overhaul of Malaysia’s pension system is long overdue
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has vowed to address the country's pension crisis, which affects over half of the country's 12.7 million Employees Provident Fund (EPF) members. The crisis has led to a significant withdrawal of funds, with at least RM145 billion taken out since 2020, resulting in many members having less than RM10,000 in their retirement savings. Anwar has hinted at making tough decisions, such as revising EPF contribution rates or setting up a new fund, to address the issue, which is expected to worsen with the country's aging population, with 20% of the population aged 65 and above by 2056.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's prime minister (middle) and deputy prime minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi at the first meeting with cabinet ministers in Putrajaya on Monday (Dec 5).

site_title: EU raises concerns over Meta’s targeted ad model: WSJ
summary: EU regulators have ruled that Meta Platforms' Facebook and Instagram should not require users to agree to personalized ads based on their digital activity. The ruling, approved by a board representing all EU privacy regulators, could limit the data that Meta can access to sell such ads. The decision does not directly order Meta to change practices but calls for Ireland's Data Protection Commission to issue public orders and impose significant fines. Meta's European headquarters is based in Ireland, and shares of the company were down 2.5% in morning trade.

site_title: Microsoft mulls building ‘super app’
summary: Microsoft considered building a "super app" to loosen Google and Apple's hold on the mobile search space, aiming to boost advertising and Bing search, while drawing users to Teams messaging and other mobile services. The move was reportedly aimed at competing with Alphabet's dominance in the mobile search market.

site_title: Asean’s growth to slow in 2023, but region remains a bright spot in a slowing world
summary: Southeast Asian economies, including Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam, are expected to see their growth rates slow to 4.4% in 2023, down from 5.6% this year, due to fading post-Covid reopening boosts and global headwinds. Interest rate hikes and currency volatility will also put upward pressure on interest rates in the region. However, some economies, such as Thailand, may buck the trend, driven by tourism improvements and lower global shipping costs. The region is expected to remain a bright spot in a slowing world, with investors remaining wary of risk assets.

images.alt_text: Ronald Chan, the founder of Hong Kong boutique investment firm Chartwell Capital, espouses a 'buy-and-hold and rebalancing approach' for growth and income.
SEA is projected to grow by four to five per cent annually over the next 10 years, led by Vietnam.
FILE PHOTO: A worker adjusts an ASEAN flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: ADDX fractionalises venture debt fund by Temasek unit, UOB joint venture
summary: Private market exchange ADDX has fractionalised a venture debt fund, Innoven Sea Fund I, allowing individual accredited investors to subscribe with a minimum of US$20,000, down from US$5 million. The fund is a joint venture between Temasek's Seviora Holdings and UOB. This move aims to increase accessibility to venture debt, which is poised to grow, according to ADDX CEO Choo Oi Yee.

images.alt_text: Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX.
Bottles of vintage wine in the Provenance Treasures portfolio. Both carry "Grand Cru'' appellations.
GSH Corp's first commercial paper in the form of digital securities will be listed on ADDX.
Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX, said blockchain allows assets to be liquid for both public and private markets.
Choo Oi Yee, CEO of ADDX, noted that the private credit market has more than doubled in size since 2015 and is now worth more than US$1 trillion worldwide.
Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX, said the move to allow domestic capital to buy into high-quality offshore assets will in turn drive further economic growth in China.
PRIVATE market exchange ADDX will now consider cryptocurrency assets in verifying accredited investors.

site_title: HBO Max returns to Amazon Prime in bid to lure subscribers
summary: HBO Max is returning to Amazon Prime, a move aimed at attracting millions of new subscribers to the streaming service. The deal will allow Amazon customers to sign up for HBO Max through the retailer's store and watch its programs within Amazon's main streaming service. This reversal reverses a move made by WarnerMedia CEO Jason Kilar in 2021, which removed HBO Max from Amazon Prime. The move is expected to bring in $600 million in annual revenue for Warner Bros Discovery, a company heavily in debt.

images.alt_text: Insider Intelligence analyst Ross Benes estimates that advertising revenues from streaming could reach US$30 billion in two years in the United States alone.

site_title: Oil prices fall on US dollar strength, economic fears
summary: Oil prices dropped 1.46% to $81.47 a barrel for Brent crude and 1.53% to $75.75 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate, amid a strong US dollar and economic uncertainty. Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak expects a slight decline in the country's oil and gas condensate output due to latest sanctions. Despite a price cap on Russian oil and potential demand boost in China, economic fears and interest rate expectations weighed on the market.

images.alt_text: From Dec 5, any company wanting to access G7 services – particularly European insurance and ships – to move Russian oil can only do so if they pay US$60 a barrel or less for the cargo.
Brent crude futures settled US$2.89, or 3.4 per cent, lower at US$82.68 a barrel on Monday.
Carbon pricing can affect leverage, profitability of Asia’s heavy emitters

site_title: UK farming union warns of food supply crisis
summary: Britain's National Farmers Union (NFU) has warned of a food supply crisis due to skyrocketing costs for farmers and growers. The union cites the pandemic's disruption of supply chains and the war in Ukraine as major factors contributing to the crisis. Rising costs for fertiliser, feed, fuel, and energy have left farmers in an "emergency situation," resulting in scarce and expensive eggs, among other food products. The NFU urges the government to take action to support the industry and mitigate the crisis.

images.alt_text: Britain’s official measure of consumer price inflation - which covers a wide range of goods and services including soaring energy bills – returned to a 40-year high of 10.1 per cent last month.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, Rabobank hit with bonds cartel complaint from EU
summary: The European Union's antitrust watchdog has sent formal complaints to Deutsche Bank and Rabobank for allegedly participating in a cartel for euro-denominated bonds between 2005 and 2016. The banks are accused of exchanging commercially sensitive information and coordinating pricing and trading strategies through emails and online chatrooms. Both banks deny wrongdoing and claim they have cooperated with the commission, with Deutsche Bank stating it has been granted conditional immunity. The investigation is the third EU probe into bond market cartels, with potential fines ranging up to 10% of the banks' revenue.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on February 04, 2021 the logo of German bank Deutsche Bank is seen on one of their branches in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - Germany's biggest lender Deutsche Bank said on July 27, 2022 it performed better in the first six months of 2022 than it has in more than a decade, but warned of increasing cost pressures down the line. (Photo by Armando BABANI / AFP)
While CEO Christian Sewing says Deutsche Bank will adhere to orders by its regulator, he warns that there can be indirect effects for the economy if the funding of companies is disrupted.

site_title: Google launches anti-misinformation campaign in India
summary: Google's Jigsaw subsidiary launches an anti-misinformation campaign in India, using "prebunking" videos to counter false claims on YouTube and other social media sites. The initiative aims to prevent misleading information that has incited violence, targeting multiple local languages and diverse sections of the country's population. The campaign follows Google's recent experiment in Europe, and aims to educate users on how to identify and refute misinformation, with results expected to be published in summer 2023.

site_title: Global airlines see return to profitability in 2023
summary: Global airlines are expected to return to profitability in 2023 for the first time since 2019, with a projected net profit of $4.7 billion, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The industry has partially recovered from the pandemic, with over 4 billion passengers expected to fly next year. However, IATA director general Willie Walsh warned that many airlines will continue to struggle due to regulations, high costs, and inconsistent government policies.

site_title: Beijing drops Covid-19 testing burden as wider easing beckons
summary: China has dropped Covid-19 testing requirements in Beijing, marking a significant easing of pandemic rules nationwide, amid growing optimism for the country's economic recovery. The move comes after historic protests last month and is seen as a step towards normalcy, with some experts warning that a hasty exit could lead to a rise in deaths. China's economy is expected to regain strength, boosting global growth, and analysts predict the country may reopen its borders sooner than expected next year.

images.alt_text: A Covid-19 testing booth in Shanghai, China, on Monday, Dec. 5, 2022. Government officials over the past week signaled a transition away from the harshest Covid containment measures, which have weighed on the economy and prompted thousands of demonstrators to take to the streets to voice their anger. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

Residents confront workers donned in protective suits who are blocking the entrance of a residential compound, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Shanghai, China, in this still image obtained from a social media video released November 30, 2022. Video obtained by Reuters/via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

site_title: US dollar kept aloft by higher Fed rates bets, RBA rate hike lifts Aussie
summary: The US dollar index edged 0.1% lower to 105.05 due to bets on higher interest rates, but remained close to levels reached earlier in the week after strong US services data. The Australian dollar rose 0.46% after the Reserve Bank of Australia raised rates for the eighth time in a row. Traders expect a half-point hike in US interest rates, while European Central Bank policymaker Constantinos Herodotou said interest rates will rise again but are near neutral.

site_title: Carbon pricing can affect leverage, profitability of Asia’s heavy emitters
summary: Asian heavy emitters face lower profitability margins and increased debt due to rising carbon prices, according to a Barclays report. The report found that some companies, such as Huaneng Power, China's Chalco and China Hongqiao, could see Ebitda margins turn negative if a high carbon price is implemented, with losses projected to reach -7% and -65% respectively. Leverage is also expected to increase for companies in the power, aluminium, and steel sectors, with some experiencing Ebitda losses and significant increases in debt.

images.alt_text: Vapour pours from a steel mill chimney in the industrial town of Port Kembla, about 80 km (50 miles) south of Sydney July 7, 2011. REUTERS/Tim Wimborne

site_title: FX swap debt an US$80t 'blind spot', BIS says
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has expressed concern over the $80 trillion in hidden, off-balance sheet FX swap debt held by non-bank financial firms, such as pension funds, which exceeds the US stocks of dollar Treasury bills, repo, and commercial paper combined. The BIS warns that this "blind spot" poses a risk to policymakers, who may be left in a "fog" due to the lack of direct information about the scale and location of the problems. The BIS also notes that recent market developments, including the crisis in UK gilt markets and crypto market troubles, underscore the need for central banks to be prepared to intervene.

images.alt_text: SGX Group has been investing to expand its FX business in recent years including through the acquisition of subsidiaries BidFX and MaxxTrader.

site_title: Singapore fintech Osome bags US$25 million in Series B round to expand Asia operations
summary: Singapore fintech Osome secured US$25 million in Series B funding to expand its Asia operations. The round, led by AFG Partners and Illuminate Financial, follows the company's revenue doubling since its previous raise. Osome, which helps small businesses manage corporate paperwork and reporting, has seen its customer base double and has helped open 11,000 businesses to date. The company plans to leverage the funding to further grow its presence in Singapore and Hong Kong, with a focus on digitizing incorporation and accounting services in new geographies.

images.alt_text: Four unicorns have been minted in Singapore this year, fewer than the 11 produced last year.

site_title: US trade deficit widens on greater imports, drop in exports
summary: The US trade deficit widened for a second month in October, growing by 5.4% to $78.2 billion, as imports increased 0.6% to $334.8 billion and exports declined 0.7% to $256.6 billion. The strong US dollar remains a key factor, making US goods more expensive for overseas customers. This may weigh on economic growth in the fourth quarter. The trade deficit has now grown for two consecutive months, raising concerns about the country's economic performance.

site_title: A hedge fund hit by FTX collapse defaults on US$36m of debt
summary: A hedge fund, Orthogonal Trading, has defaulted on a US$36 million debt after being "severely impacted" by the collapse of FTX and associated trading activities. The default occurred after taking out US$31 million in USDC stablecoin and US$4.9 million in wrapped Ether. Maple Finance, a lending protocol, severed ties with Orthogonal Trading after the hedge fund informed them of its inability to repay. The collapse of FTX is spreading to the world of decentralized finance, with contagion effects seen in the lending protocol's decision to issue a notice of default.

images.alt_text: Binance disclosed its assets and wallet addresses where the exchange stores the customers’ funds in an attempt to improve transparency.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers propose US$4.9b sovereign wealth fund chaired by Marcos
summary: Philippine lawmakers have proposed a US$4.9 billion sovereign wealth fund, to be chaired by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, to boost the country's growth. The "Maharlika Investments Fund" (MIF) would be seeded with 275 billion pesos from government financial institutions, including pension funds. Critics warn that the fund will be prone to graft and put Filipino pensions at risk, while proponents cite Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund as a success story. The fund's lack of clear direction and safeguards has raised concerns about corruption and its potential impact on the country's long-term development.

images.alt_text: The bill, overseen by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, proposes that the fund may invest in various types of instruments including, cash, foreign currencies, metals, tradeable commodities, bonds, Islamic investments and listed or unlisted equities.
Filipino coastguard personnel aboard the BRP Cabra patrol ship monitoring Chinese vessels anchored at Sabina Shoal in the disputed South China Sea, April 27, 2021.
Economists polled by Reuters had forecast inflation would accelerate to 7.8 per cent, while the central bank had forecast a figure of between 7.4 to 8.2 per cent.

site_title: Indonesia signs agreement with Denmark for potential investments up to US$500m: joint statement
summary: Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority (INA), signed a framework agreement with the Investment Fund for Developing Countries (IFU) of Denmark for potential joint investments of up to US$500 million. The agreement aims to explore investment opportunities in green energy transition and inclusive social development in Indonesia, with INA and IFU aiming to provide capital for green and sustainable projects in the range of US$100 million and US$500 million, respectively.

site_title: Turkey blocks oil tankers over proof-of-insurance rule
summary: Turkey has implemented a rule requiring oil tankers to provide proof of insurance before navigating the Bosphorus and Dardanelles shipping straits. The measure, in response to European Union sanctions, aims to verify that tankers are insured at or below $60 a barrel. However, this rule has caused delays, with vessels waiting to travel through the straits. The US has raised concerns with Turkish officials, but negotiations between Turkey and the International Group of protection and indemnity clubs are underway to resolve the issue.

images.alt_text: Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak said on Sunday that the move by the West was a gross interference which contradicted the rules of free trade and would destabilise global energy markets by triggering a shortage of supply.
Opec+ officials may prefer a wait-and-see attitude as a variety of forces play out in the oil markets.
The coalition has to contend with an especially volatile outlook, as European Union sanctions are about to come into effect on crude exports from Opec+ member Russia.

site_title: Netflix hit Emily in Paris set for global premiere in French capital
summary: The Netflix comedy series "Emily in Paris" is set for its global premiere in Paris on December 6, ahead of its third-season release on December 21. The show, which stars Lily Collins as an American marketing job in the luxury industry, has sparked controversy in France for its portrayal of Parisians. However, the show's creator and star, Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu, suggests that the series promotes cultural understanding and cooperation between Americans and French people. The show's third season adds two new cast members and explores the bridge between the two cultures.

images.alt_text: A recent British poll suggested that Prince Harry and his wife Meghan are now the least popular senior royals apart from the disgraced Prince Andrew.
The catalyst for Netflix's comeback is the introduction of a lower-priced, advertising-supported subscription tier.
Emily in Paris and the city I thought was mine

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust to develop S$210 million data centre in Hyderabad
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Telangana government to develop a data centre in Hyderabad. The data centre, situated at the trust's International Tech Park, will have a built-up area of approximately 250,000 square feet and 36 megawatts of power capacity. The project is expected to cost around S$210 million (INR1,200 Crores) over the next three to five years.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand India Trust will acquire ownership of the properties it develops with L&T Realty in a phased manner
Within Q3 2022, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit announced two acquisitions in Singapore across the industrial and logistics sub-segments, totalling purchase consideration of S$296.7 million.
CapitaLand India Trust Q3 income up 13% on higher contributions

site_title: Asian teams ‘getting closer’ despite World Cup knockout blows
summary: Asian teams made their best-ever World Cup showing, reaching the last 16 for the first time with three AFC sides (Australia, Japan, and South Korea) participating. Japan's Hajime Moriyasu believes Asia is "getting closer" to Europe, while Australia's Graham Arnold wants increased government investment to catch up with the region's growing football spending. The Asian Cup in 2023 will be crucial for the AFC to improve and potentially surpass European teams, with Qatar, the host and defending champions, looking to bounce back from a disappointing World Cup.

images.alt_text: People purchase beer from a Budweiser tent at a fan zone during the World Cup in Doha. A bottle of beer there is nearly 10 times the price of what it costs at a convenience store in South Korea.

site_title: Malaysia palm growers to lose RM20b on labour shortage
summary: Malaysia's palm oil sector is facing a RM20 billion (S$6.2 billion) loss due to a chronic labor shortage, with only 14,000 foreign workers hired despite a need for 70,000. The industry's reliance on overseas labor has been hindered by slow progress in worker approval, leading to crop losses and a potential drop in global palm oil prices. The Malaysian Palm Oil Association is seeking help from the new government to expedite bringing in more plantation workers, and authorities are taking steps to charter planes and renew agreements with source countries.

images.alt_text: Palm oil prices have come down amid concerns over a global economic slowdown, and as China maintains a strict Covid-19 containment policy that has caused mounting economic damage.
Outlook for Malaysia’s plantation sector is expected to remain resilient in the fourth quarter, said FGV, the world’s largest crude palm oil producer.

site_title: SMU launches first overseas centre in Jakarta
summary: Singapore Management University (SMU) has launched its first overseas centre in Jakarta, Indonesia, with Shoeb Kagda as centre director. The centre aims to foster deeper engagement between SMU and Indonesian institutes of higher learning, business leaders, and policymakers. SMU President Lily Kong said the centre will enable academic circles to intertwine and strengthen cooperation for higher learning skills and development in both Indonesia and Singapore. The centre will provide professional continuing education and postgraduate programmes to Indonesia's corporate, government, and industry workforce.

images.alt_text: Outgoing SMU chairman Ho Kwon Ping (right) and his successor Piyush Gupta
People enjoy the beach during sunset in Jimbaran, Bali, Indonesia, September 2, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

The Kinobi founders are (from left) Benjamin Wong, Hafiz Kasman and Joshua Pua. Kinobi, which raised US$1 million in seed funding last year, helps students draft resumes and cover letters as well as offers short online courses and job Interview practice.
A worker loads freshly harvested palm fruits on a truck at a palm oil plantation in North Sumatra, Indonesia. In May, a month-long ban on crude palm oil exports was lifted as prices stabilised.

site_title: Thaksin-linked party vows higher wages with Thai polls looming
summary: Thailand's opposition party Pheu Thai, linked to ousted Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, has launched a campaign ahead of early next year's elections, promising to lift minimum wages, crop prices, and energy costs, while boosting economic growth to 5% annually. The party's leader, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, vows to increase daily wages to 600 baht ($23.20), nearly 70% higher than the current minimum pay bracket. The party aims to score a landslide victory, but may need the support of other parties to form the government.

images.alt_text: The 35-year-old Paetongtarn Shinawatra, youngest of billionaire tycoon Thaksin’s 3 children, is launching herself into the country’s deeply divided political scene ahead of a national election due by March 2023.

site_title: Swedish real-estate companies face risk of more downgrades at Moody’s
summary: Swedish real-estate companies face increased risk of downgrades at Moody's due to rising inflation and higher funding costs, which are making debt-driven growth strategies unprofitable. Companies with low-yielding assets and significant refinancing needs are most exposed to negative actions. The sector is vulnerable to higher interest rates, with Nordic property firms needing to refinance $39.3 billion in bonds within two years. Moody's expects more "negative rating actions" as companies' ability to service debt is eroded, with valuations potentially declining by 10% on average.

site_title: Sony says it has technology for humanoid robots, just looking for use
summary: Sony has developed technology to create humanoid robots but is waiting for the right use case. The company's chief technology officer, Hiroaki Kitano, stated that the key to rapid robot development lies in finding effective applications. Sony has experience in audio-visual technology and entertainment content, positioning it well for the metaverse. The metaverse, an immersive virtual world, is a growing concept that companies like Tesla are exploring with humanoid robots. Sony is poised to play a major role in the metaverse with its expertise.

site_title: Britain’s grocery inflation falls for first time in 21 months: Kantar
summary: Britain's grocery inflation has fallen for the first time in 21 months, with prices decreasing 0.1 percentage points from October's record high to 14.6% in November. Despite this, prices remain near record highs, and consumers will need to spend an extra £60 to buy the same items as last year. The cost of a traditional Christmas dinner for four has risen 9.3% year-on-year, with prices increasing fastest in markets such as milk, dog food, and butter.

site_title: Moving into a year of inflections in 2023
summary: The world economy is expected to trough in 2023, with growth forecasts improving closer to 2024, despite a challenging near-term outlook. Inflation has peaked in the US and is in the process of peaking in Europe, but interest rates may remain high to combat inflation. China's economic recovery is delayed due to Covid-19 and property market issues, but a full reopening and higher infrastructure spending could support consumption. Asia's GDP is expected to grow around 3-4% in 2023, with a moderate mid-year recovery helping the region's GDP expand by 4.4% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong swung between gains and losses, having soared around 15 per cent over the past week on China’s easing of strict Covid containment measures.

epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Lawyer and MP Christopher de Souza found guilty of professional misconduct, denies charge
summary: Lawyer and MP Christopher de Souza has been found guilty of professional misconduct by a disciplinary tribunal. He was found guilty of not making full and frank disclosure to the court when his client, Amber Compounding Pharmacy, breached the conditions of a search order. De Souza helped his client prepare an affidavit that did not reveal the breaches, and the tribunal stated that his failure to disclose was a suppression of evidence. The tribunal dismissed four other charges and recommended a fine of S$2,000, but the case will now go to the Court of Three Judges for further action.

images.alt_text: PM Lee said Singapore’s success depends on getting 3 fundamentals right, despite its challenges. This includes always having a united people, a high-quality leadership team and high trust between the people and their leaders.

site_title: Chinese rush to stock up on antigen kits, medicine as Covid curbs ease
summary: Chinese residents are stockpiling Covid-19 antigen kits, medicine, and face masks as the country's easing of preventive measures sparks concern about increased virus transmission. Sales of antigen test kits jumped 344% in the past week, and fever medicine has sold out in some stores. Authorities have warned against hoarding and price hikes, while some residents are skeptical of the shift in messaging from officials. The surge in demand has driven up medicine manufacturers' share prices and raised concerns about the economy's price for strict Covid restrictions.

images.alt_text: Fear of Covid-19 infection was the top concern of people saying they would postpone travel in a survey of 4,000 consumers in China by consultancy Oliver Wyman.
The strict approach has battered the world’s second-largest economy, put mental strain on hundreds of millions, and last month prompted the biggest show of public discontent.
Investors are seeking potential buys as Beijing gradually relaxes curbs that combined with a property crisis made key Chinese gauges the world’s worst performers for much of this year.

Residents wait in line at a Covid-19 testing facility at night in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. China's top leaders will likely signal a more pragmatic approach toward Covid controls at a key upcoming meeting while putting more focus on boosting economic growth, economists say. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Tuesday, following Wall Street decline; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Tuesday, following a decline on Wall Street, amid concerns over US rate hikes. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,252.37, led by Keppel Corp's 2.2% drop. DBS and UOB were among the top decliners, while OCBC rose 0.2%. Analysts downgraded the banking sector to "neutral" due to softer US inflation prints. The decline follows Wall Street's drop on Monday, with most regional markets also falling.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong swung between gains and losses, having soared around 15 per cent over the past week on China’s easing of strict Covid containment measures.

site_title: US upgrades Taiwan weapons package with newer Patriot missiles
summary: The US has proposed selling up to 100 advanced Patriot air defense missiles to Taiwan, valued at $882 million. The missiles, known as Patriot Pac-3 MSE, offer improved performance and lethality compared to earlier models, and would enhance Taiwan's missile defense capability and deter regional threats. The proposal, classified as an enhancement to a 2010 sale, is expected to be reviewed by Congress for up to 30 days and would not alter the overall $2.81 billion value of that deal.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and China's Xi Jinping finally met face-to-face as leaders on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia, Nov 14, 2022.
President Joe Biden speaks at a news conference following his meeting with President Xi Jinping of China in Bali on Monday (Nov 14). The two leaders also discussed North Korea.

site_title: Indonesia government to create a mechanism for rollout of B35 biodiesel policy
summary: Indonesia's government plans to create a mechanism for the rollout of B35 biodiesel, a fuel containing 35% palm oil-based fuel, in 2023. This aims to reduce dependency on oil imports. The country is currently testing B40 biodiesel, and the government expects headline inflation to be between 5.34% and 5.5% at the end of 2022. The implementation of B35 will be monitored alongside global geopolitical and economic factors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance reported "good progress" in uplifting low-wage workers' real incomes, with growth outpacing median earners between 2016 and 2021. The Singapore Public Sector Outcomes Review also highlighted workforce challenges that can be addressed through tripartism. Meanwhile, CGS-CIMB downgraded its sector call to "neutral" from "overweight" due to potential slowdown in the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes. Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Tuesday, following Wall Street decline, amid concerns over rate hikes.

site_title: UK construction growth ebbs away as economy falters: PMI
summary: The UK construction industry's growth slowed in November, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 50.4, its lowest level since January 2021. High borrowing costs and a gloomy economic outlook led to stagnant housebuilding and deteriorating civil engineering activity. The future activity gauge also sank to its lowest level since the Covid-19 pandemic, consistent with a recession. The Bank of England's interest rate hikes have contributed to the decline, with input prices falling to their lowest level since January 2021.

images.alt_text: Kantar said grocery sales rose 5.9 per cent year on year in the 12 weeks to Nov 27, masking a drop in volumes once inflation is accounted for.

site_title: Australia's Big Four banks pass central bank rate hike to home-loan customers
summary: Australia's Big Four banks, Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, will raise home loan rates by a quarter-point, mirroring the Reserve Bank of Australia's 25 basis point cash rate hike to 3.1%. This is the eighth rate hike in as many months to combat inflation, with Westpac to follow with its rate hike on December 20. The banks will pass on the rate increase to their customers in full, marking a significant move in response to the central bank's decision.

site_title: Philippines’ Jollibee in talks to sell a stake in Vietnam’s Highlands Coffee
summary: Jollibee, the Philippines' largest fast-food operator, is in talks to sell a minority stake in its Vietnamese coffee chain Highlands Coffee, valued at around $800 million. The sale, which could pave the way for an IPO, is part of Jollibee's strategy to expand overseas and tap into growing consumer spending in South-east Asia. Highlands Coffee has over 500 stores in Vietnam and the Philippines, and its sale could further fuel the region's booming coffee industry.

site_title: Oil merchants troubled by trade norms that don’t fit the cap
summary: The Group of Seven nations has imposed a $60 per barrel oil price cap on Russian oil exports, effective December 5, in an effort to punish Russia for the Ukraine war and curb oil revenue. Companies wanting to access G7 services, particularly European insurance and ships, must pay $60 or less per barrel to move Russian oil. This move aims to prevent a supply disruption and surge in prices while maintaining exports, as the US pushed for the measure to soften European Union sanctions. The market is now assessing the cap's impact on global oil supplies.

images.alt_text: Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak said on Sunday that the move by the West was a gross interference which contradicted the rules of free trade and would destabilise global energy markets by triggering a shortage of supply.

site_title: Underground restaurants, secret bars: Beijing residents dodge Covid curbs
summary: Beijing residents are defying strict Covid curbs by dining in underground restaurants and drinking in secret bars. Despite dine-in services being prohibited in much of the city, residents have found ways to access indoor dining options, often through social media platforms like Xiaohongshu. These clandestine establishments have become popular, with some even offering full capacity to customers. The relaxation of pandemic control measures has emboldened residents to skirt the rules, highlighting the ongoing tensions between the government's Covid policies and the public's desire for normalcy.

images.alt_text: While many Chinese residents are relieves that some Covid-19 preventive measures have been relaxed – which includes less testing – there are many others who now feel more vulnerable to catching the virus.

Residents wait in line at a Covid-19 testing facility at night in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. China's top leaders will likely signal a more pragmatic approach toward Covid controls at a key upcoming meeting while putting more focus on boosting economic growth, economists say. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

Covid-19 test results are no longer needed in Shenzhen to enter public transport, drug stores, parks and outdoor tourism spots, according to statements issued by the Shenzhen government Saturday (Dec 3).

Residents confront workers donned in protective suits who are blocking the entrance of a residential compound, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Shanghai, China, in this still image obtained from a social media video released November 30, 2022. Video obtained by Reuters/via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES
Residents confront workers donned in protective suits who are blocking the entrance of a residential compound amid a Covid-19 outbreak in Shanghai, China, Nov 30, 2022.

site_title: Foreign equity funds pile into Indian financials as credit cycle picks up
summary: Foreign investors bought a net of $1.7 billion worth of Indian financial stocks in November, attracted to the country's largest lenders due to a fresh credit cycle. Indian shares are trading at a record-high valuation premium, but overseas investors see financials as relatively cheap given strong fundamentals. This optimism reflects a shift in investor sentiment, with foreign investors seeking value in India's financial sector amidst a global economic backdrop.

images.alt_text: Festive shopping ahead of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, in the old quarters of Delhi, India, in October 2022.
The Reserve Bank of India is expected to stay hawkish at the monetary policy review next week as inflation stayed above the 2-6 per cent target since the start of 2022.

site_title: Overseas football fans at Qatar World Cup feel currency pain
summary: Overseas football fans at the 2022 World Cup in Qatar are facing financial strain due to the strong Qatari riyal, pegged to the US dollar. Currency fluctuations have increased costs for everything from hotel bills to stadium food, with prices nearly 10 times higher than in South Korea and Japan. Fans are also dealing with inflation in their home countries, making the trip even more expensive. Despite measures by Qatar to mitigate rising costs, the strong US dollar remains a significant burden for tourists.

images.alt_text: South Korea's Son Heung-min (centre) and his teammates celebrate wildly after they defeated Portugal 2-1 to qualify for the Round of 16. South Korea will play Brazil on Dec 6 for a place in the quarter-finals
The BT-World Cup 2022 CEO Challenge will see 16 business leaders take part to raise funds for the BT Budding Artists Fund.

Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Group G - Brazil v Serbia - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - November 24, 2022
Brazil's Richarlison scores their second goal REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: EU agrees law preventing import of goods linked to deforestation
summary: The European Union has agreed on a new law to prevent companies from selling into the EU market goods linked to deforestation, such as soy, beef, and palm oil. The law requires companies to produce a due diligence statement proving their supply chains are not contributing to deforestation before selling goods, with fines of up to 4% of a company's turnover for non-compliance. The law applies to 10 commodities and will enter into force 20 days after formal approval by EU member nations.

images.alt_text: Stacked containers are shown as ships unload their cargo at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles.

site_title: ESG regulations worst greenwash risk for firms: JPMorgan
summary: JPMorgan analyst Jean-Xavier Hecker warns that ESG regulations may become the "hardest crackdown on greenwashing" due to the widespread availability of climate change knowledge. The European Union's stricter ESG guidelines are likely to impact major climate coalitions, pressuring them to "level up their standards". Regulators may also assess the alignment between investment philosophies and actual investment decisions, and may require fund managers to validate their portfolios. This represents an "unprecedented" level of regulatory intervention in the ESG market.

images.alt_text: Bankers expect at least half of the loan deals for investment-grade firms in Europe, the Middle East and Africa to be tied to environmental, social and governance targets in 2023.
Biopharmaceutical company AstraZeneca transformed its procurement strategy to be more transparent and sustainable.

The floating solar solar photovoltaic testbed at Tengeh Reservoir.  Newer taxonomies are displaying more similarities than differences, an analysis by the German Agency for International Cooperation and Center of Clean Air Policy has found.

site_title: China’s top air cargo carrier links with online booking platform
summary: China's top air cargo carrier, China Southern Airlines, has partnered with online booking platform WebCargo to offer real-time rates, capacity, and bookings. This is a notable milestone for global supply chains, particularly those needing smoother trade with China. The partnership increases WebCargo's accessible capacity to 50%, raising revenue expectations for airlines. The move follows the industry's rapid adoption of digital platforms after the pandemic, with air freight generating $204.1 billion in revenue in 2021.

images.alt_text: China used to be the world’s busiest domestic aviation market, handling about 14,000 flights a day.
The C919 is China’s rival to the popular Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX narrowbody jet families, as the country looks to become more self-sufficient.
Fllights in and out of China remain at about 95% below pre-Covid levels, according to data provider VariFlight.
Boeing, which hasn’t signed a major plane deal with China since 2017, took the unusual step of issuing a statement after the July Airbus order was announced.

A China Eastern Airlines aircraft at Hongqiao International Airport in Shanghai. The airline is among five China state-owned companies that will exit US stock exchanges over a dispute on the disclosures demanded by the US Public Company Accounting Oversight Board.

site_title: Over A$13b of projects in limbo as Australian contractor Clough falls
summary: Australian engineering firm Clough has collapsed, leaving over A$13 billion of projects in limbo. The projects span Australia, Mongolia, and Papua New Guinea, including the Oyu Tolgoi copper mine and major power plant and transmission projects. Deloitte has taken over as administrator, aiming to source immediate interim funding to continue work on as many projects as possible. Clough's collapse is a significant blow to Australia's energy and infrastructure sectors, with several major projects facing delays.

images.alt_text: Former union leader Christy Cain rallies workers on strike at Knauf plasterboard plant in Port Melbourne, Australia, Oct 5, 2022.

site_title: China helps with US tech firm scrutiny in sign of easing tension
summary: China has begun cooperating with the US in ensuring American technology isn't routed to China's military, a positive step in easing tension between the two countries. Chinese firms on the Unverified List, including memory maker Yangtze Memory Technologies, have 60 days to show their products won't go to a military end-use, with the deadline expiring on Monday. This cooperation comes after a breakthrough meeting between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping last month, opening the door for renewed cooperation on shared priorities.

images.alt_text: Historically lagging in a space race dominated by the United States and Russia, Beijing has made significant advances in recent years that have alarmed Washington and other Western nations.

site_title: Not the time for big macro investment calls, but be selective
summary: Markets have been driven by news flow and expectations of the Federal Reserve's actions, leading to volatility and uncertainty. Investment expert Fabiana Fedeli advises against "broad-strokes" investing, such as betting on market direction or sector calls, citing that earnings and yields are more important. She recommends investing in equities outside the US, particularly the UK and Japan, due to favorable currency and valuation conditions. Fedeli also suggests fixed income assets, like BBB-rated corporate bonds, as a more attractive option, but emphasizes the need for selectivity. For those with a 3-5 year investment horizon, she believes it's a good time to invest, but near-term volatility and stagflation concerns remain.

images.alt_text: For now, the professional investing class will need to see more conclusive evidence of a benign shift in the economic trajectory before materially changing their defensive positioning across the beaten-up world of stocks and bonds.
A sliding dollar could create pockets of opportunities in what’s already expected to be a lacklustre 2023.

site_title: Geely-backed Cao Cao said to pick banks for Hong Kong IPO
summary: Cao Cao Mobility, a ride-hailing firm backed by Geely, has selected banks for its planned Hong Kong IPO, including ABC International Holdings, Bank of America, and Huatai International. The IPO could occur as soon as next year, potentially raising hundreds of millions of US dollars. Cao Cao is expected to file its preliminary prospectus in April, pending the release of its 2022 financial results. The company aims to compete with Didi Global in the Chinese ride-hailing market, offering services in 62 cities across China.

site_title: Fuel runs short at South Korean petrol stations as union plans general strike alongside truckers
summary: A nationwide strike by South Korean truckers over a minimum pay program has led to nearly 100 petrol stations running dry, disrupting the country's supply chain and costing over 3.2 trillion won in lost shipments. The strike, which began on Nov 24, has seen two negotiation sessions with the government but no breakthrough. A national trade union plans a general strike on Dec 6 to support the drivers, with the government urging them to return to work.

images.alt_text: The union is asking the government to ensure big businesses are held accountable if they violate the minimum wages rule.

site_title: India to grow 6.9% this year: World Bank
summary: The World Bank has revised its forecast for India's economy, predicting a 6.9% growth rate for the fiscal year, higher than its previous estimate of 6.5%. This is due to India's strong performance in the third quarter, with a 6.3% expansion from July to September. The revised forecast also lowers India's growth expectation for next year to 6.6% from 7%. Despite a global slowdown, the World Bank believes India is well-positioned to tackle headwinds.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in Janpath area in New Delhi, India, on Saturday, Aug. 27, 2022. India is scheduled to release second-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) growth figures on Aug. 31. Photographer: Kanishka Sonthalia/Bloomberg
Festive shopping ahead of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, in the old quarters of Delhi, India, in October 2022.
Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharamanis expected to announce the plans when she presents the annual budget for 2023/24 to Parliament on Feb 1., 2023

Average house prices in India were expected to rise 5.0 per cent over each of the next three years, lagging the current consumer price inflation rate, after increasing by 7 per cent in 2022, according to the Nov 9-Dec 1 poll.

site_title: Goldman Sachs on hunt for bargain crypto firms after FTX fiasco
summary: Goldman Sachs is conducting due diligence on various crypto firms, seeing opportunities to invest or acquire companies after the FTX collapse, which has heightened the need for more trustworthy, regulated players. The bank plans to spend tens of millions of dollars, and its CEO David Solomon views cryptocurrencies as having "highly speculative" potential but believes underlying technology has long-term potential. Goldman has invested in 11 digital asset companies and is building its own private distributed ledger technology, amid a global crypto market that has shed about $2 trillion this year.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs and other big banks are under pressure to move more traders from London into EU cities such as Paris, Frankfurt and Amsterdam.

site_title: Workforce challenges can be solved through tripartism, say speakers at regional meeting
summary: Tripartism and social dialogue are key to addressing workforce challenges, according to speakers at the 17th Asia and the Pacific Regional Meeting in Singapore. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng and President Halimah Yacob emphasized the importance of collaboration between governments, workers, and employers in introducing job-saving measures and supporting displaced workers. The International Labour Organization (ILO) director-general Gilbert Houngbo highlighted the need for a fairer and more inclusive growth model, with a focus on tripartism and social justice.

images.alt_text: The latest public sector report found that real income growth of the 20th percentile earners was at 2.7 per cent per annum between 2016 and 2021.
An association representing Deliveroo, Grab and foodpanda disagrees with the exclusion of street-hail taxis and certain logistics companies from the new rules.

site_title: Xi hails Jiang as leader who stood up to West after Tiananmen
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping praised his predecessor Jiang Zemin as a leader who stood up to Western pressure and domestic turmoil after the Tiananmen crackdown in 1989, crediting him with carrying out the Communist Party's "correct decision" to resolve the "severe political disturbance." Xi highlighted Jiang's efforts to promote economic development and China's global reemergence, while also echoing his own assertive agenda. The memorial service for Jiang, who died at 96, comes as China faces protests against Xi's Covid Zero policies, with Xi's speech serving as a warning against Western pressure and a call to unity.

images.alt_text: Efforts to mourn Jiang who took steps to open the Asian nation to the world could provide a fresh impetus for gatherings that turn into a platform to criticise Xi.

site_title: Intel says it’s on course to regain chip production leadership
summary: Intel is on track to regain leadership in semiconductor manufacturing, according to Vice-President Ann Kelleher. The company is accelerating its efforts to introduce new production techniques, including 4-nanometre semiconductors, and has vowed to reverse market share losses to rivals like AMD and Nvidia.
