Intel's goal is to improve its manufacturing capabilities and attract customers for its contract manufacturing business, while also competing with TSMC and Samsung. The company's efforts are part of a broader strategy to address declining revenue and demand for personal computers.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as Fed worries offset China Covid easing
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday as the US Federal Reserve's concerns over interest rates offset optimism over China's easing of strict Covid containment measures. The US services sector saw a forecast-busting jump in activity, dashing hopes for a less hawkish Fed approach. Markets swung, with Hong Kong gaining 15% in the past week on China's economic reopening, while other Asian markets fluctuated. Oil prices rose on expectations of a reopening boost. Analysts predict China won't see a complete end to zero-Covid policy for several months.

site_title: German factory orders rise on hopes of milder recession
summary: Germany's factory orders rose 0.8% in October, beating expectations, as large-scale orders offset a potential 1.2% decline. Warm autumn weather helped fill gas-storage facilities and alleviate supply chain pressure. This tempered fears of a deep winter slump and eased price pressures. German inflation slowed to 11.3% in November, with underlying inflation expected to remain elevated. The Ifo Institute's business expectations gauge also rose, suggesting a less severe recession than initially expected.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Christmas shoppers wear masks and fill Cologne's main shopping street Hohe Strasse (High Street) during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Cologne, Germany, December 12, 2020.  REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo##########germany##########

site_title: Australia central bank raises rates to 10-year high, says more needed
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised its cash rate by 25 basis points to a 10-year peak of 3.1% in its last policy decision of 2022, the eighth hike in as many months. The decision was widely expected and indicates that policymakers aim to rein in inflation. Governor Philip Lowe stated that the RBA will continue to increase interest rates further, but not on a pre-set course, and will assess the impact of the rate hikes. The decision aims to pause the tightening trend until February.

site_title: ‘Paris deal’ for nature is key for business too
summary: Representatives from nearly every country gather in Montreal for the UN COP15 summit to address the world's biodiversity crisis, which is described as "flashing red." The 15th Conference of the Parties to the UN Convention on Biological Diversity aims to protect the world's biodiversity, with a key target being to protect at least 30% of land and water by 2030. However, comprehensive agreement remains uncertain, following a disappointing first phase last year where countries fell short of specific targets.

images.alt_text: Enshrined in the Paris Agreement is the goal to limit global warming to well below 2.0 deg C from pre-industrial levels, and preferably the safer ambition of 1.5 deg C.
It's estimated that a single forest elephant today contributes US$2.6 million worth of carbon sequestration services.

An aerial view of the Johor Strait. A study by the NUS Business School’s Centre for Governance and Sustainability scoped out the top 50 listcos by market capitalisation across 13 Asia-Pacific jurisdictions, and found that the overall nature disclosure rate is 31.4 per cent.

site_title: Indonesia maps out a digital rupiah as a ‘tool of the future’
summary: Bank Indonesia plans to introduce digital rupiah, a blockchain-based currency, as a tool of the future. The central bank aims to make it the legal tender on local digital platforms and applications, including the metaverse. This move, dubbed "Project Garuda," is part of Indonesia's efforts to develop a central bank digital currency (CBDC) to safeguard its position in a rapidly changing digital era. Governor Perry Warjiyo sees digital rupiah as "inevitable" and a key step in keeping Indonesia at the forefront of CBDC development.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo says his country won't follow a purely open economic model that he blamed for undercutting Latin America's growth prospects for decades.

site_title: Samsung, LG to invest billions more in Vietnam
summary: Samsung and LG plan to invest billions more in Vietnam, with Samsung adding US$2 billion, raising its total investment to US$20 billion, and LG investing US$4 billion to turn Vietnam into a smartphone camera production hub. The investments follow production cuts in Vietnam due to weaker global demand. The move aims to solidify Vietnam as a key production site for both companies, with total bilateral trade expected to reach US$100 billion by next year and US$150 billion by 2030.

images.alt_text: Many global tech giants, such as Apple, Luxshare, Pegatron and Wistron, have decided to expand their production capacities in Vietnam in recent years.

Hoe Boon Chye, chief executive of Barghest Building Performance, believes the Vietnam segment of his business has the potential to grow 40 per cent year on year, given the country's rapid industrialisation.

site_title: ‘Good progress’ made in uplifting incomes of low-wage workers: MOF report
summary: Singapore has made "good progress" in uplifting the real incomes of low-wage workers, with 20th-percentile earners experiencing 2.7% annual growth between 2016 and 2021, outpacing median earners. The country has also seen a decline in income inequality, with the Gini coefficient falling to a historic low of 0.375 in 2020. The economy has recovered from its worst recession in 2020, with 7.6% growth in 2021, and labor productivity has risen by 5.2%.

images.alt_text: The unemployment rate for PMETs dips to 2.6 per cent, down from 3.4 per cent a year ago, according to the MOM report.

site_title: Philippine inflation leaps to 14-year high in November
summary: The Philippines' consumer prices rose 8.0% in November, a 14-year high, exceeding economists' forecasts of 7.8% and the central bank's 7.4-8.2% prediction. The increase was driven by rises in food prices. The core consumer price index rose 6.5% excluding volatile food and energy components. The central bank's governor has hinted at another interest rate hike at the upcoming meeting, following a 75-basis-point hike last month.

site_title: Foxconn reports big sales drop after iPhone plant disruption
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest iPhone assembly complex operator, reported an 11.4% drop in sales for November due to a Covid outbreak in Zhengzhou, China. The company expects the fourth quarter to be "roughly in line with market consensus" after government lockdowns, worker exodus, and violent protests affected production. Foxconn has reassured that the situation has been brought under control and production will improve through the rest of the year. The company's shares slid 2.4% in Taiwan trading, while Apple's stock dropped less than 1% in the US.

images.alt_text: Workers at Foxconn’s iPhone factory in Zhengzhou in central China clashing with security forces on Nov 23, 2022. Foxconn expects its Zhengzhou plant to resume full production around late December to early January, a source said on Monday.

site_title: Adnoc, Petronas sign Abu Dhabi unconventional oil resources deal
summary: Adnoc and Petronas signed a six-year agreement to explore and appraise unconventional oil resources in Abu Dhabi's Al Dhafra region. The deal, valued at 22 billion barrels of crude, is the first investment by a Malaysian company in an Abu Dhabi concession. Petronas retains a 100% stake in the operating rights, with Adnoc holding an option to hold a 50% stake in the concession, creating significant in-country value for the UAE. The agreement follows preliminary operations by Adnoc in the concession area.

images.alt_text: The signatories of the MoU were Marina Surzhenko, Vopak commercial, business development and energy transition director and Emry Hisham, Petronas head of carbon management.

site_title: Japan plans defence spend that could put it on par with Russia
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has ordered a 57% increase in the country's defence budget to 43 trillion yen (S$426 billion) over the next five years, potentially making Japan the world's fifth-largest defence spender. This move comes after the country was shocked by Russia's invasion of Ukraine and amid growing concerns over China's threats towards Taiwan and North Korea's atomic ambitions. The increased spending will be used for items such as missile stockpiling and ballistic missile interceptors, and aims to triple the number of military units equipped with these interceptors in the next decade.

images.alt_text: The solid spending data suggests the release of pent-up demand is supporting the country’s recovery path for now even as inflation eats into households’ purchasing power.

site_title: Frasers Property appoints new head of sustainability
summary: Frasers Property appoints Paolo Bevilacqua as the new head of sustainability, effective immediately. Bevilacqua will deepen the company's environmental, social, and governance (ESG) agenda by working with the leadership team and business units. He brings over 20 years of experience in the real estate industry, including sustainability-related senior appointments. Bevilacqua will report to Chia Khong Shoong, group chief corporate officer, and will continue to be based in Sydney, Australia. His appointment aims to drive Frasers Property's ESG efforts and explore strategic partnerships with external stakeholders.

site_title: US, EU weigh climate-based tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminium
summary: The US and European Union are weighing new tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum to combat carbon emissions and global overcapacity. The move, part of a climate-focused trade effort, aims to address China's significant carbon footprint and steel and aluminum production. The plan, still in its initial phase, has raised concerns about deepening divisions between Beijing and Washington, particularly as the two countries have committed to working together on climate change. Discussions are ongoing, with a potential agreement expected by late next year.

images.alt_text: A majority of British public bodies use surveillance cameras made by Hikvision or Dahua, privacy advocacy group Big Brother Watch said in July.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam Group, Trek 2000
summary: Olam Group secured a $2 billion bridge financing facility to support its reorganisation plan. Shares of Olam Group closed unchanged. Trek 2000 International's former CFO Gurcharan Singh was sentenced to 11 months' jail and fined $20,000 for falsifying accounts and forgery. The group's founder and former executive director were previously convicted of related conspiracies.

site_title: Emmy-winning ‘Cheers’ star Kirstie Alley dies at 71
summary: Actress Kirstie Alley, a two-time Emmy winner, has died at 71 after a battle with cancer, according to her family. Alley rose to fame for her role as Rebecca Howe in the sitcom "Cheers" and starred in films like "Look Who's Talking." Her family described her as "fierce and loving" and said she left them inspired to live life to the fullest. Tributes have been paid by her co-star John Travolta, who called her one of the "most special relationships" he's had. Alley's cause of death was not specified.

site_title: DBS Foundation awards new grants to 23 recipients, including SMEs
summary: DBS Foundation has awarded grants to 23 recipients, including 15 social enterprises and 8 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), totaling S$3 million. The grants focus on sustainability efforts, aiming to impact over 2 million lives by providing access to healthcare, education, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The recipients will use the funds to scale up growth, expand to new communities, and improve their products through research and development, with a focus on reducing energy consumption and food waste.

images.alt_text: Scan Hub’s vision, mission and daily practices are intentionally aligned to enable an inclusive and impactful workplace and they should be a leading inclusive employer that many admire, says president of ARC Denise Phua
At least 2,500 of the bank’s employees will be deployed to run some 800 workshops at DBS/POSB branches.

site_title: DBS could be most susceptible to rate cuts amid slowing sector outlook: CGS-CIMB
summary: Singapore bank DBS may be most susceptible to rate cuts due to its rich valuations and incremental margin expansion already priced in. CGS-CIMB downgraded its sector call to "neutral" and DBS's call to "hold" from "add" due to slower rate hikes. The bank's target price was cut to S$36.50 from S$38.75. In contrast, OCBC and UOB maintained their "add" calls with target prices of S$13.70 and S$34.80, respectively.

images.alt_text: UOB has made headlines after lifting the maximum bonus interest rate on its flagship One Account to 7.8 per cent, following similar moves by rivals DBS and OCBC in the months before.
DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.##########banks##########CHONG JUN LIANG
DBS continues to have a home loan specially for home owners of public housing flats at 2.6 per cent a year – similar to the current HDB concessionary interest rate.
Singapore banks posted robust earnings in the third quarter of 2022 with record figures, as the lenders continued to benefit from interest rate hikes.
Despite the banks' rally, the  30 stocks in the blue-chip benchmark Straits Times Index posted a

site_title: Volkswagen resumes production at China plants
summary: Volkswagen has resumed production at its plants in Chengdu, China, after a brief halt due to rising coronavirus cases and missing parts. Production at the Chengdu plant, which makes the Jetta brand and VW New Sagitar, was stopped on November 21. The two lines at the Chengchun plant are also now running as normal. The resumption comes as China eases some of its strict zero-Covid curbs amid rising cases and widespread protests.

site_title: ‘Harry & Meghan’ Netflix docuseries opens old wounds
summary: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan's Netflix docuseries, "Harry & Meghan," has reignited a row with his brother William, sparking concerns about the impact on the royal family. The six-part series, set to air in the coming months, is expected to reveal the couple's strained relationship with their family, including complaints about racism within the royal family. A recent poll found Harry and Meghan are now the least popular senior royals apart from Prince Andrew, with only 39% and 28% of people viewing them favorably, respectively.

images.alt_text: Australian actor Elizabeth Debicki with English actor Dominic West in London, at last week's world premiere of season five of The Crown, in which they play Princess Diana and Prince Charles.
King Charles moved rapidly to evict Lady Susan Hussey from the royal household after the hurtful exchange with charity campaigner Ngozi Fulani, a black British woman.

site_title: Facebook owner Meta may remove news from platform if US Congress passes media bill
summary: Meta Platforms threatened to remove news from its platform if the US Congress passes the Journalism Competition and Preservation Act, which aims to help the struggling local news industry by allowing news organizations to negotiate collectively with companies like Google and Facebook. The proposal has been met with opposition from over two dozen groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, arguing it would create an antitrust exemption and not provide sufficient funding to journalists. A similar Australian law has largely worked, with tech firms signing deals with media outlets since its implementation in 2021.

images.alt_text: Some firms have since pulled back in the wake of broad stock-market declines and growing fears about the US economy heading into a recession.
Instagram, acquired in 2012, built an advertising business that is a major revenue driver for Meta.

site_title: Gold flat after sharp declines on US data
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged in early Asian trade on Tuesday, following a 1.5% decline in the previous session. The US dollar rebounded after data showed a strong US services industry, prompting speculation of larger interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Higher interest rates tend to weigh on gold's appeal, increasing the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding metal. The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points next week.

images.alt_text: US gold futures were up 0.2 per cent at US$1,812.60 on Monday.

site_title: UK consumer spending fails to keep pace with inflation: surveys
summary: UK consumer spending increased 3.9% year-on-year in November, but this growth was largely offset by a 11.1% annual inflation rate, the highest in 41 years. Surveys found 94% of Britons concerned about energy bill impact on personal finances, leading to reduced non-essential spending. Retail sales also grew 4.2% year-on-year, but remained below current inflation, indicating continued volume decline.

site_title: PepsiCo to cut hundreds of jobs as economic pain grows: WSJ
summary: PepsiCo is cutting hundreds of jobs at its North American snack and beverage units, citing a need to "simplify" the organization. The layoffs, affecting headquarters workers, come as the company faces uncertain economic conditions and inflation. Despite increasing commodity costs, PepsiCo maintains strong demand for its products. The move follows similar cost-cutting measures by other companies, including media giants and tech firms, as they retrench on costs in response to the economic environment.

site_title: Musk’s Neuralink faces federal probe, employee backlash over animal tests
summary: Elon Musk's Neuralink is under federal investigation for potential animal-welfare violations amid internal staff complaints about rushed animal testing, resulting in unnecessary deaths. The US Department of Agriculture's Inspector General launched the probe at the request of a federal prosecutor, focusing on violations of the Animal Welfare Act. Neuralink has killed about 1,500 animals, including 280 sheep, pigs, and monkeys, since 2018, with employees claiming the number of animal deaths is higher than necessary due to pressure from Musk to accelerate development. The company has passed USDA inspections, but employees say the rushed schedule and lack of preparation led to botched experiments.

images.alt_text: when the global soccer tournament started Nov 20, Twitter’s US ad revenue was running at 80 per cent below internal expectations for that week.

Twitter owner Elon has met with Apple chief executive officer Tim Cook, and says the two had a “good conversation” and “resolved the misunderstanding about Twitter potentially being removed from the App Store”.
Recent price cuts and added incentives by Tesla suggest that demand in China has failed to keep up with supply.

site_title: Singapore shares fall on Tuesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 7.65 points to 3,259.89. Investors feared the Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening policy to ease inflation amid optimistic economic data, which led to a decline in US shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 1.8% and 1.9% respectively.

images.alt_text: Olam Agri has secured a US$2 billion bridge financing facility to support the reorganisation plan of its parent company, Olam Group.

site_title: Australia records first current account deficit in three years
summary: Australia's current account recorded a deficit of A$2.3 billion in the July-September quarter, its first in three years, due to a record high income deficit from bumper dividend payments to foreign investors. Despite this, net exports still contributed 0.2 percentage points to GDP growth in the third quarter, beating forecasts. Annual growth is expected to jump to 6.3%, mainly driven by a one-off boom late last year. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to hike interest rates by 25 basis points to a decade-year high of 3.10%, its eighth rise in as many months.

images.alt_text: Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Philip Lowe has emphasised the benefits of pandemic-era policy stimulus for Australia’s labour market. Economists sees the RBA hiking by a quarter-percentage point to 3.1 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: Japan’s households spend more despite falling real wages
summary: Japan's households boosted spending in October for a second straight month, defying expectations of a decline, as inflation and falling real wages continue to impact purchasing power. Spending rose 1.1% from September, driven by gains in clothing and entertainment, and 1.2% from a year ago. Economists forecast a return to growth this quarter, citing private sector investment and consumption, despite a shrinking economy in the previous quarter. Real wages, however, fell for a seventh month, at a rate of 2.6% decline.

images.alt_text: The final au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers’ index (PMI) fell to a seasonally adjusted 50.3 from October’s 53.2, hitting the lowest since August.

site_title: Few Chinese keen to travel abroad soon, even if Covid-19 curbs ease: report
summary: China's consumer recovery from COVID-19 measures will take time, with 51% of surveyed consumers planning to delay international travel, despite eased domestic curbs. Fear of infection and changes to domestic re-entry guidelines are top concerns. Short-haul destinations, such as Hong Kong, are expected to be the first to benefit. Consumer sentiment remains subdued, but nearly half of respondents plan to boost spending if conditions improve, with a focus on personal well-being and health-related expenses.

site_title: Microsoft is raising price of new Xbox games to US$70 from next year
summary: Microsoft is increasing the price of new Xbox games to $70 from $60 starting in 2023. The $10 bump will affect next-generation games, including Starfield, Redfall, and Forza Motorsport, which will still be available as part of Microsoft's subscription service, Game Pass, for $9.99 a month. The move follows other gaming rivals, and the company cited the content, scale, and technical complexity of the titles as the reason for the price increase.

site_title: US factory orders beat expectations in Oct
summary: US factory orders rose 1.0% in October, beating expectations, driven by strong gains in machinery and other goods. Orders jumped 12.8% year-over-year, reversing concerns of a manufacturing slowdown. The Federal Reserve's rate hikes have dampened demand, while the Institute for Supply Management survey showed a contraction in factory activity for the first time in 2.5 years. The jump in factory orders was led by a 2.2% increase in transportation equipment orders, and solid gains in machinery and computer orders.

images.alt_text: The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) said on Monday (Dec 5) its non-manufacturing PMI increased to 56.5 last month from 54.4 in October, which was the lowest reading since May 2020.

site_title: JPMorgan is buying top-rated CLOs again after retreat this year
summary: JPMorgan Chase has resumed buying top-rated collateralized loan obligation (CLO) securities in the US, a move seen as a sign that some of the market's biggest investors may return to buying the securities. The bank is buying AAA graded CLOs sporadically, with yields having shot up in recent months. This follows a pullback by many US banks from owning the securities due to stress tests and rising rates. JPMorgan is receiving unusually wide interest spreads on its purchases, indicating the prices may be low enough for other banks to re-enter the market.

images.alt_text: Global indices are displayed on a screen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 19, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Securing digital innovations in financial institutions
summary: Banks and financial institutions are investing heavily in digital technologies, including cloud migrations and emerging technologies like AI and IoT, to meet growing consumer demands. However, this shift also presents opportunities for cyber attackers, particularly ransomware actors, to exploit security loopholes. To mitigate this risk, identity security is becoming a crucial control for organizations, with 79% of senior security leaders admitting that cybersecurity has taken a back seat to digital transformation. Securing identities is key to delivering measurable cyber risk reduction, meeting compliance requirements, and driving competitiveness in the long term.

images.alt_text: Boards of directors must recognise the critical part they play in strengthening their organisations' security posture.
Financial institutions filed 1,489 incidents related to ransomware in 2021, up from 487 the year before.

site_title: Greece, Britain discussing Parthenon Sculptures return but deal not close, Athens says
summary: The Greek government and Britain are in talks over the repatriation of the Parthenon Sculptures, but a deal is not imminent. The British Museum has ruled out returning the marbles, which include half of the 160-metre frieze, citing legal acquisition. The British government has no plans to change laws preventing removal from the collection, and the museum will not dismantle its collection. Greece has called for the permanent return of the 2,500-year-old sculptures, which were removed by Lord Elgin in the early 19th century.

images.alt_text: Stuart Fowkes recording the sound of a passing London Underground train at Blackfriars tube station in London; to him, there is nothing dull or uninteresting about the screeching of the train’s wheels scraping against the curves in the metal tracks or the clunk of the doors opening and closing.

site_title: New Zealand seeks lower building costs through more competition
summary: New Zealand aims to reduce soaring building costs by increasing competition in the industry. The government will consider recommendations from the Commerce Commission report to make it easier for new products and methods to enter the market. The report found that a building regulatory system favoring familiar products and rebates paid to suppliers hinder competition. The government plans to respond to the report by March, with the goal of bringing down costs for consumers and addressing New Zealand's high inflation rate.

images.alt_text: The survey’s headline measure showed a net 57.1 per cent of respondents expected the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, versus a 42.7 per cent pessimism level in the previous poll in October.

site_title: Modi set to retain power in key state of Gujarat, exit polls show
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), is predicted to retain power in the key state of Gujarat after regional elections, with at least seven exit polls showing a strong support for Modi ahead of 2024 national elections. The BJP may sweep Gujarat and win two-thirds of the 182-member assembly seats, while the Congress Party may win fewer seats than its tally in the last elections. The results signal broad political stability, which will be welcomed by investors despite economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Festive shopping ahead of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, in the old quarters of Delhi, India, in October 2022.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH ceases coverage on Riverstone in absence of catalysts
summary: UOB Kay Hian is ceasing coverage on Riverstone Holdings due to a lack of immediate and future catalysts. The research house cites ongoing industry headwinds and a depressed share price performance for the group's healthcare gloves segment. The "hold" rating with a price target of S$0.67 remains unchanged, indicating a neutral stance on the stock. Riverstone's share price performance is expected to remain unfavorable until H2 of FY2023 due to a demand-supply imbalance in the healthcare gloves segment.

images.alt_text: Riverstone executive chairman and chief executive Wong Teek Son said that despite normalisation of demand for healthcare gloves, its clean room segment continues to hold steady.
The Malaysian glove maker on Tuesday posted its first quarterly loss since listing amid rising cost pressures and a pullback in demand.
Brokers’ take: CSG-CIMB downgrades Riverstone Holdings on weakening demand
DBS does not expect a repeat of Riverstone's recent high payout of its a special and final dividend per share of 12.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: Binance sees 30% surge in trading activity on FTX implosion
summary: Binance, the largest crypto exchange, saw a 30% surge in trading activity in November following the collapse of FTX, citing FTX-related volatility. Trading volume jumped to $705 billion, mainly driven by Binance, while the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index fell 18% in the same month. The FTX implosion also benefited US-regulated exchanges like Coinbase and Kraken, which have seen rising trading volumes. Binance's disclosure of customer funds and wallet addresses aimed to improve transparency, potentially positioning it for benefits despite lacking an official headquarters.

images.alt_text: Zhao Changpeng, CEO of Binance said the exchange had frozen about US$3 million that hackers moved to the Binance’s centralised exchange.

site_title: World Cup: Croatia reach quarters with shoot-out victory over Japan
summary: Croatia advanced to the World Cup quarter-finals with a 3-1 penalty shoot-out win over Japan after the match ended 1-1 in regular time. Mario Pasalic scored the decisive penalty, with Dominik Livakovic saving three of Japan's weak penalties. The match saw a tense encounter with both teams creating chances, and Croatia's Ivan Perisic levelled the scores before Mario Pasalic sealed the win. Croatia will face Brazil in the next round, while Japan's bid to reach the last eight ended in defeat.

site_title: China analysts hunt for clues of property market turnaround
summary: China is taking steps to reverse its historic property slump, but analysts are cautious about a full recovery. The market's turmoil, exacerbated by Covid-19 curbs and demographic changes, will make a comeback difficult. Key indicators for a turnaround include housing sales, land purchases, and new housing starts, which have been declining since 2021. The government's policies, such as supporting lower-tier cities and easing financing restrictions, may help stimulate the market. However, economists expect a mild recovery, with some predicting the market may never reach pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: The strict approach has battered the world’s second-largest economy, put mental strain on hundreds of millions, and last month prompted the biggest show of public discontent.

site_title: World Cup: Bento steps down as  South Korea’s coach after team’s exit
summary: South Korea's coach Paulo Bento announced he would not be staying on after the team's elimination from the World Cup with a 4-1 defeat to Brazil. Bento, 53, had taken over the team in 2018 and led them to the knockout round for the first time since 2010. He expressed pride in the team's performance, citing their group stage success and the talent of his players, including captain Son Heung Min. Bento's decision to step down was made in September, and he plans to rest and consider his future.

site_title: World Cup: Neymar returns as Brazil brush aside South Korea to reach quarter-finals
summary: Brazil overcame South Korea 4-1 to reach the quarter-finals of the World Cup, with Neymar returning from injury to score a penalty and move to 76 goals for his country. Vinicius Junior and Richarlison also scored, with Brazil's forwards putting the tie to bed in the first half. The victory marked Brazil's first four-goal knockout win at the tournament since 1998, and they will face Croatia in the quarter-finals.

site_title: Bankrupt crypto lender Celsius wins approval to give out bonuses to stem exodus
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt cryptocurrency lender, has received court approval to distribute up to $2.8 million in bonuses to non-executive employees to prevent them from quitting. The payments, ranging from $25,000 to $425,000, are part of a plan to keep the company operational while it exits bankruptcy. Celsius has reduced its workforce from 370 to 170 employees since entering bankruptcy in July. The company must file a restructuring plan by February 15.

site_title: Oil falls over 3% after data raises Federal Reserve interest rate worries
summary: Oil prices fell over 3% on Monday after US service sector data raised concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate policy. US services industry activity unexpectedly picked up in November, contradicting hopes for a slowdown in rate hikes. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) reaffirmed its plan to cut output by 2 million barrels per day, but the market remains cautious due to uncertainty over the Fed's actions and potential global economic growth slowdowns.

site_title: Britain finalising plans for regulation of crypto industry: FT
summary: Britain is finalising plans to regulate the cryptocurrency industry, including limits on foreign companies selling into the country and restrictions on advertising. The Financial Conduct Authority will have broader powers to monitor firms' operations and advertisements. The new regulations come after the collapse of cryptocurrency exchange FTX, prompting concerns over market stability. The package will also outline plans for winding down crypto firms and may restrict companies from selling into the British market. The regulations are aimed at increasing transparency and stability in the sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of virtual cryptocurrencies are placed on U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken November 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Emergency call services, telcos urge EU to protect telecoms networks from power cuts
summary: Europe's top telecoms operators and emergency services lobby urged the EU to protect telecoms networks from power cuts, citing concerns about emergency call services and infrastructure. A joint letter from the European Telecommunications Network Operators and the European Emergency Number Association warned that planned outages could leave citizens without access to communications, including emergency services. The EU Commission was called upon to ensure energy supply to grids to maintain telecom infrastructure, as back-up solutions are costly and fragile.

site_title: Singapore may need carbon credits or nuclear energy to reach net zero by 2050: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore may struggle to reach its net-zero target by 2050 without relying on carbon credits or nuclear energy, according to Senior Minister of State for Finance and Transport Chee Hong Tat. Chee stated that while solar power may contribute a single-digit percentage to the country's energy mix, nuclear energy could be a viable option if it becomes safe enough for a highly urbanized city like Singapore. Carbon credits would allow Singapore to achieve net-zero while still promoting economic growth.

images.alt_text: Degrowth pushes for the downscaling of harmful industries and the flourishing of helpful ones that address social needs, justice, care and sustainability, its proponents say.
About 44 per cent of new family offices in Singapore, were from Greater China, as of April this year.

epa07757516 Chinese 100 yuan or renminbi (RMB) notes in Beijing, China, 05 August 2019. China's Yuan fell below the key level of seven to the US Dollar for the first time in eleven years, following the last week's US President Donald Trump's threat for more tariff on Chinese goods, according to media reports on 05 August 2019.  EPA-EFE/ROMAN PILIPEY

A shot of Singapore's central business district. Indonesia’s newly-minted tech billionaires are beginning to diversify their wealth and are increasingly looking to Singapore to set up family offices and seek new investment opportunities.
Singapore millionaires surge to 526,000; ultra-wealthy up 8.6% to 4,200
Singapore is increasingly favoured as it is less connected to Beijing from a regulatory, political, and financial perspective.

United Nations secretary-general, António Guterres, urges all governments to tax the excessive profits of the oil majors and to use the funds to support the most vulnerable people through these difficult times.

site_title: Germany’s Scholz: We must avoid dividing the world into Cold War-style blocs
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz warned against a new Cold War by dividing the world into blocs, emphasizing the importance of building new partnerships to protect democratic values and counter threats from China and Russia. In an opinion piece, Scholz stressed the need for stronger European and trans-Atlantic unity to address Russia's aggression and China's growing isolationism, particularly regarding Taiwan. He also highlighted Germany's commitment to becoming a guarantor of European security and a bridge-builder within the European Union.

site_title: Prince Harry says UK royal household plays 'dirty game' by leaking stories
summary: Prince Harry claims the UK royal household engages in a "dirty game" of leaking stories about each other, describing it as a deliberate attempt to harm others. In a new Netflix documentary series, Harry and his wife Meghan are set to deliver further criticism of the monarchy and accusations of racism, which the family has previously dismissed. The prince suggests he is no longer on speaking terms with his father, King Charles, and brother, Prince William, and believes "no one knows the full truth" about the royal family's actions.

images.alt_text: King Charles moved rapidly to evict Lady Susan Hussey from the royal household after the hurtful exchange with charity campaigner Ngozi Fulani, a black British woman.

site_title: GM launches first large EV plant in Canada
summary: General Motors has launched its first large electric vehicle plant in Canada, located in Ingersoll, Ontario, with an estimated $519 million investment from the federal and Ontario governments. The plant, which retooled in seven months, will produce BrightDrop Zevo 600 electric delivery vans, with a goal of 50,000 units per year by 2025. The plant's inauguration was attended by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who hailed it as a "big Canadian milestone" in the country's electric vehicle future.

images.alt_text: An assembly robot operates on the line at automaker General Motors (GM) Brightdrop unit's CAMI EV Assembly, Canada's first full-scale electric vehicle manufacturing plant, in Ingersoll, Ontario, Canada December 5, 2022.  REUTERS/Carlos Osorio

site_title: France’s Sarkozy seeks to overturn graft conviction at appeal trial
summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy sought to overturn his 2021 conviction for bribery and influence-peddling in an appeal hearing, citing his honor had been violated. The initial trial sentenced Sarkozy to three years in prison, two suspended, for trying to bribe a judge and peddle influence for confidential information about his campaign finances. The appeal trial, scheduled to last until Dec 16, will review the verdict and sentence, potentially reducing his prison time.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after more strong economic data
summary: US stocks fell on Monday after stronger-than-expected US services data raised concerns about the Federal Reserve prolonging its interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.4%, while the S&P 500 fell 1.8% and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.9%. The data also sparked concerns about a China comeback, which could lead to inflationary pressures. Individual stocks like Tesla and VF Corporation also fell due to production cuts and forecast downgrades.

site_title: Indonesia resumes football league after stadium disaster
summary: Indonesia resumed its football league behind closed doors two months after a stampede at a stadium in Malang killed 135 people, including 40 children. The league will be completed without fans, with the government prioritizing the national team's participation in upcoming tournaments. The country's football association and government have implemented safety measures, with police and association officials overseeing the matches. The season will be finished, with previously scheduled matches completed, according to the country's chief security minister.

images.alt_text: Joko Widodo, President of Indonesia, says: “Kanjuruhan stadium in Malang...we will demolish it and rebuild according to Fifa standards.”

site_title: Singapore’s Olam Agri secures US$2b for parent’s reorganisation
summary: Olam Agri secured a US$2 billion bridge financing facility to support its parent company Olam Group's reorganisation plan, which aims to categorize products under two operating businesses. The 18-month loan provides financial flexibility for Olam Agri while Olam Group continues its reorganisation pathway. This follows the company's previous loan of US$2.9 billion in August for refinancing existing loans.

site_title: US service sector activity picks up in November: ISM survey
summary: US service sector activity unexpectedly picked up in November, with employment rebounding and new orders dipping, according to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) survey. The non-manufacturing PMI increased to 56.5 from 54.4 in October, indicating expansion in the services sector, which accounts for over two-thirds of US economic activity. This upbeat report has raised optimism about a short and mild recession in 2023, with some economists even betting that a recession could be avoided.

site_title: Choppy waters ahead for shipping, but rates to stabilise above pre-pandemic levels
summary: Shipping prices have stabilized after a tumultuous two years, with container freight rates falling 40-80% in the last six months. However, long-term rates are expected to remain high, stabilizing above pre-pandemic levels. Demand is expected to slow due to lower consumer demand, recession fears, and built-up inventories, leading to a potential 2.5% decline in cargo volumes. The industry's 30-year trend of shipping getting cheaper is expected to not resume, with costs such as fuel prices and shipbuilding costs remaining elevated. Rates are expected to stabilize at 20-50% above 2019 levels.

images.alt_text: The slowdown is expected to impact shipping, which transports more than 80 per cent of global trade, although tanker freight rates could stay high.

site_title: High deposit rates are hogging the headlines, but the fine print tells another story
summary: High deposit rates are attracting investors, with UOB, DBS, and OCBC recently increasing their rates. However, a closer look at the fine print reveals that the actual effective interest rates are lower due to interest rate brackets and conditions. For example, UOB's One Account has a maximum headline rate of 7.8%, but the effective rate is only 5% when a S$100,000 balance is maintained. Savers should conduct due diligence to ensure they understand the product and conditions before investing.

images.alt_text: CPF could be on the brink of adjusting Special Account interest rates, as 10-year Singapore government bond yields have climbed to more than 3.1 per cent
The uptrend in fixed deposit rates comes in tandem with accelerating home loan rates in recent months.
UOB lifted the maximum bonus interest rate on its One Account from 3.6 per cent to 7.8 per cent.
DBS raised the maximum interest rate on the Multiplier account to 4.1 per cent a year, up from 3.5 per cent previously.

The government said it would continue to watch the interest rate environment closely “to ensure that the CPF interest rate pegs remain relevant in the prevailing operating environment”, while taking into consideration the longer term outlook.

site_title: Creditors approve HK Air’s HK$49b debt restructuring plan
summary: Hong Kong Airlines' creditors have approved a HK$49 billion debt restructuring plan, with at least 80% of creditors backing the plan. The airline was struggling before the pandemic and had seven planes seized by the airport authority. The carrier had defered a dollar-bond interest payment due to the COVID-19 quarantine, but the city has since eased restrictions. The plan is a step to stave off insolvency, and court hearings to sign off on the results are set for this Friday in England and next Wednesday in Hong Kong.

site_title: ‘Huge, missing and growing:’ US$65t in dollar debt sparks concern
summary: The US has a massive hidden debt of over $80 trillion, exceeding the value of dollar Treasury bills and commercial paper, due to institutions holding "missing" dollar debt off their balance sheets through currency derivatives. This debt, estimated at $65 trillion, poses a risk to global policymakers, particularly in times of crisis, as it can create dollar funding squeezes and settlement risks. The Bank for International Settlements warns that the lack of information on this debt makes it challenging for policymakers to anticipate and respond to financial crises.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which tracks the greenback against six peers, fell 1.4 per cent last week, and 5 per cent in November, its worst month since 2010.

site_title: From brink of bankruptcy to one of Europe’s top football teams
summary: Borussia Dortmund, one of Germany's top football teams, was on the brink of bankruptcy in 2005 with debts of $154 million. Under CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke's leadership, the club was restructured and streamlined, implementing cost cuts and a financial plan that included player pay cuts. Watzke turned the club around within a few years, and today, Dortmund is a solvent club with revenue of $334 million. The club has qualified for the Champions League knockout stage and is expected to have a healthy outlook in the coming years, with Watzke predicting a debt-free status.

images.alt_text: England's teenage star Jude Bellingham celebrates after scoring the opening goal in his team's 6-2 thrashing of Iran at the World Cup in Qatar on Nov 21, 2022.
