Manchester City paid £50 million for Borussia Dortmund striker Erling Haaland.

site_title: Central banks around the globe extend November’s rate hike push
summary: Central banks worldwide raised interest rates by 350 basis points in November, with six of the 10 most heavily-traded currencies experiencing hikes, shifting the policy tightening wave towards Asia and away from Latin America and emerging Europe. This brings total rate hikes in 2022 to 2,400 bps, with interest rates expected to continue rising in 2023 to combat decade-high inflation.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - SEPTEMBER 19: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve Board Building is seen on September 19, 2022 in Washington, DC. The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) is set to hold its two-day meeting on interest rates starting on September 20.   Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images/AFP
After hikes of 75 basis points at their last two meetings, ECB officials appear to be increasingly open to a smaller move at their final gathering of the year on Dec 14-15.
Economists have given a median 78 per cent chance of a recession in the EU within a year in a Reuters poll last month, and predicted the economy would contract 0.4 per cent this quarter.
Bundesbank president Joachim Nagel notes that the ECB’s tightening push will eventually tame price growth that is currently running at five times its goal.
Fed Chairman Jerome says that wages are the largest cost for the services sector, so labour conditions are key to understanding the outlook on prices on everything from hotels to haircuts.
Christine Lagarde, European Central Bank president, says that central banks must deliver a monetary policy that anchors expectations.
Furiously buying gold again, central banks may think they are getting a bargain, with its price having slid 3 per cent this year.

The bill, overseen by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, proposes that the fund may invest in various types of instruments including, cash, foreign currencies, metals, tradeable commodities, bonds, Islamic investments and listed or unlisted equities.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on recession fears, China optimism limits losses
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Monday due to recession fears after data showed a decline in euro zone business activity. However, optimism over easing Covid-19 curbs in China boosted miners and other China-exposed equities, limiting losses. The Stoxx 600 had gained for seven consecutive weeks prior to this drop, driven by China-led optimism and easing interest rate hike concerns.

site_title: Hertz to settle most false-arrest claims for US$168m
summary: Hertz Global Holdings will pay US$168 million to settle hundreds of false-arrest claims against it. The company had filed police reports against customers who didn't return rental cars on time, leading to false arrests, often at gunpoint. The deal settles about 95% of the 364 claims against the company, with Hertz expecting to recover a "meaningful portion" of the settlement from its insurers. The settlement ends a dispute that began in bankruptcy court, where the company had been fighting to bottle up the lawsuits.

images.alt_text: Hertz plans electric car fleet expansion with 65,000 Polestars

site_title: Sesame Street star Bob McGrath dies aged 90
summary: Bob McGrath, the 90-year-old actor who played the iconic character Bob on Sesame Street, has died following complications from a stroke. McGrath, a former member of the show's original cast, was known for his gentle and polite demeanor, and his 47-year tenure on the series. He began his career in music and television, performing on shows such as Sing Along with Mitch and recording albums in Japan. McGrath's daughter, Cat, confirmed his death, saying he died at home surrounded by his family.

images.alt_text: Fans of Sesame Street were surprised on Friday (Aug 19) to see that hundreds of episodes, most from the first 40 years of the show, had been removed from HBO Max.

site_title: Bitcoin’s bearish futures are signalling a slowdown into 2023
summary: Bitcoin's bearish futures signal a potential slowdown in 2023, as the market awaits good news. The Bitcoin futures curve is stuck in backwardation, with the January 2023 contract trading at a 1% discount to spot prices, the deepest discount since November. This trend is attributed to the collapse of FTX and increased concerns about counterparty risk, leading to a slowdown in trading activities. Market analysts expect a slow and unimpressive trading period, with no expectations of good news in the near future.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrency firms including Coinbase Global, Galaxy Digital Holdings and MicroStrategy all plunged more than 25 per cent last month.

site_title: Closing the gap of adequate work injury compensation for platform workers
summary: The Advisory Committee on Platform Workers has made 12 recommendations to strengthen protections for gig workers in Singapore, including providing adequate financial protection in case of work injury, improving housing and retirement adequacy, and enhancing representation. Currently, platform workers are not entitled to the same level of work injury compensation as employees, with coverage typically ranging from $10,000 to $30,000, compared to up to $289,000 for employees. The committee recommends that platform companies provide platform workers with the same coverage of work injury compensation as employees, and the government has accepted these recommendations.

images.alt_text: An association representing Deliveroo, Grab and foodpanda disagrees with the exclusion of street-hail taxis and certain logistics companies from the new rules.

GIA’s proposal is not a viable alternative to the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers' recommendation of requiring platform companies to provide the same scope and level of compensation as employees under the Work Injury Compensation Act (Wica), says Senior Minister of State for Manpower Koh Poh Koon.
While some platforms do provide some form of insurance to their gig workers, coverage is incomplete.

site_title: China readies new Covid rules; change to come as early as Wednesday
summary: China is set to announce further easing of its Covid-19 curbs as early as Wednesday, following widespread protests and mounting economic damage. The country's zero-tolerance measures, in place for three years, have battered its economy and put mental strain on hundreds of millions. Analysts predict China may drop border controls and reopen the economy sooner than expected, with Goldman Sachs expecting a reopening in April. The easing of rules has left some in China fearful of being caught off guard, but the move is seen as a positive sign for global growth and has boosted investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Residents wait in line at a Covid-19 testing facility at night in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. China's top leaders will likely signal a more pragmatic approach toward Covid controls at a key upcoming meeting while putting more focus on boosting economic growth, economists say. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Eurozone yields slip as investors weigh rate outlook
summary: Eurozone government bond yields slipped on Monday, with Germany's 10-year yield falling 2 basis points to 1.83% as investors weighed expectations for the European Central Bank's (ECB) rate outlook. Analysts expect the ECB to pause or cut interest rates next year, citing inflation concerns and a slowdown in central banks' monetary tightening path. The ECB's policy meeting on December 15 is expected to see a 50-basis-point rate hike, but some analysts believe the central bank may slow the pace of rate hikes.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower ahead of service data
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Monday, December 5, as investors awaited data on the US services sector and the Federal Reserve's rate-setting meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 94.1 points, or 0.27%, to 34,335.73. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 down 19.7 points, or 0.48%, and the Nasdaq down 80.5 points, or 0.70%. The cautious stance ahead of the data and the Fed's meeting led to the lower opening.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., November 29, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Will the Fed 'raise and hold' rates? Traders bet they will not
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to "raise and hold" interest rates to combat inflation, but traders are betting against this approach. Despite policymakers signaling a slower pace of rate hikes and a focus on reaching a high enough rate to cool the labor market, traders predict the Fed will continue to raise rates next year, potentially reaching 5% by May. Economists also forecast a rise in unemployment, consistent with a recession, and many believe the Fed won't cut rates until 2024.

images.alt_text: Fed Chairman Jerome says that wages are the largest cost for the services sector, so labour conditions are key to understanding the outlook on prices on everything from hotels to haircuts.

site_title: Billionaire Adani becomes NDTV’s biggest shareholder after open offer
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's conglomerate has raised its stake in New Delhi Television (NDTV) to over 37% through an open offer, making it the biggest shareholder of the country's popular news network. Adani had initially sought to acquire a 26% stake, but the open offer attracted only 8.3% interest. The takeover has raised concerns about the threat to free media in India, with some journalists resigning following Adani's acquisition of NDTV's founder entity. Adani sees the takeover as a "responsibility" rather than a business opportunity and has invited NDTV's Prannoy Roy to remain as chair.

site_title: Hedge fund bets next Korean hit will be webtoons
summary: A hedge fund, GVA Asset Management, is betting on the next Korean cultural phenomenon to be webtoons, following the success of K-pop and dramas like "Squid Game." The firm, managing $600 million, invested $15 million in unlisted webtoon producer Kenaz, becoming its largest shareholder. CEO Park Jihong sees opportunities in the webtoon market, focusing on non-listed companies with attractive valuations, as Americans and Europeans are expected to catch on to South Korea's online comics.

images.alt_text: The Korean drama earned 14 nominations, competing against the eventual best drama winner HBO’s Succession.

site_title: Bursa Malaysia to launch carbon exchange on Dec 9
summary: Bursa Malaysia, Malaysia's national stock exchange, will launch its voluntary carbon market (VCM) on December 9, allowing the trading of carbon credits. The credits will be issued by projects registered on Verra, a global standard for certifying carbon emissions reductions. The exchange will only accept credits from 2016 onwards, and a central order book will facilitate trading. The VCM aims to facilitate companies to offset their carbon footprint and support the development of domestic carbon projects to achieve Malaysia's net-zero targets.

images.alt_text: A security stands guard  at the Bursa Malaysia Headquarters, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
“The HKEX plays a key role in supporting Hong Kong’s rise as a green, low-carbon financial market,” Christopher Hui, secretary for financial services and the treasury, said at the debut ceremony.
Bursa Malaysia chief executive Muhamad Umar Swift said the exchange is on track to launch its Voluntary Carbon Market by way of auction in December.

site_title: Trek 2000’s ex-CFO jailed, fined for falsifying accounts, forgery, other offences
summary: Gurcharan Singh, former CFO of Trek 2000, has been sentenced to 11 months' jail and fined S$20,000 for falsifying accounts, forgery, and failing to disclose interested party transactions. Singh was convicted of eight charges related to the company's manipulation of financial records in 2011. This follows convictions of founder Henn Tan and former executive director Poo Teng Pin, who received 16 months and 9 months of jail, respectively.

images.alt_text: Founder of Trek 2000
Henn Tan has been in remand for 1.5 months, according to the court system.

site_title: China's Sunshine Insurance to raise US$863m in Hong Kong IPO, say sources
summary: China's Sunshine Insurance Group plans to raise US$863 million in its Hong Kong IPO, priced at HK$5.83 each, according to sources. This will be the second-largest IPO in Hong Kong in 2022, following CALB Co's US$1.3 billion raise in September. The IPO comes amidst a challenging year for Hong Kong's IPO market, with rising interest rates and global financial market volatility. Sunshine Insurance has life, health, and property insurance products, with US$58.3 billion in total investment assets as of June 30.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing chairman Laura Cha is confident that the city's IPO market activity will reverse its slowdown i nthe new year.

site_title: Hyflux’s unsecured creditors to receive interim dividend around Dec 21
summary: Hyflux's liquidators plan to declare a 1.568% interim dividend to unsecured creditors by Dec 21, totaling around S$0.01734 per note. The dividend is based on a total proof of debt of S$1.5 billion, with realisations from asset sales expected to exceed S$100 million. The remaining dividend will be distributed pari passu to all noteholders, with trustee fees and expenses paid in full.

site_title: Stock faithful hope for a wild rally before end of 2022
summary: Stock market investors are hopeful for a strong finish to 2022, driven by a less-hawkish Federal Reserve and positive inflation data. The S&P 500 has delivered double-digit gains one year after inflation peaks, and a rally since mid-October could lead to a strong fourth quarter. However, some experts caution that a hawkish Fed or a more substantial economic slowdown could trigger a decline. Despite this, many believe the market will end the year on a high note, with some predicting gains in large-cap biotech and small-cap stocks.

images.alt_text: The time to be optimistic and greedy is when others are pessimistic and fearful.

site_title: Tesla reduces Shanghai production output in latest sign of sluggish demand
summary: Tesla will reduce production at its Shanghai factory by about 20% due to sluggish demand in China, according to sources. The move follows recent price cuts and incentives, which have failed to boost sales. Production capacity at the Shanghai plant was recently doubled to 1 million cars per year, but demand has not kept up. This is the first time Tesla has voluntarily reduced production at the factory, which has been affected by previous lockdowns and supply chain issues.

images.alt_text: Tesla chief executive Elon Musk speaks with Dan Priestly, senior manager of Tesla Semi Truck Engineering, during the live-streamed unveiling of the Tesla Semi electric truck, in Nevada, U.S. Dec 1, 2022.
Coca-Cola Europacific Partners said it’s getting Renault E-tech D and E-Tech D Wide trucks that can travel around 200 kilometres a day.
Chief executive officer Elon Musk tweeted that the system Tesla calls Full Self-Driving Beta is now available to anyone in North America who’s bought the option and requests it from their car screen.

site_title: Vodafone ousts CEO Nick Read after commercial challenges
summary: Vodafone CEO Nick Read will step down at the end of 2022 due to his inability to halt the company's declining share price and failed mergers. Read, who has been with the company for over two decades, will remain as an adviser until March. The company's interim CEO will be CFO Margherita Della Valle, while the board seeks a permanent replacement. Vodafone's share price has sunk 44% since Read took over in 2018, and the company faces commercial challenges, including high leverage and a cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: Vodafone said on Monday (Oct 3) that it would own 51 per cent, and Hutchison, 49 per cent, under the deal being discussed, with the stakes achieved by adjusting ownership of debt rather than exchanging any cash.
Vodafone shares jump after investors bet on telecom mergers

site_title: Vietnam central bank raises cap on 2022 credit growth
summary: The State Bank of Vietnam raised its 14% cap on credit growth for 2022 by 1.5-2.0 percentage points, allowing banks with good liquidity and low interest rates to increase their credit growth. The move aims to address a credit crunch in the local property and financial markets, caused by the central bank's policy rate increases and a strengthening US dollar. The bank will closely monitor the situation and adjust monetary policies for next year, as Vietnam's economy continues to grow despite recent challenges.

site_title: Investors bet on furious and fleeting rally in China
summary: Investors are betting on a brief but strong rally in China's tourism, leisure, retailing, and food and beverage sectors ahead of potential COVID-19 surge in early 2023, which could impact consumption and production. However, stocks of drugmakers and medical equipment companies are expected to see a more lasting boost from China's reopening efforts. Despite concerns about the country's economic growth slowing, global banks remain bullish on China's prospects.

images.alt_text: A crude oil tanker at Qingdao Port, Shandong province, China. Oil’s gain is the latest twist in what has been an extraordinarily volatile year for the world’s most important commodity.
The strict approach has battered the world’s second-largest economy, put mental strain on hundreds of millions, and last month prompted the biggest show of public discontent.

site_title: Making SRS part of your grown-up Christmas list
summary: The Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) offers tax benefits and allows for long-term retirement savings. To maximize its benefits, SRS funds should be invested in unit trusts, shares, and government bonds, rather than leaving savings in cash, which can erode purchasing power. Singaporeans, permanent residents, and foreigners working in Singapore can take advantage of this scheme to lower their tax bill and grow their retirement savings.

images.alt_text: Higher costs of goods and services has caused a sharp drop in the level of confidence about retirement adequacy.

site_title: UK two-year mortgage rate falls below 6% in fresh sign of relief for house prices
summary: The UK's two-year fixed-rate mortgage has fallen to 5.99%, the first time it has dropped below 6% in almost nine weeks. This marks a sign of relief for the housing market, with banks relaxing repayment terms and investors seeking opportunities. However, the decline in rates is only slightly easing the cost burden for homeowners or first-time buyers, with a two-year mortgage now costing about £10,000 more than it did last December. Mortgage rates are expected to remain close to 5% for the next five years, discouraging renters from seeking to own a home.

site_title: Japanese yen set for a dramatic U-turn in 2023
summary: The Japanese yen is poised for a dramatic turnaround in 2023, with some investors predicting a rally of over 7% from current levels. A combination of the Federal Reserve's potential pause on interest rate hikes and the Bank of Japan's expected policy change, which will occur after Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's departure in April, is driving the bullish sentiment. This shift could lead to a stronger yen, potentially siphoning capital back to Japan and dampening demand for the yen carry trade.

images.alt_text: The small pay rise underscores the challenge of driving up wages in a country accustomed to decades of grinding deflation or low inflation.
The greenback tumbled after Fed chairman Jerome Powell said on Wednesday that it was time to slow rate hikes, raising hopes that the Fed was closer to the end of its tightening cycle.
SoftBank has a strong brand name in Japan, which means it can take advantage of consumers’ appetite at a time when institutional investors remain wary over market risks.
Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announces an economic stimulus package last month that includes incentives for businesses to increase wages.

site_title: Malaysia’s cabinet ministers agree to 20% pay cut: Anwar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced that his cabinet ministers have agreed to a 20% pay cut until the country's economy recovers. The pay cut, which could last 3-5 years, was voluntary and aims to alleviate the concerns of Malaysians during tough economic times. Anwar also vowed to fight corruption, saying his cabinet team is committed to good governance. Additionally, the government will review a plan for a state-owned 5G network, which was introduced by the previous administration without a transparent tender process.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who became premier last week, would also serve as the country’s finance minister.

site_title: US dollar steadies after recent falls, gains on pound and yen
summary: The US dollar index, which tracks the greenback against six peers, fell 1.4% last week and 5% in November, its worst month since 2010. However, it steadied on Monday, gaining 0.7% on the Japanese yen to 135.27 and 0.5% on the British pound to 1.2233. Speculation is growing that the 'pivot' narrative, which suggested the US dollar's weakness was coming to an end, has run its course, with some analysts predicting a return to more normal conditions for the Fed and the US dollar.

site_title: Worst could be over for S-Reits even as analysts slash target prices
summary: Analysts have slashed target prices for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) due to higher-than-expected interest costs and foreign exchange woes. However, a rebound in S-Reit prices in November has sparked hopes that the worst may be over. DBS Group Research cut distribution per unit (DPU) forecasts for FY2023 and FY2024 by 7% and lowered target prices by an average of 11%. Some S-Reits, such as Manulife US Reit and Prime US Reit, have seen significant cuts in target prices, while others like Elite Commercial Reit have been downgraded to "hold" from "buy".

images.alt_text: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s (MPACT) Mapletree Business City (MBC) recorded yoy growth in both gross revenue and NPI in H1FY23.
Digital Core Reit is no longer proceeding with plans to acquire a 90 per cent interest in a freehold data centre in Dallas, Texas (pictured).

On a year-to-date total return basis, S-Reits have seen a 10.9 per cent decline, against the Straits Times Index’s 9.6 per cent gain, while the FTSE EPRA Nareit Developed Index has seen a decline of 21.1 per cent.

site_title: ECB likely to hike rate by half-point in Dec, Makhlouf says
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to hike interest rates by a half-point in December, according to ECB Governing Council member Gabriel Makhlouf. This move would slow the pace of rate increases after inflation moderated for the first time in 1 1/2 years. Makhlouf considers a half-point step as the minimum needed to bring inflation back toward the 2% target, and other hikes will follow at subsequent meetings, potentially entering "restrictive territory" for a period.

images.alt_text: Bundesbank president Joachim Nagel notes that the ECB’s tightening push will eventually tame price growth that is currently running at five times its goal.

site_title: Ex-Wirecard CEO goes on trial over ‘unparalleled’ fraud
summary: Ex-Wirecard CEO Markus Braun and two former executives, Oliver Bellenhaus and Stephan von Erffa, will go on trial in Munich on December 8, 2022, for their roles in the massive accounting fraud that brought down the German digital payments firm Wirecard. Braun denies any wrongdoing, blaming the firm's former COO, Jan Marsalek, while a senior employee claims Braun was heavily involved in shaping the company's culture. The trial, which will last 100 court dates, accuses the trio of commercial gang fraud, breach of trust, and market manipulation, with potential prison sentences of several years if convicted.

images.alt_text: Germany charges Wirecard's ex-CEO Braun with alleged fraud

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported stronger Q3 earnings driven by the banking and commodity sectors. Retail sales rose 10.4% in October, and the three-month compounded Sora rate reached 3% for the first time since 2007. The Energy Market Authority and Maritime Port of Authority are seeking proposals for low or zero-carbon power generation and bunkering solutions. The Marina South state land sale is expected to attract bids over S$1 billion, and Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Monday amid regional gains.

site_title: Philippines trims 2023 GDP growth target due to global risks
summary: The Philippines lowered its 2023 GDP growth target to 6.0-7.0% due to the anticipated global slowdown, down from the previous 6.5-8.0% goal. This adjustment was made in light of the International Monetary Fund's warning of a global growth rate below 2% next year. The country retained its growth targets for 2024-2028 at 6.5-8.0%.

site_title: Chrono24 CEO says Rolex certification move to boost sales
summary: Rolex has announced a certification program for its pre-owned watches, allowing authorized dealers to sell the timepieces, which is expected to boost sales. The program, starting with Swiss retailer Bucherer, guarantees the watches for an additional two years and requires them to be at least three years old. Chrono24 CEO Tim Stracke sees this as a legitimization of the secondhand market, which is worth around $20 billion and is expected to grow to $35 billion by 2030. This move is expected to increase demand for Rolex watches on Chrono24 and other platforms.

images.alt_text: The move to authenticate its own pre-owned watches marks a significant shift for Rolex, whose timepieces dominate secondhand sales at dealers and online.

site_title: Putin ally Kudrin accepts tech giant Yandex’s offer of advisory role
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's ally, Alexei Kudrin, has accepted an advisory role at tech giant Yandex, as the company begins a governance overhaul. Kudrin, who resigned as head of Russia's Audit Chamber last week, will help develop the new holding company's corporate structure. The move is seen as a way to enhance Kremlin influence over Yandex, which has faced domestic and Western pressure since Russia launched a "special military operation" in Ukraine. Kudrin aims to preserve Yandex's unique management and technological culture, ensuring its long-term development.

site_title: Swiss watchdog probes banks for sharing pay details
summary: The Swiss Competition Commission (Comco) is investigating 34 banks in German-speaking Switzerland for allegedly sharing pay details of employees. The probe, initiated due to concerns under the Cartel Act, may be extended to other banks and companies. This is the first time Comco is analyzing labor market agreements under antitrust law, as they are seen as not resulting from negotiations between social partners. The investigation aims to determine if this practice is problematic and may lead to further action.

site_title: The UK is playing politics with the rental market
summary: The UK's rental market is experiencing turmoil, with landlords facing rising costs and pressures to increase rents. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's Autumn Statement capped social housing rent increases at 7% next year, potentially exacerbating the issue. Existing tenants tend to fare better, with 64% of rents remaining unchanged in 2021. The private sector is less formulaic, with rents rising more slowly. To ease the strain, measures such as longer-term tenancies and tweaked capital gains tax could be taken, but playing politics in the rental market will only make things worse.

images.alt_text: Excluding the Covid-19 pandemic, UK house prices have not fallen this sharply since the global financial crisis more than a decade ago.

site_title: Becoming the next China won’t blunt India’s 2023 slowdown
summary: India's economy is showing signs of resilience despite a global slowdown, with investments in fixed assets reaching 35% of domestic output, the highest in 10 years. A "China+1" strategy by multinational corporations is driving optimism, as companies seek to mitigate risks from China's labor unrest and offer generous subsidies in India. This shift is expected to take several years, potentially not soon enough for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who faces reelection in 2024.

images.alt_text: People shop at a crowded market ahead of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, in the old quarters of Delhi, India, October 11, 2022. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis

site_title: Japanese billionaire to make ‘big announcement’ on space after Musk meeting
summary: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa plans to make a "big announcement" about space on Friday after meeting with SpaceX owner Elon Musk. Maezawa, 47, is likely to become the first private passenger on a SpaceX moon mission in 2023. The announcement comes after his recent trip to the International Space Station on a Soyuz spacecraft. Shares in a Japan-based company that utilizes satellite data to provide space-related business surged 11.7% after Maezawa's tweet.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Monday amid regional gains; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Monday, tracking regional gains amid positive sentiment on China's reopening prospects. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,267.54, with Sats leading the gainers and Jardine Matheson Holdings falling 2.1%. Analysts say Asia's growth engine is exports, which will slow down in the coming year, and China's recovery won't prevent a significant export slowdown, except in tourism-heavy economies.

images.alt_text: The brighter outlook lifted Asian markets with Hong Kong leading the way, jumping more than three per cent while Shanghai put on more than one per cent.
Investors are seeking potential buys as Beijing gradually relaxes curbs that combined with a property crisis made key Chinese gauges the world’s worst performers for much of this year.

Residents wait in line at a Covid-19 testing facility at night in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. China's top leaders will likely signal a more pragmatic approach toward Covid controls at a key upcoming meeting while putting more focus on boosting economic growth, economists say. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia PM signals budget 2023 to stay largely intact
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has indicated that the 2023 annual budget will largely remain intact, with most proposals acceptable. Anwar, who also serves as finance minister, stated that he would give space for his finance ministry and Cabinet to provide input on changes and improvements. The revised budget is expected to be presented in one or two months, with a focus on helping the most vulnerable groups in society, according to Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim speaks during a news conference to announce his cabinet at Putrajaya, Malaysia December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: Volkswagen to discuss new software roadmap on Dec 15
summary: Volkswagen's chief executive Oliver Blume will present a new software strategy at a supervisory board meeting on Dec 15, aiming to make the carmaker's proprietary software competitive and market-ready by the end of the decade. The strategy will cost 1 billion euros and follows a delay in previous plans. The Audi brand will transfer leadership on autonomous driving software to Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles. The new strategy will focus on determining the software's design before car models are developed, a departure from previous approaches.

site_title: Wakanda Forever stays atop North America box office for 4th week
summary: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever holds its fourth consecutive week atop the North America box office, with weekend ticket sales totaling an estimated US$17.6 million. The film has now reached a domestic total of US$393.7 million and international ticket sales of US$339 million. Violent Night takes second place, while Strange World claims third with US$4.9 million. The Menu and Devotion round out the top 5.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on October 26, 2022, Tobagonian actor Winston Duke (L) and Guyanese actress Letitia Wright arrive for the world premiere of Marvel Studios' "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, California. - Disney and Marvel's "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" dominated the North American box office for a second straight weekend, taking in an estimated $67.3 million, industry watcher Exhibitor Relations reported November 20, 2022. (Photo by VALERIE MACON / AFP)

site_title: UOB’s Scan Hub marks 10th anniversary, 9 years of championing inclusive workplaces
summary: UOB's Scan Hub, a nerve centre for checking, digitising, and archiving customer documents, is celebrating its 10th anniversary. The hub, which was set up in 2012, has become a leading employer in inclusive workplaces, hiring 30 special needs employees out of a total staff strength of 80. The hub's vision and practices are intentionally aligned to create an inclusive and impactful workplace. UOB deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong stated that Scan Hub has proved that inclusive hiring can bring positive impact to both the organisation and the individuals, encouraging other employers to continue on this journey.

images.alt_text: Left to right: Dejan Kulusevski, Eric Dier, Harry Winks, Lucas Moura. Tottenham Hotspur players will wear jerseys with 'AIA Better Lives Fund' emblazoned on the front to raise funds for disadvantaged children during their EPL match on Sunday (May 1).

site_title: Malaysia’s ruling parties to sign pact for political stability
summary: Malaysia's ruling parties will sign a coalition agreement to ensure greater political stability, boosting Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's administration ahead of a confidence vote on Dec 19. The deal, finalized after negotiations, aims to generate confidence in Anwar's administration, which is led by at least four disparate political groups. The pact comes as Anwar faces a potentially disastrous confidence vote, with a majority of 112 seats required to avoid stepping down.

site_title: Eurozone likely heading into mild recession: S&P PMI survey
summary: The Eurozone is likely to enter a mild recession, with a median 78% chance of a recession within a year, according to a S&P PMI survey. The economy contracted 0.4% this quarter, with business activity declining for a fifth consecutive month in November. Despite a slight easing in the overall rate of contraction, economists predict a modest GDP contraction of 0.2%. The European Central Bank may see signs of inflationary pressures peaking, which could ease demand headwinds and mitigate the recession's impact.

images.alt_text: European Union (EU) officials in Brussels on Friday (Nov 11) slashed their forecast for growth next year, predicting barely any expansion, and raised all their projections for consumer prices. They reckon the economy is now shrinking and will keep contracting during the first quarter.

site_title: Malaysia to review plans for 5G network: Anwar
summary: Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced plans to review the country's 5G network plan, citing concerns over transparency. The plan, introduced by the previous government, aimed to have a state-owned agency own all 5G spectrum, sparking concerns over pricing and monopoly. Anwar vowed to ensure the review is done transparently and will also revise the 2023 budget tabled by the previous government. He emphasized his commitment to fighting corruption, despite appointing a co-deputy premier accused of graft.

images.alt_text: FOUR Malaysian mobile operators said on Monday (Oct 31) that they have agreed to use the government’s state-owned 5G network.

site_title: Offer to delist MS Holdings closes with 96.27% valid acceptances
summary: MS Holdings, a Singaporean company leasing and trading cranes, closed its offer to go private with 96.72% valid acceptances. The offeror, Kingswin Investment, will compulsorily acquire remaining shares at S$0.07 per share, a 16.7% premium over the previous closing price. The company, known as Moh Seng Cranes in the industry, lost its free float status in October and its shares traded at S$0.069 on Nov 9.

site_title: Kitchen Culture accuses director of tampering with company’s Acra records
summary: Kitchen Culture has accused one of its directors, Hao Dongting, of attempting to change the company's records with Acra, including changing the company secretary and office address. The company has filed corrective notices with Acra on December 2, intending to issue warnings to those involved, including new company secretaries. Kitchen Culture's board views these actions as "extremely disruptive" and "unlawful," and has emphasized that the company's registered office remains unchanged. The incident is linked to a dispute over the company's board composition, with Kitchen Culture's largest shareholder Ooway claiming a successful EGM to appoint new directors.

images.alt_text: Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. In its latest statement the company said it “sharply criticised” requisitioners for proceeding with an EGM held on Nov 25.
The meeting was requisitioned by a group of Kitchen Culture shareholders, including Ooway Group, who first requested to remove the incumbent directors in September this year.

In the bourse filing, Kitchen Culture said the redesignation is due to “the need for the chairman of the board to lead the company forward in the challenging business climate and shareholders’ issues faced by the company”
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Its largest shareholder Ooway Group together with seven individuals are requisitioning to remove five of the company's six directors.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The embattled kitchen systems provider reminds shareholders that an extraordinary general meeting intended to be held by requisitioners seeking to remove five of its six directors will not be proceeding.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture.  The group is urging its shareholders not to attend a Nov 1 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) proposed by requisitioners, as it deems notices for the EGM defective and invalid.
Kitchen Culture shareholders fail to confirm whether EGM notices have been sent out
Kitchen Culture is in the midst of taking legal advice on the validity of the EGM Notice by a group of shareholders.
Ooway's clarification comes nearly a week after Kitchen Culture's board claimed Ooway had made statements with various “factual inaccuracies and mischaracterisation of events”.
A group of Kitchen Culture shareholders intend to convene an extraordinary general meeting remove these 5 individuals from their directorships as well as appoint 5 new directors.

site_title: The big question over Taiwan in US-China relations
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping met face-to-face at the G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia, in November 2022. China views Taiwan as a renegade province and President Xi has expressed a preference for reunification by peaceful means, but did not rule out the use of force. The US has defended Taiwan, with President Biden stating that the US would defend the island, despite China's increasing military capabilities and US attempts to maintain the "one China" policy. A recent visit by US Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan further strained US-China relations.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping held talks on the sidelines of the G20 leaders' summit in Bali, Indonesia, Nov 14, 2022.
China's Defence Minister Wei Fenghe arrives for a meeting with his US counterpart Lloyd Austin in Siem Reap on Nov 22, 2022.

Washington has identified Beijing as the most consequential challenge to the United States, and the annual report on China’s military emphasised improvements to both its nuclear and conventional forces.

site_title: Commodities poised for a volatile 2023
summary: Commodities are poised for a volatile 2023, driven by growing demand risks due to tightening monetary policies and recession in key economies, while supply risks remain, particularly in energy. The US and EU plan to ban Russian oil shipments and cap prices, potentially leading to a tighter oil market and higher prices. Europe's natural gas market is expected to face significant disruptions, and metal balances are expected to remain under pressure in early 2023, with agricultural commodities expected to remain sensitive to the Russia-Ukraine war.

site_title: Three-month compounded Sora crosses 3% for the first time since 2007
summary: The three-month compounded Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) has crossed the 3% mark for the first time since 2007, reaching 3.0095%. This increase affects floating home loan packages in Singapore, with a 3.4% per annum interest rate now rising to 3.7%. Sora is on track to replace the Singapore dollar Swap Offer Rate (SOR) as the main interest rate benchmark in Singapore's financial markets.

images.alt_text: CPF could be on the brink of adjusting Special Account interest rates, as 10-year Singapore government bond yields have climbed to more than 3.1 per cent
DBS continues to have a home loan specially for home owners of public housing flats at 2.6 per cent a year – similar to the current HDB concessionary interest rate.
The uptrend in fixed deposit rates comes in tandem with accelerating home loan rates in recent months.

site_title: EMA, MPA call for proposals to develop power generation and bunkering solutions
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) and Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) of Singapore have issued an expression of interest (EOI) for proposals to develop low or zero-carbon power generation and bunkering solutions on Jurong Island. The EOI aims to explore the use of hydrogen and ammonia for power generation, supporting Singapore's decarbonization efforts and goal to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Interested parties can submit their proposals by April 30, 2023, and the EMA and MPA will assess the proposals and potentially launch a request for proposal.

images.alt_text:

site_title: Oil climbs as China loosens curbs and Opec+ keeps output steady
summary: Crude oil prices rose above $80 a barrel as China eased Covid restrictions, boosting energy demand. Opec+ maintained its output levels, while the EU imposed a $60 per barrel cap on Russian crude and banned most imports. The move aims to punish Russia financially while keeping its oil flowing to other states. Oil prices rebounded after hitting a low last week, but analysts remain uncertain about the plan's impact on Russian oil exports, potentially causing prices to spike.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$1.31, a 1.5 per cent drop, at US$85.57 per barrel. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell US$1.24, or 1.5 per cent, to US$79.98 per barrel.
The coalition has to contend with an especially volatile outlook, as European Union sanctions are about to come into effect on crude exports from Opec+ member Russia.

site_title: Q3 corporate profits rise on strong banking, commodity sector performance
summary: Singapore-listed companies saw a 45.6% rise in total earnings to S$8.5 billion in Q3, driven by strong performance in the banking and commodity sectors. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB posted earnings improvements of 31-34%, while Wilmar International and Golden Agri-Resources saw net profits rise 34.7% and 147.8% respectively. However, some companies, such as Japfa and Riverstone, saw net profits decline due to higher feed costs and depressed selling prices. Analysts expect potential headwinds from weaker commodity prices and lower external demand in the coming quarter.

images.alt_text: CPF could be on the brink of adjusting Special Account interest rates, as 10-year Singapore government bond yields have climbed to more than 3.1 per cent

site_title: Asia: Stocks up, dollar down as China eases more Covid-19 measures
summary: Asian markets rose, with Hong Kong jumping over 3% and Shanghai gaining over 1%, as China eased Covid-19 measures, lifting investor sentiment and offsetting a strong US jobs report. The move is seen as a sign of China's pragmatic approach to fighting Covid, which has been blamed for economic slowdowns and market volatility. The dollar weakened against major peers as investors lower expectations for US borrowing costs.

site_title: Charming Garden condo up for collective sale at S$175m
summary: Charming Garden condominium in District 10 has been launched for collective sale at a guide price of S$175 million. The four-storey development comprises 32 apartment units with a 999-year tenure, situated on an elevated site spanning 84,357 sq ft. Owners can expect to gain between S$5 million to S$6.8 million each, depending on unit size. The sale tender will close on Jan 17, 2023, with units in the future redevelopment likely to fetch around S$3,200 psf.

images.alt_text: 位于罗弄泉的春景花园（Chuan Park）私人公寓外观。Chuan Park, a 446-unit condominium near Lorong Chuan MRT station.
Golden Mile Tower was completed in 1974, one year after its sister building, Golden Mile Complex.
The Oxley Garden site, outlined in yellow, can be rebuilt into a 5-storey condominium with a gross floor area of 85,246 square feet, based on its existing gross plot ratio of 1.4645.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS initiates ‘hold’ on Union Gas, optimistic on growth post-acquisition
summary: DBS initiated coverage on Union Gas with a "hold" call and a target price of S$0.48, citing higher-than-expected margins and dividends following the acquisition of LPG distribution businesses. The analysts forecast an 8% compound annual growth rate for 2022-2024, driven by volume expansion and higher average selling prices. Union Gas's strong balance sheet and vertically integrated business model are seen as growth drivers, with a potential relief from pressures in the second half of 2022 due to cooling oil prices.

images.alt_text: Union
In the last week, crude futures contracts have flipped in and out of contango, where the prompt price of a commodity is lower than the future price.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Chip Eng Seng
summary: Chairman Celine Tang and her husband Gordon Tang's mandatory conditional cash offer to take Chip Eng Seng private has been increased to S$0.75 per share from S$0.72. This surpasses the company's highest closing price in a three-year period prior to the offer's announcement. The stock resumes trading today after a trading halt.

site_title: China’s BYD to start selling EVs in Japan by early 2023
summary: China's BYD will start selling its first electric sports utility vehicle, the ATTO 3, in Japan on January 31, 2023. The vehicle has a 485km cruising distance and costs 4.4 million yen. BYD aims to introduce two more models by the end of 2023 and establish over 100 dealerships in Japan by 2025. This move marks BYD's expansion into the Japanese market, where petrol-electric hybrid models remain popular but battery-driven vehicles are expected to grow in demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of BYD is pictured at the 2022 Paris Auto Show in Paris, France October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: Japan’s service-sector activity growth hits 3-month low: PMI
summary: Japan's service sector activity growth hit a 3-month low in November, according to the au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers' index (PMI), which fell to 50.3 from October's 53.2. Despite this, the index stayed above the 50-mark for a third straight month, indicating expansion. Inflationary pressures remained high, with input cost and selling price inflation above historical averages. The government's consumer confidence index also fell to its lowest since June 2020, amid the fastest price inflation in 40 years.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 10.4% in October, extending growth
summary: Singapore's total retail sales rose 10.4% year-over-year in October, extending the previous month's 11.3% growth. Excluding motor vehicles, sales expanded by 14.3% from the year-ago period. Online sales accounted for 13% of total retail sales, with F&B services experiencing a 36.9% year-on-year rise in sales. Experts expect growth momentum to continue into the remaining months of 2022, but moderation in 2023 due to inflation pressures and the upcoming goods and services tax hike.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail sales up 11.2% in September, extending August’s growth

site_title: UK rail union rejects offer, Christmas strikes still planned
summary: The UK's National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT) has rejected a proposed 4% pay rise for 2022 and 2023, which the union claims is conditional on changes to working conditions, including job losses and reduced staff on trains. The RMT is set to go on strike for 8 days in December and January, and an overtime ban from Dec 18 to Jan 2, despite Transport Secretary Mark Harper calling the deal's rejection "incredibly disappointing and unfair."

images.alt_text: epa10334170 NHS Ambulance staff outside a hospital in London, Britain, 28 November 2022.  The army may be brought in to help answer emergency calls over the festive period if NHS ambulance staff vote to strike over a pay dispute. NHS ambulance staff are voting this week whether or not to take industrial action.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Trump talk of ending constitutional rules draws sharp rebukes
summary: Former US President Donald Trump suggested disregarding the US Constitution and ignoring election results to declare the "RIGHTFUL WINNER" in the 2020 presidential election. This proposal drew sharp rebukes from politicians of both parties, with many calling it "anti-American" and a "clear and present danger" to democracy. Trump's comments came amid a series of setbacks, including poor midterm election results and criticism for hosting anti-Semites at a dinner. The proposal was met with widespread condemnation, with some Republicans repudiating Trump's actions.

images.alt_text: The jury conviction on Tuesday of two militia leaders on charges of seditious conspiracy raised the stakes for Donald Trump, who is under investigation over his role in fomenting the Capitol assault, which was aimed at keeping him in power after his election loss.
Earlier this month, Binance disclosed its holdings of major tokens and said more data will be shared later in a “full audited report”.
France's President Emmanuel Macron said free speech in democracy should be “based on respect and political order.”

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge more than 3% on China Covid moves
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 3% on Monday as Chinese authorities rolled back Covid containment measures, lifting market optimism about China's economic growth in 2023. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.58%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased. The move comes after widespread protests calling for more political freedom and a shift in China's zero-Covid strategy. Market analysts see the reopening as a positive sign for China-sensitive assets, citing a likely acceleration in growth in 2023.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Monday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,272.52, driven by gains from medtech firm Biolidics and property player Chip Eng Seng, with the latter's shares rising 2% after its chairman's conditional cash offer was increased. The top traded stocks by volume were Singtel, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, which also gained. The rally comes after a mixed session on Wall Street, where equities were influenced by a solid jobs report and interest rate policy.

images.alt_text: Chairman Celine Tang (pictured) and her husband Gordon Tang’s mandatory conditional cash offer to take Chip Eng Seng private has been upped to a final price of S$0.75 per share from S$0.72.

site_title: India’s housing market to remain resilient, defying global downtrend: poll
summary: India's housing market is expected to remain resilient despite a global downtrend, with average house prices forecast to rise 5.0% over the next three years. The outlook is stable compared to developed economies, where prices are predicted to slump. Experts attribute the resilience to low interest rate risk, which reduces the likelihood of a significant slowdown in the housing market. The Reserve Bank of India's recent interest rate hikes may lead to developers easing price increases in 2023, but overall, the housing market is expected to contribute to India's economic growth.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit multi-month highs; RBA in focus
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached multi-month highs due to signs of China easing pandemic policies and strong US payroll data. The Aussie rallied 0.8% to US$0.6849, its highest level since mid-September, while the kiwi surged 0.4% to US$0.6436, its strongest level since August. The Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate decision on Tuesday is expected to provide further signals on a potential pause in rate hikes, with markets pricing in a 70% probability of a 25 basis point hike.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six major peers including the yen and euro, fell 0.2 per cent to 104.47, having earlier touched its lowest level since June 29 at 104.36.

site_title: Gold prices inch higher on softer dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,800.02 per ounce, driven by a softer US dollar, which made the greenback-priced bullion cheaper for foreign buyers. US gold futures gained 0.2% to $1,812.60. The dollar index fell 0.1%. Despite a stronger-than-expected jobs report, the Federal Reserve is likely to slow interest rate hikes, benefiting gold. Physical gold demand was stagnant in India and China, while silver, platinum, and palladium also saw gains.

site_title: UK economy to shrink in 2023, risks ‘lost decade’: CBI
summary: The UK economy is forecast to shrink 0.4% in 2023 due to high inflation, weak investment, and a slow labour market recovery. This marks a sharp downgrade from the CBI's previous forecast of 1.0% growth for 2023. Unemployment is expected to peak at 5.0% in late 2023 and early 2024, and inflation is predicted to average 6.7% next year. The CBI warns that if action is not taken, the UK could experience a "lost decade" of growth, with GDP expected to remain below pre-pandemic levels until mid-2024.

images.alt_text: Excluding the Covid-19 pandemic, UK house prices have not fallen this sharply since the global financial crisis more than a decade ago.
Customers enter a J Sainsbury Plc supermarket in Colney, UK, on Monday, Oct. 31, 2022. Sainsbury's are due to report their latest earnings on Nov. 3. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: An ageing population is not a problem for the private homes market
summary: Singapore's aging population, with a median age of 42.1 years and 16.6% of residents aged 65 and over, may not negatively impact the private homes market. More elderly individuals are economically active, choosing to live independently, and may downsize to more affordable homes, contributing to the market's vibrancy. With the rise in labor force participation rates among the elderly, the demand for homes may remain strong. Additionally, Singapore's high-quality healthcare system, infrastructure, and public safety attract older individuals, making it an attractive place to live, particularly for wealthy elderly persons.

images.alt_text: While all three regions experienced a fall in secondary sales volume, the largest decline came from the Rest of Central Region (RCR), whose transaction volume fell 14.3 per cent q-o-q to 1,135 units.

site_title: Australia set to raise rates as tightening cycle approaches end
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to raise interest rates by a quarter-percentage point to 3.1% on Tuesday, as it closes in on the end of its tightening cycle. This move contrasts with New Zealand, which recently delivered a record hike and is expected to move higher, and the Federal Reserve, which has hiked by 3.75 points since March. The RBA aims to cool inflation without slowing the economy, with inflation expected to peak at 8% this quarter and then slow over the next two years.

images.alt_text: Australia and New Zealand are experiencing a reversal of pandemic-era property booms when rock-bottom mortgage rates fuelled a buying frenzy.

The Australian Securities Exchange will cut up to 200 contractors working on a project to replace its main trading platform with so-called blockchain technology after cancelling the overhaul, the company told Reuters.

site_title: US-France/EU ties : America now holding the cards
summary: US President Joe Biden and French President Emmanuel Macron marked the first official state visit of the Biden administration with a dinner at the White House, celebrating their shared values and interests. The visit came after a major diplomatic crisis between the two countries, but they ended up repairing their relationship as they confronted a new geo-strategic reality dominated by the war in Ukraine. The US has shifted the balance of power in its favor, with the US now holding the cards in US-France/EU ties, as the Europeans have come to accept US leadership in the Western alliance and rely on American natural gas supplies.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and French President Emmanuel Macron meeting in the Oval Office, at the White House in Washington on Dec 1.

site_title: Tenet EC in Tampines sells 72% of units on launch day
summary: Residential developer Tenet EC in Tampines sold 72% of its 618 units on its launch day, with 447 units sold at an average price of S$1,360 per square foot. The project, which opened on December 3, attracted over 5,000 visitors during its launch weekend in November. Only 30% of units were available to second-time buyers on the launch day, but experts predict the project could be fully sold once sales open to more second-timers a month later.

images.alt_text: Eligible buyers for Tenet EC can submit their e-applications up until Nov 28.
Eligible buyers bought 73 per cent of units at Copen Grand, the first Executive Condominium project at the upcoming Tengah Town, developers City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land said.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried says he will testify before House, without committing to date
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, has announced he will testify before the House Financial Services Committee, but has not committed to a specific date. He stated he will appear once he finishes reviewing the events leading to FTX's collapse. Representative Maxine Waters invited Bankman-Fried to the Dec 13 hearing, but he did not confirm attendance. Bankman-Fried's testimony will allow him to explain the events surrounding the implosion of his crypto exchange.

site_title: Foxconn expects full operations at Covid-hit China plant by late Dec-early Jan: source
summary: Foxconn expects its Covid-hit Zhengzhou plant in China to resume full production around late December to early January, after worker unrest disrupted the world's biggest iPhone factory. The plant has been grappling with strict Covid-19 restrictions, fueling discontent among workers. Production was disrupted ahead of Christmas and Lunar New Year holidays, with many workers either isolating or fleeing the plant. The company is working on a recruitment drive, with new staff hiring underway, and expects full production to resume within 3-4 weeks if recruitment goes smoothly.

site_title: Don’t wait for stock market capitulation – because it isn’t coming
summary: Ken Fisher argues that it's too early to buy stocks, despite a recent autumn rally, as pessimists predict a market plunge. However, several factors suggest a capitulation is unlikely this time, including historically minor bear markets, the dollarization of terror, and the lack of safe havens. Global equity fund outflows are relatively low, and many traditional safe havens, such as bonds, gold, and cash, are also experiencing declines. Fisher believes investors should be optimistic and greedy when others are pessimistic and fearful, and that the current situation may be a new bull market stealthily starting.

images.alt_text: US wheat prices, which spiked following Russia's first attacks on Ukraine, have fallen 31.8 per cent from their March highs.
An oil pump jack in a field near Calgary, Alberta, Canada. Higher oil prices are among a cocktail of worries keeping investors pessimistic and priming the market for a rebound.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s investment bank draws interest from Saudi crown prince: WSJ
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is considering a $500 million investment in Credit Suisse's new investment banking unit, CS First Boston. This follows interest from US private-equity firm Atlas Merchant Capital, led by former Barclays CEO Bob Diamond, who may also invest $1 billion or more. Credit Suisse aims to restore its investment banking business, which has been struggling. The new unit will operate as an independent capital markets and advisory bank headquartered in New York.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Switzerland's national flag flies above a logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse in front of a branch office in Bern, Switzerland November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Clooney, U2 among honorees at glitzy Washington gala
summary: George Clooney, U2, Gladys Knight, Tania Leon, and Amy Grant are among the honorees at the Kennedy Center's 45th annual gala in Washington, D.C. The event, attended by President Joe Biden and his family, celebrates the arts and features performances by fellow superstars. The honorees, who have made significant contributions to their respective fields, were previously recognized with private receptions and State Department dinners. The gala marks a return to the event's high-wattage awards program, which had been absent during Donald Trump's presidency.

site_title: ‘No diplomatic solution’ to Ukraine war: Nobel winner
summary: Russian rights organisation Memorial co-founder Irina Scherbakova says there is no diplomatic solution to the Ukraine war as long as Putin's regime exists, predicting a military solution. However, she believes a diplomatic resolution will occur when Ukraine feels it has won the war and can set its terms. Scherbakova also stated that the war has irreversibly changed the world, making a return to pre-conflict times impossible. The Nobel Peace Prize-winning Memorial organisation will receive the award in Oslo on December 10, along with other human rights advocates.

site_title: Protest-hit Iran abolishes morality police
summary: Iran has abolished its morality police, a move that comes after over two months of protests triggered by the arrest of a woman for allegedly violating the country's strict female dress code. The protests, led by women, have resulted in the burning of mandatory hijab head coverings and anti-government slogans. Attorney-General Mohammad Jafar Montazeri stated that the morality police "have nothing to do with the judiciary" and have been abolished, amid calls from the Union of Islamic Iran People Party for the hijab law to be rescinded.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file handout picture released by Iran's Atomic Energy Organization in November 2019 shows the atomic enrichment facilities at the Natanz nuclear research centre, some 300 kilometres south of capital Tehran. Iran's stockpile of enriched uranium is estimated to have grown to more than 18 times the limit laid down in the 2015 deal with world powers.

site_title: Indonesia’s PasarPolis aims to democratise insurance
summary: Indonesian insurtech firm PasarPolis aims to democratize insurance in the country, targeting the vast unbanked population with micro-insurance policies as low as $1. Founded by Cleosent Randing, PasarPolis has served one billion policies since 2021 and is expanding into the second-hand car market with policies starting at $300/year. The company has received significant funding from Indonesian unicorns and is eyeing a potential listing, but faces challenges in scaling its model and transitioning to traditional insurance offerings.

images.alt_text: Igloo CEO Raunak Mehta wants to accelerate regional growth.
Singapore Fintech Association chief operating officer Reuben Lim (left) with Indonesian Fintech Association deputy secretary-general Alwin Jabarti at a business seminar in Jakarta in August 2022.

site_title: World Cup: France’s Giroud and Mbappe demolish Poland 3-1
summary: France dominated Poland 3-1 in the World Cup, with Kylian Mbappe scoring two goals and Olivier Giroud netting one. Giroud became France's all-time record marksman with his 52nd goal, while Mbappe reached nine World Cup goals in just 11 appearances. France's strong start and pressing ultimately proved too much for Poland, and they progress to the quarter-finals. The win was a routine victory for the French side, led by Mbappe, who is now on course to become the first team to successfully defend the World Cup since Brazil in 1962.

site_title: World Cup: England subdue Senegal to book France clash in  quarter-final
summary: England defeated Senegal 3-0 in the World Cup quarterfinals, advancing to a semifinal match against France. Jude Bellingham's masterclass performance, including his first assist in a World Cup knockout stage game, inspired the win. Jordan Henderson and Harry Kane scored two clinical goals before half-time, and Bukayo Saka sealed the victory in the second half. England will face France on Saturday, looking to extend their stay in Qatar beyond the last eight.

images.alt_text: Results for the round of 16 are out.

South Korea's Son Heung-min (centre) and his teammates celebrate wildly after they defeated Portugal 2-1 to qualify for the Round of 16. South Korea will play Brazil on Dec 6 for a place in the quarter-finals

site_title: Rally in Asia-Pac airline stocks has more runway as tourism plays catch-up
summary: Asia-Pacific airline stocks have performed well this year, with some carriers recording near 20% returns, driven by the pandemic-recovery theme. However, tourism in the region remains a laggard, with statistics showing 29% lower overall capacity in South-east Asia and 43% lower international capacity compared to 2019 pre-pandemic levels. Analysts predict that Asia will benefit from tourism gains in the next year, with BNP Paribas expecting travel and tourism to account for 10% of global GDP.

images.alt_text: The airline last week forecast a “substantial” annual loss even though second-half results are expected to improve sequentially.
WFS is the takeover target of Sats, which has entered into an agreement to acquire the Paris-based and world’s largest air cargo handler for about 1.3 billion euros.

SIA expects the merger of Air India and Vistara will boost its presence in India, strengthen its multi-hub strategy, and allow it to continue participating directing in a large and fast-growing aviation market.

site_title: Russia will not export oil subject to Western price cap, says deputy PM
summary: Russia will not export oil subject to a Western price cap of $60 per barrel, said Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak. The move, agreed by the G7 and Australia, aims to punish Russia for the Ukraine conflict but Novak called it a gross interference in free trade, potentially destabilizing global energy markets. Russia will sell oil and petroleum products only to countries that comply with market conditions, potentially reducing production.

images.alt_text: The price cap, a G7 idea, aims to reduce Russia’s income from selling oil, while preventing a spike in global oil prices after an EU embargo on Russian crude takes effect on Dec 5.

site_title: LSEG’s diversified business model drives resilience
summary: LSEG's diversified business model has driven resilience in the face of uncertainty and volatility, including the Covid-19 pandemic, shifts in global monetary policy, and geopolitical tensions. The company's CEO, David Schwimmer, attributes this to its diversified revenue streams, high operating margin, and strong cash generation. LSEG has successfully integrated its Refinitiv acquisition and continues to build capabilities across the trade life-cycle, data, analytics, and information services. Despite rising interest rates and subdued initial public offering activity, the company remains confident in its leverage targets and is focused on executing its transformation programs.

images.alt_text: Exchanges looking to private arena as capital markets evolve
The London exchange also suspended all products and services for customers in Russia, and halted the distribution of news and commentary in the country.
Murray Roos, LSEG’s global head of capital markets, said they hope to be the first exchange group that is genuinely indifferent as to whether a company is public or private.

site_title: Don’t fear the credit card
summary: Youths who avoid credit cards to avoid debt may miss out on potential rewards, such as 3% merchant fees being passed on to consumers. Without credit cards, they also risk missing out on building a credit score, which can impact loan sizes. However, it's essential to manage debt responsibly and avoid late fees and interest charges. Credit card users can intentionally reduce their credit limit and use expense tracker apps to avoid overspending. Choosing a credit card with a minimum spend threshold, caps on rewards, and higher interest rates on savings accounts can also be beneficial.

images.alt_text: UOB lifted the maximum bonus interest rate on its One Account from 3.6 per cent to 7.8 per cent.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Is crypto still a viable investment option? (Ep 132)
summary: Correspondent Howie Lim discusses the viability of cryptocurrency with Wayne Huang, co-founder and CEO of XREX, after the collapse of FTX. The main issue with FTX's collapse was its lack of regulation, which highlights the need for balancing decentralization and safety of customer assets. Regulation may help, but the ecosystem and players also need to be addressed. Many customers have lost money due to the collapse, and there is limited recourse. Despite this, cryptocurrency may still be a viable investment option, but caution and careful consideration are necessary.

images.alt_text: What lessons did we glean from 2022? Kelvin Tay, UBS’ regional CIO has insights.

site_title: Apple is ‘fully’ advertising on Twitter again: Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk announced that Apple has "fully resumed" advertising on Twitter, ending a brewing dispute between the two tech giants. The move comes after Musk met with Apple CEO Tim Cook, resolving a misunderstanding about Twitter potentially being removed from the App Store. Musk also stated that Apple is the largest advertiser on Twitter and thanked advertisers for returning to the platform. This development comes as other companies, including Amazon and General Mills, had previously suspended advertising on Twitter.

images.alt_text: Twitter’s relationship with Apple is particularly significant because the tech giant’s app store is one of the main ways that people get on the social network.

site_title: Falling valuations dull the shine of private assets, curb exit options
summary: Private equity investors are expecting the value of their portfolios to fall due to rising caution amid valuations falling in the private market. Corrections in the private market typically lag public markets, which have seen a 20% decline in major indices this year. Venture capital funds are expected to experience a larger correction, with global VC performance forecasted to reach 14.6% annualized return between 2021 and 2027. However, private equity returns are expected to be lower, at 13.5% annualized. Market watchers predict a difficult year for fundraising and a slower exit environment for investors.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust has been facing withdrawal requests exceeding its quarterly limit, a major test for the one of the private equity firm’s most ambitious efforts to reach individual investors.

site_title: Newer sustainable finance taxonomies converging on common features
summary: Jurisdictions are converging on sustainable finance taxonomies, with newer taxonomies displaying more similarities than differences, according to a report by the German Agency for International Cooperation and Center of Clean Air Policy. The analysis found that 11 out of 13 taxonomies shared at least nine common traits, including the use of steering groups and Paris-aligned emissions goals. This alignment could improve capital flows and market clarity, but challenges remain in harmonizing taxonomies on three fronts: sectoral priorities, screening criteria, and metric types.
