site_title: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon donates S$50,000 to programme supporting local athletes
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon has donated S$50,000 to the Singapore Athletic Association's One Team Singapore Fund, supporting local athletes. The donation will be matched by Sports SG, totaling S$100,000, to support Team Singapore athletes and local elite programs. The funds will be used to strengthen the high-performance sport ecosystem, enhance athlete training environments, and increase competition opportunities. This partnership aims to develop local athletes and promote the growth of the local running community.

images.alt_text: Left to right: Dejan Kulusevski, Eric Dier, Harry Winks, Lucas Moura. Tottenham Hotspur players will wear jerseys with 'AIA Better Lives Fund' emblazoned on the front to raise funds for disadvantaged children during their EPL match on Sunday (May 1).
Insead has awarded over S$500,000 in bond-free scholarships to 24 Singaporeans and permanent residents.

site_title: Europe looks for ways to counter new US climate law
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen calls for the EU to improve its state aid framework and consider more green-transition funding to counter the US's new climate and tax law, the Inflation Reduction Act. Von der Leyen warns that the law could lead to unfair competition and close markets, threatening the bloc's critical supply chains. She suggests cooperation with the US to advance the green transition, including common standards for electric vehicle charging infrastructure and critical raw materials. The EU should work to mitigate competitive disadvantages and build an alternative to the US monopoly.

images.alt_text: The so-called Inflation Reduction Act and a separate law meant to incentivise semiconductor production “are very good for the US economy, but they weren’t properly coordinated with European economies,” President Macron said.

site_title: How companies can build circular economy business models
summary: Companies can build circular economy business models by adopting four main strategies: circular value recovery, circular product design, circular use, and circular support. Circular value recovery involves maximizing value from products and materials after use, while circular product design focuses on creating longer-lasting products. Circular use redefines the consumption process, and circular support enables the transition through digital tools and infrastructure. To succeed, businesses must overcome initial higher upfront costs and engage in iterative dialogues with policymakers and city planners. New global standards, such as the European Union's taxonomy regulation, are making investing in the circular economy transition more attractive.

images.alt_text: Just 14 per cent of the plastic packaging used globally is recycled, while 40 per cent ends up in landfills and 32 per cent in ecosystems, with the remaining 14 per cent incinerated.
Roland Berger's Hani Tohme says: "To achieve circularity, you would need to rethink the current status quo to enable economic and ecological savings."
Green financing shows a clear shift, where financial institutions clearly favour circular and climate-friendly approaches when supporting industrial investment.

site_title: With surprises galore, Qatar World Cup is a watershed for international football
summary: The 2022 Qatar World Cup has become a watershed moment in international football history, with Asian and African teams achieving unprecedented success. Five of the 16 teams in the knockout stage come from these continents, surpassing previous records. Notable upsets include Saudi Arabia's 2-1 win over Argentina, Japan's victories over Germany and Spain, and South Korea's 2-1 win over Portugal. This shift in power suggests a potential tilt in the balance of football, with Asian and African teams poised to make a strong showing in the latter stages of the tournament.

images.alt_text: The BT-World Cup 2022 CEO Challenge will see 16 business leaders take part to raise funds for the BT Budding Artists Fund.

Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Group G - Brazil v Serbia - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - November 24, 2022
Brazil's Richarlison scores their second goal REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: FTX is latest reason why the C-suite needs a chief critical officer
summary: FTX's collapse has raised concerns about the need for corporate oversight, following in the footsteps of Enron's bankruptcy 21 years ago. Charismatic leaders like Sam Bankman-Fried, Kenneth Lay, and Elizabeth Holmes have been known for their charm, but also for their lack of accountability. Critics argue that corporate boards have not changed sufficiently since their inception and are in need of an upgrade, focusing on ethics and critique. A new role, "chief critical officer," is proposed to cut through charisma and avoid future governance disasters, drawing inspiration from historical figures like Empress Maria Theresa.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried, founder and former chief executive officer of FTX Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

US authorities are asking crypto investors and trading firms that worked closely with FTX to hand over information on the company and its key figures, including founder Sam Bankman-Fried (pictured) and the former head of his Alameda Research investment arm, Caroline Ellison.

Northern Rock customers queue from the banks entrance,left, onto the pavement outside the branch in Golders Green, London, U.K., on Monday, Sept. 17, 2007.Northern Rock Plc, the U.K. mortgage lender bailed out by the Bank of England last week, tumbled to a seven-year low in London trading after customers lined up at branches across the country to withdraw their savings. Photographer: Will Wintercross/Bloomberg News
Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the collapsed crypto exchange FTX, speaks to Andrew Ross Sorkin virtually at The New York Times’ DealBook Summit 2022 in Manhattan on Nov 30, 2022.
Temasek said investing in FTX was part of its effort to keep abreast of how new technologies might affect its portfolio's returns

site_title: Thailand says most institutional investors must pay stock tax
summary: Thailand's cabinet has approved a new stock tax policy, which will impose a 0.05% tax on stock transactions starting next year. Institutional investors, excluding pension funds and market makers, will be subject to the levy. The tax will be raised to 0.1% in 2024 and is expected to generate 8 billion baht (S$310 million) in revenue in the first year, potentially doubling to 16 billion baht. Reports of exemptions for institutional investors are deemed misleading by the government.

site_title: Soccer-World Cup 2022: which teams are out of FIFA tournament?
summary: The FIFA World Cup 2022 has eliminated several teams from the tournament, including Qatar, Ecuador, Iran, Wales, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, Denmark, Germany, Costa Rica, Belgium, Canada, Cameroon, Serbia, Uruguay, and Ghana. The teams were eliminated after losing to other teams in the knockout stage, with some teams finishing at the bottom of their respective groups. The remaining teams will proceed to the quarterfinals, with the World Cup ending on December 18.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Group G - Brazil v Serbia - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - November 24, 2022

A freekick from Mexico's Luis Chavez beats Saudi Arabia's goalkeeper Al-Owais for Mexico's second goal during the Qatar 2022 World Cup match between Saudi Arabia and Mexico at the Lusail Stadium in Lusail, Doha, Nov 30, 2022.

site_title: China traders hunt for long-term reopening winners after frenzy
summary: Chinese equities are shifting focus from short-term reopening bets to longer-term plays such as consumer and healthcare shares as Beijing relaxes COVID curbs. Investors are seeking companies that will benefit from a reopening-led economic recovery, with consumer and healthcare sectors expected to lead the charge. Shares in companies like Kweichow Moutai and Inner Mongolia Yili Industrial Group have surged, while travel and catering firms have seen their gains largely priced in. Analysts expect a full easing of COVID restrictions by March, but acknowledge that the road to recovery may be bumpy.

images.alt_text: For the week, the yuan has gained roughly 1.5 per cent, while the dollar index fell to a 3-1/2 month low amid signs the US Federal Reserve will pivot away from rapid rate hikes as inflation ebbs.

site_title: Dollar gives back gains; strong wage growth complicates Fed policy
summary: The US dollar declined on Friday after a Federal Reserve official signaled that rate hikes are likely to slow, raising hopes the Fed is nearing the end of its tightening cycle. Strong jobs data and wage inflation in November complicated the Fed's hawkish stance. Chicago Fed president Charles Evans said the pace of rate increases will slow, but borrowing costs may still need to rise to a "slightly higher" peak than forecast. The dollar index fell 0.13% against a basket of currencies, while the euro gained 0.10%.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six major peers including the yen and euro, fell 0.2 per cent to 104.47, having earlier touched its lowest level since June 29 at 104.36.

site_title: Fuji Soft proxy fight the latest test of Japan Inc board independence
summary: Japanese software developer Fuji Soft Inc. faced a proxy fight by activist investors 3D Investment Partners, seeking more independent oversight of the company. The hedge fund nominated four additional board members, claiming existing outside directors have failed to address inefficient capital allocation. Fuji Soft endorsed two of the nominees, defending its current board as having ensured no conflict of interests. This latest proxy fight questions the independence of Japan's outside board members, following recent battles at Toshiba Corp and Fujitec Co.

images.alt_text: Hestia Capital Partners, which owns a 6.9 per cent stake in Pitney Bowes, has held talks with the company, suggesting a possible sale of an underperforming segment.

site_title: S-Reits rebound 6% in November
summary: S-Reits in Singapore rebounded 6% in November, with the iEdge S-Reit Index recovering 5.7% after a 5.6% decline in October. The sector outperformed the FTSE EPRA Nareit Developed Index, which gained 3.5% during the same period. Data centre, diversified, and industrial S-Reits were top performers, with average total returns of 12%, 8%, and 4%, respectively. Retail investors drove fund inflows, accumulating S$54 million, while institutional investors net sold S$95.6 million. Six S-Reits recorded double-digit total returns, led by Digital Core Reit's 18.1% gain.

images.alt_text: CDL Hospitality Trusts, which owns W Singapore hotel, updated that its net property income for 9M 2022 improved 43.7 per cent to S$82.6 million.

site_title: Art of noise: UK project aims to save lost sounds
summary: A UK-based project, "obsolete sounds," aims to preserve and archive sounds that are "just on the edge of memory." Led by Stuart Fowkes, the project collects and remixes over 150 recordings from around the world, including sounds from defunct objects like red phone boxes and vintage technology. The project's goal is to capture and preserve sounds that evoke strong emotional responses, with a focus on the rapidly changing natural environment and human experiences.

images.alt_text: A climate activist of the "Last Generation" group being overpowerd while another one has glued himself to the painting "Death and Life" by Austrian artist Gustav Klimt after pouring black liquid over the artwork at the Leopold Museum in Vienna, Austria, Nov 15, 2022.

site_title: UK government could bring in military to ease strike action: ruling party chairman
summary: The UK government is considering bringing in the military to help keep public services running if healthcare workers, including nurses and ambulance workers, go on strike. Chairman of the governing Conservative Party, Nadhim Zahawi, stated that the military could be used to drive ambulances, as part of a "surge capacity" to mitigate the impact of strike action. The move comes as the UK faces industrial action in various sectors, with strikes planned by thousands of nurses and ambulance workers over pay and conditions.

images.alt_text: Commuters use buses near London Liverpool Street railway stations, during a one-day strike by London Underground workers on Thursday (Nov 10). The cost-of-living crisis is leading to widespread UK strikes, with train workers, legal staff, dockers and even nurses among those walking out.

site_title: ICYMI: Sats’ acquisition target is in the red
summary: Sats, a Singapore-based logistics company, is set to acquire Worldwide Flight Services (WFS), the world's largest air cargo handling firm, despite concerns over the deal's funding and profitability. WFS posted a net loss of 31.1 million euros in Q3 2022, while Sats itself reported a net loss of 32.5 million dollars in the first half of 2023. The proposed acquisition is expected to be funded through a S$800 million rights issue, a 700 million euro loan, and internal cash. The deal's risks have increased due to WFS's significant debt load, but Temasek, which owns 39.7% of Sats, has indicated its support for the deal.

images.alt_text: Sats shares have fallen 22 per cent since unveiling deal to acquire WFS
SATS said this acquisition would result in an “unmatched global footprint” that would cover trade routes responsible for over 50 per cent of global air cargo volumes.

Excluding the effect of reliefs, SATS net losses for the 3 months ending Sept 30,2022 would have been S$19.7 million, an improvement from the S$30.1 million net loss excluding reliefs in the year-ago period, the company said in a bourse filing.
Investors fear Sats will raise funds through a deeply discounted rights issue, and that the purchase of WFS will not boost its profitability as much as it implicitly claims
WFS is the takeover target of Sats, which has entered into an agreement to acquire the Paris-based and world’s largest air cargo handler for about 1.3 billion euros.
Rights issue is expected to launch in Q1, 2023. Temasek, which holds 39.7 per cent of Sats through subsidiary Venezio Investments, has indicated it intends to subscribe for its pro-rata entitlement.

site_title: The value of embracing ESG for Reits
summary: Reit stakeholders and investors are overwhelmed by universal data in ESG reports, risking submerged or distorted pertinent data. Embracing ESG is crucial for Reits, with many holding extensive portfolios of physical buildings contributing to 40% of global greenhouse gas emissions. To get things right, Reits should focus on a few impactful ESG initiatives, avoiding "greenwashing" and over-promising. Third-party assessments, such as the GRESB sustainability score, can signal ESG quality and benchmark against industry peers. Reits can champion sustainability but also do little to build an inclusive society, highlighting the need for collective action and solid science underpinning actionable items in the checklist.

images.alt_text: Photos by Yen meg Jiin: Interior and exterior of SGX
“We tend to figure on bigger developments (in) higher capital value (markets) because then you can amortise the cost better”, Lendlease’s chief executive officer for Asia Justin Gabbani said.

Citadines City Centre Frankfurt is one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (CLAS) properties that procures 100 per cent of its energy from renewable sources. CLAS is the only hospitality trust in the ‘Asia Pacific Hotel – Listed’ category to receive a five-star GRESB rating.
Frasers Property's final public offering will now stand at S$350 million, while the final placement tranche is S$150 million.
Singapore bourse was a stark outlier on Wednesday as it bucked the regional trend and finished higher

site_title: Three Arrows Capital says its founders still not cooperating with asset recovery
summary: Three Arrows Capital's founders, Kyle Davies and Su Zhu, are refusing to cooperate with asset recovery efforts, hindering the company's ability to return funds to creditors. Liquidators claim the founders are more interested in rehabilitating their reputation than helping creditors, and have taken steps to undermine recovery efforts, including destroying company records. Despite incomplete access, liquidators have recovered some assets, including $35 million and several cryptocurrency tokens. Recovery efforts are ongoing, but the founders' refusal to cooperate is hindering progress.

images.alt_text: Major interventions include the US regulatory investigations of bankrupt crypto firms Three Arrows Capital and Celsius Network.

site_title: Shanghai eases Covid curbs as China’s policy shift expands
summary: Shanghai, China's financial hub, has eased Covid-19 restrictions, scrapping PCR testing requirements for outdoor public venues and public transit, effective December 5. The move follows a policy shift by the Chinese government, which has relaxed curbs in other top-tier cities, including Beijing, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou. The easing measures aim to minimize economic and social costs of Covid control, but analysts say China's Zero Covid policy is unlikely to be abandoned until April.

images.alt_text: Residents wait in line at a Covid-19 testing facility at night in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. China's top leaders will likely signal a more pragmatic approach toward Covid controls at a key upcoming meeting while putting more focus on boosting economic growth, economists say. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

Covid-19 test results are no longer needed in Shenzhen to enter public transport, drug stores, parks and outdoor tourism spots, according to statements issued by the Shenzhen government Saturday (Dec 3).

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for December 2, 2022, provides an overview of the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market experienced a decline, with the average of 5 time charter routes settling at $12,598, a decrease of $775 week-on-week. The Panamax market showed a positive week, with the Atlantic routes being the most prominent risers, driven by solid grain and mineral demand. The Ultramax/Supramax sector remained uninspiring, with no significant movements. The Handysize market continued to fall, with the BHSI index slowly falling. The clean market saw mixed results, with the Atlantic front and backhaul being active, while the European market remained muted. The VLCC market continued its downward spiral, with rates dropping 22 points on the Middle East Gulf to China route. The Suezmax market also fell back, with rates dropping 39 points on the CPC/Augusta route. The Aframax market suffered from reduced fixture activity and a tonnage build-up, resulting in a lower sentiment.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Nov 25, 2022).

site_title: Inflation will return to goal, say German, French central bankers
summary: European Central Bank officials, including Bundesbank president Joachim Nagel and Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau, have reaffirmed their commitment to bringing inflation back to the 2% target. They expect this to be achieved by the end of 2024 or 2025, despite current price growth running at five times the goal. The ECB is set to raise borrowing costs again and reduce its balance sheet, with officials undecided between a 75 basis point or half-point move. Nagel emphasized the need for governments to return to balanced budgets and adhere to European fiscal rules.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices in the 19 countries sharing the euro grew by 10.0 per cent this month after a 10.6 per cent increase in October.

site_title: Employees come before customers in revamp of HR’s old guard
summary: A manifesto published by over 30 HR leaders and an employee experience design startup Excellent advocates for a shift from "customer-first" to "employee-first" approach in businesses. This framework prioritizes employee well-being and design to elevate business performance. Companies like Patagonia, Airbnb, and Shopify have already adopted this approach to attract and retain talent in the tight labor market. By co-designing solutions with employees, businesses can improve employee experience, leading to better customer experience and reduced turnover costs.

images.alt_text: Staff can feel comfortable having candid conversations about their current state of wellbeing and workplace struggles, or arrange for one-on-one meetings with managers for professional guidance. When done right, coaching provides greater intrinsic motivation.
The recent spate of widespread layoffs by tech behemoths such as Twitter and Meta marks a  drastic shift away from the rapid and aggressive hiring in the tech sector during the pandemic.
"Think. Coach. Thrive!" introduces a distinctive coaching framework that offers people leaders a powerful business model that unlocks human talents and develops antifragility.

site_title: Fed could be pushed by overheated wages to higher peak rates
summary: US Federal Reserve officials may consider raising interest rates to a higher peak than expected due to rising wages and a strong labor market. Monthly wages rose at the strongest pace since January, and employment surged more than forecast last month. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell has cautioned that slacker job-market conditions and less-lofty earnings growth are needed to cool an inflation rate near a 40-year high. Officials may update their quarterly forecasts and lift their median projection for the rate peak next year to 5% or above, potentially keeping rates in place for longer to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell says the personal consumption expenditures price index is a more accurate measure of where inflation is heading.

site_title: Indonesia raises volcano warning to highest after Semeru erupts, evacuation underway
summary: Indonesia raised the warning level of Mount Semeru volcano to its highest level after an eruption on December 4, spewing a 15 km-high ash column into the air. The eruption followed a series of earthquakes, including one that killed over 300 people last month. The regional administration banned activities near the volcano, including sand truck movement, to facilitate evacuation. Evacuation efforts are underway, with some residents evacuating independently to safer buildings. The country's vulcanology agency raised the level of volcanic activity to IV, warning residents not to conduct activities within 8 km of the volcano's eruption center.

images.alt_text: Medical workers treat the victims outside the district hospital after an earthquake hit in Cianjur in Indonesia's West Java on Monday (Nov 21).

site_title: Opec+ rolls over existing oil output policy
summary: Opec+ has agreed to roll over its existing oil output policy, maintaining current supply levels as the global market faces uncertainty over Chinese demand and Russian supply. The decision comes amid European Union sanctions on Russian oil exports and a potential recession. Opec+ aims to achieve price stability and balance oil markets, with members committed to current output targets until the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: Opec+ officials may prefer a wait-and-see attitude as a variety of forces play out in the oil markets.

site_title: David Bonderman’s family office is opening up to world’s rich
summary: David Bonderman's family office, Wildcat Capital Management, is launching a $500 million fund to raise money from ultra-wealthy individuals and family offices. The fund will adopt a similar strategy to managing Bonderman's $4.8 billion fortune and is expected to provide a significant portion of the capital. Wildcat has been expanding its investment team and has invested in various sectors, including technology and healthcare. Bonderman, 80, co-founded private equity giant TPG and is stepping down as CEO after the company's recent public listing.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust has been facing withdrawal requests exceeding its quarterly limit, a major test for the one of the private equity firm’s most ambitious efforts to reach individual investors.

While Hong Kong’s status as the dominant hedge fund hub in Asia isn’t under threat – it’s home to nearly 44 per cent of hedge fund managers operating in the region, according to Preqin data – Singapore is an increasingly important location for firms operating strategies that aren’t exclusively China focused.
While investment banking and functions involving institutional investors have also taken a hit among banks here, demand for talent in private banking and wealth management has grown.
Caesar Sengupta left Google after nearly 15 years to start Arta with seven other long-time colleagues.

site_title: ST Engg buys back shares at S$3.49; Digital Core Reit files first buyback
summary: ST Engg buys back 500,000 shares at S$3.49 per share, part of its current mandate to buy back 0.18% of issued shares. Digital Core Reit Management also announces its first share buyback, purchasing 1.1 million units at 61.9 US cents per share. Institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions, with S$161 million of net inflow, bringing the 2022 year-to-date net institutional inflow to S$1.29 billion.

images.alt_text: caption REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: Terra co-founder’s arrest warrant rejected by court, news agency says
summary: A South Korea court rejected a request for an arrest warrant against Terraform Labs' co-founder Daniel Shin, citing concerns he poses no flight risk and would not destroy evidence. The ruling applies to seven other individuals, including early investors and developers, who also had their arrest warrants dismissed. Prosecutors will review the decision and consider filing another warrant. The TerraUSD stablecoin and its sister token Luna collapsed in May, and co-founder Do Kwon's location remains unclear. The court's dismissal is seen as a significant development in the ongoing investigation into alleged capital market rule violations.

images.alt_text: Do Kwon was previously based in Singapore but is no longer in the Republic.

site_title: Why Blackstone’s US$69 billion property fund is signalling pain ahead for real estate industry
summary: The US real estate industry is experiencing pain due to a rapidly cooling property market, rising interest rates, and waning investor appetite. Blackstone's $69 billion property fund, Breit, has limited withdrawals as investors pull money, while Wells Fargo has cut hundreds of mortgage employees due to soaring borrowing costs. The industry is also seeing widespread layoffs, with real estate agents, mortgage firms, and technology companies affected. Commercial real estate prices have slumped 13% from a peak this year, and financing challenges are becoming more common. Despite this, some real estate funds, like Breit, continue to outperform the market.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust has been facing withdrawal requests exceeding its quarterly limit, a major test for the one of the private equity firm’s most ambitious efforts to reach individual investors.

site_title: Want a four-day work week? Show this research to your boss
summary: A four-day work week trial involving 33 companies has shown significant gains in revenue and employee productivity, as well as drops in absenteeism and turnover. The study, which tracked 969 employees over 10 months, found that workers reported less work stress, burnout, anxiety, and fatigue, and increased exercise and work-life balance. Companies reported strong organizational performance, with revenue rising 8% and employee absenteeism dropping 33%. The results suggest that a four-day work week could be a viable option for businesses, but some critics argue that the study's bias towards participating companies limits its generalizability.

images.alt_text: A worker pours a pint of beer at Pressure Drop Brewery, in north London; Pressure Drop is hoping the experiment will not only improve their employees’ productivity but also their well-being. At the same time, it will reduce their carbon footprint.

Workers who shifted to 32-hour workweeks logged 7.58 hours per night of sleep, nearly a full hour more than when they were keeping 40-hour workweeks, according to lead researcher Juliet Schor, a sociologist and economist at Boston College who is tracking over 180 organisations globally as they shift to truncated schedules through six-month pilot programs.

Staff can feel comfortable having candid conversations about their current state of wellbeing and workplace struggles, or arrange for one-on-one meetings with managers for professional guidance. When done right, coaching provides greater intrinsic motivation.

site_title: KLCI in the aftermath of Malaysia’s GE
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index (KLCI) rallied strongly after Anwar Ibrahim was named the 10th Prime Minister, rising 4.04% upon the announcement. The new government is expected to be more people-oriented, pushing for targeted subsidies to help low-income groups and maintaining or revising key initiatives proposed in Budget 2023. The index also saw a decline due to profit-taking activities, but rebounded with renewed buying interest, closing up 0.8% on November 30. The market is optimistic about the return of political stability and potential easing of China's zero-Covid measures, driving the KLCI towards resistance at 1496.

images.alt_text: The FOMC minutes highlighted a more cautionary tone, that a balance is needed in considering the inherent risks of a rapid contractionary monetary policy. This resulted in a general decline in the perceived value of the US dollar. PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Confessions of a reformed Yolo-ing millennial
summary: A Singaporean millennial in her mid-30s reflects on her past "you only live once (Yolo)" mentality, which was shaped by the COVID-19 pandemic and economic changes. However, she now realizes that embracing Yolo-ism has made more sense than renouncing it. She understands that living life to the fullest means being willing to take risks, but also knowing when to cut losses and temper impulsiveness with pragmatism, as exemplified by her friend's ability to bounce back from a setback.

images.alt_text: “Yes. The most romantic thing a guy can do here in Singapore is to ask, ‘will you BTO with me?’,” I said with a laugh.

site_title: FTX's LedgerX attracts interest from Blockchain.com, Gemini
summary: FTX's LedgerX, a crypto derivatives exchange, is up for sale after FTX's bankruptcy filing in November. Interested parties include Blockchain.com, Gemini, Bitpanda, and Kalshi, with some having signed non-disclosure agreements. The sale could involve over half a dozen potential buyers, following FTX's collapse, which led to rival exchange Binance abandoning a rescue deal. LedgerX was acquired by FTX US last year to expand into crypto futures and options trading, and its sale is expected to be part of FTX's bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: China’s 2023 Grand Prix scrapped on Covid ‘difficulties’
summary: China's 2023 Grand Prix has been scrapped due to ongoing Covid-19 difficulties. The Formula 1 organization is assessing alternatives to replace the slot and will provide an update in due course. This decision comes as the Covid-19 situation in China remains challenging, despite recent shifts in policy allowing some infected individuals to isolate at home.

site_title: India to continue buying Russian oil, ministry source says
summary: India plans to continue buying Russian oil, with refiners considering term deals if pricing terms are favorable for sustained supplies. The decision comes after the European Union agreed on a US$60 per barrel price cap on Russian seaborne oil, which takes effect on December 5. Vessels loaded before December 5 will not be subject to the price cap, allowing India to continue lifting Russian oil beyond January 19. India is the top buyer of Russian oil behind China, and global oil producers have assured India of no supply disruption.

site_title: Mutual funds that consistently beat the market? Not one of 2,132.
summary: A new study by S&P Dow Jones Indices found that none of the 2,132 actively managed US mutual funds beat their respective benchmarks, the S&P 500 or US bond market, over the last five years. This is a stark contrast to previous years, when some funds managed to outperform their benchmarks. The study's results support the academic consensus that it's difficult to consistently beat the market, and using low-cost index funds is a more reliable strategy. Notably, actively managed funds generally underperformed index funds, even when the markets fell.

images.alt_text: bull, bear, stock

site_title: Bob Chapek did not believe in Disney magic
summary: Disney CEO Bob Chapek was fired and replaced with former CEO Robert Iger in November, sparking near-unanimous celebration among Disney super fans. A Change.org petition to fire Chapek, which started in 2020, garnered over 117,000 signatures. Fans and enthusiasts had been criticizing Chapek's management style and strategy, leading to his ouster. The news was met with relief among the Disney community, with many celebrating Iger's return to the role.

images.alt_text: The catalyst for Netflix's comeback is the introduction of a lower-priced, advertising-supported subscription tier.
Disney is grappling with massive changes in how consumers watch movies and TV shows.
Bob Iger, who served as Disney’s CEO for 15 years, has pledged to return as CEO for at least two years.
Disney plans to sail the ship internationally.
The move comes after Disney misses Wall Street estimates for quarterly earnings on Tuesday as the entertainment giant racks up more losses from its push into streaming video,
The company beat expectations for streaming subscriber additions in the period, signing up 12.1 million new customers for its flagship Disney+ service alone.
The number of people subscribing to Disney+ reached 164.2 million people, more than the 161 million estimated by Factset, a data company.

site_title: Elizabeth Holmes appeals Theranos fraud conviction, prison term
summary: Elizabeth Holmes, 38, has appealed her 11 1/4-year prison sentence for deceiving investors in her blood-testing startup Theranos Inc. Her lawyers filed a single-page notice of appeal in federal court in San Jose, California, without specifying grounds. The appeal faces long odds, with experts saying the sentence is "bullet-proof on appeal." A jury convicted Holmes of four counts of wire fraud and conspiracy in January, and her ex-partner Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani was convicted separately and is set to be sentenced.

images.alt_text: Jurors found Ramesh “Sunny” Balwani guilty on all 12 fraud counts charged by federal prosecutors, said a spokesperson at the courthouse in the Silicon Valley city of San Jose.

site_title: Crypto stocks teeter near abyss as Fink’s warning adds to angst
summary: Crypto stocks continue to plummet, with firms like Coinbase Global, Galaxy Digital Holdings, and MicroStrategy losing over 25% last month. The industry's woes are exacerbated by the collapse of FTX and BlackRock's warning that most crypto companies will fold. Bitcoin and other digital tokens have lost over 70% of their value this year, and mining stocks have seen their share prices cut in half. Analysts expect the crypto space to remain toxic for investors, and some money managers see opportunities in beaten-down stocks, including a forecast that Bitcoin will reach $1 million by 2030.

images.alt_text: There could be over half a dozen other potential buyers for the crypto derivatives exchange. Some of the interested parties have signed non-disclosure agreements.
Three Arrows Capital office in Singapore.Photographer: Suvashree Ghosh/Bloomberg
Sam Bankman-Fried, founder and former chief executive officer of FTX Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The worlds of traditional and digital finance alike are transfixed by the wreckage of FTX, which at one point boasted a US$32 billion valuation.
network, earth, blockchain

site_title: Energy crisis driving climate-friendly power savings: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that the global energy crisis driven by Russia's invasion of Ukraine has led to a significant increase in energy efficiency measures, with record investments of $560 billion in 2022. This has resulted in a 2% improvement in energy efficiency, surpassing the past five years' rate. The IEA notes that if current trends continue, 2022 could mark a turning point for efficiency, with annual improvements needed to rise to 4% to meet decarbonization goals by mid-century.

site_title: Young US job hunters seeking stability as inflation bites, lay-offs roll out
summary: Young US job hunters are re-evaluating what a "dream job" looks like amid inflation, pandemic uncertainty, and lay-offs, with 73% of recent graduates citing stability as a top priority. The strong job market, with nearly a five-decade low unemployment rate and 263,000 jobs added last month, is in a prime position to comply. However, anxiety and insecurity remain, with nearly two-thirds of young American adults without a college degree and those who did graduate facing disruptions and mental distress. As a result, job seekers are focusing on critical benefits like healthcare and 401(k) plans over luxe perks, and some are expanding their job searches beyond their original career aspirations.

images.alt_text: “A focus on employee experience has gained traction in the tightest labour market in a generation,” said Caitlin Duffy, research director at consulting firm Gartner. “If you don’t deliver great EX, you risk losing out.”
All this while, when I was rejecting Yolo-ism and what it entailed, I have come to realise that it actually made more sense than ever to live by this rule.
Carousell co-founder Quek Siu Rui admitted that he was too optimistic about the investment Carousell was making in hiring versus the platform's impact.
Economists are watching continuing claims more closely, as they serve as an indicator of how hard it is for people to find work after losing their jobs.

site_title: Shenzhen eases Covid-19 curbs, adds to signs of shift across China
summary: China's southern tech hub Shenzhen has eased Covid-19 curbs, allowing individuals to enter public transport, parks, and outdoor tourism spots without providing test results. This move follows similar relaxations in Beijing, Guangzhou, and Chengdu, as top officials signal a transition away from strict containment measures. The shift comes as the omicron variant becomes the prevalent Covid-19 strain in China, and officials acknowledge the virus is weakening. This easing of restrictions adds to growing signs of a shift across China, with some evidence suggesting the country's mindset around Covid Zero policies is turning a corner.

images.alt_text: Residents confront workers donned in protective suits who are blocking the entrance of a residential compound, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Shanghai, China, in this still image obtained from a social media video released November 30, 2022. Video obtained by Reuters/via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

site_title: Singapore stocks slide, tracking Wall Street declines; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% on Friday, tracking a mixed Wall Street, with the US manufacturing sector contracting in November and core inflation remaining above the Federal Reserve's 2% target. Shares of ground handler SATS declined 2.9% after it announced a plan to raise up to S$800 million via a rights issue to fund the acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services. The STI managed a 0.6% rise for the week.

images.alt_text: SATS logo on 15 December 2016.
The Stoxx 600 index climbed 0.9 per cent to hit its highest since Aug 17. It gained 6.8 per cent in November to log its best month since July.
The Nasdaq gained 0.13 per cent to 11,482.45 points, lifted by gains of over 1 per cent each in Nvidia and Facebook-owner Meta Platforms.

site_title: Delta offers pilots hefty pay raises as unions flex bargaining power
summary: Delta Air Lines has offered its pilots a 34% cumulative pay increase over three years, with a minimum 18% raise upon contract signing, and additional 5%, 4%, and 4% raises after one, two, and three years, respectively. The deal, which includes a one-time payment equivalent to 22% of pilots' earnings between 2020 and 2022, is expected to set a benchmark for contract negotiations at rival airlines. The offer comes as pilots, who have been working without a new contract for nearly three years, continue to push for higher wages and better work-life balance.

images.alt_text: United is flying just twice daily to San Francisco and Los Angeles from JFK, the busiest New York-area airport, after resuming service in 2021.
Carriers including American Airlines, United and Delta highlighted the phenomenon on a series of conference calls as they reported banner results on continued strong travel demand.

site_title: WeWork downgraded by Fitch as recession fears mount
summary: WeWork's credit rating was downgraded by Fitch from CCC+ to CCC due to challenges in capitalizing on the return-to-office trend and struggling to make a profit. The company lost $629 million in the third quarter, falling short of Wall Street's expectations. Fitch also downgraded WeWork's senior unsecured bonds to CC, citing concerns over the company's ability to recover from a recession. The downgrade reflects Fitch's assessment that WeWork's challenges will only worsen in the coming year as companies scale back spending and move away from hybrid work schedules.

site_title: Twitter keeps missing its advertising targets as woes mount
summary: Twitter's advertising revenue continues to decline, with the company missing its weekly targets during the World Cup, a traditionally lucrative period. US ad revenue was 80% below internal expectations for the week of the tournament's start. Twitter's financial woes have been exacerbated by Elon Musk's takeover, with advertisers pausing spending due to concerns about his approach to free speech and data sharing. The company has offered incentives to brands, including discounts and clauses allowing for early exit, but many remain hesitant. Advertisers, including automakers like General Motors, are seeking assurances that their data will not be shared with Musk's other companies, Tesla and Apple.

images.alt_text: From comic to heartfelt, the videos have one thing in common: the simple act of posting challenges the shame and silence that usually prevails after someone gets let go from a job.
Yoel Roth's departure from Twitter rattled advertisers, many of whom backed away from Twitter after Musk laid off half of the staff, including many involved with content moderation.
Twitter billed the offer as the “biggest advertiser incentive ever on Twitter,” according to an email reviewed by Reuters.

site_title: US says Swiss engineering group ABB to pay over US$315m to resolve bribery case
summary: US authorities announced that Swiss engineering group ABB will pay over $315 million to settle a bribery case related to improper payments at a South African state-owned energy company, Eskom Holdings. ABB subsidiaries also pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The case involved bribing a high-ranking official to obtain confidential information and win lucrative contracts between 2014 and 2017. The settlement marks the US Justice Department's first coordinated resolution with South African authorities.

images.alt_text: A federal jury in Brooklyn convicts Ng in April of conspiring to violate an anti-bribery law and commit money laundering.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 slips, but marks seventh week of gains
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.2% lower on Friday, marking its seventh consecutive week of gains despite a recent deceleration in inflation. Optimism over China's economic reopening and easing concerns about interest-rate hikes contributed to the gains. However, energy and technology stocks offset gains in real estate and retailers, and the ECB's vice president, Luis de Guindos, stated that the central bank will continue to raise interest rates to bring inflation down to its 2% goal.

images.alt_text: Christine Lagarde, European Central Bank president, says that central banks must deliver a monetary policy that anchors expectations.

site_title: Oil dips $1 per barrel ahead of Opec+ meeting, EU Russian oil ban
summary: Oil prices dropped 1.5% on Friday ahead of an OPEC+ meeting and an EU ban on Russian oil imports. Brent crude futures fell to $85.57 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell to $79.98 per barrel. Analysts expect OPEC+ to stick to its production target, but some predict volatility if the group makes further cuts. Russia's oil output could fall 500,000 to 1 million barrels per day due to the EU ban, which aims to limit revenues to Russia without causing a price spike.

images.alt_text: Opec+ officials may prefer a wait-and-see attitude as a variety of forces play out in the oil markets.
India's Reliance Industries operates the world’s largest refining complex.
Indian refiners, which mostly buy Russian oil on spot basis, would consider signing term deals with Russian oil if pricing terms are favourable for sustained supplies, the oil ministry source said.

site_title: Audi R8 Coupe V10: Last but not least
summary: The Audi R8 V10, a high-performance sports car, is set to end its production run. The V10 engine, which predates modern electric motors and turbo era, produces power through a traditional method, making it feel intense as it spins faster. The V10 Performance RWD variant is a swansong for the R8, at least in Singapore. The R8's cabin is well-laid out and durable, reflecting Audi's attention to detail. The car's legacy will be a reminder of the impact of fossil fuels on the climate, but also a testament to the thrill of petrol-powered performance.

images.alt_text:
juaudi24



Credit: Audi Singapore

site_title: Cash offer for Chip Eng Seng raised to S$0.75 per share
summary: Chip Eng Seng's chairman Celine Tang and her husband Gordon Tang have raised their mandatory conditional cash offer to S$0.75 per share, a 4.2% improvement over the initial offer of S$0.72. This is their final offer, which exceeds the shares' highest closing price in a three-year period and represents a 42.6% premium over the company's volume weighted average price for the past 12 months. The offeror now controls approximately 47.27% of the total issued shares.

images.alt_text: Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang's voluntary conditional cash offer for the property player turns mandatory after she acquires 6.3 million shares in early trade.
Celine Tang and Gordon Tang also recently privatised SingHaiyi Group at a significant discount to its net asset value.
Celine Tang, who is also group managing director of property player SingHaiyi and non-executive chairman at OKH Global, became Chip Eng Seng’s chairman in 2018 after becoming its largest shareholder.

site_title: CEOs square off in friendly World Cup duel
summary: Business leaders from Singapore are participating in the BT-World Cup 2022 CEO Challenge, a friendly tournament to raise funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. 16 CEOs, including UBS Singapore's August Hatecke and Prudential Singapore's Dennis Tan, will compete, donating $1,000 to the fund for each team loss. The tournament runs until the World Cup's grand final on Dec 18, with the funds matched by the Singapore government and eligible for a 250% tax deduction. The fund supports financially disadvantaged children in Singapore pursuing arts education.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Group G - Brazil v Serbia - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - November 24, 2022
Brazil's Richarlison scores their second goal REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
Hublot CEO Ricardo Guadalupe has transformed the brand into a Manufacture with its development of several in-house movements.
Will the FIFA branding be big enough to produce another successful game with a new gaming studio?

site_title: G7 coalition agrees US$60 per barrel price cap for Russian oil
summary: The G7 coalition, along with Australia, has agreed on a US$60 per barrel price cap for Russian seaborne crude oil, aiming to reduce Russia's income and prevent a spike in global oil prices after the EU embargo on Russian crude takes effect on December 5. The price cap, initially proposed at US$65-70 per barrel, was lowered to US$60 after EU countries, including Poland, pushed for a lower price. The cap will take effect on December 5 or shortly after, and will allow non-EU countries to continue importing Russian oil, but prohibit shipping and insurance companies from handling cargoes of Russian crude unless sold for less than the price cap.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$1.31, a 1.5 per cent drop, at US$85.57 per barrel. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell US$1.24, or 1.5 per cent, to US$79.98 per barrel.

site_title: It’s half-time at this unpredictable World Cup
summary: The 2022 FIFA World Cup has entered its knockout stage, with 16 teams remaining in the tournament. Japan leads Asia's charge, advancing to the Round of 16 after defeating Spain and Germany. Brazil's Richarlison scored an impressive scissors kick against Serbia, while Japan's Takuma Asano netted a stunning goal against Germany. Morocco, the US, Australia, and Senegal have also performed well. Qatar, the host nation, was eliminated after losing all three group stage matches. Argentina's 36-match unbeaten streak was ended by Saudi Arabia in a surprise 2-1 win.

images.alt_text: The first Fifa World Cup to be held in the Middle East will feature 64 matches over 29 days.
Argentina's Lionel Messi celebrates scoring his team's first goal against Mexico in front of jubilant supporters.a
A commuter holds an Adidas shopping bag while walking through the Lusail metro station in Doha, Qatar.

site_title: UniCredit to pay bonus to staff to help with rising living costs
summary: UniCredit, Italy's second-largest bank, will pay a one-off bonus of 2,400 euros to employees to help with rising living costs. The bank will also pay for 850 branch employees to opt for early retirement, replacing them with new staff under 35. The early exits are expected to cost 170 million euros, with the bank's overall 2022 costs guidance remaining unaffected. The bonus includes a 1,600 euro productivity premium and an additional 800 euros exempt from tax due to government measures.

site_title: US job growth beats expectations; jobless rate steady at 3.7%
summary: US employers hired 263,000 workers in November, beating expectations, and raised wages 0.6% despite job cuts by tech companies. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.7%. Average hourly earnings increased 5.1% annually, and 10.3 million job openings were available at the end of October. The strong labor market keeps the Federal Reserve on track to slow interest rate hikes, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell hinting at a possible rate cut as soon as December.

images.alt_text: US weekly jobless claims hold steady below pre-pandemic level; consumer spending rises

site_title: China Evergrande expects to hit 2022 property delivery target
summary: China Evergrande Group, a debt-laden real estate developer, expects to meet its 2022 property delivery target of 300,000 units. The company aims to deliver 44,000 units in December, with 29 days remaining. This achievement comes after delivering 256,000 units between January and November. Evergrande has been struggling to raise funds to pay lenders and suppliers, with bondholders agreeing to an extension of repayment and interest payment on one of its domestic bonds. The company's electric vehicle unit has also suspended mass production due to a lack of new orders.

images.alt_text: On Chinese social media, speculation around billionaire businessman Hui Ka Yan swirls.

site_title: Russia’s financial crisis must come sooner
summary: A diplomatic standoff between European countries and the US over a price cap for Russia's oil exports threatens to hinder efforts to limit the Kremlin's resources for its war against Ukraine. A low price cap would render Russia's war economy untenable, causing a financial crisis. The European Commission proposes a $62 price cap, while Poland, Estonia, and Lithuania push for $30. A low cap could lead to intense pressure on the rouble, weaken Russia's ability to buy weapons, and jeopardize its banking system. The balance of risks favors limiting Russia's oil exports.

images.alt_text: In the last week, crude futures contracts have flipped in and out of contango, where the prompt price of a commodity is lower than the future price.

site_title: UK insurers face crackdown for undervaluing cars in damage claims
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has warned insurers against undervaluing cars in damage claims, stating that offering settlements lower than fair market value is not allowed under FCA rules. The FCA will take unspecified action against firms that break these rules, particularly during the cost-of-living crisis. Insurers are also grappling with a rise in auto insurance application fraud, with Aviva reporting a 16% increase in such instances this year. The Association of British Insurers has defended its processes for determining fair market value, but urged customers to be cautious of lying to insurers to save money.

images.alt_text: To boost the City’s global competitiveness, Britain’s finance ministry promises a “Big Bang 2.0” shake-up of financial rules.
Interest rates in the UK are increasing to quell decades high inflation, with energy, mortgage and food bills also rising faster than wages.
Liz Truss, who hasn’t appeared in public since Friday, is preparing for her first speech to the Conservative Party conference as prime minister next week.

site_title: Court of Appeal extends suspension of HC Surgical’s Julian Ong to two years
summary: A Singapore Court of Appeal has extended the two-year suspension of colorectal surgeon Dr. Julian Ong to two years, following a professional misconduct judgment. HC Surgical Specialists, which owns Dr. Ong's clinic, stated that the suspension is unlikely to affect the group's earnings for the current financial year, as the clinic has been operating at a loss.

images.alt_text: HC Surgical Specialists posts 7.2% fall in H1 net profit to S$4.6m
HC Surgical clinic granted licence to provide Covid-19 testing

site_title: Opec and Russia to meet as global forces weigh on oil market
summary: Opec and Russia will meet on December 4 to discuss production levels amid uncertainty over the European Union's embargo on Russian oil, which begins on Monday. The group, known as Opec+, may choose to stand pat due to various forces weighing on the oil market, including global economic growth slowdown and decreased demand from China. Analysts expect tensions between the West and Saudi Arabia to persist, with Europe seeking Middle East producers to substitute for lost Russian oil. Opec+ may not make significant changes, as their primary goal is to prevent oil prices from dropping.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Crude oil storage tanks are seen from above at the Cushing oil hub,  the delivery point for U.S. crude futures in Cushing, Oklahoma, March 24, 2016.   REUTERS/Nick Oxford/File Photo

site_title: Thailand receives over 9m foreign tourist arrivals
summary: Thailand welcomed approximately 9.4 million foreign tourists from January to November, surpassing the 2022 total. The Tourism Authority of Thailand predicts 10.5 million foreign arrivals for 2022 and 22 million for 2023. Russia is a significant contributor, with a notable increase in arrivals following the availability of direct flights. The tourism industry is a key driver of Thailand's economic growth, with around 50,000 to 60,000 foreign tourists visiting daily during the high season.

images.alt_text: Foreign tourists walk along the popular Khaosan Road in Bangkok on May 17, 2022. - Thailand's economy grew 2.2 percent in the first quarter following an export and tourism boost after the relaxation of pandemic entry restrictions, the kingdom's main economic agency said May 17. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Binance pauses Ankr withdrawals after possible token hack
summary: Binance paused withdrawals of Ankr tokens after a possible token hack, freezing about US$3 million. CEO Zhao Changpeng said a developer's private key was hacked, and the hacker updated the smart contract to a more malicious one. Ankr has blocked trading and will re-issue the tokens after assessing the situation. The incident has not been confirmed, but Binance is taking precautions to protect users.

site_title: China’s top banks to issue offshore loans to help developers repay debt
summary: China's top four state-owned banks have been ordered to issue offshore loans to help developers repay overseas debt, providing a liquidity boost to the cash-strapped property sector. The banks will process three to four loan proposals secured against domestic assets, with funds aimed at repaying offshore loans and US dollar bonds to repair investors' confidence. Developers considered "good quality" will qualify, including CIFI Holdings, Country Garden, and Longfor Group. This measure follows recent support measures to address a liquidity squeeze and mitigate disruptions to foreign investors.

site_title: Singapore’s PMI records third straight contraction in November amid weak global demand
summary: Singapore's overall factory activity contracted for the third consecutive month in November, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.8, indicating contraction. The electronics sector showed a slight improvement, but local manufacturers remain pessimistic about the economic outlook for the first half of 2023, citing weak global demand and China's Covid-19 containment measures. Experts expect further decline in manufacturing PMIs in December and weakness extending into 2023.

images.alt_text: Hiring weakness has been spotted in sectors like manufacturing and infrastructure, said recruiters.
Manufacturing expectations still pessimistic, services sector less upbeat: surveys

site_title: Evergrande’s Hui sends voice message as rumours swirl
summary: Billionaire Hui Ka Yan, chairman of Evergrande Group, addressed company executives with a 50-second voice message, urging them to resume construction projects amid speculation about his whereabouts. The message came after a meeting with executives was postponed, sparking rumors about his location. Evergrande is under scrutiny due to a credit crisis that has affected China's real estate sector and the company's self-imposed restructuring deadline of end-December. The move aims to quell social media rumors and maintain stability within the company.

images.alt_text: Evergrande expects a loss of about 163 million yuan from the disposal of the 10,376.82 square metre landholding located in Shenzhen.

China Evergrande said it is communicating with the government of Jiangxia District in Wuhan City and “will file an administrative review on this matter to protect the legitimate rights and interests of the company”.
Evergrande Group’s electric vehicle unit has stopped production of the Hengchi 5 SUV due to a lack of demand.
FILE PHOTO: The China Evergrande Centre is seen in Hong Kong, China. August 25, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Corporate philanthropy: Unlocking capital for positive impact
summary: Business owners in Asia are rethinking their approach to corporate philanthropy, connecting individual giving with corporate social responsibility (CSR) programs to create a more coherent strategy and amplify impact. The shift is driven by growing focus on corporate purpose, amplified by the Covid-19 crisis and climate change. A holistic approach to giving brings benefits for both benefactors and beneficiaries, ensuring a more sustained commitment to supported causes. This evolution is part of the natural development of philanthropy in Asia, where companies and individuals seek to make a positive impact.

images.alt_text: By doing good, corporations get imbued with a valuable “superpower” – one that positions them for success by setting them apart in the highly competitive business world.

site_title: Labour beats Conservatives to retain UK parliament seat
summary: Labour secured a resounding victory in the UK parliament seat of Chester, defeating the Conservatives by 39 percentage points. The result, which was seen as a significant challenge for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, follows nationwide polls that show Labour holding a 20-point lead. The Conservative Party is facing a growing exodus of lawmakers, including Sajid Javid, who announced his decision to stand down. Experts predict that Labour may win an outright majority in the next national election, with British polling expert John Curtice stating that the party's performance in Chester was in line with national polls.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak arrives ahead of an emergency meeting of leaders at the G20 summit following the overnight missile strike by a Russian-made rocket on Poland, on November 16, 2022, in Bali, Indonesia.  Leon Neal/Pool via Reuters

site_title: Strong winds cause shipping containers at Keppel Terminal to fall into water
summary: Strong winds caused 15 empty shipping containers to fall into the water at Keppel Terminal in Singapore on Dec 1. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore reported no injuries and no immediate impact to port operations. Two patrol craft have been deployed to monitor and recover the containers, with vessel movements restricted in the area until the containers are recovered. The incident occurred due to strong winds during a squall, but no immediate disruption to port operations is expected.

site_title: Airbus faces mammoth delivery challenge to reach full-year goal
summary: Airbus faces a significant challenge in meeting its full-year aircraft delivery target of 720, having shipped only about 55 planes in November, falling short of the 700 needed. The company initially targeted 720 deliveries but scaled back its ambitions in July due to parts and component shortages, including engines. With just weeks left in the year, Airbus is unlikely to reach its goal, with CEO Guillaume Faury cautioning that the supply-chain crisis won't improve until the middle of next year.

site_title: German government not planning blanket Huawei ban
summary: The German government has decided not to implement a blanket ban on Huawei products, instead opting for a case-by-case approach. This decision contrasts with the US administration, which recently banned new telecommunications equipment from China's Huawei and ZTE due to national security concerns. The German economy ministry spokesperson stated that such decisions will be made on a case-by-case basis, indicating a more cautious approach to banning Chinese companies' products.

site_title: This AI chatbot is blowing people’s minds. Here’s what it’s been writing.
summary: A new chatbot created by OpenAI has taken the internet by storm, generating detailed and sometimes plausible-sounding answers to user prompts, including historical arguments and poems. Users have praised the model's abilities, but also pointed out flaws, such as providing incorrect answers and overriding limits on sensitive topics. OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman reported "a lot more demand" than expected, and Elon Musk offered an endorsement of the model's abilities on Twitter. However, developers acknowledge that the model can sometimes write nonsensical answers and be excessively verbose.

images.alt_text: Realising smarter, more secure healthcare
Elon Musk has long argued that humans can only keep up with the advances being made by artificial intelligence  with the help of computer-like augmentations.

site_title: Indonesia’s Jokowi points to South Korea, Taiwan as economic models to follow
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo stated that his country won't follow a purely open economic model, citing Taiwan and South Korea as examples of successful, high-income economies. He emphasized the importance of making other countries reliant on Indonesia to achieve a more developed status. Widodo's approach aims to reduce reliance on raw material exports and promote the development of domestic industries, as seen in his temporary bans on nickel ore exports and efforts to lure new investment.

images.alt_text: Sri Mulyani Indrawati, Finance Minister, Indonesia Ministry of Finance. speaking at the inaugural Asean+3 Economic Cooperation and Financial Stability Forum, organised by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO).
The annual core inflation rate edged lower to 3.30 per cent from 3.31 per cent in October.
The European Union last year drew up a new Asia Pacific geo-economic strategy, with Asean at the heart of the plan.

site_title: India's Reliance makes rare buy of Russian naphtha, ups fuel oil imports
summary: Reliance Industries, India's largest refining complex operator, has made rare purchases of Russian naphtha, a key petrochemical ingredient, amid Western sanctions against Russia. The company imported 410,000 tonnes of naphtha in September-October, with 150,000 tonnes coming from Russian ports. This marks a significant shift, as Reliance did not buy Russian naphtha in 2020 and 2021. The move is seen as a result of European countries shutting down Russian exports, with naphtha now being sold at lower premiums to countries like India.

images.alt_text: Sephora’s operations will transfer from Arvind Fashions to Reliance Retail if an agreement is reached, according to the report.
Lower storage costs will be key to providing around-the-clock renewable power supplies from intermittent renewable sources like wind and solar.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after robust Nov jobs report
summary: Wall Street opened lower on December 2, 2022, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 129.6 points, or 0.38%, to 34,265.45, due to a higher-than-expected November jobs report. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 36.4 points, or 0.89%, and the Nasdaq dropping 174.1 points, or 1.52%. The stronger-than-expected jobs report reduced investor expectations of a Federal Reserve easing monetary policy tightening.

site_title: China steps up oversight of commercial banks
summary: China's China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) has stepped up oversight of commercial banks' off-balance sheet business, requiring them to conduct stress tests and ensure activities are within their risk-management capability. This move aims to prevent risks from shadow banking activities, which China has been concerned about due to the high volume of complex and potentially risky loans in the sector. The new measures mark another step in Beijing's efforts to strengthen regulatory control.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar names himself finance minister to gain investor confidence
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim appointed himself as finance minister to boost investor confidence amid a fragile post-pandemic recovery. With the economy expected to slow down next year, Anwar aims to present a budget to steer the economy through lingering inflation and a weak currency. The move is seen as a power play to shore up his position after a hung Parliament. Anwar, 75, expressed his intention to give local traders and foreign investors confidence in the economy, starting with a new approach.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim greets people as he leaves Putra Mosque after prayers in Putrajaya, on November 25, 2020. (Photo by Arif Kartono / AFP)
“There is no way I can succeed if the backbone of the civil service is not with me,” added Anwar, who was speaking in soft tones that were a marked departure from his fiery campaign speeches.

site_title: ESG fund chaos angers investors as greenwashing concerns mount
summary: A wave of ESG fund downgrades has left investors worried about greenwashing, with some asset managers downgrading tens of billions of dollars in Article 9 funds due to EU guidance on interpreting the bloc's ESG regulations. The European Commission is working to clarify the issue, but concerns remain about the credibility of the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation and potential damage to the reputation of the ESG industry. Investors and regulators are calling for clearer guidance to prevent misleading investments, with some estimating that hundreds of funds may need to be downgraded.

site_title: US dollar slips to 5-month low, yuan set for biggest weekly gain since 2005
summary: The US dollar slipped to a 5-month low against a basket of major currencies, falling 0.2% to 104.47, ahead of key US labor market data. The yuan is set for its biggest weekly gain since 2005, rising 0.5% against the US dollar. The Federal Reserve's decision to slow rate hikes has rejuvenated investor sentiment, with futures traders pricing for a peak rate of 4.8% in May. The yuan's surge is attributed to expectations of an exit from China's zero-Covid policy and a slower pace of interest rate hikes from the Fed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Japan eyes up to 43t yen for 5-year defence spending plan
summary: Japan is set to allocate 40 trillion to 43 trillion yen ($402.8 billion to $433 billion) for defence spending over five years, a compromise between the defence and finance ministries. The new budget is a jump from the current 27.5 trillion yen, as Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aims to lift defence spending to 2% of the country's GDP within five years. The increased spending is seen as a response to an increasingly assertive Beijing, but it has raised concerns about Japan's worsening debt burden and potential tax increases.

images.alt_text: Kishida’s administration has pledged to “substantially” increase defence spending to counter what Tokyo sees as a growing security threat posed by China.
Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announces an economic stimulus package last month that includes incentives for businesses to increase wages.
Internal Affairs Minister Minoru Terada has tendered his resignation after acknowledging that one of his support groups had submitted funding documentation ostensibly signed by a dead person.

site_title: Elton John to headline Glastonbury in final UK show of farewell tour
summary: Elton John will headline Glastonbury in his final UK show of his farewell tour, performing on the Pyramid Stage on the event's final night next summer. The 75-year-old singer is approaching the end of his "Farewell Yellow Brick Road" tour, which began in 2018. This will be the last UK show of his tour, marking a significant moment in both Elton John and Glastonbury's histories. The performance will take place on Worthy Farm, a fitting venue for the legendary singer's farewell.

images.alt_text: The RMT has said that more than 50,000 workers will take part in a three-day national strike.
Glastonbury, the world's largest green field festival, is back with a bang, playing to people who secured their tickets in 2019.

site_title: Credit Suisse to speed up cuts as revenue outlook worsens
summary: Credit Suisse is accelerating its cost-cutting efforts due to worsening revenue outlook. The bank's chairman, Axel Lehmann, stated that it will exceed its initial 1.2 billion Swiss franc target for cost savings by the end of 2023, with more job cuts than previously announced. The cuts, mainly targeting mid- and junior-level bankers, will also impact the bank's private banking business in Hong Kong and China. The bank's shares have fallen to a record low amid client outflows and a slowdown in activity, which have weighed on its revenue.

images.alt_text: A sign above an entrance to the Credit Suisse Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. Credit Suisses’s chief executive officer at its securities venture in China is stepping aside after less than two years on the job, becoming the second top executive at a major foreign lender in the nation to quit this month. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg
Five-year credit default swaps have widened 4 basis points (bps) from Friday’s close to 349 bps, the highest since at least early October
A sign of Switzerland's Credit Suisse bank is seen on an office building in Zurich on November 8, 2022. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
The share issue is expected to raise roughly 2.24 billion Swiss francs.
Credit Suisse has said that its actual results will depend on “a number of factors”, including remaining its performance for the rest of the year and the continued exit of non-core positions.
Credit Suisse’s biggest round of job cuts in China comes at an awkward time for the firm.
Credit Suisse warned last month that it will probably record its fifth straight loss this quarter due to costs related to the revamp.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore homeowners will pay between S$30 and $70 more in property tax in 2023 after a rebate, according to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore. Residential annual values for private and public housing are rising, mirroring increased market rentals. Online platform Carousell cut 110 jobs, and Aspial Lifestyle acquired a Malaysian pawnbroker for RM30.7 million. US$69 billion real estate fund Blackstone will limit redemption requests, and Singapore Airlines and Thai Airways will codeshare flights starting in Bangkok. Singapore stocks slid 1% on Friday, tracking Wall Street declines.

site_title: History says Bitcoin is set for more losses in December
summary: Bitcoin is expected to face more losses in December, following a 16% decline in November, according to a seasonal cryptocurrency pattern. The pattern, evident in 2018, 2019, and 2021, shows a weak December following November declines. Experts say the digital-asset class is working through a period of contagion, with Bitcoin likely to underperform other high-beta risk assets, such as stocks. However, some predict a steadier, positive December as fear and contagion recede, and the macro environment remains positive.

images.alt_text: network, earth, blockchain

US authorities are asking crypto investors and trading firms that worked closely with FTX to hand over information on the company and its key figures, including founder Sam Bankman-Fried (pictured) and the former head of his Alameda Research investment arm, Caroline Ellison.

Nicholas Truglia will serve 18 months in prison after a federal judge on Thursday sentenced him for his role in a scheme to hack a blockchain consultant’s phone and stealing US$22 million in cryptocurrency.
