site_title: Europeans are looking for ways to hack home energy use
summary: Europeans are cutting energy use to cope with soaring heating and electricity bills, with households installing solar panels, sealing windows, and switching to energy-efficient lighting. The efforts aim to reduce natural gas consumption, but continent leaders say more needs to be done. Britain's £1 billion insulation scheme and Germany's renovated building programme are examples of initiatives to improve energy efficiency. The focus on energy optimisation has also sparked interest in "passive houses," ultra-low-energy buildings that eliminate the need for conventional heating systems, with demand for these homes increasing since the start of the energy crisis.

images.alt_text: The new cap will only take effect if the price difference with global liquefied natural gas prices is greater than 35 euros.
With supply tight, businesses and consumers have been asked to reduce usage.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after economic data renews rate hike worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on December 22, with the Dow Jones falling 143.13 points, or 0.43%, to 33,233.35. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 down 25.18 points, or 0.65%, and the Nasdaq down 161.50 points, or 1.51%. Fresh economic data reinforced concerns over the Federal Reserve's rate hike policies, exacerbating market worries.

site_title: Investing in a sustainable future for shipping
summary: CK Shipping, an integrated logistics provider, has invested heavily in assets since its founding in 2001, allowing it to offer a wide range of services, including aerospace and aviation logistics, e-commerce, and project logistics. The company now has 122 staff in 15 offices worldwide, with 1 million square feet of warehousing and storage. Led by CEO Ken Ngan, CK Shipping has established a presence in multiple countries, including Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, Hong Kong, China, Australia, New Zealand, and Samoa.

images.alt_text: Arich Tan, group chief executive officer of A Wellness Holdings, ventured into the beauty industry so that the group would not be too reliant on its original NATRAHEA brand.
Eastern Harvest Foods founder and managing director Derek Cheng (sixth from left) with staff members at an exhibition booth.

site_title: Easy-pleasing French fare at Elan
summary: Elan, a French-inspired eatery in Singapore, offers uncomplicated yet satisfying dining with a focus on quality over innovation. The restaurant's cosy interiors and efficient service make it an unpretentious choice. The menu features a mix of French and Western dishes, including king prawn, frog legs tempura, wagyu flank steak, and suckling pig, all cooked with practiced ease. A set lunch option is recommended for a more affordable and enjoyable experience. With a rating of 6.5, Elan is a dependable choice for those seeking a no-frills yet delicious meal.

images.alt_text: Kok Sen's new premises are far more comfortable and cleaner than the old space.

site_title: Trader convicted, sentenced for offences under Securities and Futures Act
summary: Kenneth Goh Jia Poh, a trader, was convicted and sentenced to 19 months' imprisonment and fined SGD 355,604 for multiple offenses under the Securities and Futures Act. Goh used a "spoofing and layering" technique between 2016 and 2018 to artificially inflate stock prices, and made false statements to induce others to trade. He also used multiple trading accounts without notification, and created a false appearance of interest in securities. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) stated that such behavior distorts market demand and prices.

images.alt_text: “Selvarajulu’s convictions gave MAS reason to believe that he has not performed, and will not perform, the type of financial advisory service for which he was appointed honestly,” says MAS.

MAS said that Han will not be allowed to provide any financial advisory service and is barred from taking part in the management, whether as a director, or as a substantial shareholder of any financial advisory firm.

site_title: Scientists discover hammerhead shark nursery in Ecuador's Galapagos
summary: Scientists have discovered a nursery of baby hammerhead sharks off an island in Ecuador's Galapagos archipelago, providing a crucial refuge for the critically endangered species. The discovery near Isabela Island is a significant find, as it offers protection for hammerhead hatchlings during mating and early development stages. Researchers are monitoring the nurseries to track the young shark population and follow their migration patterns. The discovery is expected to help protect the species from extinction, which is threatened by commercial fishing and demand for their fins used in shark fin soup.

images.alt_text: The shark initiative has been one of the most discussed at this year’s CITES summit in Panama, with the proposal co-sponsored by the European Union and 15 countries.

site_title: UAE set to host world’s largest trade minister meeting in 2024
summary: The UAE will host the world's largest trade minister meeting, the 2024 WTO ministerial conference, in Abu Dhabi from February 26, 2024. The meeting comes at a critical time for a slowing global economy, amidst ongoing conflicts and trade tensions. The top priorities for the conference will be reforming the WTO's dispute settlement system and modernizing its 27-year-old rulebook, including restoring the appellate body crippled by the US in 2019. This will be the largest global gathering of trade ministers, following Cameroon's hosting of the next meeting.

images.alt_text: WTO appeals cannot currently be heard, because the Trump administration paralysed the appellate body in 2019.
China’s push to further its own semiconductor industry, and to develop advanced military systems, has been complicated by the export controls.

site_title: Eurozone business activity signals milder downturn than feared
summary: The eurozone's manufacturing sector saw a milder downturn than expected, with S&P Global's Purchasing Managers Index rising to 48.8 in December, signaling a recession but one that may be less severe. Germany's key manufacturing sector improved, while France saw a deeper downturn. The European Central Bank expects a "short-lived and shallow" recession, with GDP likely to contract 0.2% this quarter, easing further in the following months.

images.alt_text: The ECB raised the interest rate it pays on bank deposits from 1.5 per cent to 2 per cent on Thursday, moving further away from a decade of ultra-easy policy

site_title: Russia's Rosbank halts US dollar, euro, dirham operations after US sanctions
summary: Russia's Rosbank has suspended operations in US dollars, euros, and dirhams due to US sanctions on the bank and its owner, Vladimir Potanin. The sanctions, imposed on Thursday, restrict Rosbank's ability to guarantee client funds won't be blocked by foreign correspondent banks. Clients have full access to their finances, but payments through UK correspondent accounts may become unavailable. The move is part of the US effort to deepen Russia's isolation from global markets and hinder its military operations in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat property is situated in perhaps France’s most expensive location, a magnet for royals, Hollywood icons and technology billionaires.

site_title: Finnish household debt is looming worry in OECD review
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has urged the Finnish government to introduce debt-service-to-income or loan-to-income restrictions on households to curb mortgage debt risks, following the capping of new mortgages at 30 years. This move comes as the Finnish housing market cools, with mortgage borrowing falling to a four-year low, and house prices expected to decline by 5-7% next year. The OECD's recommendations aim to address high household borrowing levels and large real estate loan exposures in Finland and neighboring countries.

site_title: Chinese companies are flocking to Indonesia for its nickel
summary: Chinese companies are investing heavily in Indonesia's nickel reserves, building refineries, smelters, and a metallurgy school, with a total of $14.2 billion invested over the past decade. The move is driven by Indonesia's goal to process and manufacture nickel onshore, and China's need to secure its nickel supply for electric vehicles. With China dominating the supply chain, the US would need to invest almost $90 billion by 2030 to break its reliance on China. Indonesia's President Joko Widodo aims to benefit from added-value exports, while Chinese companies are using advanced technology to extract high-grade nickel, despite environmental concerns.

site_title: Polish fish farm fights 'myth of Russian caviar'
summary: Poland's Antonius Caviar is challenging the "myth of Russian caviar" by highlighting its own production of high-quality caviar. The company, which produces over 42 tonnes of caviar annually, is seeking to distance itself from Russia due to the country's invasion of Ukraine. Antonius Caviar exports to major markets, including the UAE, US, France, and Denmark, and supplies Michelin-starred restaurants worldwide. To combat the misconception, the company will change its labels to simply "sturgeon caviar" without the word "Russian".

images.alt_text: This picture taken on July 9, 2022 shows fish farm cages of the Lijia Green Energy and Biotechnology Company off the coast of Checheng Township, in Taiwan's Pingtung county. - Beijing, which claims democratic Taiwan as its own, launched drills that sent missiles into waters around the island -- and it also torpedoed exports of certain fruit and fish products to China, over a visit by United States House Speaker Nancy Pelosi in August 2022. (Photo by Sam Yeh / AFP) / To go with AFP story China-Taiwan-economy-politics-sanctions, FOCUS by Catherine Lai with Sean Chang in Pingtung

site_title: Australia's housing crisis, largely hidden, is getting worse
summary: Australia's housing crisis worsens, with many struggling to find affordable rentals. Belinda, a single mother of four, has been rejected over 100 rental applications and now lives in a temporary shelter, facing eviction in six months. The country's housing shortage, largely hidden, is getting worse, leaving vulnerable individuals like Belinda with limited options.

images.alt_text: The Big Four banks' move comes after the Reserve Bank of Australia lifted its cash rate by 25 basis points, to a 10-year high of 3.1 per cent.

site_title: Ford, China’s CATL mull workaround for new US battery plant with US-Chinese tensions high
summary: Ford Motor and China's Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL) are considering a battery manufacturing plant in Michigan, with a novel ownership structure where Ford owns 100% of the plant, while CATL operates the factory and owns technology. This arrangement would allow the facility to qualify for US production tax credits without direct financial investment from CATL, amid US-China tensions. The plant will provide lithium iron phosphate batteries for Ford's electric models, with Michigan emerging as a potential home alongside Virginia.

site_title: Indonesian e-commerce startup Plugo raises US$9m in Series A round
summary: Indonesian e-commerce startup Plugo has raised US$9 million in Series A funding led by California's Altos Ventures. The platform aims to expand its operations nationwide upon its early 2023 release, offering cloud-based e-commerce tools for businesses. Founded in 2022, Plugo plans to use the funding for product development and hiring. The company's founder, Bang Kyungmin, sees "enormous potential" in the market, particularly for micro, small-and-medium enterprises, and believes there are "huge gaps" in the market for D2C platforms.

images.alt_text: From L-R; Jonathan Benhi, Eileen Kamtawijoyo and Timothy Astandu, founders of Populix
Vietnam could be Asia's next startup hub, VC says
GIC-backed South Korean fintech eyes 12-fold growth, IPO by 2025

site_title: China’s BYD to launch a second new electric vehicle brand in 2023
summary: BYD, China's top-selling car brand, plans to launch a second new electric vehicle (EV) brand in 2023, expanding its range following strong sales. The new brand, which will be a premium EV line, will be added to the existing Yangwang line. BYD has sold cars to 35 countries outside China since exporting to Norway in May, and has become the top-selling car brand in China for the first four weeks of November, outperforming Volkswagen. This move comes as BYD takes advantage of incentives for electric cars offered by Chinese governments.

site_title: Bankman-Fried makes new bail application after losing first request: source
summary: Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried has made a new bail application in The Bahamas after a magistrate judge rejected his request for bail. He is charged with financial crimes in the US, where prosecutors claim he misappropriated customer deposits to pay for expenses and investments. The Supreme Court will hear the bail application on January 17. Bankman-Fried's fortune was valued over $20 billion before FTX's collapse this year, and he is being held at a detention center.

site_title: Corporate purpose – A company’s X-factor and force for good
summary: A recent KPMG CEO Outlook survey found 73% of CEOs believe corporate purpose will have the greatest impact over the next three years, driving financial performance. ESG factors are seen as an important area for improvement, with 45% of CEOs recognizing their impact. The British Academy's report "Future of the Corporation" recommends a "whole of village" approach, prioritizing corporate purpose and social prosperity. Businesses with a strong sense of purpose are more likely to flourish, with 63% more likely to succeed than those focused solely on profits.

images.alt_text: By doing good, corporations get imbued with a valuable “superpower” – one that positions them for success by setting them apart in the highly competitive business world.

site_title: HSBC to stop funding new oil and gas fields
summary: HSBC will stop funding new oil and gas fields, aligning with its goal of net-zero emissions by 2050 or sooner. The decision is part of the bank's wider energy policy update, which prioritizes reducing its financed emissions. Although natural gas projects will continue to be funded due to the global energy crisis, HSBC aims to help clients reduce fossil fuel use and reduce sector funding. This move follows the bank's commitment to the Paris Agreement on climate change.

site_title: The most memorable wines of 2022
summary: Wine writer Eric Asimov has compiled a list of the 12 most memorable wines of 2022, chosen for their ability to evoke emotions and memories rather than just being exceptional in terms of quality. The wines include a range of styles and regions, such as a bone-dry Franciacorta rose from Italy, a natural Pinot Noir from Chile, and a 1942 Chateau Climens Barsac from France. Asimov's list highlights the power of wine to create lasting memories and connections, and the importance of seeking out unique and lesser-known producers.

images.alt_text: Patrons drink at the Ten Bells Bushwick in New York, Nov. 18, 2022. Like its forebear in Manhattan, the Ten Bells Bushwick is dark and moody, a great place to wile away an evening. (Karsten Moran/The New York Times)

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS expects S-Reits to navigate rate hikes, currency headwinds well
summary: DBS Group Research expects Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) to navigate sustained interest rate hikes and currency headwinds well until late 2023. S-Reits have entered into forward hedges to mitigate currency risks, and analysts predict most sectors will see market rents remain on an uptrend in 2023 despite a slowing Singapore economy. The research team expects the real estate cycle to enter a more modest growth phase, but still projects growth.

images.alt_text: Tenant sales in at 313@Somerset exceeds pre-Covid levels in Q3.
Pure-play Reits trading at deep discount to book value, such as Dasin Retail Trust, could be in need of strategic reviews.
DBS has cut the target price of Manulife US Reit, which is currently undergoing a strategic review, by 31 per cent.

On a year-to-date total return basis, S-Reits have seen a 10.9 per cent decline, against the Straits Times Index’s 9.6 per cent gain, while the FTSE EPRA Nareit Developed Index has seen a decline of 21.1 per cent.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange to introduce new dual counter model in 2023 first half
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) plans to introduce a new dual counter trading model in the first half of 2023, allowing investors to trade securities in both Hong Kong dollar and renminbi (RMB) counters. The move aims to support mainland investors and reduce price discrepancies between the two counters. The exchange will also establish a program to promote liquidity in RMB counters and mitigate the impact of possible delistings in the US. The measures are part of efforts to internationalize the RMB and further establish Hong Kong as a premier offshore RMB hub.

site_title: Reliable zi char cooking at the newly revamped Kok Sen
summary: Kok Sen, a Singaporean zi char restaurant, has revamped its space with a new, modern design while maintaining its old-school cooking style. The restaurant serves familiar favorites, including big prawn hor fun, prawn paste chicken, yong tau foo, and bitter gourd pork ribs. Food critic Jaime Ee finds the dishes rich in flavor, particularly the big prawn hor fun and deep-fried pomfret, but notes that some flavors can be cloying. With its new surroundings and modern approach, Kok Sen remains relevant, offering a comforting dining experience that won't get old. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: Shikar's plush surroundings.

site_title: Asian Americans’ clout in US politics
summary: Asian Americans' voting patterns in the US may have tipped the balance in favor of Democrats in the 2020 presidential election and the Georgia Senate run-off. The group's nearly doubled voter turnout in Georgia between 2016 and 2020, with 61,000 votes, contributed to the Democratic victory. Many Asian Americans voted for Biden due to his stance on issues like the COVID-19 pandemic and his selection of Kamala Harris as vice president. However, the group is not a monolithic voting bloc, with varying levels of support for Democrats across different ethnic groups, such as Indian Americans, Japanese Americans, and Korean Americans.

images.alt_text: Governor Ron Desantis addressing supporters in Tampa on Tuesday night, Nov 8, 2022. DeSantis coasted to re-election, defeating his Democratic challenger, Charlie Crist.

Republican House Minority leader Kevin McCarthy (centre), at an election night watch party in Washington, Nov 8, 2022. McCarthy is poised to become Speaker if Republicans gain control of the House, but he faces resistance from the right flank as his party feuds over a poor midterm showing.

site_title: Apple’s Japan investment crosses US$100b, CEO Cook visits chip epicentre
summary: Apple has invested over $100 billion in its Japanese supply network over the past five years, with a 30% increase in spending since 2019. CEO Tim Cook visited Kumamoto prefecture, the hub of Japan's semiconductor industry, where he met with major suppliers like Sony and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. Apple has also committed to renewable energy with 29 Japanese suppliers pledging to switch by 2030, including Sony and other major companies.

site_title: Bitcoin lingers near US$17,000; Coinbase, miners lead declines
summary: Bitcoin remains near the $17,000 mark, down over 60% this year, following the FTX exchange's collapse. The Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index has dropped 67% in 2022. Coinbase and miners, such as Marathon Digital Holdings and Riot Blockchain, have also declined, with Coinbase's revenue expected to be cut by half or more this year. The cryptocurrency market continues to experience a decline in investor confidence.

site_title: Growth downgrade for China ‘very likely’ on Covid surge: IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva says a growth downgrade for China is "very likely" due to a surge in Covid-19 infections following the easing of virus controls. China's zero-Covid policy took a heavy toll on its economy, and while restrictions are being eased, a spike in infections will create difficulties, including temporary labor force participation. The IMF is expected to downgrade its growth projections for China, both for 2022 and 2023, and global growth is also expected to slow, with the US and European Union also facing challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong shortens Covid isolation, eases testing for travellers
summary: Hong Kong shortens Covid isolation to 4-5 days for those testing positive and close contacts, and reduces rapid testing for inbound travelers to 5 days. The city also maintains PCR testing for new arrivals and outdoor mask mandates. The move follows mainland China's relaxation of Covid Zero curbs. Hong Kong's economy has been impacted by the pandemic and the city is cautious about further easing measures amid increasing case numbers and hospital pressure.

site_title: Foxconn unit invests US$500m in India affiliate
summary: Foxconn's Singapore unit has invested $500 million in its India affiliate, Foxconn Hon Hai Technology India Mega Development Private Limited. The investment comes as the company plans to quadruple its workforce at an iPhone factory in southern India over two years, citing disruptions in China. Foxconn aims to boost production capacity and meet Indian demand, with plans to add 53,000 workers to reach a total of 70,000 employees. The move follows recent reports of worker unrest at Foxconn's China plant.

site_title: Salaries across S-E Asia expected to increase in 2023: Aon study
summary: A recent Aon study predicts median salary increments across South-east Asia to rise as much as 8% in 2023, driven by supply and demand in the talent market and high attrition rates. Vietnam is expected to lead with a 7.9% increase, followed by Indonesia and the Philippines with 6.8% and 6% increments respectively. The retail sector is projected to see the highest salary increments at 6.5%, with technology and life sciences sectors following behind. Companies are adopting skill-based compensation programs to attract and retain talent amid the digital skills shortage.

images.alt_text: In addition to easing manpower shortages by filling lower-wage roles, foreign talent are also sought after to take up top positions and transfer knowledge and resources to Singaporeans.
The worst-hit region is likely to be Europe, where real salaries – nominal wage growth minus the rate of inflation – are seen being driven down an average 1.5 per cent.

site_title: Indonesia adopts law banning extramarital sex, curbing dissent
summary: Indonesia's parliament has passed a contentious new criminal code outlawing extramarital sex, increasing penalties for abortions, and restricting criticism of the president and public institutions. The law, which will be signed by President Joko Widodo, also imposes harsh penalties for insults against the government and public figures, and punishes journalists for publishing "incomplete stories." Critics warn that the law could undermine democracy, freedom of speech, and human rights, potentially deterring foreign investment and tourism.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is under pressure to pass the law to improve its cyber security as breaches at companies and government institutions intensified in the past year.

site_title: Vehicle buyers to pay more as LTA increases its fees; registration fee up 59% to S$350
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore is increasing vehicle-related fees by up to 25% from Dec 19, with the vehicle registration fee rising 59% to S$350. The fee increase is necessary to keep up with administration costs, with most fees rising between 10-25%. The move is expected to add S$5.9 million to S$16.3 million to LTA's revenue annually, and has been criticized by motor traders who say it will add to costs and may be passed on to consumers.

images.alt_text: Open category COEs, which can be used to register any type of vehicles except motorcycles, ended 3.1 per cent cheaper at S$110,524, down from S$114,009.
BT's COE tracker

site_title: Softbank’s Son quietly lifts stake to 34%, edging toward buyout
summary: Masayoshi Son, SoftBank's billionaire founder, has increased his stake in the company to 34.2%, edging closer to taking it private. The move is seen as a step towards a "slow-burn" buyout, where he gradually buys back shares to reach 66% ownership, allowing him to compel other shareholders to sell without paying a premium. However, many lieutenants oppose a buyout, citing concerns over financial constraints and regulatory oversight. The company's cash flow and asset sales will determine whether Son gets favourable terms on loans to finance any MBO.

images.alt_text: SoftBank has a strong brand name in Japan, which means it can take advantage of consumers’ appetite at a time when institutional investors remain wary over market risks.
SoftBank chief executive Masayoshi Son plans to restructure the Vision Fund investment arm after it reported a US$50 billion loss in the six months through June, as the value of its portfolio slid.

site_title: Nomura’s crypto arm seeks profit in two years in shakeout after FTX crisis
summary: Nomura's digital assets arm, Laser Digital, aims to break a profit within two years as the crypto market seeks safer counterparties following the FTX crisis. The unit, backed by Tokyo-based investment bank Nomura Holdings, plans to add 50 employees by March and leverage risk management measures to win over institutional investors. Laser Digital will operate in Switzerland, Dubai, the US, and Japan, and plans to invest in early-stage startups and entrepreneurs in the crypto sector.

images.alt_text: Japan’s biggest brokerage is seeking new revenue streams as rising global interest rates and market volatility slow key pillars of Nomura’s business, from brokerage fees to stock underwriting.

site_title: South-east Asia in thousands of pictures
summary: National Gallery Singapore's "Living Pictures: Photography in Southeast Asia" exhibition explores 150 years of photography in the region, featuring over 300 works by various artists. The show includes installations by Singapore artists Heman Chong and Chua Chye Teck, as well as Vietnamese-American artist Dinh Q Le's 5,000 found photos from Vietnam. The exhibition delves into the history of photography in Southeast Asia, showcasing black-and-white photos of Singapore during the colonial era, studio photography by Asian entrepreneurs, and contemporary works by regional artists. The show runs until August 20, 2023, with admission free for Singaporeans and PRs.

site_title: Biden to visit Taiwan’s TSMC chip plant in Arizona, hail supply chain fixes
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to visit Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co's (TSMC) chip plant in Arizona, marking a significant milestone in the company's $40 billion investment in the US, the largest foreign investment in US history. The visit aims to boost US technology manufacturing and counter China's growing influence in the semiconductor industry. TSMC will announce plans to build a second facility in Arizona, producing advanced N3 chips by 2026, and expand its current facility to develop even more cutting-edge chips.

site_title: Deck the halls
summary: Experts advise against over-the-top Christmas decorations, instead opting for understated and muted color schemes. For a festive yet hassle-free atmosphere, consider using colors in moderation and incorporating festive hacks. Meanwhile, a rare exhibition "Kaleidoscopes in Clay" showcases ancient ceramics dating back thousands of years, featuring pieces from the Neolithic period to the Ming Dynasty. Local eatery Kok Sen has also relocated to new surroundings, offering old-fashioned zi char.

images.alt_text:
scfeature15 - Our slow Housefloat: EL

float: EL
credit: Our Slow House

site_title: Airbus cuts full-year delivery target amid supply woes
summary: Airbus lowered its full-year delivery target due to supply-chain disruptions caused by parts shortages, engine issues, and soaring energy prices. The company had initially projected 700 deliveries but now expects to hand over 565 units by the end of the year. Airbus will adjust production rates for its A320-series jets and maintain its goal of lifting production to 75 units per month in the middle of the decade. The revised target won't impact profitability and free cash flow guidance for 2022.

images.alt_text: An Airbus A320 aircraft lands at San Pablo airport in Seville, Spain, on Friday, July 3, 2020. Photographer: Marcelo del Pozo/Bloomberg

site_title: The rise of dark tourism
summary: Dark tourism, a form of travel that focuses on destinations connected to death, disaster, or macabre events, has become a lucrative business model over the past decades. Countries like Vietnam, Cambodia, and Croatia have developed theme parks and attractions centered around atrocities such as the My Lai massacre, the Khmer Rouge regime, and war tourism. While dark tourism raises moral questions about exploiting tragic events for commercial gain, it also provides a way for countries to present their histories and raise funds for preservation. The phenomenon is expected to continue growing, with the commercial value of dark tourism expected to increase in the years ahead.

images.alt_text: Britain's National Railway Museum has acquired some of the photographs and is seeking to put names to the faces and tell their stories.
Some 40 visitors, most of them Iraqis, were allowed to walk around the more than 2,000-year-old archaeological site in the golden hour of twilight.

site_title: Macau approves launch of second exchange for small Chinese companies
summary: Macau's second financial exchange, Macau Micro Connect (Macao) Financial Asset Exchange, has received approval. The exchange will allow foreign investors to invest in financing products issued by small Chinese companies, such as shop owners, using blockchain-backed smart contracts. This platform, backed by former Hong Kong stock exchange chief Charles Li, aims to provide yield-generating investments to companies like those in China's 70 million small stores, which are often underserved by commercial lenders. The startup has raised US$120 million as of March.

site_title: Why a global recession is likely unavoidable in 2023
summary: A global recession is likely unavoidable in 2023 due to a tight labor market and stubbornly high inflation. The US Treasury yield curve is inverted, a historically reliable indicator of recession, and the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates aggressively to combat inflation. Global monetary tightening is synchronised, with nearly every major economy experiencing rate hikes, and Europe and China are not expected to provide a growth boost. The recession is expected to be mild to moderate, with a focus on inflation-driven growth, and investors should consider adjusting their portfolios to fixed income and value/quality stocks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.4 per cent lower at 33,947.10 on Monday.

site_title: Solid Indian classics and modern twists at Shikar
summary: Shikar, a new upscale Indian restaurant at Maxwell Reserve in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with its plush surroundings and carefully crafted menu. The restaurant, led by consultant chef Surjan "Jolly" Singh, serves both traditional Indian classics and modern twists, such as roasted sweet potato and goat's cheese tikki chaat and peri-peri prawns. Signature dishes like lamb biryani and tandoor chicken makhani are also notable, showcasing the chef's ability to balance flavors and textures. With a rating of 7, Shikar is a prize worth paying for, making it a great addition to Singapore's dining scene.

images.alt_text: Yakiniku Heijoen takes over the premises of a previous barbecue restaurant.

site_title: Sale of Marina South state land site for 790 units could see bids around S$1b
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a state land tender for a Marina South site, which can yield about 790 residential units and up to 8,073 sq ft of commercial space. The tender is expected to attract 3-5 bidders, with a top bid of S$1 billion or S$1,355 psf ppr. The site is part of the government's plans to develop a mixed-use residential neighbourhood with residential, hotel, retail, and office uses, and is located next to the upcoming Marina South MRT station.

images.alt_text: Launched by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, the Jalan Tembusu site is the largest of the three, with an area of 20,572.1 sq m and a maximum gross floor area of 72,003 sq m.

site_title: University grads’ median pay of S$4.2k is twice the S$2k for those with ITE, secondary education: Study
summary: A new study found that Singaporeans with university degrees or post-graduate degrees earn a median salary of S$4,200 per month, more than double that of those with secondary and lower education. This figure is 62% higher than the median salary of S$2,600 for those with diploma or A-level qualifications. Associate Professor Irene Ng of the NUS attributed the wage premium to the value placed on paper qualifications. The study highlights the substantial wage advantage of holding a university degree in Singapore.

images.alt_text: In addition to easing manpower shortages by filling lower-wage roles, foreign talent are also sought after to take up top positions and transfer knowledge and resources to Singaporeans.
Full-time employment rates, pay for fresh grads better than pre-Covid levels: survey

site_title: Philippines eyes central bank profits as wealth fund source
summary: Philippine lawmakers plan to use central bank profits to seed a proposed sovereign wealth fund, Maharlika Investments Fund, after opposition to using pension funds. The fund aims to invest government surplus capital and provide safety nets. Critics, including Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas governor Felipe Medalla, have raised concerns over governance and monetary authority independence. The proposal is part of efforts to support the economy after the pandemic, joining other developing nations like Indonesia and India in using sovereign wealth funds. The House appropriations committee will discuss the changes on Friday.

images.alt_text: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas headquarters complex in Manila.Photographer: Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg

site_title: New Year holds promise for China IPOs after  record 2022 haul
summary: China's IPO market is expected to continue its strong performance in 2023, following a record-breaking year in 2022. About 376 companies have announced IPO plans, with a total of $92 billion raised in 2022, accounting for 46% of global IPO proceeds. Factors such as policy easing, rising borrowing costs, and the end of Covid Zero are expected to drive the market. Many high-quality companies are expected to raise capital in 2023, with sectors like consumer goods, hotels, and new energy companies attracting attention.

images.alt_text: A view of a giant display of stock indexes, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 24, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: LTA awards S$758m contract to build MRT tunnel which will run under Central Catchment Nature Reserve
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$758 million contract to design and build a 5 km tunnel for the second phase of Singapore's Cross Island MRT Line (CRL), with 2 km of the tunnel passing beneath the Central Catchment Nature Reserve. Construction is expected to start in 2023, with passenger service slated for 2032. The project will also include a S$496 million contract for the Punggol interchange station. Measures to mitigate the project's environmental impact will be taken, and the LTA will engage stakeholders, including nature groups, during construction.

images.alt_text: Announcing the alignment for phase 2 on Tuesday (Sep 25), Transport Minister S Iswaran said it will provide greater public transport access to areas in the west such as Jurong Lake District and West Coast, and improve connectivity between the eastern, western and north-eastern parts of Singapore.

site_title: Yen, pound hit strongest in three months on Powell remarks on Fed slowing
summary: The US dollar weakened to three-month lows against the yen and the pound after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated that the Fed may slow down rate hikes as early as December. The greenback fell 1.64% to 135.85 yen and rose 0.88% to $1.2164, its highest since August 12. Markets now price in an 80% chance of a 50 basis point rate hike at the next meeting, down from a 20% chance of a 75 basis point hike.

site_title: Yakiniku Heijoen’s wagyu doesn’t really make the cut
summary: Yakiniku Heijoen, a new Japanese barbecue restaurant, has opened on Orchard Road in Singapore. The restaurant, which shares a name with a Japanese family, serves a variety of wagyu cuts, including beef stomach and large intestine for adventurous eaters. However, the quality of its ingredients is inconsistent, detracting from the dining experience. Despite its convenient location and helpful servers, Yakiniku Heijoen falls short of meeting expectations, making it a mediocre addition to Singapore's dining scene.

images.alt_text: Wagatomo's interior.

site_title: Pretty, precious gifts
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels' latest creations, including the Frivole and Alhambra collections, celebrate the delicate artistry of the French High Jewellery brand. The Frivole collection features flowers made from precious stones and gold, while the Alhambra collection showcases sunbeam-like striations and clover motifs. New additions to the Perlée collection highlight colours and ornamental stones. The pieces are available in gift boxes and range from S$6,400 to S$52,000.

site_title: Rising Sorn
summary: K-pop star Sorn is embarking on a solo career after a decade with girl group CLC, releasing four English-language singles and music videos in under a year. Her lyrics are autobiographical, charting her journey of self-discovery under the public eye. With 1.5 million YouTube views and 2.8 million TikTok fans, Sorn aims to break down barriers for Asian artists in the global music market, citing her Thai heritage as a key factor in her success. She plans to release a new EP and tour Southeast Asia in 2023, driven by her determination to succeed despite the challenges of the music industry.

images.alt_text: Willabelle Ong in olive green knitted pullover by Hermes.
Mae Tan

site_title: A time for togetherness
summary: Ophthalmologist Audra Fong is excited to host Christmas parties at her new home in Bukit Timah, which features three kitchens. The spacious kitchens were a result of her family's decision to demolish the swimming pool to expand the kitchen space during the reconstruction of their two-storey detached house. Fong, a veteran home chef, plans to cook a Christmas dinner with a crown roast of lamb or prime rib roast, accompanied by starters and side dishes. She emphasizes the importance of presentation and planning, and enjoys the process of cooking as a way to be present and mindful.

images.alt_text: Passion for design

site_title: Leader of the pack
summary: Canadian-born architect Jason Pomeroy, founder of Pomeroy Studio, has been advocating for sustainable design since childhood. His studio has created numerous eco-friendly buildings, including Singapore's first carbon-neutral home and a net-zero F&B outlet. Pomeroy emphasizes the importance of a sustainable process, not just the product, and advocates for an interdisciplinary approach involving master planners, landscape architects, and engineers. His design approach prioritizes reducing waste and costs through "evidence-based interdisciplinary sustainable design." The studio's work aligns with luxury car maker Bentley's Beyond100 strategy, aiming to become climate neutral by 2030.

images.alt_text: An expansive landscaped lobby and terrace creates an indoor-outdoor gathering and workspace for building occupants at 8 Shenton Way.

site_title: Legendary Trans-Bhutan Trail reopens to the world
summary: The 403 km Trans-Bhutan Trail, a legendary cross-country journey, has reopened to the public after being restored over two years. The trail, which was once the only way to travel between east and west, was carved out in the 16th century and had fallen into disuse since the 1960s. Following a 2018 announcement by King Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck, the trail was rediscovered and restored by a Canadian-led non-profit foundation, with over 10,000 stone steps and 18 bridges rebuilt. The trail reopened in September 2022, coinciding with Bhutan's border reopening, and has been welcomed by dignitaries, adventurers, and travel writers.

images.alt_text: What Bhutan offers the world is not a top-of-the-world ranking, but a very useful holistic way of analysing every state initiative for society.
Bhutan opened to high-end tourists in 1974 when it received 300 visitors. The number soared to 315,600 in 2019, up 15.1 per cent from a year earlier.
Bino Chua

site_title: How to buy T-bills: The mechanics
summary: T-bills can be purchased by anyone 18+, including non-residents, and institutions. The minimum investment is S$1,000, with a maximum of 15% of issuance size. Six-month T-bills are issued fortnightly, while one-year T-bills are issued quarterly. Applications can be made through local banks or online, with fees ranging from S$2 to S$2.50, depending on the source of funds. Deductions occur on settlement day, with refunds for unallotted amounts and discounts. Investors can check allotments through their CDP, SRS, or CPF accounts.

site_title: Noma’s Japanese connection
summary: Renowned chef Rene Redzepi's upcoming pop-up in Kyoto, Japan, has sold out in minutes, marking a bright spot for Noma after a tough two years since the pandemic. Redzepi and his team of 70 staff will move to Kyoto for the pop-up, which runs from March 15 to May 20, and will explore local produce and traditional kaiseki cuisine. The pop-up was initially planned for Tbilisi, Georgia, but was cancelled due to the pandemic. Redzepi's affinity for Japan dates back to his Tokyo pop-up in 2015, and he is excited to be back in the country, citing the end of Covid-19 as a reason for the trip.

site_title: Ahāra appeals with modern Indian flavours
summary: Chef Vikramjit Roy's Ahāra, a modern Indian restaurant in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with a focus on contemporary Indian flavors and cuisine. The 32-seater restaurant, officially opened on November 29, 2022, features a diverse menu that showcases India's rich food culture. With dishes such as Hay Smoked Oysters with Sol Kadhi and Caviar Course with Rajasthani buckwheat khichdi, Ahāra aims to reimagine Indian cuisine for a global audience. The restaurant's interior is adorned with modern artwork and features a sophisticated setting, making it a must-visit destination for foodies in Singapore.

site_title: Christmas grandeur at The Raffles
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore is celebrating Christmas with grandeur, offering a range of festive experiences, including exquisite cuisine, splendid gifts, and joyous gatherings. The hotel's restaurants, such as La Dame De Pic and Osteria BBR by Alain Ducasse, are serving special menus, while the Festive Afternoon Tea and Festive Tour De Force menus are available at various restaurants. The hotel also offers a Festive Indulgence package, exclusive Raffles suites, and gourmet home dining sets. Additionally, Raffles Boutique is a treasure trove of gift ideas, featuring extravagant hampers and lovingly crafted floral arrangements.

site_title: Gift of the bag
summary: A Louis Vuitton bag is the ultimate gift for the special someone on your list, offering a luxurious and indulgent present. The article highlights four festive collection bags, including the Capucines Mini in Safran Imperial and Petite Malle, which showcase the brand's craftsmanship and iconic design. These bags are not only stylish but also come with a sturdy leather handle and detachable strap, making them perfect for everyday wear. With prices ranging from S$3,550 to S$9,300, these bags are sure to bring a touch of glamour to the holiday season.

site_title: A starry Christmas
summary: Chanel is celebrating 35 years of watchmaking with the re-release of its iconic Première Édition Originale watch, featuring a black lacquer dial and quilted bag-inspired design. The luxury brand is also offering various festive gift options, including glittering rings and necklaces, as well as its Coco Crush fine jewellery line with hand-polished quilted motifs. These new additions showcase Chanel's continued inspiration from Mademoiselle Chanel's love of stars and comets, making it a star-studded Christmas for the brand.

site_title: A Christmas of whimsical delights
summary: PARKROYAL COLLECTION Marina Bay has crafted exclusive festive menus at its restaurants Peppermint, Peach Blossoms, and Portman's Bar, offering treats such as 16-hour pot roasted wagyu, salmon and prawn mousse, and baked oysters. The hotel also offers a festive takeaway hamper and a New Year's set menu at Peach Blossoms. These offerings cater to a range of tastes and preferences, providing a whimsical delight for guests during the yuletide season.
